viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
On the verandah at Brookfield - from left to right:
Miss Scratchley, the governess; Blanche Llewhellin, Wynne's mother, and Wynne.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1st - 7th

The Bazaar, painting classes and Christmas preparations begin. On the 7th Wynne has a scare from a runaway horse.
viewer_2.description:
December 1st, Sunday
Went to Church in the morning, prayers were requested for poor old Mrs Todd who I fear is very ill. General (?) came as usual with Maudie and talked scandal all the evening being assisted by Gran, Eve and Miss S, frightful scandalmongers all of them. They settled things about everybody so there was nothing left of anybody when they had done with them.

December 2nd
We drove to Blandford this morning, did a lot of shopping but met nobody very particular except Mr Todd who told us he doesn't think Mrs Todd will live long. (Code: "wrote to the Earl"), but on the whole this has been a most uneventful day, did nothing all the afternoon, and prep in the evening. Bought Xmas cards in B. I think I have got all I want now. The household air is sublime to say the least of it, at present it seems too good to last, but lets hope it may continue!

December 3rd - !!!

December 4th
We went over to the Down House to lunch. I bicycled all afternoon. I enjoyed that part of the business very much but they are most uncomfortable people all ways (sic) picking at each other, I should hate to live there with them. I did a lot of shopping in the town but saw nobody particular. We are still having vile weather.

December 5th
Today was quite an eventful day. In the morning we did as usual lessons, I got a letter from Father. The parents are getting on very well and seem both very cheery. I wrote 4 letters today (initials follow, including CWM, who was Wynne's "Earl"). I am so sick of letter writing. In the afternoon we went to the Bazaar. There was a painting competion which Eva went in for and got two first prizes. I was so pleased. There was also a men's hat competition. Some were too peculiar for anything, for instance the Duke of Bedford's had one flat bow and a flower on it, he took just 25 minutes over the bow and as long over the flower and when it was finished the effect was like a hay rick with all the hay scraped from off it!! I heard they were going to sell them half price. I think I would have given the whole price for somebody to take it away.

We played whist this evening, Y and I against Gran and BGS. We were rotting all the time making signs and revoking in turn, but in spite of all our efforts we were beaten. True we had no hands and our revokes got us at least two tricks!! I believe Mrs Todd is about the same, but I have not heard for certain. We still have vile weather, such wind I wonder if it will ever stop. I am so sick of it.

December 6th - !!!

December 7th
Our painting class as usual. Miss Coles was most complementary to me and said a great many nice things about my painting, in fact she pleased us all a great deal by telling us we were much the most industrious class of the two and that she held us up to them as an example. How they must hate us! Just before the class began I was crossing the street when I came in contact with a runaway horse. It was dashing down the street with all its harness on it, evidently it had broken loose from some carriage. It created quite an excitement in the town. We lunched with the Daniells and walked home afterwards.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The family home, Brookfield, Tarrant Keyneston, Dorset. The Llewhellin's lived here until they gave up the lease in 1914. The house is virtually unchanged on the outside to this day...unlike the interior! These photos were taken in 1890, but if you move your mouse over the first two, you can see what they look like about 100 years later. The first is the view of the house from the garden, and the second is the sitting room, which is the room on the ground floor behind those open french windows you can see.

The sitting room above led onto the dining room, which you can see through the doorway. Below is a photo of the dining room today - again, no clutter, but sadly the beautiful mahogany doors have been overpainted.

And finally, the view of the entrance. The woman talking to the owner at that time is actually Win Steed, the Win mentioned in the diary throughout the diary. She was born in 1899, and was Wynne's niece. She spent a long period at this house before the First World War, as her parents worked in India and had sent her Home to stay with the relatives, as was the custom.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 8th - 14th

December weather. Hare coursing, mud, love letters and horrible new hymns in church.
viewer_4.description:
December 8th, Sunday
The organist in church this morning disgraced himself by bawling out the Litany in concert with Mr H (Highton, the vicar), who was vainly trying to commence the Communion. We all laughed of course. Our hymns this morning were distracting to say the least of it as not one of us knew them. I happened just before the first to glance across at the other seat and there I saw Miss S and Eva perfectly white with rage at Mr H. They can't stand the new hymns! Mr H came to tea and stayed I should think nearly two hours. We did talk a lot poor creature, he seems to be awfully dull and lonely over there as Ede has gone to live with the Bakers for a day or two. Poor Mrs Todd is much weaker today.

December 9th
We had a most delightful day today as the hounds met at Ashley. We arrived in splendid time and joined the pack as it went into the wood, unfortunately they did not do anything there but had to do afterwards and draw Blackberry Wood. On their way over they killed in a root field but had no run after. We were able to follow splendidly for a long time although it was very rough walking on plough after the rain, the mud was so frightfully thick and wet that we all got simply filthy, especially the long-skirted ones, Miss Scratchley being among the worst. I have drawn a picture of her here:

...this is the exact picture of her as she looked crossing a plough. We were all pretty well as bad but she was by far the choicest. I forgot to mention we were all much enraged because that wretch Mr Bussy was there and he insisted on grinning at us for about 5 minutes. His face is somewhat like this:

There were a lot of people out, Hanky among them, but I avoided him because of his hair grease. We calculated to have done about 10 miles altogether and came home very ready for our dinner and exceedingly mud-clotted!! The Castlemans have asked us over to lunch sometime this week. Edward was out today looking very nice. Rachael's horse is ill so she cannot hunt until after Xmas, so disappointing for her. Miss S and I go to Bath on Friday, I am so excited.

December 11th, Wednesday
Nothing particular happened this morning. Went to Blandford while Eva and Miss S changed the drawing room furniture. I like it very much as it is now. This afternoon we had great fun... (to find out, check out Editors Picks, and scroll through to A Young Victorian...below is Wynne's drawing of the two young women dressed up to fool their sister).



December 12th
(Code: "Charles is My Dearest! Quite true")
Poured all day long, we were going to lunch to the Castlemans but could not go because it was so wet. (Code: "Got a letter from the Earl, he said something too sweet for words. I do think he is the sweetest being on earth!!!") I have nothing more to say as we have done nothing all day long. We have begun our Xmas holidays but still continue to have our music as usual. We are not go to the Burns until Monday, I am so awfully sick about it but lets hope we shall go then. We have been put off so often that I don't believe we shall go before Xmas.

December 13th, Friday
As it was a lovely day we drove over to see the Castlemans in the morning and although they asked us we couldn't stay to lunch, because of the women meeting. The wind was simply frightful on the way and we got nearly blown away, did not do anything all afternoon.

December 14th
Went to our painting class as usual, great grief because it is our last class and we do not begin again until Feb. 15th. I am not in the mood for writing so I shall stop this rot.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.excerpt:
December 15th - 21st

A Christmas trip to Bath for present shopping and much visiting of friends and relations.
viewer_5.description:
December 15th, Sunday
Of course went to Church in the morning. Elliot sang like a jackass!! Winnie like a nightingale, Elliot says. "Ginny donkey"!! He behaved most shamefully, we were shrieking most of the time because of him, I hope

(here Wynne has drawn a picture of the vicar, see left!) did not see us. All the afternoon I spent with Edie Highton, poor little girl she seems so lonely. We sat and talked and read and then D'arcy Todd came to tea and jawed about the migration of birds etc. Lorgues! Then Yso came and called for me and we talked a little longer, then came home. We go to the Burns probably tomorrow.

December 16th, Monday
Arrive here (Bath) by morning train. We had a fearful rush for the train. I thought Miss Scratchley would have had a fit rushing up the station stairs.
We shopped in the afternoon and Miss S went to a big concert in the evening and came home delighted with it.


December 17th
Miss S and I went shopping all morning, got a lot of Xmas presents. In the afternoon we went to hear an organ recital at the Abbey. He played Nazareth which was just beautiful. I have been doing my accounts tonight and am in a perfect muddle with them.

December 18th
It poured all the morning, but after lunch we went to see the Hugh Llewhellins where I met Laura Rossiter. I think she would be very nice but at present is rather quiet and shy. She took me all over the house, such funny cricks and crannies all about the place, it is a very large house and exceedingly clean and airy. They have a large garden and field. Laura is small and dark with very pretty eyes and rather a long nose. She was very sweet to me and hoped we should meet again! We came home down a very steep hill almost perpendicular with funny little shops in it and quite different people about. When we passed the pump room we went in and tasted the Bath waters, they are hot and irony but not bad. Uncle Hugh walked home with us. We return Friday and had letter from home imploring us to return Thursday but in vain. I hear the Babe goes down to B on Fri. to stay until Tuesday, I am very glad. I don't think Eve cares much however he is always very nice to me, only always rather proper!!

December 19th, Thursday.
Shopped in the morning and visited Blaxalls in the afternoon. They are such sweet people. In the evening we went with Milly and Ethel to the Latin play at the College. It was most amusing especially as in the middle of the play one of the boys' undercostumes came down, it looked just awful and Sybil Garret who was sitting in between us nearly died with laughing. There was a great deal of cheering and clapping. Ethel stayed to the supper and arrived about 1 o'clock. The room was very full and I recognised several boys I knew when I was here last time. I got a box of paints for each of the children and Miss S gave them a painting book each. They were just delighted.

December 20th
We return to the bosom of our family rather sick as we are having such fun here. Today to our surprise when we looked out the ground was covered thick with snow. I hope it wont come on badly this evening because we shall probably get snowed up!

December 21st, Saturday
We arrived quite safely yesterday. Yso and I went for a walk and Jack nearly got strangled by getting his head in a rabbit wire, but we managed to get him out of it. Pooh pooh, I am not going to say any more, am feeling exceedingly decayed. (Jack must be a pet dog, but as he is not mentioned in the frontispiece, he may have belonged to Yso).

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 22nd - 28th

Wynne has a very dull Christmas...presents are given and received on the 24th, so the 25th seems very boring.
viewer_6.description:
December 22nd, Sunday.
Went to Church. Mr Muddlecoot is with us at present. I stayed in with Granny while the others went out.

December 23rd
This was an exceptionally dull morning, did simply nothing. The afternoon post was most interesting and brought us our mails, good news of the parents and many good wishes in the afternoon. Uncle Stanley came over and the boys were out shooting. I've made some crosses and wreaths for the church of iris and privet, having no holly berries whatever, but when we had frosted them they looked lovely. Danced and played games after dinner.

December 24th
The Muddlecoot returns to Town today. I am quite sorry as I like him very much, slightly superior sometimes and wants ragging which I gave him!! Our Xmas tree came off this night. It was fun. I had 20 presents, among which was the sweetest ring which Gran gave me, all the Hightons came and we took everything off the tree at the end.

December 25th - Christmas Day
This seems very like Sunday as we went to Church this morning, we were again tortured by a most frightful new hymn which I didn't know a bit so sang La La to it!! at which Yso caught me. At our dinner we had Mr Highton who was very mournful. We drank toast all round (Code:"I drank the Earl's of course"). Yso got the thimble and ring and I the button, Elliot 6d, monkey and beer jug which looks bad. (Wynne here refers to the charms they picked out of the Christmas pudding. These were small silver charms buried in the pudding, and each one was reputed to offer you a clue as to your future, hence the comment).
After dinner we had some songs which was all. This has been the dullest Xmas evening I know.

December 26th
Had a very nice letter from CWM, who is in excellent spirits and writes most cheerfully. I am so glad. Mrs Todd died on Xmas day, very sad, her funeral is to be on Wednesday to which I suppose we are going, they are going to take Col. Todd up to Town with them when they go. I'm sure he will hate it.

December 27th
We got our mail letters today, it is unusually early this week and we shall probably not get them again for about 10 days which is vile. I got a long letter both from Father and Mother. The former sent me a cheque for £1.00 which I am going to get the silver wedding present with.

December 28th, Saturday
Miss Scratchley and I drove in yesterday and got Walter out and today Adie came to stay over Sunday. (Walter I think may be Wynne's Uncle, and Adie was Adie Maclean, Charles' brother). We played fives much to Elliot's disgust who has now forbidden us to play again!! Played all sorts of mad silly games. Walter is still very charming but not half so good looking as he used to be however that doesn't matter.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.excerpt:
December 29th - 31st

New Year's Eve is a much more rumbustious affair - games, pranks, and the house in uproar...
viewer_7.description:
December 29th
The decorations were still up in Chruch today and looked quite nice. Slept all the afternoon and in the evening we played games as usual, lights and word games, the latter proved a degree too much for me as I distinguished myself by making a remark which was too awful to repeat here; for at least the space of 3 minutes nothing was heard but titters and giggles, in my life I never disgraced myself so much as this, it was too awful, especially on looking at the word I discovered lots of most fearful other words! Another excitement we had was our language which the men had got hold of and were trying to make out. They did not succeed this night but the next day they made out a long rigmarole which we gave them.

December 30th, Monday
Adie left us and Mr Highton called, we went for a walk and I think that is about all we did do, except disobey Elliot and played 3 games of fives. Yso and I against Adie and Walter. We beat them hollow and have now established ourselves as champions of the kingdom of Brookfield. In the evening we all played pool at which I am no good whatever, therefore I am afraid I have no great affection for!!

December 31st
In the morning we did nothing special but in the evening we played pool and danced till about 10.30 and this being New Year's Eve we of course had Snap Dragon and sat the old year out. At 10.30 it was ready, we all assembled in the dining room, heated then lit the brandy and put the lights out, then set to work to pick the almonds and raisins out, it was such fun especially as we didn't burn ourselves very much. When it was all over we decided to go out and listen to the bells and leave all the door open so as to let the New Year in. The night was lovely and warm. We then sang Auld Lang Syne with crossed swinging hands and afterwards returned to the dining room where we smoked cigarettes and drank the healths of all our friends until 1 o'clock when we turned in for bed...so we thought. I must mention here that whilst the men were having their first smoke we went to their rooms and filled the rooms with practical jokes. We gave them each an apple pie (ie: folded the bed sheet and tucked it in so that the occupant discovered they could not get into the bed), holly, sewed Elliot's pyjamas up in 600 places and hid his shaving brush. So far, so good. When we had retired to bed we thought we would leave our doors ajar so as to hear how our jokes went on, but unfortunately by some accident they both found out and as soon as E had done so he came tearing up the stairs and I had just got into my nighty when he burst in, in spite of my having bolted the door, caught hold of a corner of our bedclothes, pulled them all off and rushed down the stairs with the whole lot. I in my shortest nightgown flew after him and just as I reached the drawing room out came Walter, I in terror hid until Yso brought me my dressing gown, in the meantime Elliot flew upstairs and did exactly the same to Yso and Miss S while we went to Walter's room, pulled all his clothes off and blew our his candle and bagged his matches!!
It was a joke!! One thing dreadful which happened, W came to our room to get our matches and the whole place was littered with our underclothes of all sorts, but worst of all (code: " under the bed there gleamed the butler's eye!!!!" This must be a shocked reference to a chamberpot!). I nearly had a fit not knowing what to do. However W went out seeing I believe my embarrassment! We then got one of Eva's bed socks, hung it on a nail outside the door and filled it with a boot, soap etc as an Xmas present from W to E!! Yso and I then went down to see how Elliot was getting on and found him making his bed whilst Eva was slaving at his pyjamas. We finished the evening by making our beds again and W's , getting to sleep at about 2.30. They say they are determined to pay us out but we are prepared and have locked our doors, however if Elliot bursts through them again like he did it wont be much use!!

december.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary in November .

The family now prepare for Christmas at their home, Brookfield, in Dorset.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This is the first page from the first diary Wynne kept - the drawing at the top is of the family home, Brookfield, in Tarrant Keyneston. The portraits are, from the left: Miss Scratchley (BGS, governess), Eva (older sister), Ysobel Butler (cousin) and Wynne (W.G.Ll). The small sad little face bottom right is Granny!

You can find out more about the family and the characters and houses mentioned if you go to the relevant sections: click here for the Family - and here for Houses.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 18th - 22nd

Wynne is at home, preparing for the departure to India of her parents. Her cousin Yso is staying. They both have lessons with the governess, Miss Scratchley.
viewer_2.description:
November 18th, Monday
I am beginning my Diary today because it is the beginning of the week. I don't expect I shall make large entries as we are not going to be wildly exciting this winter. I am feeling naturally rather decayed this afternoon as the parents leave tomorrow for India, I don't in the least know why as they only go for 4 months. I am to send my bicycle back on Wed. but dear old Bogel (Wynne's nickname for her father) says he will get me one in Spring when they return, so I don't mind much. He has also given me 10/- for Xmas presents, ripping. I shall be able to get such nice ones. Crowds of visitors are pouring in to say good-bye I suppose. What pests they are. Mum will be so tired. Yso and I went to Monkton this morning on our bykes, it was glorious, no wind and hardly any mud. When we arrived we went to the post office and got a glass of water and then to a baker's shop and bought sweets and then spun home. Yso (her cousin) has just made this () filthy mark here, objectionable child! I wrote to Worry and Pussie, also Eleanor Wilkinson today. I have been good. I am not going to put in any more now as I think this is a very good entry for the first time of asking.

November 19th
The parents went away this morning, so in consequence of this we are rather dumpy. Yso and I amused ourselves this morning by having our last ride together, and we went to Badbury taking our bottle of milk and some biscuits with us. When we arrived we got down on a mound and eat (sic) them and then returned and did figures on the lawn. I am awfully sorry, its our last day with it, but it cant he helped. This evening Y and I consider ourselves great conquerors having beaten Miss S (Scratchley, the governess) and Eva (Wynne's older sister) 6 times at 5s. Of course we are as proud as punch. The post was very dull today, I did not get one letter and am ashamed to say did not write any either. From 5s our hands are like this!!

not pretty but true. Y is awfully good but her hands are unfortunately rather soft. Peta (the cat) distinguished herself today by being sick all over the floor, tiresome child. I had to clean it up too!!.

November 20th, Wednesday
It poured all day long today so we could not go out for a walk. Yso began regular lessons with me today: Music and French were the order of the day, it all went off well. Heard from Bogel this morning from Town, they started early and were to reach Paris about 7.30 I believe where they dined. Mother had been shopping and one or two friends had come. I had a most interesting letter this morning from AR and laughed at the contents very much. I wish I had one like it every day. We have again been playing fives and Y and I as before beat them 6 games. Our faces were like this afterwards!



November 21st
I have been most remiss as today is Saturday and I have written nothing for Thurs. or Fri. however I must do my best to remember what happened on these days. In the morning we heard from Mother just before they started, they were very busy getting things together. Yso and I did our preparation in the evening and that is all I can remember.

November 22nd
Today to our great astonishment Rachel and Harry Castleman came riding over here and stayed to lunch, it was so jolly but unfortunately Gran and Eva had gone to Bath for Xmas shopping and so they missed them. In the evening Yso, Miss S and I will (amuse) each other and when the others came home we amused ourselves looking at their shoppings.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The family around the time Wynne started writing her diary. They are sitting on the verandah that overlooks the garden at Brookfield.

From the left: Blanche (Wynne's mother), unknown, Wynne, George (father), Elliot (brother) and Eva.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 23rd - 26th

Dress fittings, games and love letters. Wynne invents a code to stop spies.
viewer_4.description:
November 23rd, Saturday
This morning we went to our painting class which came off most successfully, and I finished my model. The wind was blowing rather high in the B.G.G.quarter this morning but it dropped about 3.0. I expected to hear this week (then sentences in code,see below: "from the Earl, I do hope he is all right" - Wynne was very excitedly beginning on her first love affair, which when it became serious was quickly squashed. Her boyfriend was a family friend, Charles Maclean - see Love in the Highlights section where you can follow the whole story.)


Mr Todd has just been in, we (Y and I) played 5 games of fives, 4 of which we won, he is not quite so good as he was I don't think. We bought some very pretty Xmas cards today, Y and I are going to Bournemouth sometime next week to do all our shopping, I am looking forward very much to it.
Dress Entry!! I am having a new serge skirt made, dark blue and tight fitting, made with hussar braiding on it like Mother. A green velvet blouse with a collar of macramé lace on it is coming tonight from the Dressmakers - something like this...I do hope it will be nice.



Sunday 24th
Mr Highton is away so Mr Salmon came to preach, I think there must have been some mistake because Mr Adie came too and finding Mr S there he went back. We had no morning service and as the weather was vile I for one was rather glad. Gen. Deane came to tea and told us all the news, or rather gossip. Poor old Mrs Todd is not quite so well today I think, but Mr Daniel thinks she will get better all right.

November 25th
Today Yso and I went to Bournemouth, it was great fun, we got all our Xmas presents. We went by the early train and came back by the 2.10, having spent a most delightful day. Played fives in the evening, and beat them.

November 26th
Did lessons in the morning, and at 3.0 drove into Blandford with Eva to meet Nan who came by the 4.4. I had my dress tried on, and then went up to the station, waited 30 minutes for the train and got thoroughly chilled. The wind was so bitter and driving home I got nearly frozen. We played fives in the evening, N and I against Y and E, but as I had to do all the work we got beaten.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne had two "narrative" photos taken in 1898 in the garden at Brookfield - the story is obvious, but typical of that period. She continued to live at home until her marriage to Herbert in 1900.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 27th - 30th

Letters, painting classes and making a wish while stirring the Christmas pudding.
viewer_6.description:
November 27th, Wednesday
Did lessons all morning and darned stocking. I had (code starts) "a letter from the Marquise yesterday, is not very well poor old thing" (unidentified suitor, but it does not appear to be another name for Maclean). I did not get one letter this morning but Yso heard from Brenda, what an odd cove she is. Yso and I went for a walk and in the evening I did prep,after dinner played to them in the drawing room, absolutely nothing more to say.

November 28th
Did lessons this morning and heard from both Father and Mother this morning from Brindisi, getting on very well indeed. Went for a very muddy walk with Yso and returned to tea after which did prep and wrote to Bogel. We amused ourselves after dinner with playing all sorts of mad card games such as Advertisement Grab etc...my word was Robisson and Cleavers Cambric Pocket Handkerchiefs!! It was great fun. A very dull day in general. Eve and Nan went to B to shop but nothing else happened at all. Poor old Mrs Todd is not so well today I hear, and Mr Highton came back today. We stirred the puddings today, I wonder if our wishes will come true, mine of course was the same as usual and does not come off till I'm 21 if ever! We put eight different things into the pudding.

November 29th, Friday
Wet day all day long. (Code) "I had the Earl's letter this morning" Played fives in the evening with Nan. Had to do all the work. Nothing more to say!!! !!!

Saturday 30th
Went our painting class this morning (sic). I have finished my model and am beginning another of oranges and grapes, rather pretty. I got my new dress today. I am to have a short jacket made for it like Yso's. We did work in the afternoon and played whist in the evening. After we had gone to bed Gran gave us a fearful frightful fright by falling headlong down the three steps into Yso's room with a crash. Thank goodness she wasn't hurt or rather declared she wasn't!

november.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary on 18th of this month.

She was 16, and living at the family home, Brookfield, Tarrant Keyneston, Dorset with her parents, and her two siblings, Eva and Elliot.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
April 5th - 7th

Fun and games at home, and the excitement of a large private concert that Wynne is involved with prompt a return to the diary.
viewer_1.description:
April 5th, Easter Sunday
I have been so remiss in writing my diary lately. I do wish I hadn't been so for several reasons. One is that Carnac, Ray's friend, has been and gone and I have never stated the fact in this journal, what a mistake!! At any rate I can but describe him, now he is in my mind. Distinctly good looking, tall, rather fair with brown eyes and lovely teeth, his manner is charming and everybody seems to like him. He certainly isn't a bit like what Ray describes him as but he only stayed about 3 days so we couldn't see much of him. The Rectory people and the Todds came to tea and we had games: "Twos and Threes", likewise "Giant's First". Mother and Ray were Giants and then Carnac and I. We caught the whole lot in about 3 minutes. I was so sorry when he went but probably he is coming here again in a year's time with R.H. when they return from sea. DV. RSVP. IOU. PTO. Yesterday we decorated the Church all morning. I did the reading desk with wallflowers, forget-me-knots and primroses and I was glad to say that they were quite fresh today. It all looked very pretty I think.

April 6th, Monday
We are fearfully busy over this concert that we are getting up. The Castleman lot are coming over to help us. I and Miss S are going to open the concert with the Gondoliers, we are also to play the Henry VIII dances and last but not least I have to sing a duet with Eva in costume. Its called "Sweet Nightingale". I am to be dressed up as a boy!!! I know I shall have a fit of giggles in the middle. R.H. came to tea to say goodbye as he leaves tomorrow. After tea he came with us down to the schoolroom and helped us to decorate it. He worked like a galley slave and was so good about it whilst Bill and I employed our time by using his legs as pin cushions which he didn't seem to appreciate! Poor old thing he is very sad at going away and I believe we are to hold a correspondence whilst he is away (by permission!!).

April 7th
I forgot to say that Uncle Arthur (Butler, Ysobel's father. Ysobel is also Bil, above) came yesterday to the great delight of us all, the more especially Yso who rode in on the byke to meet him. This is a most lovely morning and instead of writing this in the evening I am doing so now. The weather at present is just too lovely for anything and the birds are just shouting all round.
All the morning we were down at the schoolroom decorating the stage. The whole place looked awfully jolly. The Castlemans arrived just a little before lunch, also the two Clowdy girls. In the afternoon we practised all our different things over which went all right. We dressed at about 6.30 and had just soup and meat before we went. The doors were open at 8 and we had a very full room. The Pennys, Todds, Hightons etc all came. We all sat behind the scenes and had great fun. Our duets went off very well and Eva and I went encore 3 times in our costume song. The people simply shrieked with joy, in fact everybody said they enjoyed it very much. When we came home we had a champagne supper and played "Bogie in the Dark" and went to bed at 12.30!!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 8th - 12th

Croquet, concerts, painting classes...but its not enough to keep the diary going after the 12th.
viewer_2.description:
April 8th, Wednesday
Played croquet in the morning. Edward C(astleman) and Georgie Maclean came over, both riding. We were 15 at dinner. This afternoon Ell, Bill and I went over to the Williams' for hockey but when we got there we all agreed that it was too hot to play so I went on the river with young William and they played croquet. After tea we played hockey as it was cooler. Driving home Elliot went quite mad and we sang all the ribbled (sic) songs we could think of. The Castlemans went away soon after luncheon so we didn't see them again.

April 9th
Did Jumbles all day long. Absolutely nothing else.

April 10th
Had a most amusing day. We went over to Bournemouth, Mother, Miss S, Bill and I to hear "Patti" sing at a big concert there. It was just delightful. I think she sings just too beautifully. I liked Liebich very much too, he is a pianist. We also heard the Australian prima donna Ada Crossley. We afterwards had tea at the Brockes when we saw the celebrated Charles Holt!!, such a funny little shrimp. We then hurried to the station just in time to catch out train.

April 11th, Saturday
Painting class as usual from which we came back rather earlier than usual because of our jumble sale. to make a long story short it was a great success and with it and the concert we have made over £5 which is very good. We opened the sale at a quarter past 3 and in an hour's time every blessed thing had gone. Bill and I sold close upon 10/- worth of 1d and ½d things which the children reveled in.

Sunday 12th
Went to church in the morning and behaved shockingly during service as for Bill and Ell, they sat yelling all the way through. I forgot to say that last night the toddies came to dinner, also Miss Pettitt and we had a muscial "soiree"
-----

Goodbye dear diary. I cannot write any more in you now. I shall never forget the good times I have written about in you, that I have had. I hope I shall have lots such others. It makes me quite sad to stop here and say goodbye but as nothing very interesting happens just now I think it is best to do so. Goodbye once more, perhaps some day I may continue this.

april.description: Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895...but she is getting rather lazy about keeping it up!

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
August 1st - 10th

The Homburg visit includes visits to the famous hat maker and to the Saalburg. Friends leave, taking their eligible son with them!
viewer_1.description:
August 1st, Saturday
Went as usual to the Brunnen and Milkhouse, also to my baths, and called at the Post Office for letters, found two for me, both of which were very amusing, one from the babe and one from Gammy. The latter is the oddest fish I ever came across. It poured all the evening. Went to the Kurhaus as usual.

August 2nd
Simply pouring, it seems to be doing that most days. Much too wet to go to church and looks as if it would pour all day. Have just finished my book Zoroaster, its just wildly exciting but I don't care for the ending. This is how I feel at present:

August 3rd
Got a letter from Eva and went through the usual routine of the day without anything else having happened.

August 4th
Went to Wiesbaden, saw Auntie (Aime) and all the children. Its a fairly long way and when we arrived it was about 2.30. Auntie and Nora met us, then we drove up, the town is large with very good shops. We had lunch and then I played with the children in the garden. Bill still continues to be my favourite, he is so sweet. Rita is not near so pretty as she used to be, nor Walter either. It is such a pity. I eat such heaps of fruit that I felt quite ill! and Auntie gave me a huge bag to take home with me.

August 5th
Blank!!!

August 6th
Today we went over the hat manufactory. It is most interesting. At the first stage the hat is as big as this

just like a thimble and as it goes on it gradually gets thicker and smaller. I forgot to say that yesterday we drove up to a place in the wood where we imagined the hats were made but when we got there it wasn't the place at all, it was miles away in the woods and we had gone all the way for nothing.

August 7th
The day proving fine I went as usual to the Brunnen with Father and had also my glass of milk. All the morning we lazed about and in the afternoon we took a fly and went up to see Saalburg, a Roman Camp of large dimensions. We had tea up there and then drove home. Its about 5 miles away and we took just an hour and a half getting there. True it was rather up hill a good bit of the way but even on the level road the horse insisted on walking!! and in spite of the abuse we hurled at the driver he took absolutely no notice whatever and continued to meander along. Considering the language we used was half Hindostan, Italian and German I don't blame him because I'm sure he couldn't have understood one word. The Camp is very interesting and very large, its on the top of a hill and has five huge wells which contained all the treasure which they found. The drive there is awfully pretty, all through the pine woods and coming home through corn fields.

August 8th, Saturday
Did nothing particularly.

August 9th, Sunday
Poured steadily all the morning but in spite of it we went to Church. And in the afternoon I wrote letters and listened to the band, then went and had tea with the Hurdwoods at Brahe's.

August 10th
Today our nice friends the Hurdwoods left us, I do miss them so awfully, its perfectly beastly here without them, but they have asked me down to stay with them. I do hope I shall be able to go. We went to see them off at the station, there were many regrets and much weeping, especially on the side of Geoff who was far too overcome even to look out of the window!! In the afternoon we went to the Dog Show. There are some awfully sweet little dogs there but they make an awful noise barking and yelling. Spent a very dull and most depressing evening, have got the most fearful blues, it is the effect of (code: Geoff's absence) I know.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 11th - 15th

One young man quickly replaced by another. Stags heads are viewed with the Prince of Wales, and they visit a synagogue.
viewer_2.description:
August 11th
Most beautiful weather. Went to the springs, got a letter from Mopsel and we have decided to go there on Sunday, stop the night and not return here. This afternoon I spent with the Roses. We went for a drive up in the woods, it was just lovely there. We had tea at ……, I cant remember the name. I forgot to say we met them here, they consist of father and son, who are both charming. Young Arthur Rose is very nice and amusing, I like him very much (I hope he wont ever get hold of this!!). He is 6 foot 2 inches and so good looking, fair and very determined to look at. Enough of him for the present as I'm sure this diary will see a good bit more of him before I finish!!! Dr Caverhill also came to drive with us, and presented me with a lovely bunch of roses and at table d'hôte Mr Rose, senior, also gave me a bouquet - quite festive.

August 12th
Grouse shooting. I wonder what Gany and Elliot are doing today. Footled all the morning and spent the afternoon in the garden here with AR. Smoked and amused myself generally! After tea we sauntered down to the tennis when I suddenly thought I would like to hire a bike so I did, and when I was performing gaily suddenly I heard a voice saying "now why haven't I got a Kodak!" and looking up I saw AR, upon which we went for a turn.

August 13th
It is simply pouring.

August 14th
Today we drove again in the woods with the Roses and Dr Caverhill. Arthur played the fool all the time. I never saw such a mad one as he is, as bad as Elliot. We drove up to the keeper's lodge where there was a show of all the stags heads that had been shot during the year. A lot of people were at the judging, among them the Prince of Wales. We drove on up to Saalburg where we were caught in a tremendous shower of rain. Went to the Kurhaus and spent the evening with the Roses.

August 15th, Saturday
This morning at 10 o'clock with a party of six we set off to the Jews' Synagogue to hear their service. It is too weird for words. Mrs B and I simply sat in convulsions up in the Gallery where all the ladies sit, the men sit downstairs with their hats on and lots with grey cloaks on (here the diary has been taken over by another hand, and the following is written:) and trousers and such like which to my mind were far from necessary but then Father said that was because I was too young to understand. All the old Mumps round me called the Chief Rabbi Bandersnatch Touser which made me simply split my sides and cry "Lorks". Then they who were in the auditorium whistled, spat and choked and when I said lorks, screamed "Church is out" but no one moved. Father said it was because they none of them wore braces but of course I don't know.
I beg here to state that I didn't write any of this rot, persons name I'll not mention him as I'm not likely to forget who did it in a hurry. (Arthur Rose, perhaps?)
Well, to continue - we didn't stay long, and Mrs Budd and I went for a ride afterwards and in the middle of it her treadle came off so I had to ride it back as she couldn't ride with one leg. (it is possible this was actually a treadle bicycle - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treadle_bicycle - or it just may be that Wynne is using old terminology for a peddle.) We did blow the man up but I don't suppose he understood.
We went to Frankfurt today, started by the 12.10 train and as soon as we arrived we trammed to the Palm Garden where we had an excellent lunch, after which we flew off to the Zoo which I found most interesting. I love Zoos, that's to say all except the London one on a Sunday with a large party! We went of course to see the Ariadne, she is beautiful, I don't know when I have seen anything so exquisite in sculpture. (Wynne spells this Ariadny, and it must refer to a copy of the sleeping Ariadne that is in the Vatican, a Roman copy of a Greek original).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.excerpt:
August 16th - 26th

The holiday draws to a close with visits to relatives at Wiesbaden, then on to Heidelberg and Titisee, before returning to Brookfield.
viewer_3.description:
August 16th, Sunday
Today we left. I don't know when I hated anything so much. I do dislike leaving all my nice friends whom I haven't the slightest chance of seeing again. Last night Arthur Rose gave me such a neat watch bracelet of Russia leather, as mine was broken. I do think it was sweet of him. He also had put in my room an anonymous box of chocolates, how charming some people can be when they choose. Neither Arthur or Dr Caverhill could see us off as they had to go to church! Or rather the latter had and so dragged off the former too. Old Mr Rose came to see us off and brought me a huge box of fondons (sic) and roses, amongst other people Mrs Kennedy gave me such a sweet little bouquet. Everyone was so kind to me no wonder I hated leaving. We arrived at Wiesbaden where Auntie and Algie met us and drove us first to the "Block" where we deposited our luggage then drove on up to the Schon Aussicht. The children were all flourishing and I got Auntie to give me a photo of my precious Bill. (This is Bill Fallowfield - he died in WW1).

August 17th
Went shopping with Mopsel after which I left her to go and see the children whilst she went to meet Uncle Hugh at the station. He wasn't looking at all well. I played with the children until I thought I should have a fit from running and laughing. We left about mid day for Heidelberg.

August 18th
This as everyone knows is a beautiful place. After we arrived we took a drive along the river (Neckar) round by Wolfsbrunnen and the Castle. The scenery is just too lovely for words. The river runs between two high chains of mountains and all over the place there are little villages dotted about. Wolfsbrunnen is a quaint little place chiefly used for trout fishing and as for the Castle I should have liked to roam about it for hours. It is a dull red colour and all in ruins. We saw there the largest cask in the world, it holds 300,000 bottles of wine and the story goes that (cant remember his name) was making it he used to drink from 18-20 bottles every day!! I bought at the hotel some photos of it for my collection. Whilst we were driving to the Castle a little girl ran up and gave me a little bunch of flowers for which we gave her a trifle, but I lost the flowers more's the pity.

August 19th
Today we left Heidelberg for Freiberg and a more decayed hole I have never been at. The only object of interest here is an old Roman Catholic Minster, very old and interesting but the place itself is (not) and I was glad enough to leave the next day for Titisee. Today is Ell's birthday and we drank his health.

August 20th
Never have I seen such beautiful scenery than I did today coming up in the train. It was very fine weather and as we had to go very slowly because of the uphill way we had plenty of time to look about. The mountains are simply huge on either side and on one side of the line there runs a river which is simply sweet and makes a tremens noise. The scenery reminded me very much of Scotland only of course here the mountains are covered with firs. This place Titisee is on a plateau and in front of our hotel is a lovely lake 3 miles long and 2 wide. After lunch Father and I went for a walk round the lake and I suppose I must have got my feet wet or something as ever since I have had a beastly cold. I went to a little shop here and bought two little Swiss chateaux and some tiny carved wooden animals for my collection.

August 21st
Spent the day in reading and writing letters as it poured without ceasing all day long. This place is certainly not exciting in wet weather. There are two Americans and two English here, added to this we have 50 fat Fraus yelling all round us, gracious how they talk. Their figures are like this:

One wouldn't know one from the other, decayed lot, they are just like a collection of hens.

August 22nd
Today my cold was so bad that I had to stay in bed until 3.30, it is a bore. All day it poured so that we have decided to try and get away on Monday. I am so sorry as its a bad ending to our trip.

August 23rd, Sunday
Much brighter weather today and the Lake looks lovely but as my cold wasn't better I had to stay in bed. I had a most amusing letter from Bill this morning which made me laugh.

August 24th
As the rain still continued today we determined to hoof it so accordingly we packed up our traps and started from here at 12 for Freiberg, where we arrived at 3. We then went into town and bought 2 cow bells and a cuckoo clock, after which we went to fetch my cape at the post office. We had the greatest difficulty in getting it and blessed the Brookfieldites for not having sent it sooner.

August 25th
We started for home this morning at 8.30. We stopped at Koln and visited the cathedral. We had a lovely crossing and arrived at Liverpool St at 8 the next morning.

August 26th
We just passed through town and went onto Brookfield. It was very nice seeing them all again. Now that I have returned from my lovely trip I shall say goodbye dear little diary once again until I have another time worth writing about.

august.description: Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895...and the German holiday continues, ending in Titisee

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Mikado playbill stuck into her diary by Wynne. She has cut the bottom off, but note that it was preceded by a Vaudeville, entitled After All. This started at 7.50 and the Mikado at 8.30. Several presentations in a theatre in one night were not uncommon, and for those with a mixed bill, it was perfectly in order for theatregoers to arrive at different times. Wynne, for instance, did not see the Vaudeville.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 3rd

The Mikado is a high spot...then lots of church visits on Sunday, and a museum filled Monday followed by tea in Langham Place.
viewer_2.description:
Feb 1st, Saturday
It is very foggy today and a regular London morning. A most dull post this morning, not a line for anybody. After we had finished our breakfast we of course wended our way towards the inevitable High Street, Bill and I. She ordered some paper like mine. In the afternoon we three went to the Mikado had splendid seats in the Dress Circle. I enjoyed it immensely. I think it is just one of the prettiest pieces I have ever seen. Ko Ko is my favourite character, he is just too sweet. Pooh Bah (Rutland Barrington) is also splendid. It is such a pity that he hasn't a better voice, he sings just like a cat in a tin kettle. The dresses are lovely, and the songs also. It ended about 5.30 and when we came home we found Edward Fairholme sitting there. I hadn't the faintest notion who it was at first and only found out by what he talked about. I don't think much of him, he is so fat and his legs are like this:

Feb 2nd
This morning early I was woken by Eva and we all went to Early Service at St Stephens. It was very nice and I liked it exceedingly, there were a lot of people there. We returned to breakfast at about 9 o'clock and directly afterwards Bill and I went off to Westminster Abbey, by underground. We got very good seats there right amongst the choir so we were able to hear all right. After the service on returning to the station we found it closed until 1 o'clock so we had to walk up to Trafalgar Square where we got the bus right home. Of course we went on the top. It was lovely, so nice being able to go out by ourselves. We saw a girl riding a bicycle in bags, it was just beastly, especially as they were rather tight. Weather very foggy and horrid, rather cold also. When lunch was over we all reclined on different chairs and sofas with books which we read until about 4 o'clock when Miss Shaw came in to see us. She is so funny with her everlasting "Lady Bloomfield". B.G.S. also came in afterwards, she was looking well and smart, we went to the Oratory and walked as afar as Gloucester Road with her, it was very foggy but not really bad, and we reached the Oratory in good time so that we had all the whole service, parts of it are very funny, for instance at one time they say 7 "Our Fathers" then "Hail Mary" and then they "Glory" each 7 times for different things. I couldn't bear it and felt as if I must go out, it seems so awfully irreverent to gabble out things like that, especially "Our Father" but although I didn't like that part the sermon was quite beautiful and not in the least Romish and singing was very nice.

Feb 3rd
Went this morning with Eva and Yso to South Kensington Museum. We looked chiefly at the pictures, they have some very good ones, several of Leighton's, Lanseer's (sic), Turners, Brett etc...the rings are also very interesting. After lunch just when we were starting Puss came in and bringing with her Le Joli Garcon of all people in the world. We used to know him at (?) and then he was exceedingly good looking or rather I should say "pretty" but he hasn't improved in looks at all and Bill thinks he is ugly now, but I don't at all and like his face very much still. However there is no accounting for tastes and it is quite unreasonable to expect Bill to like anything I like or to agree with me in any way whatever!! When they had gone we went off to Langham Place to the "Cosy Corner" to meet the Wilkinsons and have tea with them there, we were a quarter of an hour late to our appointment, dreadful, however the girls were there all right. I was so glad to see them. Edie is such a sweet thing; after tea we sauntered all down Regent Street, the people are funny down there but the shops are so lovely. We saw a hat there as big as a round splash bath with out any exaggeration whatever, beastly hideous thing, we then got on to the top of a bus and came straight away down. Did nothing in the evening and saw nobody (good ending!!).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The cast list for the Theatre Royal production of Cinderella. Pantomimes had become an annual ritual, and theatres competed with each other to put on ever more lavish shows. Judging by the amount of new-fangled electricity in this one (see below) it was clearly an expensive show - even Cinderella's carriage was motorised! Sir Augustus Harris's shows were the most lavish in town, and the double act of Leno and Campbell definitely one of the most famous. Harris had been responsible for producing bigger and better shows from the moment he took on the lease at Drury Lane in the 70s. He died in , the year Wynne saw the show. Leno and Campbell's double act continued, surviving one nervous breakdown by Leno, but in 1904 both men died - Campbell in an accident, and Leno in an asylum.

Check out this website about Panto.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 4th - 6th

Cinderella enthralls Wynne, as does Dan Leno...but later in the week The Prisoner of Zenda proves to be even more exciting....
viewer_4.description:
February 4th, Tuesday
This was one of the most amusing days I have spent since I came up to Town, as the boys came up and went to the Pantomime. Directly after breakfast we three went off to Covent Garden to get some fruit and flowers but to our great disappointment when we arrived there the flower market was shut and so we had to content ourselves getting some tangerines, it is a funny place and still funnier people, nothing but costermen and not a single lady anywhere, so we felt rather out of it, especially when one of the men ventured to remark "they be fine big girls!" I laughed, I must say, but was rather alarmed at what they might say next. We then determined to go down to High Street and get some flowers there. We got what we wanted and as they were just ringing the bill up drove the boys. We had lunch as quick as we could and then started off directly, Eva and Mr Brocklebaum in one cab of course! and we three in another. We had a ripping horse so arrived a good bit before they did. All I can say about the Pantomime itself is that I have never seen anything so lovely before, the scenery and dresses were too beautiful for anything, absolutely glorious.
Dan Leno is splendid as the wicked Mama. I laughed till I was perfectly ill at him. The transformation scene is lovely, they are all turned into flowers, and the Spirit of the Pantomime with her six attendants float up and down in the air with a large sort of silk embroidered sheet, then the wedding procession if beautiful. The bridesmaids are dressed in gold satin with sequence (Wynne means sequins) and Cinderella in white satin with silver sequence, it is awful pretty. The other parts are slightly vulgar but still one cannot help that, the Baroness was lovely in the funny way! and the two sisters were also very good, in fact I enjoyed it all very much. Coming home we came in the same order and again we had splendid luck with our horse who ran away most of the time and once we ran into a van but nothing happened more than that and we got along in no time leaving the others miles behind (I daresay they didn't mind). The boys both stayed with us to dinner and went away about 9.15. I am so glad they both were able to come as we had such fun.

Feb 5th
As for this day it has been the dullest and most decayed I have ever spent. Did nothing all the morning but went to lunch with Amy Mangles of all people, it was dull. We stayed awhile and jawed during which I and Yso nearly fell asleep. We traipsed in to aunt Mary's where we had tea and Mabel showed her room and this is the end of this beastly and decayed day. Ta ha ha.

Feb 6th
This proved to be a very fine day so Bill and I determined to start off to the British Museum "on our own" as they say. We bused it all the way but it was so cold that we went inside. When we were in Piccadilly one lady enquired if we were in Bond Street, a bit off her chump I should think. Well, we had a regular day at the "Mujeem" and as soon as we got there we wended our way towards the mummies. They are most interesting, one old fossil had her toes, skull and hair sticking out, it wasn't the least pretty. The Library was very interesting, and the bindings of some of the older books were simply lovely, they have got an immense collection there. At 1.30 we repaired to the Express Dairy Company and had our lunch which consisted of coffee and cakes, it was very nice. We then took our bus back and arrived home at about 3.30, when Admiral came in to tea, dear old thing. It was very nice her coming. In the evening we had such an enjoyable time, we went with Henry Fairholme to see "The Prisoner of Zenda". I can say here that it is the most excitable and interesting piece I have ever seen put on the stage, at one time it is so realistic that everybody jumps up with excitement. Oh! gracious I should love to see it again. As for George Alexander he is too beautiful for words. I am quite made about him. He does act so well. Eveline (sic) Millard is very good and pretty too, also Lily Hanbury, but at the end it is so frightfully sad that Beaver and I sat and sniffed and coughed. I am no good at theatres like that. I always disgrace myself. I don't at present seem to be able to get the play out of my head at all and anybody who hasn't seen it can't imagine what it's like one bit. I could go one prosing about it for hours. I had a very dull drive home with henry and that's the end of this day.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
St James's Theatre charged the following: Private Boxes £1.11.6d to £4.4s. Stalls 10.6d. Dress Circle 7s. Upper Boxes (bonnets allowed) 4s. Pit 2.6d and the Gallery 1s. A huge differential as you can see.
They were proud of their electrical lighting, a new feature of the period, and clearly had a strong policy of no tipping. The show started at 8pm and lasted nearly three hours.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 7th - 11th

To Olympia for a big army show, and later to see the "Shop Girl", though a nasty accident in their hansom cab intervenes.
viewer_6.description:
Feb 7th, Friday
In the morning Bill and I thought we would take just a little turn in the Gloucester Road, and ended up by going all round by Old Brompton Road, Fulham Road and New Brompton! Just a nice little turn!! We also forgot that lunch was at 1.0 and just scraped in in time to change, have lunch and fly off again to the Frasers with whom we went to Olympia. We saw first of all bicycle races, then the Derby, the latter was exceedingly good and they say its very like but what was far and away the best was the Storming of Chitral. It began with a Gymkana in the middle of which came tidings of war, of course there is a great deal of commotion and clearing away of tents etc and then the troops all assemble and drill after which they fight like fun and take the fort. The wounded are carried out by the ambulance, attended by nurses. It is really very good. When it was over we went and had tea in the Winter Gardens where a most fascinating band plays. Mrs Fraser is very kind but rather booish and doesn't talk much. I don't suppose I shall see Pussie again before she leaves for Cairo. I am rather sick about it but it can't be helped. I have been reading rather an exciting book called "The Haunted House at Kew" by Gertrude Warden. Its perfectly ripping and I sat up till 2.30 reading it one night. My present one is called "The Potters Thumb".
(Gertrude Warden was a prolific writer, producing many novels from the 1880's until the War. She was a leading light in the Women Writers' Suffrage League. The book Wynne mentions had been published in 1893. The other book mentioned is by Flora Annie Steel, and is still available).

Feb 8th
Whilst Gran and Bill shopped in the High Street I went up Harrington Road to get my hair washed. The man who washed it was very amusing and bucked the whole time. When that was done I went with Bill to watch the bicycles in the Park, but unfortunately arrived too late to see many of them so we hurried home just in time to get our lunch as quick as we could. Eve came in just at the last moment (I forgot to say she had been down to Cam to a dance), we got two very nice hansoms but on the way a very nasty thing happened to Eve and me. When we were driving through the Strand a man suddenly rushed across our hansom, the horse knocked him down and we went right over the thick part of his legs. We felt two distinct bumps and the wretched man was picked up more dead than alive. Of course the cabby poor beggar got it hot and probably will have to go to court about it. We gave our names and address to the bobby but I hope nothing will come of it, it was so beastly and I felt jolly sick after it too.
The Shop Girl was of course too beautiful for words and Seymour Hicks and Ellaline Terriss were too sweet as usual. Miggles (Frank Wheeler -see playbill) was splendid also. I should like to see it heaps of times more and like it much better than the Artists Model. It has got much more in it.

Feb 9th, Sunday.
Felt so beastly sick and decayed that I did nothing all day but sleep, and in the afternoon the Fairholme boys and Miss Shaw called of course, so we found the evening none of the most exciting.

Feb 10th
Bill (Wynne's name for Yso) left us at 10.15 and Eve and I went for a shopping tour down the Brompton Road, our last in Town. We came home just ladened of course . After lunch we packed off Gran to the Fairholmes, and then we rushed off ourselves and caught our train and got down to Sunningdale in good time for tea. When we arrived they were busy making marmalade and that evening Walter and Mr Ben came up to supper, the latter seems very nice.


Feb 11th
John came over on his byke, much to the amusement of the Household! Miss Heath is very nice and the ? are of course sweet, just the same as ever. The weather is lovely and we just idled our time away all day long.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 12th - 19th

Return to Brookfield via Sunningdale and friends. Home seems very dull after London.
viewer_8.description:
Feb 12th, Wednesday
I had a most delightful time today. Walter took me for a byke ride, we rode 16 miles almost to Windsor. We stopped at the top of the Long Walk and had a splendid view of the castle. Coming back the wind was rather tiresome and tired me rather but I was enjoying it so much that there was no time to think about it much. John rode over again!! and Eve, he and I sat in the woods and smoked cigs all the afternoon. In the evening Mr ? read aloud a most exciting book called "The Sowers" by Merriman, but we couldn't finish it, so we are longing to get it from the library.

Feb 13th
We packed up our boxes today for our return journey. I must say I don't want very much to go home. We started in the morning and met Gran and Miss S at Woking, arriving home at about 4.30. At the station we met Mr Highton and Ray who returned unexpectedly soon. He was looking very well indeed and nice in his uniform. Dear Loo welcomed me most sweetly, neat little child. She was looking very well. (Highton was the local vicar, as you can see if you visit the little church in Tarrant Keyneston).

Feb 14th
Unpacked and did music in the morning, and had tea in the afternoon with the Dennes where we met dear old Edie who leaves tomorrow so we shan't see her again I'm afraid until the summer. Mr H and Ray also came up here to tea.

Feb 15th
Went to our painting class. Denn and Edith also came. I gardened in the afternoon and when I was in my filthiest state who should call but Mr H and Ray, jolly fun. I washed my hands as quickly as I could and in the end even I'm afraid put in a fearfully wild appearance. He had a long jaw with Ray who had a good deal to say for himself.

Feb 16th, Sunday
Went to Church twice today. That's about all we did do this is a long interesting entry, make no mistake!

Feb 17th
Go a note this morning from R.H asking me to go for a walk with him but was not able to. Did lessons in the morning and went for a long walk with Miss S, the weather being too lovely for anything.

Feb 18th
Mail letters came this morning, good news except that ? has had influe (flu?) as most of the people in Mozufferpore, but she was much better when she wrote.

Feb 19th
Went to Church in the morning, being Ash Wednesday. There were exactly 7 people in Church counting (pix) so the responses were not very loud!! Went for a walk with R.H. a good long one and then returned to tea with him after which we played games - new Old Maid and Russia Games.
After that we went again to Church, there was a better congregation this time but when we got out it was simply pelting with rain so we had to bid a hurried farewell to the Hightons and fly home as fast as we could, barely escaping a bad wetting.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Wynne's playbills often had lots of adverts on the back and sides - here is a flavour of some of them!

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
February 20th - 23rd

News from the Suez Canal is not good for Wynne's returning parents...but Wynne's diary writing runs out of steam.
viewer_10.description:
Feb 20th
Did lessons from 10 till 1.30 and went to tea with the Hightons afterwards, today being Ray's birthday. He is 17. We played games after which Ray came home with me, he is certainly very jolly and looks so nice in his uniform. He is so polite too. Evey left us for Chettle where she is to stay until Saturday I think. Its been pouring all day long, I wish I could (code) " hear from the Earl" - I am just longing to.

Feb 21st, Friday
Spent a very exciting day doing nothing but hold a Mothers Meeting in the afternoon. I read to them and all that, after which I gave them tea and sent them home.

Feb 22nd
Went to our painting class as usual thinking to meet Evey in B but she wasn't there and when we arrived home we found that the Castleman's had driven her over but only for a few hours as she went back again after tea and is to return on Monday. I believe she is having a very amusing time over there.

Feb 23rd
This morning I took the first Sunday School class with Alice Combes, who took the infants. We had it in the servants hall and Mr Highton came and opened it, read prayers etc. We got on very well and at a quarter to 11 I walked with them to Church but thank goodness I haven't to sit with them. I had 5 in my class. Gen. Denne, Maud and a Miss Lyon called at tea time and after tea Bessie and Emily Penny came so we had quite a stock of visitors. I have finished "The Red Cockade" by S. Weyman, its a very good story but rather like the rest of his books, all about France. We hear that the Suez Canal is blocked and that the "Caledonia" (mails) and Thames with several others are delayed. The parents return in the latter so I expect they will be fuming. A man-of-war is I believe stuck midway and that's why they can't get on. I do hope it wont keep them long there.


(and here Wynne ends her February entries, resuming in March with news of her parents approach via Italy).

february.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895.

The exciting visit to London comes to an end, but not before theatres, shops and an accident get in the way...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Playbill for the Artist's Model - playing at Daly's Theatre, which is pictured in the small strip you came from. Interestingly, Wynne does not mention the name that is probably the most famous in this list - that of Marie Tempest.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 21st - 24th

Wynne and her sister Eva go to London, to spend a few weeks. They are staying near High Street, Kensington, and plan to do a lot of shopping.
viewer_2.description:
January 21st, TOWN
I cannot understand why I have been so lazy in not writing my diary. I am so sorry I haven't as all sorts of interesting things have happened lately.

I see by my last date it is almost a month since I have touched it. It is useless to try and remember what has happened but in this time Mr Brocklebank came to us, he is very nice indeed and rather good looking but has a nose like this .....
which however one does not seem to notice after a bit. Walter and John teazed us very much because he said he had such beautiful eyes but this bit of news is quite true for they are quite worth looking at!! Well it strikes me I am meandering rather so I'll go on! From about the 15th to the 20th we did absolutely nothing, Ebbo went to Witham and Eve to Gillingham to the Hayes, so we came to Town yesterday which was the 20th. Eve joins us again on Thursday and Bill either Sat or Mon I think. Yesterday we made our journey very comfortably and were not in the least tired when we arrived at 4.30. After tea Gran and I went to see the Fairholmes but found only Alice in, we talked a lot about all the relations. Went afterwards with Miss S to the High Street and did some shopping, and then we retired at a very early hour to bed. Today, 21st, it has been very foggy but in spite of this we all went shopping at Barkers the whole morning. I ordered monogram note paper for myself, it is sort of very pale and rough, azure blue, with a dark blue (monogram) on it. I think it ought to be rather sweet. After lunch we rested, had tea early after which Miss S went to see her people and we to Aunt Mary. Gran (in her eighties) would give me dreadful frights by insisting on nearly running under huge Drays and busses and flying across the roads 60 miles an hour. She is so rash. However I piloted her home safe all right. It seems so lovely to be up here again, and not having seen scarcely a cab for weeks we find it even exciting seeing a hansom!!

January 22nd, Wednesday
I haven't got very much to put in today. This is a good way to begin, because we have done nothing but shop all day long, in the morning we went to the Grove with Gran and in the afternoon Miss S and I went to the High Street and did a lot of shopping. I got some things for my work box, I think I have about fitted it up now. Eva is going to a big ball tonight. I hope she will enjoy herself.

January 23rd
I am so lazy in remembering to write my diary, and I go leaving it for days and then cant remember what to write when I do begin. I think on this morning we went to the Grove to do some trifling in the way of shopping!! Dear old Gran walks so very slowly we can hardly get along at all. I nearly did such a stupid thing: I had two letters to post and having them in my hand with my purse I crossed the road to drop them into the box and by mistake I very nearly dropped my purse in instead. All but. I was in a fright. In the afternoon Eva came, she enjoyed her dance well enough but to our great astonishment at about 5.30 who should drop in but my great joy himself*. He had been down home with the Marriotts for some shooting and thought on his way he would just come and see us, he was looking very fit and jolly. No more for this day.
(*Wynne is referring to Charles Maclean - see Love)


Jan 24th
In the morning of this day Eva and I went up to Oxford Street with the view of going solely to Mrs Hunt's office servant hunting, but on the way we went into a jewellers shop and bought quite by surprise the Silver Wedding Present - it is a pair of very pretty wine decanters, silver mounted and a very queer shape. I hope they will like them. It is so difficult to choose a thing like this. My brother, "E".v."A". came today. I am delighted and am looking forward to having a very good time with her. (Wynne like most people then had a habit of using numerous nicknames...here she is referring to her cousin, Ysobel Butler. Yso crops up in the diaries as EvA, Bill and possibly Ebbo, although this last name might refer to Yso's younger sister. Wynne was very close to Yso, and as a result named her eldest daughter after her).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.excerpt:
January 25th - 28th

Joined by her favourite cousin, Ysobel Butler, the girls shop endlessly, and go to see a production of "The Artist's Model".
viewer_3.description:
January 25th, Saturday
As far as I remember we did nothing the whole day because it rained all the time and I made a mistake by saying Bill came yesterday because she came today.

Jan 26th
In the morning we went of course to church, viz: St Stephens. It is a very nice sort of church, the sermon was a good length and the music very fast, in fact it was impossible trying to keep up with them. Coming out who should we meet but Miss Shaw, the last person in the world, it was odd. She is coming to tea tomorrow. In the afternoon we all went to hear a concert in the Albert Hall, it was lovely, especially the string and brass band of the Royal Engineers. They did play well. Next Sunday the Royal Artillery is to perform so probably we go again. A man played "The Storm" on the organ, it was grand, he did the thunder so well and the wind, it was very realistic. When we came home to tea the Fairholme boys called and stayed some time, then walked with us to the Oratory where we heard some beautiful singing, but it's a very funny service, they do such a lot of bowing and scraping one feels rather strange at first, and it did not look like a church in the least.

Jan 27th
This morning soon after breakfast Yso and I went down to the High Street and did some rather interesting shopping. She bought a gold bracelet and a pair of Oxford shoes, and I bought a pair of evening shoes besides some trifles. After dinner she and I again went to the Norfolk Hotel as we had heard Pussie was in Town. I had heard it this morning from the Wanderer and of course I was game to go and look for her at once, but we found that they were not there, so we went to one or two shops and as we were sitting in one who should pass the door but the great Puss herself. I was so surprised and delighted, we went and talked with them a long time after which she came home to tea with us, dear old girl. I was so glad to see her again. After she had gone who should turn up but the two Wilkinson girls, really it is funny how two such nice things come together.
This morning our mail came in, a most interesting one with letters from the dear Barent Birds. They are well and soon will be with us again, Mother in fact both of them, have been making preparations for next year's outing, I do hope it wont go to smoke as I am so longing to go out.

Jan 28th, Tuesday
In the morning Eve and I went out shopping, and Yso and I went in the afternoon to the Imperial Institute. We went to the Indian Department, there are a lot of awfully good things there, so like it all. There was a little model of Bengal bazaar, just exactly like it all, the pictures were also very good, some sets of native armour were very interesting besides. In the evening Charlie Fairholme went with us to the "Artist's Model". We had very good seats although we could only get them in the Upper Circle. I enjoyed it very much. One thing which was rather a pity, they had got a lot of new songs instead of the old ones which we knew so well. I was rather disappointed but I enjoyed it all so much that there was no time for disappointment. I have kept the programme and stuck it in here.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 29th - 31st

A daring second visit to the Roman Catholic Oratory in Brompton Road. Lots more shopping, and some very fast antics for a girl of 16!
viewer_4.description:
January 29th, Wednesday
This morning Yso and I went up the Brompton Road and on our way we went into the Oratory. I think its one of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen, the marble is too lovely for anything. Yso was very naughty and wanted very much to put up a candle to one of the Saints but I wouldn't let her. Did you ever hear such a mad idea!
I bought a silver padlock for my friendship bracelet and Bill is having F.v.A* put on the back of it for me, rather smart I think. In the afternoon I didn't go out feeling a bit done in, the other three went somewhere or other, Alice Fairholme came to tea and in the evening we didn't do anything particular all being rather chippy with our beastly colds. Bill has now got one, thank goodness mine has taken its departure.
*(Wynne's writing is difficult to decipher - it is either E or F, but here looks like F, and I have no idea what the letters meant, but they refer to Yso and are clearly a nickname.)

Jan 30th
Eve and I went to the old High Street and shopped, trifles. We bought a wee doll to send to Elliot as a "Turvey" trick (no idea what this means!) - we are going to dress it up. I wonder what he will say. Bill thought she wouldn't go out, but went with me after dinner to a shop in the Brompton Road to fetch my padlock which by the way is a great success. When we were walking there I met Mary Castleman and a Mr Openshaw, to whom I was introduced at Lords (or rather who was introduced to me!) but he didn't see me which wasn't much loss! When we had been home about 15 minutes I heard a most peculiar sort of screaming noise and on looking out saw two women walking along, one of which looked like a nurse and the other was simply yelling at her as loud as she could. It sounded something like a cat and a peacock combined. I think she must have been mad. It was so horrid to hear her as she seemed perfectly furious. Bill and I had a very comfortable tea together. Didi's collar came from barkers with "Trin Cole" inscribed on it, it looks awfully smart and we are going to address it to "Master Richard Medleycotte, 4 Jesus Lane, Cambridge". I wonder what Buttons will say. (Another of Wynne's practical jokes? Her brother was there at the time and this could well have been addressed to him. Didi is Wynne's pet cat).
The others have just come in and Eva has presented me with 3 beautiful little handkerchiefs embroidered all round the edges. We have already been up here for nearly a fortnight, it seems to awful to believe.

Jan 31st, Friday
Went as per usual to the old High Street. It strikes me that we go there every day, you see its our nearest shopping street. EVa and I went this morning and then we went to Cecil Roys and got tickets for the "Shop Girl" and the "Prisoner of Zenda", to which we go on Thurs. and Sat., and Tues. to the pantomime. I am looking forward very much to them all.
John came over to see us, he had lunch with us and stayed till after tea and then departed about the middle of the afternoon. Having nothing better to do we commenced to chuck cushions at each other and when our rotting was at its height who should come in but that old cat Mrs Maugham. Of course there was a sudden lull, and as the room was filled with our cigarettes there was no disguising what we had been doing! however I hope we shocked her well. (Bear in mind Wynne was then 16, so was clearly very fast for her age and period...lucky her to be living with such a relaxed family! - but read on...) We played whist after dinner and went to bed, Yso and I each armed with a glass of claret. When we got upstairs we found we hadn't got a drop of spirit to heat the water for our drinks so we balanced a kettle on the edge of the mantel shelf and put a candle under it!! it took about 3 quarters of an hour to heat and by the time we wanted to get to bed it was fairly hot but it looked too silly sitting up there with pounds of soot on the bottom of it from the candle!!

january.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895.
