She resumes writing it in the middle of this month, prompted by a visit to London

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
July 24th - 27th

Wynne and her father travel to Homburg to take the cure. They pass through London, visiting the Tissot exhibition, before catching the boat train.
viewer_1.description:
I had no idea how soon I should write in this again, for here I am again before a few months have elapsed and now I am just going to put down an outline of my jolly visit abroad with Father beginning on:

July 24th. HOMBURG
We started today by the 10.56 train accompanied by the Babe who went with us as far as Vauxhall where we all got out. The beloved Athlete left by an earlier train for the North. I wonder if we shall ever see him again. I hope so. What would the "Fair Maiden" do otherwise!! On the way up I must say I felt awfully sleepy and disgraced myself by sleeping all the way to Town, but as our dance had been the night before I had only 2½ hours sleep so I think I deserved the rest. We stopped the night at the Norfolk Hotel and did some shopping.

July 25th, Saturday
Went to the city in the morning to see about our tickets and in the afternoon we had a look in at the "Tisotts" pictures of the life of our Lord. They are indeed wonderful. (Wynne here refers to the painter James Tissot. The 1896 exhibition was a huge success, and came on the back of the painter's conversion in 1885, an event greeted with some scepticism by his artist friends).
We left the Hotel at about 6.30 and drove to Liverpool Street Station. We had our dinner at the Hotel and started at 8.30, arriving at Harwich at 10. We were lucky in having a very (good) crossing, but in spite of this advantage I cant say I cared much for it. I had a four berth cabin with two other ladies in it. We reached the Hook by 5.15 where we got into the filthiest train I have ever had the misfortune to be in. The country is very ugly and flat as most of Holland is, at any rate the parts I have been to.

July 26th, Sunday
We passed through Rotterdam today, the canal is very picturesque, such funny old boats, quite broad and flat painted in broad bands of bright colour. The cows of this country are nearly all black and white. I cant think what was the matter with me. I slept nearly all day long from the Hook to Koln. At 9 they brought us some sausage and ham with weak grey coffee for breakfast, ugh! It was beastly. I was nearly sick, but our lunch was very nice and at 5 we reached Frankfort where we changed and came on almost directly reaching Homburg at about 5.45. In our carriage there was such a lovely young officer. I have never seen such a beautiful thing in all my life, but this isn't business and very frivolous into the bargain. Winifred, how could you let yourself stray like this.
We drove to the Hotel Victoria where we got very good rooms but as they are on the street we are going to get them changed.

July 27th
This morning Bogel went to see Dr Hoeber who has given him full instructions as to what he is to do. (Wynne's father was evidently travelling with a cure in mind. As he suffered from Bright's disease, a blanket description for kidney problems, he might well have been treated with baths, diuretics and laxatives). In the morning we strolled into the garden and town which are just the same as ever, the flowers are just too lovely here for anything and so cheap.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 28th - 31st

Spa treatments, music at the Kurhaus, and the company she keeps all get entries...but young men take precedence, and two seem to have attracted her.
viewer_2.description:
July 28th, Tuesday
Wrote several letters in the morning. Hope to hear from (code NW Athlete) soon and also (code: HM Babe). We have all our meals in the Hotel garden. Its pretty and fresh, there is an idiotic parrot here who says all sorts of things including cats and dog noises. I often go and tease it. The family who sit next us at meals look awfully nice, I hope we shall get to know them. I have already named the son (as I imagine him to be) but I shan't put it down, its too dangerous!! We went to the Kurgarten this evening. There is a very good band which played every afternoon and evening. We called on old Mrs Kerwood this afternoon, thank goodness she wasn't in. I believe she is rather decayed. I went in also to see the doctor about my pine baths, and I am to take 6. In the waiting room at the doctor's house there was a poor wretched child with (face) like this….

I wonder what was the matter with it. Doesn't look particularly bright at all events.

July 29th, Wednesday
Went down with Father to the Brunnen at 7.30. (This may refer to the Elisabethenbrunnen, site of the well that the spa water came from. The spa developed in the mid 19th century, but was only officially recognised by the prefix Bad in 1912. Brunnen is the German for well). There is a certain decayed Mr Hollway here, he is a specimen. Father knew him in India and so had to speak to him. He is just like a sat on frog, or worse - to look at. I think his intellect is weak. I had my first pine bath this morning, it was just delicious. and smelt so nice. I have to take them for a quarter of an hour. Yesterday I hired a bicycle for an hour but it was a bit of an ark, with a seat like a rock. I heard from Mother today, all is well at home. They have had torrents of rain like we, as today its been pouring all day long. We have changed rooms three times now and I like our present ones best of all, they are in the chateau. Tonight I went with Father to the Kurhaus to hear a concert, it was lovely. I like this place very much, it is quite close to the mountains and consequently the scenery is very beautiful and there is always lots of music going on everywhere.

July 30th
It simply poured nearly all the morning and only left off for five minutes to give us time to fetch our letters. All the rest of the morning I read and wrote. I am reading an immensely interesting book called " the Slave of the the Lamp" by Seton Merriman. We belong to a library here which is a great thing. Tomorrow I have another pine bath. Went to the Kurhaus again and listened to the band. Saw the "family" there. Father saw my beautiful officer again, of course I nearly had a fit when I heard that I had missed him!! Changed my book for Zoroaster by Marion Crawford.

July 31st
Had pine bath in the morning. Found out the family named is Hurdwood. Mrs Kerwood called to see us, what a funny old muff she is! I went down early this morning to the Brunnen with Father, had my glass of milk as well. There is a female here who has hair just like this of a bright golden hue …

so we call here the hen because it looks as if she has been dust bathing in it!! There are some awful people perfectly putrid and decayed.
Went and had tea at Brahe's, very nice indeed, after which we went to leave cards on the Brigstocks but when we had rung twice and nobody came we took our hook and so got out of it nicely. I spent this evening with the Hurdwoods at the Kurhaus. They are nice people. I walked up and down for a long while with Joe and afterwards a long jaw with old H on archaeology.

july.description: Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895...and a trip to Hombury makes her pick up the pen again.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The first page for March, with some strange illustrations at the top...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 8th

News from the parents returning to England, and some local activities suitable for a Victorian young lady.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Sunday
Since the last dates here we haven't done anything at all exciting so I haven't taken the trouble to write about it. Yesterday we had very good news of the parents who are at present travelling in Italy: Naples, Rome, Florence, Lucerne is their route and to come home by Wiesbaden is their intention I believe so we'll have them home in a week or so I suppose. We heard from them all about the Canal block, it must have been beastly, they were there for 4 or 5 blessed days and it was a German vessel and not a man-of-war that was blocked there. Went to church this morning and it rained the whole time.

March 2nd
On Sat I had a vile chain sent me and this morning I got another, both of which I did. I think I must be turning into an angel. Did nothing particular this day.

March 3rd
Did lessons in the morning and went for walk with the Hightons to Rushton and back. Somehow Ray and I got on ahead I don't know how it happened! but we jawed the whole time and coming back we were caught in a pelting shower of rain which continued until evening. R told me rather a funny story about Mrs Barnet and Den. One day the latter called in and she said to him "Ah sir, I shall be glad when I'm gone" and he answered thinking she said something about the weather "Yes, so shall I"!!! What a fatal mistake.

March 4th, Wednesday
No news by the post whatever for anybody. We asked the Hightons over to tea tomorrow and I had a letter from R saying that they could come, that's about the 100th note I've had from over there and I get so chaffed about it. Bill and I are painting a model together, its such fun and as it poured all day long we had a good long time at it. Its a blue teapot and cup with a fan at the back leaning against a terracotta background.

March 5th
We had lots of news from the "Parients" today. Mother wrote such an interesting letter form Rome and also sent me a post card which I am putting in here because its so pretty. Miss S having gone to Blandford we are having a good long time at our model. I had one of my chairs returned to me this morning which I instantly threw into the fire. The Hightons came to tea this afternoon. When tea was done we played all sorts of games amongst which was fortune telling. This was most amusing. Bill and I make it our business to chaff R who is the most nervous person I know I think but he is so good and takes it so well.

March 6th
----------------------------------------!!!

March 7th
Went to our class this morning after which retired to the dentist where I had a tooth stopped and am going again next Saturday, how I hate him. We took our model to show Miss Coles and she was so nice about them and said ever so many nice things. After the dentist we went to lunch at the Daniels' new house, they have it so nice now, everything is quite new. We had the sad news of poor old Col. Todd's death. He had very severe bronchitis and died on Friday night, poor old man. He only last(ed) a few months after she did. In the afternoon we all went over to the Highton's to tea, we played all sorts of silly games and told fortunes again. I of course got very chaffed, silly old apes they all are.
Last Thursday I had a letter from CWM. He is very well and seems in splendid spirits. (Diary then goes into private code: "he said so many sweet things that I feel quite embarrassed"). It was just 6 weeks since he wrote to us, bad boy.

March 8th, Sunday
Weather simply beastly, very muggy and yet raw. I don't think the parents will like this cold. We heard from Mother this morning from Paris, they will be with us tomorrow evening (D.V.) "RSVP", "I.O.U.", "P.T.O." etc.. hurrah!!
Picture of the household on the return of the:

(Parents are the two birds at the top...followed, right to left, by Miss Scratchley, the governess; Eva, Wynne's elder sister; Ysobel Butler, her cousin; and Wynne. Below them sit the cat and Eleanore, Wynne's grandmother, who appears to merit a much smaller cameo!)

Went to church and Mr Bulloch took the service, he is an awful man, at the second Creed he and the organist had a race with the latter beaten early but it was so ludicrous that in spite of its being the belief I am very much ashamed to say I laughed out loud. I did feel bad, perfectly ill from restrained laughter which wasn't as restrained as it ought to have been. Everything seemed to go wrong this morning. The boy forgot to blow and the organist responded aloud without music and by himself!! He then had the above race, after which Mr Bulloch gave us the driest sermon. In fact one might say the "whilst his sermon is dry his walls were wet"!! Mr H came into tea this afternoon and we talked a long while and I wrote letters all the afternoon, one to The Earl (CWM). This morning I had one from E.A.W who took the chain I sent, good girl, Miss Shaw sent back hers, mean pig! and that's about all I have to say for today, tomorrow will be the day to make entries!

(For CWM, see Love)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The Post Card sent from Italy by Wynne's mother:

Bogel was the family name for Wynne's father. Pita is the cat, pictured by Wynne in her drawing of the family you can see in an adjoining window.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 9th - 19th

The excitement of the parental return is compounded by the decision to order a bicycle for Wynne, a Sunbeam with Dunlop tyres!
viewer_4.description:
March 9th
This being the day of the parents return I have got a good deal to say but first of all I must say that in the afternoon of this day we had been invited to tea at the Pennys but I wrote and said I couldn't come as we did not know what time they would arrive, but today we got a wire to say they would be with us at 7 o'clock so we could have gone after all, but in consequence of my note we didn't but went for a walk instead upon the Rushton road hoping to escape seeing the Pennys. We passed their house in safety and as we were going up the road to Blandford it began to pour and at Down Barn Farm we saw the Daniels driving down the hill (they were going to teas at the Pennys) so to escape them we rushed into the farm on the pretence of getting shelter, but when we came out who should we meet but Amy Daniel who was riding! It was fate! We managed to escape with a long made up story and went on. We got just dripping wet and our hair got all draggled like rats' tails. When we got home we had to change everything so we dressed and at 7 the parents arrived, it was nice having them again. Of course we had loads to say and that very evening M unpacked a lot of things. She brought me two turquoise brooches, one a butterfly which one clips on by his wings and the other a wee frog with a pearl stripe down his back. She also gave me some flowers for a hat and some curiosities for my cabinet among which was a rosary from Father made of eucalyptus wood and a most beautiful old Roman vase from the baths at Carra Calla (sic). Mother has bought herself some lovely old Tuscan peasants jewellery and one or two other things. They gave us all some lovely "Guiandinas" which will not take long to finish I'm thinking, also some eucalyptus liqueur from the Trappists at Rome . (The guiandinas Wynne mentions were probably chocolates - gianduja was a chocolate containing hazelnut paste, and was a well known speciality).

March 10th
Did nothing at all today but listen to the parents news of which they have a lot. I had a letter from Nellie Macnaughton and also from A.R who has at last thought it necessary to write to me, she is at the hospital at present and I jolly well know that it will be some time before I give her the pleasure of an answer.

March 11th, Wednesday
Today there was a very dull post and I didn't get any letters at all. Mother and Bogel went into Blandford to the Presentation of Lord Portman's picture. They say it was very good. This evening they got hold of this diary and made such fun of it, they were very much amused at the portrait of Miss S!

March 12th
Bogel has put me on an allowance now, 10/- a month for my boots and gloves. I like it awfully, its such fun having a little money of one's own. The weather at present is vile and Mater says she is going straight back to Italy and I certainly don't blame her. I forgot to say that yesterday afternoon the Highton's came with us for a walk and also to tea, they all insisted upon having their fortunes told again and are all most amusing about it.

March 19th, Thursday
A week has elapsed since I last wrote this in which nothing particular has happened. Today is Mother's birthday and I gave her a table hussiff made of white and yellow satin, rather neat. To me it was a red letter day. In the morning Bogel, Mater and I went into Blandford and ordered my bicycle!! I am nearly mad with joy. Its a "Sunbeam" with Dunlop tyres, and I am to get it sometime before Easter and until then Conyers is going to let me have one to ride. Its a dark cherry tipped with gold and I am going to have a brass plate put on it with my name and address thereon! I am so longing for it to come and I could go on talking about it for ages. We also had a most delightful afternoon - we all walked up to pick daffodils, and after having gathered a lot we walked back to the dog cart which we had left at Bit Cottage and had our tea, and then walked home. All the way we chaffed R(ay) H(ighton) about his different girls. He is an ape. As if it mattered to us if we know their names or not, still he is in an awful fright about us knowing them, old donkey. Eva was simply yelling all the time at his embarrassment and so were we.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A page containing a sentence in Wynne's code - which you can read translated in the text in the adjoining window.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 20th - 27th

Silver Wedding celebrations and the arrival of the new bicycle. A young woman is liberated by transport!
viewer_6.description:
March 20th, Friday
Bogel's birthday. I gave him a new purse but it poured all day long so we couldn't do anything.

March 21st
Painting class as usual in the morning, and Hightons in the afternoon. We played great games of "Bell and ?" for sweets which was very amusing. Also "Up Jenkins" in a new and very good way.

March 22nd
The Parents Silver Wedding Day. Eve and I got up very early to arrange all their presents. They had 10, our decanters, a match box from Bill, silver bowl from Gran, a sugar sifter from B.G.S., salt cellars from Uncle Walter, menu stands from Mrs Mangles, sugar bowl from Aunt Aimee, and tea caddy from Mrs Burn. Mother gave Bogel a gold watch and he to her a diamond necklace. Quite a collection. The weather was just beautiful in the morning but clouded over rather in the afternoon. A few days ago RH declared he never had a chance of making a face at us in church because we never looked his way, so we told him he wouldn't have to complain of that today. Accordingly we both stared at him the whole service through, and I'm afraid he rather lost his temper over it which of course was of no matter to us as it made it all the funnier. Post has been so dull the last few days, I have't had a letter for ages but as I owe a lot I don't see how I can expect them.

March 23rd
My byke came today. It is a beautiful machine and I am perfectly wild about it and in the afternoon Bill and I went into Blandford and round home by Rushton. We called at the Pennys and had tea there. The ride down from B was just too heavenly and I long to do it again.

March 24th
Bill and I went for a ride up the valley and went and asked the Hightons afterwards to walk with us tomorrow.

March 25th
Mabel Marriott came over today so we couldn't go with the Hightons but go tomorrow.

March 26th
Went over to the Hs to tea and also for a walk with them. We had evening church and that's about all. One thing I do think and that is that RH is one of the most silly donkeys I know and I don't feel in the least inclined to write a diary so I'll jolly well shut up.

March 27th
Did lessons all morning, and cleaned my byke over which I'm more proud than ever.

march.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895.

Her parents return from abroad, and celebrate their Silver Wedding.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
November 18th - December 1st

Wynne's brother Elliot and mother leave for India. Wynne is upset as she knows it means a long absence. She starts hunting.
viewer_1.description:
November 18th, Wednesday
It is scarcely necessary to say that as I write this I am feeling absolutely miserable in consequence of our being up in Town to see Mother and Ell off to India. We started today by the 11 train. Coming up we had great fun, there were two people in the carriage and at intervals Mother and I made the most awful faces at them. I thought the others would have had a fit from laughing. After we arrived we got a cab which had a horse in it just like Puck to look at, only not so fat and strong. We took quite an hour and a half to get from Vauxhall to the Norfolk as the horse was only warranted to go on two legs. All the little boys laughed at us in the streets, however we took no notice whatever. We went to the theatre: "The Belle of Cairo" with May Yohé but didn't care for it much.

November 19th
Rushed off directly after breakfast to Falls in Baker Street to get photoed. I do hope they will be good. Then to the High Street where we had our lunch and did lots of shopping after which we tore to the stores for more shopping . When we got home we had had about enough of it. Soon after the Butlers came. We had a cheerful party in spite of it being our last evening together. We didn't do anything this evening as there was a lot to see to and we went to bed very early.

November 20th, Friday
Got up at 7. I am not going to enlarge upon this morning as it was exceedingly unpleasant. We said goodbye at 8. I am ashamed to say that I gave way to my feelings fairly considerably and we were all very upset to think that I and Father will not see dear old Ell for a whole year is simply too terrible and I am feeling frightfully low. I shall look forward to next year when we hope to join them in India.

November 21st
Rode my bike into Blandford for my painting class and when I got in I found I had left my block at home so I had to paint something else. Practised in the afternoon and did stamps after dinner.

November 22nd
Miss S and I went to church in the morning. When we arrived there wasn't a soul there, we were in despair but afterwards quite a lot came in . We have heard from Mother three times already, once from Dover, Calais and Paris. They are getting on alright.

November 23rd
Bicycled into Blandford - roads vile, all stoney.

November 24th
Drove with Father and Eve returned. It is so nice to have her back again. Heard again from Mother.

November 25th
This morning by the post came the proofs of my photos. They are excellent and I am going to have 7 of each. This is quite a memorial day and I put my hair up today and think its just too beastly for words and I also had my first day's hunting. I did enjoy it and we had quite a nice run. I rode Harlequin.

December, Tuesday 1st
I have been lazy in not writing my diary but nothing of importance has happened. Yesterday we rode up to the kennels to see if the hounds were going out but they didn't as the frost was too hard. I was rather disappointed but we had a nice ride so the day was not altogether lost. I have heard again from the travellers. Marseilles was the last place. We have seen the ship advertised as having reached Port Said, they are getting on fast. I wonder how Ell is getting on with the voyage and how often he has had occasion to call steward. He anticipated that would be his one employment, silly old ape!

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
July 1st - 3rd

Wynne tries to continue the diary, but stops after July 3rd. The next extant diary starts in April 1898 - you can read some of the events in the Love section.
viewer_1.description:
July 1st, Thursday
Spent a most lazy morning in. At 3 drove to the Franks for tennis. There we met a lot of decayed boos. I did nothing but gossip and eat, therefore it wasn't exciting.

July 2nd
Drove into B for shopping in the morning. Father has put me on an allowance now of £36 a year, not so dusty and I like it awfully, it makes one so independent. After lunch we went to the Hughes Gibbs to tennis. It seems so useless my always going as I cant play and I cant say I find it very exciting sitting and watching and talking to such dullards! However it has to be done so what's the good of talking. We met the sweet Castlemans there which was refreshing and I played a dull game of croquet in which I was badly beaten. The cold driving home was just intense.

July 3rd
Leech came out this morning to look at poor old Jim's leg, he says its set beautifully and getting on well. He put a plaster of paris bandage on today and in about a week he will be able to run about with me, little poor beast, its awful hard lines on him.

I am not going to write any more in this diary as I have got a new book with a lock!! so goodbye my precious volume, I shall keep you as long as I possibly can. July 9th, 1897

(The diary Wynne refers to above is lost - perhaps too much incriminating evidence in it of her adolescent loves? The evidence for this is on the last page you can see copied in an adjoining window. So her third diary starts in April 1898, when she included information about Charles Maclean's exploits on the West African campaign - you can read more about that in the Love section.

The Castleman family much mentioned in these pages lived at Chettle. You can still visit their old home).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.description: This is the area Wynne lived in - Brookfield was at Tarrant Keyneston, and she bicycled all over this part of Dorset, thinking nothing of travelling 40 miles for an outing.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The final page in her first diary, which started in 1895 and was finally stopped in . The diary she refers to in her final entry is lost - she may have destroyed it herself if it contained adolescent indiscretions, particularly as the family mercilessly teased her about the diaries. The next diary in the surviving set starts in april 1898.

july.description:
Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895.

The final entries in the first diary.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This painted card dates from September 1831, painted by a Mrs Thomas, was just the sort of thing Wynne liked. It had been given her by an aunt, and she stuck it into the diary, along with an amusing article about keeping diaries, taken from The Idler magazine.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 7th

A quiet week at Brookfield, Tarrant Keynston, dreaming of young men while doing the chores and arranging for a pleasant picnic.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Tuesday
Its been a fearfully wet day today, such a beastly way of beginning my beloved month. To think that I shall be 18 is beyond all comprehension!!! I half expected to hear from Sonny but had no letters, better luck tomorrow I hope. I drove into Blandford and saw a good many people but it was not at all exciting. I do hope young Osborne will come and stay here this summer, I would give anything to see him once more.

(Italicised words are in code in the diary, an example of which you can see via this link. However the code did not confuse her Mother. The real object of Wynne's affections was Charles Maclean, whom she named "the Earl", which you can read about in the special Love section, but there were clearly others under consideration).

June 2nd
I must just quote a little incident that occurred to us on our return journey from Sandhurst last Saturday. As we got into the train Sonny said "Why look here is a busby case, who does it belong to, 'Macallister MaGregor' " and on looking up he saw the only man sitting in the corner of our carriage! (having known him previously). Well I looked at him of course and saw that he was exceedingly "lovely" to look at and as he stared out of the window all the time I had the opportunity to glare at him for at least six miles, he was beautiful, just too mic (?) looking for words and now Mother chaffs me all day long about him. I'm sure if he knew he ought to be flattered! Mother has gone to Chettle to go with them to Salisbury. Oh! how I wish I were with her but that's naughty because Bogel (her father) would then be alone, but better luck next time. This evening is lovely and I am afraid I am being foolish enough to be a little melancholy and the only thing that cheers me up is the thought of the Earl's return home.

June 3rd
Weather just beautiful. Read my task and wrote letters in the morning and did stamps and gardened all the afternoon, so you see I have had a regular "rural" day. Hebditch has done nearly all the planting out now and the place looks so clean and tidy. We had a wire from Mum to say that she wouldn't be home till tomorrow but I hope she will come then as I believe Mr Clarke is to appear and as I don't know him in the least it would be slightly awkward. I wrote a letter to C.W.M. this afternoon and addressed it to Southampton hoping it will reach him in safety but I have my doubts. (CWM is Charles Maclean, aka the Earl).
Mother returned today but Mr Clarke is not to be here until Monday. We drove into Blandford, such a rare occurrence I have to put it down.

June 5th
Drove again to B or rather cycled, did pounds of shopping. I have got myself an old woman sun bonnet, its just sweet, I also got some pink print which I am going to have made up by Mrs Jennings who does them very neatly for the maids. The "uninteresting, stodgy, doughy but good natured under done bun" came over this afternoon. We generally see him on Saturdays.

June 6th, Sunday
Its a lovely day and a little cooler than yesterday. I got no letters this morning and as I am writing this before breakfast there is not much to say, but I must depart now as its prayer time.
(Later) I think there is nothing more to add here as nobody called and we only went to church as usual.

June 7th
Today both the Mater and I went and got up early as she had all the butter to make and I the flowers to do. The butter took over three hours to do, the flowers not so long. Directly after lunch Mother set off to meet Mr Clark arriving back with him at about 3.30. I shall here describe him - he is middle height, fair, and a little stout, that's to say not thin!! Very pleasant in manner but not very good looking and I'm afraid in connection with a little certain "affair d'amour" that I think him a fool for his pains as I count him 40 times too good for her, she being a foolish little minx while he is a regular good sort. At 4 we started for Badbury Rings where we took our tea and where we were met by the under-done-bun who appeared with a huge cake as a contribution to our tea. When we had unpacked everything, to our horror we found that "husk" of a maid had gone and forgotten the teapot and tea! did you ever hear of such rot. That wretched *** had to traipse down down on my machine to fetch them, at least he offered to and wouldn't let me go, I could have beaten that goat of a girl, however we had great fun and at about 6.30 we went home again.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
This faded (and fading) photo is of a school XI - Woodcote. It was taken around 1889 or 1890, and Wynne knew a lot of them.

On the back of the photo is written
Mr Hayter (centre back)

Richardson, Fraser, Holland, x, Grimston, Walton, Hooper

Keen, Neville, Vibart, Baddeley.

Soon this photo will fade further, and these images will be lost - what happened to them all I wonder, and how many survived the war?

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 8th - 12th

Her family tease Wynne about the Diary, and her Mother makes a wicked entry in it. No wonder Wynne used code!
viewer_4.description:
June 8th, Tuesday
This morning while Mr Clarke and Mother drove to Blandford I read my task and at 1.30 the Todds turned up to lunch.

June 9th
We drove to Blandford and whilst there we got caught in a deluge of rain and had to stop there until 1.0. All afternoon it continued to pour and this being the chief event of the day there is consequently not much to put in here.

June 10th, Thursday
This morning to my great surprise Father read out of the Globe Charles' arrival at Southampton so I suppose we shall see something of him soon (D.V.)

(Then in another hand,which I am sure is her Mother's, is added )
I wonder if he is still as handsome as he was and will love me just as hard. Darling Charlie, how my heart beats thump thump when I think of him. If he only knew that I am not at all particular who I kiss if only I may kiss someone, how wild he would be. I am rather like the young lady in the following rhyme:
"There was a young man who said 'miss'
I must and I shall have a kiss
I see no harm in it and it wont take a minute
And will give me such infinite bliss.

The young lady replied to him 'sir'
There's another young man I prefer
But since you do press it and no one will guess it
Why, let us no longer defer."

(Given what happened later, this might seem rather odd, since it reads rather like encouragement to me, but clearly was not meant to be. The family was given to much teasing, and perhaps it was thought this invasion of the diary, and the tease involved, might prove a deterrent? Who knows.)
Wynne continued;
I here beg to state that I did not write this owlish and silly entry, also that there is absolutely no sense or truth in it, but I hope this last statement is not necessary!

June 11th, Friday
This was the first day of our tennis tournament and the weather brilliant, heat appalling, but tempers in general good. A lot of people came and they played hard. I was weirdly busy doing flowers etc…

June 12th
We continued the tournament today and Mrs Burn came in the morning and her son the great James in the afternoon. He is immensely tall and feels altogether exactly like his father beyond that I shall say no more of him as he interests me not. We had enough time to finish the tournament, and having had another fine day it turned out quite successfully. We had the most extraordinary dinner of which I can scarcely give a detailed account, but one awfully funny thing happened. Mother told the maids to bring in a small quantity of ice for the whisky so in it came and we all invested largely in it. What was our dismay to see our drinks turn rather a weird soapy colour and on investigating the matter we found the fools had brought in washing soda instead of ice!! All the guests thought it was a practical joke of Mother's but she was naturally furious.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 13th - 20th

The build up to the Diamond Jubilee celebrations include a garden tea for the village children. Wynne is 18.
viewer_6.description:
June 13th, Sunday
This is the laziest Sunday I have ever spent, the weather is just boiling. We went to church en masse and were nearly choked with the heat. I wrote most of the afternoon whilst the others slept on the grass. I have written to CWM who is by the way at Woolwich to know if he cannot come with us on the 21st night to a theatre. I do hope he will be able to come but I doubt if he will be able to get leave on the night before the Procession. (Wynne is here referring to the Diamond Jubilee).

June 14th, Monday
We got our first honey from the bees today, such lovely honey and so nice and clean looking, it is so nice having ones own, I find.

June 15th
This is my 18th birthday, dear me how old I am getting!! Soon shall have to sprout grey hairs and wrinkles. Mother gave me the Jungle Books and a lovely moonstone necklace, Father 7 pairs of gloves and two ebony brushes with silver monogram, Gran a powder box of ebony and silver and I also got a muff made of an albatross skin from Ray, two silver trinkets from Harry and Rachel besides numerous letters and cards etc. We are going over to play tennis this afternoon at Chettle, I do hope it will keep fine. I took another 1lb of honey from the hive this morning.

June 16th
Mr Clarke left today. Mother says she could not stand him another day.

June 17th
Today we had rather fun. We gave a tea at the Golf House to all Players and friends. All the morning we were busy cutting bread and butter and jam sandwiches and making cakes. At 3.30 we started off each armed with a cream jug and when we arrived we spread out the clothes and each had a tea pot from which we poured weird contents to anyone who felt thus inclined. When everybody had stuffed enough we packed up our goods and chattels and returned.

Friday - lazy day, did nothing

June 19th, Saturday
Drove into Blandford and did a lot of shopping, and also went to see poor little Jumbo (a dog?), who, I don't know if I mentioned it, broke his leg the other day in the dog cart step. it was awful but we took him into Keech and had it set alright. I went in to see him and he was just wild with delight. I met Brother Edward there and tried to persuade him to come home with us but he would not. In the afternoon we had all the village children here and gave them a tea, presenting each child with a Jubilee mug. The boys played rounders with which they were delighted, and close on 7 o'clock they departed.

June 20th, Sunday
This morning we had a grand Jubilee service, sang special humans and "God Save the Queen", had special prayers and sermon etc…the singing went well and there were a good many people in church. Ate too much luncheon and consequently felt exceedingly stodged, however lets hope it will pass over!!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne found this "so neat"

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 21st - 23rd

London. Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee. Wynne goes up to watch the great parade, and to meet Charles.
viewer_8.description:
June 21st
This is really Friday, but the last few days we have been up in London Jubelizing, and what a time I've had. I thought I would leave these 4 days diary until now so here goes…we went by the 10.56 and met Rachel at the station, also the Hughes Gibbs with whom we travelled up as they had reserved a carriage. This we found rather nice as the train was very full. When we arrived Rachel very sweetly took our luggage to the Norfolk as she lives quite close there and Mother and I went off on different business. We then returned to dress for dinner as we were to dine at the Cafe Royal with Poppet and CWM. We started at a quarter to six and arrived there at 7, the crush was so fearful we could scarcely get along. Charlie was looking more beautiful than ever but not very well and so thin, however down at home we will fatten him up well! We enjoyed an excellent dinner and afterwards walked over to La Poupee which I cannot say I found so funny as before. (Operetta by Edmond Audran, which ran very successfully in London in an English translation)
Harry insisted on our coming to his Club and having drinks which we did accordingly, Mother and HC in one hansom and I and CWM in another. As far as he was concerned I think he enjoyed himself immensely but I cannot say that drive amused me as I was the whole time trying to make him see reason which is needless to say he wont. We arrived home at 10 minute to 1 having had a regular spree.

June 22nd, Jubilee Day.
(Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee)
Today at 5.30 we arose from our downeys in order to arrive in time at our seats after a hurried breakfast consisting of a cup of coffee. We tore off with Alice, Rachel and Harry in a bus to Piccadilly- having ridden as far as possible we got off and walked to our seats in crowded and broiling streets which all looked lovely being hung with flags and decorated up to the roofs, the Baroness Burdett-Cootes house being among the finest was all hung with purple and gold. St James Street was wreaths all over and our house in Pall Mall was beautifully decorated with white and mauve orchids and ferns, it was just too beautiful for words.
We arrived before 8 and had to wait until eleven. I cannot describe it properly and exactly because I've forgotten how they all came but I know our street was lined with the Manchesters and in the procession first came hundreds of soldiers Colonial and English, next all aide-de-camps, equerries etc and then the Royal carriages with all foreign representatives, the Royal family and lastly the Queen - in her carriage was the Empress Frederick and the dear Princess of Wales who as usual was looking sweet, the queen looked very well and the cheers were simply dense as she drove along, people went nearly mad with excitement and the street was a perfect sight with waving hats and handkerchiefs. The Prince of Wales, Duke of Cambridge and Duke of Connaught rode beside her and her carriage was drawn by five or six pairs of horses almost buried in gold trappings and led by men in most gorgeous livery. When it was once started it didn't take long and the whole show was past us soon after 12 o'clock. I am indeed glad I saw it, as of course none of the present generation will ever see such a sight again.
I must not forget to add that we (Rachel and I) had an excellent lunch and made the acquaintance of a most charming young man who was most attentive to us and came and sat with us after it was over and talked for quite a long time. He was nice looking, fair, and tall and said he lived in Blackheath. I wonder if he knows the Wilkinsons and if we shall ever see him again!
As soon as it was possible to move we all went to the park for a while, and at 4 we started to tea at the Oriental club when after awhile we were joined by the Butlers, Uncle Walter, (and others). When we had eaten and stuffed as much as possible we strolled down Bond Street and each took our different ways.

June 23rd, Wednesday
So having done my duty in describing yesterday I must begin on this early before breakfast. Mother left for Plymouth and I by my little own self sat me down to wait for the Castlemans who were coming to fetch me for the Academy. Accordingly they arrived three strong including Jack Moon who is such an amusing fellow. The Academy was a sight to see and I don't know who laughed so much as I did over "Loves Baubles", a more grotesque production I have never yet seen. We all had convulsions and behaved so badly, however rotten show as it is I am glad I went and mean to go again when I am up for Lords. (Wynne is referring to a painting by John Byam Liston Shaw, known as Byam Shaw. Apparently mirth greeted some of his other work, some of which appears to be lost).
When I returned I found the beautiful Charles awaiting me and we had lunch together after which he took me down to the New Gallery which is on the whole better than the Academy I think. Poor Owl isn't in the best of spirits I fear and every time I say anything I seem to put my foot in it. I hope he is not going to be depressed because of a certain affair as that would be foolish in the last extreme. In the evening as I was sitting reading my weird and beastly task (this appears to be the sole educational element of her life at that time), when all of a sudden I heard a voice say "come out into Onslow Gardens" and looking up saw R and Mr Moon, so out I went and we sat out for over an hour smoking and shrieking. The illuminations were lovely all round and I suppose in the city they must have been exquisite.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
This is the diary open at the entry about the tattoo, that you can read in the next window...clearly Wynne did not travel First Class!

This first diary was quite small. After this Wynne graduated to a larger format, and continued with those for the rest of her life. Below is the first of the new ones, which she started in 1898.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
June 24th - 30th

Back to the diurnal domestic round...though a picnic at Badbury Rings enlivens life up a little.
viewer_10.description:
June 24th, Thursday
Alas the day has come for returning and I packed up my goods and chattels with a heavy heart for I dearly love the gay village. We met Uncle Walter at the station and travelled down very comfortably. At Salisbury a young sailor fellow got in. To my chagrin he drew out a weird and evil smelling cutty (a short pipe) and began performances by spitting on the floor repeatedly which wasn't quite so pretty as it might have been perhaps but to our relief he soon stopped that and amused me immensely when on pulling up his sleeve he exhibited to our gaze an arm on which was tattooed this:

 

I laughed immoderately. We met Mother at Templecombe and arrived home safely.

June 25th
Did nothing in particular

June 26th
A day similar to yesterday with the slight variation of a thunderstorm.

June 27th
Went to Church which was very long this morning. Did nothing all day but read.

June 28th
Mother and I drove into Blandford this morning and I think it poured without ceasing the whole time and when we had got thoroughly soaked we returned.

June 29th
This morning I had quite an exciting post, letters from Ray, CWM, Con and N Ll. I was extremely thankful for the second as I was most anxiously awaiting it. Felt very cheap all the morning and so did nothing but I cannot say I did much more in the afternoon although I was better!

June 30th, Wednesday
We were going to Badbury Rings and take our lunch and tea today but it is too wet. I am so disgusted as I was looking forward to it fearfully and had anticipated tremendous high jinks, however it cant be helped. Disastrous indigo news this morning, hang it, but the less said about it the better so I wont enlarge. The C's arrived and to our great delight we went to B after all and a more amusing afternoon I have never yet experienced. We went 6 strong. Arriving there about 4 we hastened to tie up the horses and make the tea, unpacking all the things. We made the men heat the kettle and all the way through tea that goat Seamus (one of the horses) would keep rubbing his collar, consequently Harry had to jump up 40 times to stop him. As soon as we had finished those wretches Mother and Harry walked away and left us to put all the things away and look after the horses, so thought we this is not to be borne and as soon as we had put our tea things away Rachel and I started off to claw in the others leaving Mary and Haskins in charge of the horses. We found the culprits seated on the top of the furthest ridge right away on the horizon! so we yelled and shrieked for them to come and play games, then when we had got them fairly home we and the other two shrunk off, depositing the victims in our place with the horses. Now I call that very neat and R and I went and took their nice seeing seats. But we have sworn that never again will we go for picnics unless each is armed with a separate young man to play about with.

Wynne started keeping her diary in November 1895.

The month of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee - apogee of Empire.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt:
May 14th - 20th

Wynne has another try at keeping the diary - friends visit, and an invitation to the Sandhurst Ball arrives from a friend - Sonny Wilkinson.
viewer_1.description:
1897

May 14th, Friday
I see my last diary failed, I suppose my ideas ran dry so I am going to do my best to write one during the greater part of this summer. To begin with today that weird Mrs Burn and Rita are coming to stay. I don't know how long. Father has gone to meet them. This morning I had a letter from the Rikki who is quite penitent now I am glad to say, surely he wanted a good hiding!! I have also heard lately from the beloved C.W.M. who will very probably be home in the end of July and then what joy!! I hope soon to hear from him again. I get a letter every three weeks generally.

May 15th
Spent a most idle morning pottering about and doing nothing. In the afternoon Amie and Dukey came, both looking flourishing, also Mrs Penny and Bessie called and Mrs Williams with her eldest son, the curate. As I have called the younger one the under done bun, this one is to be the over done one. He is very weird to look at, most decayed I think, and his eyes are just like two currants. He is very bald and his head is this shape

They brought us four sweet fantail pigeons and we have made a house for them in the cedar tree where they look simply sweet. I finished my reading in the evening - I am wading through Frederick the Great now, its not so interesting as Motley by half.

May 16th, Sunday
Lovely morning all going to Church! I am very delighted at present because I have lately received from Sonny Wilkinson an invitation to the Sandhurst Ball and we are going! I am just longing for it, my dress is white satin trimmed with sequins and white roses. I lazed all this afternoon reading "Phroso", a recent book of Anthony Hope's, and as far as I have got it is awfully nice, let's hope it will end well. They have all gone for a walk so I have a moment's peace. Nobody called this afternoon thank goodness. We thought that perhaps the Gen might be in. I am a perfect martyr to the midges at present. I sat under the chestnut tree last evening talking to old Deb and got my

May 17th
Rachel and Harry came over today to settle about our Warder Castle picnic and we have made up our minds to go on Tuesday next. I do hope it will be fine as we have had to put it off so often before. They also want us to go to Salisbury with them on the 3rd of June to a large singing festival in the Cathedral. I wonder if we shall. We are to drive there and back and sleep the night with them. They stayed with us to dinner and afterwards Harry sang us lots of sweet songs which I always enjoy. He is such a dear thing and I get more fond of him everyday.

May 18th
The weather is glorious and this morning I rode up to Rushton with the Englishman and sometimes the wind nearly blew me off. Did nothing but wrote letter all afternoon. Have finished Frederick the Great. Am going to begin a Short History of England by Cyril Ransome, M.A.

May 19th
Mrs Burn left by the early train but Rita is staying till Monday. I got no letters this morning, therefore I am very cross.

May 20th, Thursday
I forgot to say that yesterday Mrs C(astleman) and Rachel came over to see us, biking, and today they invited us to go over to tea so Mother and I biked and they drove. We found them all flourishing. We started home at a quarter to 7 and Harry, Rachel and Miss Montgomery came part of the way back and to our intense horror I had a perfect pancake puncture. Rachel very sweetly lent us hers and took back mine but her machine was so fearfully heavy I could scarcely move it, consequently on getting home at last I was nearly dead.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 21st - 25th

Long expeditions are undertaken with her friends from Chettle. The bee man augments the hives, and a visit is made to Bournemouth.
viewer_2.description:
May 21st, Friday
We had a very long day today at Bournemouth. We met HC (Harry Castleman) at the station and as soon as we arrived I rushed off to the dentist where I sat having teeth stopped for a whole hour and a half. He did hurt and I was thankful when he had finished and I was free to go. We had our lunch at the Bungalow, after which I went to the hair-dresser and had my hair cham-pooed (sic). I then joined them on the Pier where we sat until it was time to catch our train. My teeth by this time were simply ramping.

May 22nd
I am to have my Sandhurst dress fitted on I believe today. Weather is still just too glorious.

May 23rd
We were let off easy today in church as

was not feeling very fit. We had no sermon but litany and communion instead. Went in to feed the dear horses after church. They know me so well now, especially the youngest carriage horse. (I think the above must be a caricature of Mr Highton, the Vicar. He was not liked, and on his death his son pushed into the church where the women were doing the flowers to announce "the old devil is dead!")

May 24th, Monday
This wasn't a very eventful day. All afternoon I sewed at my fronts, and Alsford the bee man came bringing with him a swarm for us. He also tried to get the one out of the blue room but failed, after having torn half the (timber?) wall down. He's coming again tomorrow to get another out of the apple tree so we shall be quite rich in bees.

May 25th
Today we had an exciting day. We started cycling at 8 o'clock and went to breakfast with the Castlemans, after which we strapped our lunch on different bikes and rode to Warder Castle (I think Wynne means Old Wardour Castle, Tisbury, in Wiltshire). Harry, Alice, Giddy Montgomery, Mother and I. Only when we had gone for about 3 miles GM declared it was too much for her and returned. Well, we got to Warder at about 1.15, had our lunch, after which we three strolled around and Alice sat down to do some sketching. About a quarter of an hour after, the rain began to come down and very soon it simply poured, unfortunately catching us separated. I was hunting in a vault and Mother and Harry in the caves, so there I sat quite alone for a whole blessed beastly hour, smoking a cig and eating a "muff"!! When it cleared we were able to make it homewards, Harry and I coasted nearly the whole of Win Green to Chettle, it was lovely. They wanted us to go to the Karma Tree but we virtuously refused and hurried home to dinner. We did just about 39 miles.

May 26th
Went to Blandford and did a lot of shopping. Called to see how General Deane was, he is much better.

May 27th
We had rather fun this day. The Casltemans slept last night with us and early this morning we biked to Spetisbury taking the train to Winchester. As it was Southampton fair day the trains were crammed full and we arrived ever so late. I must explain that we were on our way to lunch with the under done bun and he was to have met us but as we were so late he gave it up in despair and left so we had to find the best of our way to his farm. When we arrived we had an excellent lunch for which we were all simply longing. He presented us all with squirrels' tails which we put into our hats. After lunch we inspected the farm and then at about 3.30 we set off riding to Southampton. Its just 15 miles and the roads are just perfect. We trained from S to Wimborne and then rode home doing in all close on 30 miles. The C's stayed the night with us but we all felt too tired to romp at all!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.excerpt:
May 28th

The Sandhurst Ball

This is Wynne's formal coming out, and she is very excited about it.
viewer_3.description:
May 28th, Friday
I was in a terrible state of excitement this day as it was one of the most eventful ones of my life!! Namely my coming out day and I am going to give a long and detailed account of it so that there will not be the slightest chance of my forgetting the smallest event of the day or evening. To begin with Father drove us to meet the 12.42 train which we caught in good time having to change at Templecombe and Woking. Already at the latter station the train was beginning to fill with smartly dressed girls bound for Sandhurst. We very nearly did an awfully stupid thing, we had to get our box labelled to Woking as they wouldn't book it farther. Well at this station we quietly got into the train, forgetting all about relabelling our box and only just thought about it in time to get it seen to. Imagine our feelings if we had left it behind!! Well we found Sonny awaiting us at Camberley and having procured a bus we drove off to the College to have tea with Sonny in his rooms. Then we met a man who he had invited up from Brighton (to meet us) and I may as well say at once that he was the most charming person it has lately been my lot to meet. Rather short but exceedingly good to look at, dark brown hair and eyes, straight nose and very much burnt by the sun, not his nose in particular I don't mean!!! but his face altogether. His name was Osborne and I shall count it my fortune if I ever happen to meet him again which I sincerely hope I shall. Tea in Sonny's rooms was great fun, the kettle refused to boil and by way of finding out if it was hot or not he used to put his finger in the kettle! After tea we walked down to our rooms at Blackwater, dressed, and had dinner at our leisure after which we drove at 9 o'clock to the Gym were the dance was being held. We arrived in good time as it began at 9.30. Sonny and Mr Osborne soon arrived and we began making out our dances. Sonny did his duty like a man and introduced 10 men altogether in consequence of which I danced every single dance, the first of which was taken up with introductions! I am going to put down the names of the men I know and see if in a few years time I shall remember any of them. The band, supper and floor were perfect and the rooms were very prettily decorated. I cannot write enough about the enjoyment of the thing. It all went so quickly that it was gone before one realised anything about it. There are also lots of things I should like to put down about it but as I don't think it would be quite the thing I must trust my memory serving me as well as this would. My dress did awfully well but I got my shoes quite black. We finished at 3.30 which was rather early I think.
Dances:
1. Mr Osborne
2. Mr Pike
3. Mr Lucas
4. Mr Hughes
5. Mr Fraser
6. Mr Ridgeway
7. Mr O'Donnel
8. Mr Graham
9. Mr Keen
10.Sonny!

I wonder how many survived the war - many of Wynne's friends from childhood and early marriage did not - Sonny included. See February 13th, 1915.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 29th - 31st

After all the excitement, life feels a little dull, but the approach of the Jubilee and the return of Charles Maclean make life more interesting.
viewer_4.description:
May 29th
Got up at 7.30, had breakfast, and at 10 young Osborne called for us to drive up to see the Parade. It was an awfully pretty sight. When it was over Sonny and Mr Grayham found us and we went round seeing all the different men's rooms etc, also the Chapel is awfully nice. At last the time of my departure arrived alas! I felt fearfully dumpy as I said goodbye to Mr Osborne on the steps for who knows if we shall ever see him again. I cant say I think he seemed to mind much but of course I cant tell. We have asked him down to Brookfield but its 9 chances to 10 he wont come. Of our return journey I have nothing interesting to say. I slept nearly all the way being rather dead and feeling beastly dull. At Camberley station I met Mrs Kennedy looking awfully well and also Mrs Campbell. Oh why is it all over, I have got the "morning blues" awfully badly today. Of course its awfully silly but perhaps when I get a bit older I shan't be quite such an ass. Bogel met us at the station and it seems just as if we had been away for years. Well, no, lets say weeks or months!!

May 30th, Sunday
Went to church and had a very dull and long sermon and actually found myself several times thinking of Sandhurst!! A few days ago to my great joy I had a letter from C.W.M. saying he would be home in less than a month having been chosen to take command of several picked men of his regiment who are to walk in the Procession (for Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee) and he is to have leave till Sept, after which he goes to the Coast so now it wont be long before we see the precious boy. I wish now I was going up for the Jubilee but no seats can be had and we don't see the force of going in the crowd.

May 31st, Saturday
Still feeling weirdly dull, did the flowers and wrote most of the morning. Cissy came over in the morning, her new expression is "My dear Winnie" and she uses it on every possible occasion so I am trying my very best to cure her of it. The Gen and Mrs Denne called this afternoon, he poor man is laid up with a bad leg. that's to say he cant walk much. I took my dear little Jumbo for a stroll this afternoon in upper Townsend field. I see the hay is coming on nicely there and with this frequent rain we ought I think to have a decent crop

After a pause, the diary is picked up again to record bicycle expeditions and a great Ball.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1902

Wynne is living in Woolwich, in army quarters. 
            Her husband is a Major in the Royal Horse Artillery.
            It is conveniently close to London, so that she can indulge herself 
            with visits to "Town", but there is also plenty going on 
            at home. She is worried about the family finances.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st
April Fool's Day! but this is not a place for tricks of this sort I fancy. Wrote letters most of the morning but didn't go down to the Town with the others, who made an expedition to an old curiousity shop...I have been reading Stephen Phillips' last work, "Ulysses" and am now anxious to see it given at Her Majesty's by Tree. I believe it is wonderfully staged, and hear that 30,000 yards of black velvet were used for the scene in Hades! I like the piece immensely as a poem. I am also longing to see "Paolo and Francesca" at St James by Alexander. (Stephen Phillips was an actor and poet who determined to revive poetic drama. Both Paolo and Ulysses were performed in 1902, to considerable acclaim, but his later plays failed and he died in 1915. Christopher Fry continued the tradition, and in the latter part of the 20th century, the remarkable reworking of the Mysteries and the Oresteia by Tony Harrison for the National Theatre showed how powerful the technique could be).

April 5th, Saturday
The market here is a perfect sight on Saturdays. I went down this morning to buy flowers for my drawing room and really the choice was so great that I hardly knew what to choose....I bought 1/5d worth and filled my room to overflowing! (One shilling and fivepence translated into modern coinage would be about 7p...though of course it would have been worth a lot more then).

April 6th
We went as usual to the Garrison Church...officers and their wives sit in front, unmarried officers in a secluded corner to themselves, and all the men behind, the services are short and brisk and god Save the King is always sung at the end, all and everyone looks gorgeous in their Sunday kit and after service ladies have the opportunity of peacocking about at Church Parade, whilst the soldiers march past and the band plays gay tunes.

April 8th, Tuesday
By the 10.18 we rushed off to Town today (London), Poggy on dentist's business and I on doctor's. This was my last visit to Mr Lennox Browne. I must say it has been worth the £4.4.0 (ie: four guineas, most professionals charging in that manner. It shows what a terrifyingly expensive business it was if you fell ill). On leaving he said "if at any time you feel your throat again just come in and have a talk to me, and dont make it a professional visit. I know that military people often aren't Croesuses".

(The month continued with much calling on neighbours, often in the hope that they would be out and you could then leave a card and cross them off the list..."I took the opportunity and 'called', luckiily finding no one one at home"...

Wynne seems to have filled her days, when not looking after the house, with all manner of social engagements too, ranging from concerts to flower shows to visits to various army mess halls. There was also ping-pong, and other games at neighbours..."This afternoon I went up to the Bainbridges and played mad and wild games with a lot of other enterprizing people - rounders and "tip and run", till I all but died of heat and exhaustion. It was great fun"...
It was an immensely social life, with very little time spent by oneself at home. Even the evening meal was often taken in company, and the couple seem constantly to be running home to change for dinner at some neighbours.)

April 20th
I am hoping so much that tomorrow will bring satisfactory news from India. Our financial affairs as far as Bank dividends seem to go are nil since last October and it is so very awkward having this long delay, more so for poor old Eve than even us. (Clearly the financial affairs of Wynne's mother had still not been sorted out - one of the reason why the family had decamped to a smaller house in Witchampton, called The Hive. This was a legacy left from the death of Wynne's father in 1898 - you can read about that in the Love section).

The diary breaks off on the 23rd, with a note in May: "During the last week of April I had really too much to do to find time for my diary." But there was time of visits, and a dance at the Mess where Wynne seems to have had fun: "I had quite a jolly evening - danced all but two for which I felt a brute when our guests were not always dancing."

It clearly did not stop her though!

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
was the year of Edward VII's coronation. Wynne didn't stick any memorabilia into her 1902 diary, but nine years later, she was writing about the next coronation - of George V.

On this occasion, there seems to have been two separate days - one for the coronation itself, which Wynne did not bother to go to London to see, and one for a march past including the royal couple, which she did go up for on the following day. She also managed to get onto a warship to see the review at Spithead, and that must have been a truly extraordinary sight - probably one of the last great demonstrations of naval power. Her entry for 1911 is below...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1902

Wynne attends the Coronation of King Edward VII, travelling up to Town to watch the Procession.
viewer_2.description:
August has come and gone, a month of rain, wind and dull weather. Sept. has been prophisied (sic) to bring us very hot weather but I write this on the second and certainly so far it has shown no signs of arriving. I am utterly disgusted with our vile summer, a few days in June were indeed so boiling that we all nearly expired and that may be said to have been all the summer we have had.
The Coronation came off this month all right and H and I went up for it. The rain kept off which was a blessing as for such an event fine weather is essential. We started at 7.30 and got to our seats in Pall Mall quite comfortably without any undue crush. On arriving we had refreshments and watched the crowd until 12.0 when we had lunch for which I was more than thankful. The Procession didn't pass until 2.0 so I was rather thankful when it was all over. We had a splendid view of everything and saw the King and Queen quite close. After all had passed we repaired to the United Services Club with some people called Beckett with whom we had tea. This was at 3.30 and at this unearthly hour there were lots of poor unfortunates there having lunch! I can't think how they managed to do without food until so late, I should have died!
We have been plunging this month and invested in a cob and cart, both to my mind are eminently successful. The animal is a mare, about14.3, bright bay with black points, very splendid action and sound in wind and limb. She is a dear, so gentle and good, and I am trying to get her to eat out of my hands but nothing will induce her to take anything except from the manger.
Gran came on the 21st, the day before the visit of the Shah to Woolwich. On that day there was a large Review, all Artillery, and the whole place was in an uproar...Gran was immensely amused, I think she has "scarlet fever" worse than any of us!

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The front page of Wynne's 1901 and diary. The address is that of her Mother's house, since the book was begun before her marriage...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1902

Wynne continues her life in Woolwich, with duty visits and Badminton, before going to her Mother's home at Christmas to await the birth of her first child
viewer_2.description:
December 1st
Mrs Usborne left us today, in such horrid black depressing weather, and I spent the morning in writing 550 dull letters for which job I did not feel in the least inclined. In the afternoon although it was so fearfully wet and unpleasant we went to the Badminton Club, where we met Mrs Hutch, Mrs Cogan, the Farmers, Pauls etc and of course "Col" Annersley was there in great form, shrieking, shouting, gesticulating over her violent efforts to get the ball over the net. We were playing Ping Pong up above but could scarcely play on account of having to rush and look over the side 50 times during the game to watch Mrs A when a fresh outburst of laughter announced her wild antics. I wish Capt Fatty were here to play with her! banish the thought! he is far too sweet to be coupled in any capacity with so vulgar a toad.

December 2nd
Having one or two more Depot women to make the acquaintance of I sallied forth this afternoon upon this arduous task, for arduous I find it as they live such miles away and so far apart. I visited two today only, Mrs Richards and Mrs Marsh, both Sergts. wives and most superior ladies! I found Mrs Marsh occupied in making a ball dress of white silk and lace which she was to wear that night at the annual Sergeants Ball. She is a bride and a very pretty one too, but white silk! odds bodkins! when does she ever intend to wear it again?

December 3rd
The morning was spent in scratching mail letters as hard as I could, this is the Xmas Mail for India and consequently I have a good many to send.

Wynne busied herself with preparations for departure. Now nearing the end of her pregnancy, she was going down to her Mother in Dorset to spend Christmas and to have the baby. She attended some of the local concerts, did her shopping, showed her friends the collection of baby clothes she had amassed and finally set off on the 16th, laden with presents and lots of library books. There she promptly caught a cold and was sent to bed.

December 28th
A week has passed and Christmas is once more over. I have not written anything day by day since yesterday week but then I think I have sufficient excuse. It has all been very jolly, our party consists of the Butlers and our selves.
We went to church of course on the morning of the 25th after having distributed our presents, spent the afternoon labeling the toys for the childrens Xmas tree, which is to take place on Tuesday, and had our own tree in the evening. We had a most festive dinner drinking the healths of many absent friends and finished our dinner by passing round a loving cup, viz: one of the German glasses.

Wynne concluded her year with some quotes from a book dated about 1600, entitled "How to become Wealthy" which seems to have contained more information about health than wealth. Here are two quotes:
"For sore eyes in humans"
Take red snayles and seeth them in faire water and then gather the oyle that ariseth thereof and therewith annoynt your eyes morning and evening.
"To make the haire grow"
Take treacle, water and honey and boyle them together and wet a clothe therein and lay it where you would have the haire grow and it will come speedily.

At the back of the diary she stuck in some of her Christmas cards - you can see a few of them in the Christmas section, and in the panel here.
On January 12th Wynne gave birth to a son, Thomas Herbert Elliot, or as she put it, "THE" Jackson!
In March 1903 she wrote:" I cannot see a likeness to either of us yet, but he has "pink" hair in which he favours us both! and such lovely blue eyes."
Poor boy, he was forever after to be known as Pink.
Wynne's second child, a daughter, was born in 1904, followed by another daughter in 1908. You can read about them in the Family section.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Below are some of the Christmas cards that Wynne stuck into the end of her diary for this year...

And one from her ex-governess...Miss Scratchley

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1902

The month entire Wynne is living at Woolwich, London, in army quarters.

The weather is horrible, and she has to struggle to get the Depot Christmas tree organised for all the army kids.
viewer_2.description:
Sunday 2nd
Thank goodness January is over, and now I long for the 28 days of this disgusting month to pass away, the weather is truly seasonable as far as English winters go, black fog, howling winds and rain - charming prospect from our windows all day long.
I went up with Poggy (her husband) to Town (London) on Wednesday...and picked up Mother to help me at Gorringes with the toys for the Depot Xmas tree. Then off to the theatre: Shock Headed Peter was given at the Garrick, a faithful record of the book of one's extreme youth! (This was based on the children's book, Struwelpeter. A recent version has just been staged again in London).

February 4th, Tuesday
Throat beastly, and what a worm it is. This afternoon we went down to the Stores (at the Woolwich Arsenal) and ticketed all the children's presents for the Xmas tree which comes off tomorrow. The Riding Master Sergt. and his wife and daughter were there to help. They are wonderful people, he was of course a ranker and had previously been a flunkey whilst she was a lady's maid, but this one would never know from their looks or speech.

February 5th
The tree was given in the Gymnasium, a great big barrack of a room, and the entertainment began at 4. First they all filled themselves to the brim with tea and buns, such a tea, I never had a better one myself, as they couldn't finish it all the trumpeters were turned in who after filling themselves likewise failed to clear the board! During tea Christy Minstrels and a conjurer performed and at half past six the tree was given. I being the only lady in the Depots had to present the presents, I felt very pompous!

February 6th
For a change the weather was lovely this morning, quite sunny and warm, so I took the opportunity of riding over to see the Wilkinsons, the roads were too dirty for words, inches deep in greasy mud and I nearly came off repeatedly.

February 11th, Tuesday
I don't know whether I have mentioned in this diary or not that some time back at the instigation of Mrs Halliday I became a Fellow of the Royal Horticultural Society and on this day I went with her to my first meeting. There are fortnightly meetings at the Drill Hall consisting of a lecture and Flower Show...the flowers were lovely, chiefly cyclamen and primula and a few orchids.
(The venue was the Drill Hall of the London Scottish Volunteers, Buckingham Gate, Westminster. Fortnightly shows were held here from 1888 until 1904, when the new hall was built in Vincent Square. Monthly shows continue to be held there.)

February 14th
St Valentine's Day!
Mother and Uncle drove over to lunch, it was a joy to see them. Uncle has bought a ripping dogcart and pony, such a smart little turn out.
(and here the entries for February break off, to be resumed in March).

february.description:
..

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt: January 1902 Wynne, newly married, has set up home in an army house in Woolwich, near the famous Arsenal where her husband, Herbert, is now a Major.
viewer_1.description:
Wynne is newly married, and has moved to Woolwich, in London where her army husband now works. She has been lazy about the diary, and resolves to start it properly again...this volume is now the fourth on her shelves.

The parade ground at Woolwich.

It is with the best intentions that I open this Diary once more and endeavour to pick up the lost thread, I don't know how it is but at one time I could write so easily and such plenty of nonsense but this great art has departed from me! However here we are settled for the present at Woolwich where we came about three months ago. We have been in these quarters just over a month, No 53 the Common. They are small but very comfy, and consist of a nice hall, dining room and servants bedroom on the ground floor, drawing room, smoking room and spare room 1st floor, and our bedroom and dressing room above...it is a great regret to me that we have no garden, if we are still here in summer it will be a terrible deprivation but I almost think that we shall be moved to Christchurch before then. Strange as it may seem we both like this much abused dog hole, partly owing to the fact that there are so many nice people here and we nearly all live so close to each other. Visitors come showering in every day and I do nothing but try and get on the right side of any call, it is hopeless...

January 24th
Went calling this afternoon, I never saw such a place as this is for calls, there are hundreds to do and I never seem to get even with them. I heard to my horror today that I am to buy all the presents for the Xmas tree (for the army children) which is being given next Saturday, there are 125 children to provide for and my flesh creeps lest I should make a mess of it all.

(It was the custom then to leave your card at every suitable house, and then to follow it with a call. This proved a very arduous process, and the trick was to call when folk were not in, so that you would not get caught, but could simply leave a card and escape!).

January 25th
I have been in bed all day with a chill. On going to bed last night I felt decayed and still more so this morning so I stayed there and spent a lovely day.

January 26th
Got up after breakfast resurgam joy! I didn't go out of course and was not sorry to stay in as it looked so bitterly cold from my window and half a hurricane blowing. This afternoon to my great joy Uncle Arthur came in having walked over. I was so glad to see him, the more so as we had been prevented from going over there to spend this weekend with them on account of my seediness and also because H had suddenly been put on duty for this week but we hope to manage it another week end. I had a long cheery letter from Eve (sister) last also from CG at which I was extremely surprised, it is the first he has ever written me in his life! and was to thank for a pipe I sent him.

(Arthur Butler lived six miles away - a short walk for a person in those days. He was the father of Yso, who features in the very first diary entry. Yso and Brenda, his two daughters, were about the same age as Wynne, and had grown up with her. Yso was to end her life during a journey...)

Wynne and Herbert are on the right of both photographs - they were obviously fooling around, probably in a neighbour's garden in Woolwich.
