viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is a typical funereally black-edged invitation - in fact sent after Edward VII's death. In the nation held its breath when the Coronation was postponed, but the King recovered and the Coronation was held. You can read about it in August.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1902

The Coronation of Edward VII is postponed but the Rose Show in Holland House goes ahead.
viewer_2.description:
June, which was to have been such an eventful month has passed away with little to mark it save disappointment and anxiety.
The Coronation which had so long been anticipated and looked forward to by thousands was postponed two days before it was to have taken place owing to the serious illness of the King. We were in Town at Holland House Rose Show the day this disastrous piece of news was announced, everything was all but prepared and finishing touches were being put to the tremendous decorations and huge stands. About the middle of the day the news came and almost directly the work of demolition commenced, now London is in a state of undress, half the work remains whilst the other half has disappeared again, one couldn't realize all it meant, the return of troops, royal visitors and disappointment of all concerned. I write this about the middle of this month and the King has so far recovered for arrangements to be made concerning the coronation which is to be hoped will take place during the second week of August.
Mother came up to us and we had a very jolly week, in spite of the disappointed (sic), it was awfully nice having her as usual, and we were sad when she left. The Rose Show which was held in the grounds of Holland House was of course delightful, though roses were certainly in the minority the season being late and also an indifferent one, but such a display of carnations, begonias, orchids and such things as annuals I have never seen. I think though, that the House itself and gardens fascinated me as much. We met Mabel early in the day and after we had seen flowers enough and eaten lunch we went all over the gardens. People were not admitted into the house, but the perfect picturesque appearance of it gave one an idea how beautiful the interior must be. It is built of very old red brick and white stone and was erected in the year one I should think!
The property belongs to the Earl of Ilchester and has done so for centuries, there is a certain ball room in the house that was prepared for a ball that was to have been given to Charles 1 but on account of non arrival it was put off. The room however is the same now as it was then, curtains, hangings, wall papers etc...all the same.
The month is nearly over and where it has gone goodness only knows, the first week or so the weather was warm but ever since rough dark days and a fitful climate has been our lot. Today, the 29th, it is blowing a hurricane and I can only have the windows open an inch or two as the draughts are frightful. It is a real pity that we have had such a vile summer. This week August comes and on its heels we may look for autumn, it all brings one so near winter which I dread.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
In Wynne stuck into her diary the menu's for several Mafeking Relief celebrations, including one from Mafeking. After the Relief, it became a custom for the Relief column to meet annually. In 1902 they signed Herbert's menu, which he proudly brought home for Wynne.

As you can see below, they did themselves well! Go to the links below to read about Mafeking, and find out more about the war. The original menu from the relief is also in the diary

Colonel Mahon was the officer commanding the relief column, and his ADC was Alexander of Teck, later the Earl of Athlone and a Governor General of South Africa.
At the top of the page you can see Herbert's signature, and just below and to the right of it is Lieutenant Gray's. This is the same Gray whose wife befriended Wynne and who appears in the 1912 diaries - by which time Gray was a Major. It was with Mrs Gray that Wynne set off to Wales in 1912 in a motor car, a journey that started in May and which you can read about further along....and you can also read about his death during the First World War - he was wounded at Mons, but never really recovered, and died in London on February 9, 1916. You will find him mentioned in that month. He is buried in Kensal Green.

If you click here on Love, which is the section devoted to Wynne and Herbert's courtship, you can read Herbert's letter from Mafeking, and you can find more about the Boer War if you click here on Editors Picks, another of the side sections of the diary.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1902

Peace at last! Wynne celebrates the end of 
            the Boer War and sticks Mafeking Relief dinner menus into her book
viewer_2.description:
June 2nd
PEACE!
Peace has actually been proclaimed and one can hardly realize what it means, here we sit and rejoice over it, most truly too but as yet one cannot grasp all it means. This fearful war has lasted now for 2 years and 8 months, very nearly 3 years, and one began to feel it would never stop. I can fancy the tremendous rejoicings out there and also throughout all our possessions. I have been reading a long account of how it was received in London, the news was given out there yesterday and the papers actually signed on Saturday at Pretoria. Oh! how splendid it all is and how thankful one is for it all.


June 5th
The days of convalescence pass by much the same as each other (Wynne has been ill with a chill leading to pleurisy). I sit in whatever sun is allowed us as the Doctor says that is the best plan of getting well. I am indeed so much better and soon I hope to cast aside shawls and invalidish fads and a few dozen of the various garments with which I am afflicted at present.
Today is the first anniversary of our wedding day, I cannot believe that we have really been married a whole year....at dinner we drank healths and eat wedding cake, then at the end of dinner Mother filled one of the German glasses with champagne which was handed round, emptied and then to our astonishment and joy the glass was presented to us!

June 13th
(Wynne is still staying with her mother, while her husband has returned to Woolwich and his army duties).
I have not been writing in here regularly because one day passes as another and as it pelts and pours with rain every day we never can get out. I have stuck in here the Programme, I mean Menu, of the dinner to which Herbert went on Friday May 16th to celebrate the Mafeking Relief. As it has the autographs on this side it is rather an interesting relic. I return to Woolwich tomorrow and although I want to see my "one and only" frightfully I shall hate leaving the country for a dirty old Town. Last night our big annual ball was held at the Mess and I am just awfully sad at missing it as being full dress it must have been a gorgeous sight.


(Wynne stuck in here not only the 1902 menu for the Mafeking Relief dinner, but the menu that was printed in Mafeking for the dinner given by the Special Correspondents who had accompanied the column. It is dated May 26th 1900. The toasts were made by the correspondents, and the menu carried the following note: "The proposers are limited in their speeches to 150 words at full rate, to which everyone is expected to listen; they may add 400 words at Press rate, but attention to these is optional." You can see the original menu here, but try out the relevant love strip for more, or go to the editor picks section for additional items.

june.description: The Diary - in JUNE... Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1902

Wynne and her husband are living in Woolwich to be near his regiment. There are local entertainments, but the big city is easily within reach, and Wynne travels up there often.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st
Last night we went up to Town, took rooms at the Westminster Hotel as Mother had had the Duke's box at Drury Lane given her for the pantomime. The scenery and dresses are perfect and this year they had an insect ballet and a fan ballet, both were beautiful. Of course Dan Leno is the life and soul of the piece and we nearly died with laughing at his ridiculous jokes.

March 2nd, Sunday
...to the Garrison Church in the morning and Church Parade afterwards, but the weather was impossible - foggy, damp and very cold so it was not enjoyable and one could not hear the music properly or see the uniforms. (Wynne was living at Woolwich, where her husband was serving in the Artillery. The main Georgian buildings and the parade ground are still there - a picture of them now is in the January entry - but the church was hit by a German V1 flying bomb on July 13th, 1944 and remains a ruin, as you can see below).



March 5th
Uncle Arthur and Bill came to lunch yesterday, and as they talked indigo all the afternoon Bill and I sat upstairs and conversed on subjects far more edifying!
We were much amused this evening by a Cafe Chantant which the cadets gave at the Shop, the room was very prettily decorated and carpeted with crimson felting, at one end sat all the "men", the stage was at one side in the middle of the room and arranged around were tables and chairs for guests. (The Shop was the local term for the Royal Military Academy building, used by officers in the Engineers. The term originated because it had once been a workshop. It still stands).


March 14th
This afternoon we had tea at the the Shop with young Shaw and Archer. We were asked with the intention of showing us round the place but it was raining too hard. It was a most amusing afternoon, a neat little table was spread out with a neat cloth and pretty tea service with as much to eat as if there were to be 50 people. Much palaver over the tea making and much ceremony over the whole performance! It was Archer's room , a nice little room hung round with pictures, photos, etc to say nothing of uniforms, rifles, whips etc!!

March 19th
Mother's birthday! I sent her a hare's foot set in a band of turquoises, may it keep off the Evil Eye as it is supposed to do. (People were much less squeamish about this sort of thing - women often had a rabbits paw with which they applied their rouge, and various animal objects could be found around the house. There was a long tradition of hares bringing luck.)


March 20th
Today was Father's birthday, how much this day brings to my mind.

March 22nd
I have so many calls to answer, and never do I seem to get a day, this afternoon we went and played Ping Pong at the Peels, but as neither of us ever play it was not a brilliant spectacle! Still quite amusing all the same. They have taken a house over at Charlton, Springfield by name, a pretty place, very old I should think and has charming ground for a Town, but as they belong to B Depot which is under orders to move I must say I think its rather a risk saddling oneself with a house even for so short a time as six months.


March 23rd
It seems very odd on Church Parade having no Middlesex Regiment - they sailed for St Helena some days ago, so now the R.A.Band has to play for both Parades.
(Wynne concluded the month with visits to London, to see the Tuesday Royal Horticultural display at the Drill Hall, an event she tried never to miss, and then went with her husband to stay at his family home in Chelmsford - a routine that continued up to the First World War. She had first gone up there before her marriage).

March 30th - Easter Sunday
We were disappointed in thinking it would be a fine day because although the weather did not come up to this forecast (the Dyspeptic's Forecast you can see opposite), it was cold and grey which is always such a pity for Easter I think. Poggy and I went to early Celebration, I am reminded by this of last Easter when we were here together, he having just arrived from S.A. (the war in South Africa) such a wreck, my poor old dear. How thin he was.

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.description:
May 1st
This is May Day and we came down here (to her Mother's home at Witchampton, near Wimborne, Dorset) for our month's leave. Oh! what a joy it is to be in the country, everything is so fresh and green and one feels alive again. As soon as we arrived we rushed round the garden which is very pretty with polyanthus and auriculas and it does feel nice to be here again, just like coming home after school.

May 3rd
I passed a beastly night and didn't sleep much, very early before it was light I awoke and birds were singing beautifully such a concert - three times I heard the cuckoo, this being the first time this year.

May 4th
The weather was brilliant when we first awoke this morning but too brilliant to last and sure enough clouds soon came and the day has been uncertain in consequence. Nevertheless after lunch, Poggy and I went up to the lovely little wood that is above the house here, such a lovely place, full of birds - thrushes, blackbirds and nightingales, the latter sing night and day, the bluebells were perfect - a perfect sea of colour - but the primroses are nearly over and I wish I could have seen it a fortnight ago.

May 5th
Poggy and I had a great morning at gardening, weeding cart loads of weeds out of the kitchen garden and thinning out the rank growth of the rampant cornflower. In the afternoon came the Cocherans in full force and we played Ping Pong wildly after tea until all was blue. Ping Pong is an amusing game but I cannot understand how it has taken such a hold upon everyone, where ever one goes it is played and people are quite made about it. Costumes are even designed for it!

May 12th, Monday
I have not been writing every day since I came here because one day passes like another, but such a time is indeed after my own heart.
(She had heard from her relatives in India, with news of their plans not to decamp into the hill stations for the hot weather, and she writes excitedly of a visit from CWM - the Charles of her earlier dreams - who she clearly still had a very soft spot for. Indeed his visit on the Wednesday sent her scurrying to her old diaries..."all of which gave me the blues, I read through the old diaries, parts at least, and wished for the good times that were therein...."
Then Wynne got pleurisy, so the rest of the month is blank...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Playbill for the amateur production that Wynne attended in November, , at Woolwich.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: November 1902 Gardening, visits, charity and the occasional theatre. Wynne is heavily pregnant, so the London trips are less frequent.
viewer_2.description:
A time of cold weather, staying indoors, and plenty of visits and visitors. Wynne appeared to have appointments for tea or dinner, and sometimes lunch, on most days, and the diary is very domestic, but in between this activity, a few other events occurred, typical of the period.

November 1st
Only two more months of this decayed year, never have I come across such an awful summer and thank goodness is is over now. We were energetic enough to walk down to the Market after lunch, what an odd place it is , on one side flower stalls, then come the butchers horrors, after that fruit and fish, whilst further on are birds, fur, ices and chestnuts, American drinks, shirt studs and links etc...all in close proximity, a babel of noise greets one and the place is anything but clean but it is all really rather interesting!

November 4th
Mrs Sealy has given me a set of duets by German of Nell Gwynn dances which ought to be rather pretty and which I am to learn up and make day and night hideous with. I have so given up my playing nowadays that of course I shall not be able to read a note, much less play anything.

November 6th
Spent the afternoon in planting the various treasures that Mother sent us from the Hive, and now our little cat run looks quite fine, I wish so much that we had done all this last year, however we must just hope to be left here now for the remainder of our appointment and then we shall be able to enjoy them all next summer.

November 9th
To tea came Capt. Gordon, Mr Furse and Mr Craven. The first reminds me of something between a sheep and yellow macaw, the second seems nice, and the third is our senior subaltern, quite pleasant but not over exciting and rather a fledgeling. I am at present reading Hichen's last - "Felix" - clever but dreadfully and painfully modern and I long to kick "Felix" so far as I have got.
(Click on the name, and then check out the last box in the February diary entry for 1912 for another reference to Hichens).

Wynne was heavily pregnant. Her long walks continued, though were often commented upon, and she managed to attend band concerts and the local amateur dramatics, where she saw an English version of Sardou's play "Dora" - called here "Diplomacy". She also managed to attend the inaugural meeting of the Badminton Club, and presumably played a game there. Much Bridge was also played, usually after dinner, and for money. One entry comments that she lost 1/6d but had previously won 3/- so was not too worried!
Finally, an entry typical of the times:

November 29th
(Took) some grapes to a sick man who is dying of consumption. It filled me with melancholy to hear from his sister-in-law how very ill he was, of course there is no possible chance of his recovering and he is in such a state that one cannot help wishing the end would come.

november.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Woolwich Arsenal at the beginning of the 20th century.

Wynne's husband was based in Woolwich during the first years of their marriage, and after he had returned from the Boer War. Above this picture in her diary, Wynne had written: "Below is a picture of the outside. 35,000 workmen are employed here and during the war work went on all night as well as day and all Sunday." The war she refers to is of course the recent one in South Africa - many more men, and women, were to be needed in 1914.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1902

Winter thoughts, home visits, rat catching and a sad funeral....
viewer_2.description:
October 8th
October has come again with its fogs and chilling winds, the days as a rule are one long perpetual fog and twice this week I have had to write my letters by candlelight all the morning, but after all there are still a few joys left, there are always muffins for tea and a cosy fire to sit by. Tea in winter is an essentially cosy meal and we always sit in bright fire light afterwards and idle till the lamps come.

October 14th, Tuesday
Long has it been upon my conscience to go and visit my battery women (an unfortunate description! - Wynne means the wives of the soldiers serving in her husband's Battery).
Therefore at 3.0 of the clock I sallied forth accompanied by the Quartermaster Sergeant who acted as herald to my arrival, announcing my name as I entered. I first went to Mrs Martin, the Sergeant Major's wife, a most superior lady who received me graciously and we conversed in a chaste manner upon the topics of the day. I next went to Mrs. Brown, the Master Tailor's wife. She is a homely old cove, very fat and friendly and like a large overflowing omelet soufflé. The Quartermaster Sergeant's lady is a pretty little thing, quite young, very bright and has a neat little kid. Mrs Young, our manservant's wife, was then visited, such a nice looking woman but poor one she is a martyr to rheumatism and only 25 years old, the small daughter is sweet and has such neat manners. This couple, like so many others, have one small room in which to sleep, eat and live; how they manage I cant think, but everything was as neat and clean as a new pin. Mrs Offord was the last I went to, she is our groom's wife, a nice civil spoken woman with 4 children, they also live in Cambridge Cottages and have two rooms, one better than the Youngs, but he, she and the 4 kids have all to sleep in one room! I think its awful and really not decent.

October 15th
I struggled to Crisps (a shop in Woolwich) and got various household trifles amongst which was a large rat trap. I have in a cupboard outside some pears stored for ripening and found to my disgust that the rats had been eating them so I purchased and set this trap in hopes that my efforts will be rewarded. We catch many mice here but so far have not been troubled with rats.

October 18th
As there is a garrison here of over 4000 men it is not strange that we are seldom long without a soldier's funeral, but one passed today the circumstances of which are so particularly sad that I felt more depressed than usual at watching it go past. The man only came back from South Africa (from the Boer War) last week and was leaving Woolwich one night by train with a lot of other fellows for their respective homes. He was poor chap very intoxicated and in getting into the train whilst it was leaving fell between it and the platform, nearly severing an arm and a leg. They conveyed him immediately to the Aux. Hospital where an amputation was found necessary and he died the next day from the shock.

October 20th
I cannot realize that we have already arrived at the 20th, but if one looks outside it doesn't take one long to do so, the rain pours down and the wind blows in true Oct. fashion, it has stripped the trees of nearly all their leaves and everything has an air of the usual Autumn decay...fires all day and everyday, Muffin man and he whose call only comes in winter: "Loggo, loggo". I have bought some this year and find them lovely.

october.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne is expecting her first child, and her mother brings her a special card from Germany...she filled it in when the baby arrived the following year, but stuck it into September 1902

Below is a picture of Wynne at Woolwich in 1902. She is the woman on the right, with her husband standing behind her. They were obviously playing about for the camera!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: September 1902 Wynne is in army accommodation at Woolwich, London. She is pregnant, and the weather is getting her down.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st
The year is slowly creeping on and as far as climate goes is as monotonous as ever. Yesterday was muggy and dark but I think the rain kept off at night for which I was indeed glad as Col. William's 3 batteries started for the 10 days camping down at Bulford. The place will seem quite dull without them all.
Poggy and I played croquet last night but it didn't amuse us much, the ground was impossible - grass a foot long where there was any and inches of mud and wormcasts elsewhere.
Yesterday I was peacefully snoring when the door opened and Mrs Russel was announced to my horror, up I sprang and tried to look as if I had never slept in my life but I fear it was a poor specimen of bravado for if she didn't observe my vice from my eyes which were "on sticks", my hair must have told a tale. Later on our new chaplain called, a Mr Armitage, he will turn out an improvement upon the others I think, trust and hope. He has a clever face and preaches well, we heard him last night, an energetic man I should fancy and will stir up the place. I wish he would stir up Mr Reed to drop his ridiculous mouthing of words - when he preaches it is very trying.


Sept 2nd
We have much enjoyed ourselves today having been to the National Dhalia (Wynne's spelling of Dahlia) Society Show at the Drill Hall. The old pompom made a great show but it is quite going out in favour of the cactus, which is very much "en evidence" now-a-days. I think my favourites are "Vestas", a delicate pin, "Gabriel" with petals like coral in form and colour, and a flame coloured one with no distinct centre. I cannot remember its name.

Sept 3rd
Atrocious weather as usual.
I am reading a most interesting book at present, Sir Harry Johnston's "Uganda Protectorate" - beautifully got up with numerous illustrations coloured and otherwise, it is a most fascinating work and I am much engrossed in it.

Sept 4th
Gran and I have been in London again all day and such a day it has been but she was as bright as a bee and far less tired than I on our arrival at home! If ever I attain the age of 87 I shall never be as she is!. Thank goodness today she did not dash in and out of buses and trains whilst they were moving so my day was free of shocks.

Sept 6th
Mother arrived home at lunch today (from Germany) and very glad we were to see her. I also had Brenda (cousin) and her man to lunch so we were a lively party and did no end of bucking. It was most interesting hearing all her (Mother's) adventures and then she loaded us all with various and most fascinating gifts - a lovely ivory pig for me for my collection, a bottle of scent, Münchener preserves and an ivory spinning wheel which is simply lovely.

The weather improved a bit, and Wynne broke off the diary on the 9th with an entry about it. Both her mother and grandmother were staying, and she welcomed the company. She was now five months pregnant with her first born. Her mother had brought her a card back from Germany which you can see in the first page view - she filled in the details the following year, but in 1902 she had written above it: "This is the Post Card that my frivolous Mother brought me from Germany. What can it mean!!?"

september.description: The Diary - in SEPTEMBER... Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. In this section you can read what Wynne was doing in . Her entries are short.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The family, minus Herbert, spent the whole month down in Devon, and this is the first page of the August diary. Eve, Wynne's sister, was on holiday from India, and as she was an avid sketcher, there are plenty of additions from her in this month, as you can see below and in the following pages...

Mrs Giddy, who ran the tea rooms you can see in the next picture window, arranged everything - is this the cottage they stayed in? Below it, a picture of the bay...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 7th

Arrival at Lee Bay, to be looked after by Mrs Giddy. The ritual of bathing and picnics begins, but the High Church service is disapproved of.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Tuesday

LEE (click here for Lee Bay information)

I started off at 9.12 with all my bags and baggages and Trix came with us as far as Woking where we changed for Salisbury, changing there again and meeting Eve and Win. We didn't get to Morthoe until after 5 and we were nearly an hour late but we got a carriage to ourselves from Salisbury.
I do hope the weather will keep up whilst we are down here, it seems so odd being back here again, dear little place, and Eve and I have just come down with our kids in order to have a month real peace. Mrs Giddy made us very welcome, nice little old woman, and we found the house most beautifully clean and comfortable. We set to work at once to unpack and dispatched the children off to the beach where I fetched them at 8.0.

August 2nd
The Diary of this month will be entirely uneventful. We are so busy doing just nothing but lie on the beach, bath, paddle etc that there is no time for events. We bathed in the afternoon today because of the tide and took our tea out. Win had never sea bathed before, Eve not since 20 years. It really was utterly perfect.

(In this picture, Eve is on the left, and Win far right, holding her Box Brownie camera)

Aug 3rd
Out all day long from 10.35 till 6.30. I long to lie for hours in the sun, do nothing, write no letters and no diary, but simply let myself go on one long laze.

Aug 4th
Spent the morning on the right hand beach, the afternoon on the left. After bathing we had tea but it came on to pour with rain alas so we had to flee.

Aug 5th
Alas when we awoke it was pouring with rain and continued to do so for several hours. I spent the morning in housework and Eve cooked and when all that was done I sat down to write many letters and Eve to paint. The children meanwhile made a huge "house" in the back kitchen with rugs, bolsters, blankets and coats where they played contentedly for hours. Win is a great hand at inventing games and they all get on splendidly together.

Aug 6th, Sunday
Such a horrible cold day blowing strong and cold and off to church we all went. The service was stranger and more distracting than ever, Mr MacMichael very absentminded as usual and being the 1st sunday of the month he spent his time in rushing in and out of the vestry dressed in different vestments. Each time it reminded me of charades and I find concentration of thought in such an atmosphere an impossibility. I know it is done in all reverence but not having been brought up in that light the whole thing is mummery to me, the genuflexions, bowing, kneeling in the middle of the creed etc I eye with curiosity and somehow one feels that perhaps that sort of ritual is in its place in some grand splendid building where the whole service and music is in accordance but down here with a squeaky organ and no choir, painful intoning etc it all savours of the ridiculous rather than the sublime. I would rather say my prayers in some field close to God's earth - and how different I felt when sitting on the beach this evening in the quiet when the wind had gone down and I watched the glowing sun go down behind the sea casting a huge brilliant reflection and making one feel indeed that "God's in His Heaven".

Aug 7th, Monday, Bank Holiday
To escape the crowd of Ilfracombe trippers which we knew would visit these shores today we took our elevens, lunch and tea and were out from 10.30 to 8! We bathed in the morning and then climbed the cliff and had lunch after which we all went over the golf links and down on to a strip of beach from there, whilst Eve sketched and then we returned to her to tea. Meanwhile the horrible trippers melted away from the beach below and we betook ourselves to the jewel beach where we sat till about 8. Such a perfect day and how we have enjoyed it. Maggie has caught a vile cold which is now passing to Win and Baby, such a bore. I do hope and trust that in a few days we shall be quit of it, it is this change of temperature I suppose as it is so hot and cold by turns that it makes dressing a difficulty, especially with children.

(note the painter on the right!)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The famous Mrs Giddy's tea rooms, where on August 12th they all had a sumptuous tea. In this, and the next 2 picture windows, you can draw your mouse over the image to see what Lee is like today. Not much change!
(The modern pictures were kindly supplied by Simon Ailes, for which much thanks)

Below, photos of a row of cottages, and the Post Office. Wynne still expected post on holiday, and even though strikes were threatened, she noted that there were two deliveries a day in spite of that.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 8th - 13th

Apart from a hot trip to Barnstaple, the days are spent out on the beaches and in the "sun filled" meadows.
viewer_4.description:
August 8th, Tuesday
I do not think I have ever bathed in more perfect weather than this morning. We repaired early to the bathing beach and to say it was hot is to put it mildly. The sun poured down so in we all went. I swam about, came out, and lay basking on the beach, then went for another swim and then instead of dressing in hurried shivers I just lay down behind my dressing rock draped in a towel and a hat because I feared the sun, and smoked a cigarette till I was dry! and how I sympathised with the ancient Britons who swathed themselves in woad! We took our tea up to the Valley this afternoon, that lovely place of magic calm, the sun filled the fields with a golden light whilst the trees on the immense hills threw deep blue shadows and everything felt at peace. How perfect a place is this and I know and feel that the fairies are there.

August 9th
A change for this morning has come over the weather, a dull grey sky and not over warm. I bathed alone as the others have this cold running through them. After lunch I went and answered the calls of the MacMichaels and Bridsons, finding the former in and the latter out. On the hill I met Joe driving from the station. She has been so seedy that I advised her to come down here and feed with us whilst I found a room (the last remaining one) for her in the village. We followed the rest of the party into the Valley where we had tea and gathered mushrooms and heaps of blackberries.

Aug 10th
Another glorious day and we spent the whole of it out of doors taking lunch and tea and having them in the bathing beach and cliff respectively. Eve sketched like mad and did some very pretty work. At 7.30 we toiled home filled with ozone

Aug 11th
As I had some business to do in Barnstaple in connection with our forthcoming bazaar I thought I had better go over today so accordingly Joe, Eve and I sallied forth. We got Armstrong to drive us in by the 9.12 and there spent a busy day. Being Market day the little old town was crammed and we made a characteristic sight going through the market ladened with honey, plums, beans and buns stuffed into our baskets and eating ginger snaps as we went. I then went to the Pottery Works where I bought two pounds worth of stuff for the bazaar and on to the basket makers where 20 baskets were added to my collection. But the heat! it was tremendous, the trains were crammed with trippers and market people and we were rejoiced to get back to the sea where we joined the party at tea on the shore. Every evening in this dear little place one is simply overcome with sleep.

Aug 12th
The tide being suitable we all made an expedition round to the cave on the right hand side, it was the greatest fun and I took many photographs which i hope to be able to be successful with on my return home. There is something magic about that shore, the long stretches of yellow sand with the jagged rocks sticking up all over it and you feel as you walk along that there must be a water sprite sitting behind them but he is always gone when you look round the corner. We went through both caves and gathered shells and the spirit of the place was upon us, the utter quietude and loneliness, the immense cliffs, the feeling of being far removed from all human creates besides ourselves. Bathing took place in the afternoon from the Gilson beach and we all had a lovely tea at Mrs Giddy's - bread and honey, cake, raspberries and cream. The children and Maggie went off up the hill to gather blackberries and we took books on to the cliff until 7.30.

Aug 13th, Sunday


The small still voice did not urge me to go to church today. I know I ought to try and make the best of that quaint little service but somehow I cannot rise to it. We have all come out to the Jewel beach bringing lunch and here we shall stay till the tide drives us away at about 3.0. I am staying on the JB itself with Joe and Baby who is having her midday sleep, the others have gone round to the cave again and I wanted Maggie to see it. Here we 3 are sitting upon this heavenly spot, there is not a sound in all the world except a lazy sigh now and then from the receding tide, the sun is fierce and strong but we sit in the shadow of the cool deep rocks, the sea is like oil and we are absolutely alone. How I love it. There is no peace like it and one is filled with a sense of goodwill toward men. This evening the children and I went blackberrying and got pounds upon the highlands.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Lee Bay, unchanged - more tree cover, and a newer building on the right...but otherwise, only the occupants of the photos are different.

And below, another page from the diary.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 14th - 19th

Politics, Drought and Strikes. The real world intrudes on the idyll. Wynne hears her husband's leave is cancelled, as the army is called out to police the strikers.
viewer_6.description:
August 14th, Monday
Such a perfect day again as each day succeeds the last they seem to vie with one another in seeing which can be the hottest. The sun shines out of a cloudless blazing sky, the sea alone looks cool and we are in it nearly all day, a swim in this weather is simply heavenly and I am doing my best to teach Eve and the others. We spent the entire day out today as usual and not getting back till nearly 8.0. We all turn out, locking the house up. The amount we eat is frightful, stowing away loaves of bread, lbs of jam, lbs of butter and gallons of lemonade. I am sure all this must be doing us a frightful amount of good and judging by our looks there seems proof of that.

(Wynne is on the left, with, from left to right, Ysobel, Win, unknown, Thomas, Eleanore, and the adored nanny, Maggie).

Aug 15th
We have been here a fortnight today, it is horrible to think that half our time is over and today another cloudless blazing glorious day is behind us. We were down on the beach by 11 and didn't get back till nearly 8, that's 9 hours of sunshine. We are much amused with Nootle in the water - we have a pair of "water wings" and the child sticks them on and half swims and floats all over the place far out of her depth perfectly fearlessly and like a little frog.

Aug 16th
Another of our long days on Bath Beach. The tide was very high when we wanted to go round this morning but nothing daunted we scrambled round and when we were really stopped by the water we undressed and carried our clothes round. At least I and the children did whilst the others followed more leisurely. We bathed a long time, the water was beautifully warm and an absolute absence of wind, quite lovely. And all the time we are enjoying this perfect period of rest and quietude the world is in a distracted state, the English world at least. Socialism is having its way and gigantic strikes are the result. The London dockers are out and Town is we hear in a perfect state of chaos, the situation is becoming frightful.

Aug 17th
Each day the paper brings more and more alarming reports of the extraordinary state of affairs. Strikes seem to have become the fashion or as one striker expressed it, "we're sure to get it pretty bad till we get some rain". The dockers are still out and now a general railway strike is threatened which if it come into force will of course paralyse the entire country. Liverpool is in a dreadful condition, the troops had to fire on the mob, wounding 4 and killing 2. The strikers are all out, terrorising all trade and everything is at a standstill, all public houses and restaurants closed, also theatres. There is no light or very little and the scavengers having gone on strike they expect pestilence as a natural consequence. Thousands of soldiers are on the move and the companies (rail) declare that even if all their men come out they will provide a service of some sort with the aid of the Government.

Aug 18th
The weather continues to give us its apparently inexhaustible store of sunshine and each day is cloudless. We cannot help revelling in it but the want of rain is becoming very very serious. Water in some parts of the country is being bought at 2d a bucket and farmers are killing their stock because there is nothing for the poor brutes to eat, everyone's garden seems to have long gone brown and bare and I hear the stream at home is dry and all the trout are dead. It is indeed a phenomenal year this one of 1911, what with Politics, Drought, and Strikes. I have not heard from H today and am wondering what is going forward. He was going to come down here Monday but writes to say that all leave is cancelled and all officers and men away have been recalled. It is a bitter disappointment to me. I had so much looked forward to his coming.

Aug 19th
We expected no posts today as the Railway Strikes were declared yesterday but to our intense joy the post man came twice as usual and we hear the South Western is still running. Tons of troops have gone to Town and are bivouacked in the parks. They are all armed and equipped as for War. It is most fearfully serious. H writes that every available man has been warned in Aldershot but his Division and the 1st have not apparently gone, at least not all, only some from Bordon. We don't get papers here till 4.0 and then we rush to the Giddys and get their Daily Mail. People on holiday are sorely put to it, many trying to get home in vain and those intending to leave wiring to cancel their rooms. The air is full of disturbances and one cannot get the whole thing out of one's head. Our days however go on in the same peaceful way and we at any rate enjoy life to the full.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This picture seems to say everything about that summer - somehow, it feels innocent, idyllic, and utterly without any sense of the cloud hanging over the whole country. The boy in it was very luckily just too young - had he been older, like his cousins, he would probably not have survived.

"For I was once a swinger of birches too..."

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
August 20th - 25th

The strike situation appears to be improving. Wynne's husband wires to say he can come after all. The country is still in turmoil though.
viewer_8.description:
August 20th, Sunday
We were out early today because the tide was in a position which necessitated our getting to Bath Beach pretty soon. We took lunch and tea, both of which we had on the cliff and we bathed both before lunch and tea. The water on both occasions was very high and most delightful, one got out of ones depth immediately and it felt most buoyant and warm. It is too funny seeing Nootle paddling about with the water wings far out of her depth. I went to church in the evening but I cannot do so again. I try to put myself outside all the forms and ceremonies there indulged in, but fail miserably.

Aug 21st
We spent a delightful day today. We got out by 11 and went straight to Bath Beach where we established ourselves on the further side and where we allowed the tide to catch us and then waited till about 7 when it went down and allowed us to get back again. By so doing we had the place entirely to ourselves the whole day. At 3.30 the children scrambled up the cliff and went to tea with the child Tootles whose acquaintance they have made.

Aug 22nd
We were going to Rockham Beach today but poor Win got a nail into the sole of her foot which prevents her walking far so we just pottered instead.

Aug 23rd
Arriving down on the shore this morning we found the tide was so low that we stayed this side of Bath Beach and bathed before going over there for our lunch. Tootles Pilly spent the day with us, she is a nice little creature. We came back round to the right about 2.30 on account of the tide and had tea on the cliff. Whilst down there we buried our milk bottle in the shingle to keep it cool as is our custom and forgot it! Consequently Tootles had to extract milk from her home and our poor bottle was dashed to pieces on the rocks. Joe left us this morning very sad to go and we miss her much. I had a ripping surprise today, a wire from H to say he is actually coming here on Friday.

Aug 24th, Thursday
I got two letters from Poggy today, he says that he is coming tomorrow. It will be absolutely heavenly seeing him again, I am no good at doing grass widow. He says that no troops have returned yet, all being employed in various parts of the country keeping the peace but the strikes seem to have settled themselves fairly, anyhow in the south, though disturbances are rife up north still and especially in Wales. They are having great scenes in the House of Commons and the toads are rounding well upon each other. Had our usual 2 bathes today and it has been a good day in spite of rather a wet morning.

Aug 25th
A lovely morning and a very low tide, accordingly we bathed from the centre sandy cove and had our lunch there at 1. Soon after I left and took Baby to meet our Daddy. Taylor played us false with the conveyance and so I had to dash down to the Hotel and get one from them. Baby was awfully important going off with me and much impressed with the fact of having a new overall on. We had tea at home on our arrival, the children were all at the Pillys and afterwards we went down to the shore and watched the big evening tide coming in, a fine sight, and of course nothing would please the kids than they must stand by the wall and get drenched to the skin. It was a cold windy evening and I fear the weather is breaking.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Herbert managed to get away for a very brief visit, his army duties necessitating him remaining in Aldershot, and kept there longer than expected because of strikes taking place across the country. As you can see, he makes no concessions to the beach!

and another typical page...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
August 26th - 31st

The weather gets colder but improves for their last day. The end of the perfect summer...but while rain is promised, the political and industrial situation, unrecognised by most, is ominous.
viewer_10.description:
August 26th, Saturday


A dull grey windy morning, so sad to get like this after the perfect month we have had, just as Poggy comes too. We all went down to Bath Beach and had our dip and dressed to our utmost discomfort in pouring rain! However my dressing is a simple matter and consists of about 4 garments! We came back to lunch and went to bathe afterwards. at least Nootle, Olive and I, the other two children going out to tea with some boys they have picked up and Eve and H joining us at tea on the beach. The tide was a very big one and we watched it racing in over the rocks for a long time, it was very grand. There was a splendid sunset but stormy and I fear our weather is broken up, I am terrified for the bazaar.

Aug 27th
Such a horrible wet cold day but we put in a bathe in the morning but sat indoors gnawing our nails all the afternoon till tea after which we mooned down to the beach for exercise. Lee is not the place for wet weather.

Aug 28th
We got a bath in the morning but had lunch in after which we all set out to Morthoe and spent the afternoon and evening on Rockham Beach. Even my Baby came and walked nearly the whole way and wasn't a bit tired. I think its rather wonderful because she is only 3½ and we must have walked the best part of 6 miles. A sweet dear little place it is and we found such heaps of cowries to the children's great delight. There was hardly a soul in sight all day on the bay and the scenery is grand.

Aug 29th
Fine again but a cold wind blowing after much rain in the night. However nothing daunted we bathed twice, took lunch and tea out, and didn't get in until 7.30. There was a perfect sunset of gold and crimson and so I trust that means a fine day tomorrow.

August 30th, Wednesday
Alas! our last day at this dear place has come and I sit on the beach writing this after the last lunch, last bathe, last tea…everything last and we are awfully sad. Luckily it has been a perfect day of bright sun and we have been on Bath Beach the whole day. I cannot bear to think it is all over, it has been such a lovely time and a perfect success in every way. We packed hard all the evening.

Aug 31st
Alas at 9.30 the cart came for our luggage and a sorrowful party left the dear little place of delightful association. I, Maggie and the children came down here to Brookfield, Herbert went to his home, Olive to Farnham and Eve and Win to Salisbury so it was indeed a dividing of the ways. We parted at Exeter as we had to get into a train which stopped at Templecombe and as soon as we did we fixed up the tea basket and had a sumptuous lunch. We arrived at about 3.30 and Mother who had been in Town came home at 6.30 bringing with her Herman who I was so glad to see again, he is a dear and such good company. Mother had been up to see about a flat as she intends spending the winter in Town, this place being so bad for her rheumatism. She thinks she has found a very nice one in Tite Street, Chelsea, in the same house and same floor as Leila which is very curious.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: A last lingering look - if you take the mouse over the first photo you will see the same scene taken at sunset.

august.description:
The Diary - in AUGUST...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

An idyllic month spent at Lee, in Devon, looks like the quintessential Edwardian dream...but trouble and strife are brewing.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.
Seems to be a placeholder with no content.
Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Mrs Gray, a kind friend, drives the family to Hayling in her car - an exciting outing for a family of horse owners, currently without their horses!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 7th

Temperatures rise, and a London visit proves exhausting. As all the horses are quarantined with the mange, the family is without transport and is stuck at home.
viewer_2.description:
1919

July 1st, Saturday
Our fears as to mange are correct and it is found that the bay has it too so here we are stranded with no means of getting about whatever. All the stable will have to be burnt out with lamps, all the harness scrubbed with Jeyes, the stuffing taken out of the saddles and burnt, even Herbert's gloves cant be used again. It is all too dreadful and I don't expect the animals will be back for 2 months. It is thought that the mare must have picked it up in the horse box going down to Camp. We ought to have been at the Landon's party this afternoon but of course couldn't go so picked strawberries instead.

July 2nd
I let Maggie go off for the afternoon today and took the children down into the Park where I lay in the bracken whilst they played about most happily, Pink trying to catch butterflies that wouldn't come near him. This is his latest craze and he can think of nothing else now. I am to get him a killing bottle in Town on Tuesday when I go up and Nootle insists that I shall bring a book on Red Indians for her!

July 3rd
Poggy had to go off to Appleby inspecting today, and at 11 Mrs Gray came with her car and fetched us all and took us down to Hayling. It was a perfect day but rather too cold a wind blowing for real comfort. We got down by 1 going by the Petersfield road, such lovely scenes, and when we arrived a very hungry company sat down to a lovely lunch and devoured nearly every scrap of it. All of us then paddled and at 3.30 started for home, arriving at 5.30. A very delightful day and the children were so rejoiced at getting to the sea. Baby slept nearly all the way home and so did I, the effects of sun, sea and a big lunch. This is what we look forward to a month hence at Lee. I am longing for that time, there is too much going on at present for comfort, and I am not a sociable person.

July 4th, Tuesday
I went up to Town this morning by the 9.12 and joined Eve at the York Hotel at 11 when we both sallied forth to Lords. We had not been there together since about 14 years and it was delightful to see it all again in each others company. At 6.0 we took our leave having been much entertained chiefly by the wondrous clothes of the women which surpass all this year. We dined at 7.0 and then went off to Her Majesty's where we saw a perfect cast do The Merry Wives, Ellen Terry taking Mistress Page, she was simply delightful and we made her come back again and again. I never saw such an ovation as she got.

July 5th
In tropical heat H and I sallied forth to the Stores where we shopped hard all morning and were met there at lunch time by Eve. The crush was frightful and the temperature 569 I should think. We all three then went off to Olympia where the RHS are holding their big show this year. The papers say there has never been such a show held in England before and I am sure I have never seen such perfect flowers. It was all a dream and one could do nothing but walk round and gape and gasp. We parted company then and came home only to rush out again to dine with the Grays. One felt quite exhausted by the heat, it is quite phenomenal. We all sat out after dinner in the cool evening air.
(The flower show referred to is what is now known as the Chelsea Flower Show - was unusual in that the original RHS venue, Holland House, and the grounds of Chelsea Hospital, were unavailable, so for this year only it was held at Olympia).

July 6th
The heat continues. Great heat wave in America and so I suppose this is what is coming to us. I revel in it and never feel so well but most people are feeling it dreadfully. I let Maggie go off on her holiday today and so I have my baby with me most of the day. This afternoon I toiled up to a sale held in (a) garden, but left at 4.30 because I had to take Baby to tea at the Allasons, an amusement I cant say I enjoyed. Children are so shy of one another, looking grim and repellant and these refused to play together at all! I do not care for Mrs A, it always seems rather a fetish of hers to find fault with most things in a very superior tone which bores me.

July 7th
Miss Cookson was coming over to have lunch but this wretched bother with the horses has deprived us of being able to send and fetch anyone so I have put her off. There was an At Home at the Mess today to which we went, Major Dally sending up his car for us and we took with us Mrs Watson whose host was Mr Ardagh. It was pleasant sitting there under the trees watching them play tennis and listening to the band. After dinner we sat out on the terrace in the moonlight with the strong scent of the tobacco flowers , likewise the scent of the cigarettes to inhale!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 8th - 14th

The heat wave continues, and alongside local duties and entertainments, Wynne takes her group of mothers to the Festival of Empire at the Crystal Palace.
viewer_4.description:
July 8th, Saturday
To lunch came the boys from Sandhurst. I am afraid this is the last time we shall see Mr Cope as they break up on the 20th and disperse. I am hoping Herman (her cousin) is coming to me to stay for a week. I had a crowd here for tennis and they played until 8.0! but it wasn't as good tennis as last time.

July 9th
I didn't go to Church this morning but stayed at home with Baby and got through arrears of letters. Such perfect weather still each day, more roasting than the last and I just love it, every morning I get up at about 5 or 5.30 when I garden and enjoy myself most tremendously. The lazy household lie in bed and about 2 hours after they crawl sleepily from their couches. I cant think how anyone can lie abed in this weather.

July 10th, Monday
Oh! "I'av 'ad a day". It has been the day of the Mothers Meeting trip. Mrs W, a Miss Rogers and myself started off by the 9.12, changing at Woking, Surbiton and Clapham. We eventually arrived at the Crystal Palace, there in that odious place the Festival of Empire is being held this year and the usual pandemonium reigned. How vile a hole it is, but it was good to see how the women enjoyed it and great was their unseemly mirth when all the fat ones stuck in the turnstile. They indulged in rides on the Joy Wheel, the Motor Whirligig, the The Cake Walk etc…but thank goodness I was able to escape by an earlier train on the plea of Amy Daniell who I found on my arrival. The heat was intense and we felt like a lot of sheep in pens during the journey.

July 11th
Thank goodness yesterday's experience is over the for the year, and today a crowd came to tennis again. The heat was terrific and I cant imagine how they could play. I plied them all with many drinks and fruit which was the only way of keeping them going.

July 12th
Glorious sunshine still continues, this is indeed a record summer. We walked over to Farnham Castle across the Park after lunch to the Flower Show, arriving boiled but getting a lift home in the Grays' car. The show was poor but it is a lovely place and high up on the top of the ancient keep they have a most beautiful rose garden, such a perfect spot and quite unique. I am glad to have seen it.

July 13th
Poggy left this morning for Okey (Okehampton) where he has gone inspecting and returns tomorrow night after dinner. Poor one, he will feel this heat in the train. Amy and I went off to the Romers garden party, where a great crowd was assembled and tennis, croquet and fortune telling the order of the day. The teller told me the usual stuff and was highly complimentary and made some quite good shots as to the past. Exhausted by heat Amy and I sat out on the terrace after dinner where the cool air was heavenly and the great yellow moon rose up slowly between the trees.

July 14th
A dreadful garden meeting for the Mary Yolland House had to be attended today on my bicycle too. I was nearly dead and really this seems the hottest day of all. We all felt like melting and lay about like flies.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Wynne was very proud of her tennis court, and organised great tournaments. She did not play herself, however.

Below are friends seated at the edge of the court, and a single shot of players - Wynne was still struggling with her photography, but bear in mind that she had to develop and print the pictures herself.

Wynne was an avid photographer - and a very keen gardener. Below you can see her at Upton Lodge, with the family, and posed at the french windows with her cousin Herman von Poellnitz, fresh from Sandhurst (see July 21st).

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 15th - 22nd

More heat, and the children are suffering, with one consigned to bed. Tennis, charitable teas, and numerous "At Home's". Herbert has to work.
viewer_6.description:
July 15th, Saturday
My Nootle is knocked over by the heat, a regular fever attack, headache, sickness and so I am keeping her in. Dr Hussey who came to see her says they have heaps of cases like this, Dr Tanner's child is the same. Pink too hasn't been at all fit the last two days but it is really not to be wondered at. I feel so thankful that I love it so, I just live through every minute and dread a change. Very selfish of me. I was going to the General's Garden Party today - the Grays called for us but I felt I couldn't leave Nootle so Poggy went without me. I was much disappointed as it is such a great meeting place and one sees people there one never sees at any other time of year.

July 16th
More sun, more heat but rather a strong wind today. I do hope it will still keep fine for tomorrow for I have a tennis tournament. Major Ward came over to tea, walked all the way in this awful heat from Ewshott.

July 17th
Morning preparing for my tournament. At 2.30 punctually they turned up, 5 couples, and they played with much energy whilst I plied them with fruit and drinks.

July 18th
The heat continues and the garden is more and more dried up. One waters daily but with very little success. It is most disheartening after all our endless work. I rushed round my district directly after lunch to see some of my women as I shall be away all August and then I went up to the Institute to the de Mornays who had some people there to tennis. H was out all day on a Field Day and didn't get in until 6.30.

July 19th, Wednesday
H was out again on his fighting tack but got back in time for us to lunch at the Bacons, then at 4.15 the Grays came and took us to the Duffus' At Home where we met a concourse of people, heard the band, ate largely and smoked cigarettes in Major Ward's nice little quarter. After dinner we went over to the Watson's for a talk until 10.

July 20th
I had all the girls of the Mary Yolland Home to tea this afternoon. Poor little creatures, they are all incurable with tubercular trouble. We gave them a huge tea and then they played croquet and hobbled about the garden. It is sad to see them and to know that nothing can be done for them.

July 21st
Herman arrived yesterday afternoon from Sandhurst which he has now left for good and all. I had to go to Town today to a dentist and the heat pretty nearly did for me. I never felt anything like it. I did some shopping and lunched and tea'd at my Club and really almost expired.

July 22nd
Still the heat increases and one hardly knows how to bear it. yesterday my Dearest had to go off on a lengthy Field Day. He started at 9 and didn't get back till 6.45 this morning as they bivouacked last night. The Barnes dined with us and we played Bridge. After dinner when they had gone H(erman) and I sat out on the terrace looking at the stars. I have never seen so many in my life, perfectly beautiful. This morning I got up at 5.15 so was up with tea ready for my man on his arrival. He got in so hot and fagged and after breakfast went off to bed and slept till 11.30. The Grays took us to the Findlays At Home this afternoon. They have got a lovely place and I enjoyed it much.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 23rd - 31st

"Grilling weather", but Wynne loves it. She has her pony back at last, so can get around again. Tennis tournaments, and Herbert goes off to Army Camp with the 2nd Division.
viewer_8.description:
July 23rd, Sunday
Grilling weather, will it never rain again? We went down to church and on my way back I looked in on Joe who has been very seedy with a sort of flu attack. I also went in to see Mrs Boone, a nice newly married girl whose man belongs to us. To tea at which we boiled came Maj Barker, Maj Lamont and Mr de Mornay. After tea the weather grew dark and cloudy and perfectly breathless. It felt like a storm but we were disappointed for it all cleared away and we gasped once more. I have not remembered such a summer for years and if one hadn't a garden I would wish it to go on for ever.

July 24th
A day at home and a very hot one. We feebly sprinkle water and keep the hose going in a sort of half-hearted way but it isn't much use. We planted out a lot of wall flowers today, yellow ones, and the rest are to follow as soon as ever we can find the room.

July 25th
I have actually got my pony back at last. It seems quite strange having anything to drive and I took her into the town this morning.

July 26th, Wednesday
This being the day of my second tennis tournament it was with mixed feeling that I awoke at 5 and found it actually pouring with rain. Knowing how the land was thirsting for it I rejoiced and yet I trembled lest it should continue all day. However by 9 it had cleared and came out most beautifully fine, so that by 2.30 when they started all was well. I had 6 couples this time. In addition to these, tons of people chose to call and I had 23 to tea in all.

July 27th
Despite the heat Herman and Trix played singles all morning. The rain has done good and now we have a blazing day again. This afternoon they all set forth to see the Army Running, I stayed at home and thoroughly enjoyed a solitary afternoon.

July 28th
A day at home thanks be, and I just gardened. Herbert went off bivouacking this night, a perfect night, cool still and bright. I say cool, but that didn't appear till about 1. At 7 the thermometer still registered 80 degrees. H and Capt Gray dined here at 7.30 and then went off saying they would be in by 5.30 the following morning so I have promised to get up and have tea for them!

July 29th
At 4.20 I arose this morning, dressed and went down to get the promised tea. Just as the water boiled at 5 up came the two poor wanderers looking very jaded and sleepy and I plied them with much drink and bread and butter.We went over to the Grays to tennis at 4.30 and on our way home a thunder storm burst but we got in just in time before the rain.

July 30th
My man and I went to early service and then we all went down to the 11.0 service.

July 31st, Monday
Dear Poggy went off on his weeks camp today and we all breakfasted at 7.30 and then went down the road to see them go. The whole 2nd Division marched out and even at that early hour with only shirts on the men looked already cooked, poor ones. We spent the day doing photography and packing.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The 2nd Division leave Aldershot for their summer camp.

Every photo of soldiers taken before 1914 must prompt the question - how many of them survived?

Marching into the shadows...

july.description:
The Diary - in JULY...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Temperatures continue to rise to record levels - the perfect summer.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
These photos are of Wynne's youngest, Eleanore. However what Wynne perhaps did not realise is how interesting the background is in both pictures. In the top one, notice the paraphernalia associated with the weekly wash - on the left, the oil lamp on the wall, the large basins, and the buckets to collect water - nothing on tap here. On the right you can see the huge tub with the Victorian washing dolly for pumelling the clothes.

In the second photo notice the well and pumps - both on the left and behind the child. No mains water then.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 8th

Army duties, dinners and gardening. Wynne celebrates 10 years of married life.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Thursday
Off into the old town in the morning to do the month's shopping, then home to a meeting on the Mary Yolland Home, after lunch all round my district with magazines and so a day of dullness only redeemed by the arrival in the evening of my dear Poggy from Camp. It is ripping and lovely to have him back and indeed to be en famille again.

June 2nd
District visiting all morning and now thank goodness I have finished it all for the month. I have one or two weird women to deal with and I don't care at all for this job although some are quite nice.

June 3rd
Here is a picture of the white cactus we have at home, it was a most beautiful, this greenish white, its back petals being tinged with copper colour, the scent quite perfect. We dined this night with General Lawson and found there a party of 14, including Lady Douglas of the Southern Command, a pleasant woman of about 50 with a faded appearance, her sister Lady Kennedy also was present, tall, thin and worn, with experience written in her face, a clinging gown of emerald green and a very moth-eaten coiffeur, a bracelet with SHE in diamonds on it, and a man's heavy ring, and a cigarette always in evidence. A pleasant evening and much Bridge at which I was lucky. Colonel Burbeck took me in and the Aide sat on my right. Much cackling and the first strawberries at which I wished the same old wish, trusting for luck!

June 4th, Sunday
Whit Sunday here once again, and still we have perfect weather. The last 5 weeks have been a dream, endless sunshine and although the garden cries for rain one is loathe to let the sun go.

June 5th
Ten solid years ago we led each other to the Hymenial. We spent the day after our own hearts. I actually got H up at 6.30 and we gardened the live long day as this being Whit Monday he had a holiday, and it was all perfect enjoyment and contentment. How absolutely blessed is my life with this delighted creature, one endless cycle of peace and the more I see of him the more impossible I feel life would be without him.

June 6th, Tuesday
Having to attend an At Home over at Tilford today I went before lunch and partook of it with Geoffrey H.W. in his little sanctum at the San. His father has given him a plot of land where he has made the sweetest garden in miniature with a sundial, fountain, fish pond and all and is now building a house there! At 5.30 I went over to the Beaumonts where a certain Mrs Willoughby Hodgson gave a lecture on old China, which proved most interesting, and I was sorry H couldn't be there but he is dancing attendance on the King all day today. The Grays took us in their car yesterday to see His M as he rode through the Camp. He was looking awfully well and has a good seat on a horse.

June 7th
I had a crowd in here to tennis today, including Herman and Mr Cope who stayed to dinner.

June 8th
My usual programme of gardening took place, it is what I give every spare minute to, and the result so far very pleasing. At present we have a blaze of lupins, poppies, iceland ditto, rocket and stocks. I do so love it all and to think we have still 3 more years here makes it worth while doing something to it.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne's garden at Upton Lodge, Hale, this sunny June. If you take your mouse over the first photo you will see how much her borders have grown since the previous month - the second photo is another view of the herbaceous border.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 9th - 18th

Another week of glorious weather. Wynne's Uncle, Arthur Butler, dies.
viewer_4.description:
June 9th, Friday
Rita came today to stay a week and she brought the news with her that Uncle Arthur Butler who is now in a nursing home is most awfully bad. Aimee (Fallowfield - Rita's mother) was telegraphed for this morning and she and Topsy (Brenda, his daughter) are with him. He has suffered so much since Xmas, that it can only be a blessing if he dies. We went over to a garden Mission Meeting of the Watsons. (Arthur Butler was the father of Wynne's favourite cousin, Ysobel, and the two girls, along probably with Ysobel's sister Brenda, had shared a governess. In the 1895 diary frontispiece you can see Wynne's sketch of Yso).

June 10th
I wired this morning to Aim for news of Uncle and reply came that he died last night, his last day was passed unconsciously and his end was peaceful. One will miss him very much but one couldn't wish him to live through any more such trouble as he has been going through.

June 11th
Rita, I and the children and Miss M all walked over to the Garrison Church today. The way was hot, long and dusty but it is always a delightful sight and an inspiring service. The Cavalry and Horse Artillery attended and I do so wish we were near and could go oftener.

June 12th
I had to go off to a dull meeting this morning. Several people came to tennis and played till 7.0

June 13th
H and I went up to Uncle's funeral, a horrid sad day. H went off to Springfield for the night.

June 14th
Day after day for weeks now we have had the most glorious weather, one long enjoyment of unbroken sunshine, but the garden badly needs rain now and there are signs of it coming - only when once it breaks in this country of ours there's no saying when we shall see the sun again.

June 15th
This morning to my great joy I get a wire from Walter (von Poellnitz, her uncle) to say he arrives here tonight at 5.15 so accordingly at about 6 he turned up and looks very fit and well. The village nurse came to tea today, an excellent specimen, sensible and keen on her work and belonging to the class of the people most suitable. Tonight we had a duty dinner party.

June 16th
I forgot to mention that yesterday was my birthday, perhaps when females come to the age of 32 it is as well to forget it. Mother sent me a lovely silk evening cloak, Eve a painted parasol which I so much longed for, and H gave me a cheque. Rita left us today.

June 17th, Saturday
Pottered about over household jobs all the morning and wrote tons of letters, and after lunch Walter and I drove to the Cameron Sports, a large and gay gathering but I am dreadfully blasé about these shows nowadays and find them dreadfully boring, all except their lovely pipes which are quite unique and absolutely perfect.

June 18th
Off to church in the morning. Snoozed in the afternoon.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne's single photo of the Mall before the great procession - they moved around, chatted to friends, and do not appear to have been constrained as they would be now, though they had seats - huge numbers of stands were constructed.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 19th - 23rd

The Coronation. Wynne avoids the main event, but goes to London for the royal procession on 23rd. Rain elsewhere but London avoids the worst.
viewer_6.description:
June 19th, Monday
Alas the weather has really broken and all are fear and trembling for Thursday, it will be a real calamity if Coronation Day should be wet. The Lomaxs garden party was on today and so H and I drove to the Club where it was held. There was to have been a cricket match but it was too wet to play so we all just sat inside and had tea and listened to the R.A. band. It was a fearful sell for the poor Ls as they had expected 600 people and at the most there couldn't have been more than 100.

June 20th
Thirteen years ago today my dear Father died - 13 years - it seems all that somehow and yet how short a time to look back on in comparison to looking forward, and how very much has happened in it all, all the most important events of my life.

June 21st, Wednesday
A day at home and one with nothing on, what a blessed relief. I sent Bessie and Maggie up to Town with Mrs Young (her servants) to see the decorations. They came home full of it and I fancy it must be lovely but the weather looks bad tonight alas.

June 22nd
King George V Crowned Today!
How frightful to look out of the window this morning to find a gale blowing and drizzling rain descending, and to know that for hours many thousands had been waiting and hanging about already, poor people. I felt thankful that I had given up my original intention of going up to take my chance in the street. We all trooped off to the Coronation Service which I thought rather gloomy and the rain poured down, the village band played the children down to Church and away, starting back all in different keys, and after lunch the festivities commenced on the green, the poor children trying to do their dances whilst the band let forth watering miserable tunes.

June 23rd
It was still raining this morning when we arose from our beds much depressed by the gloomy outlook at 4.30! However we determined to go, and accordingly caught the 6.30 train, and on arrival took the Tube to Embankment from whence we walked to our stand at the Mall through the gaily decorated streets. There was no crush whatever and everything was quiet and orderly. We put our coats down on our seats and then walked up and down inspecting decorations, troops and crowds, besides meeting many friends on the same errand. At last it was time to take our seats and soon the Procession came in sight. I have since heard it described as "dull", of people being "bored to death". Not wishing to be intolerant I cannot understand the mind that can remain unmoved by what we saw pass, the colour alone gets into ones throat to quote Kipling, and when one realised what it all meant one could not help feeling most justly proud of all it represented. With the exception of a group of officers who were taken from the regiments of which the King is Hon Colonel, there was not a foreigner among them, the whole Procession was composed of Home troops and those of the Colonies and in the midst drove the King and Queen in their wonderful gilded coach drawn by 8 cream coloured horses covered with harness of scarlet and gold led by grooms in golden livery. Troop after Troop of Household Cavalry, Hussars, Lancers, Dragoons, Guards Artillery, besides all the Colonial contingents including a big group of native officers in their perfect uniforms sitting their horses as only a native officer can. I thought it all perfect and the people cheered and cheered again as it all went by. When at length it had all passed we made out way to the Club where we had lunch and so home by the 4.12.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The Naval Review at Spithead. The family were invited onto HMS Argyll by Walter Fallowfield, see below in the first photo. Scroll down for further photos both of the sailors on board, and a distant view of the Royal yacht as it progressed through the lines.

HMS Argyll is shown at the bottom of the page.

In this photo, Walter von Poellnitz is centre, top hat, and Herbert in full army rig is on the right, wearing his sword and Boer War medals. Because of the familiarity in Walter's pose, I can only assume that the man between him and Herbert is in fact Walter Fallowfield. Walter F is Walter von P's nephew , and Wynne's cousin - he and his siblings Bill and Rita feature in the diaries.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 24th - 30th

They attend to the Royal Review of the Navy at Spithead, and watch the Royal Yacht progress down the endless lines of ships. Dinners, garden parties, fun - and then the horses go down with mange.
viewer_8.description:
June 24th, Saturday
In describing yesterday's events I forgot to mention one most important thing and that was the weather which began by being so hopeless and then cleared up, remaining fine all day with the exception of a few drops of rain. We found also that on the Thursday though dull at times they hardly had any rain so that our pity for them was wasted.
Again this morning we were greeted by torrents when we arose at 5 to start for our journey at 7 for Portsmouth where we had been invited by Walter Fallowfield to see the Naval Review from his ship, HMS Argyll. Walter Poellnitz had left us in Town yesterday to go straight down and spent the night on board and accordingly on our arrival we met him and the other Walter at the ship's side. It was very rough during our passage from the shore but fine as the sun came in sight at about 9 and stayed with us all day. I never saw a more impressive sight than this, hundreds of enormous ships drawn up in 4 lines all dressed in flags and representing (the English ones alone) 81 millions of money. We had lunch on arrival and soon after the Royal yacht commenced her progress. I shall never forget the salute, it was grand, the air vibrated and the ship shook as one after the other the 21 guns were fired from ships. We left again at about 6.30, getting home at 10.30 and feeling as if our brains would hold no more.

June 25th, Sunday
It has poured without ceasing the whole livelong day. My Christian man braved the weather and went to church but I became heathen today and had a real day of rest.

June 26th
Dinner party night and so much to do with various odd jobs and Walter returned. To dinner came the Howards, Major de Rougement, CApt MacClellan and Mr Frazer. The last two hailed from Puckridge Camp and were quite nice and dull. Maj de R is always charming, one of those men whose manner is beyond reproach. Mrs Howard looked charming, she is extremely handsome. We played Whisky Poker as usual and Mr Howard won.

June 27th
Quite a lovely day again, but it isn't gong to last so our "home made" weather prophet, Baker, says. (How wrong he was!)

June 28th
