Today I had a lot of people here playing tennis. I dont think I ever saw better play, they continued to do so until 7.30 and then rushed off in fright at the time. The court is playing awfully well and I do so wish I could play the wretched game, I would give anything to do so.

June 29th
A most inconvenient thing has happened, Sinnott (the groom) has gone down with flu. I do hope he wont get complications. Magazine meeting at 3.0 and at 4.0 the Grays turned up to take us down to the Milroys 'At Home'. There a string quartet performed very nicely whilst we had tea, strolled and ate strawberries. Also I smoked a cigarette with Capt Gray behind the bushes! We afterwards flew off with them to their place and saw their lovely roses and sweet garden.

June 30th
The last day of my beloved month has arrived, most of the things that have mattered in my life have happened in this month. The garden is very gay with delphiniums, campanulas and monkshood at present and we are and have been busy sowing many spring things, seeds I got from Barr, Ryder having turned out such a failure this year. We are much disturbed today on finding out that there is a fear of H's mare and the pony having mange. It is too vexing if it is the case and they have been sent down to the sick lines to find out. I only hope the horse wont get it too as we shall have an empty stable for weeks.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Centuries of British naval history!

june.description:
The Diary - in JUNE...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The Coronation of King George V. Celebrations in London and a visit to the Royal Review at Spithead.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne's three children playing with wastepaper baskets - Herbert (Pink), Eleanore (Baby) and Ysobel (Nootie or Nootle). Her family were not immune from the Edwardian mania for nicknames. The audio clips you hear in the diary are Ysobel's memories.

Below, you can see them again, with the addition of Win, their cousin. Win's family lived in India, which meant she rarely saw her parents. In effect her family was her Aunt's - and once the war started even the very infrequent trips home stopped. However was a great year for her, as her Mother, Eve (Wynne's sister), was over in England for a holiday.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 7th

Wynne's sister Eve is over from India, and the whole family decamp from Hale to Brookfield in Dorset to stay with their Mother.
viewer_2.description:
(Many of the 1911 illustrations are done by Eva Lees <Eve, Wynne's sister>- although as usual Wynne's Mother contributes. Certainly the larger scenes, and work in August, would be by Eve).

May 1st, Monday
This is about the first really warm May Day I have ever remembered. I took my Nootle down to the town in the morning and we were quite hot. Mother went off to Town by the 9.19 and by the 2.15 there came Miss Hamilton who put up with me this night and who I chaperoned to the Sapper Mess Dance. Mr Glenday was out host, a typical sapper, but not a bad little pogbag. He looked after her very well and I felt a real chaperone when at about the 14th dance they both came up to me and told me to be sure and say when I wanted to go home!! Ye Gods! It is the last thing I ever wish to do! Major de Rougemont and Captain Dathie were both there, a gunner saving grace amongst such a wilderness of sappers!!

May 2nd
Oh! a breathless morning. We all cleared out for Brookfield and the whole house was like a disturbed beehive. Mother and Gran and Clark went off by motor at 11, on the top of their car we piled cardboard hat boxes by the dozen and later in the day we learnt that as it came on to pour they had to bring all inside! We started at 11.30 in the fly and brougham, each conveyance groaning with luggage. We travelled 7 strong with 14 hand packages and 7 in the van! We all arrived without mishap and found the others awaiting up, Gran not at all tired, the new servants installed but will not prove of any use, before Mother had been in the house half an hour they both came with endless complaints. Brookfield is looking simply lovely and it is delightful being here en famille and actually having Eve (Wynne's sister) again.

May 3rd
This day we spent in much hard labour. The house though clean is of course upside down, and we spent our time in getting the drawing room into order. The floor has been stained and is having Indian rugs on it for the summer which is nice and cool and looks very pretty, and Mother as usual has brought many treasures from the East! We had one lovely experience, one box, which contained rice and taparee jam, on being opened we found that these two things had shed themselves over everything! The mess was indescribable.

May 4th
I spent my time in filling the house with flowers and cleaning and unpacking silver so it all looks a bit more homely now. The weather today is stormy and cold.

May 5th
There is not much time to breathe at present, all are busy the whole day over various jobs and the time flies by. To my great joy my Poggy came today by the 6.45 and I and the children went in to meet him. He is just able to get away between the 2 Brigades practices.

May 6th
It has been a most perfect day, warm, still and sunny and we were enjoying a lovely lazy afternoon in the summer house when the Jacksons called. I roused myself out of my torpor most unwillingly and made polite conversation.

May 7th, Sunday
The family all went to church this morning. Directly after lunch we all walked up to dear old Ashley, that place is a perfect dream. I have never seen it look more lovely, one vast sheet of bluebells, primroses, campion and the vivid green of young spurge. One felt, what did one feel? sort of "filled to the throat" with the beauty of it all. We gathered heaps of flowers and lay basking in the sun listening to all the wood sounds and those in the valley below.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Gardening was Wynne's passion, and below you can see two pictures of her garden at Upton Lodge, Hale, that she took at 6.30 one May morning (they are stuck in the diary with that additional note).Scroll down through them and you will find two pictures taken at her family home, Brookfield, Tarrant Keynston

Below: the view up the lawn to the house at Brookfield, and below that, proudly photographed, the viola border - which must have taken some doing, looking at the quantities involved!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 8th - 16th

Apart from one storm the weather improves and the Brookfield garden and surrounding countryside is enjoyed to the full.
viewer_4.description:
May 8th, Monday
Another perfect day. Wrote letters and gardened and lazed about. H, Mother and I drove into Blandford and did some shopping, every minute I spend out of the place I grudge.

May 9th
To my sorrow and regret my man left me today for Okey (Okehampton Army Camp - see below, and notice the two women visitors!) and Mother and I drove into Blandford to see him off. More perfect weather but thundery and hot. On our way home we went to Ashley where we found the others all awaiting us and having brought cups and buns we joined them all and had a delicious picnic tea. After tea we all wandered away and gathered tons of flowers to send to hospitals.

May 10th
This day 16 years ago I was confirmed, what ages it is to look back on. We and the children took tea to Preston but seeing a storm approaching we hurried home and only got back just in time before a most terrific storm broke. I have seldom seen a worse one, the lightening was grand and the sky inky, quite frightening.

May 11th
Spent a lovely lazy home day. How I do love not having to go out, one has so much of that sort of thing to do at Aldershot. All sorts of catastrophes occurred during yesterday's storm, and it seems to have broken all over the British Isles.

May 12th
I got up at 10 to 6 this morning and was out in the glorious early morning sunshine by 6.20. Again the feeling of enchantment seemed in the air, the birds all busy over their domestic arrangements and no one to disturb the peace.

May 13th
Again I got up early and was down by 6.30. It was misty and rainy when first I came out but now 8.30 it has turned quite sunny and hot. I am sitting in the shelter and the birds are interesting me very much, a chaffinch is searching everywhere for nest materials and goes away with his mouth stuffed, giving her the appearance of a fierce moustache! A robin is collecting grubs and worms by bunches for her importunate crew and many other do the same, the wood pidgeon is at his old game of "take twooo cows", the cuckoo sings incessantly and the air is so full of calls that it is hard to distinguish which is which.

May 14th, Sunday
Eve and I went down to the churchyard this morning before breakfast to put flowers on the grave (of their father). I do not wish to give way to lugubrious sentiments but how many of our old friends lie in that quiet little spot: 4 Coombs, the old Belbens, Miss Cook, old Mayers, the Pile sisters, and many more. To lunch came the Macleans in their car and after lunch we all went down to the Chase which was looking perfectly beautiful, a carpet of bluebells which amongst the silver birches were just beyond describing. We then went to Ashley and had a picnic tea, such a perfect evening again. We are having lovely weather.

May 15th
I got up at 5.30 this morning and was down by 6.15. These early mornings are my most treasured times, one can just sit and feel at peace with oneself and the world. Mother and I drove into Blandford to see the dress maker.

May 16th
This morning I got in 2½ hours work before breakfast at the front borders which I have planted with snapdragons. By the time breakfast came I was pretty hungry! I spent the rest of all this perfect day in the garden.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Picnics were a very common and favourite occupation. This one is probably at the aforementioned Ashley (see May 9th), where the company often met up. Below it is a photo of the wild flowers that Eve has coloured for Wynne, to give some idea of the luxuriance of wild flowers in those days.

Wynne is taking this photo, and the children are largely recognisable. The large lady extreme right is Blanche, Wynne's mother, with whom they were all staying.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 17th - 24th

The legendary hot summer is underway. A trip to the sea at Studland, and a return to her home in Hale for Wynne. The children stay in Dorset.
viewer_6.description:
May 17th, Wednesday
Surely this has been the hottest day this year, an absolutely cloudless day and though I was working on the north side of the house I haven't been so hot for ages. So lovely, so perfectly still and brilliant that I for one esteemed it a waste of sun to go and sit in the Town Hall to hear the townies perform "Our Boys", which we did. The atmosphere in there was stifling and smelt of bad gas, but it was a treat to see Mrs Curtis and young Cherry etc….they did it very well! but oh! the fearful accents.

May 18th
Another beautiful day spent in doing a lot of chores

May 19th
This day has been one of great enjoyment and fun.
At 11.30 Henry Maclean and his wife came for us with two motors and took us all to the above for the whole day - dear old Studland, it was jolly to see it again and although it is rather built over since we were there yet there were very few people there and we spent a lovely day having both lunch and tea there. We motored home by Bournemouth and Henry tore along at 60 miles an hour, too fast and Mother was very upset. Personally I loved it and found it most exciting!

May 21st, Sunday
Eve and I went to early service and then I took Gran to the 11.0 and after lunch we and the children went off up to Preston, that enchanted wood, with our books and slept whilst the insects feasted upon us at their sweet will.

May 22nd
I worked hard in the garden all day. After lunch we did bees, dressed up to the eyes in bee veils. It was most interesting and we neither of us got bitten, stung I mean!

May 23rd
I this day returned home starting by the 10.45 and stopping in Salisbury on the way to see Farebrother who filled 5 teeth for me, making 21 in about 15 months. It is really fearful and senile decay must be coming over me. I got home by 6 and immediately rushed all over the garden to inspect. I was surprised at the way everything has grown and closed in and it was so very interesting.

May 24th
I got up this morning at 5.30 and went down and made myself some tea and then sat writing letters for a while after which I did photography all before breakfast. Then the whole day I spent gardening, there is so much to be done just now and being here alone one has more time for such things. I sowed my spring annuals, such things as wall flowers, canterbury bells and the like and worked at it all till 8 when I reluctantly went in to eat my garbage!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 25th - 31st

Busy with work and garden at Hale, Wynne manages to get a party down for the King's Parade at Aldershot, and has a night in London to see Julius Caesar.
viewer_8.description:
May 25th, Thursday
This day passed like Wednesday. I have written home to try and persuade Eve to come here for the Birthday Review on Sat., also am trying to get the Jones, Gertie and Aimee, it is a good show if the weather is fine and I only wish my Poggy were going to be here too. (Herbert was always away on exercises, something that meant Wynne missed out on royal invitations etc…as you can hear).

May 26th
To my great joy Eve writes she intended coming today. It will be good for her to see lots of soldiers, they are always a tonic. As the house is upside down with cleaning Eve had to bed down with me, but we don't mind and it seems like very old days sharing a bedroom.

May 27th, Saturday
Review Day. Lovely weather so we donned out best clothes and set off at 9.0 to meet the Jones, Gertie and Aim who all arrived by different trains. We drove straight on to the Plain and there saw this most inspiring sight. It is always a joy and makes me want to cry! We all got back here at 2.0 for lunch and they departed by various trains in the evening.

May 28th
The perfect weather still continuing we had the energy to walk over to the Garrison Church for the Cavalry Service. The heat was tremendous but it is always a treat to go to such a church with its delightful organ and band taking the service and hundreds of men singing as only the tommy knows how. We spent a most delightfully peaceful afternoon and evening, took rugs, chairs, books and pillows under the trees and there lazed away many hours in perfect quietude and peace. It does do one good to get away and be alone sometimes.

May 29th
Eve went back today. We both drove down to the station today, she leaving by the 12.35 and I went up to Town 12.3. I drove to my Club and put up there for the night, there I found consternation reigning, the premises have been sold to the Junior Arts Club and the dear old Empress no longer exists and so in self defence I suppose I shall have to join it as one cant be without a Club. I rushed about all day shopping and bought myself three very sweet little frocks, everything nowadays is so cheap and pretty and all frocks are made in one. I took my things to the Goldsmith Co to be cleaned, went also to Douglas where I had my hair done and then home to dress and be ready at 7 for Major White -T who came for me to do Julius Caesar. We dined at the dear old Troc and at 8 went on to His Majesty's to see this splendid tragedy. It is very well put on and Basil Gill and Arthur Bouchier excellent, only I cannot away with Tree as Mark Antony, he is too Treeish for words, so full of mannerisms, mouthings and gestures, but anyhow the man is a genius. The heat was awful and between the acts we went and stood out on the balcony where the air was lovely. We supped at Scotts, quite a nice little restaurant in Piccadilly Circus, where the food is excellent and company ordinary.

May 30th
I returned home today. Such heat and so airless, storms hover round but pass us by and the garden is drying up. I long for a real good rain.

May 31st, Wednesday
A very busy day. Baker and I did all the bedding out, snapdragons in the four corner beds - stocks, asters etc in the side ones - geraniums in the big bed under the windows also in vases and boxes. When I was immersed in this work of art Herman and Arthur Cope came in having come over from Sandhurst. They were boiling and went off directly to have a bath. Then we had tea. When thoroughly replete I made them help me with gardening and at 6.30 the children and party arrived. The boys stayed to dinner and left about 9.30, such a nice couple, so unaffected and free from frills. I am going over to their dance on the 30th, and am to chaperone Rita there.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
May was an important month at Aldershot, and the King's Parade was something not to be missed. Units of the army processed in front of the monarch, who usually attended a church service as well on the following Sunday. Wynne was always complaining that she could never attend to invited events as her husband was always away on manoeuvres. You can follow these links to 1913, May and September. The "on manoeuvres" link will let you listen to Ysobel's memories on September 13th 1913. There is also a short description in May 1912.

Listen to Ysobel's memory of the Parade that took place each year, and which Wynne describes visiting this year.



You can see the Cody crash she describes, which took place in 1913, if you click here.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.description: All the diaries contain illustrations as well as the additional cuttings and photos. The one is particularly rich, probably because Wynne's sister, who was a great watercolourist, was around to add extra pictures. Below is a classic example of one page, May 14th:

may.description:
The Diary - in MAY...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

This is the start of that famous, perfect Edwardian summer.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.
Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Back at Wynne's old family home, Brookfield, and with Mother now available to do the painting after Eve had supplied the additional material for August.

This is Brookfield house in - very overgrown. You can see other pictures of the house, from 1890 to the present day, if you click here.

...and three youngsters in the garden, with the summer house in the background where Wynne liked to read.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 8th

Back at Brookfield, staying with her Mother, Wynne is occupied with a charity bazaar. Her daughter has an abscess and is operated upon on the kitchen table.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Friday
As Mother has this bazaar next Wednesday we are awfully hard at work getting things ready and spent the whole of today pricing the goods. She has a lot of awfully pretty painted things and Indian embroidery and I am holding a pottery stall of Dunmere, Barnstaple and Torquay stuff. It is a great work as there are so many things to think about. I do hope it'll be a fine day and a success.

Sept 2nd
Eve returned today from Salisbury. She intended coming yesterday but was delayed by Win's teeth which required Farebrother's attention. The Bazaar and nothing but the bazaar fills our minds and hands at present and we are at it all day long.

Sept 3rd, Sunday
The season still keeps up its odd and extraordinary record. A pitiless and blazing sun all day long and not a cloud to be seen. We are horrified to find that the main well is drying up, the kitchen well has long since gone dry and what will happen if this one follows suit I cant think because the whole house depends upon it. There is only 6 inches of water there and we are necessarily very much restricted as to baths etc…the place looks burnt and dried and tired, the lawns are brown, there is not a flower in the garden and the river like a road, all the fish being dead long since of course. As far as I can see there is no sign of a change. I went to church twice, it was Harvest Festival and Eve and I of course were let in for decoration yesterday. I do hope those at Hale will be finished with before I return.

Sept 4th, Monday & Sept 5th, Tuesday
Both these days were spent alike in breathless work and preparation. I have had no time to do any writing or anything besides endless last jobs arranging and pricing etc and rushing about from morning till night. My little Nootle has developed an abscess on her head, the result of a blow on the door down at Lee. It is thought by H Daniell who inspected it today that she must have grazed it and got some foreign body into it so causing irritation and poison. He says he must operate upon it with chloroform and is to do it on Thursday morning. I do so hate the prospect but he says it will be nothing bad and it is naturally the only thing to do.

Sept 6th
I fear we have suffered something of a disappointment. The great day is over, the weather has been perfect, but the attendance was poor and we only made £30. There is £20 more in the bank so the Church clock for which we are working has £50 towards it but we expected to make quite that at the show alone. I cant tell quite how it resulted but it seemed a lot of work for that small sum. We were up at 6.0 working away like mad. We had much kind help from various people and the Blandford tradesmen were most generous and most of our county acquaintances turned up but not many villagers but as the clock is only to cost £60 it will not be difficult to find the extra.

Sept 7th, Thursday
At 9.30 both the Daniells turned up and after all the preparations were completed, administered chloroform to my Nootle and performed the operation. It was over pretty soon and the child slept till 11.15, waking fearfully hungry but wasn't allowed food till 4.0. I am so thankful it is over and the Drs are quite satisfied. Poor baby she was so good and they said they never saw any child make less fuss or be more good.

Now click on the arrow and hear how Ysobel recalls that operation...


Sept 8th
Mother had been asked to have a drawing room meeting today for Waif boys but Mr Baverstock who is the mover got ill and it had to be put off in a hurry, however Miss Wingate, Mrs Bugg and Mrs Castleman Smith and her Mother turned up! My dear B (Scratchley, the ex-governess) also came today, it is so awfully jolly having her again.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This interesting postcard is stuck into the diary for September, and records the very first official air mail post. On September 9th, Gustav Hamel flew a small bi-plane from Hendon to Windsor, and as you can see, this publicity card from Schweppes was in his small post-bag. Amongst many other major events, this story is told in Juliet Nicolson's wonderful book about this summer of , called "The Perfect Summer". While this diary is one small record of an individual's experience of that year, her book covers the whole country, from monarch to dock worker.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 9th - 15th

She leaves Brookfield and reumes the daily round at Hale, feeling strange being home again. The rain finally arrives on 13th, and they all turn out for the Searchlight Tattoo at Government House.
viewer_4.description:
September 9th, Saturday
Aim and Rita (Wynne's Aunt and cousin) left today for Ireland where they are to stay for 3 weeks with Topsy (Brenda, another cousin, sister to Yso) at Queenstown (since 1922 known as Cobh). We miss them much. B and I went up to the Church yard after tea, it was quiet and peaceful up there and I did the Father's grave. It seems so natural having her again and there is always so much to talk over with her about old times and all our mutual friends. I do hope I may claw her in at Hale but she is very difficult to catch.

Sept 10th
Eve and I walked over to Crawford to early service this morning. What a charming little church it is now, so beautifully done up and restored. I am sure nothing could be in better taste than everything in it. We didn't go to morning service but went in the evening instead. I wish one could always do this, especially here, as it is so frightfully long and PB will insist on having Mattins Litany communion service and sermon every Sunday. It is stupid and shortsighted of him.

Sept 11th
This masterpiece is by Mother to show our sorrow and sadness at departing for alas the day has come to return home. We left at 2 and got back at 7, to find all well and very glad to see my dear Poggy again.

Sept 12th
It seems so odd beginning the daily round and common task again, after 6 weeks absence. I drove into Town in the morning where I did the months stores and various other commissions. I also unpacked my treasure cabinet which I dragged back with me this time. Numerous chores that required attention were seen to and fowls were looked after so the day went.

Sept 13th, Wednesday
I have been busy developing my photo films today and got through 3 rolls, tomorrow I hope to be able to print them. An extraordinary thing is happening today, it is raining, and really coming down splendidly. It is weeks and weeks since we have seen such a thing as this and I am sure such a summer has never been known.

Sept 14th
My entire morning was spent in printing and I got through 79 prints! It was most interesting seeing all the various Lee scenes and I am sending off fat budgets to Eve and Win for their collection. It has stopped raining but a cold wind is blowing. The Grays and a friend of theirs, a Miss Campbell, dined with us tonight and we all went on to see the Searchlight Tattoo at Government House afterwards. Last year we dined there beforehand and did it in style! but we got very good seats and saw beautifully. I so much enjoy this splendid sight, the massed bands of 12 regiments besides Highland pipes and massed drums and fifes. When the Largo and Dvorak's Humoresque and Abide With Me were all played I felt creepy and wanted as usual to cry. It was all so beautiful and impressive.

Sept 15th
I washed my hair this morning and also got a fit of clearing out and throwing away on me, I cast out aged relics right and left sparing nothing. I wonder I didn't cast myself away with the rest of the rubbish. We gardened all the afternoon clearing out rubbish there too but there is an enormous change in the temperature and it was cold and windy.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: These are photographs Wynne took of her friend's garden (see September 21st) - and I can only assume that the rather spectral figure on the right of the frame is the Geoff she mentions, see below!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 16th - 23rd

Home duties - and no blackberries to be found anywhere! Wynne goes to London to shop and see "The Chocolate Soldier".
viewer_6.description:
September 16th, Saturday
I spent the morning in the town doing 101 shoppings, met Poggy down there and we both came up together. We gardened hard all the afternoon and evening and Colonel Fitzroy and Joe came to tea. It has grown so cold and autumnal since the rain, alas! The summer has flown.

Sept 17th, Sunday
Although we have had splendid rain yet the weather doesn't seem inclined to break yet and today has been perfect, but the change in atmosphere is extraordinary. I should think there was a tremendous drop for the nights are quite cold now and the air feels nippy. This sweet little picture was done by Mother. I have made both she and Eve very busy all over this diary but I do wish I could do it too! Colonel Sandilands came to tea, a nice little man, and the Terrys turned up too. She poor girl has been rather suffering from a shock owing to a motor smash up she had whilst driving with Major Gray, but luckily they were not hurt. She was still looking a bit shook.

Sept 18th
Another perfect day but distinctly autumnal. I drove down to the baths where I had a lovely swim. I intended going next Thursday but heard this morning that there is to be no more clean water till next Monday so that's off then! I went to call upon the Langrishes, dear funny old people, they have a sweet garden full of lovely fruit and flowers all of which he manages himself. I had to inspect every plant and tree and they presented me with watercress and three lovely red apples for the children and one huge one weighing 18 ounces! Mrs Boone came to tea and at 6 I went over to the Rectory to a conference upon Mothers Unionism, a branch of which is to be started here in October and I have consented to take the chair!

Sept 19th
Waking up this morning to find a most perfect day we accordingly made our minds to go out blackberrying directly after lunch. I went at my photography with much diligence all the morning and developed my last two rolls of Lee films including some of the Divisional manoeuvres which have turned out excellent. We lunched at 1 and at 2.30 started forth, Poggy and the 3 children in the cart whilst Miss Male, Maggie and myself bicycled. We rode over to Crondall, finding none, there we were directed to a common round Farnham way so on we went for miles still finding none or next to none, finally we gave it up as a bad job, had tea in a wood and came back through Farnham. I haven't bicycled so far for ages and was surprised to find I didn't feel it more. The country is simply lovely round there but I never saw fewer blackberries in my life.

Sept 20th
Down to the old Iron Room in the morning to an S.S.& A meeting (Staff and Soldiers Association?).

Sept 21st
H and I bicycled to Whitmead today and Joe drove his legged charger. We went to see Geoff's neat little house and garden, it is the sweetest little place and the house has been built entirely after his own design, whilst he himself made the garden, it is all like a toy and I took two photos of it which I hope will be a success. (They were - you can see them in the previous window).

Sept 22nd
I started off to Town this morning in order to stay with the Todds and do a theatre with White T. On arrival taxied straight to Norfolk Sq where I left my box going on by tube to Evans, B&H etc to shop. At 5 I returned to the Todds to have tea and dress for the evening. I met White T at the Troc at 7 where we dined, going on afterwards to the Chocolate Soldier which I had never seen before, a delightful musical play. We supped as usual at the Carlton afterwards and sat there till it was time to seek our downies (beds). White T looks very well but thinner than ever.

September 23rd, Saturday
Off to Whiteleys in the morning to buy a tea tray and photo books for Eve and then I said goodbye to my most kind host and hostess and drove off to keep an appointment at my Club with Lady Fulton. I returned by the 3.5 and got home rather late, the train being very slow, and found Eve had arrived. She leaves London on Wednesday and is busy over last jobs. She left Win at Sherborne yesterday and feels parting with her very much poor dear. (Eve was going back to India, so would not see her daughter again for another huge gap - in fact I think because the War intervened this may well have been the last time she saw her daughter until 1919).

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 24th - 30th

Eve stays with them and they all go to London for a final night out before she departs for India. They go to see "Peggy" at the Gaiety, but the farewell makes Wynne anything but gay.
viewer_8.description:
Sept 24th, Sunday
It is so very nice having been able to get Eve here just her last few days. She and I drove over to the Garrison Church to service and went in afterwards to have a talk with the General where I had put up the pony.

Sept 25th, Monday
I drove Eve down to the station in the morning and then went on to have a swim. The bath is well heated and so beautifully clean. I then went to meet the Hutches at the station who came down from Town for lunch with us. They both look so much better and return to India in about a fortnight

Sept 26th
By the 10.2 we went up to Town today and drove straight to the Strand Palace where we luckily got a room and then went to meet Mother who had taken a room at the Club, they both tried to get into the S.P. yesterday but failed, it is always very full and only a chance if one gets in. At about 12.30 Ni Elliot turned up and the delightful old dear proposed taking us all to dine, theatre and supper tonight, so H and I went to K.P. and got five seats for "Peggy", then Mother and N went off to lunch and we to the stores, lunching at the Grand Grill Room on our way. Footsore and weary we taxied back to the Club where we had tea and as I was leaving to go to Douglas (her hairdresser) Mother and Ni came in, their meter showing 10/-!! and they had been driving around Hampstead!! Not having made an appointment with Miss Worrall I found her engaged of course but got another excellent woman Long by name and she did my hair beautifully. I then proceeded to the S.P. where I met H and we dressed, arriving at 7 to the Rendezvous in Soho, an odd little Bohemian haunt very full and excellent food, we had a wild and shrieking dinner, all being very bon camarade, and the waiters thought us mad. Then off we drove in the two taxis to see Peggy, this play is just lately on and I don't know when I laughed more. We all rolled helplessly back and fore with tears also rolling and really by the end I felt quite tired but what would one expect with Connie Ediss and E Payne playing the fool. Such a good cast and so clever and smart. Nowhere but in England can they produce a thing like that, such clever witty songs, such pretty dancing and such lovely colouring. We then squashed into one taxi, "very hug", and ended up our ripping evening at the dear old Carlton of joyous memories. One never goes there without seeing someone one knows and at the next table to ours sat Frank Roe and Mr Sheepshanks with two ladies, one of which was F.R's wife. At 1 we left and departed to our respective homes.

The Carlton Hotel, in Pall Mall.

Sept 27th
Alas the sad day of Eve's departure has arrived and we all went to Victoria to see her off. It was as horrid as usual and I am glad it is over. When she had gone Mother and I went to Hampton to choose carpet and cretonne for her new flat which she has taken, No 7 Shelley Court, Tite Street, Chelsea, and into which she hopes to move about the end of October. I am so glad this has all been decided on and the peace of winter arrangements assured. I am sure it is a splendid move. We went off at 3.5 meeting Denys Highton who is coming down to us for a few days.

Sept 28th
Shirts have begun again and as Mrs Kavanagh is away I have to act as Vice P in her absence, so Major Chisham and I worked away at them till 12 and then I picked Poggy up at the Office and so home.

Sept 29th
I was asked to do church decorating this morning but I was firm and refused. I do not wish to become a convenient handle in this place and find I am quite enough used up!

Sept 30th, Saturday
The last day of September, how this year has fled. I have never known one go faster, it is the result of the perfect weather we have had and our lovely time at Lee. The wind today is icy and I have got a cold! Drove down into Farnham with Dee and the two children to shop and gardened after lunch but it was not enjoyable and I was so cold. We have started a fire in the evenings.

And so ended the "perfect summer" of 1911....

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Peggy was played by Phyllis Dare:

And after the show?

This is the Carlton Hotel's Palm Court...an exterior of the hotel can be seen in the diary entry. Wynne adored this hotel, and went there regularly after the theatre. This illustration is from a souvenir booklet that she stuck into her 1908 diary.

september.description:
The Diary - in SEPTEMBER...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The Perfect Summer is coming to an end - a month of colder weather and farewells...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Spring at last...Wynne's niece and son in the garden, and below, Thomas with Ysobel and the toy cart...

Listen to Ysobel's memories of the garden at Hale, and the escapades they got up to:

Below you can see another view of the long wall, and also Young washing Peter the dog - presumably this time Thomas and Baby were in good favour!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: April 1st - 7th Wynne celebrates 2 years living near Aldershot, where her husband is now a brigadier-general. It is Easter, and there is even time for a journey in a newfangled motor car.
viewer_2.description:
As an army wife, Wynne was living in Aldershot. The family moved there in 1910, when her husband was promoted to the final position he would occupy before his retirement in 1914. An announcement in the Morning Post in April 1910 which Wynne stuck in her diary for that year reads: " From today Col. H.K.Jackson, from half-pay, will take up command of the Artillery of the 2nd Division at Aldershot, with the temporary rank of brigadier-general. " They settled into a very comfortable house, and as the posting was for four years, had the prospect of a settled existence....as she wrote at the time: "how heavenly it is to have married a man who is thought worth giving a billet such as this to..." (You can see the house in the next page view).


April 1st 1912
A new month and a new week and this day 2 years ago Poggy got this billet. I can hardly believe that half our time here has actually gone, it is horrid to think of. I held my Mothers' Meeting this afternoon, 29 women and 13 babies, but they are all very good and with the aid of diplomacy in the shape of biscuits the babies never utter! I have nearly come to the end of these meetings, the women so much appreciate them but I couldn't keep on all summer.

April 5th, Good Friday
Once more this sad day is upon us. It always fills me with gloom but we spent it very nicely and quietly going to the 10.30 service with the children and on to the 3 hours afterwards at the Chapel which was taken by a Mr Griffiths - it was very quiet and restful. We had an early tea and did a lot of gardening afterwards. It is so nice to have Poggy home and he is free from Office now till Tuesday. I only hope it keeps fine for the holidays although I fear this year many will be disappointed on account of train suspension.

April 6th, Saturday
We have motored about 118 miles today! At 8.0 we breakfasted and I then hurriedly gave out linen, did my house and rushed off to the Church to decorate the chancel rails and at 10.15 the car called here for us and picking up the Grays we motored off down to Brighton where we lunched at the Metropole and came home a different way reaching home at 7.0. It was a lovely trip and I did enjoy it, the country was just looking perfect with all the fresh Spring green and masses of blackthorn blossom which is very much in evidence this year. We had much amusement from the freaks at the Hotel. I have never seen such men and women and clothes, they really were unique and fit only for a comic paper, we simply laughed helplessly and I wished for a Kodak!

Click to hear about money and the household at Hale


April 7th. Easter Sunday
Our whole household has been to its Easter Communion today, some at 7.0 and others at 8.0. I say our whole household but I know naught of Young - I don't believe he has ever been to communion since he has been with us but I cannot control his ways.

(Young was now acting as the butler, and had probably been Herbert's batman. His daughter married Dickens, of Dickens and Jones, the famous London shop - an example of the upward mobility gradually taking place during that period. The establishment at Upton Lodge was probably the largest that Wynne had run, now that Herbert was in an important post. She had a cook, 2 parlourmaids, a butler, a kitchenmaid, a gardener, a gardener's boy and a groom. They also had three horses, a pony and trap for short trips and a brougham drawn by one of the horses.
In a sad epilogue to this story, here is a headline from the UK Guardian newspaper of Friday 17th, 2005...as you can see if you put Dickens and Jones into search, Wynne would have been very upset!)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Wynne's sitting room in the house at Farnham, with the desk where the entries from 1910 - 1914 were all written...and below, the exterior.
Notice the candlestick on the desk - it was either that or oil lamps...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 8th - 14th

Birthdays and expeditions to buy school uniforms. The children are growing up.
viewer_4.description:
April 8th
Yesterday was Win's (her niece's) birthday, dear child she is actually 13. It doesn't seem all that time since I held that small grey worm in my arms at Motihare in that dreadful little bungalow where she was born. She was to have been with us all the holidays but Miss Hoyle wrote reporting chickenpox and so for fear of infection she is with Mother until she is safe - such a bore.


April 10th
Into Aldershot early to sit on a committee meeting, it is a waste of time this sort of job and I have so much of it. We sat for a solid hour cackling and jawing over points we couldn't hope to settle and came away feeling most unprofitable.


April 12th, Friday
Today the first signs of Pinkie's (Thomas) growing up showed in the fact that he and I made an expedition to Town in order to get his school outfit, just he and I , and it seemed so odd trotting about Town with my son!...we went down to the Scotch House where we tried on various garments and purchased all sorts of things, he looked such a quaint monkey in his Etons and Norfolks! I got a dark grey and a heather mixture, both very neat, an overcoat, underclothes of all sorts, bag, umbrella, sponges etc., bed linen and towel - in fact all the papfernalia common to the school boy. We then went on to Harrods where I did some shopping and we had a very nice tea and where I found a very comfortable ladies room with a ladies smoking room attached and where I had a cigarette! We caught the 5.30 down and got home by 7.30 - on the way up we saw a monoplane flying at Brooklands and at Waterloo a whole heap of guards evidently just returned from Strike Duty all of which excited Pinkie very much.


April 13th
My Nootle (her daughter, Ysobel) is 8 today, bless her, and we had a great "present" hunt in the morning and 15 children for an Easter Egg Hunt after lunch. A lovely fine day and all very happy.


April 14th
The weather though cloudy and dark today still holds up but we want rain badly and the garden sadly needs refreshing....nice letters from Ell and Eve, the former full of a pig stick where with 3 spears they got 10 pig!
(Pig sticking was a very popular pastime in India, and involved hunting pig from a horse. In the margin of this entry Wynne has written: The loss of the Titanic)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne's late entry describing the loss of the Titanic.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: April 19th - 22nd The Loss of the Titanic. Wynne catches up with her diary, and relates the story that had Edwardian society transfixed. It doesn't interfere with her busy life though.
viewer_6.description:
April 19th, Friday
I have been neglecting my Diary and am therefore "writing it up", in consequence of which I have forgotten to mention the occurrence of the most frightful sea disaster ever known in the memory of man. On Sunday 14th shortly before midnight the Titanic of the White Star line, the largest ship in the world, struck an iceberg and at 2.30 she sank in 2 miles of water. This was her maiden voyage and she had only been about 4 days at sea. She carried on this occasion 2340 souls, 1635 of these have perished only 705 being saved, the papers are full of the most fearful horrors and for sheer dramatic sensation the scene can hardly have been equalled, nearly all who were saved were women and crew, the latter mostly having been picked up later, there was no confusion or panic and the shock was so slight that some went on playing cards and few realized the danger but it soon dawned in upon them and when the boats drew away taking the few who were saved the wretched remainder must have realized the horror of the situation for she began very soon to sink. We hear that the band lined up and played "Nearer My God to Thee" until the water touched their feet, the ships lights were full on almost up to the end, she then broke in two, her machinery was heard to rattle and tear out of her and so with 1600 souls that most splendid invention, "the last word" in ship building, went to the bottom. It is all too frightful to realize, she was fitted up with a swimming bath, racquet courts, gymnasium, Palm Courts, private suites which cost £870 and every sort of luxury man could invent and when one realizes that Nature without the least effort destroyed this work of years in a few hours it does indeed make one feel small. Every day the papers contain fresh tales of heroism and the survivors who were picked up by the Carpathia have arrived in New York so we shall hear more details. That any were saved at all is simply due to "wireless" without which it would probably have been a second "Waratah" over again.

April 21st
So many years ago that I don't like to count them up I became engaged to that best of men, my man - was it emotion or the time of year that made it so hot? I wonder? but the atmosphere of the balcony at Watson's Hotel, Bombay lingers with me yet.

April 22nd
Very early this morning I drove Tom (her nephew who had been staying) to the station, we breakfasted at 7.0 and he caught the 8.4 train. Such a perfect morning though I was quite glad of the excuse of getting up. I had a most busy and buzzling day. H. had to go off to Brighton inspecting and Carol (another relation who had been staying) departed too so they went at about 2.0. I then betook myself to my MM (Mothers' Meeting) where I held a large and "festive" meeting, back to tea at 4.0 and off to Town at 6.0. I reached the flat (where her Mother was living) at 7.45 and hastily dressed to which Yso and Denys Vanrenen came. They have just arrived in Town from India both looking awfully well and just the same as ever. It was so jolly seeing them again and we had a long gossip about all and everything. (Yso was Wynne's favourite cousin - she appears in many of the very early diaries - check out Family and the story in Editor's Picks/A Young Victorian.)

(Phew! A typical Wynne day, in fact).

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The loss of the Titanic notwithstanding, Wynne managed to get up to town for some entertainments before the end of the month...here are two of her playbills:

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: April 23rd - 28th The family visit Herbert's relations at Springfield, and spend some time in London, where Wynne meets up with her cousins after a long absence.
viewer_8.description:
April 23rd, Tuesday
I set forth at 10.0 and went to Ebury Street to the Vans' rooms and there I saw my godchild and the wee one, such dear children, and it seems so odd to think of Yso with 2 babies. I am delighted to hear from her that Brenda's wish has at last been fulfilled and she has a daughter, she will I know be awfully pleased and what a good time that girl will have with her 3 brothers. (There is however a sad ending to this story of new arrivals - Doris, Wynne's godchild mentioned above, ended her life in a mental home, and Pauline, the much-longed for daughter Brenda had been waiting for, died aged 19 from a cat scratch).
Yso and I went off and did much shopping at Evans (D.H.Evans) and B&H (Bourne and Hollingsworth) and then met mother at the New Gallery with Thurie where we lunched going on our several ways when that was over. I personally hied me to Douglas (her hairdresser) where a Miss Dance attended me to my satisfaction, then home at 5.30 . Tom arrived as he was putting up at the flat and going to the opera with us. Mr Wingate surprized us by walking in too having come to Town to be present at the wedding of the Buggs' son. We heard all the home news and Mother asked him to join us at the opera. We then drove to the Hyde Park Hotel where we had a most excellent dinner with our dear Grays, it was a very amusing dinner and we laughed a great deal. Carol joined us at about 8 and we all went on to Covent Garden together. The Rheingold was given and I was glad as I have never heard it before. It went on continuously for 3 hours with no break but it seemed all too short. Dr Rottenberg conducted and Kirkby Lunn was singing. Aimee was of the party and we all returned to the flat for supper making a very gay and jolly party. The Grays took Aimee and Carol on their respective ways and then Tom and I proceeded to drag my bed into the drawingroom where I slept with much comfort.
Wynne continued in this manner - dashing back to Aldershot for meetings and to sort out shopping for her niece, Win, who was due back at school. Many of the people mentioned above are family - Thurie and Aimee were uncle and aunt to Wynne. They all seemed very close.

At the weekend the family decamped to Springfield, near Chelmsford, Herbert's family home, but they still stopped off in London on the way to take in a matinee - she was never one to miss a chance to get into a theatre! She saw Gerald du Maurier in a new piece, "Jelf's", but was not unduly impressed: "it is good because he is always nice but I've seen him in things I like better".


April 28th, Sunday
It is so pleasant and friendly and quiet here (at Springfield). After lunch Mabel and Tom and I went up the fields and sat under a hedge basking in the sun and eating grass! It was very lovely there but it made me sad to feel that it was the last Sunday I should spend with my dear Mabel who is so well now that she goes off to S.A. on the Ist June. I do hope she'll keep fit now. (Mabel Jackson went off to Portuguese East Africa to be a missionary).


By the end of the month the family were back at home in Aldershot.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
But for Edwardian theatregoers there were other outstanding considerations!

The evening headdress of nodding plume and blinding pin is a nuisance. But we must bear with it. In these days of baldness, 'tis a necessity.

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: - Wynne's home at Farnham, near Aldershot. She was a fanatical gardener.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 2nd - 7th

It's a terrible summer, with torrential downpours. Everyone is complaining, even the relatives in India...
viewer_2.description:
August was to prove another disappointing month for Wynne, in what was turning out to be a very poor summer - her complaints sound very contemporary. She spent it quietly at home in Farnham.

August 2nd
I went up by the 9.12 and by Tube and Underground got to Paddington at about 10 to 11. I there met my small son (who had been in quarantine at school after catching chickenpox), he having come up all the way from Malvern alone!

August 3rd
The children went down to the Legards party today and I did my duty on a round of calls which I had long wanted to do.

August 4th
Such depressing letters from our dear things in India. The rains after having held off till nearly too late had come with such violence as to spoil and ruin the crop so that prospect's were once more nil. It is a hopeless profession and a hopeless country to make money out of.

August 5th
Being Bank Holiday the yearly sports were held on the Green and I gave away the prizes being presented afterwards with a lovely bouquet and felt like the Lady Mayoress!! It was fine at intervals but the weather at present is too terrible and we are sodden and mouldy with constant rain.

August 7th
The poor Fitzroys were by way of having a Refuge Home Sale in their garden this afternoon, as usual it poured but we went down and found a sad 5 or 6 people and that's about all - too frightful and I felt so sorry for them poor things but what can one do with such a frantic summer as this.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Wynne had various servants to help her in the house at Farnham. Here you can see the washing being done in the background - no machines in those days, just a lot of hard work. Notice the large wooden barrel with its wooden stick for beating the washing, and on the left attached to the table, what looks like a mangle.

Her youngest is busy playing with the chickens. (This is in fact a 1911 photo but is included here to show the house surroundings again - if you check out 1911 you will see another shot of the yard).

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 8th - 14th

Rain and yet more rain...Wynne's entries feel very contemporary!
viewer_4.description:
August 8th
For the 5th time lately I tried to have Tennis here today and about 8 valiant ones turned up, played one set and then had to chuck it, its too fearful really, torrents and buckets fell as usual and nearly drowned us.

August 9th
It has actually been pretty decent today and we bicycled over to the H.W.s to see the garden. Its looking awfully pretty and sweet and seems so sheltered and quite untouched or spoilt by rain. Our garden is a wreck.

August 10th
Torrents of rain fall as usual but this season there is no earthly use in taking any notice of it so we went to the 19th Sports. Joe came over to lunch and went also and we took the 3 children who greatly enjoyed themselves. It was rather cold and cheerless and I was greatly bored.

August 11th
We all managed to get down to Kirk this morning and after lunch I took my 3 kids up to the common where we spent a most delightful afternoon sitting about picking heather and making gardens, but a frightful storm coming over I hurried them home and only just got back in time when down it came.

August 12th
Alas poor grouse! how Ell (her brother) must be longing to be at home. I had such depressed letters from them this mail - crops very bad, spoilt by the rain and many things upside down apparently, Mother too writes in the depths, her sciatica is bad, the weather is worse and the state of the garden worst, so my poor ones are not cheerful at present. I took the children to play in a cricket match at the Bruces today but of course rain prevented their playing.

August 13th
At a quarter to 5 we arose this morning and Poggy left on the Medical Manoeuvres. I went down to the corner to see them go off and it was bitterly cold. We were electrified to hear today that General Lawson is engaged to be married! to Lady Lathom. Wonders will never cease! gay old thing, but what does she do it for!

August 14th
I have spent a most delightful morning. At 7.15 I went out with Capt. Skippy in the car to Frensham Mill Bridge to the Otter Meet. It was actually a fine morning and we ran or walked rather, for the day was blank one (ie: no otters were found), through the valleys of Moor Park and Waverley - it was quite lovely and I just enjoyed it enormously. I got back at 2.15 and straightway went to sleep!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne was very proud of her tennis court, though the weather in seldom allowed anyone to play. Upton Lodge was the first really substantial house she lived in - previous married quarters were comfortable, but often amounted to huts built with corrugated iron...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 15th - 22nd

To compound the miserable weather, both daughters catch chickenpox from their brother, recently returned from boarding school.
viewer_6.description:
August 15th, Thursday
All morning I was taking Mrs Kavanagh's Shirts, we had a specially big go this morning and I didn't get out till 12.30.
We dined at 7.30 tonight and went to the Military Tattoo, perfectly lovely as usual and I always love it.

August 16th
This afternoon we tried for the 6th or 7th time to have tennis but only about 2 sets could be played and it rained nearly all the time. I'm sick of it.

August 17th
It has drizzled on and off all day long and I've had the entire day at home, such a treat, I've just done household chores and gardened....letter from Eve and Ell (sister and brother in India) tonight to my joy, they are screeching for rain now, just having been in flood, it is too odd.

August 18th, Sunday
All trailed down to church, it being fine for once, and I let Mag (nanny) go off after lunch and took over the children who were very good amusing themselves with books and beads and stamps.

August 19th
My Ell's birthday, bless him, the creature is 38 I believe today, how old we all are getting, Eve actually reaches 40 next Jan, I simply can't realize it, and I've forgotten my own age!
Nootie and Baby are covered with spots, alas and alack. Is it only sand fleas or is it chickenpox - Tanner shall decide tomorrow.

August 20th
Alas it is chickenpox all right and I could kill the Dr who sent the boy back before he was free from infection. (Pink had caught it at Malvern, hence his delayed return for the holidays).
They are not bad luckily but Win (Wynne's niece, Eve's daughter) is bound to have it and its all most inconvenient.

August 21st
Horrible weather as usual, it never does anything but pour with rain every day and all day. We spent the night with the Findlays and they sent their car for us at 4.0. They have such a jolly house and grounds, 3 horses and 2 cars! A dinner party of 14 took place and Flying Demon afterwards, what a mad game and everybody cheated hard all round of course.

August 22nd
The kind Findlays conveyed us both at different times into Camp, H to his office and I to Shirts. It was actually a find day and we gardened until 8.0, such a lovely treat to see the sun again.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The children largely amused themselves - though occasionally Father could be engaged to wheel them around in the garden barrow...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
August 23rd - 31st

The Royal Artillery Sports Day livens things up, as does Baby and a garden party which was not rained on!
viewer_8.description:
August 23rd, Friday
The Skippys had asked me to stand proxy this afternoon at their baby's christening but I was afraid of carrying infection to it so I didn't go.

August 27th, Tuesday
Actually a fine day and so lucky because the R(oyal) A(rtillery) Sports were held today. We had to go over early as H was judging. The Hurdwoods came to lunch and came with us and also the two boys (Pink had a friend staying with him). It was a gay and pleasant gathering and one met a great many old friends, all the people from the various camps came in and I gave away the prizes at the end. I sent for S(ergeant) M(ajor) Richards who is now in 1 and arranged to go and see his wife who lives in Barracks. Hers is a curious history, related to John Petty Orchardson etc...she marries a common soldier and comes down to this but I believe she is quite happy.

August 28th
We spent the whole day upon the common, took lunch and played games and had tea brought up. It was lovely all the early part of the day but grew cold and cheerless towards the end, alas for the summer is really gone.

August 29th
H went off to Springfield (Chelmsford - his family home) yesterday to stay the night and I went up early to Town today to meet him. We did a lot of business but I was glad to get home. Town is a howling wilderness now full of strange beings and horror.

August 30th
We had arranged to have a blackberry picnic with Joe today but the rain descended in torrents so of course it was out of the question, but we valiantly took our tea to Pine Needle Wood and H came too and we all pretended to like it very much.

August 31st, Saturday.
I drove Baby over to the H.Woods this morning to see the picture Fergus is painting of her, it is very sweet and pretty and he is presenting it to us. On the way home Baby seeing a lot of sparrows sitting on the telegraph wires says: "Do you know Young says they are getting full of fleas ready to go, they only live on fleas you know", but I asked where do they get them, I wonder. "Out of the wires I suppose" she answered. I shrieked inwardly.
Mrs Fitzroy and Mrs Franks had a joint party this afternoon in the former's garden. Luckily it was fine and the lovely band of the 19th Hussars played such perfect things: Madame Butterfly, Valse Triste etc...the place was looking very pretty and a good many people were there. We ate heaps of tea and fruit, Mrs Legard and I vying with one another who could eat the most.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The Royal Artillery Sports Day,

Wynne's husband, as the C.O., is walking in front across the parade ground, second from the right. In the picture below this, some of the onlookers arrayed in their finery along the edge of the field:

august.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.excerpt: December 1st - 8th A dark and cold month, but Wynne has enjoyed her year at Upper Hale, Farnham
viewer_1.description:
December 1st
Here is the first day of the last month, how fast this year has fled away and what a very jolly year it has been. The cold is very bitter, unusually so for this time of year and snow has fallen on the Yorkshire moors. I was in charge of the children today, Nootle spent the afternoon reading and Baby painted strange things in a Suttons catalogue, her hair whisking in and out and creating much disturbance in her works of art. She sang little songs to herself all the time and carried on a sotto voce conversation about the lovely pictures she was making, she is a darling. They both are so awfully good, so contented and happy and both to my eyes such sweet little creatures with their lovely colouring, but then of course I am biased.

Wynne's week then continued with much work around her "district" - Mothers' meetings, entertaining and a Mission Sale, about which she commented "a pity that Mission work always savours of the pogbaggishness!"

December 6th
I have had a very busy day of doing various Xmas jobs and so trying to get a little ahead with the thousands of things there are to do and after dinner we went up to a Political Meeting at which the Member spoke and we had a Lantern Lecture on Home Rule, the Lecturer being a member of the National Union Association. He was indeed fluent but I think fancied himself to be Hamlet in disguise!

December 8th
If one hadn't in one to be depressed this weather would do it all right, so dark and gloomy, but its mild at present which is a blessing. The Grays came to tea, it is so nice to see them again, they have been away for 5 weeks at Cassel, he undergoing an operation to his poor nose.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.description: Wynne's entry for December 13th, with fashions celebrating Mr Punch's anniversary...

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.excerpt: December 9th - 17th A lament on modern dancing styles, a rush to do the Christmas shopping, (with the occasional theatre!), and the continued work of committees.
viewer_3.description:
December 9th, Monday
Here are pictures of the present style of dancing - look like 2 leaves blown together by the wind! simply hideous and rotten. Poggy has gone to Brighton today for two days inspection. I miss him much. Mothers Meeting 38 and a 1000 babies.

December 10th
My space is getting so short in this my old Diary that I have to cram 3 days into a page, I don't know how I came to have so little left. A dark wet day but very busy with a thousand jobs and rather glad to have it wet!
More meetings follow - Shirts, charity work and a lecture on Malay which Wynne enjoyed. She also continued to entertain and be entertained, though not always approving of the company: one poor man she described as "an ultra modern production of an unspeakable poseur - I can't away with his freakish ways".

December 13th
To Town today by the 9.12 and such a busy morning at the Stores, I simply flew around shopping hard and at 2.15 went off to the Tower where that kind Mr Mitchell took us all round such interesting places and I just enjoyed it enormously. At 6.0 I flew off back to Waterloo to pick up my box then to the Flat (her Mother's) to dress, to dinner came PG, and took me to see "Drake" at his Majesties, a lovely play and we went on to the Carlton afterwards there to quiz the weird frights assembled. A very jolly day.

December 14th
This morning more and more shopping with Mother, lunching at my Club and on to hear Carreno at the Queens Hall, a most splendid performance I did enjoy it. Then we went to tea at Mother's new Club, the Travellers and County, quite a nice place and admirable situation in Piccadilly, but I should very much hate to leave the old Empress which is now on a really sound basis.

December 16th, Monday
A nursing committee at 12.15 and a Mothers' Meeting at 2.0. Oh joy and rapture wild! One woman fainted and I dont wonder as the atmosphere in that room is awful! but they will have it. (Wynne is referring to the heat - she preferred all windows to be thrown open!)

December 17th
The time is so short and there is so much to do that every day is just stuffed with jobs but how I do love it.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.description: The cast list for the production of the play about Sir Francis Drake that Wynne saw at His Majesties...

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.excerpt:
December 18th - 24th

Preparations for Christmas continue at a frantic pace - shopping, parcels to post, and lots of children's parties to attend. Wynne's two daughters are joined by her son and her niece, back from school.
viewer_5.description:
December 18th, Wednesday
Poggy was away on a route march all day, and such a day, snow showers and icy wind. I felt thankful for being a woman and having the option of staying indoors, besides one wants all the time one can get now-a-days.

December 19th
We went up to Town today to gather in Win and Pinky who arrived back from school, it is such a joy meeting them at the station. Such a bustle and excitement. We all went to the Flat were we had lunch and then rushed out to do shopping returning by the 5.55. Nootie and Baby meanwhile had been to the Allasons Xmas Tree.

December 20th
I had to attend the Infants Tree at the Schools today, and then we had a long and weary drive to the St Clairs to dinner.

December 21st
Mother came down today and I went and met her whilst the children went to the Edens Xmas Tree. They are most awfully gay.

December 22nd
The Skippys came in to dinner last night bringing with them his sister, a nice girl but so plain which seems strange his being so good looking. I stayed at home with Mother today, not feeling awfully fit and we got through a lot of jobs, one always seems so driven at this time of year.

December 23rd
I spent the morning sending off more and more parcels and more cards and letters but at last I think I have got all off, what a ripping and exciting time it is! At 3.0 I set off with the children to get another Tree, this time at the Duffus where we had also a conjurer and dancing, it was a very gay show and the children got such nice presents and enjoyed their dancing - at least all but Noot who hates dancing!

December 24th
Such a busy day, at 9.45 to the Church to decorate. On arrival I found Mrs Watson was in bed with flu so the Church was left in our hands. I just did my altar rails and rushed off into Farnham to do many last shoppings, the place was like a distracted beehived, every one on the same errand. I got home to lunch and decorated the house all the afternoon, then we played games with the children whilst I worked away at Gran's night caps for tomorrow, then we prepared their stockings and then at bed time we stole up stairs to place these misshapen limbs on their bed ends. Nootle is still a firm believer and asks how many children Father Xmas has and who his Father was!!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.description: Christmas Day, - the first page of Wynne's entry for the day...

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.excerpt:
December 25th - 31st

Christmas...stockings, presents and the Tree...

and the end of 1912 celebrated with a String Hunt and a game of "Giggipeg".
viewer_7.description:
December 25th, Christmas Day
Very early this morning 4 children came creeping into our room each laden with their stockings which they opened with much excitement on our beds, and soon we were covered with a litter of pencils, paper, sweets, apples, oranges etc...what is there I wonder so intensely exciting in a stocking, I can myself remember it well.
It has been a pouring wet day torrents fell all day long but despite the fact dear old Gran got down to Church and stayed to communion which Mr Watson kindly brought down to her seat. Mother was so awfully bad that she didn't venture out. After lunch we simply flew about carrying in all the presents to the dining room and dressing the tree in which we got Maggie's help and by 4 we were ready and had tea. To this came the Skippies, Capt. Masters, Colonel Sandilands and Mr Burn so for our tree we had pleasant additions. At 5.0 it was lighted up, the magic bell was sounded and in trooped all the children and servants, the men, their wives and children. When all the presents had been distributed and the tree stripped I turned my attention to my own presents and there among many other lovely ones I found in a tin tobacco box Mother's lovely second diamond necklace. At first I thought it just a joke and was rather appalled at the thought of such a thing! but in very truth the thing belongs to me and I am proud! The men had the wildest games with the children who were dressed up in suits of red Indian kit given them by Mrs Skippy and Baby who clutched a packet of sweets tightly in her warm pud was found to have rubbed it well all over Capt Skippy's coat and trousers! It has been such a jolly day.

December 26th
A day of pouring rain again, such weather and fearful gales and loss at sea, how sad to think of when at this particular season everything feels somehow as though it ought to be gay. We were to have had tea at the Skippy's and gone to an entertainment in the Schools but it was too wet and so we shirked both but were fully occupied in writing dozens of letters to innumerable kind friends to thank for presents etc...

Letter writing and church took up the next few days. Wynne expressed the hope that her friends would lose their pens, ink and paper! The children went off to other parties, some becoming rather seedy, no doubt as a result of over indulgence. Wynne's niece, Win (Lees) was kept in, and spent Sunday reading "The Last Days of Pompeii" "with her longs legs spread out in front of her!"

December 31st
Mother and H went over to lunch at the Grays whilst I stayed at home and prepared for my childrens' party and got Maggie to help me do the string entanglements for the String Hunt, this took us the best part of an hour and we could not of course commence until the kids were dressed and downstairs. The Kavanaghs, Howards, Camerons and Margaret Duffus came and after all the string had been unravelled we played wild games, a new one introduced by the Howards called "Giggipeg", most thrilling and entertaining. This evening being the last we sat playing Dummy Bridge till 12.0 when we went out to listen to the bells at Farnham and to let the New Year in. Alas I am sad 1912 has gone it has been such a jolly year in every way, and we have been so awfully happy. One always wonders when one stands on the brink of a new year what it will bring forth. Mais nous verrons, and when 1913 ends I will try and remember to take out this Diary and read these words. Goodbye.

(There is no evidence Wynne did this - she did occasionally go back and annotate, but not in this case...)

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.description:
At the back of each Diary Wynne often stuck in fashion plates, usually with a comment about how awful they seemed, though sometimes with a more covetous little entry. Of these ladies, she merely said:
"The Winter kit for ".

Check out Fashion for the overview.

december.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Springfield Place, Chelmsford...

Wynne and Herbert often came to Chelmsford to stay with Herbert's mother, who lived in a large house on the edge of town. The house, called Springfield Place, still stands, and is Grade 2 listed.
The family appear to have vacated it on the death of Herbert's mother, and by the time of the First World War it was in use by the Army, as you can see in the photograph at the bottom of this page. The photo below shows the house in its heyday, covered in creepers, and with Cox the coachman posed at the front, waiting to take the family into town...

The house is described as follows: "Red brick, of 2 storeys with attics, dormer-windowed, behind and through tall parapet. Front of three bays and 9-window range, central bay of 5 windows recessed, with stone Ionic porch, pedimented window over, red brick cambered arches and jambs and red brick to principle quoins. Stone eaves cornice is moulded, on modillions, above which are floating projections with Diocletion windows. Roofs hipped and peg-tiled, framed in heavy oak. H-plan. 3 chimney stacks, red brick with octagonal shafts in groups of three. Inside, many 18th century details of good quality".
Wynne's children loved staying here, because they were relegated to the attics which ran the length of the house, and where they could play without interruption.

Springfield during the War

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: February 1st - 8th Based at Aldershot, Wynne is away staying with Herbert's parents at Springfield Place, in Chelmsford. She goes ice skating and finds a great junk shop in the the town.
viewer_2.description:
(Wynne is still staying at the Jackson family home, Springfield, In Chelmsford, where she has been since January 19th, though the visit is being interspersed with regular trips to London)


February 1st, Thursday
One bleak month has passed and here is the second. I spent my morning writing mail letters with my feet in the fender, burning my face whilst my back froze. It has been a black bitter day, no gleam of sun and a leaden sky.

February 2nd
That for which I have longed has come, and I have actually skated today for the first time for about 12 years, indeed it is 15 since the winter when Eve, Norman and I had such ripping days...I was awfully wobbly at first but it soon came back, and Oh! how lovely it is. The cold meanwhile in the house is awful, bed is the only warm spot, and bathing in lukewarm water a penance, however skating compensates for all.

February 3rd
It has been a glorious day, but alas a cold wind blowing. However we went up to the pond at 11.0 and there I skated until 4.0. ...we took our lunch out, children and all.

February 5th
I went up at about 11.30 to skate upon our pond but a bitter East Wind was blowing and I hardly enjoyed myself but at 1.0 the carriage took Mabel to the station and on its return drove me and the 2 children over to Boreham where we joined the girls skating there on a most lovely stretch of ice. (The weather changed the next day, and a thaw set in, so that was the end of the skating).

February 7th
My little mouse is 4 years old today, the sweetest creature you ever saw with her lovely pink colour, her red brown eyes and her hair which is more beautiful than anyone else's. Much excited by all the presents she is getting and too excited even to eat!

February 8th
After finishing my mail letters to Eve, Ell and Brownie, I drove down to the town with Mary and whilst she was shopping I walked up to old Gosling (the local junk shop in Chelmsford) to poke about and bought a 1788 edition of Sterne's Sentimental Journey with engravings for 1/-. He (Gosling) is a quaint old curiousity, short and encrusted with dust, wearing two pairs of specs upon his hookey nose and there he sits like an old spider in a fastness of cobwebs. He is a trifle mad I think and most amusing to talk to his shop is crammed with real rubbish and I asked him where on earth he collected such a lot of stuff to which he replied "Ma'am I am what is called a 'picker up of unconsidered trifles', there are some who throw all upon the dunghill and others who pick them up".

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
i

Chelmsford High Street at the time of Wynne's time there, and below, a view of London - around the same time.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: February 10th - 16th Wynne worries about her Mother-in-law, her children's tendency to break the china, and the coming Coal Strike.
viewer_4.description:
February 10th, Saturday
I wish H and M were not away for the household is not at its best, Mother being very low and depressed and Mary having taken to her bed with a chill. Mother is in that low state of health when anything and everything worries her. (The Mother mentioned here is not Wynne's mother, but Herbert's. You can see a picture of the old Mrs Jackson in the Family section. You can see her in a family group at the top, but scroll down and you will see a picture of her taken at about this period).

February 11th
The Sabbath has passed like every other Sabbath. Church at 11.0 , H and I staying to second service. The afternoon in the shelter where young Tom joined us. Tea in the dining room and the usual quiet evening over books, then bed.

February 14th
This is Mary's birthday and she got up about midday. She is 60 today and has had 20 letters. In honour of the occasion we all had tea together in the dining room and the children were allowed to pour out their own tea from a quaint little set Mary had as a child. To me this was a most frightening performance in case anything should be broken and I was thankful when it was over.

February 15th
Mail day, and therefore many scribbling to be got through. I wrote long screeds to Ell, Eve, Yso also the Hamster (her Uncle Walter, who provided the titlepage illustration for 1912). At 3.30 we drove over with Mabel to some people called Hurst with whom she had tea, but we returned and walked back. Whilst over there we walked up to see an old house called New Hall which is now a convent but which formerly belonged to Anne Boleyn, such a lovely old place, the erstwhile banqueting hall is now the chapel. I wonder if the ghosts of former revelers disturb the devotions of the nuns!

February 16th
On reading the Times leader this morning on the subject of the coming Coal Strike, it occurs to one how extraordinary it is that the public of which one is a member can go on living its daily life in work or idleness as the case may be with the utmost indifference to the grave issues with which we are threatened in less than a fortnight. Parliament meanwhile goes on discussing party politic rot and side issues and never attempts to life a finger to try and prevent this frightful catastrophe which seems inevitable. Socialism is bringing things to a frantic pass, there seems to be no longer any real powers in the land but it, as for "the Crown" it will be found in the way before long and put on the shelf and even at present is only really a sort of ornament to be brought out on pageant days.
