viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Off to town, Wynne and Eleanore prepare for a journey.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: February 17th -22nd The end of Wynne's holiday in Chelmsford - plenty of church services, a visit or two, and then the inevitable packing of cases.
viewer_6.description:
February 17th
My yesterday's entry seems depressing but unfortunately it is all horribly true. The paper today continues to think the worst and I cant see that there is anything else to think considering that nearly all the men have sent in their papers. Government is being called upon to interfere but it is too late and after all can only be in the way of persuasion and not compulsion. Being Saturday, Tom came home early. How these city men must look forward to week ends, it is such a grind going up every blessed day of your life. (An early comment about something that was rather unusual - the city commuter!)

February 18th, Sunday
It is not easy to write a flowery and interesting description of a day which consists of Church, eat, Church, eat, sleep, eat church, sleep!!as today literally did, but I do so enjoy a good long slack as we had from lunch to tea. (It was not uncommon to attend three times on a Sunday, and as you can see Wynne also went during the week.)

Click on the audio below to hear Ysobel's take on a typical Sunday!

February 19th
We drove this morning over to Hatfield and spent the day with Walter Butler. Alas! it poured most of the time but I was quite happy and spent most of the time playing his delightful Angelus organ having a feast of Wagner, La Boheme etc....

February 20th
Our time grows short here and I am very loath to go...spent nearly all day in the shelter reading. I have just finished "The Claw" by C. Stockley, a most interesting novel about Rhodesia, and am now embarked upon "the House of Lisronan" a novel which Miriam Alexander wrote for the £250 competition and won. It is about Ireland and the Prince of Orange time and is most awfully nice.

February 21st
Ash Wednesday. Church in the morning and slackness the rest of the day. Tomorrow we pack and are off so I make the most of the idleness which remains. We go to Mother, leaving the family here to join us at home on the 1st.

February 22nd
I spent most of the day packing, a most dismal occupation and one included with that rich and rare accomplishment, the blues. I hate going away, it makes it all the more depressing to feel that Mabel goes into hospital today to have an operation. Mother doesn't seem to improve one bit and in fact there is much to worry over. We arrived in Town about 6.30 and found Algie at the flat, all well there.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
London visits....

Wynne adored her visits to London, and appears to have been able to indulge herself, although on her relatively meagre means much of her outings were treats paid for by others - her Mother often managed to get free seats at some theatres, and in those days men took you out to dinner - as happened here, where she was treated to a meal at the Berkeley. The illustration below the menu is of the Savoy, which had only recently been enlarged, and which Wynne visited on July 6th, 1908.

As you can see on the Berkeley menu, Wynne has added a little rhyme, presumably referring to her consort, Charles Bridge, who added his signature before dashing off to sort out the attempted suicide. Wynne and Bridge often exchanged verses.
July 6th 1908
(Wynne writes in an earlier diary)
"Here is a picture of where I supped this evening. Philip Lyster came over and we dined first at the "Troc", table No 90, (her favourite spot), and then went on to see "Jack Straw". I laughed and laughed again and loved it all. We then went on to the Savoy which is the place to sup at now, very much enlarged and very smart crowds of the most fashionable people and the noise like a parrot's cage."

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: February 23rd - 29th...a leap year. Wynne rejoices to be back in London, walking around town, taking tea in a bohemian cafe in Soho, visiting numerous theatres...and having the occasional elegant dinner.
viewer_8.description:
February 23rd
Off to the stores this morning, Mother H and I, where we shopped much then parted, H to the W.O. (War Office) and I went off and lunched with Tom at the Strand Palace Hotel, meeting H at 3.0 at the Queens Hall for the R.A. concert to which also Mimi and a friend came, a splendid concert.

February 24th
I set off early to my beloved Douglas where I had my hair dressed and then went off in time to meet Tom at the Troc (the Trocadero, now converted to an amusement arcade in Piccadilly Circus). We sat at No 90 , table of many delightful days, afterwards walking over to the Apollo to see "The Glad Eye", an amusing piece but I fear me, corrupting the Town's morals! We then went off to the Club where we sat talking till it was time for him to go and I drove down with him to L'pool (Liverpool Street Station) to see him off.

February 25th, Sunday
I went off to early service this morning to a church here in Chelsea, a lovely still peaceful morning and somehow all seemed well on in Spring but it is only mockery, we shall be surely punished. I felt out of tune with it all rather though, I still have blues which the sublimity of this peaceful service only seemed to accentuate. I hear that Mabel is through with her operation all right but had ill effects from the chloroform and is in much pain poor dear.

February 26th
As one goes flitting about enjoying oneself the dreaded Coal Strike grows nearer and nearer and no one of us frivollers seems to think about it, the public at large doesn't give it a thought and the powers that be are every day proving more and more that they are no power at all. It is gruesome.

February 27th
Yesterday morning H and I went to the Tate Gallery. I hadn't been there since I was a child, it is a most interesting collection.

February 28th
I spent a full and amusing day, went off first of all to the Stores again to get various birthday presents for the family and then off to Princes to lunch with Algie, Walter and the latter's girl, a Miss Sykes usually called Psyche! She was brought chiefly for my inspection, a pretty girl and very much all there. Then Algie and I went off to see "The Blindness of Virtue" at the Little Theatre. This is a charming little house consisting solely of ground floor seats and boxes more like a drawing room and the play I thought excellent. We repaired afterwards to the dear old Piccadilly where I have spent so many delightful hours and whilst there I spied Charles Bridge of all people. I made signs to him and over he came, promptly engaging me for dinner. This fixed up I went home, changed rapidly and drove off again to dine at the Berkeley with this mad hatter. It was delightfully refreshing to see him again and we laughed much, but he had little cause to do so really as his man had brought him up word that a man in the guard room had attempted to commit suicide that afternoon and as Charles was orderly officer he had no business in Town at ll. I do hope it'll all blow over. We went on to the Palace afterwards.

February 29th
Another full day. H and I set off early and went first to the Stores once more, then took a motor bus to Charing Cross and from thence walked nearly all the way into the City which I loved. What is there about the Strand, Ludgate Circus, Cheapside etc. which fascinates one so? The very air breathes business and order and earnestness. I love it and one is proud to be English when one is in the City. H came as far as Winchester House with me where I met Tom with whom I was to lunch, and he then went off to do so with Charlie Jones. We betook ourselves to Palmerston House just opposite, a huge cavern of a place full of eating holes and offices and a general air of solemnity about it. We sat and ate and talked for an hour and then he walked up as far as the Bank with me where I left him to take a bus to the National Gallery on the steps of which I met H again. We went round this vast place until 4.0 struck and it was closed. I often wonder why one goes abroad to see pictures with this place in our midst. After this we went for another ramble all along the mean streets of St Martin's Lane, Old Compton Street, Wardour Street and other Soho haunts finally fetching up in Dean Street where we had tea at the Rendezvous, a strange Bohemian haunt much in vogue at present. This done we marched home and after an early dinner sallied forth once more to see "Bella Donna" which is unpleasant, of course, very, but intensely interesting I thought, and have seen no finer acting. Alexander as the Dr. and Mrs P Campbell as Mrs Chepstow are splendid, but the whole cast is without fault I consider and I was intensely interested.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Playbill for Bella Donna, which Wynne saw on February 29th, ...

Robert Hichens (1864 - 1950) was a very well known Edwardian writer whose book, "Bella Donna", achieved a certain notoriety. It was converted into a play by James Fagan, opening at the St James Theatre on December 9th 1911. It ran there very successfully, and then opened on Broadway in New York a year later.

 

Bella Donna was a classic love triangle story about a woman who attempts to poison her husband in order to be with her Egyptian lover. Her attempts are foiled, and both men discard her. The story proved perfect for the new film industry, and was first made into a film in the U.S.A. starring Pola Negri in 1923. This vehicle of romance, tragedy and forbidden, hinted-at-sex was a huge success for her, much to the annoyance of her rival, Gloria Swanson.
In 1934 it was remade, this time in England at Twickenham Studios, starring Mary Ellis and Conrad Veidt.

In 1923 the work gained further publicity when it featured in the famous murder trial of Edith Thompson. Accused of being an accessory to the murder of her husband Percy by her lover Freddy, she found her private life paraded in the court and across every newspaper. Amongst other items of evidence cited were letters in which she discussed the novel, Bella Donna, and this was used against her. She was found guilty, and hanged.

february.description:
..

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
I would be true, for there are those that trust me,
I would be pure, for there are those that care;
I would be strong, for there is much to suffer,
I would be brave, for there is much to dare.


The titlepage in Wynne's diary, ornamented by her German uncle Walter on vellum, as an illuminated manuscript.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: January 1st - 8th Wynne starts a new diary. She is now living in army accommodation in Aldershot, and has three children (see Family details)
viewer_2.description:
Wynne is now married with three young children. Herbert is coming up for retirement, and they are living in a comfortable house in Upper Hale, Farnham. These years were very happy ones for Wynne. There are now ten volumes on her shelves.

Monday January 1st
Once again I find myself beginning a new Diary, I have many of this kind now and it has become a sort of second nature to sit down and write about the humdrum events of each succeeding day, at present of course it is of very little interest but I daresay in years to come it will be amusing to look back and read of all we did in these days. To my Mothers' meeting as usual - 26 attended, and insisted on having both windows and doors shut I was nearly sick at the end too horribly aromatic.

January 6th
Mother and Gran arrived here in pouring rain and today they left in ditto. It has been pitch dark the whole day and raining most of it.
( But at least now Herbert and Wynne could have the windows and doors open again!! as you can see from the illustration drawn by Wynne's mother before her departure which is in the next browser section...look at the picture of her with twisted feet, surrounded by her paperwork, including the diary, then pull down the page viewer and see the whole scene! Her description of this is below).

 

Sunday January 7th
To continue about Ell (her brother) he writes that he with some of his officers and men of the BLH (Behar Light Horse - you can read more about them in the page view with their picture, which is about their earlier connection to Lumsden's Horse during the Boer War. ) went across country over the Ganges and Gogra to Arrah 17 miles and that day had a rehearsal. The next day the King arrived, held Church Parade and inspected them, shaking hands with all, presenting them with 2 signed portraits of the King and Queen and spoke to Mr Apperly and Elliot. Theirs is the only volunteer regiment thus honoured and they are justly proud. (King George V had arrived in India in 1911, to attend his famous Coronation Durbar in Delhi).

I hear from Mother this morning that they made out their journey quite safely and that Gran got along splendidly. I am much relieved, dear old thing. This picture here represents our drawing room as viewed through Mother's eyes. Whilst here she would have no door or window open ever in spite of which she always froze whilst we roasted. We would never do to live together. She cannot bear a breath of air and is always icy cold and I simply expire in that boiling atmosphere. I laughed over this picture and felt at once it must be put in here. Notice the attitude of my feet - they are so placed at this moment!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The House of Winds, January

Both: thank goodness Mother has gone! Let the fire go out!
Wynne: My dear do open some more windows, the door into the garden, the window and the hall door are not enough in this stifling weather. The howling wind's so nice and fresh.
Herbert: Delicious! It is freezing outside and we shall have snow!

Blanche's signature. Can you spot it on the original?

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: January 9th - 13th Suicides, parish magazines, Australian Egyptians! Plus a birthday and a Mother's Meeting.
viewer_4.description:
Tuesday January 9th
Poggy (Herbert) has been absent today from 10.0 until 8.0. He and Major Gray motored down to Brighton to attend the funeral of a poor young fellow Fitzpatrick by name who shot himself on Sunday. It has been a most perfect day. All round my district we left magazines and calendars galore. One woman newly come said she didn't take the Parish magazine because she always had the congregational one but said she wouldn't mind having the calendar if I liked as she always liked to be "convivial"!!! Another was delighted at having received a parcel from Australia containing some tray clothes worked she said by the Egyptians out there!!

Thursday January 11th
A day of much business and work. Firstly I drove down with Poggy in the morning and did shirts, a great number of women came and we were there till 12.30.
( "Shirts" was organised so that soldier's wives could earn a little pin money. They sewed buttons onto army shirts, at 2d a dozen shirts, and Wynne read them suitably uplifting tracts while they worked.)

Friday January 12th
Pinkie's (her son's) birthday and he is nine years old. We had a birthday party 2 little Norths, 2 Bruces, Charlie de Mornay and Joe and had the usual string hunt afterwards playing "sardines", a strange edition of Hide and Seek in which when you find a person instead of catching him you get in and hide too!

Saturday January 13th
Such a busy day all day, this being the Mothers' Meeting Tea. I went up to the church room at 11.30 with Bessie where we arranged the room, cut up 150 bits of bread and butter, 3 sorts of cake and buns and made a corner of mystery with screens and a cloth for the "dip". At 2.30 I returned...we were a party of about 50. We stuffed them first with oceans of tea after which came the dip, this being greeted with shrieks of joy and then we played games, poor things how they enjoyed it and I had private fits of laughter at musical chairs to see the fat ones gallumphing round and round and enjoying all the games just as children would. We broke up at 5.30.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
This picture, taken in Calcutta prior to their tumultuous departure in 1900, represents most of the Behar Light Horse Contingent (Indigo Planters) Together with others amounting to some 250 men, they made up
Lumsden's Horse, an entirely volunteer force, and according to the Viceroy the first body of volunteers from India ever to fight beyond its borders.

On embarkation day, enthusiastic crowds gave them a rousing send-off as they marched through thronged streets and under decorations which included latin tags such as "dulce et decorum est pro patria mori". The Viceroy, Lord Curzon, then spoke to them in classic late-imperial fashion:
"You are engaged on a glorious, and as I believe, a righteous mission, not to aggrandize an Empire, not merely to repel an unscrupulous invasion of the Queen's territories, but to plant liberty and justice and equal rights upon the soil of a South Africa henceforward to be united under the British and no other flag" (loud and continuous cheers according to the newspaper report). Sound familiar?

Of the crowd here pictured, at least one was killed. H.C.Lumsden presumably came from the distinguished Anglo-Indian family whose forebear became famous during the Mutiny, and whose current leader was the Colonel in charge of this unit. He is fourth from the right, bottom row , and of all those pictured looks the most miserable. Perhaps soldiering was not his bag. It must be hard to live under the cloud of a legend, especially one as illustrious as Sir Harry Lumsden of the Corps of Guides.

Wynne's brother, Elliot, is third from the right in the second row from the front, directly behind Lumsden. He came through the war unscathed. A closer picture of him is in the diary browser strip, and below is a cutting from the Army and Navy magazine of May 20 1900 which shows them in South Africa.

A closer view. Lumsden is standing on the left, under the ink "v". Elliot is next to him, kneeling, with an ink dot above his head. When this picture was published, Lumsden was already dead.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 15th - 21st

A London holiday on her way to visit her in-laws' in Chelmsford.
viewer_6.description:
Monday January 15th
I spent all the morning packing my box and the children's and looking after Win's effects and up to tea went at it hard.
(Win was a niece, the daughter of Eva, Wynne's sister who lived in India. She spent much of her childhood with the Jackson family in England).

Tuesday January 16th
We started off by the 10.2 this morning in the brougham and a cab, reaching town at 11.0, I taking the 3 kids (the two elder and their cousin, Win) to Mother and H escorting Baby and Maggie (the nanny) to Liverpool (Street) Station for Springfield. In great excitement the children dressed and after a 12.30 lunch we went to Drury Lane to see "Hop o my thumb". George Graves with Will Evans made us ill with all their nonsense, the children were delighted...we sat there from 1.30 till 6.0 as of course we couldn't possibly think of leaving before the end of the Harlequinade, at which they threw crackers and we caught 3!

Wednesday January 17th
In most fearful weather howling wind driving rain and icey air we bravely sallied forth with the kids to the Tower! I had not been there since I was a child myself and H since about 30 years! It is an interesting old place but one rather longs to be there alone and not in the crowds of gaping tourists that rush round with empty ox-like heads, being a horrible day we were mercifully spared a good many of them.

Thursday January 18th
In spite of more dreadful weather Pa, Ma and babies set forth again on pleasure bent, and this day the Zoo seized upon us and kept us from about 11.0 till 4.0! The interest of such a place never flags, and we got several keepers to show us lots of extras. We fed the monkeys with fruit and nuts, went and saw the baby chimpanzees so their tricks, a man fed his sea lions to show us how they dive and catch, we saw the lions fed of course but the catty and meaty smell of that place rather puts me off. The keeper of the Kiwi produced that odd little bird from its nest of straw, a creature weighing 60 oz. which lays one egg a year 20 oz: it is nearly blind by day and its feathers almost like fur. We then fed elephants and at 4.0 we left, the weather was fearful and we were quite unconcerned. To "Charley's Aunt" in the evening, alas! it has lost its charm.

( The family then decamped to Herbert's family home in Chelmsford, Springfield Place, where they were to spend most of February.
This is a photo of it, taken around this period. The house is still standing).

Sunday January 21st
To Church in the morning and after lunch I lay down on the sofa in the drawing room with Mrs Ward's latest "The Case of Richard Meynall", where I slept and read till tea with the greatest contentment.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
A proud young mother with her two eldest. This photo was probably taken in 1905 when the family were in Ireland, living in Kildare. Ireland was still part of the UK then, and Herbert was serving in the army there.
Thomas, on the right, was born on January 12th, 1903. Ysobel, on the left, was born on April 13th 1904. As seems to have been the custom then, both unfortunates ended up with nicknames given them at birth - Thomas became Pinkie, Ysobel was known as Nootie. The former was obviously a comment made over the cot of a new infant, but the meaning of the latter has been lost. Neither much enjoyed being called that when they were 50!

In 1908, on February 7th, a third addition was made to the family: Eleanore Mary, forever afterwards known as Babs, short for Baby. In many ways, she was the luckiest, as her shortened nickname at least approximated to a real one!
In this photo she is posed with the two older children, both looking utterly miserable, alongside Maggie, their nanny who is holding Babs. Maggie arranged for the photo herself, as a surprise for Wynne, but Wynne's only comment in her March 21st 1908 entry is that the children look like stuffed pigs!
The other lady is Maby, the governess, who is often mentioned in the diaries.

Finally, a picture of the three which I think was taken sometime around or just after . Here they are looking very grown up, though only Pinkie was allowed to go to school. The girls remained at home, much to Ysobel's annoyance.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 22nd - 27th

At the family home, "Springfield", in Chelmsford, Essex...and then back to London
viewer_8.description:
Monday January 22nd
Mabel and I drove down to the Town this morning where we both did some shopping. When I had finished and was waiting for her I walked out to see the old man Gosling who keeps a junk shop. There I poked about and found to my joy an original Culpepper, not original exactly but dated 1703 of course he lived long before that. I have been much entertained by reading it what a quaint conceit, but it seems to me that a concoction of any sort of herb you like is good for every sort of disease under the sun. I also purchased a little old religious treatise called "The Soul's Preparation for Christ or A Treatise on Contrition 1635". Such an odd little volume, long winded simple and full of condemnation for "vile worms". I paid him 6/- for the two books.

Tuesday January 23rd
I have seldom seen anything like the darkness today, it has never lightened once all day long. I spent the morning writing and after lunch I forced myself to go out with the gloomy fog and went over to see the Blakes, poor Letty she still looks worried to death, she has had a bad year what with Blakes' trouble and her babies' illnesses, they have got the job of caretaker now in the house the Sworders had and he goes jobbing but it is all very unsatisfactory and precarious and I wish he could get a permanent job.

Friday January 26th
Herbert has gone up to Town this morning to a committee meeting at the W.O. (The War Office) and returns to tea. I have told him that if he does so without chocolate I shall get a divorce!

Saturday January 27th
At 9.40 I betook myself off to Town (London, this time - the town is usually Chelmsford - or any town nearby - but Town is London). Leaving my bag at the cloakroom of Charing Cross I went on up to Evans (D.H.Evans, the big store) where I did some business and then spent an hour at Douglas' having my hair done...at 3.15...journeyed down by tube and taxi to Mother who I found half inclined to flu and Gran very well. At 7.30 we dined and went off to Covent Garden where the kind Duke had given us a box to see that most wonderful performance "Oedipus Rex". (This was the private box of the Duke of Bedford, often loaned out to Blanche, Wynne's mother. The Duke and Blanche had met years before in India where, as a very junior officer he had been taken under her wing and looked after. He never forgot it).

What a storm of criticism this has called forth - good, bad, indifferent. Some enthuse and others rail and say it is not Greek, for my part I have never seen anything to touch it and I have no words in which to describe its perfect beauty, but then I am emotional and not a Greek scholar. Our party consisted of Algie Fallowfield, Dr Vaughan Sawyer, a type of cold blooded modern female who I cannot away (sic) with and a certain young novelist Desmond Coke by name and an insufferable young ass. These three thought it fit to giggle and make fatuous remarks all through and I would willingly have poisoned them all. I enclose here the programme which explains all, it is a production of Max Reinhardt's and certainly most unlike anything one has ever seen - there is no curtain - one is at once brought face to face with the only scenery used throughout, ie: the outside of the palace of the King of Thebes. Dark pillars with a terrace at the foot of them, the rostra and steps which latter lead straight down to a space at the foot of the stalls up the centre of which is a broad way left for the players who come up and down it as well as through the sides. All is dark and gloomy and a weird gong sounds and soon the populace come flitting in to the foot of the steps and call for Oedipus - Martin Harvey and Lillian McCarthy are the hero and heroine and for 2 solid hours one sits lost in the wondrous and tragic history of an evil fate - I shall never forget it and whether it is produced correctly or not it will ever remain in my mind as quite the most perfect things of its kind I have ever seen. The audience were enthralled and called again and again and M Harvey came forward to say that the attendances had been so large they intended keeping it on for another week.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The programme for Oedipus Rex. Because it is hard to read, and I liked it, I transcribe the words for the International Correspondence Schools advert at the foot of the bill:
"The greatest modern development, as regards Technical Education, has been the growth of the International Correspondence Schools, whose system of Technical Training has won the eulogy of leading public men, educationalists and social reformers.
From His Majesty the King down to the humblest worker, the I.C.S has evoked interest - indeed, there are over 180,000 I.C.S. students in the British Empire...."
The advert goes on to extol the virtues of their new language training system, using phonograph records - very modern, and a forerunner of the audio-visual systems that came later - and to offer training in over 200 courses.

This cutting was included by Wynne with the programme. As you can see, the sort of behaviour that Wynne found so offensive in her own party was obviously rather common, and certainly affected this performance. Clearly it touched a nerve in the Edwardian viewer...perhaps the laughter was nervous? Little did they realise they were about to enter their own very real tragedy....

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
January 29th

A final day in London taking in another show: Max Reinhardt's famous play, "The Miracle"
viewer_10.description:
Monday, January 29th
We never waste a moment when I am in Town. Accordingly after a late and lazy breakfast in bed we taxied up to Keith Prowse where we got seats for the "Miracle" at the Olympia tonight, and then went on to the New Gallery for lunch. There we found our way into the Continental Room and had a German lunch, devouring with many quilps and cranks much succulent food and drinking Munchener Bier! From there we went to the Coliseum and saw the usual excellent programme, but had to come away before the end as Mother was expecting Nellie Burn and her lady to tea, I was sorry. We dined at 7.15 and then set off to see Reinhardt's other piece, the Miracle, this again in quite another way is splendid, the whole of Olympia is transformed into a huge cathedral with enormous hanging lamps and coloured glass windows all round. The audience sit round the arena which is formed like the floor of a cathedral and in the centre is the throne where on sits the Miraculous Image. It is the story of a Nun who hearing the call of the world leaves the convent and during her absence the Virgin to shield her descends from her throne and personifies her till she returns. It is all very beautiful and remarkable - the play is wholly wordless and the music by Humperdinck goes on all the time and is most lovely. Vast crowds move about giving one a true medieval picture and I loved the Mass music and smell of incense, criticism of this too is most varied and some people find it irreverent but to me it gave quite the other impression and it was all so beautiful that nothing seemed to offend. We got back about 11.0 and were lucky in getting a taxi almost immediately as poor Mum is awfully bad at standing and the crowds were immense.

Maria Carmi as the Madonna.
The programme notes say she was selected "for her rare beauty, which is of a type not often met with. She is stated to have an exact 'Boticelli' face and to perfectly realise that artist's Madonna now in the National Gallery, London"

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
The scene in the main arena at Olympia, with the audience in specially constructed stalls around the edge of the performance area. No expense spared when it came to the sets!
And no expense spared for the animals it seems....

The main cast list - there were hundreds of extras, and many other roles....

january.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Wynne now has 10 volumes on her desk, and has become completely committed to the task.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne's grandmother in ...when she was 98. You can read about her in the family section.

Ysobel remembered her very clearly from this period!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: July 1st - 7th Wynne does her duty, at home and abroad
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Monday
A new month and a new week, I feel so thankful that I have passed that stage in my life when the day after Sunday represented Black Monday to me. Today, all days are the same and all are lovely. The Taylors to tea and a committee meeting in the evening.

July 2nd
A District Visitors' meeting after lunch and H off to a committee meeting in Aldershot. I took tea with the Bacons and this evening we dined at Government House. A very pleasant informal dinner to meet the French Military Attaché. The Gordons and Kavanaghs, Col. Sandy, Dr Cane, the Douglas Haigs, their Aide Capt. Baird and another man made up the party and after dinner we played "Coon Can" an excellent new round game. The D(ouglas)H(aig)s seemed so very nice and friendly and quite unofficial.

July 5th
Such a busy day of preparing and getting ready for my women's tea. Caesor carted from the vicarage all the tables, chairs, cups plates etc. Vast stores of food came down from Rogers and by 3.30 they had all arrived. We had the piano out on the lawn and it actually was a lovely day. We were nearly 60 at tea, and all went very well. We dismissed at 6.30 and all seemed very happy and gay.

July 6th
Oh breathless day, I got by the morning post a letter from Mother who is off to Baden with Win for her eczema, asking me to go down there (Brookfield) to be with Gran for a few day so as to keep Aimie Halliday company, so within an hour I had gone, it was a rush. I was nearly mad! and a wire arrived 2 hours after I left saying I needn't go!!

July 7th
Aimie Halliday has most kindly elected to stay with Gran the whole of Mother's absence. I find my dear old Gran very much aged, very tottery on her feet, so very deaf and often most hazy. She is undoubtedly aged tremendously in the last six months. She had one of her slight attacks at tea today but within an hour she was all right again. She now lives in the erstwhile smoking room and it is a most comfortable arrangement.
(Wynne's Gran was 98. You can read more about her in the Family section).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Brookfield House in Dorset. You can clearly see what Wynne meant when she complained about the overgrown front - creepers cover the verandah, and the rooms behind it must have been very dark indeed.

Below is an early photo of the house, taken in the 1890's, and you can see the little bridge linking the garden to the island. This would have been where Wynne stood to watch the kingfishers.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: July 8th - 13th Wynne spends some time at Brookfield with Gran, and sees the kingfishers, but at home two naughty girls go without pudding.
viewer_4.description:
July 8th, Monday
The rain descends in torrents, it is most dismal and oh! the place seems so damp and dark, the creepers are dreadfully over grown and hang peering in at the windows to such an extent that the drawing room is too dark to use and we sit in the billiard room.

July 9th

Yesterday after a day of rain it cleared a bit in the evening, and not being able to bear it any longer I went down on to the island for a stroll. I am afraid I felt thoroughly "blue" this place is too full of memories to do it alone, every spot is associated with some episode and one is continually raking up "old bones". I stood for a long while on the end of the little island bridge and strange things happened. A small leveret came lopping up, peered at me, but in no ways disconcerted hopped about and ate his supper. Then various field mice, a water vole and a moor hen all came playing around but the most delightful of all was a family, 2 babies and a parent, of kingfishers came flashing up and down and finally settled at my very feet. Mrs had a small fish which the babies fought over and then she left them to quarrel by themselves. Such darlings, each sat bobbing up and down making chucking noises, jumping their heads and tails up and down, then one began to fish, but never succeeded in fetching anything but twigs and leaves up. All this but a yard from my feet. I was spell bound and had perforce to allow the most venomous mosquitos settle all over me and feast because I dare not move. All was utterly still and I half fancied I could hear the Great God Pan rustle in the leafy boughs!

July 10th
I left today at 10.45. I was sad to say good-bye to my old dear. She is so frail now that one feels anything may happen. I returned to find all well at home and Maggie just off for her holiday.

July 11th
We attended the Bishop of Winchester's garden party at Farnham Castle, and such a gathering of clergy I never did see, hundreds, indeed we hear that there were over 1400 guests present. It was looking very pretty, the lovely old Castle with its perfect garden and view but our chief joy lay in quizzing the strange and fearsome outrages with which the Mrs Padres decked themselves - such a galaxy of beauty seldom is seen.

July 13th, Saturday
I was to have had a tennis party today but the rain fell in torrents without ceasing and thank goodness no one turned up except Miss C. I felt it in my bones that she would - so silly when one couldn't possibly play.
I am depressed tonight as I have to brace myself up to punish both my babies because they've been naughty. The punishment consists of no nice pudding for a week, no sweets and no Saturday penny. Sounds trivial and small to one but its very real to them and when their pathetic faces look up and they accept in silence ones dictum I could cry. One feels how helpless the little creatures are in our hands, and I just hate it but one must do this sometimes. It is so wrong to them to be soft hearted in the way of spoiling them.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Two naughty girls - Babs (on the left) and Noots (Ysobel) in the summer house at Brookfield, both looking rather naughty here....

Listen to Ysobel's memory of the garden.

Check out a 1911 photo of all three children at Brookfield, or go to September 1912 to see wonderful photos of the brook that ran at the bottom of the garden. No wonder they loved the place. Two windows back will also give you a good view of the overgrown verandah of the house, something Wynne mentions this month.

A photo of the viola borders.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: July 15th - 21st Field Days and visitors from Canada
viewer_6.description:
July 15th, Monday
A boiling hot day very lovely and delightful but everyone panting peevishly in consequence. I went to have a swim with Noot then rushed back to a nursing committee at 12.15.

July 16th
Every morning I slip out of bed and do my flowers and gardening before it gets too hot. Poggy very busy at Field Days yesterday and today. Children went to the Bacons to tea and to dinner here came Grays, Wrigleys, and Major Walsh, and we played "Coon Can" till all was blue. (Thanks to Miss Dominie Watts of Windsor, Ontario, you can read the rules of this game below - scroll down)

July 17th
The world and his wife if they belonged to the 2nd Division assembled today on the ground behind the General's house for their sports, and then we all went in and had tea in his garden.

July 18th
I spent a busy day. Poggy went away early till Sat on manoeuvres. I took Mrs Kavanagh's day at Shirts today. I was much annoyed because not one single lady turned up so Miss C had to do all the passing and I all the paying. They are a slack lot. I then went on to an enormous lunch party given by the O'Malleys to 300 Canadian teachers sent over here to enjoy themselves by the Canadian Government. It was a very smart show and quite interesting, each one was given a souvenir of the occasion.

July 19th, Friday
A wire today saying Rita and Herman are coming today (Wynne's nephew and niece - Rita Fallowfield and Herman von Poelnitz). The former is engaged and Herman is home on two months leave from Gib.

July 20th
My poor Poggy got in at 5.30 this morning after a wet night spent on a heap of stones on the Hogs Back and I arose to give him his tea. We had planned to have a lot of tennis today but the rain fell in torrents.

July 21st, Sunday
All the household went to church this morning, Walter (her uncle) included and then as ill luck would have it we must have that changeling of a curate here, with his whining voice and lisping tongue. I did more photography all afternoon and to our great pleasure Major Newcome came in and had a long buck all about old times and people. He is a nice little creature.

Coon Can

Paraphrased from Parlett's "A Dictionary of Card Games".

Conquian. A proto-rummy game for 2 players.
Deck is 40 cards: A234567JQK
Each receives 10 cards, rest stacked face down.

Object is to be 1st to go out by melding 11 cards, including the last
one drawn.

Meld = 3+ matched cards (same rank) or 3-8 cards in sequence.

Since there are only 10 cards in a suit, and you have to meld 11 to
go out, the longest sequence is 8, because the other 3 cards have to be
a different meld.

A23 is valid as is 67J, but not QKA.

Non-dealer starts by turning up top down card. Can't pick it up; must
meld immediately (with at least 2 cards from hand) or pass. If he melds,
must also make a discard face up. If he passes, Dealer has same choice
(meld with it or pass [in this case turning the card face down]).

Play continues in this way. Whoever turns up a card must either meld it,
add it to an existing meld, or pass. If both pass, second player turns
it down and turns up new card.

In melding, you can use cards from other melds, as long as all melds
remain legal (i.e. you can take a 6 from a meld of 4 6's to make a
sequence of 456, but you couldn't take it from a meld of only 3 6's).
After melding, your discard is available to the other player, who may
either meld it, or turn it down and turn up a new card.

Game end when one player melds both the face up card, and all remaining
cards in hand (either by making a new meld or adding to existing or both).

If a player refuses to take a card that can be legally melded to
existing melds, opponent can demand he do so. In this way a person can
be forced into a situation they can't get out of - one of the main
startegies of the game.

If neither has gone out when the last available card has been declined,
the game is a draw.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The souvenir booklet issued to the Canadians when they visited Aldershot. It contained the history of the Artillery, with some up to date pictures on the back....below:

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: July 22nd - 31st Duties in Aldershot, pleasure in London, but her son is detained in school with chickenpox.
viewer_8.description:
July 22nd
Rita and Walter took their departure today and so did Poggy, this time to Oxford for a Staff Ride. I went and bathed and Mrs Watson came too and we had a jolly swim.

July 23rd
Had to attend a decayed children's party at the Savinglers today but the kids enjoyed themselves immensely and brought home chocolates for which they had hunted in the garden.

July 24th
I actually had a day at home today and spent the whole of it gardening, a great treat.


July 25th
I shirted in the morning (ie: ran the weekly Shirts event, where army wives sewed on buttons for pocket money), and at 7.30 went to a strange gathering of sheep and goats at the Vicarage where all the Parish workers were assembled and where the Bishop and his wife came to be met. We sat out in the damp garden and listened to a very excellent discourse by him and some indifferent music.

July 26th
Herman left today, Poggy taking him down in the morning. My man went off at 6.0 again to bivouac out (?) way.

July 27th, Saturday
This day has been a long one. I was out of my bed for 20 hours! H came in at 5.0 so I arose at 4.15 and got him tea! It was a horrid dull grey morning and he was very done having stood most of the night. The Hurdwoods came to lunch and went to the Queen's Bays Sports with me, then I met Eddie and Mabel and a certain Capt. Springfield who had planted indigo a hundred years ago and got a commission from Lumsdens in the Bay. I was not in bed till 12.15.

July 28th
As the weather was very fitful this morning Poggy represented the family at Church and we occupied ourselves in stringing a lot of lavender which kind Mrs Wrigley gave me for my linen cupboard. As Poggy goes off on his wild career again tomorrow I am off to Town till Thursday for a jaunt of my own.

July 29th
I went up by the 9.12 and Herman met me in the rain at Waterloo. We hied us first of all to a Palmist who predicted amongst other things a change next year and billet abroad fro Herbert. Pooh! We then lunched at Hatchetts and went afterwards to the Coliseum where we saw Lydia Kyaksht dance. She is not a patch on the Pavlova I think who is perfectly and absolutely without fault. (Kyaksht was one of the many amazing dancers from the Imperial Russian Ballet who were allowed to dance elsewhere during their summer break. Their appearance in Europe just before the First World War revolutionised ballet in countries outside Russia. You can read more about her in her memoirs: "Romantic Recollections".) There were several other excellent turns and in the evening we did the Empire, a splendid show also with a very clever medley called "Everybody's doing it" in the programme over which we laughed and roared.

July 30
Spent the day at Lords. Much bored by Lords where very few people assembled to see the Gunners vs Sappers match.

July 31st
I was much disappointed at receiving a card today saying my dear son was not to be allowed to come home tomorrow, as I had come up on purpose to meet him (from Malvern). The Dr. thinks he wont be free from infection from chickenpox till Tuesday and as Town swarms with Mothers meeting their creatures I am green with envy and rage.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Thomas (Pink) in his Norfolk jacket...his holiday was delayed by an outbreak of chickenpox at the school.

july.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The joys of the motor car - !
A different take on the problem of the car disappearing while the owner was elsewhere!

And below, a view of Snowdon and Beddgelert...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: June 1st - 6th Wynne is holidaying in Wales, so she can be near her husband's Artillery summer camp. She goes to Bettwsycoed, Chester, and attempts to climb Snowdon.
viewer_2.description:
Wynne and her friend Mrs Gray have been staying in Wales, to be near their husbands who are on army exercises.


June 1st, Saturday
I really think that we have surely reached the limit of perfection as far as scenery is concerned today. We drove up to Camp first of all with the men and whilst they were in office we strolled away up into the brushwood and sat about reading till 1.0 . Well, we gathered in Major Ward there who returned to lunch with us and then we started off to go to Bettwsycoed via Beddgelert, we passed through that perfect place the Vale of Aberglaslyn over the Bridge where we got down and took photos and then on through Beddgelert all along the Aberglaslyn Vale. Up above us towered Snowdon, down below the river ran through green and sleepy pastures, whilst several lakes increased the perfection of it all. At length we arrived at Bettwsycoed, the surrounding country couldn't be more glorious but the place itself is now such a "Resort" that its really spoilt with hundreds of tourists, their cars and their necessary hotels. We returned by a higher road over the Roman Bridge and past the Roman Tower, and our way ran up up up into the wilds of the mountain top. We gradually rose from 444feet to 1063 feet: the view was splendid, and how strange and lonely it was right up there in that far away spot with nothing but the sheep and a lonely farmstead here and there.

June 2nd
This day we set forth upon our tour within a tour, and at 11.30 we were on our way to Chester. The fog settled down on us and the rain, it was almost dark and we couldn't see 6 yards ahead, but the spirits of the party kept us going, we arrived in the quaintest of quaint towns at about 6.0 and ate a huge tea, it was too wet to go out so we just changed and soon had dinner - a large and most excellent Hotel full of Americans, called the Grosvenor.

June 3rd
What a strange and unique town. We all went forth exploring in different directions, and were fascinated by it all. The famous Rows took up a deal of our attention, a double row of shops one above another on each side of the street with a gallery running along - funny old over hanging half-timbered houses stretched out over the street as if to shake hands, and many side alleys so narrow that they almost met. We saw "God's Providence" house, the only one spared during plague time, and Bishop Lloyd's wonderful house with its beautiful old windows and carved beams.
We left again at 12.0 and lunched at one of the oldest coaching inns in existence, the Bridgewater Arms, a delightfully clean place, arriving at tea time at the Raven, Shrewsbury.

The party returned to base the next day, having covered 225 miles, which Wynne proudly noted. They rested on the 5th, and then set out on their last day in Wales to climb Snowdon.


June 6th
Well this being our last day in this most ripping place we determined to try the ascent up Snowdon. We lunched at Beddgelert first and Major Gray and I were for walking up but when we got to the foot of the path we found the weather too threatening and so had to abandon that idea. We all therefore took the train up , Maj. and Mrs G, Major Ward , H and I. I had a bad time with them, Major Gray being my only champion, they chaffed me the whole way along making varied remarks as to my "pore feet", advising I should pour libations of whiskey down my stockings to ease the bunions and corns, and Major Ward had purchased a pair of carpet slippers which he had intended to present to me on my arrival at the top!! They on their part I likened to craven pog bags because they were afraid to go up at all!! We all laughed ourselves hysterical. I am glad we went up - it is an interesting experience but so cold.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Wynne's ascent of Snowdon, albeit by rail, seems to have been a highlight of the trip, to be commemorated by cartoon and certificate designed by other members of the party...

.Note the prominent slippers, presented to Wynne on her arrival at the summit! And below, a handsome certificate, painted by one of the party...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: June 7th - 14th Back home in two days, getting soaked to the skin. At home, its the old mundane chores and the King's Birthday Review.
viewer_4.description:
June 7th, Friday
Alas! the day of our departure has arrived and we are indeed sad to go. It is just horrid and I've never been more loth to say goodbye to any place. The men left at 8.0 off to Camp, back to work alas. We started at 9.0 a horrid wet day and before we reached Hereford where we stayed the night we were drenched to the skin and rather miserable. Very early to bed.

June 8th
We got home about 6.30. It is always lovely getting back to my home and babies and the most refreshing welcome one gets but oh! how I long to have it all over again, I miss them all so much and how boring at first are all the endless jobs of "good works", a pile of magazines await me and such like reminding me that life cannot all be froth.

June 9th
I have spent hours writing today, reams and yards, it is frantic what a lot there seems to do. The garden is looking lovely, and the rain has done an enormous amount of good. I picked sweet peas today, 2 of them for the first time, it is most interesting to see it all and I spent the evening in weeding and playing with the children at shop, dear things, so good and sweet.


June 10th
I went down with my Nootle to her swimming and then spent the day bedding out, working on till 8.15, and after dinner I went over to the Skipwiths and played awhile.

June 11th
I have been in Town all day, did a little shopping in the morning and then after lunch I attended Lady Fulton's "At Home" as I thought it a good thing to do but I was much bored by many dozen females and the crush. She was looking quite charming and so very smart. There was there a Palmist who told me some extremely clever things and some unpleasant ones which I hope will not come true. There are also great changes in store for me before the year is out and next year someone is to die and leave me some money - pooh! stuff rot bosh!

June 13th
A day of parochialism and camp chores and I am tired. What with "Shirts" and my district I've had enough today, the latter is a job ... and little did I think what it involved when I took it up with such a light heart. I have been sowing my spring seeds today, Oh! how I should love to spend my whole day gardening always and never move out. What horrid selfish views are these, lucky I'm not able to carry them out.

June 14th
The Kings Birthday Review took place today. It was a fine day, and the show was excellent, especially the gallop past of the Horse Artillery and Cavalry - I took the children who enjoyed it immensely dear things.

Listen to Ysobel's memory of one of these parades by clicking on this link.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The journey home - this time in two days. The age of speed!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: June 15 - 22nd To Malvern, to visit her son, before returning home to memories, the Mothers' Union and the complexities of the new Insurance Tax.
viewer_6.description:
June 15th
My birthday today and Mother has sent me the "ruby ring", words cannot express my joy and delight and I can hardly believe that it is really mine. I had an additional treat today in going down to Malvern to see my Pink for it is Parents Day. I started off at 8.0 arriving there at about 2.0 and as I appeared there came towards me a little flying figure in green blazer, white flannel trousers and felt hat looking so well and splendid and I just felt I could have cried for joy. It was so lovely to see him again. We gathered in Bobby too and then sat watching the match and talking till tea time which we all had together in the gym after which we went into the Town to buy strawberries and cream for tea tomorrow.

June 16th
This morning at 8.30 the boys came up and we had breakfast together and went at 11.0 to the Priory to service. Then lunch at 1.15 after which we gathered in 3 other boys, Jagger, Gornall and Duggleby who had no parents there and went for a ramble up the hills till tea time which they all took with me and played about in the Hotel garden afterwards till 7.0 when supper was partaken of, and alas at a quarter to 8 I had to take them back again. It was very horrible to me saying goodbye to the child as I could see he was feeling it so poor dear darling, indeed it is such a particularly dreadful form of parting that one almost wonders if the whole show is worth it but I really think they get over it sooner that we.

June 17th
I got back at 2.30 and went off fairly soon to a Mothers Union meeting at the Vicarage where we had a very large meeting and a most able speaker, a Mrs Gosslet, who talked to us on hygiene.

June 19th
A boiling hot day and with fear and trembling I went to Town to place myself in the hands of a dentist. What was my joy and delight when he found only one tooth to do, and I stepped off his doorstep with a light heart and betook myself to shop.

June 20th
This day 14 years ago my dear old Father died. The room today is again filled with Sinkin Pinks (Dianthus, "Mrs Sinkins") as it was then and brings the sadness all back to me so vividly.
I went down with Nootle and swam this morning, the Frazers came to tea and I dined at the O'Malleys, a party of 15 not getting home till 1.0! A very jolly evening and great fun.

June 21st
Bicycled over to lunch at the H-Ws - a high wind was blowing, seizing alternately and together my hat, hair and skirts and I also picked up a puncture. I did not feel very amiable. On my way home I had tea with my dear Mrs G and she brought me home in the new motor!

June 22nd
Quite a nice hot day and the afternoon spent if not wasted at an Insurance Tax meeting at Farnham. What a maze it all sounds and I am bewildered. (This must refer to the recently passed Insurance Act of 1911 - presumably the meetings were held to explain its ramifications. The Act provided for the first time a system of benefits for the unemployed and the sick. Wynne would have attended to find out how it affected her staff, not herself, though it may be she was attending because at this time there was a general movement away from private philanthropy to state benefit. )

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
A group of schooboys, waiting for their outing...Wynne's son Herbert is second from the left, bottom row.

and a photo from the "ramble' they went on in the hills above Malvern.

But most of their days were spent in the classroom. As you can see, it doesn't look very inviting!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: June 23 - 30 Gardening heaven!! At last the chance to indulge in an abiding passion.
viewer_8.description:
June 23rd, Sunday
A high wind dashes around and ruins my dear garden, blowing everything to pieces, its too disgusting. We went to church in the morning and after lunch I and my two babies lay on a rug on the lawn, they looking at books and sleeping. Mag (the nanny) went out so I had charge of them.



June 24th
Mid summer day! Very showery and uncertain but I managed to put in a good deal of work. Went round leaving invitations for my women's tea on the 5th July, then (after lunch) I gardened till dinner which I took with the Bacons dear nice people. I returned at 10.20 and wrote letters till past 12.0!

June 25th
As there is so much to be done in the garden I aroused myself early and soon after 6.30 was working at weeds and so got in nearly 2 hours before breakfast, just as lucky because it started to rain then and never ceased till lunch time. Then I had to go down to the S and S sale held at the ASC Theatre.

June 26th
I have spent a day after my own heart. I got up at 6.0 and by 7.0 was working in the garden and until 7.30 pm I continued to do so, it was a lovely joy to me, I ought to have been at the Scots Guards sports but just wasn't and my own "sports" interested me much more!

June 27th
Shirts in the morning and Nootles swimming. Giles declares that in 2 more lessons she should swim across the bath alone. I got in an afternoon of gardening and had to have food at 7.0 as at 7.30 the District Garden party took place at the vicarage. Over 200 present and great festivities took place, it is really awfully good of them and now they have asked the whole parish to tea!


June 28th
I did much gardening today against the coming of my lord and at 4.0 went down to the Milroys to their annual show. This time the good people had provided a Palmist and who should it turn out to be but Madam Collier of Ladbroke Grove. She was certainly not inspired today and talked in a most vague and general way. I betook myself to a bush where I smoked a cigarette with Dr Hussey.

June 29th
Very early this morning, in fact at 20 to 6, I got up and did the flowers as my Poggy returned today and I spent the day in Town. I went up by the 10.2 first to Douglas, shopped and then lunch with my dear Mrs Gray at her club the Sesame, after which she took me to see Milestones. I have never been to a more interesting play, it is quite delightful and so wonderfully thought out. It is most difficult to get in and was crowded. We got back at about 7.0 and at 8.30 my dear man came home once more, how ripping it is to have him back. (Milestones was a new play by Arnold Bennett and Edward Knoblauch, starring Dennis Eadie. It was a family saga, in three acts: 1860, 1885, and 1912.)

To show that nothing changes, here is part of a poem Wynne cut out and stuck in at the end of June 1912. It starts:

"The parents of my childhood's days
(I'm glad to say I have them still)
Were somewhat uppish in their ways
And noted for their iron will....

Today the parent is defied,
And while I turn a pleasing pink
Miss Impudence and Master Side
Tell me exactly what they think.
Yea, criticised, misunderstood,
I mourn for my unhappy fate;
I have attained to fatherhood
To find the parent out of date!"

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
An article from the Morning Post, celebrating fresh air and June. The sentiments clearly co-incided with Wynne's - she loved walking and being out of doors.

"What is the great thing about June in England now as we touch the zenith of the year? I take it to be the splendid length of the day. This is the time when some of us may almost get our right share, full measure, of open life, instead of those mere snatches of it which is the usual allowance at other seasons. Full measure, I reckon, is eight to nine good hours spent without the least break, supremely free from custom and interference, in absolute country.
But I question much whether the effect of a single day like this of eight to nine hours, even with weather and scene kind in every way, is enough, unless it falls to the lot of one who is already elate or fairly keen, and in almost perfect health and heart. The man who is jaded at all or overstrained wants an allowance of quite two or three continuous days in the open, each day yielding this eight to nine hour measure...."

The author, George Dewar, was obviously a favourite of Wynne's. A later cutting in the diary offers a wonderful extended essay about long summer evenings - "walking home from the station a few minutes after sundown, through wheat lands, through hazel and oak coppices into the wooded dell, and up again out of that steep dark place to the light hayfields of the uplands beyond. This is not a hard plan, because England is fairly wound about by footpaths of the kind - they are one of its modest glories."

june.description: The Diary - in JUNE... Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne was no fan of the Suffragettes, as you can see if you read March 2nd and March 4th...she was in fact part of a surprising majority of women who did not agree with the aims of those struggling for female emancipation. It is perhaps unfair to include on the same page an advert for clothes - but these are two sides of the same coin, and as you can see from both, much has changed! (Layettes, for those interested, were clothes, toilet articles and bedding needed for a newborn child). Check out 1918 for a change of view!

This advert is on the cover of the programme for "The Tales of Hoffmann" by Offenbach which Wynne went to see at the New Opera House on March 1st.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: March 1st - 8th The Coal Strike is on everyone's lips, and Wynne is horrified to see the damage done to London by the Suffragettes. Her holiday is over and she returns to Farnham.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st
This month has come in fairly quietly as far as weather is concerned, but the dreaded Coal Strike is now in full swing and thousands of workers are idle, every one is in a scare ordering supplies of food and coal which already has risen enormously and one can't imagine what the poor are to do through it all.

March 2nd
I went off at 10.30 this morning taking No 19 for Bond Street in order to go to Douglas (her hairdresser), on alighting I noticed unusual crowds and then found that all along the street in every direction that the Suffragettes had been at work smashing shop windows. Up Bond Street almost every other window was in fragments, Duveen, Asprey, Truffitt, Harborow, Lucana etc etc...all had things pasted over the holes, some with labels marked "suffragettes", up Regent Street, Piccadilly, Strand etc...all was the same everywhere, rack and ruin, and I believe about £4000 worth of damage was done, it made one ashamed to be a woman. Of course they are all clapped into prison and I do hope the sentences will be heavy.
Drove to L'pool Station and saw (Tom) off, on arriving there I found I had left my little bag in the taxi, so sickening but I shall try at Scotland Yard on Monday.

March 3rd, Sunday
I induced Mother to come to the City Temple with me today to hear Campbell preach - it is a curious service nearly all singing, and a long sermon which seemed like a few minutes.

March 4th
Mother and I drove first to Scotland Yard where to my great joy I found my beloved bag - such luck! Then to Harrods to order provisions against the rise in prices, there all along the road we found the Suffragettes had just been at work again, fragments and smashes all along Sloane Street and Harrods itself much damaged and everyone in a state of great excitement.


March 5th
We found all very nice at home (at Upper Hale, Farnham) and it is delightful being back again (Wynne had had a long visit to her in-laws, with breaks in London, throughout February). My joy would be still greater if it weren't for parochial work which at once rears its dragon head at me on arrival but one can't play for ever and I must now set to work with renewed vigour. I find the whole house so beautifully clean, it is a joy to see and the flowers are simply perfect - the drawing room full of them and the conservatory a perfect blaze of daffodils, jonquils, narcissi, hiacinths (sic) and tulips. I spent a busy day setting many household chores to rights, paying house accounts, ordering stores etc in fact all the things which compose a hausfrau's duties. Of course one feels a bit flat and unprofitable after such a lovely bust as I have had. The Strike continues everything is at a standstill and the situation most serious. How and when will it all end.

March 6th
I spent the morning writing letters and after lunch the Grays drove us to Aldershot to the finals of the Football Matches where I presented the Shield and medals to the winners of the season's efforts. Our Division won and the enthusiasm was great.

March 7th
I made cakes and wrote letters all morning - the cakes were a failure much too hot an oven and so they rose up at once to opulence and then sank back exhausted! However I'll not be beat but try again tomorrow.

March 8th
More cakes and with great success this time! (This battle continued through March. Since people cooked on a range, with no control over temperature, it became a matter of judgement and luck whether things would emerge cooked, burnt or raw! The good cooks developed a sort of instinct about their ovens, and learnt how to regulate the fire).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: March 9th - 16th The Coal Strike continues, delaying trains, causing prices to rise and bringing the economy to a halt. Wynne resumes her duties - Mothers meetings, District visits and endless committees....
viewer_4.description:
March 9th
I drove this morning into Aldershot to do some shopping, the pony going beautifully and as well as ever. I called on the way to see if I could pick up Joe but she was going in herself. I did many jobs and got back only just in time for lunch. The one topic of conversation in everyone's mouth at present is this terrible Coal Strike which continues day by day and negotiations are still at a deadlock, great distress is prevalent more so among the out-of-works of other industries than the miners who are absolutely obdurate and refuse to give in one iota.

March 11th
I took my first Mothers' meeting today since my return and 31 attended with more than a dozen babies. They all seemed very pleased to see me and gave me a very kind welcome. It certainly is an effort this work if one is unfitted for it as I but it is some compensation when one realizes how much they appreciate it.
H and I attended a Missionary Meeting tonight where we had a discourse from a Mr Kennedy who comes from Gorruckpore. We feel very virtuous!

March 12th
More cakes this morning and I am glad to say that this time they were a great success. I set forth this afternoon with good intention of going round my district but had not gone very far when I realized that it was washing day, a most inappropriate one for visiting so instead called on Mrs Eden and finding her out went on to make the acquaintance of Mrs Newcome. (Wynne had to "do the district" most weeks - this involved visiting the homes of soldiers serving under her husband, hearing problems and being a conduit for solutions).

March 13th
Many happy returns to my dear old Gran who is 98 today. We started off betimes to Town to spend the day with her. Today in consequence of the Coal Strike the train service is suspended and only 3 trains run up in the morning, and 2 down in the evening - by reason of this they were awfully crowded and when we got to Waterloo pandemonium reigned, same in the tube, but eventually we arrived...we had to leave at 5 to catch the 5.30 which we found to be a very long train and absolutely crammed full even to people standing, and if we had missed that we shouldn't have got another till past 7.0. Daily conferences are taking place between the Govt. and the miners' leaders and Owners but nothing comes of it and the situation becomes worse and worse every day.

March 14th
I attended a committee meeting of Yolland Home at the Vicarage which made me yawn and after lunch I went to another at the General where I also had tea, such an odd collection of old boo-boos, I couldn't think what I was doing in such company!

March 15th
The Strike Conference continues. One can only say it has not failed in so far as it still exists, but nothing comes of it and things are getting more and more desperate. I dont know what coal is now but some had risen to 40/- a ton last week.

The papers are full of distress and the enclosed cutting shows the number of unemployed at present. Rioting with the police has begun in Lancashire and wholesale pillaging and law breaking of course. All food stuffs are up and bread has risen. We have to economise in water and gas also and creep about at night in the dark. Thank goodness we were able to get in about 4 ton just before we came back but the contractor owes us a ton which I suppose we may whistle for. I have been doing District all the afternoon and my head aches from stuffy rooms.

March 16th
Today we were not surprised to see in the M.P. (Morning Post) that the "Conference" has broken down and that Parliament now proposes bringing in a Bill for minimum wage. What the result will be cannot be foreseen but the M.P. predicts "rocks ahead" to use their own expression.
(The period before World War One was one of great economic prosperity coupled with increasing labour and political unrest. The Asquith government had already brought in the Coal Mines (8 Hour) act in 1908 to limit the working day, The Trades Board Act in 1909, Insurance Act in 1911 and a Shops Act to give shop assistants a weekly half day off...The Miners Minimum Wage Act was passed in 1912. The Morning Post was a conservative paper, and Wynne's opinions reflect that).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The visit to Malvern to check out the preparatory school for her son allowed Wynne to explore the town. These cards are from her visit there in .

Above: Malvern from the North Hill, and below, Malvern looking towards the British Camp.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: March 17th - 23rd Herbert's birthday remembered with joy, Committees commemorated with hatred, the Coal Strike continues and Wynne and Herbert brave the railways to go and inspect a school for their son.
viewer_6.description:
March 17th
This is my Dearest's birthday, so very many happy returns to him. It seems to me only a short time ago that we began spending birthdays together, and yet what was the world like I wonder before we did that. I can't imagine a world without Poggy somehow, my dear blessed man. It has as far as weather is concerned been a most horrible day, pouring so with rain that I did not go to Church. My Christian went however, nothing daunted, but then he doesn't wear skirts! I spent the morning and a good deal of the afternoon in going over my oak box of treasures and reading a lot of old letters. Dear me, what memories they do rake up, I read also his to me before we were engaged and some just after - dear letters they are my greatest treasures and I value them more than gold, how blessed it has all been and still is and when I think of all he has had to put up with in me and my monkey

tricks I think him more wonderful and splendid than ever, I mean this most truly and there is no mock humility about it. I read too a great number of letters of congratulations on my engagement, funny old things, each so characteristic of the writer, but I must say it all seems so long, so very long ago, that it makes me feel a thousand and I would that I could have that time back again. Where is the use of digging up old bones - it is rather a melancholy occupation, and there is no denying the fact that I have arrived at sober years where frivolity should be behind me! but is it? Ah! that is the question, and I cannot help but own that as yet I allow my years to sit lightly on me!

March 18th
Oh happy day! What a day! would that I were like a pelican in the wilderness and an owl in the dessert - no desert I mean! that I might escape such days as this, for after a very busy and "Monday morningish" morning I sallied forth to the Church House to attend a Committee of the Nursing show here. That finished I rushed back to lunch at 1.0, back up there for my Mothers' Meeting at 2.0 until 4.0 then home to tea. From 5.30 till 7.0 I refreshed myself at the Skipwith's on their Pianola, dinner at 7.30 and once more back to the Church House for a Committee of the Parish Council which lasted till 10.0. I was just about sick of this day by the time I had finished with it, and wondered why I had ever been born. I hate serving on committees - rotten shows and nothing ever seems to come of them!

March 19th

...how strange it seems that I have never forgotten the above childish amusement, this "language" which Meantys (?) Grimstone and I made up when we were 12 years old, it comes as easy to me to read and write as English almost, and what fun we have had over it.

March 20th
The Strike of course continues and the situation becomes worse and worse naturally - the Bill which is proposed finds no sort of favour in any quarter so far as I can see, it is altogether a curious affair and I should think no Govt. had ever put itself into such a complicated situation before.


March 21st
After taking a good many days to make up our minds we at length set off today to Malvern to inspect the school to which my Pinkie goes in May. We knew beforehand of course that on account of the strike the train service had been greatly suspended and that we should have trouble but we hardly thought we should spend 9 hours in the train!....at 7.0 we got to Malvern and found Mr Wood the headmaster waiting for us, we drove up the hill and put up at the Gold Hill Hotel and after dinner went over to the school where we were greeted by Mrs Wood, his sister Miss Wood and hers, Miss Gibbs who acts as Matron. They all seemed very nice and pleasant and we sat talking over matters until 10.30.

March 22nd
At 11.0 we went again to the school and inspected everything, the class rooms and dormitories, the isolation ward, the gym, fives and racquet courts, playgrounds etc. and were thoroughly satisfied with everything. I feel quite contented to send my dear darling there but oh! the horrible wrench it will be. I hate the thought. (Wynne added postcards of Malvern to the diary, and you can see them in the page viewer before this entry).


March 23rd, Saturday
We didn't get back until 8.0 last night thoroughly sick of trains. Wrote letters all afternoon, going over to the Bacons for tea and the Skipwiths afterwards to play the Pianola. They are so awfully kind and friendly and are always asking me to go over to play, I simply love it, and wish to goodness I had one too! there is a thing called Finlandia by Sibelius which I could hear all day and never tire of, just grand and sublime.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The Coal Strike generated much debate. Here is a cartoon cut from the Morning Post, which Wynne stuck into her diary...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: March 24th - 31st Monday chores, and Mother comes to stay, but plans for Easter abandoned. The Coal Strike finally comes to an end, and a new Minimum Wage law is passed...but there is more trouble ahead!
viewer_8.description:
March 25th
My usual Monday chores occupied my morning, the giving out of linen, ordering of food, store cupboard dustings and flowers, all the usual things which go to make up the daily round and common task so that the time soon fled away.

March 26th, Tuesday
Mother came down from town to spend the night with us.


March 27th
Another perfectly glorious day, quite impossible to beat...Poggy and I set to and gardened again whilst Mother sat by crowned with the Morning Post to keep the sun out of her eyes. At 5.30 I drove down to the station with her and saw her off back to Town. We had originally planned that she, Gran and Win were all to come down for Easter but in view of this wholesale train suspension we have decided to give it up - it is very disappointing and I fear poor old Gran will feel it but it really wouldn't be safe to risk her in the rush of Easter traffic.

March 28th
The Parliament has passed a Bill, the Minimum Wage has now become law but as Govt. has refused to include the miners' schedule it remains to be seen if they will accept it. Today the papers announce that the men are to Ballot, beginning on Sat. and Wed. we are to know the result. These are in truth most troublous times and no one can complain that we live in a dull (age) again. At last many small mines are beginning to work and as there has been trouble in consequence already in Wales troops have already gone there from Shrewsbury whilst the 4th Fusiliers and the 2nd Suffolks left here today to take their place. The camp is in a hubbub about it and I hear that 2 hours after they received the notice they were gone. It is rather curious to realize that out of the 4 men at the Parry Crooks on Tuesday 3 have now gone on strike duty.
I read today that coal in Leicester has risen to £2 a ton for engine slack and £5 a ton fro household - too frightful for words.

March 29th
I have actually had a whole day at home, it has been a treat and I have spent the whole of it, as soon as I could get away from the house, in gardening. Poggy had to go away to a footer match where the General was presenting a cup given by himself and they walked by here together afterwards, he is a funny old boo boo, much given to muttering under his breath, but very pleasant and nice.

Here is a rather clever little poem describing poor Asquith's thorny position. I think his must be a fearful lot, what with this Strike, Home Rule, Disestablishment, Insurance Act and the Labour Socialist Nationalist factions all shrieking their various outrageous demands - enough to drive a man to suicide.

March 31st, Sunday
A quiet day with the usual service in the morning during which rain came on and we walked home in torrents, drenched...found to our joy that the blackbird's nest in the ivy stump has 3 eggs in it today, everything in the garden looked so lovely after the rain and all is growing so splendidly. The papers yesterday seemed to think that the strike is drawing to a close, the men are gradually returning to work and now the next thing will be to see the result of the Ballot. Of course trade will be crippled for weeks and everything disorganized, but the end is in view and is a great thing. The next commotion will be the Home Rule Bill which is to come after Easter.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The strike created acres of newsprint...just as it would today. One popular pastime at that period was parody, and the readers of this column would have instantly recognized the original on which H.H.Munro based his piece...do you?

The piece concludes with the whole jungle in uproar, which in turn brings out the comb-bees ("that have their tunnels and galleries underground"). The furious bees stop everyone in their tracks - an allusion to the miners bringing the country to a standstill. The assumption in the whole article is that Lloyd George and his "socialist" ideas are to blame for it all.
