H.H.Munro, better known as Saki, was a brilliant writer of short stories, many of them with a satirical slant. Oddly, wolves featured in quite a number of them - indeed in one subversive story (Gabriel-Ernest, 1909) the hero appears in a respectable house entirely naked, and actually becomes a wolf at sundown.

Nearly all his work appeared in the Tory press. His best work is short, and suited to this medium. His novels were less successful.

In spite of his age (he was 44 at the outbreak of war), Munro enlisted, and was killed at the Battle of the Ancre in 1915. His battalion, the 22nd, Royal Fusiliers, were advancing, and he spotted a soldier lighting up. His last words were: "put that bloody cigarette out!" before a sniper pinpointed them, and he was shot.

The article that Wynne cut out and stuck into the diary consisted of a single newspaper column. At the bottom was a news item: Otter Killed At Chelsea. It reported the arrival of an otter at Cheyne Walk, and the subsequent attempts to catch it. In the end, at the suggestion of the police, the butler of the house where it was hiding "obtained a gun and shot it". Now there's a change - can't imagine that being allowed to happen today!

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Marconi straddles the world - Wynne was fascinated by the new technology. Everyone used the telegraph system rather than phones, as you can see from entries this month....

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: May 1st - 6th Wynne is based at Aldershot, and this month has to wave goodbye to 3 of her household - 2 children off to school, and her husband to Army camp in Wales.
viewer_2.description:
"MARCONIGRAMS FOR ALL" - this new service starts, and Wynne sees three members of her family off from home, but she still manages to have a good time in London too...later in the month, she benefits from the wire service.


May 1st
(Wynne has cut out an article about the new telegraph service. It reads: "This is a deedful day in the history of the British Post Office. On and after this, the 1st of May, Marconi messages can be sent from any telegraph office in the United Kingdom to those in the United States and Canada. A wireless word can now be transmitted over 3000 miles for fourpence.")
I found the enclosed in the Graphic today, tis a wonderful world we live in but I suppose if anyone reads this 20 years hence they will think it the most ordinary thing in the world and wonder at one making such a fuss about it!
I miss Win so much (her niece had just gone back to school, and her son is about to go), and on Friday Pink goes and Monday next sees H off to camp. I am having a rotten time. (While this may have been true, the departure of the family didn't stop her from having a good time up in London, and later in the month she travelled to be with her husband at his annual army camp in Wales).

May 2nd
I packed my Pinks school trunk for he is off tomorrow and my heart is like lead. I wonder if anyone but a parent can realize what a loss this is the first child's first step into the world for I don't fancy they are ever quite ones small mouse in the same way again.

May 3rd
The dreaded day has come and is over, a veritable black Friday. We took the child up to Paddington and as we were early we had lunch there. We found Bobbie and finally deposited them both with the Master who was in charge of 10 other small creatures. Pink looked so neat in his Norfolks and eton collar and school cap - it was a fearful and horrible moment when the train disappeared into nothing taking with it our dear little shaver, he however went off quite gaily and much excited I am thankful to say.

May 6th
This week has been like a series of visits to the dentist - first Win, then Pink and now H has gone - three teeth pulled in one week - "too much, too much".
I went up to town tonight, my dear Mrs Gray sending the car for me. I just enjoyed that drive more than I can say, it somehow blew the cobwebs away and the country was looking its very best. I never saw anything to equal the colouring of the brilliant young larches, birches and beeches against the blue green of the firs and the splendid young copper beeches - everywhere the lilacs, laburnums and pink and white May are out and over all the scent of spring intoxicates one with its beauty.
Went on afterwards to see Marie Tempest in "At The Barn", an amusing and smart little play in which she wears the new pannier frocks, at present they look like fancy dress but doubtless we shall al be prancing about in them before long.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Theatre visits continued - this month Wynne managed to see Pavlova dance. She had caught her on her first visit in 1910 (see bottom) when she had appeared at the Palace Theatre partnered by Michael Mordkin. Notice how she is part of a very varied variety bill.

By , she was a huge star in England, and took star billing. Mordkin, who had been given equal billing in 1910, was now dropped!

The 1910 programme is below. Note also the cinema item at the end of the evening - films were little more than fairground attractions, and often featured at the end of theatre variety shows...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: May 10th - 16th Anna Pavlova dances in London, Granny admires the new aeroplanes and Blanche has a bad motor-car crash!
viewer_4.description:
Committee and duties don't prevent Wynne from catching several London theatres, including Anna Pavlova on her famous annual visit to London. She takes her 98 year old Gran to see the new airplanes too...and then has to comfort her Mother, who has been in a car accident. The telegraph system works overtime!


The week started with dreaded committee meetings, and more "shirts" (where the army wives sewed on buttons to the accompaniment of Wynne reading), and more districting, which she hated. This involved endless visits to army households. However on Friday, she was off to Town again...
May 10th
Once more to Town. I fled away. Hurrah, hurrah! (She then rushed around the shops, the hairdressers etc and in the evening prepared to go out to the theatre).
I went off to the Rendezvous and met there Philip Lyster who took me to the "Sunshine Girl", the old Gaiety lot are going strong and Connie Ediss is as delightfully vulgar as ever. We went on afterwards to the Carlton where we coffeed and smoked till nearly 1.0 when he took me home and so ended a pleasant evening for it is always pleasant to find a friend who can be faithful for so long in this world of change.

May 11th
Went to Dickens and Jones and then to B and H and from there strolled down into Soho through some very mean streets and odd places and finally turned up at the Rendezvous where Tom (her nephew) met me and we had a most excellent lunch beer included for 5/4d the two! We then walked over to the Palace to see the Russian dancers and I cant remember ever seeing anything more beautiful than Anna Pavlova - she is simply exquisite and the rest all splendid. (The playbills are in the next window)
We went afterwards and had tea at the Club and then Tommy came and saw me off at Waterloo.

May 14th
I have had a lovely home day and spent it in the garden, staking and tying and cleaning and weeding. I took Gran over to Farnborough today to see the flying. They fly every evening at about 6.0 and she was immensely interested, it is wonderful to think that she remember the first trains and the first steamer from Edinburgh to London and now she has indeed seen the last word in locomotion. We saw five mono and biplanes go up and they looked like huge birds, they seemed under perfect control wheeling away here and there and starting and alighting with such grace and lightness and yet only yesterday two men again, were killed at Brooklands.

May 15th
This has been a day of surprises. Firstly I get a wire from P.G.Lyster saying he is coming to see me on his way through to Scotland. Then Mother yesterday had written saying she would pick Gran up today en route for Brookfield and as she was to leave Town by 10.30 I calculated she would be with me at 12.30 at the latest, but when 1.30 arrived and no Mother I said we would have lunch when there came a wire from her saying she was all right but had had a bad smash up at Surbiton and was coming on by train. At 3.0 she arrived and it appeared that the chauffeur (of the hired taxi) in trying to pass between a big car and a tram had got caught in between and simply was rolled out flat. Thank god Mother wasn't hurt nor he, but the car was matches and she had to come back by tram to Surbiton and get a train. Poor one she was much upset and shaken and had to stay the night.

May 16th
We wired to Henry Macleans works for another car and it turned up at 10.30 and took Mother and Gran home. Then after lunch Maby and I went off to the Queens Parade to see the King present the Colours to 3 different regiments. It was a splendid sight and I had never seen it before.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Wynne's journey by car was a real marathon - it took her three days to get from Aldershot to the Welsh coast, and must have felt like a serious expedition. It was made much more civilised by constant stops for meals and sightseeing, but as you can see from her notes opposite, the whole thing had been planned out with military precision....it starts out at Henley, then to Oxford for lunch before heading on the Moreton in the Marsh...as you can see, Hotels are all noted, as is the mileage.

The notes below refer to a three day option that they actually did not take, choosing instead to stop at Worcester on the first day.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt: May 18th - 25th A royal visit to Aldershot, and the start of a great expedition to Wales...in a motor car!
viewer_6.description:
Up to Town to say farewell to her sister-in-law, and final rounds of duties in Aldershot, including a Royal visit, before setting off to join her husband in Wales, travelling for the first time all the way in a motor car!

May 18th
I went up to Town by the 9.12 today, shopped at the stores and then met Mabel and Tommy at my club where we lunched and went on to see the Bear Leaders afterwards - it is very amusing, we all shrieked and Miss Compton is as clever as ever ...but I am indeed say that this is the last I shall see of my dear Mabel as she sails on the 1st for South Africa.

May 19th
Through the good offices of Gen. Lawson I obtained a seat in the Garrison Church today at which the King and Queen were present, but as no lady was supposed to be there without her husband he lent me his aide, Capt. Boger, who acted as such! and sat beside me. It was a fine service, the K and Q sat on chairs at the foot of the chancel and nothing below a Colonel was present in this august assembly! The Parade was enormous and King took the salute, the crowds assembled to see him were huge but as the Royal ones came and went through Gen. L's garden the public hardly saw them at all and much disappointment ensued.

May 22nd
Round my district in the morning with bundles of old clothes! and another round of calls after lunch. I dined this evening over the way. Tomorrow Mrs G and I start for Wales!

May 23rd
This day we started off to Wales in Mrs G's car. The weather on starting was fine but fresh so I took two big coats. We left at 9.30 and went by Fleet straight up to Oxford where we stayed for lunch, alas the day though fine had grown so cold that we were simply perished. Over all the country there hung a sort of black blight so that we could see no views. We stopped at Moreton in the Marsh for tea which was most refreshing and then went on as far as Worcester where we put up at the Star Hotel for the night, after a splendid run of 117 miles. It was cold though, one couldn't have believed it to be May.

May 24th, Friday.
After a bit more sight-seeing they set off again...
at 11.45 started off. Oh! the country - it was perfect and for lunch we stayed at Ludlow with which I was fascinated, the inn "The Feathers" where we lunched is a most unique and elaborate specimen of half-timbered house - we went up to see the Castle which is now a ruin and which was used for the council of the Marshes, there Arthur eldest brother of Henry VIII sat as first Warden and the little Princes were also kept there prior to their removal to the Tower. It is a grand place and I longed to stay and ruminate but we had to leave at 3.0 for Welshpool where we arrived about 6.0


May 25th
Welshpool. Here we stayed last night at the Royal Oak, a nice large old fashioned inn...we sat up in the churchyard for a long time, a perfect evening very still quiet and calm and at 7.45 had dinner, turning in soon after. The country round here is lovely, huge high hills very much wooded mostly pasture lands but good roads though sometimes very steep hills! We arrived at the Cross Foxes, Trawsfynydd at 4.0 and were joined soon after by our men but we are horrified to find that H and a lot of others have been poisoned by dirty cooking arrangements.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne was amazed to find herself in a part of the country where little English was spoken...she stayed at a hotel called the Cross Foxes, in Trawsfynydd.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt: May 26th - 28th Watching Artillery manoeuvres in the Welsh hills, and enjoying being with her husband again...this visit continued into June.
viewer_8.description:
Having arrived in Wales to stay near her husband who is on army manoeuvres, Wynne does some serious sightseeing....

May 26th, Sunday.
I got up early and was out by 7.30 this morning writing letters, it was a perfect day but now as I write at about 12.30 is has clouded over. The view here is too lovely, the mountains stretch away for miles and all is absolute peace, but we are indeed at the back o'beyond, all the people in this quaint little place talk Welsh and very few understand English at all. Being very strict Sabbatarians, most of them are draped in "decent blacks" and all over the place are chapels - Salem, Bethel, Ebenezer etc..at which today much chanting and praying is going on. I have never heard such long winded prayers as are taking place just opposite to us at Salem and such funereal hymns. I believe tonight at 6.0 they have another bout.

May 27th
Very early I arose today and went down to the meadows where I wrote letters. How beautiful it was, with the huge blue mountains in the distance and the absolute feeling of peace around one.
Dear old Poggy stayed at home today and couldn't come motoring. We went of via Portmadoc to Pwllheli on the sea where we lunched and walked upon the beach afterwards and Major Gray tore his trousers on a boat, roars and shrieks from us, offended dignity from him! Home by 6.0

May 28th
I have enjoyed this day more than I can say but how to describe it? We started off at about 11.0 taking our lunch and motored up to the Ranges. We picked up Mrs Boone en route and betook ourselves to one of the largest and loneliest spots I've ever seen. We sat upon a high crag and below us in the valley were the batteries, the officers grouped round about the gun teams at the usual distance whilst Gen Lawson and his aide, H and his staff were up above us. The air was full of shouted orders and being so still we could hear every word. When the order to start firing was given, round after round was fired and the effect was grand. The flashes at the guns, the shells bursting in the far distance looking like small powder puffs and the wonderful roar as they rushed unseen through the air. Every hill echoed and rang with the sound and it all gave me the feeling as if I wanted to cry! When all was ended they assembled for the pow-wow, the guns rumbled home and in the stillness caused by this absence no sound came up to us except the men's' voices and the chinking of the horses bits as they waited about to take the officers home. At length we all left and the valley was once more given up to its original calm. What must the spirits of the men of Stone Age and Roman times be thinking of such strange proceedings?


What indeed - this entry reminds me so much of Hardy's poem, "Channel Firing", written in April 1914 with ominous prescience. The last stanza goes:
"Again the guns disturbed the hour,
Roaring their readiness to avenge,
So far inland as Stourton Tower,
And Camelot, and starlit Stonehenge."

Wynne visited Barmouth and Harlech, and Beddgelert to see Gelert's Grave, and Dolgelly. The visit continued into June.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The purpose of Wynne's journey was to be with her husband, who was in army camp with his artillery. The women went out to watch the exercise, and Wynne took the photo below from a hill above the valley. It wasn't to be long before these guns were in action.

(You can read about them in action in the Boer War if you cross to Love, and check out Herbert's story...and of course also the years of World War 1)

The officers' camp.

may.description:
The Diary - in MAY...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Postcards from her brother in India, where he was on holiday at one of the hill stations - Darjeeling.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: November 1st - 6th Good news from India, bad news from the Balkans...mothers' meetings and golden weddings.
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Friday
Once more the weather has cleared and the sun is with us, it is really a splendid autumn but very cold. (However everyone had colds, and Wynne complained about the ceaseless epidemic!)

November 3rd
Ell sent me these PCs of Darjeeling, how lovely it must be and I have it in my heart to envy him being in such a perfect place, he was staying with the Gwythers and having such a good time. I am so glad as the dear has never been to the Hills before in all his years in India.

November 4th
My Mondays programme doesn't alter much, there is always the Mothers Meeting and tonight in addition we had a general meeting of the H.P.A. in the Institute. Everyone is very fierce at these meetings and for some time back it has been war to the knife - being outside the fighting line it amuses me much.

November 5th
The other day the Bacons had their Golden Wedding day and all went up to town to celebrate it at the Buckingham Palace Hotel where they had the original breakfast, dear old people, and today they had an At Home to welcome their friends.

November 6th
A day at Home with many jobs and charing. The War still rages on, the Allies heap up more and more successes and the world is viewing with astonishment the utter inability of the wretched Turks to stem the flood, but it is want of organization more than anything that has caused this debacle. The men are literally starved.
(Wynne is referring to the war in the Balkans. This had broken out in October as a direct result of the changes in Turkey after the Young Turk rebellion. There was an upsurge of Balkan nationalism, and the various Balkan states managed to comprehensively defeat Turkey, pushing her out of the area she had ruled for several centuries, but this merely whetted the appetites of the various lesser and greater powers, and added to the instability which led ultimately to the assassination in Sarajevo and the First World War. It is interesting to see Wynne give the events only a passing notice - earlier diaries show her sensible to the dangers developing in Europe, but she clearly did not give this current war much thought, though it rates several mentions).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A photo of Wynne's brother, Elliot, who was out in India. It was Elliot who sent the postcards you can see in the earlier window, but this photo was taken down on the plains.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 7th - 15th

A visit to the hidden parts of the Tower of London, and an exciting excursion for the children to do their Christmas shopping
viewer_4.description:
November 7th, Thursday
(Went) to the Tower to see Mr Mitchell who is Chaplain there. This kind one took us all over that lovely and most interesting old place, into all the bogey holes where the public are not allowed to go. He showed us the priceless and absolutely unique old Chalices, Pattens etc out of which those poor victims of the block took their last communion. It seemed strange to hold them in our hands, and also see the ancient register recording so many tragedies. There in the Sanctuary under the Altar lie the bones of the illustrious people including three of Henry V11's wives, Anne Boleyn, the Earl of Essex, Judge Jefferies and that pathetic figure Margaret, Countess of Salisbury, who was not beheaded until she was over 70, and who refused to put her head on the block and rushed screaming round the square pursued by the headsman who hacked her to death. When first discovered all these bones lay just under the stone slabs and only Anne Boleyn had any form of coffin which consisted of an old nail box. What books one could fill with the hopes and fears of these poor handful of people. We also saw the gloomy dungeons, the Jews Hole, Little Ease etc - oh! the unutterable darkness and silence of these horrible places one could literally feel it.


Taxi home to Mother, where on arrival I found a phone message to the effect that my Peter (her dog) had been run over by a motor and they feared a broken jaw, leg and internal injuries. I was distraught.

November 8th
I came down by the 11.45 and went straight to the vet, and there to my very great joy found the only injury a broken leg which he says he can mend all right. I was so relieved.
Various family visits followed, and the usual round of work meetings and district chores.

November 13th, Wednesday
This was the great day of the year for the children, for we set off to the Bon Marché with our bags of money to do our annual shopping for Xmas. Alas! I missed my dear little son this year. We went by the vulgar train and stayed away until 8.0 doing all most successfully and spending a very happy day. The children were so good and did so enjoy all the lovely things they saw, and I am always quite sorry went its over for another year.
(This was an annual outing, to the large shop in Brixton that was quite famous before the First War. In 1910, Wynne had described it thus: "the very name savours of the shabby genteel, however the B.M. turned out a splendid place, a huge selection of everything, very cheap, we bought many fascinating things for the children and I think I shall go again later for the remaining necessities.")

November 15th
Drove this day to have tea with Major Ward, he pro tem is out of Barracks in consequence of alterations to quarters and has taken the neatest little house at Crookham, it has a tiny garden opening into a wood and he has made it all so very nice. We had the most delicious tea with jam and cakes and all that's good.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: From the Morning Post, a quirky little note from Italy about the current situation in the Balkans, where the status quo of Ottoman rule had been shattered by the war.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 16th - 25th

A wedding, and a visit to London to see the new du Maurier play.
viewer_6.description:
November 16th
This being the day of the General's wedding, H and I went up early, did some shopping first then lunched at Mothers and went on at 2.0 to Holy Trinity, Sloane Square to the wedding. There assembled a large concourse of people, snuffy for the most part and all went off very nicely and quietly. She looked charming in a lovely gown of deep cream satin trimmed with lace, diamonds and sable with a huge brown feather hat. We went back to Mother for a short spell and then on to the Carlton to tea with the Skipwiths, they are up in town for a fortnight, she to be with her sister, and we miss them much at home.

November 19th
Poggy has been away all day long. he went down to Brighton by the very early train so we arose by the light of a candle at 6.30, a very dark morning but no rain and he didn't get back till dinner time.

November 20th
I offed it to Town today , went by the vulgar train, walked on arrival from Oxford Circus to Hanover Square where I had lunch with Walter Butler and Topsy and then on to du Maurier's new play "Doormats". It is beautifully staged and a most clever piece. I enjoyed every word and it is a piece every married couple ought to see. Old Alfred Bishop is so clever I just shrieked at him and I am longing to go again. I came home by the 5.30 sorely tempted to stay at their bidding!

November 21st
A day at Home, a whole free day and how I have enjoyed it. My morning I spent in household chores and after lunch went for a long walk with Maby and Nootie to the quarries above Ewshott and through the village round by the church and home. It was a soft still grey day, so warm it might have been Spring and one felt refreshed by the real exercise.

November 22nd
Dear Gran is keeping so very well thank god, she has been walking in the garden this morning and yesterday took a drive. She is more and more wonderful, reads and writes without her glasses and looks so sweet in her close fitting round caps with her dear serene face.

November 23rd
Alas another cold approacheth, how welcome are these frequent joys one knows and loves so well!! (and Wynne took to her bed, but still managed to get up for Mothers meetings and other chores).

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Playbill for the new du Maurier play Wynne went to see on November 20th.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 26th - 30th

Recovering from a cold, Wynne catches up with her reading and worries about the Balkan War.
viewer_8.description:
November 26th, Tuesday
I stayed in my bed till 11.0! but really I just felt as if I'd like to stay there for ever but I felt better when once down. It has been a most fearfully stormy day, howling wind and torrents of rain and my poor man had to be out all day in it and attend a committee meeting after dinner as well. War news goes on at present much the same, the talk of Peace is in the air but the Balkans' terms are so severe that Turkey is refusing them and so there is a deadlock, but cholera as well a famine has attacked the poor wretches now and the most fearful horrors are taking place.

November 28th
I have been employed lately in reading the Mill on the Floss, the Tower of London and Wuthering Heights, and how interesting they are, and now I am engrossed in Mrs Gaskell's Life of Charlotte Bronte. I have been giving myself a present of some "Everymans" Library, there are such heaps of them I should like and hope by degrees to get lots more. They are awfully nice for 1/-.
Shirts all morning and after lunch I went off for a walk with Maby and Nootie to try and get warm - it is so bitterly cold and I really feel simply shrammed, but it is so seasonable!

November 29th
Such a dark dripping day how vile but a bit warmer thanks be. Herbert is away all day long on a regimental exercise and at a lecture in the evening. I employ myself writing and Nootle sits on the floor in any sort of position everlastingly reading, quite unaware of anything that may be going on round her.

November 30th
Accomplished some work in my district today, called on the Davis', a wretched and most miserable poor family with a drinking Mother and 8 children. She is away at work at Woking and descends periodically upon them. I must ferret out a bundle of old clothes. The de Mornays came to tea, they are going to send Charlie to Pink's school and he having been down inspecting came to tell us all about it, and was much pleased with it all.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: A Map of Wynne's territory: she lived in Upper Hale, and the walk she describes on November 21st to Ewshot is, as you can see, quite a long hike. Her visit to Crookham, described on November 15th, would have taken place with the horse and buggy they had. The area would have felt quite rural in those days, and walks would not have been impeded by the motor car!

november.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: A domestic scene - Young, Herbert's batman, washing the newly gifted terrier, watched by Thomas (Pink) and Eleanor (Baby). The photo is one of many Wynne took, developed and printed herself.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 7th

The usual chores for an army wife in Aldershot.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Tuesday
October has come in warm, windy and turning to torrents after lunch. It can never do anything by halves in this country. We are much interested in a new work now, that of making a dolls house for the children. The wood has come and H has been on the start this afternoon.

October 3rd
Shirts all the morning from 10.0 to 1.0. Oh! weary work. We were detained a full half hour whilst one woman took off and put on about 60 buttons

October 4th, Friday
Church decorating from 10.0 to 1.0. The result of everyone's labours looked very pretty but I had had enough of it by 1.0! I finished up my district and at 7.30 we went to the Festival Service which was very nice and cheery.

October 5th
Poggy (her husband) and I did a lot of pricking out today of spring seedlings and then Mrs Wrigley came to tea. At 6.45 we dined tonight with the Skippys, afterwards going to see "When Knights Were Bold" at the theatre here. James Welch's company was down and it was very well given.

October 6th
Good news from India. Each one very well and cheery. Ell was just off to Darjeeling to stay, I don't think he's ever been to the Hills in his life and I am so glad. We went to early service as usual and I had my horrible faint feeling. I wish I could get over that, its horrid. My dear man left me at 2.0 for Chatham where he has gone for a weeks engineering.

October 7th, Monday
The winter season seems really begun to me for my Mother's Meeting commenced this afternoon and I had an attendance of 29. Such a lovely day and I longed to be in the garden.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Brigadier General Jackson, C.O. of the 2nd Division, RHA at Aldershot, on his favourite horse.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 8th - 14th

More duties. Wynne's husband is the Commanding Officer, so she is much in demand and has to perform many public services.
viewer_4.description:
October 8th, Tuesday
Perfect weather again. I took Baby down to Farnham where we both had our hair cut! and then I did spring planting till tea to which Mrs Richards came, poor woman, I think it was a change to her to get away from Barracks though I suppose she is used to the life. (Mrs Richards was the Sergeant Major's wife. Wynne had taken pity on her, as she had crossed the class barriers to marry, and was living in the barracks, in very restricted accommodation).

There continued much talk of weather and visits to neighbours and friends. On October 12th her husband returned from his engineering stint at Chatham, his journey delayed by fog, but the Indian Mail brought news of her brother enjoying himself in Darjeeling. Wynne's weeks seem filled with chores:

October 14th, Monday
This has been a day of wild parochialism. A Mothers Meeting after lunch and an HPA Meeting at 8.15. Oh! how chaste are these joys I shall soon turn into a mixture of Parish Charwoman and Camp hag. I had a big meeting: 37 women and about 18 babies, the latter I had taken up toys for in order to keep them quiet but I think it only incensed them to louder squawks! The meeting in the evening was fierce to say the least of it, and all flew at each others throats. Talk of women fighting and Kilkenny cats, these men could give them points all round.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Springfield, the family home in Chelmsford, where Wynne and her husband made frequent visits.

If you move your mouse over the old photo, you will see a picture of the house as it is today. (Thanks to Pippa Lewis and Gillian Darley at Edifice)

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 15th - 21st

A visit to Herbert's mother at Springfield, near Chelmsford. Then its back to Aldershot for the continuing round of duties.
viewer_6.description:
October 15th
We started off at 9.12 to go to Springfield, but found the fog so thick that we missed our train and had to wait an hour at Liverpool Street. However we amused ourselves by going for a walk examining the new arcade outside the station and testing personally with many shrieks the Escalator which they have at the Tube entrance in the station. We watched others at this pastime too, all trying to look as is they had done it all their lives but their footsteps betrayed them badly! We got down by lunch and are quite a large party...12 of us...and Mother is ever so much better and comes down for lunch, tea and dinner which last she has in the drawing room.

October 16th
The usual walk down to Town in the morning and after lunch we all went down to an entertainment given at the Grammar School by a Dr Collisson...such a clever show, I laughed so that I really nearly had hysterics.

October 17th, Thursday
We left this morning by an early train as I had to be back by 2.30 for an M.U. meeting.

October 18th
Mrs Gray came for me at 10.0 this morning and we went over to Camberley to find a present for Gen. Lawson who is to be married on the 16th Nov to Lady Lathom. We chose a very handsome Sheffield Plate cup with curious old coins let in all over it, such an uncommon thing. Then I flew back and attended at 12.0 a committee meeting of the Yolland House and after lunch I hied my round my district on various errands taking my Babbit with me. She is such a darling, so good and sweet and trotted along holding conversation all the time.

October 21st, Monday
My programme on Mondays is never thrilling and always consists of a Mothers Meeting. This day I had the extra excitement of a nursing committee as well. At my meeting there were present 36 women and 14 babies and their gear. They are such a noisy crowd of young monkeys, the babies I mean. I give them toys and biscuits both of which only seem to make them worse and its awful reading against it.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The family in the garden at Upper Hale, Farnham. Wynne is carrying her camera. Thomas and Ysobel stand between the adults.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
October 22nd - 30th

Lectures, concerts and various dinners - some to Wynne's liking, others not!
viewer_8.description:
October 22nd, Tuesday
I went to rather an interesting lecture today upon the Seaman's Mission, held at the Milroy's house and given by a Mr Lees who spoke awfully well. Why is it I wonder that the attendance at these sort of shows is always composed of the most mouldy and motheaten old women, never a man amongst them and surely today it was a man's subject.
We had to dine tonight over at the Robbs. It is quite 8 miles, the cold was horrid and it was quite foggy and Oh! the Dr Fellish feeling I have for them both, he is a prissy old pedant and she is a horsey "g clippin" lady. The Northeys were there, also the Stopfords, the Commandant of the RMC, a nice man, but the Robbs are so impressed by their house and money and valuable possessions that I cannot away with them and I do not think we need do it again.

October 24th
I was much fed up at getting the usual letter from Mrs Kavanagh yesterday asking me to do her Shirts, so off I went this morning.
To dinner tonight came the Hakings, the O'Callaghans and the Grays. We had a very cheery evening despite my depression when the Charlotte Russe came in looking as if Veacock (the cook) had sat on it.

October 29th, Tuesday
Went to a very good concert this afternoon: Liza Lehman was down and had with her Evangeline Florence, Powell Edwards and that arch pogbag Lady Tree who recited with many coquettings and engaging smiles, but the music was charming.

October 30th
To Town then we did go by the 10.2 ( although Wynne by now had a heavy cold and really wanted to stay in bed). Did much business and went and lunched with Mum and then out again, returning in time to dress and go off to dinner at the Hyde Park with the Grays, then after much lovely food we went to see the "Little Cafe" which is Cyril Maude's new play and very amusing indeed.

October 31st
We got up and had breakfast at 8.0 this morning. Ugh! My cold felt horrible and such a throat, but I had to go to Shirts so I took the 9.35 down and got to the Hut about 10.45. It poured the rest of the day so I didn't go out again and here endeth a very lovely October.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The programme for the "Little Cafe" play that Wynne went to see. Almost all theatre programmes were like this - a folded card or single sheet with the relevant details, and some adverts up the side or over on the reverse. They were not like the little books one gets today.

october.description:
The Diary - in OCTOBER...

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Tarrant Keyneston in Dorset was where Wynne grew up - compare the photos she took of the Church and her father's grave in 1910 with the ones taken in 2001

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: September 1st - 8th Aldershot. As the commanding officer's wife Wynne has many duties, but still manages to get back to the family home and visit her father's grave
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Sunday

"Dirty days hath September
April June and November
(February days are quite all right
It only rains from morn till night)
All the rest have thirty one
Without a blessed gleam of sun
And if the others had two and thirty
They'd be just as wet and just as dirty."

Oh! how appropriate is this, for every day the rain descends and the sun is pleased to hide his face - but just for today he really showed himself for a short while and we all took a family walk to the catchment and gathered blackberries.
Win is showing signs of c.pox so alas she must go tomorrow with Maggie and Nooty off to Brookfield (her mother's house in the country).
On the 2nd, a farewell dinner was held in the mess for one friend, but on the 3rd, more serious news...

September 3rd
Mrs Taylor also came to lunch, poor woman she is in dreadful trouble, her husband actually having left her, he is off his head I think and I cant imagine how its all going to end as he has exchanged for India and sails at once, meanwhile he cant be found.

Sept 4th
I drove down to Barracks today to visit Mrs Richards. I found her very happy and comfortable and had a long talk with her, but what a life really, how can anyone contemplate marrying beneath them, everything must jar so really. (And see Wynne's comments in August - marrying out of one's class, and worse, leaving one's wife were things almost unheard of then).

Wynne packed up on the 5th and travelled down to Brookfield on the 6th to stay with her mother.
Her niece was better, but "such a sight", presumably covered in spots. As you can see from the accompanying photos, she clearly got over it, and was a pretty as ever.

September 7th
I have just come down here to idle and do it splendid. This day was spent in pottering, writing letters and playing with the children. It is a delightful rest and I am enjoying it much.

September 8th, Sunday
To Church (at Tarrant Keyneston, in Dorset) in the morning, it seems so strange to think that I haven't been here for over a year. I fear poor Mr Wingate (the vicar) must be very bad as they prayed for him in Church. After service I went round to the grave (of her father) and found it neat and clean, they are taking in another large piece of ground behind there and despite the fact that Sir William is giving it, the wall I hear is to cost £50. Everything seems to stand still in this sleepy hollow - the same people sit in their usual seats but one feels old when beside old Drake one sees sitting his youngest son a grown up lad. The eldest daughter has just gone to British Columbia to marry young Cave.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The joys of the country - Wynne's two eldest, Thomas and Ysobel, play in the stream at Tarrant Keyneston...

While her niece Win reads a book and smiles at her aunt holding the camera. Compare this with the photo of the same scene taken in 2001...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 9th - 15th

A country idyll. Staying in Dorset with her Mother, Wynne enjoys lovely weather, country walks and many memories.
viewer_4.description:
September 9th, Monday
Quite a lovely morning, still and warm and sunny so after a pottering morning I took the children down to the stream where my three paddled and got drenched to the skin, thoroughly enjoying themselves whilst Win (her niece) read the Gladiators. We sat down by Lanes Bridge with the water rushing swiftly by and falling over the weir making that long accustomed sound which we all know so well, there I saw again the roots of the old willow like coral strands and smelt the indescribable smell of mint and river weeds - it all reminded me so strongly of our salad days where we used to do just the same.

September 10th
I have been writing all day long or rather all the morning, my mail and to H who sent a P.C. from Swaffham saying they were in a swamp, poor fellows, so dreadfully uncomfortable. Went for a walk down to Crawford and on towards Spettisbury Church through the fields.


Sept 11th
The Macleans came over to lunch today and Henry afterward took the children and me up to Badbury Rings, dear old place what jolly days we have spent there, what heaps of picnics and blackberry parties we have had up there. We picked a lot today.

Sept 12th, Thursday
Pink and I have got up early and I am writing this under the pergola, it is a glorious morning bright and fresh indeed, a real autumn feeling in the air, the sun is making long shadows over the grass and Bob Robin is singing his autumn song.

September 13th
The children and I went sloe picking today and found a bush of perfectly lovely ones, huge like damsons. We are going to make sloe gin. The kids and Mother drove into B(landford) after lunch and I took Baby down to tea at the Pennys. Such a lovely day.


September 14th, Saturday
I broke the record in wool gathering this morning. Thinking it was Sunday I went off to early Service! finding of course the Church locked , really I must be getting softening of the brain. We have been making sloe gin all day, such a business, I hope the results about 2 or 3 years hence will be satisfactory. We have been awfully busy answering enquiries of Brookfield, the result of adverts in the M(orning) P(ost). I do hope something may turn up.
(Wynne's Mother was attempting to let the big house and move to somewhere both smaller and more affordable).

September 15th
I went to Early Service this morning - struck the right day today! it is a glorious day and we sat lazing in the summer house all day, indeed I slept nearly all day long! and went to Evening Service where the usual quite large congregation was assembled.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A page from the September diary, with photos...all taken in Dorset

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 16th - 22nd

Picnics and blackberrying. Then its an end to the holidays - back to school and back to Aldershot and her many duties.
viewer_6.description:
September 16th, Monday
The lovely weather continues and I took the kids up on to Abbeycroft Downs, to the far Plantations which lie beneath Badbury where we roamed about gathering nuts and exploring the secret hiding places of the rabbits. No one seemed to have walked there for years and it was lovely to sit in this still cool remote place and listen to the autumn songs of the robins which are perfection this month, and so melancholy, it is always connected in my mind with burning weeds and autumn mist.

September 17th
After lunch the children and I went off blackberry picking and got 7lbs just in the home fields.

September 18th
Oh how lovely is this Indian summer, all day long the sun pours down upon us and we are just revelling in it. The Macleans turned up at 1.30 and took us all up to Badbury Rings to blackberry, we lunched up there and picked many lbs whilst Mother looked after the Baby and was made to be a lion, crocodile and various other things. Poor Mother, so dreadfully nervous driving no wonder she hates it, but it was impossible to persuade her or to calm her fears.

September 19th
The Macleans stayed the night and we played Coon Can and Whiskey Poker till all was blue, and today they drove us into the Show. I always enjoy it and it reminds me of old times when we used to have such fun at it. I paid long visits to the large and fat pigs and cows and sheep. It was a very big show and full of entries, all but the jumping which was atrocious, and no horse who jump anything!

September 20th, Friday
Alas my dear darling left for school today, how I do miss him and how horrible is the wrench. I took him as far as Cheltenham from where he travelled in the guards van and had no change. I didn't get back to the house till nearly 8.0 worn out and bereft.

September 21st
We all left today another horrid wrench. I did so hate leaving Mother it is so deadly dull down there for her alone with Gran, indeed it is bad for them both.

September 22nd
I took the children down to Church in the morning and wrote letters all the afternoon. At 5.0 my man arrived looking so well and it is so ripping to be together again. We had lots to talk about and mutual news to exchange.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: A picnic at Badbury Rings, Dorset. Wynne's Mother refused to come because she was scared of the transportation....

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 23rd - 30th

Shirts, shopping and other duties, with a quiet aside about the army chaplain!
viewer_8.description:
September 23rd, Monday
Poggy (her husband) took a holiday from office today and so we spent the whole of it gardening, the remodelling of the borders has begun and confusion reigns. I met Mrs Barnes yesterday and she has presented me with Peter, her terrier I've been looking after. I am so delighted as he is a dear and today we have given the children a canary much to their joy. I hope in time to tame it.

Sept 24th
I went up to the Pound Day of the Mary Yolland Home today. Luckily it was fine and warm, they had quite a nice little gathering and all who could be out and about were so, how dreadful it must be to be so crippled all ones life, but they all seem so cheerful and content. The Matron is a most splendid woman and has affected some wonderful cures.

Sept 25th
At 10.2 we went up to Town today in order to much shopping, we first went to Lawn and Alder to get an order on Bennett for some cretonne but couldn't find any we liked, then off to Evans, lunch at Gambini's (?), then ordered a suit for Ell (her brother) at Hills after which the Stores and lastly to Whiteley where at their Sale we bought a piano. It is such a beauty we got it with Uncle Arthur's legacy and it is the greatest joy to us.

Sept 26th
Shirts all morning, a matter of over 600. Luckily there were a lot of ladies present or I dont know how we should have got through it all. We gardened all afternoon planting the tree border with phlox and canterbury bells having had it well dug and manured so hope for great success.

Sept 27th
Mr Colfox and Mr Jardine came to say goodbye, they are both off to India. I envy them!

Sept 28th, Saturday
I went and did 3 calls which have been on my mind for some time, the Needhams, Williams and O'Callaghans. It was a very windy blowing day and as I bicycled I didn't enjoy myself at all but a sense of virtue steals over one when one feels certain duties are done and off ones back.

Sept 29th, Sunday
To Kirk as usual where Mr Abdy preached his last sermon (I hope) for he leaves in about 10 days. His elocution lessons have left him saying for ever gospel and prevent and Jerusalem...most trying.

Sept 30th, Monday
This is my last free Monday for next week the Mothers' Meetings begin. Hallelujah!I have been hard at developing today and shall do some printing tomorrow. I have some very pretty ones of home. (Wynne was a keen photographer, and developed and printed her own shots. The pictures she mentions here include the ones at the stream you can see in this month's page views. All the pictures in this month's diary are taken by her, with the exception of the one in 1902 and the one taken by me of her father's grave).

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The reluctant schoolboy, "with his satchel, and shining morning face"....
Thomas (Pink) off to school at Malvern.

september.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 7th

Home pleasures, April Fool jokes and some thoughts about Mrs Pankhurst and the suffragettes when her sentence is announced.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Tuesday
I send yesterday so as to arrive this morning the "Snowdon Shoes" as a little April 1st bon bouche to Maj. Ward and I am hoping that when I go over tomorrow to the Point to Point he may be wearing them! anyhow we are now quits!! (This is a reference to the time in June 1912 when Major Ward presented Wynne with a pair of carpet slippers after her ascent of Snowdon - you can read the entry on June 6th. Strangely, no mention is made of them on the following day when she did indeed attend the meet).

April 3rd
This has been a veritable day on which the Thrush sings. (a comment linked to a poem sent to her, possibly by the same Major Ward, which ended: "A happy Thrush is singing, and he sings, he sings of you").
I stepped out into the garden at 6.25 this morning and didn't go to bed till 12.0 because I was reading, but such a day, simply lovely still warm and brilliant though the wind rose in the evening and rain fell.

April 4th
A horrid cold wet and windy day and one which seems to have been marked by a variety of petty annoyances...I wonder should a broken best glass, coffee like grey ink, a dirty vegetable dish etc make any impression upon one at all they are such trivialities, but there are days when life is made up of such then its difficult to escape. I have been all round my district today and reading at the Home, poor things what drab coloured lives they have many of them and what a monotonous existence.

April 5th
Actually a day at home, a whole day! and I have spent it nearly all doing the dolls house. More staining and papering and enamelling the doors. It is beginning to look sweet. Letters from Ell and Eve, the former leaves India 16th May and Oh! how I am longing for my trip to meet him.

April 6th, Sunday
At last this wild woman of the woods (Wynne is here referring to Mrs Pankhurst and the suffragette movement - see the next page view) has received her due but of course she'll do hunger strike and a week will see her out again, public feeling runs high against these strange creatures, their window smashing and bombs and general destructive methods are raising great wrath and fury but one cannot see how the law as it stands at present can touch them and one wonders what the end will be.

April 7th, Monday
Poggy returned today having spent the week end with Baby at Springfield, his report of her is good, her general appearance is better and she is eating well. I only hope it may last and I shall be glad to have the little creature back again on Sat. A nursing committee today and my usual M.M. after lunch. This particular dissipation is coming to an end - only a few more Mon. and then peace perfect peace.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Wynne's views about the suffragettes were strong - she was against them...and many women at that time agreed with her. She stuck this cutting in next to her April 5th entry...

and below, a political cartoon which also manages to satirise the futurists - in many ways it seems very contemporary: Montenegro in the Balkans causing problems, Marconi in the news, militancy and Irish problems...can you recognise the politicians? There are five, in addition to the gagged face of John Bull and the sneering balloon of Montenegro....

(From the left: Lloyd George, Prime Minister Asquith, Sir Edward Carson, Churchill (top) and Sir Edward Grey (bottom).

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 8th - 14th

To Malvern to collect her son from school and to attend the prize giving...

Everyone converges on Upton Lodge for the holidays, and Ysobel has her 9th birthday.
viewer_4.description:
April 8th, Tuesday
Win's birthday yesterday, many happy returns to the 14 year old. She and Mother come here on Thursday. I started off today by the 8.17 for Malvern where I have come to be with Pink for the last 2 days of term. I arrived about 12.0 after many changes and found my dear small shaver looking well and jolly. The last day of the sports took place and he managed to come in second in the 200 yards winning thereby a ripping cricket bat.

April 9th
It has been such a jolly day and I've thoroughly enjoyed it, at break time I went over to the school and saw them all for 15 minutes and then went over the house with Mrs Wood and inspected the new wing all very nice, to lunch then came 4 of the demons: Pink, Charlie de Mornay, Home and Fitz Wood. At 2.0 they had to return to Mr Wood for a few minutes and when they returned to me I was much touched to see each arriving with a large bunch of daffodils having bought them on the way, dear things. We then went on a ramble on the hills where they eat sweets and ragged around and young Home made me tempting offers to "swop 2 sweets for half a cigarette"!! At 4.30 we were back for the prize giving which I was honoured by being asked to give away and imagine my tremendous pride when Mr Wood gave out "Good Conduct Prize Jackson junior" - dear little son, I felt inclined to cry! it seemed so splendid.

April 10th
Very early this morning we left for home, Pink and I coming as far as Oxford with the crowd and Mr Brooks, this is their young master, quite a boy but to whom they are much attached, he has asked Pink and 2 others to spend a week of their holidays with him at Shoreham and of course we are delighted though I shall miss him dreadfully. We met Mother and Win at Aldershot station and all came up in a taxi. I flew off immediately after lunch to a committee meeting at the General's where I met pogbags sundry and various.

April 11th, Friday
It is delightful having our holiday party again I always love it and on Sat when my Babbit returns we shall be quite complete. We drove down into Aldershot this morning, Mother, Pink and I and did much shopping, the devoted Granny buying all sorts of things for the children like old Mrs Todd used to do of yore. I went and read to my cripples as usual and that is all.


April 12th
Great excitement, Mother has received a cable from the Coffins asking for Brookfield (Wynne's family home) for a year and has wired acceptance so there it is let from June 1st for a year and I am awfully glad. H went up to Town to fetch the Baby who returned looking sweet and so much better.

April 13th
This is the beloved Nootles birthday 9 years old is she today and such a darling, really very sweet with her lovely colouring of chestnut hair and bright complexion. We had a great present hunt as is usual and much delighted the heart of the little creature.

April 14th, Monday
This being a cheerless and cold day my Mothers refused utterly to have a single crack open and the "esprit de corps" was frightful in consequence! (Wynne was a great fiend for fresh air!) We dined at the Grays this night and found Major Ward doing the same, a nice little evening, a most excellent dinner and Coon Can at which I won 3d!

Wynne was breeding chickens, and proudly announced her latest hatchlings...left and above!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne stuck in this letter from Eleanore (Baby) sent from Springfield - much if not all must have been written by her nanny....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 15th - 22nd

Egg hunts in the garden for Easter, chores in the district...and poems and primroses in the post for Wynne.

Her husband goes off to Army Camp.
viewer_6.description:
April 15th, Tuesday
We had our Egg Hunt today - 16 children and were to have been 19. It was fine for a wonder and great fun, all over the garden the baskets were concealed and some took ages to find.

April 16th
I have had an interesting invitation from Lady Fulton to her dance at the Ritz on May 20th to which I hope to go and take a party, it will be great fun and I only wish Ell were home for it. I am to ask my lot to dinner at the Flat first and am sad Mother will not be there as she is going off on the 1st to Baden for a months cure, she is bad just now and I do hope it will do her good.

April 17th
I spent the whole day in Town today, took Pink up and left him with Mr Brooks at Paddington - they went off in great delight, 3 boys together!
I shopped till all was blue and caught the 5.30 home arriving at the house at 7.0 and dashed out again at 7.15 to dine with the Hoopers. I really was dead and longed for my bed.

April 18th
A day of chores and much home business, my reading at the Home and vile wet cold weather. It is sad how quickly April is slipping away and how little Spring we seem to be getting out of it, such a waste of this lovely month.

April 19th, Saturday
I received this day a touching little box of primroses from Ashley Wood from Amy Daniell, they are sweet and remind me of home. I was to have gone to Town to see the Tower with Mr Salmon today but I just felt I didn't want to lose one of Poggs last days and so I cried off and we have spent most of it gardening and have much enjoyed it. He is off to Camp on Tuesday for 2 months and how I do hate the thought of being without him.

April 20th
Mr Salmon came last night, it is very pleasant indeed to have him again, always nice. He has been having a great jaunt with Mother. I drove him over to the Garrison Service this morning, we unfortunately were too late to see the cavalry come out but the K.R.R took service and very well.

April 21st, Monday
I wrote the other day to ask Charles Bridge to the dance, he replied refusing because he is working for the Staff College and must not frivole. I accordingly wrote him a chaste poem and received his answer in like manner. I insert them both here, he is an amusing card. (You can read both poetic efforts in the next page view).

April 22nd, Tuesday
Oh! day of days! in the year 1899 how long ago it seems and that day I left for England and today he leaves for Camp. In recalling that far off time he called it a 'blessed day' - it was indeed a blessed day and I have no knowledge of anything in this life better than all our years together have been.

"A picture of Poggy on his first day in Camp!!" and "When he returned, 2 months later!"

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The two poems Wynne stuck into her April diary - the first, her effort sent to Charles Bridge, the second his reply. The picture in the strip you have come from is meant to represent Charles in all his glory at Church Parade...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 23rd - 30th

Down to the old family home, to get it ready for tenants. Then home for visits to the Review of Guards in London and to see the newfangled aeroplanes at Farnborough.
viewer_8.description:
April 23rd
At a quarter to 11 last night I got a letter from Mrs Kavanagh asking me to open a bazaar for her today because forsooth she wants to go to Epsom. I'll see her sugared first! I've been up since 5.0 today and was out at 5.45 such a gorgeous day full of sun birds and spring. I only hope it may last. Tomorrow I go down to Brookfield with Mother to set things in order, it will be nice to see the dear old place again and I am anxious to know how our new garden is getting on.

April 24th
We found all well at home, the new gardener and his wife welcomed us and she had tea ready for us in her house.

April 25th
This has been a day of days, a clearing out throwing away sorting and cleaning day. We began on the top landing and oh! the treasures of countless price! We sent over tons of rubbish to Miss Wingate for jumble sale, we interviewed Mr Traill and Stickland, and to tea came F.S., the Pennys and Arthur and Miss Wingate. We sorted out linen, glass, crockery, listed all, threw away rubbish and burned papers. We are enjoying ourselves immensely, Mother brought down a chicken, tongue, sardines and we have plenty of eggs, milk and butter. I am also parlourmaid and housemaid whilst Mother is the cook! Its real fun and we live like fighting cocks and I look a pig all day. We went off to bed awfully early, dead and done, and slept like logs all night.

April 26th
The builders and painters have been in the house all the winter so the place is in a fearful mess, a great improvement has been made in several new windows, one in the hall which makes it much lighter and nicer, another in the black and gold room looking down the drive and a third in the red room, whilst a door has been knocked into the boudoir from the hall and the old passage entrance blocked up. It is all an immense improvement.

April 27th, Sunday
Although this is the Sabbath we had not time to treat it as such and worked away up to the last minute of leaving, which we did by motor for Wimborne at 3.30, packing, sorting and burning again. Our train to Town started at 3.50 and didn't reach Waterloo till 8.5, a weary journey stopping at every station but we had a tea basket and books and all things come to an end in time!

April 28th
This morning at 10.30 we went to see the Review of Guards at Hyde Park, it was a great show though somewhat spoilt by rain as umbrellas are not conducive to a good view. However I'm glad to have seen it and the massed bands were very fine. Coming home the crowds were immense and we couldn't get a taxi for love or money so we had to take a bus, Mother nimbly leaping on whilst it was in motion and I scrambling up after her. Mother is giving me a lovely new ball gown for Lady Fulton's dance to which I am taking a party on May 20th, the dressmaker came after lunch and took measurements and then at 5.30 I came down home to find all well.

April 29th
A day at home of gardening and chores. I got up very early, 5.0, and went out. It was a perfect day and I am so enjoying comparative peace in not having to do any entertaining or going out.

April 30th, Wednesday.
I took the children up to Farnborough to see the flying but the weather was bad and they left off earlier than usual so we didn't see much. Poor Mr Harrison's death on Mon. was a horrible shock. I saw him fly last Wed. in Cody's biplane and now both have come to an end, its horrible. (This reference is to a plane crash, the both referring to the man and the plane, not to Cody - however in August 1913 Cody himself was to die when his plane crashed. Samuel Cody was to Britain what the Wright brothers were to the USA . On October 16th 1908 he piloted the first powered sustained flight in Britain, and was to achieve many more in the following years. In August 1913 his Cathedral VI broke up in mid flight, and he was killed. 50,000 people attended his funeral - he was one of the great stars of the pre-war period).

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The Review by His Majesty, King George V, at Hyde Park on 28th April, . The Regiments taking part were: Grenadier Guards, Coldstream Guards, Scots Guards and Irish Guards...

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 7th

Bank Holidays, Otter Hunting and the tragic death of the flying ace, Colonel Cody.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Friday
This was to have been and would have been a very jolly day but owing to unforeseen circumstances it turned out a failure. The Grays asked us to a picnic at Hayling to which the Hoopers and the Wrigleys also were to come. We motored with the Gs and the Ws went along in their little car behind us. When we arrived at Hayling no Hoopers turned up, so after waiting a long time we bathed and had lunch and not feeling happy we were about to return when the others turned up, having had a puncture which delayed them for 2 hours. So sad.
Poggy and I dined at Government House to meet the Sec. of State for War, Colonel Seely, a fatuous ass, a noodle full of facetious fool ways - a huge party composed of uniformed Generals.

Aug 2nd
Went into the Town to buy Win a bicycle from her people and Mother, and also to get one for the children much to their delight.

Aug 3rd
A most peaceful and lovely day spent chiefly in lying on the lawn sleeping and reading, no callers thanks be and I've just enjoyed it awfully.

Aug 4th, Monday
This being Bank Holiday we spent it in a peaceful and gardening manner, turning Ethel on to digging and weeding and the Skippys dined with us, playing Whisky Poker afterwards which Jan won and was quite embarrassed at "playing for money"!

Aug 5th
Jan left us today and I very horridly left her for the morning for Capt S had asked me to go Otter Hunting with him and as this great joy only comes once a year I couldn't refuse. We started at 7.30 and went along the river to Waverley and Moor Park, a perfect day, sunny, warm and still all along that lovely river with the overhanging trees. Alas! they didn't find but it just made no difference at all, we strolled and sat and idled and it was over all to soon. I got back at 1.30 and found Mrs Lees arrived at 2.0 and to Tennis came a lot of people who played until about 7.0.

Aug 7th, Wednesday
I went off to Shirts this morning as usual. I am doing Lady Wilma's now in her absence so get a double dose. On my return I drove Win down in the dogcart to the Winwood's where she lunched and spent the afternoon. We have heard today of the most fearful and disastrous news of Cody's misadventure and death. He was up in his machine with a passenger, a Mr Evans, and something happened which boxed the wings and the whole thing crashed to the ground killing them both. One can't believe that this indomitable spirit is no more, a great loss to the world of flying. Poor fellow, and his sons saw the accident.
Noots and Pink went to the baths to swim this morning.
(Samuel Cody was to Britain what the Wright brothers were to the USA . On October 16th 1908 he piloted the first powered sustained flight in Britain, and was to achieve many more in the following years. In August 1913 his Cathedral VI broke up in mid flight, and he was killed. 50,000 people attended his funeral - he was one of the great stars of the pre-war period).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: One of the earliest aeroplane crashes. The death of the pilot Colonel Cody was the occasion for national mourning.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 8th - 14th

Elliot, Wynne's brother, comes to stay and much fun is had by all.
viewer_4.description:
August 8th, Friday
Ethel left this morning and as Pink and Charlie de Mornay were playing in a cricket match at North Camp got up by Mrs Maxse I drove E to North Camp station and then deposited the boys at the Field, went off to do some shopping and returned to see them make many runs! and win their first innings. At 6.30 we returned and I was frozen sitting watching.

Aug 9th
Mother and Ell arrived at lunch time having motored down from Town, its lovely having them and our afternoon was spent in playing with children...we all set too and played wild games of rounders, cricket and duckstone, great fun.
To dinner tonight came the Grays and Skippys and Oh! My! the riot. We played Whisky Poker of course but everyone shrieked and no one attended and were much more occupied in doing each a different monkey trick on their own, it was all great fun and we had been doing our duty for so long with pogbags I felt an evening for our amusement was necessary and I just love all these four. I can't help thinking of the time which draws nearer and nearer when we vanish into the evigkeit and are no more, it just fills me with blues....
(Wynne here refers to her husband's forthcoming retirement in 1914 and the consequent departure from Aldershot).

Aug 10th, Sunday
a day of rest for most but photography for me.

Aug 11th, Monday
Ell went up to Town today till Wed, gay dog. He has seen and done a lot since he came home, more than I do in a year, I think! Poggy took a day off today and we went off to the Baths where I had a lovely swim, it is an enjoyable amusement but I wish we could have the Baths oftener, we only get them Mon and Thurs.

Aug 12th
Grouse Day! many poor fledglings will take the sun and air no more.


Wynne's brother Elliot with his niece Eleanore and Peter, the terrier....

Aug 13th
Ell back from Town in the morning, to Tennis came Mrs Skippy, Capt Trench and Mrs Legard...the day being gloomy and rainy the others didn't turn up and these 4 played 6 or 7 sets on and on and on! Poggy unfortunately couldn't join us at night, we going to dine at the Grays and he at the South Camp Mess. We had a most mad evening, ending by dancing and the men performing tangos and bunny hugs etc...quite mad and we all were dead from laughing.

Aug 14th
To Shirts and Baths - as usual I alas! too shirty to bathe, I grudge the days. Win is learning now and Giles says she'll swim directly, its splendid.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne's dance card, with her booked dance partners noted on the right. Her brother Ell features prominently, alongside various family friends such as the Skippys. Below is a clearer list of the actual dances...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 15th - 24th

Holiday amusements, assisted by the welcome addition of a new-fangled motor car!
viewer_6.description:
Aug 15th, Friday
A day of great fun and joy to me for we've actually been to a dance! We and the Skippy's made up a party of 12 and went to a most splendidly managed hop at the Club....and being such a large party one danced the whole evening through. The floor and band were good and a very well managed refreshment bar. The evening was still and warm and all the garden lit up - I just enjoyed it all immensely.

Aug 16th
Dora Lockhart has been with us today, she came over from Wokingham and we were very glad to see her, especially Gran. Then as Eric Duggleby had to be fetched at 5.15 Ell lent us the car and taking Gran too we motored down, picked him up and took Dora home to W. It was a lovely evening and we all enjoyed the drive through the most lovely country, though coming home I fell asleep, much to Gran's amusement.

Au 17th
H and I trailed off to Church this morning accompanied by Maggie and 5 children, feeling simply patriarchal!

Aug 18th
We went down en masse to the swimming baths today and Mother came too. It was great fun and all the children splashed about and had their swimming lessons.

Aug 19th
My dear Ell's birthday, many, many happy returns - I am sad that he should spend it away from us but we are really getting to an age when sentiment about birthdays should cease, he being 39 today.

Aug 20th, Wednesday
Mother motored me up to Town today, Ell having left his motor for her in his absence. We had a lovely drive up and down and took Nootle too as she and I had a visit to the Dentist to make, for her he had nothing to do and said she had the best set of teeth he had seen for a long time which is a blessing, he stopped one for me and says I must go again for two more dash and blow and drat!

Aug 22nd, Friday
We motored over today in the Skippy's car with them to Fleet where we had tea with the Camerons at the Club and then played tennis. To dinner tonight came the Lushingtons and Mrs Corry and Mrs Legard. The Winwoods were coming only he got a bad sting and couldn't get a collar on. Quite a cheery evening and usual games.

Aug 23rd, Saturday
Mimi and Charlie Jones were to have come to us this week end but wired yesterday to say he was unwell and so they cannot come, I am sorry.

Aug 24th
A quiet Sunday spent in the usual way, very fine and lovely weather.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Caroline Jackson, in old age. She died at Springfield House in Chelmsford on August 27th . She bore 13 children, 11 of whom survived....more details in Family

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
August 25th - 31st

The death of Herbert's mother brings another chapter to a close.
viewer_8.description:
Aug 25th
This has been a long day for us - we had to attend the Bordon Sports and the Lewins very kindly gave us lunch and sending for and fetching us in their car...but we had to stay till past 7.0 as I was presenting Prizes and oh! how tired I got by the end. (Bordon was another army camp near Aldershot)

Aug 27th, Wednesday
We have had a great shock today. I had to go to Town again for teeth and H to Bordon inspecting and when I returned in the evening I found my dear man had gone to Springfield on receipt of a wire which arrived in our absence telling of Mother's sudden death this morning. I am longing to hear more details. We heard from Mary that on Monday she hadn't been quite so well.

Aug 28th
Such a long tiring day. I went off the Shirts at 9.30 picking up Mrs Boone on the way and dropping the children at the Baths. I then caught the 12.5 to Town where I had to go to get the necessary things in the way of clothes and got back at 7.0 . The heat in Town was tremendous and I was just fagged to death.

Aug 29th, Friday
A letter this morning telling me more news, how that Mother had seemed a bit better in the morning and so Mary went off to Matins leaving the maid with Mother, an exclamation of "Oh!" made her turn round to find she was dead, a most peaceful and quiet end and having suffered so much of late one cannot wish her back. The funeral is tomorrow at Amwell and I shall meet them at Liverpool Street. (Amwell is a small village in Hertfordshire, and presumably the funeral was held there because it was connected to other members of the family, but its a long way from the old lady's home).

Aug 30th, Saturday
At 9.45 Mother and I started off in the motor for Town leaving ourselves 3 hours to get to the station. We made good progress as far as Town where we had to get some more petrol and then commenced going down Oxford Street and Holborn to L:pool, there we found confusion worse confounded all the streets up and traffic tremendous. We were held up everywhere and I realized I should miss the train which I did, however I met Willie Jones in the same plight so we took the next arriving luckily about mid way in the service. It is a lovely quiet old place and the whole service was very nice, all the family nearly were there, a great gathering and I am so glad I just managed it, but what a break up this all means and what an upheaval.

Aug 31st, Sunday
My man has stayed on at Springfield to be with Mary and help her, till Wednesday. He came over to Waterloo yesterday and saw me off. I miss him most horribly but dont grudge him. I took the children down to Church in the morning and after lunch it started to rain and has continued steadily ever since.

august.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1st -7th

Routine chores and a visit to Malvern to watch her son in the school play: The Pied Piper of Hamelin.
viewer_2.description:
December 1st, Monday
A new day of the week and a new month of the year, the last of a very lovely year for me with its joys of travel and Ell. He by the way sent a cable to say he had arrived safely at Bombay after a vile voyage: dirty, rough, crowded and a break down. I rushed down to my German lesson at 10.0 and got back at 12.0 in pouring rain, set forth again at 2.15 for my MM, a big meeting this time, many babies and much rebellion about open windows but I always win in the end!!

December 2nd
Mrs de Mornay and I arose at screech of dawn this morning and went off down to Malvern to see the boys act the Pied Piper of Hamlin. It is an awful journey and takes from 8.50 to 1.24, changing often and waiting everywhere. Our boys came to meet us at the station , escorted us to our Hotel where they left us to have lunch and returned to school to get ready. At 2.30 we went over and there saw the performance. It was awfully well done. Bob as the Piper acted with entire confidence and has a most beautiful voice, Pinkie was one of the children and dressed in a pink bonnet, white and blue dress and blue stockings skipped about and sang. The singing was charming and its awfully pretty music and the scenery was really excellent, all done by their drawing master. We had tea when it was over and then took the boys up into the town for marbles and sweets!

December 3rd
We said goodbye to our boys last night and started away by the 8.28 train, changing at Oxford, Reading and Ash, and arriving at 1.0. We had an hour to wait at Oxford so we went and saw All Souls College and the lovely screen in their chapel dating from 1437 and destroyed partially by Cromwell, after which it was walled up and only reopened in 18 something. (Wynne also notes that the Vicar, Mr Watson, and Captain Skippy were both on the mend - following her comments about them last month).

December 4th
I spent some time in writing mail letters today but not till after dinner could I get at it as I went the round of my district all the morning and to the Mission sale from 3 to 6 at Farnham.

December 5th
I went to read at the Home as usual, found them all busy finishing up work for their little sale next Thursday.

December 6th, Saturday
I spent this day at Winchester where I went to see Dot Seeley. Hers is the saddest lot I know, there she is at 33 working as a Matron in a school, her husband in an asylum and her youngest son nearly blind and with the same strain as his Father. The other little son, the elder one, is at school but she has no money and no prospects and only 33, its too dreadful I think.

December 7th
Nice letters from Ell and Eve both very jolly and the former nearing the end of his tedious and dreadful voyage.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The programme for the boys' play - Wynne's son is at the bottom left as one of the children: E.Jackson.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 8th - 15th

Charity work, a visit to the stores and an accident reported in the local press.
viewer_4.description:
December 8th, Monday
Dear Gran improves every day and as I sat talking to her this evening she was as clear headed and normal as a year ago.

December 9th
Nootie has been having dancing lessons for weeks and weeks and having never been to one I went this afternoon with Mrs Legard to see the little creatures disporting themselves, and then I went back with them to tea after which Captain L drove me to Aldershot station and I hied me off to Town to spend the night with Mother.

December 10th
Herbert came up today and we met at the Stores and spent the whole day shopping, such a day and so much to do, I felt dead by the evening.

December 11th
This is the day of the little sale at the Yolland Home.
