We had just the girls work and a little stall for provisions and flowers, quite a fair number of people came and we made £16.9.6 with which we were very pleased. An early dinner and then off to a Conservative meeting at the Club where Viscount Middleton and Mr Welch spoke all on the subject of Home Rule and Tariff Reform.

December 12th
To read at the Home as usual, the girls none the worse for their dissipation yesterday. An early dinner again tonight, Maby and I went off to an excellent entertainment of acting and Pierrots given by the ASC at their theatre. All the rank and fashion were there. Poggy was lazy and wouldn't face uniform! (ie: her husband did not go because he could not face putting on full dress uniform for the event).

December 13th, Saturday
A day off and am thankful for there is so much to do and see to.

December 14th
Our delight was intense today when the Grays wrote and said we were to meet them in Town on Wed, dine at the Carlton and do a play with them. It will be a joy to see them.

December 15th, Monday
I distinguished myself by having an accident this morning. Driving down to Farnham in my dog cart to my lesson a vile idiot of a hawker woman wanting to turn right drove straight across my bows without any warning, I consequently went into her, was thrown out, and smashed up my cart. I could've beaten the idiot but thank goodness neither the pony, Sinnott or harness were injured and I not hurt at all. A kind lady in a motor picked me up and took me on to my lesson and I returned in the bus, the cart to the wheelwright and I led the pony home. Such a bore. (But what a big repair bill - £2 was a lot of money!)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Theatre programme for "The Girl From Utah"

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 16th - 21st

London Christmas shopping and the theatre. The pressure of Xmas builds as the children come home from boarding school.
viewer_6.description:
December 16th, Tuesday
I went up to Town today to spend this and tomorrow night to shop and play. As soon as I arrived I went off to do Xmas presents and oh! the labour of it, its just frightful at this time of year, hundreds and thousands of people doing the same thing and hours one waits before one is served at all. I'll never leave it this late again. I got back really done up to tea and changed soon after for at 7.0 I dined at the Troc with P.G. going afterwards to see "The Girl from Utah", an excellent and most amusing play with Coyne, Phyllis Dare, Edmund Payne and Gracie Leigh. We all laughed very much and enjoyed it immensely and when it was over we went on to the Carlton where we sat drinking coffee and watching the freaks until a late hour.

December 17th
More strenuous shopping in the morning fighting and waiting in the crowd and never, oh! never again. H came up today and we battled together at the Stores, Evans and B&H and at 4.30 returned feeling beaten and done. We had a most joyous evening - at 7.30 we met at the Carlton the Grays and Wrigleys and had there the most lovely dinner, the menu of which I stick in here, and afterwards went on to see "Never Say Die". Privately I was rather disappointed in it, the humour struck one as rather forced and I've seen him in much better things but it was a very jolly evening and we drove to the Theatre like bloated aristocrats in a huge covered motor and two men in livery, this turn out belonging to the Braidwood Grays. Our dear nice friends were as delightful as ever.

December 18th
I went off at 10.30 to meet Win at Waterloo and H went to Paddington to pick up Pink and Charlie de Mornay. I arrived at W.loo very early and there found P.G.! Curiously enough he had come to put his luggage in the cloak room. Well, Win's train was half an hour late and Pink's late too and so we only just caught the 11.45 as it was leaving the station. Its lovely to have them back again and we are a huge household. I love to hear the row! We took them to Mr d M lecture on Malay this evening, it was a lantern one and most interesting but lasted two and a half hours!

December 19th
Reading at home as usual and all the children went to a party at the Edens, coming back at 6.30

December 20th, Saturday
Every day seems more and more busy. I have a thousand things to do and never more than 3 minutes to do them in. This afternoon I took the children to a large party at the Addisons, a fancy dress party where they first were amused by a lightening sketcher story teller and then a lovely Xmas tree at which they all got 2 lovely presents and many smaller things. Win went dressed as a Quaker, Pink and Noot as American Indians and Baby as a fairy. It was a most awfully jolly party and very well done.

December 21st
Whilst we were at lunch today Mother suddenly arrived having been lent a covered motor to come down in. Maggie has lent her her open motor for a fortnight but it is following on and will be most useful. More packing of parcels and letter writing.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The programme for "Never Say Die"

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 22nd - 26th

The joys of Christmas - the last before the Great War.
viewer_8.description:
December 22nd, Monday
My Mothers Meeting as usual but beyond that I've kept this week free of outside engagements as there is so very much to do at home. I had the MM at their special request today but as I had thought there were very few present and it wasted my precious time considerably.

December 23rd
Ever since Dec 6th we've had the Waits on and off and not one worth listening to, only 3 or 4 little children and Peter resented them very much. It has been an awful day, fog, ice cold and rain and going the round of a few poor people I got literally soaked to the skin.

December 24th, Xmas Eve
Here is Xmas Eve once more, how soon time goes by, it seems only yesterday that we were hanging stockings, Church and house decorating and doing all such jobs a year ago. The posts bring delightful parcels and remembrances of very many friends and its lovely to think of the heaps of people who remember one. At 10.0 I went down to decorate the Church, afterwards rushing into Farnham to do a few last jobs whilst in my absence H and the children decorated the house which looks as usual so festive and pretty and Christmassy. We spent the evening getting the Tree things ready and filling stockings etc...

December 25th, Xmas Day
A happy Xmas to all and sundry and a health to all I love. As usual at the hour of 7.30 4 creatures arrived in our rooms each ladened with their mis-shapen limbs the contents of which were poured forth onto our beds. After breakfast to Church we all went except the two Grannies and then after lunch we set to with feverish haste to decorate the tree and arrange the tables, such a collection of things to distribute and so many secrets right up to the last minute. At 4.30 we had tea and at 5.30 lit up. According to custom the youngest in the house enters first after the bell is rung and so the dear Blokey who came over with the Skippys and Capt Master proudly marched in ahead and rushed to the Tree as fast as her 18 month old legs could carry her. There followed all our crew. Dear old Gran was wheeled in before and sat beside her table of presents taking the liveliest interest in all and looking very sweet. Then came the servants, the men and their wives and children and in all we numbered 32! We then distributed all their presents and the things off the Tree. It was a perfectly shaped one this year and looked particularly lovely with the coloured balls, silver wreaths, crackers, candles and the silver strands of angels' hair falling like rain all over it. H and I got some lovely presents amongst others Mother gave me a sweet set of corals, also her lovely emerald and diamond earrings and old paste brooch to match. Just for remembrance sake I must mention too a blue morocco despatch case and cigarette holder from the Grays and H a copper and brass Thibetan (sic) "lazy stand" and painted china from Mother, besides heaps of other things so we were very lucky. To dinner Col. Sandilands and all the children except Baby came down to it or rather "stayed up" for it. When we had bundled them off to bed we went over to the Skipwiths. We played most difficult games and didn't win prizes! it was great fun and at some late hour we returned, so ended a very jolly Xmas Day.

December 26th, Friday
This whole morning was spent in writing letters of thanks and I got off 19! My hand quite ached from cramp but its a good thing done and after lunch I went to read as usual to my girls at the Yolland House. Its rather a rest to have the rush of Xmas over but I always feel sad when its all done, it lasts so short a time and one has to wait so long before it comes again and next year who knows where we all may be.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The last page in Wynne's diary...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
December 27th - 31st

Snow, a children's dance and new Year's Eve...the end of a perfect year for Wynne - what will the next one bring?
viewer_10.description:
December 27th
Letters from India this morning. Ell writes from Seryah where he and Mr Campbell have fetched up, all safe at last, and Eve writes that they are all going to spend Xmas together. I am so glad of this as it hasn't occurred for quite a long time. I took Mother down to the Winwoods to have a rubber of Bridge this evening, just 4 ladies, the 4th being Mrs Wilberforce (her husband is Colonel of the Bays). She is a very fierce lady and I dont think I should like to meet her at night alone in the dark. She reared her crest in fury over "Shirts" and I am just waiting with a sense of comfort for the peace which April will bring when I shall be quit of all the Mrs Wilberforces and the peevish pecksniffy ways!! Why cant everyone be a Lady Wilma, what peace on earth it would bring!

December 28th
Such a lovely day and hard frost, it was perfect on Xmas Day too, bright, clear and still. I've had Win and Pink in bed with colds for 2 days and Noot rather sniffy also so we took only Baby to church who stayed on through the sermon and was so awfully good all the time.

December 29th, Monday
It has turned very cold and at about 8.30 it began to snow very fast and thick, and it was so bad that I had to give up my German lesson and couldn't get out till later when H and I ran down in the car, did some shopping and I called in at the convent to see the little Nun. MM after lunch as usual.

December 30th
Hard frost and a white world, a glittering earth and brilliant sunshine, the children all out in the snow making a snow man and snow balling - how well I remember the joy of this myself! I occupied my afternoon by cleaning out the dolls house aided by Pinkie and it took ages. Before I finished who should roll up but our new subalterns followed by the Colonel and David full as usual of quilps and cranks. After tea we played Bridge and what possessed Gran I cant think but twice during the evening she leant forward in her chair and the first time fell right out on to the floor, we had such a fright, but she wasn't hurt luckily. The second time Mother's chair was in front of her and she hit her head against it but apparently didn't mind that either! This evening was a great event for the children. I took them to the childrens Ball at the Castle, a big affair and a very lovely scene. It commenced at 7.0 and lasted until 11.30. The 3 elder went as Baby is still too small for such late hours. We arrived to find a large assembly, the lovely old place was all hung and decorated with garlands of evergreens and the room where they danced is the great dining hall, a huge high room with a gallery running all round the top and from the walls the portraits of all the former Bishops looked down upon us. The children enjoyed it immensely and danced the whole evening, eating 5 and 6 ices and much lemonade. Nootle had a serious flirtation with a young man called Wooding whilst Pinkie was quite at home among the girls!! We got home at 10 to 12!

December 31st, Wednesday
By 11.30 today the house was swept and garnished as Mother left us and took the 3 elder children with her to Town. We are following tomorrow and stay till Saturday as we are taking them to the Panto and on Friday to Peter Pan and we take Baby up with us. I've just been reading a speculative entry written on the last day of last year in my Diary - in it I wonder as to the events of this year etc - little did I realize all the joys of Elliot, Italy and many other things which fell to my lot during this very ripping year. It has been tremendously full and busy the the coming one will see greater changes* for us and where shall we be this time next year. The servants are dancing this one out, each maid has her man and all are very gay. Goodbye 1913, Good luck to all and may the next be as happy as the last.

*(Added in a little note in the margin, written in 1921, Wynne notes: "Yes indeed, such "changes" that the World never dreamt possible".)

december.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 5th

In London Wynne goes to an early wild-life film, an opera, a Henry Wood Concert, and a big family wedding...but the suffragettes are still on the march!
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Saturday
A busy day, we went over in the morning to Harvey and Nicholls to do a little shopping and then after lunch we went to an extraordinary show, the cinema of Paul Rainey's African Expedition. It is wonderful to think that this man took his cinematograph into the wilds of Africa and what one sees produced really took place, a lion hunt, a cheetah hunt, a rhinos charge etc...and the water holes where the animals all come down to drink.
This evening the Opera again, Rosenkavalier by Strauss, but although a most wonderful thing I feel I am not really educated up to Strauss, he is too mad and tuneless.

February 2nd
Although the Sabbath this has been another full day, for at 10 I started off to the Tower to attend Mr Mitchell's Church St Peters ad Vincula. It is of course a garrison service and it was nice to be amongst soldiers again. In front of me sat the Keeper of the Regalia and the Constable of the Tower, and we had a very nice service, it seemed so wonderful somehow sitting there in that place of historic memories where lie the bones of so many illustriate victims, and I stayed to Celebration where is used the original Chalice and Patten from which these same unfortunates took their last communion, a strange and inspiring thought.
Then at 3.0 Mother and I went to a charming concert at the Queens Hall where Woods Orchestra gave Tannhauser and Tchaikowski's Symphony Pathetic, Sibelius Valse Triste and a man sang delightfully. It was crammed to a seat and we could only get front stalls. On coming out no taxi could be got for love or money, this strike is awful and goes on and on, however at length one passed and we secured it and drove to Aims (Aimee Macpherson's, her aunt) where she (Mother) dropped me off and went home herself. There (at Aimee Macpherson's) I found them all very busy over the coming wedding on Tuesday, and Walter Elliot is to give Rita away in the absence alas of all her brothers.

February 3rd
I left town this morning by the 11.45 reaching home at 1.30 as I had to take my Mothers Meeting. Great excitement among the Women as their Bill has been rejected and more window and pillar outrages have taken place to which are now added golf greens which are cut to pieces and burnt! They are mad and an outrage to humanity.

February 4th, Tuesday
Today we went to Town to see the Katchen married and a very pretty smart wedding it was. The ceremony took place at St James Piccadilly, and the reception at Princes. Everyone seemed to look their very best, Rita sweet and her gown of brocaded velvet quite lovely, she wore the veil Eve and I wore and I hope it will bring her our luck. All the clan were there and we met many people we hadn't met for years. Aimee looked charming in a lovely gown of black satin and veiled lace with a big bouquet of crimson roses. Rita's train was held up by two little Swingler children in white satin empire frocks trimmed with pale blue and the bridegroom was very smart in his uniform. Dear old Gran went to the reception and enjoyed it immensely - when we all went down to see the bride off she was left upstairs with Clark so she hailed a waiter and said "Just go to the Bandmaster and tell him I should like to hear some music" upon which he played away to her and for her only!

February 5th
This being Ash Wednesday we went to church.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: On February 1st Wynne went to an "extraordinary show" - in fact one of the earliest Natural History films, the sort we see every day now on our television screens. It was shown at the Holborn Empire, as an afternoon matinee, the evening being devoted to music hall.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 6th - 12th

Nijinksy is in London, and Wynne manages to see the Russian Ballet as well as doing her home duties. She records the sad news of Scott's death in the Antarctic
viewer_4.description:
February 6th, Thursday
Up to Town again and as H had to go up, no he didn't I'm wrong, I went up alone this time and got in for tea, found there Sir Ben Simpson, Lady Franklin and Maud, both of whom I hadn't seen for ages. The Russian Ballet was a great treat, I enjoyed it awfully and have never seen a more clever dancer than Nijinksy, perfectly marvellous, the house was crowded, such a gay and lovely sight and the music was just awfully inspiring, so wild and strange. I'd love to see it all again.

February 7th
I returned by the 11.45 today bringing Gran back with me, she stood the journey perfectly. This is my darling baby's birthday but alas she is a baby no longer for she is 5 years old today, but as sweet and good as ever. We brought back from Town a collection of tiny things for the dolls house we are making and presented them to her.

February 8th
I went down to the Boones to tea and to see her baby, a dear little creature and very like him. They are off to dear old Bulford in Sept. I envy them and long to go back to its wilds.

February 9th
Another horrible day, a heavy mist and darkness, went off to Church and arrived hours too soon after lunch and actually took Mrs Watson's Bible Class for old women, what am I coming to? 11 turned up and we filled the little room up at the Church house.

February 10th
My usual Mother meeting and an H.P.A. after dinner made up the sum of dissipations for today. How very parochial one would become if one always lived in such a place as this, but one must do something to justify ones existence.

February 11th, Tuesday
The kind Grays lent us their motor today and went and did calls.

February 12th
A dense fog so different from yesterday which was the loveliest day we've had, simply perfect all round. The garden was really quite gay, everything is so extraordinarily forward. I made a Spring Pie today and was able to find 20 different sorts of flowers for it. I must give a list of them as its so unusual for the time of year: Prunus, Ribes, crocus (3 sorts), daffodil, tulip, daisy, aconite, scilla, chiondoxa (sic), violet, arabis, aubretia, wallflower, primrose, rosemary, polyanthus, anemone, blue primrose, snowdrop and jasmine.
Everyone is sorrowing at present over the horrible news of disaster to Capt Scott's Anartic (sic) Expedition. The party were expected back about now and their ship went to meet them as arranged but not finding them sent out search parties only to find that after having reached the Pole they died from want 11 miles distant from food and their records which have now come in are most desperately sad, they have been dead for nearly a year...and Capt. Scott's poor wife is on her way to New Zealand to meet him as she believes and cannot hear the news till she gets there, its all too tragic. Capt. Scott's record is most wonderfully calm and resigned. Of course he knew as he wrote it that he would shortly die and those with him, a fearful situation. Capt. Oates who was desperately ill left the party deliberately earlier and went out into the blizzard to die as he knew he was retarding their progress, what strength of character. The record says they found Amundsen's tent and records at the Pole and left their own there, one wonders what is the use of it all and one only only hopes that death under the circumstances comes mercifully.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Wynne adored the famous Russian Ballet - she had been before, but this programme was special - she was able to see the fabled male dancer, Nijinksy, and some of the other stars, most notably Tamara Karsavina.
This was the group brought over by Diaghilev which had caused such a storm in Paris.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 13th - 18th

At home in Farnham, near Aldershot, and carrying on with her army duties. A bad head cold is about to start.
viewer_6.description:
February 13th, Thursday
Last night I went to the first of the Lenten services at St Marks, just to see if I should be inspired by the preacher but alas he was just the usual youthful pogbag who could aspire no further than platitudes and I doubt me if I'll go again! We went up to tea at the Frazers today, taking Baby too. Mrs Kerr and her family are there, what a charming house and garden overlooking the lovely old Park, and the wonderful tropicals that grow there. We dined tonight with the Hakings, a large party including the Lawsons. She looked extremely handsome in a deep rose coloured satin, she is such a fine handsome woman and such a good figure. Gen. Haking surpassed himself and told a series of hair raising stories and we all laughed very much.

February 14th
Poggy poor dear has been out from 8.0 to 4.0 on a Field Day with a mobilized Brigade of Infantry,
Field Artillery and Company of Engineers. I went down early to see them pass and they took an hour to do so, it was cold standing there.

February 15th
I have started going to the Yolland House once a week to read to the girls, poor little maids, cripples all their life and though awfully well looked after, what must it be to be like that all ones days. Every day fresh details are to hand concerning this really frightful tragedy of the Anarctic (sic), the more one hears the more grim and fearful it all seems and one can picture their hopeless and helpless feelings when they realized after success they just had to give in and simply die. Poor chaps.

February 16th, Sunday
A lovely day again, and still mild. There was a man preaching this morning on behalf of the Bishop of Winchester's Fund, describing the needs of Portsmouth and the horrors they have to deal with there, and the hopelessly inadequate staff, a most eloquent pleader and we went to hear him again this evening. After lunch I took again Mrs Watson's Bible Class and the old things were so affable and nice. To tea came the Boons and Mrs Newcome...a very nice old thing but a vinegarette and I'd rather be her friend than not. The cold fiend I fear is upon me again. I haven't had one for quite a month so its time I started off again I suppose.

February 17th
A very busy morning of Monday chores - linen, house flowers, clearing and tidying and Mothers meeting after lunch. Poggy has been absent nearly all day and even now as I write after dinner he is away on an Executive Committee meeting poor one. It blows cold today and slight snow fell alas!


February 18th
We awoke to this today and a cold North Wind. Alas my poor flowers. I am nursing a cold today so stupid to go and get one now and we have to dine out tomorrow night.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne's Mother had taken season tickets for Beecham's opera performances at Covent Garden - on February 1st she saw Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" and later in the month, on February 22nd, she saw Wagner's "Die Meistersinger"

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 19th - 24th

Snow and cold, but entertaining and Aldershot duties continue, though Wynne finds time to catch Die Meistersinger at Covent Garden, and joke about the problems of food during a long performance
viewer_8.description:
February 19th, Wednesday
This is not exactly how it looks today because its not snowing, but lots still lies on the ground and the wind is bitter. This is how Noot and Baby will look! Alas my poor flowers, I fear they will all be cut.
Tonight we went to an official dinner at the Lawsons, 16 were present and all the men in uniform. I went in with the General whilst H took the Lady Wilma Lawson, and it was very interesting to note all the changes she had made in the house.


February 20th

Which is the most fascinating of these quaint crowd. I rather fancy 1913 (on the right by the ?) but I suppose in 20 years time it'll be considered very hideous! The cold is intense the wind really bitter and as I still have a bit of a cold I felt very disinclined to go out so stayed in till the evening when we had to go with the Fitzroys to a Social at the Institute there to derive much amusement out of the costumes of the elite!

February 21st

A biting wind again but I braved the elements and went off to Charman to get some flowers and then after lunch up to the Home to read to the girls.

To tea came the Grays, H going off with him afterwards to a lecture. These perpetual lectures, there is no end to them and the accompanying picture represents this household.



February 22nd

To the above city today by the 10.0 train - and rushing straight off the the Stores I did much shopping, at about 1.30 I went on to Mother going back to Waterloo to pick up my box and to tea came Mrs Lees, Aimee, Gertie and Mice Fairholme. Gertie has now established herself at a resident ladies Club and spends her mornings teaching a small boy. At 6.0 we went off to the opera and had the perfect treat of hearing the Meistersinger which I had never heard before, as we didn't get out before 11.45 the opposite picture (see in the next page view) rather appealed to us! but we took a vulgar brown paper packet of sandwiches and devoured them with much joy in the stalls!

February 24th
I returned by the 11.45 and Mother came too to spend a week, so nice. She is certainly in less pain but very crippled still, and she finishes her treatment with Dr Stone on her return next week. I made a hasty change and rushed off to my Mothers meeting where the usual large party was assembled, we number 62 now but only about half come at a time or a few more which is lucky as our room wouldn't hold more. I really am quite happy doing this poggish old show as the women so appreciate it and some of them are very nice. If only fewer babies would attend, today we had close on 2 dozen.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
February 25th - 28th

Another wedding, this time that of Field Marshal Earl Roberts' daughter, Edwina, but the army station duties cannot be abandoned....
viewer_10.description:
"Just do your best
When worst seems easier. To bear the ills
Of daily life with patient cheerfulness
Nor waste dear time recounting them.
To talk
Of hopeful things when doubt is in the air.
To count your blessings often, giving thanks
And to accept your sorrows silently,
Nor question why you suffer. To accept
The whole of life as one perfected plan,
And welcome each event as part of it.
To work, and love your work; to trust, to pray
For larger usefulness and clearer sight. " (J.B.Smiley)


February 25th, Tuesday
What could be nicer than these verses above, I think J.B.Smiley must be a charming person but what a trying name! Would that one could follow such sentiments always but somehow there's no doubt that sometimes its very hard. Mother has painted this picture for me here as a hint of tomorrow's event I suppose.


February 26th
The Wedding today of Major Lewin and Lady Edwina Roberts, to which we went with the kind Grays so my little picture with its bells and health drinking apparatus is quite appropriate. We motored over and got to the church in good time, which was most beautifully decorated with lilies of the valley and lilac. A great crowd was assembled and the bride looked very nice in a silver brocade dress. After the ceremony they drove to the house in a brougham with a team of 6 and 3 Subalterns up led by his Captain awfully smart and used it again to leave the house when it took them to where their motor awaited them. The presents, two rooms full, were quite lovely, such jewelry and I felt so proud to shake hands with Lord Roberts.

February 27th
Once again I found myself at Shirts - I haven't been for quite a long time now owing to leave and Lady Haig's attendance and one horrible lapse of memory when I forgot to go at all! This is the last of the session for Infantry and we paid away nearly £33. To dinner tonight came Gen and Lady Lawson, Col. and Mrs Hall and Col du Cane, a most successful evening and I do trust the garbage wasn't too fearful, but what wouldn't I give for a first rate cook on these occasions.

February 28th, Friday
The last day of the second month of this year actually how time flies it only seems a day since Xmas. I spent a morning over many chores and then at 2.0 I went to the Home to read to the cripple girls, finishing up with the Magazine Meeting at the Rectory, it has been decided in future to hold them at the Church House a most satisfactory place I should think.
A letter from Lena, (Wynne's aunt), they come to us on the 12th I think to stay over Gran's birthday on the 13th and I hope that Aimee and Mother will come down for the day. Gran keeps wonderfully well but has a good deal of headache so we are getting the eye specialist from the Cambridge Hospital to examine her eyes on Tuesday to see if that is the cause.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
February was a month for weddings. On the 4th her cousin, Rita Fallowfield, was married, and on the 26th Wynne and her husband attended the wedding of Lord Roberts' daughter. The Roberts were family friends.

Below are details of Rita's wedding, and the page from the diary, followed by the invitation to the marriage of the Roberts' daughter, Edwina.

february.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne was a very keen gardener, and each month of her diary is prefaced with one of these cartoons...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: January 1st - 7th The New Year starts cold, but a ball enlivens things before the family decamps from their army home in Upper Hale near Aldershot, to stay with the in-laws in Chelmsford.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Wednesday
The New Year came in in a grizzly way, cold dark and wet. It has been so mild for so long that aconites, primroses, snowdrops all are out, but I fear we shall get it all right later on and things will be much damaged.
We spend our time still writing endless letters of thanks for Xmas remembrances and the days are short for all I want to do. The servants had their Party tonight, 27 of them with the usual huge supper and games and dancing over the stables, the room looked so pretty all decorated and a table of refreshments on one side including a box of cigarettes!

January 2nd
Eve's birthday! many happy returns to her. I cannot believe she is 40 today, we are all getting very old!
Mother and Gran left us today, and we miss them much, the house seems so empty and bereft somehow. Whilst Mother was here we made her slave at our fancy dresses and now they are completed and tomorrow is the dance. I am much looking forward to it and so is Win who goes with me dressed as "Silver" . A lot of other flappers are going too and it'll be her first big show so I want it to go off really well for her.

January 3rd
The programme which I stick in here will show how well we occupied our time, the dance was a huge success. We drove there with the Skippys in their motor...Win looked sweet and I got her programme full up and my dress which was nearly a hundred years old which belonged once to Aunt Maria really was lovely. When we got home we found Poggy waiting up for us because we had forgotten to take the key!

January 4th
I never felt less tired in my life and wish we could have it all over again! We were to have gone to Springfield today but my babbit has been rather seedy all this week and so we thought it better to put off till Monday. One day when she was playing with Gran I heard the latter mummering (sic) this funny little catch and as it must come from her childhood I write it down as she laughingly told it to me:
One-ory, Two-ory, tickory seven,
Alomy crackomy ten and eleven
Pin Pan Musky Dan
Twiddleum Twaddleum twenty one
Black Bear White Snout
Eerory Orery you are out.

January 5th
Such a vile day, we were blown to church and back again.

January 6th
We travelled en famille to Springfield today by the 2.5 which gave us plenty of time to pack, and found Mother and Mary rather poorly. I am glad we are able to come now in order to be of some use. (Wynne's reference to Mother is to her mother in law, Mrs Jackson. Mary is Herbert's sister, poor thing now delegated to the role of nursemaid).

January 7th
Mother continues to be better, but poor Mary is full of cold and cough and headaches still. She is really in a very bad state of health and Dr Storrs with his mild variations of treatment and medicines seems quite powerless to know what to do with her.
(Perhaps a change of scene, and the knowledge she wasn't going to have to spend her life looking after her aged mother, might have helped?)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: On January 3rd Wynne went to a dance...with her niece Win. This is her dance card. Dances were formal, and the trick was to get all your partners signed and waiting early in the evening! As you can see from the card, most of the dances were Waltzes.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt: January 8th - 15th Lazing at Springfield, Chelmsford, with a visit to London to see the Pantomime at Drury Lane as a Christmas treat.
viewer_4.description:
January 8th, Wednesday
My days are spent in writing, reading, working and driving, this is the programme and I am utterly content for the rest and change. I love my life but sometimes it is a relief just to do nothing as our days are very full at home always.

January 9th
Mail day and I have just sent off two long screeds to my dears and am in the middle of a third to Mabel giving her all the details of family history. (Mabel was Herbert's sister, and was now a missionary in Africa). H and I are very much occupied with making the bannisters for our dolls house. We have a little turning lathe which is great fun when it chooses to work properly!

January 10th
A gloomy day, dull and cold but what matters it. I am so busy doing nothing that I have no time to look out of the window.

January 11th.
Arthur left us today as his short holiday was up. I think he was much better and it has been jolly to see him. The household in general is really on the mend too.

January 12th, Sunday
My Pinkie is 10 years old today, actually in double figures, it seems hardly possible that it is ten whole years since that day at the Hive when first he put in his appearance.

January 13th, Monday
We have had a truly vile day today. I had to go to Town to a dentist and the day was bitterly cold with dense fog. Our train was 20 mins late in starting and one and a half hours late in arriving consequently I was over an hour late for my appointment, however that did not prevent him seeing me I'm thankful to say and now I am once more at peace but it was a horrid visit this time.

January 14th, Tuesday
Quite a nice day so different from yesterday and spent in the usual peaceful idle way except that I went down to the Town to get the presents for the Social Tea for Mary.


January 15th
We have had a long and very jolly day, we took the 3 children up to the Pantomime. Mother gave us all lunch and then we started off to the Aldwych to see "The Golden Land of Fairy Tales".
This being Baby's first visit to London properly and to a Panto everything excited her, even the Underground Railway, and Tubes and taxis! As for the performance she simply shrieked with joy at it all and when Puss in Boots did his dance she screamed out "I call that jolly good for a thing like that!" We had tea in the drawing room at the back of the box during an interval and it was all great fun. Baby sat on Win's knee her cheeks burning and her eyes glistening with excitement, the good kind Duke how many hours of joy we owe to him. We didn't get back until 7.30 but they weren't at all tired.

(The illustrations are taken from the Christmas crackers that were thrown to the children from the stage during the pantomime. Wynne stuck seven of them in her diary, so the children obviously did rather well!)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Wynne and Herbert often visited Herbert's Mother at the family home, Springfield, near Chelmsford in Essex. Wynne enjoyed the visits, but they were very quiet affairs - almost retreats, as you can see from Wynne's comment when a very occasional visitor called!

The picture below is of a typical Springfield interior, taken at this time.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 16th - 24th

The winter break at Springfield continues, with occasional forays to London - to the Zoo or to Paddington to wave goodbye to her son, going back to school.
viewer_6.description:
January 16th, Thursday
A lovely day, especially this afternoon which I spent in the shelter writing mail letters. I sent a long one off to Bill who wrote me last week. He comes home in April and is very anxious we should meet on the continent, Ell, he and I, but I fear Ell doesn't come till May. (Bill was Wynne's cousin, the brother of Rita Fallowfield, whose marriage took place at the beginning of February),

January 17th
I drove down into the Town this morning and did some odd jobs and then to the Shelter to sleep!

January 19th, Sunday
Mother and Mary both got to church today for the first time since Xmas, it is nice that they are well again.

January 20th
I, by dint of patent doctoring, got my cold well again almost and we took the children up to the Zoo. At the gate we met Mother (Wynne's this time) and Win, the former doing the show in a chair and we walked solid from 11.0 to 4.0 with a short interval for lunch. It was a jolly day and being Baby's first visit she just enjoyed it no end, everything fascinated her and at the end even when we got home she wasn't at all tired. We got hold of various keepers who took us behind the scenes and showed us all sorts of extras, the two baby chimpanzees are sweet. I remember we saw them last year and they are most human in the way they eat and do their tricks. Jacob the big Orangotang (sic) got out this winter through the roof and built himself a nest in a tree in about 10 minutes and they had to turn the hose on him to get him in again!

January 21st/Jan 22nd
I put these two days together because each one passes so exactly like the last that there is really nothing to record.

January 23rd, Thursday
I spent my morning writing mail letters but I fear they wont enjoy them as I felt in rather a growsy humour, and it is such a luxury to indulge sometime. Aunt Emmie came this afternoon. Mary went down to fetch her and Walter Butler came to tea, it is quite an event for a stranger to enter the house in this retired seclusion.

January 24th
I am bereft. We took Pink up to Paddington where we had lunch and saw him off by the 1.40 with 13 other small demons and Mr Brooks. The de Mornays were there with Charlie who goes to Southlea also, they all went off very gayly and I fancy had a good riot all the way home but I do miss the child so much and there is no small person to go up and say goodnight to after dinner.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
On January 29th Wynne noted that her brother was enjoying himself in Calcutta. He had travelled there as part of the Behar Light Horse team, to play in the Jubilee Polo Tournament of the Calcutta Polo Club.

Below is a newsphoto of all the contestants. Wynne's brother Elliot is on the extreme left, back row.
Beneath that is a photo of the original Calcutta club members - 1864/5 - taken from the cover of the anniversary programme.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 25th - 31st

Back home to Aldershot - but letters from her polo-playing brother in India and a London visit to an opera make it bearable
viewer_8.description:
January 25th, Saturday
A lovely morning and I went to early service with Aunt Emmie but later on it came over so dark and gloomy and though I spent the afternoon in the shelter it wasn't nice. I picked a huge bunch of snowdrops, violets, aconites and crocuses today.

January 26th
A lovely day and our last Sunday here, for which I am very sorry; it has been a pleasant quiet rest and I am sorry to say goodbye to Mother. She is however very much better but always so tired. She managed to get to service and stayed to choral celebration - it is curious to see how Gran who is 10 years her senior is so much stronger in body, though not of course her mind is as a child's in comparison.

January 27th
Today we left Spring(field) at 11.0, had lunch with Mother and then all went on to the box being joined there by the Mathesons. It was indeed a lovely show. Got home at 8.0.

January 28th
It is always so nice to be home again after all ones own Castle is best for comfort and however delightful it is in other peoples houses one always misses ones own particular fancies and then I hate having to smoke in one room always and sub rose, it seems so silly this latter at my age. I find so many jobs to do on my return and have spent a really good day in clearing out and settling in. Poggy has leave for a few days more which is delightful.

January 29th
I got a lovely silk evening Japanese cloak from Bill this mail, pale blue embroidered in pink such a lovely thing but I fear he must have paid a lot for it and a sweet little gold frog charm from Ell which I love, he wrote a long letter this mail telling me all about his ripping stay in Calcutta where he had been for Xmas playing in the Polo Tournament.
Our quarterly meeting of the Mothers Union took place today and lady from Farnham came and spoke very well, it was a very full meeting and the women seemed much interested. After dinner we went up to a Political Meeting combined with a concert at the Conservative Club.

January 30th, Thursday
We both went up to Town today, Herbert to attend an Uncle's funeral at Beckenham and I to Mother to stay till next Monday. I got up for lunch after which we went off and did some shopping and to the Goldsmiths Go where we had a lot of jewelry cleaned and where I got my ears pierced! a disgusting little operation and for which I shall get scolded by Eve and Ell doubtless but my earrings were always falling off and I got tired of it. This evening we went to Tristan und Isolde at Covent Garden. Beecham's season. Mother has taken cycle tickets and I am doing 4 with her, it was a splendid performance, such a wonderful orchestra and Beecham more monkeyish than ever.

January 31st
We spent our morning writing mail and after an early lunch sallied forth in a coupé for the afternoon, first we went to interview Dr Barton Wright as Mother has made up her mind to try his Barlitsu treatment. He seemed a pleasant man and entertained no doubts whatever as to be able to cure her so she is to start on Monday week. We got home at 5.0 and to tea came dear BG ( B.G.Scratchley, Wynne's old governess) with whom we had a great buck, she is going to be companion to a lady in Shepherds Bush and amused us much by vivid descriptions of them.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: On January 30th Wynne and her mother went to Covent Garden to hear the first of a season of operas conducted by Thomas Beecham...below is the programme for Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde". You will find others later in the year.

january.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The fashions for - Wynne obviously does not like the "3 decker" but would have liked the cloak....

And below is what is printed on the reverse of the illustrations!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 7th

Army chores at Aldershot, a picnic and then a welcome start to a London jaunt...
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Tuesday
Garden Parties, sports and entertainments of all sorts flourish at present today. I ought to have been to two at once and the Magazine Meeting but went to none as Arthur arrived to spend 2 days and I wanted to be here to receive him.

July 2nd
We had a lot of people in to tennis today, the court though little played on plays well and is as hard as iron. We had to leave Arthur tonight as we were booked to dine at the Lawsons where were gathered a party of about 20.

July 3rd
Once more I went to "Shirts", its quite a long time since I had this job to do what with the break and being abroad, no insurance today to torment one as there is a great fight going on and operations are in abeyance at present but it'll surely return. (This must be a reference to the new National Insurance plans set up by Lloyd George).

July 5th, Saturday
This has not been a suitable day for a picnic, grey and dull and rather cold, but we had promised to go and meet the Hurdwoods at Frensham Little Pond so stuffing the two children into the cart, Maby and I set off on our bicycles - taking the wrong turning we found ourselves quite in the wilds, so turning the cart back to seek the proper road we ourselves went across country and Oh! the toil of it. I thought we should never arrive, however we eventually all fetched up together. It is a lovely place, an ideal spot but the sun refused to come out and coming home we got caught in the rain. It is a pretty long toil on a bicycle and such fearful hills.

July 6th
A day of rest and photography. I am busy developing the films I took abroad and its most interesting. (You can see some of these in the June 1913 and Travel sections).
I am off to Town tomorrow to Lords and 3 days Bust.

July 7th
Started off by the 10.2 and went to the Flat, there I found Miss Halliday and when I had changed into Lords kit we all started off, I going to the Williamsons to lunch, Mother and Miss H lunched on the ground. It was so very nice doing this old show with Ell again, made us both feel 19 again and we met many old friends. This evening Mother, Miss H and I went to Oh! Oh! Delphine, its rather silly rubbish but quite amusing in its way.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 8th - 14th

In London, Wynne visits the theatre, sees Pavlova dance and has a good time before reluctantly returning home.
viewer_4.description:
July 8th, Tuesday
There is something rather fascinating in being in Town when I really ought to be at Home attending a Sale at the Vicarage! but I have turned a deaf ear to duty's stern call and here I am. All day rushed around shopping. Stores Russell, Dickens and Jones, Hamley, Evans, Marshalls and Harrods and Selfridge and bought several very necessary things amongst which a lovely sage green silk sports coat which is Poggy's birthday present to me!
Mother and I went to see "Gen. John Regan", Hawtrey's play, tonight and I did enjoy it. Its one of the finest Irish pieces I've ever seen, so witty and clever and we laughed like two maniacs over it, it brought back Kildare to me. (Wynne and her husband had been stationed there).

July 9th
I was to have returned to home and duty today but Ell persuaded me to stay till tomorrow as he had taken tickets at the Palace for the Williamsons and me. At 11.0 I went off to Lords where I met him and watched an interesting end to the Match in favour of Cambridge, then to lunch after which Ell and I drove off to the Club. ... (In the evening) I dressed hastily, had dinner and went off to meet the others at the Palace. There we saw an excellent performance and the immortal Pavlova who never danced better in her life - to the Carlton to supper, very nice and sat there till past 1.0.


July 10th
G(ertie Maclean) and I came back by the 11.45 and I slept most of the way down! After lunch the Grays called for us and took us over to the Findlay garden party, their yearly big show, everything very nice and well done. The world and his wife present and the rain kept off till the last minute which was kind.

July 11th
I went off to Hussey this morning, the rest of the day being fine and warm was spent in picking raspberries.

July 12th
People to tennis.

July 13th, Sunday
Another day of rest and photography, another roll of films developed.

July 14th
All the men are out and away attending to Field Days and monkey tricks of sorts, and Gertie and I this afternoon went to the John Henry Knights, this is the first invitation of theirs I have accepted I am ashamed - they had a tournament on which Miss Skippy won and Oh! the pogs which were there! where do these sort of people hide in the daytime as a rule?!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 15th - 21st

Bad weather means the Mothers Meeting tea is reorganised...but her brother's new car means some welcome (and unwelcome) diversions...
viewer_6.description:
July 15th, Tuesday
Anxiously I watched the weather from a very early hour this morning and down came the rain with steady determination and never eased all day. My feelings are better imagined than described for this was the day of my annual tea to my 60 women of the Mothers Meeting. All arrangements had to be altered. I had of course intended having them in the garden but we had to have it up in the Church room and I was disgusted and disappointed, however all went very well and many games, quilps and cranks took place.

July 16th
St Swithin is already a failure with his prophecy I'm glad to say, for its a lovely day today and no rain has fallen. Alas, why couldn't it have been like this yesterday. My Ell came today, his car turning up yesterday, and I went in it to Woking to meet him. We got back at 3.0 in time to go out to the Divisional Sports...tea with the Lawson's afterwards where a crowd of people assembled and the R.A. Band played.

July 17th
Poggy left early today and Ell took me down to Shirts at 10. and the afternoon was spent at a M.U. meeting at the Vicarage, a great attendance but an indifferent speaker.

July 18th
All troops being out there was no chance of Tennis or Bridge for Ell and the saint took me on a huge round of calls - we went to Fleet and round by Farnborough and did about seven, such a weight off my mind and still I have several I must do, they are a bore in this place.

July 19th
Poggy and Major Gray got in at 6.0 this morning and I being a dutiful wife arose to give them tea on their return. They had been out on Caesar's camp all night and this morning at 4.0 awoke the entire countryside with the fiendish noise of their guns.
People to dinner today, I was rather sick at having to refuse an invitation to dine with Lord and Lady Roberts this day. I hear Lord Milner and Bonar Law are to be present and it would have been so very interesting but unfortunately we had our own party.

July 20th, Sunday
The usual day of peace, spent in church and sleep and tea visitors.

July 21st
Poggy away out till tomorrow night at Frensham. Mother and Aim came and spent the day with us, Ell having sent his car up to fetch them, and after lunch the whole lot of us repaired to the Skippys to attend the Blokey's first birthday party. Babies swarmed and they had a Punch and Judy show, I had never seen one before, or at least for years, and just loved it.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Two photos Wynne took of her brother, Elliot, on his home leave from India...with her dog, Peter.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 22nd - 31st

A visit to the Ladies Horticultural College, Field Days and a French Tutor...but the real excitement is watching a propaganda film of the Army being shot.
viewer_8.description:
July 22nd, Tuesday
Gertie (Maclean) left this morning at 11.0 for Wimborne, I shall miss her, one of the very nicest and easiest people to have in the house. Ell and I started at 11.0 , after G had gone, on an expedition to Swanby - the Ladies Horticultural College - to see Ethel Rutherford who is studying there. We proceeded through Guildford, Croydon, Leatherhead, Epsom etc until at last holding E's letter in one hand and the map in the other we at length by devious ways found her bungalow where we had lunch with her and her companion worker Miss Roberts. It was Prize day at the College and all the students in their best, it all interested me very much and I longed to go and study there too.

July 23rd
Ell left this morning...and at 1.30 Bill and Herman arrived to stay a few days. To tennis today came a crowd of 17 in all I think, amongst them the Gen and his lady, the former skipping around like a 2 year old.

July 24th
Bill went off up to Farnborough in the morning with Mr Smith to see if he could get a fly but failed and after lunch the two boys went off to the Army Sports leaving us to enjoy a lovely peaceful afternoon in the garden.

July 25th
To dinner came the Drakes, Colonels Birch and MacMahon and Major Lewin, our 4 selves making 9. Colonel MacM. is an amusing old boy full of Irish fun and humour and full of noise! Of this we had plenty and laughed a great deal, and I think the food was decent but old Veacock is full of surprises these days.

July 28th, Monday
Poggy has gone out again for Field Day and night show, this is the last of its kind he'll ever do, seems odd to think of. (Wynne's husband, Herbert, was due to retire...though in fact events were to take a different turn).
Its just a perfect day and I've spent it idling deliberately, but was paid out for so doing by poor old Madamoiselle who stayed to tea after giving Noot her last French lesson for this term, and for a solid hour sat talking 19 to the dozen. Noot had to stand up and repeat a long French fable to me about a wolf and a lamb! She really is getting on quite well.

July 29th
Poggy returned about 8.0, sooner than I had expected having spent rather a disgusting night in fog. Attended the Magazine meeting and the Mothers Union tea at the Lawsons, what wild dissipations and how nice behind one!

July 30th
The weather has been gloomy and dull all day again and I spent my morning printing 50 odd photos.

July 31st
The last day of July! how the time does fly. My Pink returned from school today. After (lunch) we all went up on to the Common to watch the troops, cavalry and artillery performing for the cinema, a scheme of the Government to aid recruiting. Charges of cavalry and guns in action pranced before the photographer and we are now all eagerness to see it in the Halls!

july.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 3rd

Italian Holiday: Venice St Marks, the aroma of the backstreets, and serenaders in the Lagoon. Wynne makes a personl discovery of a secret garden.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Sunday
This being a Sunday we thought we would attend St Marks and see some churches. Accordingly at 10.0 we and Mr Todd, a fellow passenger of Ell's, started off. Mass was just ending as we got in and the crowds were enormous, indeed it felt more like a theatre than a Church. The Priests being the actors and the people the audience, for very many were taking no part whatever.
(Wynne then went on to Santa Maria della Salute and San Georgio Maggiore, which she noted was by Palladio but " like so many of these wonderful Venetian churches has an air of desolation and desertion about it.")
Ell being addicted to that reprehensible habit of sleeping after lunch took himself off, and I guide book in hand found my way through strange places to the church of San Giovanni e Paolo, an enormous church of old red brick begun in 1234 and finished 1430. Outside is the splendid equestrian statue of Bartolommeo Colleone" ...with a later pencilled note by Wynne in the margin:"This statue was destroyed by German bombs, 1916-17"
(I do not know where Wynne got this information, and as everyone will know, the statue is still there for all to see.)
I passed by and went through such odd places on the way, some streets being too narrow to pass a man in without touching, and oh! the aromas, the houses which are very high nearly meet and the streets are strewn with refuse in many places and look dark and gloomy whilst the tiny dark courts fill one with a wish to hurry by!


June 2nd
Last night we took a gondola and went out on to the Canal to listen to the Serenaders whose lantern lit barges looked very picturesque and were surrounded by gondolas listening to their songs, the scene was like fairy land, the warm still air, lights red green yellow all reflected in the Lagoon, and the voices across the water all filled one with a sense of perfect enjoyment and I just lay back and lived, it was quite beautiful. This morning we went to the Academy and when we came out our brains were mazed with all the wonderful and perfect pictures we had seen, the most lovely to my mind being Titian's Assumption.
A most perfect afternoon was spent in a gondola in which we went to Murano to see the glass factory ...and on our way back we visited the old and the present cemeteries which are on an island right away from the Town. We were filled with disgust at the neglect and decay of the graves, the RCs are not to be understood in their apparent sense of negligence in the matter of their dead, it was just a scene of desolation. (This is an extraordinary comment, and certainly does not apply now. Italian cemeteries, as most visitors will recall, are usually both immaculate and much visited, and Venice's in particular like most in Europe is available for constant reuse - which means that neglected graves can be opened and offered to new occupants. In the UK in contrast, where security of tenure leads to the opposite situation, old graveyards are in a deplorable state, and are rarely visited anyway. Since Wynne's visit to Venice, the cemetery has accepted many more famous names - Stravinsky and Diaghilev to name but two. )


June 3rd, Tuesday
I have succeeded in doing a most interesting thing today. In Thurston's book, "The City of Beautiful Nonsense" the scene is laid in the Palazzo Capello, and by following the directions in the book we found our way to this place. A certain Englishman lives there now, Williamson by name, and I wrote him a note and sent it in with my card asking if I might see the garden, not only did he allow this but offered to show me the house as well, this we didn't accept as we didn't like intruding but we walked all round the sweet old garden with its roses and tangled ways and I pictured the scenes in the dear old book I love so much.


(Wynne went on to the Modern Picture gallery, where she was not impressed by the "impressionist daubs"! Then on to various churches and the Scuolo di San Rocco. Long walks with occasional tea refreshment ended on the Rialto Bridge. She was an indefatigable walker).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A page from Wynne's Venice entries...

and a view of St Mark's Square in

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 4th - 6th

After watching a Venetian sunrise, Wynne and her brother depart for Ferrara and then go on to Perugia - "this wonderful old town".
viewer_4.description:
Maria Santissima delle Grazie, Perugia



June 4th, Wednesday
Alas, this is the end of Venice for us, we go today at 9.15 leaving by the 10.15 train for Ferrara. I am at this moment at my window waiting for the sun to rise! It is 4/25 so I am sure it ought to be up by now. I am determined to see one sunrise in Venice and the scene before me at present is perfect, the whole thing look pale pink and grey, the water undisturbed by traffic as yet reflects S. Giorgio and the Salute to the last pinnacle, the wonderful old building must be looking much the same as they did 6 or 700 years ago but in the near distance there stands a German cruiser just to remind one that its 1913. The sky is getting brighter and paler, I think that lazy bones must soon be here. I don't think I can see him actually rise from here (the Danielli) but I shall see the reflection all around, the tide is low and all the sand banks stand out grey in the water and away over at S. Giorgio where the Barracks now occupy the former Benedictine monastery they have put out all the lamps and are sounding revéillé.


We left Venice at 10.15 and arrived at Ferrara about 12.30, the heat has been tremendous, and there must surely be thunder coming. So far as the town itself is concerned I am disappointed, it is just a quiet modern commercial town with wide clean streets, ugly houses of uniform shape and all as straight as a dye, but one thing is splendid, the Castle over which we went...it is an enormous red brick building with a moat all round it, and most of it is used by the municipality now, but the old Custodian who showed us round took us down into the dungeons where the poor Parisana and Hugo were imprisoned by her husband Alphonso d'Este and afterwards beheaded. I never was in more gloomy horrors.

June 5th
Reached Perugia at 9.30 (pm), a long journey but through such lovely country, right over the Appenines, first we went up and up till we reached a place called Poretta, then descend through the most lovely wooded mountains and rocky ravines to Florence, at last we came to Lake Trasimeno, what a perfect country! The sun set just then casting a pink glow over the water and making the mountains look purple and as it grew darker myriads of fireflies flitted around and all the thousand crickets sang that song which reminds one of summer and warmth and peace. Soon Perugia came in sight, a brilliantly lit town high up on a hill and when we arrived we found an electric tram belonging to the Hotel awaiting us.


June 6th
This is a wonderful old Town, the only level spaces are the Piazza V. Emmanuele on which this Hotel stands and municipal buildings once the site of the fortress of the Farnese Pope Paul 111.
All the rest is up and down, tiny narrow dark streets, stairs and steps but not half so aromatic as Venice or Ferrara.
More detail in Travel/A Second Italian Journey From Perugia Wynne then went on by train to Rome, passing Assisi and Folignano on the way without stopping, much to her regret.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A page from Wynne's Ferrara entries...

And a view of the main square in Perugia in . For another sequence of photos from this town, see the last page view in this month...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 9th - 16th

Rome - another chance top see the Sistine Chapel, and excursions to Tivoli, before catching the train to Paris and home.
viewer_6.description:
June 9th, Monday...Rome
We went first of all to the Post Office where we picked up many letters from home, and which gave us good news of there. We then went on to the Vatican to see the Sistine Chapel again. After lunch we got hold of our erstwhile guide Signor Solditino who took us to the Baths of Caraculla where they have been making some extensive excavations, and have discovered an underground temple dedicated to the God Mithras, a curious sect or cult of the East. It appears that when the Emperor was building these enormous baths he had to employ certain workmen or slaves probably from the East and he allowed them to make their underground place to practice their rites in. there is another under the church of S. Clemente which unfortunately we haven't had time to see, and another has just been discovered at Ostia. (Wynne seems ignorant that this religion was a popular one with the Roman legions - these altars have been found throughout the empire).


June 10th
We have spent a truly lovely day. At 9.0 we set forth with Solditino to Tivoli and Hadrian's Villa. It took us all day and we went out by road train, the most dusty mode of progression I know. (What does this mean?) We first went to Tivoli where we saw the Villa d'Este and the truly perfect garden....after which we drove on down to see Hadrian's Villa, that wonderful result of the brain of a genius.
(Wynne afforded the gardens a good page and a half, and the Villa a few lines - testimony to her priorities - you can read her full description in Travel/A Second Italian Journey. The next day she was not feeling well, so took it easy and merely spent the evening sitting in the Forum, which she describes as being full of flowers, most growing wild through the ruins. Then the next two days they spent in the Vatican, and seem to have been able to do a great deal - everything from dungeons to the Library).

June 14th, Saturday
Our last day at Rome, alas! At 9.30 we left, travelling right up the coast of Italy passed Genoa to Paris, never shall I forget this journey, the heat was fierce and the dirt indescribable, the scenery absolutely lovely but one is continually running in and out of tunnels so that one can see very little. We had two men in the carriage all day and we all just sat and gasped. They left us at Genoa so we had the carriage to ourselves at night.

June 15th
Paris. We arrived here at 2.30 and I have never been so absolutely dirty in my life, we went straight to baths and after 2 hours scrubbing and dressing drove for another 2 in the cool of the evening all through the Bois, a lovely drive and were much interested in the crowds of happy people. My birthday - 34 today!

June 16th, Monday
Finding to my great disappointment that the Louvre and Versailles were closed today we came home, starting at midday and arriving about 6.0, a good journey and crossing and once more we are cool!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Rome - a view of the Forum, and below that, a part of Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli, wonderfully overgrown with flowering plants. Nowadays all the monuments have been cleaned up and the romantic wilderness has been lost...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 17th - 23rd

Back to her homely chores, with tennis and the Searchlight Tattoo as pleasant diversions...
viewer_8.description:
June 17th, Tuesday
HOME AGAIN
I went off shopping all day (in London) and on getting back at 4.0 found Mother arrived having come up from Hale. Ell also was in and at 6.30 my Dearest came in, having been up at Newcastle inspecting. A very ripping family party and we all went off to see "Milestones" together.

June 18th
H and I came back home today, and I have been away just 3 weeks, it seems ages.

June 19th
I spent a very busy morning doing a hundred jobs and preparing for Mother, Ell and Mr Salmon who all arrived today in order to go to the Searchlight Tattoo tonight. It was a most beautiful show, quite the best I've ever seen, the massed Bands numbered 26 making a total of about 1400 performers in all. The music was lovely and the weather being fine all was well.

June 20th
I am making a mistake as to the day we went to the Tattoo, it was today, not yesterday (I am writing this up)- this day was spent playing Bridge from lunch till tea and I got bored stiff. I hate playing on a sunny afternoon and 4 rubbers on end is too much, but Mother is mad upon it.

June 21st
Mother went away today and we drove over to the Grays thinking there was tennis but all had failed so Ell and Major G played singles.

June 22nd
Ell went off early to bathe with Capt Skippy and afterwards to the Kennels and the afternoon was spent in sleeping, to tea came Mr Smith and Capt. Springfield who he used to know so well in India and to whom he had a lot of happy days to talk about!

June 23rd
Today we had a lot of men to tennis and they played hard from 3.30 till 7.0. The court is already brown from drought - what will it be in August. We are wanting rain badly.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
From the diary of her Italian journey, a single photograph upon which to meditate...a moment caught, like the moment with the children by the river...who is this girl, what is she thinking, what became of her?

Let us go a little closer

Does she have a name?

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
June 24th - 30th

Gardening, painful Vicarage parties, and a visit to Malvern to see her son at his school.
viewer_10.description:
June 24th, Tuesday
Today Ell left for Town where he is entering upon a career of wild dissipation and the "Road to Ruin"! I have spent two ripping days at home gardening hard and its lovely being able to grub about in peace.

June 26th
My dear is at Okey, he has gone to watch the Heavies shoot and tonight I attended duly the district garden party at the Vicarage where a number of performers caused pain by their strange efforts giving one the feeling as if it were all ones fault!

June 27th
Joe Hurdwood came to lunch today and I took her to the Suffolk Sports, a fine day and pleasant company made quite an amusing afternoon. The Sports were quite a secondary consideration!

June 28th
I started off this morning at 8.17 with the de Mornays for Malvern to spend the week with my dear son. We arrived at 12.13 and at 1.0 went down to the school where we embraced our boys and had lunch after which a cricket match between Fathers and Sons took place, the former very properly beating the latter.

June 29th, Sunday
We were allowed to have our boys all day today so they came to breakfast, dinner tea and supper. We all went to church together and to lunch...after which we went off to a hayfield where we lay in the shade till tea, the boys ragging and teazing of course. Our boys stayed until 7.45 when we took them back to the school and sadly said goodbye, after this we strolled up the hills and saw the lovely view one gets from there for miles and miles round.

June 30th
We made an early start this morning and got home at 1.0 it was very hot and I was glad when the journey was over. Found all well at home and a large bundle of letters awaiting me accordingly I sat down after lunch and till 4.0 I just wrote and wrote when I joined Poggy in the garden and there we worked with an interval for tea till dinner time. There is a lot to do in it but it is looking quite lovely: such canterbury bells, roses, delphiniums, correopsis, campanulas etc etc... a perfect blaze of colour and sweet peas finer than ever, I only hope they won't succumb to streak this year like last. The rambler roses are particularly fine this year and the sight of the garden from my bedroom window is really wonderful, I've never seen such a blaze.

june.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt: March 1st - 7th Spring is in the air, and wynne enjoys the change and the flowers. Her entertainments include Moliere and a point-to-point.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Saturday
I am glad to say our garden looks better than the one depicted in this picture! (The March picture in the first viewer page). Indeed it is quite gay with crocus and daffodils and if we have no further frost will soon be lovely, but the wind today is dreadfully cold and we had to go down and attend the finals for the shield which I had the honour of presenting to the winners - I Battery Royal Horse Artillery. There was great excitement over the game as they tied first of all - they had to play for half an hour more, it was cold.

March 2nd
I did not go to Church today as I indulged in a go of Jungle Cramps instead - very unpleasant and unusual.

March 3rd
Mother returned to Town today and I miss her very much. H has gone out to an Executive Comm. tonight so I am having a quiet evening alone. I had my usual MM today where the same number as usual attended, I also had a Nursing Comm this morning so my day has been a parochial one!

March 4th
Above is a picture of my small neighbour Miss Skipwith, such a neat sweet person, the birds and hares look rather alarmed. He has gone to Brighton for the night so I am dining over there. I have had Capt Lloyd Jones here this afternoon making examination of Gran's eyes, he finds that her glasses were much too strong so I am writing for proper ones.

March 5th
I spent the whole of this day in my district and got all my mags off my back. I found them all fairly perky but a cold and influenza season is with us and a good many down with it. After dinner the Grays picking us up we went over to Fleet to some theatricals got up by Mr Dobree. He himself had translated the two pieces from Moliere and it was all excellent.
We have this week received dear Pink's report, such a good one stating that he has kept the top of his form all the time and is working very well.

March 6th
This very sweet and pretty bouquet was of course painted by Mother and are just the flowers which I have in the drawing room at the moment. The garden looks so gay and pretty and Baker is having a clearing up, cutting grass and tidying etc...and Poggy and I planted out some autumn sweet peas today.

March 7th, Friday
A lovely day today and we went off as usual with the Grays to the Point-to- Point, a gay and jolly meeting seeing there everyone one had ever known. Several falls but no real accidents, it was all very well managed and well done.
We were shocked to hear this morning from Major Turner that his poor wife died last night, they had only been married 4 or 5 months, 3 of which she has been in bed, it is too tragic for words. We were going to the Sergts. Dance tonight but in consequence of this we felt we couldn't do so, poor couple, how sad it is.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Local theatricals attended by Wynne on March 5th...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 8th - 13th

The week of Gran's birthday, a great celebration for her 99th year. But Wynne is also celebrating the new Insurance Act which pays out for doctors and medicine!
viewer_4.description:
March 8th, Saturday
This has been a lovely bright day clear and frosty but during the afternoon we had a sharp short snow storm in which I got caught as I had been over to tea with Mrs Taylor and was bicycling home. A high wind was blowing but luckily it was at my back.

March 9th
Long letters from Eve but none from my naughty Ell, however he's very good as a rule. To Church in the morning and to sleep in the afternoon. Capt. Sherlock cam to tea, mad and very nice. Bessie is troubling me at present, very seedy with a bad chill since Wed. can't get her right.

March 10th
I am alone as I write tonight, H having gone down to Keynston with Mother, he to look at a horse and she on Brookfield business. I wish he were not away as Bessie is no better, the Dr has not been and now Baby is seedy with a curious attack of indigestion pain and I am worried.
We are actually benefiting by the Insurance Act! in the case of Bessie as we have had Dr Coad in for nothing and medicines and now I think we are going to get her money benefit besides, I hope so, anyhow and then we shall not feel quite so rabid about it all!

March 11th

I had intended going to Town today to do various shoppings but Baby getting seedy and Bessie being still rather bad I thought I would put off till tomorrow and then H would be at home. Asking Mother what this strange bird might be she said she thought it must be a japanese tit! looks rather a depressed person!


March 12th
A most hurried day. An appointment with Hussey at 9.30, then SSFA in Aldershot at 10.30 and then Town 11.30 where I rushed about doing a hundred things. I met Thurie and Lena and George Elliot at Waterloo, and the two former came down with me. They have come down to spend a week with us for Gran's birthday.
(Thurie was Arthur, Blanche's brother, and Gran's 2nd son. He was married to Lena, and they had one son, Herman.)


March 13th, Thursday.

 

My dear Gran aged 99 years.
When we awoke this morning the sun was streaming in at the window, there was no March wind and so absolute stillness prevailed. A perfect day and this must have been the weather's birthday present to dear Gran. The first post brought in a sheaf of letters and parcels, last night bringing some too, and all day the telegrams came pouring in. Soon after breakfast T, L and I went in to give her our best wishes and to op[en with her all her things. She was delighted with them all and so pleased to think that so many should remember her. By lunch time Mother Aimee and young Walter arrived from Town and we had a great luncheon party drinking Gran's health with many "quilps, cranks and wreathing smiles", then we made her go and rest till tea. Mother, A, T, and L sat down to play bridge of course whilst Walter went into the garden to build sand forts with the children. Very soon Maggie Elliot appeared with Archie boy and then to tea which we had in the dining room came the Fitzroys, the Grays, the Bacons and a Capt Miles who poor man was paying his first call and found himself launched with this!! Telegrams kept pouring in and she had 47 remembrances in all, dear thing. How happy she was and hardly tired at all, a most successful day and a great joy to us all.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A birthday Ode written by Blanche, Wynne's mother, for her son-in-law Herbert, to celebrate his birthday....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 14th - 21st

More birthdays, this time her husband's and her mother's. All on top of the work of answering Gran's many letters of congratulations...
viewer_6.description:
March 14th, Friday
Lena and I have spent almost our entire day in answering Gran's letters and have actually got them all off our backs, it is a great thing done.

March 15th
Another lovely day but very blowy. Poggy took a holiday and all day long he and Thurie have been working at the Dolls House, it is getting mast interesting.

March 16th
Last night we had the most fearful storm I can remember for a long time. I thought the window at our bed head would blow in and the house seemed to shake, it was awful and horrid. I had 2 letters from Ell this mail which accounts for none last mail and he tells me he has been offered the management of Seryah, but is waiting to see if the Rajah will accept his terms before settling, it will I feel sure affect his home coming and I long for further news. Its all rather upsetting for him I fancy as he will I know hate leaving Ramcola.

March 17th, Monday
These sweet and very neat birds are of course painted by Mother and I think must have come in honour of my dear man's birthday. Mother gave him such a jolly reading lamp at which the house generally benefits greatly. Baby's present to him was a pincushion which she sewed all by herself, her first piece of real sewing and her excitement over it was tremendous. Nootle gave him mignonette seed, they did this last year too and we had such lovely results the whole summer long.

March 18th
All day long the industrious Thurie works away at the dolls house which is really getting on quite fine now, and has its staircase and bannister fixed and main doors on, it really looks most awfully neat.

March 19th
