Mother's birthday bless her! how many birthdays there are in this month. The Thuries left us this morning and we miss them very much, so pleasant and nice and so easy to amuse. My babbit hasn't been doing very well lately so Tanner came to see her, said nothing was really wrong but that she must eat more and a change of air is the thing so we have asked them to take her at Springfield. I shall miss her so.
(In the margin, Wynne also wrote: Assassination of the King of Greece)

March 20th, Thursday
My Father's birthday was today, how much one misses him still. Indeed that miss never grows less with me. I made a mistake, the Thuries left today not yesterday, I am writing up my diary today and was wool gathering.

March 21st, Good Friday
Spent a quiet day, such awful weather coming home from Church got simply drenched in a tearing hurricane.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne processed all her photos herself - she was a very keen photographer. She also seems to have spent considerable energy making her subjects pull ugly faces - here are a few examples, the first of her and the second of her daughter, Ysobel, in the centre, flanked by two friends...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 22nd - 31st

A visit from a friend, and good news from India. Baby is sick, though, and is packed off to Springfield. the month ends with the Regimental Races - a great day out for them all.
viewer_8.description:
March 22nd, Saturday
I have been and still am reading a most fascinating and interesting book, The Brenner Pass by Clare. It is most charmingly written and has given me such fearful "wanderlust" that I fell I must go there before I die, such quaint old old world places quite untouched by time, and never heard of before.
I have had a letter from my dear Ell this morning saying he is actually coming home!! It has excited me beyond all words and I do trust my plan of going to meet him will come off. Gertie Maclean came today, its very nice having her and we have not met except in Town, for so long.
(Gertie was Charles Maclean's sister - see the Love section for more about Wynne's connection to this family)

March 23rd, Easter Sunday
I spent the whole morning yesterday decorating the Church in company with several others and it looked so pretty though Easter falling so early the white flowers are scarce.

March 24th, Monday
Bank Holiday so I have had Poggy at home. Most of his day was spent doing the dolls house and I other chores. We then went out and did slugs and found that many mice had eaten most of our sweet peas so they had all to moved, such a pest and such a loss.

March 25th
Gertie and I drove into Farnham this morning and took Nootie to have her hair washed and to do shopping. After lunch I went off into Aldershot to a MU service which was held in St Georges, Stanhope Lines and we all adjourned afterwards to the RF Theatre where Mrs Talbot and the Bishop's wife spoke.

March 26th
This morning Poggy left the house at 8.15, his Division and the Ist have all gone out for 2 days on a billeting scheme and as they all passed along the upper road we went to see them go by, it was a fine array and I saw many fellows I knew.

March 27th
I feel bereft this evening my little Babbit has not been up to the mark lately, not eating and having colds so we have sent her for a fortnight to Springfield for change of air. We do miss her so dreadfully. I went up and saw her and Maggie off at Liverpool Street and then flew round the Town doing shopping coming home by the 5.30. We had a gay dinner party of 9 today.

March 28th, Saturday
This is not a racing note book nor am I a syce but being the day of our Regimental Races I thought it an appropriate heading. Well it began by pouring and pelting, the Sandars who wanted to be early started off in a cab and we followed at 12.25. We watched the first race and then had lunch at a reserved table with exalted company: the Douglas Haigs, Lawson, Findlays and Gen. Burton. During the day we saw so many friends and it was awfully jolly, despite the weather which though its stopped raining was very dull and gloomy all day. I am sad this day is over - the last Races we shall be at on service.

March 29th
The Sandars have gone away. Gertie and I spent the whole afternoon doing photographs but unfortunately they were a bad film and a good many were failures. (Though not all - check out the next page view).

March 31st
I am sorry that Gertie left today, I miss her much. I had my huge Mothers tea today from 2 to 5.30, 57 of them turned up with babies innumerable and oh, the esprit de corps.

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 9th

Slugs and variable weather, but Wynne also finds time for a visit to London to see a play.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Thursday
A lovely day so no one should mind being Queen of the May today. Out very early for we are having a campaign against the slug colony and they have to be caught early. We have got over 3000 now. I dined with the dear Skippys tonight and they took me to the R. A. Acting, an excellent show awfully well given, they did "Little Mary" by Barrie.

May 2nd
Win went back to school this day, I saw her off at the station, and Mrs Lees met her as I wasn't able to take her up myself this being my day for reading at the Home.

May 3rd
After a perfectly lovely day it has been gloomy and cold and wet today. We are and have been for ages having such uncertain weather and this was the day of the R.E. Sports to which I took the children. There was a great crowd there and it was wet and cold and I cannot say I enjoyed myself over much.

May 4th
Torrents of rain have fallen and prevented us from going to Church. Letters from Eve and Ell both well and I am to meet Ell in Venice on the 30th. Oh! dear how excited I feel as the time comes creeping on.

May 6th, Tuesday
I had the great joy of going to Mrs Gray at the Hyde Park Hotel and to Diplomacy in the evening. I went up by a morning train, first to B&H to get a coat and skirt and chose a very nice grey whipcord which is to be fitted for me. To the Hyde Park at 6.0 there finding Mrs G resting - Oh! the luxury and comfort of this place, we have a suite of rooms opening on to our own passage, our bedrooms, a drawing room, and a lovely bathroom. My room has 5 electric lights and a telephone beside the bed, hot water pipes heat all the suite, pretty china and flowers and lovely beds and bed linen, it is 20th century luxury all round and I naturally love being here. We had dinner at 7.30 and drove in an electric brougham at 8.30 to Wyndhams to find to our horror that the play began at 8.0 so we missed the first act! It is a splendid piece and although I daresay there are those who miss the original cast yet to one who hasn't seen it before it couldn't be better, and I enjoyed it enormously. Spent a lovely comfy night in the bed of luxury.

May 8th, Thursday
I hear today that my Dearest can't be home on Friday as he had hoped but must put off till Sat even on account of rain having stopped their shooting. I went to a Lantern Lecture on Canada, a very large and full attendance and much esprit de corps.

May 9th
Alas I am bereft indeed to day for my dear son has gone back to school. I miss him more and more every time.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 10th - 16th

The Royal Visit to Aldershot, marred by her husband's absence at the annual army camp.
viewer_4.description:
May 10th, Saturday
This day a great many years ago, more than I like to remember, I was confirmed, how well I recall that day. I went down Church decorating for Whitsun in the morning and spent the rest of the day gardening and in the evening about 7.0 my Dearest arrived from Camp just to spend 2 days at home, it is so absolutely ripping having him again and all is very well with the world.

May 11th, Sunday
This day speaks of Kings and Queens and Royal Princesses, for the Highest in the land are here at Aldershot and donning our best we went to the Garrison Church to attend the service at which they were present. It was a great assembly and a fine day, the world and his wife filled the church and by 10.45 we were all seated. The R.A. Band played most beautifully while we waited and afterwards conducted the service. The King and Queen, Princess Mary and Princess Victoria just sat in the front seat like ordinary people, the Queen being dressed in a pinkish mauve coat and skirt, a black hat and roses and the Princess in pale blue. Service over the King etc went out and took the salute and then walked out of the front gates all up the road to the Pavilion between cheering crowds.

May 12th
As I sit writing this my dear man has gone back to Camp and in all probability it will be more than a month before I see him again as he doesn't return until June 13th and if I go abroad it will be from the 28th to June 17th. I am missing him more than anyone knows, such a presence and personality in the house and such a blank when he goes.


May 13th
This day I went off to have my arm rayed at Husseys house and to tea came Mrs Gray.
(Wynne was experimenting with a current fad that involved bombarding her armpits with x-rays to stop her sweating. Ignorant of the risks, it was a very dangerous fashion, which led to problems for her later in life).

May 14th
I have been working at the dolls house, staining and sizing it preparatory to varnishing it for we are not going to paint it. It is beginning to look awfully neat. I quite forgot to mention that yesterday I received our annual command to dine with Their Majesties at the Royal Pavilion and for the 4th time have had to refuse on account of Poggs' absence. I am so sick, its just disgusting bad luck, especially as its our last chance which will never come again. (Herbert was to retire early in the following year). They have quite informal little dinner parties at which they are homely and friendly and I am awfully disappointed. However it was of course quite impossible to accept or rather I should say obey.

May 15th
I did some duty calls this afternoon and ended up having tea with Lady Wilma. She is a very charming woman, quite a grande dame but makes one feel so at ease and not frills about her. (Lady Wilma Lawson was the wife of the C.O.) General L is down with the C in C at Rollestone Camp where Poggy is now and I hear has had to borrow pyjamas from Poggy having left his behind!

May 16th
This is the very day my Ell is supposed to be starting for England. I read to my cripples today, then drove Gran to tea with Mrs Gray.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 17th - 23rd

Her cousin comes to stay: a good excuse for another London visit and other "mad" excursions, including a visit to the first ever Chelsea Flower Show.
viewer_6.description:
May 17th, Saturday
A day at home and much have I enjoyed doing the hundreds of odd jobs that always accumulate.
Bill my dear old Brownie turned up today. It is 3 years since we met. He looks much older and very thin but 6 months at home may do much. (Wynne is referring to her cousin, Bill Fallowfield. You can see him below, playing with Wynne's daughter Ysobel. With him, on the left, is Herman von Poelnitz, their mutual cousin).

Click here to hear Ysobel talk about Bill, and again here for Herman.


May 18th
I drove Bill to the Garrison Church today as I thought he would like to see the Parade, a lovely day and warm and after lunch we just lazed, at least I did photos and he slept. We spent this evening in getting through 3 years arrears of conversation.

May 19th, Monday
I set forth to London this morning for a 3 days jaunt. Bill came too. I went to Mother's flat where I left my baggage and then went off to B&H to have my dress fitted, to Douglas to have my hair dressed and to my dressmaker then home for tea. To dinner came Bill and took me afterwards to see Strife, a play on the labour question by Galsworthy, very clever and very harrowing but absolutely true to life and most interesting. We me Aim (Aimee, Bill's mother) at the theatre and went on afterwards to the Carlton where we had sandwiches and cigarettes which I very much prefer. I seldom feel suppery so late at night. This play is all about a strike and as Bill had been through just such a thing it must have been doubly interesting to him.

May 20th
This has been a very jolly day, and a most strenuous one. I had breakfast fairly late and then Bill came again and together we set forth to the City there to sign a Power of Attorney for Algie who has some scheme on, then I went to Cooks to enquire about my journey. We lunched at Rendezvous and went afterwards to see "Hello Ragtime" at the Hippo, a typically modern production and rather clever. I had to leave before the end however as WT was due with me at tea. Tonight I had great fun. I took a party of 6 to Lady Fulton's dance at the Ritz. They all dined with me first.

May 21st
At 7.30 after 3 hours sleep I arose to wake Tommy and give him his breakfast and he went off at 8.30. He is going to India in Sept I am very glad and I am sure it is just the thing for him. Ethel Rutherford came and together we went to the Flower Show at Chelsea Hospital, it was absolutely charming. Bill came too and we were all lost in admiration and joy.

May 22nd
A horrible day of good works - Shirts, Nursing and Aldershot committee. Oh! the pogbaggishness of it all.

May 23rd, Friday
This morning we did a perfectly mad thing. Bill was very anxious to fly and last Thursday when we were up watching them go up a mechanic told him that if he were up there any morning by 5.30 the pilots would take him up, so accordingly this morning we arose at 4.0 , had a small breakfast and by 5.45 we were on the ground. It was a dark and sunless morning and slight drizzle falling so not really very inviting. When we got there we found that the flying corps were not going up as there was too much wind and only 2 from the factory and the pilots of those when asked said they were not allowed to take anyone up without a letter from a flying officer so we just had to come home again!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 24th - 31st

Departure for Venice, and the longed-for reunion with her brother, Elliot.
viewer_8.description:
May 24th, Saturday
A perfectly lovely day, and the country looking its very best. I drove Bill over to lunch at the Hurdwoods. We left pretty soon as I had people to tennis, they played until about 7.0 and then Bill and I watered the garden with riches from the barrel.

May 25th, Sunday
A very hot day, really terrific but how I love it. To Church first, then a most lovely treat, motoring to Windsor with the Skippys and then on the river all the afternoon. I did enjoy it all most frightfully, the men rowed and we just lay on our backs and basked.
Wynne then packed and prepared for her big trip to meet her brother in Venice. If you want to see some additional pictures with more information, go to Travel, and check out the Italian Journey for 1910 and 1913.

May 28th, Wednesday
Left my happy home this morning at 10.2 and although I am going off to do what I want most of all to do yet there is always a horrid feeling saying goodbye. I went to the flat where I welcomed my Mutze (her mother) who arrived home from Baden last night. We had lunch and then she came and saw me off at Charing Cross. I write this on board during the crossing, it is perfectly smooth but of course I am feeling sick!

May 29th, Thursday
Well here I am just passed Lucerne. I spent a most comfortable night, I had a carriage to myself all the way to Basel which we reached at 6.30. There an Englishman who entered into conversation turned out to be a certain Col. Molton Barret travelling to see some property in Florence and having just come in for all the Browning Estates.

We parted at Milan, and I having 3 hours to wait went and saw the lovely Cathedral which is like a piece of delicate lace work and so beautiful inside. Also I went to Santa Maria delle Grazie to see the Leonardo de Vinci, also it is pathetic to see it, so faded and faint and soon I should think it will have gone altogether. I continued my journey at 6.20 and then began very long hot hours until at last I arrived at Venice at 11.30.


May 30th, Friday
My first impression of this most lovely place was one of fright! I arrived as I have mentioned at 11.30 last night, there was no moon and I found I had to set forth in a gondola quite alone, away we went up the Grand Canal which was silent and almost dark, at the Rialto bridge we turned off into small and gloomy canals with no sound save the swish of my gondolier's oar, on and on for half an hour until the climax was reached when as I passed under the Bridge of Sighs the clocks struck midnight! I was thankful to reach Danielli's and very soon was in bed.
This morning as soon as my box arrived I changed and went down to the quay to meet my Ell who arrived at about 11.0. Oh! it is so splendid to see him again, the first thing we did was a drink and a buck and then we set forth to see St Marks....
(Wynne also visited the Doge's Palace, to which they returned on May 31st. Check out her comments in the Travel section, link above)

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9

may.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 1st - 7th

Worries about Granny, visits to London, and the surprise arrival of an old flame...
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Saturday
Here is November, how the time does fly, only about 6 weeks off Xmas and I've got nothing done this year and no preparations of any sort so far, but I suppose all will be finished in time as usual.
My dear things got back at 3.0 (her husband and youngest child had been at the paternal family home), both looking very well and it is a joy to have them again. I've done about 5 months grass widowing this year off and on and I do hate it so.
Gran is causing considerable anxiety at present. She is very feeble indeed, so tired all day long and sometimes almost speechless. A week ago I had to get in a nurse to assist Clark on account of her (Clark's) back which after a week's massage is better. Gran submits to the nurse but doesn't care for new hands.

November 2nd
My Gran being a bit better I went up to town on business and pleasure combined. We find it necessary to get a maid attendant to help Clark as a permanency and so I went up to see about it, but today after taking my Mothers' meeting and getting the Vicarine to come and wind up for me I went up by the 4.6 and to the new English Opera Raymond Roze's "Joan of Arc". His music is very much criticised and they say its much cribbed but though parts were familiar and the language somewhat crude yet I enjoyed it awfully.

November 3rd
Breakfast was at a disgraceful hour for Ell and me - we just lolled in bed till 9.30. Mother being dressed and away to her Dr before we were out of our rooms!! I then set off with Ell who came as far as Sloane Square with me, to go to Clivedon Road to search for a maid and made appointments with two for Mother to see, then off up to New Cavendish Street to see about a wheelchair for Gran. Home to lunch and down by the 4.12.

November 5th, Wednesday
Being Guy Fawkes Day we had our usual display of fireworks. How we laughed. H and Young set them off making the most of them by waving them frantically in the air! much to the childrens' delight.

November 6th
Mother left us at 11.0 today, her visit has done Gran no end of good and breath of the outside world has roused and cheered her up, she is wonderfully better, it is just delightful to see her for though she has practically lost the use of her legs now her speech is clearer and her brain also.
I had the great pleasure today of Charles coming for the night, it was a pity H had to dine out just this night but we amused ourselves by talking over old time with many "Do you remembers".
(Find out more about Charles by checking out Love)

November 7th, Friday
My dear Gran being so much better we put her in the wheel chair and took her into the drawing room. Its the first time she has left her room for 3 weeks.
CWM left this morning, he has a new car and in setting it going injured his hand most horribly, running a spike deep into it, but I dressed it up for him and set him on his way.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 8th - 13th

Wynne's brother Elliot returns to India, practical jokes are played on her old governess, and the family visit Brixton for Christmas shopping.
viewer_4.description:
November 8th, Saturday
My dear Ell came down to lunch to say Goodbye to H and the children and I returned to Town with him for the week end so as to see the last of him.

November 9th
Breakfast was at the disreputable hour of 10.30! today but a real good laze occasionally is delightful. BGS (Miss Scratchley, Wynne's old governess) came to lunch and knowing she would not know I was up we had the inspiration to hoax her most successfully. I dressed up in Mother's black coat and shirt stuffed with pillows, a hat of hers, yellow goggles and 2 grey tails stuck on my hair and got the maid to announce me as Mrs Barbarina Booth! In I walked and could see at once she didn't know me. After talking fearful twaddle for a while with lump of sugar in my mouth I suddenly sprang up and said for old times sake I must embrace her, this accomplished she hurriedly got up and said she must go and take her things off whereupon I sprang after her with leaps and bounds and with shrieks of laughter disclosed my identity, she meanwhile was filled with fear thinking Mrs Booth had gone mad!! How we laughed. I felt quite weak and it was a complete success. We went to an Albert Hall Concert after lunch, B returning with us to tea and then to dinner came the Williamsons. He sang afterwards to us, it was very delightful to hear him and I haven't done so for about 15 years. This sweet picture (which you can see in the next window) Mother painted and this is what the tits do all day outside the drawing room window.

November 10th
In the sad grey of this gloomy Nov morning my dear Ell left us. At 6.30 I went to his room to wake him and at 7.30 he had breakfast, leaving at 8.15 and Oh! the desolation of it. I went to the stair head to see him go and then to my room to try and collect my wits for really I felt at the very end of all things. I was glad that I came up but so awfully loth to leave Mother as early as I had to (on account of my Meeting this afternoon) for it seemed so desperately lonely for her there poor dear thing. This hideous parting seems to get worse every time indeed the anticipation hangs over one all the time he is at home, but thank God he loves India, his life and his work and he has splendid health to back him, but Oh! how I want him back and how the future stretches into eternity just after he has gone.

November 11th
Poggy has gone to Springfield again to finally settle up the business (after the death of his Mother). They are having a great family meeting for the purpose of dividing the things. Thurie turned up today for the night and Aim for the day (Uncle and Aunt of Wynne) both to see dear Gran who is wonderfully better, much brighter and clearer in head. The nurse attendant, one Mead by name, came yesterday. She is a woman of about 50 with many years of training at St Georges, a very nice gentle manner and quiet ways, most capable and seems very satisfactory in every way.

November 12th, Wednesday
This day we made our annual expedition to Brixton Bon Marche, a party of 8 as the Legards joined forces with us, the children each armed with their green bags and part of their year's savings. We spent as usual the entire day there, Baby shopping with me and Noot with Maby this year, with much deliberation and choosing we selected her presents for various people and with the remainder she plunged on her own account!

November 13th
We are having very cold and cheerless weather, dark and windy, not conducive to cheer but I keep a smiling countenance as is our duty towards the community.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 14th - 21st

Home Rule in Ireland - the worries about an increasingly dangerous situation surface above the usual round of chores and good works.
viewer_6.description:
November 14th, Friday
The world at large, at least the English speaking world more especially, is much interested in the present complex state of politics: the threat of Home Rule is in the air, and the Prime Minister (Asquith) is torn between Ulster on the one side and Redmond on the other. At present is seems as if a General Election is the only way of solving the difficulty and that Mr Asquith wont have, this cutting pretty well explains the situation and its about as bad as it can be. (See next window).
I have been to a Womans Suffrage meeting at the Institute today held by the N.S.W.S.S., a lot of women were present and the speaker spoke very well and to the point. They are entirely non militant this society and were most interesting. There is no doubt that Womens Suffrage will come and in many ways we shall greatly benefit I feel sure but one wishes the means employed to arrive at it were not so frantic often.

November 15th
My Poggy came back today after having spent a strenuous week amongst the family assembly at Springfield dividing the goods and chattels. I was having tea with the Lawsons and as he got back at 6.18 I drove down to the station and picked him up. Dear man, so ripping to get him back.

November 16th
To church as usual, the Vicar is ill with flu and very bad I believe poor fellow.

November 17th
My Mothers Meeting and 37 and many babies present, a drenching evening.

November 18th
My dear old Gran goes on much the same by fades visibly every day. Her mind is failing and she does nothing but sleep, just waking for her food.

November 19th
Poggy has been away inspecting at Farnham all day, and during his absence I've been very busy unpacking and arranging all the things which arrived today from Springfield. We have the big gold mirror, their dining table, barometer and some pictures, glass, china and silver. All very nice and very interesting and a ton of books besides!

November 20th, Thursday
To Shirts, 7 ladies, 900 shirts and every shirt has to be examined all over before its passed, it takes a bit of doing and I had them into our pay room this morning and passed as well as paid and even so we didn't get away until 12.30. I bicycled down and had tea with Mrs Legard today and stupidly forgetting to take a lamp I had to walk home, it was dark and I nearly ran into hedges and ditches and people all the way.

November 21st
We are having truly seasonable weather - dull, dark and wet and really when one gets up it might be night. I wrote letters all morning and read at the Home after lunch.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: This is the article about Irish Home Rule that Wynne cut out and stuck in her diary - she refers to it on November 14th. How little things change!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 22nd - 30th

Illnesses, charity sales, German lessons and news from her brother.
viewer_8.description:
November 22nd, Saturday
I went this afternoon to the Winwoods to have a ladies 4 at Auction - it was very interesting but I disgraced myself by losing 1/9d! I wish one got more Bridge here but none of our near neighbours play.

November 23rd
My Sunday Diary is always a dull one for we consider it a day of rest and refuse to go anywhere.

November 24th, Monday
I am doing a weird thing, viz. taking German lessons from a little nun at the Convent at Farnham. Poggy and I have a plan of going next Spring to the Brenner Pass and if we go I must speak a little German but oh! its difficult! To tea came the Lawsons and Mrs Eden and whilst at tea Mrs Skippy came in to say he had had a fall out hunting and strained his back so Poggy went over to help carry him to bed poor chap. I do hope its not serious. We are all very anxious about the Vicar who is lying dangerously ill, they say its typhoid, anyhow he's been unconscious for days and has 2 Drs. and 2 Nurses. My dear Gran on the contrary is much better.

November 25th
I have had news from my dear Ell from Marseilles and Port Said - he writes wretched accounts of the voyage, the boat is a disgraceful old tub and they are all suffering much discomfort, its bad luck. The Skippys lent me their car today and I went a huge round of calls, we have 2 new Brigades in both of which have 5 married men in them living at Tongham, Aldershot, Fleet, Church Crookham and Ewshott - such distances! This is Skippy's birthday and the Addisons had got up a dinner for him, now he poor one is in bed and we had to go and have it without the hero, it was sad.

November 26th
Such a busy day, we started off at 9.12 to Town and got back at 7.30, shopping hard all day with an interval for lunch which we went to Mother for.

November 27th
The Annual Sale of the Disabled Soldiers and Sailors took place today and I helped to sell at the 2nd Division stall. The things are so cheap that it takes a good time to get a £1 - we made about £9.10.0.

November 28th
We hear the Mr Watson (the Vicar) is a bit better today but they now don't think it can be typhoid for though he is still unconscious his temp. has dropped, its most strange. Capt Skippy is better, we went in and sat with him tonight. We have been to a most delightful Concert this afternoon given by the RA band at Aldershot Hippodrome - I here stick in the programme.

November 29th
A lovely perfect day, drove into Aldershot first thing, then wrote letters and spent the afternoon gardening in the warm still sunlight. It felt like Spring and several thrushes were singing.

November 30th, Sunday
Mr Watson being ill we have sundry and divers preachers now, this morning's being a very tall man with a huge deep voice who preached too long a sermon. I spent the afternoon learning German lessons - they seem to become more and more complicated and I feel a worse fool as time goes on. Shall I ever learn the grammar!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9

november.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 7th

The end of summer...but not before the church was decorated.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Wednesday
Poggy and I spent all today in Town shopping and loafing - its ages since we were up together and I much enjoyed, but it was very hot and full and we missed our return train by half a minute.

October 2nd.
I went the round of my district this morning leaving magazines and words of wisdom and I wrote mail letters all the afternoon.

October 3rd
The perfect weather continues, warm, still and fine with early mists typical Autumn weather and very lovely. I spent my morning Church decorating, the flowers were lovely and such profusion that we didn't know where to put them all. I've never seen a finer year for Michaelmas Daisies...we went to the Harvest Festival at 7.30, a very full church and Mr Hitchcock our former vicar came and preached.


October 4th
A morning of many chores, being of a domestic turn of mind I always find a lot to do in my house.
I also bicycled up to see two people in my district and after lunch Poggy and I went up to Charman to order some bulbs and plants. I had a cheery letter from Eve at lunch, she is enjoying a hard earned rest up in the hills, a picture she drew me I here insert and from her account it must be a perfect paradise. (Eve has written Bhimtal - Kumaon at the top, as the location. If you google Bhimtal you will see how beautiful it is!)

October 5th, Sunday
Such torrents of rain in the early morning but cleared in time to go to church. I didn't take the children as my Noot has had a cough and cold all the week so they had a short walk after lunch instead, then the dear things being told they must not disturb us shut themselves into the school room with books and never uttered a sound till tea.

October 6th
Really winter seems to have commenced today as once more my Mothers' meetings have begun and for 2 hours did I sit with 47 women and 20 babies! thank goodness it was a lovely afternoon so that we were able to have both windows wide open even so the atmosphere was sultry.

October 7th
I was to have taken Gran to tea at the Fitzroys today but she had one of her tired days on and spent the day in bed.

(The picture at the top of the page is from a card sent from the Octoberfest in Munich.)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: An autumn day in the garden - Eleanor (Baby) sits on top of Ell, who lies behind Ysobel (Noots). Taken in the garden at Upper Hale.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 8th - 15th

Good works, family visits and worries about Gran.
viewer_4.description:
October 8th, Wednesday.
A cackling Committee at Wellesley House today of the SSFA, a lot of ladies present and I stopped and had a cigarette with Lady Wilma after they all left, she has asked for particulars as to Gran's birthday date so that she may ask the King to send her a wire on it. Alas my dear Gran is very shaky and seedy today and being rather anxious I sent for Tanner. He felt her pulse, said it was poor and added -"I fear she is breaking up and I don't think she'll last the winter". I am much depressed at the thought, to be so near 100 and not outlast - it seems so hard. She seems really collapsed today, utterly tired and speechless. Her frequent headaches he attributes to blood pressure on the brain resulting from weakened arteries, poor old darling, but he is sending her some medicine to relieve this pressure.

October 9th
The dear Grays who are staying with their brother and sister at Shiplake, sent their motor for us and we went over there 30 miles to lunch. What a lovely "old" house and only about 3 years old! beautifully built and quite old looking with grounds running right down to the river upon which we spent the whole afternoon - they have 4 boats and oh! how I should love such a place.

October 10th
I went up to read at the little Home today, my poor little cripples all sit round and sew and are such a patient cheerful little lot. Gran continues much the same at present, is very helpless and feeble, and I cannot but feel anxious but God willing she'll weather the storm.

October 11th
My dear Ell came down today for the week end and Gertie M(aclean) to stay awhile, its very nice having them, the latter is not well and looks very thin but is going to Town soon to see a Dr. (The children enjoyed Ell's visits - here Baby is sitting on him! while Noots reads)

October 12th
Perfect weather, still, warm and silent but the robin has started his winter song and one feels that summer has really gone. The usual Sunday programme, all to Church except Ell who is a heathen!

October 13th
Ell went off early and as H had to go to Town too they went off together. H returned in the evening, he went to meet young Tom in order to have his gun fitted but he never turned up so the errand was fruitless.

October 14th
This morning I spent in getting ready my second batch of photos for the Happy Moment Competition which closes tomorrow.

October 15th, Wednesday
Topsy's birthday! She has caught me up and we are both 34 now! Poggy and Baby left us for Springfield today, he has gone on about 3 weeks leave for he is much needed down there just now for sorting and clearing and helping Mary generally, and Babbit went down for a change and to keep him company: "the old monkey and the young monkey" I call them. I miss them much, my heart strings.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: These are the playbills for Wynne's plays in October - "The Shadow" by Eden Phillpotts, and "The Great Adventure" by Arnold Bennett...and the reverse of one, the Shadow, to illustrate the adverts of the time. Note how simple the programmes were - certainly not the expensive monstrosities of today!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 16th - 23rd

Gran continues poorly, but Wynne manages to get to London to see a play, and receives a visit from an old love....
viewer_6.description:
October 16th, Thursday
As Monday brings Mothers' meetings so Thursdays brings Shirts and Fridays the cripples, my winter programme and the weeks fly past so quickly that I always seem to be doing them all together!

October 17th
Just as I was starting off for the Home this day a message from Sister Margaret arrived saying they had influenza up there so on account of Gran I didn't go.

October 18th
A perfect day again and Mother and Aim came down to see Gran. She had a better day on and came into lunch but she is so very feeble on her legs that we could hardly get the poor old dear back to her room again.

October 19th, Sunday
A non church going house party today, I wanted to be with Mother who leaves tonight, Gertie was feeble and seedy and Maby had a liver attack so Mother and I went and sat awhile with Mrs Skippy, he afterwards playing to us and after lunch we sat and talked hard till it was time for her to go.

October 20th
Dear Gran goes on much the same, varies a good deal, some days seems very much better, others so feeble and almost speechless.

October 21st
Tanner came this morning and pronounced Gran much better and pulse stronger. I am troubled now that Clark has strained his back supporting Gran. It is a trial and if she doesn't improve I'll have to get T to look at it.

October 22nd, Wednesday
Very thankful this morning to find Gran well enough to leave as I hied me off to Town for the night and left by the 11.0. At Mother's flat Poggy joined me and at 2.0 we went together to Major Bethell's wedding. David was best man and marshalled his troops admirably, even to flinging rice all over me! The reception was at Buckingham Palace Hotel and all went off very well. We then went on to tea at the Club. This evening Mother and I went to one of the finest plays I've ever seen, "The Shadow". I was tremendously taken with it but it is so fearful tragic that I simply wept and couldn't stop even after I got out. I've never seen finer acting, absolutely to the life, and I did enjoy it.

October 23rd
I see that by some forgetfulness I never noted down a great event which occurred on Monday. Who should come in on his way through to Bournemouth motoring but Charles Maclean, my long lost beloved one! it was with the greatest pleasure I saw him again and it was a joy that he seemed the same as in the old days. It is 14 years at least since those times. He and his lady are off to India shortly but I hope to see him before he goes.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: This is the start of the article Wynne refers to on October 30th...we are still debating these issues today, though now the arguments concern birds of prey etc...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
October 24th - 31st

Discussions with the gardener about Lloyd George...while strikes, calamities and the debate about Irish Home Rule are noted.
viewer_8.description:
October 24th
A Mary Yolland day, a committee on it in the morning and reading there in the afternoon, and after dinner I went over to the Skippys where I stayed till 11.30 listening to the pianola.

October 25th
A day of many jobs and chores.

October 26th
Seldom have I experienced such a fearfully wet day, a dense fog to start with and then rain all day long...by night I felt positive mould growing on me.

October 27th .
As I write this in the evening a wild gale is blowing and much rain has fallen. I've just come back from the S's where I've been dining. Capt. Campbell who is going out with Ell as assistant is putting up with me but is staying over there, really Ell left this morning alas! and once more I am alone, Poggy being still at Springfield. They are to have a great meeting tomorrow of all the brothers but Ted and Landon to settle the division of the household gods.

October 28th
I have been gardening all the day, cleaning out borders and replanting and just as we finished down came the rain in torrents. Baker and I had much political conversation and he cited his beloved L.G. (Lloyd George) to me at length, I trying to keep up with him by making fatuous remarks with great assurance to lend them weight - he is a queer character.

October 29th
I heard yesterday from Poggy that poor Tom is down with bronchitis and so their meeting has had to be postponed, it is a bore. I went up to Town today, lunched with the Fultons and on to see The "Great Adventure", a clever and amusing play with Henry Ainley as its chief. Mother also lunched, she tells me that Wow (Aimee's husband) had another fit yesterday and was unconscious till night but is resurgam again today!
The world is a queer place at present, strikes in every quarter and during the last few days there have been frightful calamities on land and sea, in air and underground and tonight Bonar Law addresses an indoor meeting at Newcastle of 15,000 on the subject of Home Rule. What will the result be?

October 30th
On the opposite page I have stuck an article which I cut out of yesterday's Post, one of the most charming things of its kind I've ever read before. ("The Passing of Bird's Nesting" by F.G.Aflalo - you can read a bit of it in the previous page view).
A long morning of Shirts, then out again at 3.0 to a magazine meeting, and after tea I went over to the Skippys for a short while to find when I returned home that my Gran had just had a fall out of her chair but seemed in no way hurt - indeed she declares it has done her good and has shaken her up a bit!

October 31st
A perfect day, it always seems to be so on Fridays, and up to the Home I went to read to my little cripples. Tomorrow my dear man and Baby return it will be ripping to have them again.

october.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 7th

September weather depresses Wynne, but a present from her friends cheers her up.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Monday
Oh what a day for the 1st, it has never ceased to pour from morning till night even now as I write me at 11.0 pm I can hear it coming down in steady torrents. Mrs S (kippy) took us all down to the Baths in the morning where we swam about with enjoyment and after lunch feeling the rain literally soaking into my brains and bones I went over to the Ss till tea and brought her over to me for that meal to which came my dear Grays, it was ripping to see them after so long.

Sept 2nd
The torrents of rain still continue and I feel mouldy and dreadful. I am missing my man so much and after occupying my day with many chores and useful jobs I wrote over to the S's and said, please may I come after dinner which with joy I did. I can't bear to think of this month when H is away and both of them and all the station and I am left here like an owl and a pelican, however there will be plenty to do in the garden and with a houseful of children who can be idle?

Sept 3rd
Much rejoiced in the return of my man and my Ell (for one night).

Sept 4th
My dear Ell left this morning, he is motoring down and intends shedding Gardener today and managing by himself. I wonder how he'll get on. (No Licence necessary in those days - you just got in the car and tried to drive it!) We went off to lunch with our beloved Grays today I do so feel saying goodbye to this dear blessed couple. Nothing could exceed their absolutely delightful friendship. The other day they gave us both most lovely presents, to me a lovely gold wristlet watch from Asprey and H a perfect gold match box with a silver monogram.

Sept 5th
The weather is fearful, its pouring and pelting and has done so all day. The Skippys went off this morning, their house looks lonely and dull and I do so miss them, they will be away for a month.

Sept 6th, Saturday
The children who were to have played in a tennis tournament at the Winwoods yesterday have gone to do so today instead as it was put off on account of the weather, but today although not quite so wet is quite as gloomy and horrible, I do so detest such weather at this time of year. I spent my morning round my district and after lunch sorted books and did chores. The Grays came during the afternoon in consternation. They have been ordered to India but will have to get an exchange as he cant stand the heat.


Sept 7th
It has cheered up today and although a high wind the sun has appeared quite a long time, after lunch I took the tribe up to the Bourley Waterworks. I do so love that place. Noot and Baby sailed boats in the catchments, Win and Bob stretched out in the heather and Pink bug hunting as usual, he is getting quite a jolly collection now and the schoolroom swarms with boxes of caterpillars in various stages of turning whilst the mice do their best to eat up the butterflies on the setting boards!
(On this page Wynne stuck in this piece of white heather she found - remarkably it is still just about white!)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The Gray's gift to Herbert - it is designed for non-safety matches, which you strike on a grid of small teeth on the base of the container. The monogram in the centre that Wynne mentions reads HKJ - Herbert Kendal Jackson. The small ring at the side is presumably so that Herbert could add it to his watch chain.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 8th - 14th

The weather improves, and Wynne's husband Herbert sets off on Army Manoeuvres - the troops leave Aldershot in a great wave.
viewer_4.description:
September 8th, Monday
It has been a lovely day, the morning spent in swimming, the children have quite mastered that art now and Noot for the first time swam halfway up the baths from the deep end. After lunch we planned to take our tea up on to the Common but as I was setting off in the cart with Sinott and provisions who should come along but Mrs Addison and Capt Skippy so, delighted to see them, I stayed and gave them tea instead and sent S up with the children's tea. H went up to town to see Mother about the plans for next summer and it has been arranged that this house be taken on for another six months, Mother taking over charge and we boarding out the children with her. It will be a great convenience to us and such a blessing about Gran. (This is a reference to Herbert's forthcoming retirement, due in 1914)

Sept 9th
I did some gardening in the morning and Joe came to lunch after which it poured and pelted and ended by being a fearful evening, now as I write this I am alone, H having gone to dine with the General who is giving a farewell dinner to the Gunners who are leaving us after Manoeuvres.

Sept 10th
At 9.20 this morning I started off and bicycled to the Grays there to select a heap of books they are casting and some clothes of hers presumably for the poor but charity begins at home!

September 11th, Thursday
To Shirts in the morning, Oh! this horrible old job, it bores me and this morning I had to take on the book and the paying as there were so few ladies.


Sept 12th
A lovely day and in answer to many entreaties I piloted the children all 3 of them on bicycles down into Farnham, it was just like a bag of fleas let loose and when we got down there we met hordes of troops marching in for manoeuvres, it needed all the nerves I could muster to keep my fleas from being run into and over.

Sept 13th
At the hour of 7.30 we all breakfasted and at about 8.15 my dear man set off on Preston for the last time "On Manoeuvres" and the blank which he leaves in the house grows worse every time he does it. Still to think that this is the last time that "active service" will see him is to me most melancholy. I took the children up to the Addisons house on the Farnborough road to watch the columns march out and there said farewell to our batteries from South Camp and Ewshott who go on to Bulford and Sheffield after this and return to us no more, it all made me feel rather deadly. The troops and their baggage took hours to pass and we didn't get back till past 12.0. I took many photos but the light was bad.

Click the play button to hear Ysobel's anecdote.

This anecdote refers to the fact that because Herbert was away he usually missed the big Parade for the King, which was normally in May. For the 1912 manoeuvres, click on 1912, to find Wynne with him in Wales, or go to 1911 for a description of the Parade.

Sept 14th, Sunday
I feel the loss of my man, most horrible is his absence, makes a vile blank in the house but really I must not be so feeble. I took the children to Church where Nootie was so busy dogearing her prayerbook and dropping it at intervals in to the pew in front that I wrested it from her, substituting an old one much to her disgust!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Army Manoeuvres, ...looking at these regular troops, moving out to their exercise, you cannot help but wonder how many lived to see Christmas 1918...


The civilians crowding around in the background above, or the man on his bicycle below...must too have been sucked into the cataclysm that was just around the corner.

And what of Major Bethell of the Royal Artillery - what happened to him I wonder, and his spendid horse...and had he managed to pop into the Hippodrome the night before to catch "The Mysterious Lady in Red" which is advertised behind him?

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 15th - 22nd

The end of the school holidays...and following the progress of the Army in the newspapers.
viewer_6.description:
September 15th, Monday
To the baths this morning for our last swim of the season.

Sept 16th
Mrs Frazer having lent me her car and tickets I and Mrs Boone went over to Wisley today to the RHS garden and were both immensely interested. Took down names and got many hints.

Sept 17th
Yesterday morning I took the children down to be photographed - we hadn't had them done for years and I do hope they'll be a success. Win's cold is very troublesome so I am keeping her in bed and having a day at home.


Sept 18th
Alas! the last day of the holidays has come. Win being better I let her up today for she has to go to Town tomorrow. I have been very busy packing their boxes and sort and listing their clothes. I shall miss them so much. After tea Maggie bicycled with Pink and Noot up to the Hangars to see the flying.

(The cards on the left inserted by Wynne in her diary show the Army Airship, the "Gamma" and a B.E.Type "272 with pilot and passenger about to commence a flight. If you click here, it will take you back to 1911, where Ysobel describes seeing some early planes and airships)

Sept 19th
I took the children up to Town first to Mother's flat where we had lunch and then we all went and saw Pink off by the 1.40 at Paddington, after which we did a lot of shopping and home by 5.30.

Sept 20th, Saturday
I drove over to Whitmead today to have lunch with the Hurdwoods. I hope to hear from Poggy tomorrow - he is so busy at the "War" that he hasn't much time for writing but I follow his movements in the papers with much interest.

Sept 21st
I had a long letter from my man today blessed one to write, he and his lot were lying at Chalfont St Giles and there he found Gertie and Col. Phipps for it is their home and he has dined and teaed with them. The papers are most interesting and I follow their movements daily, they leave CSG early tomorrow morning having a march of 24 miles.

Sept 22nd
I have been away nearly all day. I bicycled over to lunch with Mrs S. Clair and then went and had tea at Mrs Taylors close by. These cuttings (see adjacent page-the cuttings are about the manoeuvres) are rather interesting reading, I heard from Poggy again today, very fit and well and I'm wondering where they are at this moment.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Below is an article Wynne cut out and pasted into her book - it describes the exercise currently being undertaken, but makes rather chilling reading in the light of hindsight...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 23rd - 30th

Manoeuvres end, Lloyd George is teased and a new vicar discourses on the appearance of angels...
viewer_8.description:
September 23rd, Tuesday
I bicycled over to Redhill Farnham today to look at a garden that is to let for (?) but as this particular piece has no glass I don't think it will be any use to her, but I envied the soil, light, rich and loamy.

Sept 24th
Went up to Town. Joined Mother, Ell and Win at the Box (Drury Lane theatre) and saw "Sealed Orders" - a most marvellous play, an air ship, man o'war, motor cars, Chelsea Flower Show etc all on the stage. Many thrills and sensations - it was most interesting.

Sept 25th
A day after my own heart - a whole day at home and with leisure to sit down and do the various jobs and chores and an afternoon of gardening. I shall hope to do it tomorrow as well and the next day when my blessed man returns. No one knows how I miss that man as the years go on I find myself less and less able to do without him, the papers are full of their march north, what an immense thing it must have been, the King and Queen have been present and I hope they're proud of the army, that's all.

Sept 26th
Yesterday's paper contained this cutting which I thought so clever I had to cut it out, it really is rather unique with its various references to all the topics of the day concerning this much discussed man, he is clever enough to be amused at it himself I should think. (You can see the cuttings in the next page view - Wynne is referring to Lloyd George, then the Chancellor of the Exchequer).
Tonight to my great joy Poggy returned to me.

Sept 27th
A lovely day, still and hot and we spent it pottering and lazing, a real enjoyment and I have loved it. Personally from lunch till tea I lay in the garden reading and sleeping and after tea we gardened in a mild way until the lovely day drew to a close.

Sept 28th, Sunday
The family party once more took itself over to Church where we suffered a new preacher, an old man from Yorkshire who gave us a long dissertation on the characteristics and personal appearance of angels, quite a new idea and queer!!

Sept 29th
I have had a lovely morning, a clear out of all the back premises in Leacock's absence (the cook), who is away on pass till tomorrow. Never shall I forget the accumulation of rubbish, mouse nests, spiders and dust. Ugh! all is clean and clear now.

Sept 30th, Tuesday
Never have I known a month pass so quickly as this one has, I suppose it is because I have spent it in longing for the end which was to bring my man back to me at its close. I drove Babbit down to the Town this morning to get her weighed and as far as I can tell she had gone up 1lb in the last fortnight. She is being fed on Benger Framefood Robboleine and Allenby's Beef Juice! and really does look less peaky but she is growing so dreadfully fast. H and I bicycled down to Farnham after lunch for various ends. Noot in bed with a cold.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: This is the article that amused Wynne - a typical piece, smothered in classical allusion - how many readers today would find this amusing?, but this writer was catering for an audience brought up on Greek and Latin. He also appears to have had plenty of time in his Club to pen this!

september.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 6th

Wynne and Herbert begin to come to terms with retirement...and the weather!
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Wednesday
I was so occupied in writing about our official extinction yesterday that I forgot to say that the Skippys took me to their Pt. to Pt., it was a lovely day and we all enjoyed it very much and the ground though very heavy was not quite such a bog as usual. Aunt Mary came to spend the day here today in order to see Gran, luckily the latter was up to seeing her and seemed very glad to do so. I went down to meet her at the station and took her in to catch the 4.6. We are reduced to the pony now as Sinott has gone to the Winwoods, both the horses have gone, it seems so odd without a stable menage, also Young who has also left us. We miss him awfully.

April 2nd
We went over to spend the night with the Findlays this day, and having no means of getting about the kind Skippys sent us over in their car.

April 3rd
We came home early and this afternoon went over to Ewshott to the Pt. to Pt, this is the combined 1st and 2nd Division one and a very good little show it was, all the gunners were there and after it was over went to the Mess for tea buy we returned as Major Sandars arrived this evening for the Races tomorrow. He motored all the way from Oxford.

April 4th
To our horror this morning began in torrents of rain which continued 'til 12.30 when we started off for the Races, arriving on the course it had stopped and gradually turned into a lovely day. there as usual we met many old friends, heaps and heaps of people one knew, almost too many as one sees too little of them. One thing that strikes one meeting people like this after a lapse of time is how old so many of them look and one realizes that after all one is only looking into a mirror! The age of mould is creeping over us all!

April 5th Sunday
Philip Lyster arrived last night to spend the week end looking much better than I have seen him for years. We marched him off to Church in the morning, very good for him, and after lunch we went off for a walk over to Caesar's Camp. It was lovely up there but such a high wind blowing. We left PG to his own devices this evening as I wanted to hear Mr W preach for the last time but one. He leaves us on the 15th. I am very sorry.

April 6th, Monday.
My Mothers' Meeting and little else. (Wynne's Army duties were nearly over, and this meant that much of her charitable work would cease too. MM meetings, committees etc, plus a magazine round that meant walking all over her "district" were all due to finish in May. She had mixed feelings about it all. She, along with many members of her class, expected to do a great deal of voluntary work, but the end of her husband's career meant a move and some changes.)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 7th - 14th

Children back from school...and the Easter holidays begin
viewer_4.description:
April 7th, Tuesday
My Win is actually 15 today, I simply cant believe that its 15 years ago since she arrived in Motihari, a long thin grey looking worm with skinny fingers and toes and a propensity for howling.
My beloved son came home today, H went up to Town last night, spent the night with Mother and brought both children home by lunch, or rather I should say such was his intention for he and the boys missed the 11.45 and Win had to come home alone and they followed later.

April 8th, Wednesday
Went up to a little service at the Home chapel this morning, it is a charming and delightful little place with its lovely old Italian decoration, carving, embroidery, furniture and pictures, a real Sanctuary, a very good organ and everything so nicely done.

April 9th
Another quiet day. My old Gran has become very feeble of late but in actual bodily health keeps well.

April 10th, Good Friday
In the evening we took the children down to the Lantern Service which was taken by Mr Watson, they having returned on Wed or yesterday, he looks wonderfully well but I am sure is not fit for work yet and seems still tired. (Mr Watson, the Vicar, had been very ill in November - at one stage Wynne wondered if it was typhoid. He appears to have recovered).

April 11th
The usual Church decorating for Easter, it is the one I like best and the Church really looked very pretty with all the daffodils, jonquils and narcissi.

April 12th, Easter Sunday
Very early this morning our household started off to make their Easter Communion. Poggy and I going to the 8.0 at the Parish Church which was Choral minus choir boys, a very full service. Mother arrived yesterday from Town to spend Easter with us, she is awfully bad poor dear and it is so awful to see her suffer like this and not be able to anything, but the weather is lovely now and so perhaps she may benefit. This day last year was the last time my dear Gran was in Church. I am so thankful she hasn't realized what day it is or she would have been so distressed at not going.

April 13th, Easter Monday
My dear little Noots' birthday, she is 10 today, it seems so odd to think that this year she has got into 2 figures whilst Gran has 3. We had a great hiding of presents after breakfast and then spent the morning sorting eggs and preparing for our big Hunt this afternoon. We had about 22 children and a lovely day, it was great fun and we all played baby games and skipped about like 2 year olds.

April 14th
Being Easter week I thought I should have a holiday from MM but alas they would not let me off so I had to have one today for them instead.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne, like everyone else at that time, was very wrapped up in the story of Scott's expedition to the Antarctic... Herbert Ponting's film show was very popular at the time, and has recently been re-released as "The Great White Silence".

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 15th - 19th

London shopping, and the delights of Adeline Genee and the Scott's Polar Expedition film show
viewer_6.description:
April 15th Wednesday
Mother took her departure today and H, Pink and I went up with her to stay till Friday. I had a lot of school shopping to do for the boy and so went and got him fitted, on arrival Mother and H took the boxes home and Pink and I wandered off. We lunched first at Harrods off galantine of Chicken, Peche Melba and drinks from the ice cream soda fountain! then to the Scotch House for kit, then to Our Boys for boots after which to Selfridge where we explored the roof garden where they have tea and gold fish ponds and flowers. One can get a tremendous view up there. You can also practice golf in nets if you are so minded! After a little more shopping we went home walking down Bond Street where Pink was much amused at the latest hats shaped like a horse's straw hat minus ear holes!

April 16th
I went off this morning and did much shopping and after lunch we all went to see the incomparable Genee dance at the Palace. We took Pink to the first Music Hall he has been to! and he thoroughly enjoyed it. As for Genee she was as delightful as ever and it seems sad that the world is to lose her for she is giving her farewell performances before retiring. She gave representations of dancing from the 18th century and very beautiful it was too.

April 17th
Mother and I betook ourselves to the Goldsmiths Co this morning on a very exciting errand, that of choosing the lovely suit case she is giving Herbert: pigskin fitted with ivory and silver, everything one could wish for is therein and he will be a swell. It is really beautiful and will be a lasting joy. We then went to Brices where we had an excellent lunch for 1/8d for 4 courses! and draughts of Munich beer. It is one of those many Italian restaurants in Compton Street. We then went to the Philharmonic Hall to see Ponting and his cinema show of Scott's Expedition. This is such a wonderful thing that I think everyone ought to see it and I am going to take Noot and Baby to it as Win has already seen it. This what Filson Young says is indeed true and one cant really realize the wonder of it all as one sits there gaping and taking it all for granted. To think one is actually seeing here in Town what took place at that far away spot, some of the films being found on them when they were discovered dead in their tent 18 months after.

April 18th
Our plans for going abroad have undergone a change. It came to me yesterday that we couldn't go off abroad and leave Mother to do all the getting out of Brookfield alone as there will be much to see to and so we have decided to put off our journey for another month. We shall in this event go down there about the 30th with her and stay till all is sorted, divided and arranged and then I shall depart feeling much happier.

April 19th, Sunday
Primrose Day! and all of us forgot it! Not so Mrs Fitzroy who was duly ornamented and when H went down to spend the afternoon with her she insisted on decorating him with a primrose bouquet.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Having retired, Wynne and Herbert were beginning to house- hunt - and Oxfordshire took their fancy...this was a house they stayed in, typically captured on a post card. Almost every street in the country seems to have appeared in a similar way before the First World War...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 20th - 25th

A trip to Oxford, to start exploring for a home to live in when they leave Aldershot.
viewer_8.description:
April 20th, Monday
We are having such perfect weather - it is abnormally hot and cant last, the garden is a blaze of white, yellow, purple and wall flowers, a really lovely sight.

April 21st
A most magic day for us. 15 years ago today we got engaged, and there comes to my mind that breathless April night in Bombay, the unromantic verandah of Watson's Annex and the voice of the man I hardly knew beside me - it must have been fate which made me accede to his demand for I'm sure I didn't know my mind, and oh! how blessed has been the result. Could anyone have been happier that I?

April 22nd
And on this day so long ago I sailed away to England and have never been back since, would that the Fates might take me back but there is no chance of that alas.

April 23rd, Thursday
We are away today on an expedition into Oxfordshire. We have come to spend 2 days with the Sandars and are much interested in their charming old house which they have bought here at Little Tew. It is in the depths of the country but having a motor puts all right. (Wynne and Herbert are beginning to look for somewhere to live now that he has retired - the property would be rented, as almost no one bought in those days).

April 24th
A lovely lazy morning, the feeling of being able to do nothing is quite delightful, and after lunch we made a long run in the motor to Chipping Norton, Burford and Stow on the Wold. The surrounding country of these parts does not fascinate me, it is too high, flat and cold, awfully exposed and very treeless. We teaed at Stow and at Burford went over the beautiful old church and explored a weird old house, Lady Hane (?), which is for sale. The mill stream runs immediately against the back of the house and oh! the dampness of it! We rambled all over it and I was much taken with and wished it had not been so damp. The church at Stow has been much restored and I didn't care for it, and the Rector keeps the churchyard in a horribly neglected condition. Evidences of much vandalism around and he would not let his garden look like that.

April 25th, Saturday
We left today at 11.30. I am so glad to have been, this house of theirs is exactly what we want, old stone with stone slabbed roof, mullioned windows, and the usual queer interior, oak beamed and all different levels. They are having to build on to it on account of the newcomer! At North Camp we were met by the Skippys with whom we went to Wisley Gardens and there interested ourselves in all the lovely Spring things. It is very educative and I wish one lived nearer. We had a tea picnic in the woods, so very jolly and still and warm, and then the drive home over the Hog's Back was quite too lovely and I wished it could last for ever! The country has dressed itself in every possible shade of green and the blossom of apple, pear, prunus etc is wonderful this year.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.excerpt:
April 26th - 30th

Holidays are ending, and more important, so are the army chores Wynne has been doing for so many years.
viewer_9.description:
April 26th, Sunday
And still this perfect weather continues, so lovely and hot, no wind, no clouds and after lunch I took all the children over to Bourley that place of enchantment. We lay about and then picked primroses and came home reluctantly to tea. Old Hunt the warder came and accosted us but telling him I was a friend of Skippy's put all right as he knows him well.

April 27th
That one should have to spend the afternoon indoors on such a day seems a sin, but Mothers Meeting called and I with 30 women and many babies in close and puggy conclave sat "lovingly" from 2.15 till 4.0. Tis the last but one! Much gardening and much watering took place this evening and we did not stroll in to dinner till all hours. Why be a slave to meals and punctuality!

April 28th
We were much disappointed today in having to refuse a visit from Lord Roberts, so many times he has proposed coming and each time something has happened to prevent it and now I don't believe we shall ever catch him. We couldn't stay in to see him this afternoon as we had promised to go to a concert given by Miss Leefe with Mrs Skippy, it was a very good performance and the world and his wife present.

April 29th
I took Win down to the station today and saw her off, she spends tonight with Mother and goes back to school tomorrow. I do miss her so awfully, the house seems lost without her. Mrs S and I went calling today and I wrote our names and left cards finally on Govt. House, it does seem so odd and so horrid being a soldier no more but poor Poggy is thoroughly enjoying his hard earned holiday!

April 30th
This lovely month is at an end. I always regret it, I think in their own way there is nothing to touch April and May for delight and beauty, the country is looking its very best, so fresh and green and the garden is a blaze of colour. I attended the last magazine meeting I ever shall attend and tomorrow I go round with my last batch of magazines and shall say goodbye to my people. I've worked amongst them for 4 years now but it is rather a thankless task and for the most part I do not regret it! The Watsons are resigning. We heard yesterday from him to this effect, his health is not at all satisfactory and his Dr. will not allow him to continue. It is a wise move but he will be much missed. After tea I did some gardening and ran the obstacle races with the children. I must be getting into my second childhood!

april.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband is commanding the Artillery.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne starts to stick all manner of things into her diary, including lots of patriotic cards - these are quite small, about 7cm x 8.5cm - and probably purchased at the newsagent. You could send them for a half penny postage provided you only wrote the address of the recipient....no message allowed!
The Allies: Belgium (King Albert), France (Poincaré), Russia (Tsar Nicholas) and Japan (the Mikado Yoshihito), with George V in the middle.

And another card Wynne has stuck into the diary, with all the important ministers of the Government: Kitchener (War Office), Churchill (Navy), Asquith (PM), Sir Edward Grey (F.O.), and Lloyd George (Exchequer).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 4th

Europe sleepwalks into war...people start panic buying and the prices start to rise. The army is mobilized.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Saturday


What a dreadful beginning to a new month, each hour brings further fatal news. Germany has sent an ultimatum to Russia to the effect that if she does not cease to mobilize by noon today she (Germany) will also mobilize, of course the reply is a foregone conclusion. Knowing that provisions are likely to be scarce and go up in price I set about ordering in an increased quantity today and got them all. ES and I also went down to Aldershot to the Stores. There we found confusion worse confounded, people feverishly ordering in all sorts of food stuffs and the men said they would have to work all tomorrow as they could not keep pace with the orders. Our intention was to purchase flour. ES wanted 70lbs and I 50lbs. At first the man said he'd book it and forward it in the course of a day or so. Not so, said we, we'll take it away with us and I personally paid for mine there and then. It had already gone up 2d on the 12lbs. I also invested in tinned goods and potted meats and tongues and on my return had a consultation with Mrs Bacon who went down afterwards and purchased for me a ham. I also got her to get me a £10 note changed to gold whilst Swansborough did the same for me as I hear that soon we shall even find it difficult to get gold. In France it is already almost unprocurable and today Bank Rate in England has risen to 10% and the Stock Exchange is closed. I think so much of my dear man and wonder exactly where he is. I don't know his address but got a line from Town written last night saying he would send it soon. (The currency was still on the gold standard, and some of the coinage was still gold - notably sovereigns, which were £1 coins. This is what Wynne was sending out for. There were 12 pennies to a shilling, and twenty shillings to a pound - in other words, 240 pennies in each pound. A penny bought a great deal then. As you can see in the cutting oppositie, the Government soon acted, but they did not bring in rationing, and this was to cause great suffering later in the War).
.
August 2nd, Sunday
Everyone is most kind and sympathetic. Mrs Fitz asked me to tea and Mrs Newcome to lunch but I feel somehow as if I couldn't go out and prefer to stay at home. When we got down to Church the news reached us that Germany has declared war against Russia. That means France will follow immediately and indeed hostilities have already commenced on both the Russian and French frontiers of Germany. It is an inconceivable thought. Mr Bacon, the Naval Reserve one, has received his orders and left this afternoon, and Skippy is hourly expecting his. Everyone is overwhelmed with the paralyzing thought of what it all means and one thinks of nothing else all day and night. I bicycled down to Farnham to try and get a decent Sunday paper but could get nothing but rags. I just long for tomorrow's MP and Times. (The MP is the Morning Post).

August 3rd
All day long everyone has been longing and waiting for mobilization orders. Dread fears have taken hold upon all that this Ministry will shirk the responsibility of helping France but one feels somehow it couldn't be, however the thought depresses one. The wildest rumours are afloat, and everyone is filled with vague alarms. I heard this morning from my man who gave me his address and I was able to write to him but he is far afield and goodness knows when he will get the letters. One goes about with a restless haunted feeling all day, most terrible things are happening abroad and all telephonic communication is cut off between us and the continent. Germany has invaded the neutral state of Luxembourg and this evening has it that she has entered Belgium!


August 4th
Germany has declared war against France. How dreadful it all is and this morning's paper has the speech made by Sir E Grey explaining the grave reasons for not sending an expeditionary force over there but assuring France of our protection. (see opposite:)
Thank God the House was unanimous with the exception of a few extremists like Macdonald. (This is Ramsay Macdonald, who later became a Prime Minister). Then Mr Redmond got up and made a surprising speech saying that if England wished to withdraw her troops from Ireland that the Nationalists would join with the Ulstermen and defend their own coasts. It is splendid how the common cause has brought the generous Irishman to the fore, even the Nationalists - indeed its a case of an "ill wind".
(It is true that the declaration of War let the Government off the hook in Ireland, though the problem did not go away, it was only postponed).
Tonight at about 6.0 orders came for mobilization, so it has actually and really come this thing, and to England, who would have thought one could live to see it. All of course is for the moment upset and the prospect of getting anything delivered from Aldershot is nil. The worst of it is my bicycle is bust and so I'm awfully handicapped. Meat I hear has risen enormously, foreign meat especially and English stuff is scarce. I had all my servants in today and explained matters very thoroughly to them and pointed out the dire necessity of economy etc. They are all very good and will I know help me but we are a household of 12 including 4 very ravenous children.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne's diary page for the day when War was declared. The cutting is enlarged below.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 5th - 10th

WAR IS DECLARED

German advances, rumours, and services of Intercession.
viewer_4.description:
August 5th, Wednesday.
England has declared War upon Germany.
The weather is most suitable to these awful times, it is cold and dark and depressing. Mrs Bacon came in this morning and we had a talk together. Mrs Skippy came and we gloomed together and then after lunch (went) down into the town. I went to the station to enquire about Herbert's sword that has got lost and found there swarms of Reservists both arriving and departing, the station a mass of men, many alas only too well "treated" by their friends and heaps of women and children seeing them off. Well the die is cast. Germany rejected our Note about Belgium whose territory she is now invading and so today War has been declared. In these few words hangs the fate of thousands and all our men go to the Front in due course. (Poor Wynne - little did she realise that it would be millions, and that all meant all. Her reference to "treated" refers to the fact that many of the men were very drunk).

August 6th
Owing to strict Press Censorship we do not get a great deal of news and it is a weird thought that unknown horrors may be going on in the North Sea where our Fleet is concentrated. The German army is slowly but surely and with heavy losses engulfing poor Liege which is making a brave resistance. I went down with ES to the Town to make some store purchases for Skippy, a strange scene it was, all our friends there in uniform of course, with their wives trying to make last purchases, the shops a seething mass of people laying in provisions and the shelves and counters getting more and more bare. The Camp presented a strange unwonted sight, masses of reservists being inspected in their new kit, piles of baggage and kit lying about and lines upon lines of horses.

August 7th
The news today is that the Germans are within the forts of Liege, how terrible it is. I heard from H last night, they are full of alarms and excursions, wild rumours and constant wires but how thankful I am that my beloved is not to leave the country, so far at least, for it will indeed be awful when they are all gone. Nearer and nearer the dread day approaches. Blanche Gray writes the Major goes this day week but I have not heard any definite dates for any of our troops here yet. I have filled my day with trivial tasks, it is the only way to keep our mind from distraction for if one thinks one can no longer bear it. I am so lucky getting letters from H, so often, so much luckier than these others will be, poor things.

August 8th, Saturday
