The report of the fall of Liege has been contradicted today and wild rumours arrive instead of wholesale surrender and losses on the German side. An armistice of 24 hours was asked for but the Belgians refused. They have put up a wonderful resistance and it must indeed be a surprise to the Kaiser and his Invincibles, but all sorts of rumours come to hand and one doesn't know what to believe. A very wise move is that there is to be a Government source of news for the Press in future with F.E.Smith at its head in order that all news which comes to hand may be authenticated, a very strict censor on all letters will be in force, and the utmost care that information does not leak through. S.A. has taught us a lot through our hapless mistakes of that time. I went over the way after dinner and she is with me most of the day which is so nice. We can be together.

August 9th, Sunday
Our Service today was one of Intercession, special Psalms, Lessons and Hymns. Mr Douglas preached very well and read a long letter from the Bishop and we ended by singing the National Anthem. It was all very sad but beautiful, the men (soldier men I mean) were conspicuous by their absence alas! all being on duty. Being Sunday no papers of course. I got a Lloyd in the evening but one cannot believe anything these rags say and I must await tomorrow's Times. I heard from my dear man last night, he says his letters soon will probably be read by the censor so I may not hear again for a day or two. ES came with us up to Caesar's Camp after lunch, and all was activity and stir, men exercising everywhere, on the plain, at the ranges etc. so unlike the usual Sunday.

August 10th, Monday
ES took me and all the children down to the Town this morning and we did various shopping and business. I met various people down there including the Horns who I hadn't seen for ages and who are up from Southampton for the day, she being down there with him awaiting embarkation orders. I went this afternoon to a little Intercession Service at the Chapel, very short, simple and pathetic, and the congregation was made up mainly of wives and mothers.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 11th - 17th

Dramatic departure of the British Expeditionary Force, "almost like a phantom army". Wynne's nights interrupted by the continuous rumble of troop trains.
viewer_6.description:
August 11th
I was overjoyed today when Col. Sandilands and David turned up to tea and to say Au Revoir. How odd it looked both being in uniform as everyone always is now. Not a man has worn mufti since mobilization. The days pass somehow and one lives for the papers, each one containing more and more horrors.

August 12th, Wednesday
I should think the grouse are the only things that benefit by the War, for many a one will keep its life this year, men are shooting each other instead. What news we get, and very little is authentic, brings more and more tidings of Belgium success. On the other hand in Berlin they are all rejoicing at German triumphs and say that Liege has fallen. Mother and Aim came down today in the Ure's car and Clark who followed with the luggage had nearly a 2 hour journey, twelve in a 1st class. Aim has rooms at Mrs Pharos and will come up here for tea and any other meal I can claw her in for. Its very cheery and nice all being together but is anything really cheery these days. One drags on with a hopeless and nameless dread, that's the truth.


August 13th
England declares war with Austria
One thing has brightened up and that is the weather which for the last two days has been brilliant and hot. This is what the papers say today, German and French troops are about to engage in one of the biggest battles ever fought. Yet the poor Belgiums (sic) are fighting like fanatics, some think the Kaiser has bitten off more than he can chew this time but I fear the wish is father to the thought. Our troops are on the move, nightly and hourly indeed, they are melting away into the evigkeit. The utmost secrecy is observed as to dates and ports and it is almost like a phantom army, it moves away so quietly. Oh! the horror of it all, was there ever such a time. This evening all along the high road we actually heard them marching, it sounded weird when one realized their errand.


August 14th, Friday
Last night when I went to bed I leant out of the window, the night was still and warm, an old tired-looking moon hung low in the sky and from the distance came the sound of continuous movement of troops and the trains carrying away their precious freight and I was filled with a sense of the tragedy of it all, the second time within recent years that England has sent her best from the country. This war seems worse somehow than S.A. but thank God one has complete confidence in the steadyness and fitness of our troops and their wonderful organization. I spent the afternoon in Aldershot with the Skippys, everything seems to have an air of finality, in camp all is ready, many have gone and the 11th Co. R.E. with Skippy leave tomorow morning at 9.30 from the Government Siding.

August 15th
I have seldom known a worse beginning to any day. I got up at 5.30 and an hour later went over to see Skippy off because I felt perhaps it was less desolate for her than to be alone. The rain comes down in torrents and it is grey and cold. What can one say or feel at such a time. No one can describe the sense of loss that hangs over us all. I feel so thankful that the Good God has spared me this for though my man is away and so far away its not like this horror.

August 16th, Sunday
To Kirk with ES and Aim and to sleep "the rest of the day", an unutterable feeling of deathly staleness is over one. The troop trains keep running all day and night and all is vanishing in a sort of silent mystery. ES and Capt. Master and Aim came to supper which was cheery and nice. It is good to congregate at these times.

August 17th
No fresh news this morning at the Front. News at any time is naturally very scarce and as so few Press Correspondents are allowed there one can place very little credence on what one does read. The French and Germans have had their first encounters and it is believed their huge armies will soon be in more general touch. Our force has left in a most dramatic way to my way of thinking, the whole thing has melted away into the unknown, even at the hour of embarkation not a man knew his destination, and not a paper has so much as mentioned the fact that one single soldier has left for the Front. How different from the times of the S.A. when an army of the Press rushed out, hosts of useless women and endless mistakes were the order of the day. We have learnt something from that anyhow.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
August 18th - 24th

The Expeditionary Force lands safely in France, but the German Army is advancing relentlessly. To a service wife, the realities of war are very clear to Wynne from the outset.
viewer_8.description:
August 18th
The splendid news of the safe arrival of the Expeditionary Force was published in the papers this morning. All got over safely without let or hindrance so that anxiety anyhow is over, but great sorrow will be felt at the news of the death of Gen. Grierson, who it is simply stated died of "heart failure whilst travelling in a train", so one cannot know on which side of the Channel it occurred. Poor fellow, what a sad thing for his people. ES and I went to a meeting Mrs Bacon has got up for work and we have decided the result will go partly to a hospital and partly to officers' wives and families fund. There is sure to be distress in that class and it is very little thought about. We dined with ES tonight and had meat a great treat! in these famine days.

August 19th
I think these two letters from the King and Lord K are so inspiring I must put them in here. Day by day War news gets more and more thrilling and our men are so much in our thoughts. I cannot understand the German tactics, though from all accounts (which may be lies) they are most brutal, burning villages, killing all the people and utterly destroying all - it seems most dreadful in the 20th century.

August 20th
The Germans are nearing Brussels, poor people how panic stricken they must be, crowds of refugees come pouring in whilst hundreds are leaving for Ghent and Ostend etc. it is no use, the hoards will over run all sooner or later.

August 21st, Friday
Universal Day of Intercession
Every day is filled with the thoughts of our precious handful of men over the Channel and one wonders indeed what is happening to them for no news filters through. So far the Belgiums and French have had it all their own way but it is nothing these losses to the German hoards. The Mad Dog doesn't care how many are sacrificed but I think the delay they have been caused will put them out somewhat.

August 22nd
The Germans have entered Brussels and a huge tax has been levied upon the city also upon the province and town of Liege, this article from tonight's Globe is not flattering, how a German's blood must boil to read such a thing. Went down into Farnham with ES and then on to the Bacons to discuss work. Layettes for officers' wives is our job. (Layette: clothes etc for a newborn child).

August 23rd, Sunday
Luckily we got a Sunday Times today, a great joy, and I've read it from start to finish. The latest is that Japan is about to declare war with Germany as no reply has been given to their Ultimatum. Meanwhile the Russian hoard creeps on and Austria has had another warship sunk in the Adriatic and a severe defeat by the Servians at Nish. German troops are expected at Ghent and Bruges and Ostend are said to be in panic. The Belgium Government have withdrawn to Antwerp which is strongly fortified and German troops are advancing on Lille. The papers are full of fearful horrors. God grant they are not true. We all went up to Bourley after tea, a perfect evening, and as one strolled along that peaceful spot one could not realize that War is in the very air, it seemed impossible until the fact was forced upon one's mind my the word "halt", and there stood a sentry guarding the water reservoir from would be poisoners. We found some white heather which is a sign of good luck and some is going to the Front.

August 24th
ES and I went down into Farnham this morning to purchase the materials for our baby linen which we are making the officers' families fund. At 4.0 I took the children to the Intercession Service, poor pathetic congregation of wives and mothers and relatives, and such a long list of men were read out.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The Army leaders who were to dominate the first year of the war: Kitchener, Sir John French and Roberts at the top, Haig, Hamilton and Smith Dorrien at the bottom...the family were closest to Roberts, who was an old friend, but they knew Smith Dorrien well too, and their respective children sometimes played together, much to the Jackson children's displeasure!

Wynne added another picture to her diary later, stuck into the August 26th page. This was one of a series of paintings by Wollen, commemorating heroic moments from the very first days of the war...this one pictures the 37th RFA battery being saved on August 24th.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
August 25th - 31st

The fateful telegram arrives - the first of many. Wynne's husband Herbert is ordered abroad - he is to command the Royal Artillery 7th Division.
viewer_10.description:
August 25th, Tuesday
Every day at 12 throughout the length and breadth of the land the Church bell is rung for a few times, this by order of Canterbury so that all at this particular time may turn their thoughts to our troops and ask God's protection for them, a very lovely idea I think. We hear this morning to our consternation of the fall of Namur, a fortress which was expected to stand for at least 3 months and no once can understand it. The Great Battle is pending and our troops are fighting at Mons. At the moment success has been to the Germans and the Allies have fallen back on their fortified positions, but our troops are holding their own. Heavy casualties are reported on all sides and we dread tomorrow's paper.

August 26th
Such a wet day, rain almost incessant all day but I didn't care at all and spent the day doing many odd jobs and chores and got at the back of many letters.


August 27th
Here is a sample of what a p.c. looks like when it arrives. Personally I've heard from no one at the Front or Sea but this came to Mother and its rather interesting, the stamps from sea always look like this. I went down with Mrs Bacon to Farnham to choose the stuffs for the work guild, then after lunch the round again of my Offs to find out various things for the committee, then we all went to tea with Aim and Bill and ES came to dine with us off a lovely salmon sent by H!

August 28th
I spent the morning down at the church room. We sat there till about 12 going into various cases and meteing out assistance of sorts, most of the women with the exception of one are most grateful for the help afforded them.

August 29th
This afternoon whilst lying in the hammock Hetty brought me a wire, what fateful things telegrams can be. It was from H, said "Cromarty - am leaving here Monday ordered abroad if I cannot come home will wire you to meet me in Town", and then went on about some business. So it has come and I in common with so many others have this horror to face.

August 30th
My thoughts all day long are with my man and I cant help wondering why he has been sent for and who he is going to replace. I am so longing to see him and do trust he will be able to get down. We went to Kirk all of us today and I stayed on to second service. War news continues to be most dreadfully anxious but we hear today that Germany is removing one while Army Corps from the Front to return and face the Russian advance which is surely and steadily creeping on. The victory of our first real naval engagement came to hand last night. I insert an outline of it, also a short account of the destruction of Louvain. What barbarism and what mean tactics, one might be dealing with uncivilized hoards like the Huns. We all went for a walk after tea up on to the Common. Bill who has enlisted in the London Scottish leaves tomorrow early for town. (Bill Fallowfield, Wynne's cousin. He did not survive the war.)

August 31st, Monday
My man writes that he has been appointed to command the Royal Artillery 7th Division and he is leaving Cromarty tomorrow . He was to have got away today but Gen. Hunter Blair who succeeds him wasn't able to go there till today. The 7th is not completed yet so it will be some days till they sail. Anyway he will have Wed. here I'm thankful to say. We have the most lovely weather, it seems somehow as if it was sent to help us through this awful time. War news continues to be scarce. We know that the Allies are retreating towards Paris but have nowhere been broken through and it is considered that it is a ruse to draw the German Army on. Our troops are doing most splendidly but we have had between 5 and 6000 casualties.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: A satirical postcard - one of many that appeared very quickly - see next month too....and below it, a double page from the diary containing cuttings and the fateful telegram that told Wynne her husband had been ordered abroad: "Am leaving here Monday ordered abroad if I cannot come home will wire you to meet me in town have wired White for valise etcetera if they cannot supply will you try stores Herbert"

august.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot.

WAR IS DECLARED....

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
For obvious reasons the RA were close to Wynne's heart, so she stuck this into the page for December 1st,

"...conspicuously gallant and daring was the conduct of all ranks then that the officers, non-commissioned officers, and men were invited to elect their own recipients of the four Victoria Crosses awarded. At the recent battle of Mons L Battery showed the same splendid resolve....If anyone gains honour and distinction, all equally feel that it reflects upon the whole family, and all equally glory and rejoice in it. "

(reverse side of article, now partly obscured by stamp paper used to stick it into the diary).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1st - 6th

Wynne visits her son at his Malvern school, but is finding life difficult....
viewer_2.description:
December 1st, Tuesday
Up at screech and caught the 9.24 from North Camp arriving at M (Malvern) at 1.24 where my dear son met me at the station looking very well and jolly. He came and had lunch with me and spent the afternoon till 4 when he had to go back to work and I had tea with the Woods. Then at a quarter to 6 he, de Mornay, and Charsleys senior, Pink's chum, came up to a shop in the town with me and there they regaled themselves on poached eggs and coffee and cakes and at 7 went back.

December 2nd
Today I witnessed the Shakespeare Reading by the boys, they did Merchant of Venice and Pink was Nerissa! They all did it remarkably well and it was most amusing to hear these sprats spit forth Shakespearian oaths! The Watsons are staying at M (Malvern) and were present and asked me to dine at their Hotel, where her Mother also is, a charming old lady.

December 3rd
I left by the 11.18, a slow train and went to Town where I spent the night with Mother. This seems a Diary of bare facts but just at present somehow one doesn't seem in the humour to write Diaries though there is much one could say. Shopped hard all the afternoon and spent a nice quiet evening with Mother. The flat is so pretty, all square now and very charming.

December 4th, Friday
I spent the whole day till 3.30 at the stores, shopping for the men for Mother and for Gran. It is a strenuous time and there is no peace within or without. I left for home by an evening train and got back at about 8 to find all well. It is nice to be home again, these journeys these days are a bore - everything is rather a bore!

December 5th
I found this poem on the Boer War in some old papers, it is curiously suitable to this war but what is still more interesting is the reading on the back of it, evidently a description of transports starting at that time. What a contrast to this time, when every thing was done in secrecy and no one was allowed to know anything, much less be present. The other cutting too is most interesting, a study in contrasts indeed. Tom Jackson is here today spending the week and so nice to have him. I am hearing much family news.

December 6th, Sunday
Church in the morning and a wrastle over accounts with Tom in the afternoon. He is so good and helpful over money matters in Herbert's absence and I find it a great help.

They say that "war is hell", the "great accursed",
The sin impossible to be forgiven -
Yet I can look beyond it at its worst,
And still find blue in Heaven.

But below is the back of the poem - which interested Wynne more than those rather poor verses...

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 7th - 13th

Colds at home, success at sea, and the South African revolt is crushed.
viewer_4.description:
December 6th, Monday to December 12th, Saturday
This has been a week of colds and chores, Nootie in bed 3 days with a cough and now Baby is following suit. One expects this sort of thing in winter but it is rather a bore. I've heard twice from my Beloved today, and twice during the week, he is very well and all are having an easier time thank God. We have scored a great Naval success and wiped out the loss of the Good Hope and Monmouth as Admiral Sturdee has sunk the 4 German Cruisers who effected this loss and only the Dresden is to be accounted for now. Also this week comes news of the death of Beyers so that with Maritz and Kemp wounded and flown to the German territory, and de Wet captured the rebellion pro tem is ended. What history there is in that piece of tragedy. I think Beyers a particularly interesting character.

General Beyers had been a Boer commander, and he favoured passive resistance when the war started, but was overruled by De Wet. Beyers resigned his commission in the army when the government decided to invade South West Africa. He led the resistance in the Transvaal, but the rebel co-ordination was poor and the government was able to extinguish the revolt. Beyers drowned in the Vaal River during the uprising, and was considered a martyr.

If you are interested in exploring this further, here is a site to check out as a starter - it offers a good summary of the story Wynne mentions:
<http://www.rapidttp.co.za/milhist/2/c02marne.html>
and check out the October mention of this too.

Here is the Afrikaans version of Tipperary, one of the most famous World War One songs:
Dit is ver weg na Tippererie,
Dit is ver om te gaan;
Dit is ver weg na Tippererie,
Om my hart se punt te zien. 
Goen dag, Pikadillie
Vaarwel, Lester-squeer;
Dit is ver, ver weg na Tippererie
Maar my hart le net daar.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The first part of the newspaper account of the German raid, and below, the extraordinarily detailed list of casualties and locations - everything minutely noted, something that would soon cease alas as raids on non-combattants became acceptable...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 14th - 19th

Scarborough, Hartlepool and Whitby are bombarded from the sea with great loss of life...and another friend is killed in France.
viewer_6.description:
December 14th, Sunday
The Queen has sent out to every man in the ranks a body belt and this notice with it. H sent it to me for my Diary, what tons of things the men are getting, H has requested no more clothes at present as the men are now being supplied by the Govt. as well as privately so I send eatables instead.

December 19th, Saturday
BOMBARDMENT OF EAST COAST
Another week has gone. I can't write a Diary this present time although there is so much I could write about. Wild things have been happening to this country this week. The long expected has happened and on Wednesday December 16th the Germans raided the East Coast and bombarded Scarborough, Hartlepool and Whitby and in the mist got away. The death roll is very heavy and the destruction of property enormous. Of course this sort of thing was only to be expected but it's rather horrible to think that over 100 people were killed and many more wounded. (See previous page view for the full list of casualties and the detailed way they were noted down)
I've been away staying with Brenda this week and whilst there got a letter from H saying all leave is stopped so he cannot be with us for Xmas as he had vaguely hoped. I am so very sad. I did so hope to have him but the Good God will bring him in his own good time and I must just be decent about it, inwardly as well as outwardly. At present all is well with him and Oh! how thankful I am for his health and safety, for our dear neighbours the Bacons have now lost their eldest son Basil in the Worcesters. He was killed on Tuesday and it only seems yesterday that I said goodbye to him on the doorstep here. Poor chap and poor old people.

(Basil Kenrick Wing Bacon was a Major in the Worcesters. He was 42. He has no known grave and is commemorated on panel 17 and 18 of the Le Touret Memorial. His father and mother were Capt K.V.Bacon J.P. and Mrs Bacon of Hale, Farnham, Surrey. Wynne was a great friend, and had attended their 52nd Wedding anniversary on October 30th which you can read on that date)

I picked Pink up in town on my way back home, looking very well and jolly. Win is back too but staying with Mother till the 23 when they are both motoring down in the Skippy motor. History has been made this week by the Turkish Power being kicked out of Egypt and Britain taking it over, a big move and with the consent of France. The papers are full of interest now and one really cannot read enough. My dear old Gran has been very poorly the last few days and so I sent for Tanner tonight and he says her pulse is very feeble tonight and he is coming to see her tomorrow morning. My dear kids are a great joy to me, laughing and playing all day long and always in good humour. A great help in these troublous times.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Part of a long article stuck in - the 7th Division was her husband's...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 20th - 27th

Wynne celebrates the achievements of the 7th Division and tries to put a brave face onto Christmas.
viewer_8.description:
December 20th, Sunday, to December 27th, Sunday
This most interesting account of the work of the 7th Division is a great piece of reading and I feel proud that my man belongs to it. Poor 7th, what times it has had and what desperate losses. I am writing my Diary a week at a time now partly because I have so little room left and partly because I simply dont feel inspired, goodness knows there's enough to write about and when this beastly War began I tried to follow it in this but it's too big a job and I couldn't keep it up. Mother and Win came down on the 23rd in the kind Skippy's motor. Our Xmas went off outwardly as usual. I made no difference for the children's sake but it was a sickening feeling for me and I was thankful when it was over, how could one rejoice and sing Peace on Earth etc. when there is nothing but strife and ill will throughout so many lands and so many are in mourning. However the children and servants enjoyed the usual festivities and the dear Skippys came to dinner to which all the children sat up. I thought much of my dear thing for this is the first Xmas we have been absent one from another. Better times will come doubtless but meanwhile its hard to be brave. I sent no cards this year and got very few. One did not miss them and really to go wishing people A Merry Xmas seemed absurd. We are all well which is the great thing and so is my man.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: An interesting article - already, but December , the Sapper triumphs over the Cavalry....

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
December 28th - 30th

Herbert gets leave from the Front and brings news of the extraordinary Christmas truce experienced by many of the men in the trenches.
viewer_10.description:
December 28th, Monday to December 31st, Thursday
Much has happened these 4 days. Monday and Tuesday were spent in answering letters and sending parcels to my men and on Wed 30th as I was sitting writing a letter to Mabel I suddenly got this wire from H, it was then 4.15 and at 5.0 he arrived!! The whole house suddenly went mad! We all rushed about getting his room ready which was full of soldiers' clothes and at 5.0 there he actually was. What I felt I simply cannot describe, I've certainly never been so glad to see anyone before, and he is looking so well. It is a joy, such a ripping treat to have him back and we just sat and talked and talked till all hours, there was so much to hear and tell. He has brought home 3 cartridge, a French, English and German, also two neat little Pom Pom shells from his aircraft gun which being useless has gone back to store! Another trophy was a box of matches bought at Ypres! Here also is the King and Queen's Xmas card to the troops, also those of the Rawlinsons to the 7th and 8th Division and one from a Flying Corps to H, all interesting mementos of these times. H has much to tell and its all so awfully interesting to hear it first hand. he tells us that Xmas Day was spent on their line in complete peace. There was an early service in a little house to which a lot of them went, and during the morning an officer mending a telegraph wire called out a Happy Xmas to a German he happened to see, who immediately came out of his trench followed by all the others and our men and they fraternised and hobnobbed all day long having lit up their trenches with lights and Xmas trees in some places. this peace with them was kept up all next day and then of course it all began again, how weird it seems that one day they should shake hands and exchange comforts and the next day shoot as many of each other as possible. There seems so little personal feeling against each other.

December 31st
On this day the last of the year the whole family went to Town and actually did 2 Pantomimes in one day. The kind Duke sent Mother a whole heap of boxes and we had a large party for Drury Lane. It was a splendid show as usual, Sleeping Beauty for the 3rd time but just as amusing. Then Mother took Baby home whilst we and the Elliots went on to the Waldorf Hotel for food and then the Aldwych for Cinderella, getting home at 11.30. Our sleepy children were asleep at once and we just sat the Old Year out, this year which will never be forgotten and as the bells and hooters rang in the new, one was glad to think 1914 was dead though we've had good times in it nevertheless and much has happened.
Goodbye.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
For more about Christmases in the diary, check out the special section.
The card from the King and Queen mentioned is shown in the last window of this section.

december.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She manages her daily chores, but is finding diary writing increasingly difficult

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The programme for the production of Parsifal that Wynne saw on February 10th

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 6th

A week of duties, lovely weather, and the making of a "Spring Pie".
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Sunday
Why seaweed and fishes as a heading for February, mad, and nothing to do with the case. A nice warm and springlike day and the birds are feeling the spring in their bones. The news of Bill today (Herbert's brother, William) is that he has had a fair night and is as well as can be expected. We wired to the hospital at Malling where he is. H took the children out for a long walk after lunch and I lay down on a sofa with a book and just slept! Mother writes asking me to go to Parsifal on Thursday, a delightful prospect and I am looking forward to it.

February 2nd
The day today is like a perfect spring day, brilliant sunshine and that fresh clean look about the world, I bicycled down to the Town for my lesson and spent the afternoon stuffily having a Mothers Meeting.

Feb 3rd
This morning I spent round my district and quite enjoyed the walk because the day was so absolutely lovely.

Feb 4th
The glory of this sudden Spring goes on, each day is more brilliant than the last, the wind is gentle and warm and I just go and dig in the garden because I must, not because there is any good to be got from it. I have made a Spring Pie and despite the very hard frosts we had recently I find aubretia, rosemary, jasmine, primrose and polyanthus, snowdrops, crocus, double daisy and a rose! (Spring Pie's were a favourite of Wynne's, and consisted of a moss-covered bowl full of earth into which you stuck every flower you could find).
I went to read at the Home today because I thought I shouldn't be able to on Friday on account of the Opera but Mother writes she made mistake and it is Tues 10th.

Feb 5th
To shirts in the morning and a great doing, got rid of £26 odd and didn't get away till 12.30 but I'm thankful that plenty of ladies were present otherwise we should have been there still! Poggy arose at 6.30 today and went off inspecting to Farnham, not getting home till 6.30 this evening. Gradually his leave draws nearer and Monday will see him for the last time in uniform, alas and alack I cant realize it.

Feb 6th, Friday
A free day and still lovely so I dug in the garden, cleaned out Sir Thomas Tit's summer residence which I found full of maggots, most undesirable, and the children played with their cart all the afternoon. Only 5 weeks today to my dear Gran's birthday, we watch her so anxiously day by day.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Some of the set designs for the production of Parsifal...The Flowery Mead, Klingsor's Castle, and the interior of the Temple of the Knights of the Grail.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 7th - 11th

Birthdays, letters from old flames, and the excitement of seeing Wagner's Parsifal - the first time the opera was performed in England.
viewer_4.description:
February 7th, Saturday
Six year ago today the stork brought me my Baby and I simply can't imagine where the time has gone to, here she is a tall thin creature very sweet with heaps of lovely auburn curls and deep brown eyes, very like a robin in general appearance. Young calls her "my little cock sparrer" much to her disgust. We had presents in the drawing room: a tea set, dolls house furniture, a boat, 2 half crowns and a box of chocolates. Also a lovely yellow shawl Nootle had crocheted for "Fanny", this was the creme de la creme and Noots' first piece of crochet, a great treasure! (Fanny was Babs' doll).
Nice letters from Eve and Charles - how nice it is to have "found" him again. (For Charles, see Love)

Feb 8th
The usual quiet day. Church in the morning and sleep in the afternoon!

Feb 9th
Not so this day, Mondays are always busy and this one was exceptionally so. At 10.0 I was at my German lesson, at 12.0 the Nursing Committee was held at the Church Room and then back for a quick lunch and off again up there for Mothers Meeting, after tea I went in for a while to see the dear Skippys who have returned from their travels. It's lovely to see them again and after dinner we repaired once more to the Church House where the H.P.A. met and discussed with many words and much heated controversy its usual difficulties and trouble until 10.30 and I felt by the end of the day I had had enough.


Feb 10th
A day to be remembered, a gala day! To Town by the 11.0 and to Parsifal this evening! We got out at Vauxhall and to my consternation I found my box hadn't been put out! We waited there half an hour, telephoning, to no avail, so I went to the flat and H on to Waterloo, no box - they then wired to every station we had stopped at and drew blank. He then returned and as at 3.30 no sign of it was forthcoming we went off to Peter Jones, I to buy a "reach me down" and he a shirt for all his were in my box. I was just paying for it and he had bought his shirt when we got a phone message from Mother to say the box had arrived! so P.J. let me off my purchase and we hurriedly returned. I believe they had it at Waterloo all the time, it wasn't locked and had all my jewelry in it. Hastily dressing we hurried after Mother and BG for the performance began at 5.0, and arrived there at about 5.30 finding Aim, Col. Sandilands and Onslow Ford assembled. It lasted from 5.0 until 11.30 and seemed all too short, at 7.0 we had a break of an hour and a half and the whole house turned out for dinner whilst we had ours comfortably in the drawing room at the back of the box. Sandwiches and cakes of all sorts, champagne and whiskey and soda! Then at 10.0 there was another break of half an hour. The music and the scenery were both absolutely perfect - Bodanzky conducted and his orchestra did indeed do him credit. The scenery by Harker took a year to paint and the panorama is said to be an eighth of a mile long. It was all beautiful, sublime and grand and I shall never forget it.

Feb 11th
I am almost ashamed to confess that last night after the most solemn performance of Parsifal Col. Sandilands took H and me off to the Automobile Club where we had an excellent supper and from the sublime to the ridiculous we witnessed the latest thing in tangos! The very latest! also other dancing and singing with which it is customary to amuse restaurant guests now-a-days whilst they languidly refresh themselves after a strenuous evening at the Theatre or Music Hall. We did a good deal of shopping today and Thurie came to lunch whilst Col Daniels and the Fultons looked in for tea, the latter are just home from a trip abroad. We went out afterwards to a very good show at the Chelsea Palace. We amused ourselves very well there and there were some extremely clever turns, H laughing till he cried! He always does!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Parsifal costume designs..

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 12th - 17th

Wynne's London visit ends with a concert, then its back to Aldershot duties...and her garden.
viewer_6.description:
Feb 12th, Thursday
Mother has hired a brougham for a week so she and I went off shopping the whole morning, after lunch I went and picked up Gertie Maclean who lives near and took her to a Beethoven and Wagner concert for which I had been given seats by O(nslow) Ford and where we heard Kirkby Lunn sing and Landon Ronalds orchestra play many divine things, the last being Tannhauser's overture. It was perfect, quite lovely and I enjoyed it tremendously. We then went back and had tea with her, she is living with a lady in Glebe Place situated in a queer old part of Chelsea and there at the corner stands a funny little cottage which was formerly Henry Vlll's shooting box and where it is said he used to meet Anne Boleyn! (If you would like to hear Louise Kirkby Lunn, click on her name and when the site opens, you will find at the top of the page an audio icon. It is a recording of "Have you news of my boy Jack?", Kipling's poem about the loss of his son John at the battle of Loos in 1915).


Feb 13th
The time flies so fast up here and alas the day has come to return, it has been a very nice little bust and I've much appreciated the "rest" and change. I came down in the morning because I had the Home to read at and H followed by an evening train.


Feb 14th
St Vals. Day, Mary's birthday and the birds wedding day. Sir Thomas Tit and his wife will soon be occupying the villa. (A reference to the bird box in the garden).
On Wednesday last Baby began lessons - her days of absolute freedom are over! poor mite, but she only has a half hour and thoroughly enjoys it. We spent the afternoon gardening, cutting away at old bushes and clearing out dead wood. The Spring is waking up and Oh! how I long to garden all day and every day!


Feb 15th, Sunday
Long letters and good news of our two in India: Eve very thrilled at the thought of going to the Louis' jungle tiger shoot. I am so glad she is going and I envy her frightfully, it will be ripping. Ell in the midst of the M.pore meet, he and Mr Campbell both going strong and all seems well with them. Oh! how I wish myself out there, perhaps if I go on wishing hard enough it may one day come.


Feb 16th
The account of Monday's doings can never be exciting - I have my German and I have my Mothers Meeting, all and every Monday and c'est tout.


Feb 17th
A perfect day! We are having a lovely Feb as is often the case, I had a long afternoon gardening and cleaned and remade "Pinkie's Path", also cleaned out Sir Thomas Tit's house and various other jobs, the garden is full of crocus and in the house we have jonquils, narcissus, primula, obconica, azaeleas, hyacinths and tulips, most of the fibre grown bulbs have been a great success and the room smells sweet.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The Chelsea Palace programme

I love the Special notice at the top, which is hard to read here, so I transcribe it: "At commencement of each performance Novel and Interesting Pictures will be shown by World's Advertising Co, 11, Old Jewry Chambers, EC."

No escaping the modern world now!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 18th - 24th

A quiet week. They meet the Percivals who are scheduled to take over the command when Herbert retires.
viewer_8.description:
February 18th, Wednesday
Another lovely day, and my old Gran seems to thrive in this weather. Mr Douglas came and gave us a little service this morning which she much appreciated. I gardened again this afternoon. It just felt good to be alive.

Feb 19th
Such a strenuous morning at Shirts, many people being away only 5 ladies turned up and there we were. Miss C and I and these five coping with nearly a 1000 shirts. She and I got through 200 besides all the paying and signing and actually got away by 12.15.! the fluff of grey backs covering us like rabbits!

Feb 20th
We dined last night at the Bacons, dear friendly people and she let me nay asked me if I would smoke in the drawing room. I call that true charity. I went and read at the Home as usual, poor little girls all so crippled and yet all so cheerful.

Feb 21st
A free day, Oh! joy and spent in doing many home jobs. Long letters from the dear things in India, Ell had a fall over a jump and broke one of his ribs which incapacitated him from tennis and polo during the M.pore Meet which was sickening. Eve didn't go down but they are both going to the Louis' tiger shoot which is a joy to her. We lunched today with the Percivals, our successors - it seems to bring it horribly close to feel they are actually in the neighbourhood.

Feb 22nd, Sunday
Not feeling quite up to the mark I did not go to Church today but stayed at home and took it easy. Maggie (the children's Nanny) is away for the week end at her home so I am doing Nurse tonight.

Feb 23rd
Letter this morning from various and sundry including one from Hamster (Wynne's Uncle Walter, who lived in Germany) who says he is coming over on or about the 7th and goes first to Mother. I feel thankful he is really coming, dear Gran is fretting for him and I do hope nothing will prevent his arrival. German lesson and Mothers Meeting as usual. A day of torrents at intervals and hail storms.

Feb 24th
I spent my morning making a table centre for Eve and sent it off, and after lunch I went off on a round of jobs, to post office, the de Mornays there to see Mrs Pearce and on to leave my MM money at Mr Galsworthy. It has been a lovely day, a joy to be out and I think on the whole February has quite done its duty, barring a few fearful storms.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
February 25th - 28th

Back to London for another theatre, a treat from their old friends the Grays. Then it's time to entertain their successors at Aldershot.
viewer_10.description:
February 25th, Wednesday
Here is Ash Wednesday and Lent once more. We went down to service in the morning and it started and ended by being a lovely day but in the middle of the day grew so bitterly cold. Gran is making me nervous tonight, she has just had one of her little attacks of speechlessness and it always frighten me. It would be so sad if anything were to happen just now.

Feb 26th
Poggy and I went to Town today just for the night to meet the Grays who had asked Mother and us to dine and go to a theatre with them...at 7.0 (they) sent their car for us and we dined with them at the Hyde Park and went on to the Marriage of Kitty, a revival and as amusing as ever. It was very lovely seeing them again. (The programme is in the next window)

Feb 27th
I had to get back by lunch time today as I had my reading at the Home to do, so very loathe to return home I arrived at 1.0. this evening we had people to dinner. The Percivals, our successors, the Crees and the Halls. Mrs Hall has a most unfortunate appearance, she is very stout with a high colour and dresses in very brilliant garments and reminds me in face rather of old Mrs Cox the furniture shop woman in Aldershot! Gran is a bit better today but very feeble and tired. We are keeping her as quiet as possible.

Feb 28th, Saturday.
The last day of Feb, it has been a very good one on the whole. We've had some lovely days but I am always glad when its over. Miss Chisham and Capt. Barnes came to tea, the former is trying but poor girl I am so sorry for her, she has a dull life and no prospects on earth.

february.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband is commanding the Artillery.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The little grey card is from the Duke of Bedford, enclosing the tickets for his box at Drury Lane. The pantomime was the Sleeping Beauty. The programme is below - note the complex scenes, each with credit for their creators...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 5th

The Pantomime, a visit to Peter Pan and other excitements in London are finally replaced by a return to the onerous duties of home.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Thursday


I always feel as if the first day's entry of the New Year should have something of importance written upon it, and today we did indeed begin with a great festivity. Mother, who has been spending Xmas with us, took the 3 elder children up to Town yesterday and we followed with Baby this morning and the whole lot of us went to the Pantomime (to) the box which the kind Duke sent us, alas! now that he has sold it all shall we ever get it again! (The Duke of Bedford, who owned a large part of London including the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, was a friend of Wynne's Mother, and used to send them tickets for the above named theatre, where he had his own box. He had recently sold up much of his property).
It was a lovely show and we all enjoyed it enormously, such lovely scenery and dresses and Graves and Evans were as funny as ever.


January 2nd
The children's long wished for treat actually came to pass today, for we took them to see "Peter Pan", this play which is now become an established thing every year, this is its 10th and its almost a classic! We went off shopping in the morning to Hamptons Sale to the sixpenny halfpenny shop for the things for my Mothers' Tea and then dashed home making a hasty lunch and off again to the Duke of Yorks where Poggy had got a box. When he took it boxes and stalls were the only things left and people were already booking seats for next year! It is a charming performance and the children just loved it all knowing the story so well as they do.

January 3rd
After a mornings shopping and a visit with Pink to the dentist we had lunch and returned home by the 3.5, a tired and dissipated party, but it has been great fun and a jolly 2 days. I found Gran very well on our return but so hazy and so wool gathering, full of conversations which was just all wandering poor old dear. Very jolly letters from Eve and Ell and the former is going down to Seryah to settle Ell in to his new abode shortly. How I wish I could be there too.


January 4th, Sunday
All the church this morning except my Noots who is rather headachy and seedy, and after lunch I just wrote letters hard till dinner, getting 16 off my hands. There is always such an accumulation after Xmas and I have so many foreign ones now it seems. We are having it very cold, 11 and 12 degrees of frost, but I care not these days as I no longer feel the cold like formerly.

January 5th
Such a strenuous day! Off to German lesson at quarter to 10 taking Win with me to have her hair washed, great change in the weather, and torrents of rain. Back we rushed at 11.15 and up to the church House to prepare for my Womens Tea this afternoon, found that all the crockery had been seized upon and taken over to Heath End, great consternation but I soon clawed it back again and by 1.0 all was ready . At 2.15 I went up for an hour and took their payments and tea tickets and then we set to and fed them, Win coming up and proving most useful in looking after the children. After tea we played various games and each woman received a present chaste and rare and at 6.0 we broke up. It was a great success but I can't help feeling glad that it is over for it is rather a strenuous job!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Peter Pan programme for the 1913- season...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 6th - 12th

Winter colds and flu, the Sergeants' Dance and other events. Lady Haig helps out at Shirts...
viewer_4.description:
January 6th, Tuesday
In this picture given to me by Mother we have indeed the truth. I think the first picture must be the Hamster (Wynne's German Uncle Walter), and I think the second is Herbert! I spent 2 hours in my district this morning leaving Calendars and Magazines and having a chat at each house. Oh! how puffed up with self righteousness I feel!

January 7th
A lovely day and a free one. I haven't had a free day for weeks and weeks and Oh! how one appreciates the prospect of several hours all our own to do ones own jobs in. I made up accounts, paid bills, wrote letters and generally squared up and now I feel so tidy!

January 8th
At Shirts once more, I've had quite a long holiday thanks to Lady Haig who very often seems to attend and apparently enjoys it! Shopped a little and got back at 1.30 and all the afternoon I've written letters and done more accounts...the children are playing at Witches and Torturers, it sounds most bloodthirsty and Nootle is sliding down stairs on her face having escaped from the "sworn tormentor". (Probably her brother!)


January 9th
We went this night to the R.A. Sergeants Dance. On arrival at the Gym we were met by Mr (Sergt. Major) How, H's head clerk. I went and left my cloak and then emerged to be introduced to various and sundry, the room looked splendid with flags and bunting, the floor was excellent and some of the Gunner Band played. I danced with the M.C. (Master of Ceremonies) a waltz. I then pranced round in some other queer dances and finally taking the floor in the Artillery Quadrilles, a very lengthy affair. The ladies costumes were rich silk, satin sequins and décolleté! altogether a very amusing entertainment!

January 10th
Feeling thoroughly vile with a chest like a board I actually stayed the whole day in bed and enjoyed myself thoroughly. I wrote much and read more, my book being "The Judgement of the the Sword" by Diver, an account of the First Afghan War. I've seldom been so engrossed.

January 11th
I lazed in bed till 12 and am all right again, instead I have Nootle and Baby down now, colds and coughs poor wretches, and last night my Noot had violent earache and didn't get to sleep till 11.0.

January 12th
My little son is 11 today, bless him. At 10.15 I hied me to Farnham for my German lesson and some shopping, then up to the church House for a Nursing committee, back to lunch, back again to the CH (Church Hall) for Mothers Meeting and finally had a party here for Pink's birthday so that by dinner time I had had about enough! The cold is intense and we all continue to bark but its no wonder considering the changes of temp: we had 11 degrees this morning and more yesterday and on Sat. it was like Spring. I hate this cold when there is no possibility of skating for there is no water near enough.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The cartoon Wynne refers to on January 6th. You can see her additions to it: "Hamster" is her uncle, and Herbert her husband. Check out the "House of Winds" drawing done by Wynne's mother in January 1912!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 13th - 19th

A letter from Portuguese East Africa underlines the intense cold and darkness of the January weather, which has turned beastly.
viewer_6.description:
January 13th, Tuesday
This day 2 months is dear Gran's birthday and she is so awfully well at present that we are much more hopeful about her. Letters from Mabel today (from Portuguese East Africa), one post a week, no green vegetables, no fruit and very little to eat at all! She does cook besides other things and says before you can make bread you have to sift the weevils and maggots out of the flour, it does sound horrible. The other day a rhino was seen sauntering along the shore under their windows! I've not been out all day because it has really been too icy, it freezes one's very bones.

January 14th
Oh! the darkness of the mornings. When Bessie calls us at 7.15 it might be night and to crawl out of bed is a horrible effort, I simply detest the vile winter, catch me staying in England for Jan, Feb and March if I hadn't got to!
H and I drove out in a wild blizzard this morning in the dog cart. I had to attend SSandA com. Sinott is ill with a very bad poisoned hand and so cannot drive. He goes down to the panel Dr who merely glances at it, says "poultice it - good morning" but it doesn't improve and is very painful and this rotten panel system is a perfect farce.

January 15th
The cold continues intense, and today I saw my Win off at the station today for school and miss her much. This picture is a true one of the English home!! (Wynne here sticks in the Haselden cartoon you can see in the adjacent panel).

January 16th
I spent my morning in writing business letters and various chores and after lunch whilst we were in the midst of moving the furniture in the drawing room who should turn up but Joe whom I hadn't seen for ages, she's been having an awful thin time for long as they have had no servant for ages and she's been doing all the cooking - awful.

January 17th
I went to read at the Home today instead of yesterday (Wynne had forgotten her duties on the 16th).

January 18th, Sunday
All the Church in the morning, its the first time for some Sundays as we have lately all been taking our turn with colds. I spent a peaceful afternoon reading and sleeping, most thoroughly appreciated.

January 19th, Monday
I don't think I ever felt colder than I did this morning when bicycling to Farnham for my German lesson. The wind went right through one and I really felt quite sick with it. At my Mothers' Meeting 23 turned up despite the weather, one bringing a baby of 4 weeks old! I went back to tea most thankfully that the days chores were done.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 20th - 24th

The General and his wife leave Aldershot, and Wynne is involved with farewell dinners and much ceremony at the railway station.
viewer_8.description:
January 20th, Tuesday.
Perhaps if one could be a dormouse this weather might be bearable but under existing circumstances its not, every morning the usual candle light of this season lights us to bathe and dress, my bones rattle in the N.E. Wind and my blood is as ice in my veins.

If only I could get someone to allow me to creep into their skin I'm sure I should be warmer for I'm certain anybody's skin is less draughty than mine, the wind having chapped it so that it lets air in at every crack. The prospect of turning out in very thin kit tonight to dine with the Lawsons was not alluring owing to the intense cold but I must say we both enjoyed it very much. We were 16 at dinner, the names of some of the nicest I have here on the menu: the Pleydell Bouveries, Lady Wilma's brother and sister, were there, he sat next to me, a most interesting and much travelled man and after dinner a host more people came in and we had some excellent music playing and singing from men and ladies.

January 21st
The black cold frost still continues each day succeeds the last growing just a bit colder every hour, and today I went down to the Winwoods to play Bridge but being too cold to bicycle I walked.

January 22nd
A busy day. H drove me down to Shirts in the morning as although Lady Haig was doing my paying for me I thought an extra hand at passing would not be amiss and was glad I went as we had 100s in and didn't get away until 12.30. A Mothers Union meeting in the afternoon, and Mrs Dundas who addressed it lunched here first, and Mrs Fitz came back to tea to which two new fledglings also turned up. H dined at Bordon so I spent my evening doing German.

January 23rd
The frost reaching 14 degrees this morning I felt that Fleet Pond and skating called me so I got the Skippy's car and went over with the two children. There we dug out the Camerons and actually skated till lunch, it was lovely and such a lovely silver and white world, every leaf and twig glistened in the sun with hoar frost and everything looked dressed in silver. After lunch I read at the Home and walked up to Charman to buy flowers which are scarce and very dear, and on my return home I found Gen. Davis who had walked over to tea, he is a very interesting and nice little man of great ability and an interesting career. To dinner came the Lawsons, Huttons, Majors MacCarthy and Seagram - all new people save the Ls whose last night it was in the command and we were proud they should spend it with us. They go tomorrow and we shall miss them much.

January 24th, Saturday
There has been 16 degrees of frost this morning, the sun shined brilliantly all day and everything looked lovely. The frost flowers this morning on the windows were like huge branches of palms, really wonderful and these things are always a mystery to me. We set off at 2.30 today and went down in the Skippy's car to the station to see the Lawsons off. There we found assembled a host of people also a band of buglers of the Oxfords. The band played on the platform, then the buglers blew the salute and as the train moved off the band played Auld Lang Syne and the Gen. hung out of the window waving his hat till out of sight, it was all rather touching and we shall miss these nice kind people very much. She is a most gracious lady, such charming manners and so good to look at and he so hospitable and genial, their place will be hard to fill. I asked her about Gran's wire from the King on her birthday which she had said she would put through for me and she said she would be sure to remember but she is such a busy lady that I half fear she may forget!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Some fashion plates Wynne put into her diary for this year...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
January 25th - 31st

More colds, but the weather improves. A Cafe Chantant is not a success, and there is worrying family news.
viewer_10.description:
January 25th, Sunday
This day I spent in bed, a cold and general mimsyness. I enjoyed it immensely and look upon it as a great luxury! Thank goodness it is warmer, it is a real blessing and one feels alive again. I have a ripping book to read "I Will Maintain" about William of Orange, it is extremely interesting and very well written and I am sending for "Glen o'Weeping" as that is also about him, both by M. Bowen.

January 26th
I crawled out of bed at about 11.0 feeling very wormish but Mothers Meeting called me this afternoon, 33 present and 13 babies! My cold is in my head and I cried off German this morning. The weather is quite warm and lovely, it has been like Spring all day, the children have been playing in the garden and we had tea by daylight today!!

January 27th
I spent the morning cleaning out the dolls house and wrote letters hard all afternoon. Enclosed is a plan of Seryah (her brother's new home in India) Ell sent me this mail . Eve was down with him, very busy creating changes in the house and settling him into his new home. I envy them both seeing each other and working together, it is such a huge place and apparently needs a lot doing to.


January 29th, Thursday
Thursdays seem to come round very quickly and they are rather marked for me as they often bring Shirts but today is Infantry so I'm off duty. I wrote a long letter to Mabel this morning having had two from her on Tuesday. Their's is a curious existence, so far in the wilds and such weird and odd things happen. I was rather tried this afternoon by a Cafe Chantant to which I had to go by request of Mrs Fitzroy, I went down at 3.15 and sat there till 6.0 listening to various performers of mediocre quality, then I came home, dressed and we set off to dine with the Hakings.

January 30th
We have had most disquieting news of poor Willie (Herbert's brother?), a sudden illness, an operation and the discovery of an internal abcess broken so that they fear complications. We got the wire tonight just before dinner and I was rather glad we had people as perhaps it may have helped to take it off Poggy's mind. To dinner came the Baileys, Davis', and Captain Trench, H's staff Capt. I think he might be very nice but he seems so awfully shy. Our food was fair but the stewed celery came in smoked and looked like a weird and grey mystery!

January 31st, Saturday.
The last day of the first month of 1914, how time flies, I can hardly believe that Jan has already come and gone. I must say I rather rejoice when Jan, Feb and March are no more, the weather is often so dark and gloomy and the cold and the winds so tearing. I got the Skippy's motor today and went over to lunch with the Gordon Geddes who are now stationed at Deepcut. It was very nice to see them again and we talked over old Bulford days and old friends and I then proceeded to go 5 or 6 calls and found them all out so I was in luck and got home to tea to which General McCausland came, a genial old boo-boo.

january.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband is commanding the Artillery.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Views of Rothenburg, Wynne's last stop on her Tyrol journey before she went to spend time with her relations....these scenes are some of the last of a peaceful country before the outbreak of war. The boy below is a closer view of the wide shot in the diary entry for July 2nd. I was intrigued by the vehicle and the contents. What do you suppose they are selling from his cart?

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 4th

Wynne and Herbert arrive at the final destination of their holiday: Schloss Frankenberg, the ancestral home of the Poellnitz family.
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Wednesday
The beautiful month of June is gone for yet another year and now we have intense heat, the whole valley is hazy with it and then mountains look quite misty and indistinct. Feeling that the town would be too hot we took the mountain railway ...but it was just as hot there and we could do nothing but crawl up to a little shade and stay there till it was time to return.

July 2nd Rothenburg

As we didn't leave till about midday we went out and bought various remembrances for our friends and then left the fascinating town of Innsbruck. We had to change at Steinach for R is on a small primitive loop line. The train laboured on its way puffing and panting as though it "had bones in its legs" and the track was covered with grass. At last we came to Rothenburg and having been advised by the porter (fool) at Innsbruck to go to Hotel Wilbad we accordingly did so. We were much annoyed to find it right outside the town down the hill, a great rambling new hotel with only about 2 other people in it besides ourselves. We had quite a nice bedroom with a balcony and a bathroom attached but as the water in the latter was always cold we didn't benefit much and it also was so fearfully brackish the soap wouldn't lather!

July 3rd
Early this morning we packed up our goods and leaving them to be sent to the station started off to explore the town. It is a most wonderful old place, far more interesting to my mind than Nurnberg which now is so over grown. There is not a single modern touch here and anyone wishing to build a house must apply to the authorities and build it in the old style and with materials supplied from the town authorities who place their brick and tiles in the open for months in order to get them weather-stained. Very quaint are the narrow streets, the purely medieval houses of old red brick and half timber walls all leaning together and clinging to one another. Huge walls and towers surround the town with a deep fosse running all round. Window boxes are much in vogue each house a perfect hanging garden of colour, and how fascinating is the old Rathaus built in 1240 and partially burnt down in 1501 when that part was replaced by the Renaissance portion one now sees. We roamed all over it and went into the archives underground and again underneath them the grim sad prisons where it is said their famous Burgermeister Topler was poisoned and thrown there to die by the citizens on account of treason. These prisons reminded me of those in the Tower of London, just square holes really with heavy doors, no light and no means of ventilation even, a grim place but times were rough in those days.
(Wynne then went on to detail some local historical events, before describing catching a train out of the Tyrol and up to Herrnberchtheim, from where a coach and horses awaited them to take them to Frankenberg. They had arranged to stay with their von Poellnitz relations.)
All my life I had longed to go to this house of my ancestors, about which one had heard so much, but as we drove up the steep hill leading to the castle and into the courtyard we both felt much embarrassed and frightened for we had never met them both and had so little German!!

July 4th, Saturday. Frankenberg.
My entry of yesterday having already exceeded its limit by far, I felt I must leave off to begin another day! Well it was about 4.0 when we arrived yesterday and were met by Theodor and Annie Poellnitz, the first greetings over we were shown our room which is an octagonal one in the left hand tower with a sitting room attached, the walls of the castle are an enormous thickness, room enough to sit and write in them, the floors are all parquet in pattern and the walls panelled. Everywhere is lovely old furniture, books, china curiousities and from the walls looks down the portraits of many ancestors, an ugly lot for the most part! We then had tea and afterwards took a walk all through the woods and round the walls and at 8.0 had supper consisting of soup, meat and savoury. They have their dinner in the middle of the day and don't dress in the evening. Theodor is a very genial amusing fellow and his wife is nice looking and not stout like so many German ladies and is most amiable and hospitable. They have one daughter of 16, Marie Mathilde, a typical fat pleasant German girl, and there is also a governess and a lady friend whose name I haven't caught. The Poellnitz came here in 1738, the property being given to them by the Margrave of Ausbach whose portrait and that of his wife hang in the drawing room. Alas that Theodor has no son, the place at his death goes to Wolfgang Poellnitz who is unmarried and after that what becomes of it goodness knows. It is sad to think it may pass into other hands. Last night soon after our walk in the woods it began to rain very heavily and by supper time it had developed into a thunderstorm, the noise was tremendous and the country below was lit up frequently by vivid flashes of lightening. All night long it continued and to our chagrin all today until about 6.0 but the day was spent in exploring the Castle and we wandered with such interest through all the rooms and then into the dungeons and prisons and cellars. Underneath all these there is a vast water cellar into which we were to have gone but we found that the water in it had risen to the level of its roof and beyond and Theodor said he had never known it do that before. On the wall of one passage a woman's stone mask with open mouth is fixed and it is said that one was buried alive there. One prison evidently intended for solitary confinement or for those considered dangerous has the slit for communication placed so that gaoler and prisoner cannot see one another. No light and double doors and during the recent arrangements for laying on water and light T found an oubliette in the roof of it. Anny showed us many relics and treasure, every drawer is stuffed with them: one had gloves long suede and chamois leather printed and stamped with flowers, another was filled with silk and embroidered men's' garters, "L'amour est dans vos yeux" was woven into one white brocade pair. In another drawer we found silk for embroidery, fine floss stuff and yards of hand made trimming for dresses. Oh! how I longed to sit there all day and examine it all alone. Then we saw all the pathetic and sad remains of "Die unvergesslichen Julia" - she was the wife of a long ago Poellnitz who died within a year of her marriage at the birth of her son and her husband kept every little thing, all tied up in paper packets and inscribed, even to a drop of blood on a piece of cambric where perhaps she pricked her finger. Then we saw the two historic gloves, one presented by the present Emperor of Austria with some ribbon and a piece of edelweiss to Tante Lotte, my grandfather's sister who reigned in a stately fashion at Frankenberg and left so many debts that Theodor is still paying them off. She married our cousin Fritz and was a grande dame and had an enormous family. The other glove was given by Prince Albert at his wedding with Queen Victoria to Ernst Poellnitz, my great uncle who came over as one of his gentlemen.
After tea we walked down to the old farm on which are employed Russians and Poles throughout the summer, whose only accommodation is one room for women and one for men and in winter they go back to their homes. We visited the stables where 49 huge cows live all year round, horses, pigs and the huge treadmill wheel worked by men for drawing the water, and then we plunged through a sea of mud to their Wirthaus and home up through the fields. After supper Maide (the daughter) played on the harmonica to us, she is very musical and played the piano too. Whilst on a pleasant tune on the former instrument I saw Theodor say something rapidly to her and suddenly the tune changed to God Save the King whereat we promptly stood up and were greeted by roars of laughter from the family. At 9.30 drinks are brought in and we sup up much beer to our contentment! And so to bed, alas. I wish the time were not so short, I should like to stay here a week - perhaps one day we will return who knows, but by then I must become a professor in German.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Below is a photo of Theodor and Annie von Poellnitz, Wynne's relations whom she visited in July just before the outbreak of war. The couple's daughter, Maide, is the girl on the right....

And here are some shots of the castle - the room Wynne and Herbert stayed in was in the tower in the top shot, the room with its window open (Wynne being a fiend for fresh air!)

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 5th - 13th

Returning home via Ipswich, where they did a bit of house hunting, Wynne resumes her domestic labour.
viewer_4.description:
July 5th, Sunday
We left for home today and had to make a horribly early start, breakfast at 8.0 and the carriage took us to the station at 8.20. At breakfast I said to Annie "I do hope we have left nothing behind, whatever you find you may keep", then halfway to the station H discovered he had left his gold watch and chain under his pillow!! Horror and consternation, we were in a way and sent an abject note back to Annie. We travelled all this day via Wurzburg where we stopped an hour and then toiled on and on all through that ugly part of Germany and Holland till at 11.30 we arrived at the Hook rather tired and glad to lie down in clean and comfortable bunks holding our thumbs for a good crossing which we had.

July 6th. Ipswich
Very early this morning we arrived at Harwich and set forth for Ipswich as 2 days house hunting is before us, a bore as we want to get home. We put up at the White Horse Inn, an indifferent hostelry kept by independent folk and very expensive. We went to our house agents to find they only had 3 for us. We rushed off to Trimley and saw a pretty farm house, much too small, and in the afternoon made a weary journey to Aldborough and saw an atrocity at Thorpeness, no use at all.

July 7th
We made another lengthy expedition today to Harleston, this time the house was an old one, a very nice interior but bad garden and no sun inside, so that's no use and we journeyed up to Town putting up at Liverpool Street Hotel.

July 8th. Home
Here we are home again and very nice it is. I find all very well, my dear Gran better and stronger since we went away. Aime left yesterday having been here a month and has looked after everything so well for me and endeared herself to all. We went and spent the day with Mother, found her in bed of course as she is undergoing a cure with Rabey, he came some time ago and set her ankle and both knees and strapped them up and she has to be in bed a month but she is very cheery, sees plenty of friends, plays bridge and we have great hopes of this cure.

July 9th
It seems so strange to be back in England again and to think that our lovely tour for which we waited 13 years is all over. Well, it is a good time to look back on and I am happy to be home again.

July 10th, Friday
I find plenty to do on my return, sorting and tidying. Mrs Amey my new cook is most satisfactory and has bottled me tons of fruit and made much jam, she is a treasure and I trust will remain.

July 11th and 12th
These days were spent in gardening chiefly and picking fruit. We picked 25 lbs of raspberries one day and made them into jam. Our affairs the last few days have matured - failing to find a house, we have taken on this one for a year!! so we are planté here and that's settled.

July 13th, Monday
I went down into Farnham this morning with ES and did some shopping, flew back to a committee meeting at 12 at the M.Y.Home where a large party of ladies cackled and came to no conclusion, then after lunch ES and I motored about and did some calls and after dinner at the vile hour of 8.40 I had to trail over to the Howards to a Committee meeting of Nursing. The HPA is dead and a new Nursing Committee has been formed and now I trust that there will be peace throughout the land.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The courtyard at Schloss Frankenberg...with Annie and Theodor. The view in the strip is another side of the same yard.

If you are interested in the fate of the castle, you might like to go to another site:www.schloss-frankenberg.de. As you will see, it is still thriving! though sadly not under Poellnitz care any more.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 14th - 24th

Wynne's life is principally preoccupied with her struggle to employ a cook...small domestic worries on the eve of a catastrophe!
viewer_6.description:
July 14th, Tuesday
I came up to Town today to get some clothes. I am in rags and having had a lovely cheque of £100 as a present from Mother from Brookfield which is now sold I felt it would be a good occasion to go a small bust! I am with Mother of course and very jolly it is.


July 15th
The Sales are on and it is an odious time to shop, the things are crumpled and soiled, one can get no attention and all the shops are crammed. I was at it all today and yesterday and managed to collect a few rags but it is no pleasure and very hot.

July 16th
I love a few lazy days with Mother. We settle in early and I get up late, 8.30, and breakfast in my room. I went to my dentist today and for the first time in my life I had nothing to be done!! Topsy is coming to us tonight and I must be at home. I went back by the 5.30 and found Brenda at home.

July 17th
Topsy only stayed for one night and went on to Godalming at 3.15. We motored over in Walker's car. She took with her Nootie's nightie and left her own and bedroom slippers, quite like old times it seems!

July 18th
I arose at 5.30 this morning to get some writing done, and at 7.0 Bessie came to me and said would I go and see Mrs Amey who was ill in bed. Accordingly with a heavy heart I went and found her in great pain and the arrival of a Dr. at 11.30 proved that she has neuritis of the sciatic nerve and must go home, but my luck as usual favoured me and through Mrs Payne my washerwoman I secured a substitute who comes on Monday so all is well and I am very thankful.

July 19th
Again this week the mail is late, monsoons I suppose. We did not hear till Monday last week. To Kirk this morning, it seems quite odd to be there again after a lapse of several weeks. A nice lazy day, read and slept and pottered and now at 9.30 as I write this the heat is oppressive and a thunder storm is raging.

July 20th
It is a curious thing that Mondays often seem to live up to their name of Black, a series of things seem to have set themselves out to worry today: the cook didn't turn up and though the others are very good I cannot bear this upset, besides this a variety of other things have made me long for the desert island. However I have had a month's peace and so I suppose must be strong and full of energy to cope with the daily round.

July 21st
In despair on receiving a letter from the cook who was coming here, saying that her boy is very ill and so she cannot come. I raced round the village and all the known sources only to find that one after another couldn't come for some reason or another but I engaged Martha Englefield just for a few days but she is not at all strong and I cannot keep her. Help Help I'm feeling desperate.

July 22nd
Still cook hunting - a blank draw, Mrs Bacon with whom I had tea tells me Marth E has a weak heart and may collapse any moment, she told me of a Mrs Dew, in despair I went to her and found her with a 3 months old baby but she is coming baby and all tomorrow at 10. It is like a pantomime and I don't know what's come to my well ordered house!

July 23rd, Thursday
A most strenuous day! I had charge of the Mothers' Union Meeting and tea. It was to have been held down here but the weather looked so doubtful and the wind blew so cold that we decided this morning to hold meeting and tea at the Institute which we did, afterwards adjourning to the garden here where they had a few mild amusements and prizes. As there have been various cases of scarlet fever and diptheria lately I thought it best not to risk having my babies about and H took them up to the zoo for the whole day!

July 24th
I have secured a cook! I say "secured" but I shall not feel sure of her until she actually turns up. I answered an advert and back came a reply with many splendid references and I've written to her to come tomorrow so I hope to be at peace once more. Mrs Dew is most satisfactory, an excellent cook, and if it wasn't for the baby I'd stick to her but I want someone to sleep in the house. I had all the Yolland girls to tea today here, poor little creatures, but it is splendid to see the wonders Sister Margaret does with them. I think not to be straight of limb is one of the most fearful afflictions, one child today with both feet turned in and paralized hands, so cheerful and patient.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne's entry for July 30th. The blow has fallen. The Austrian Emperor's manifesto is added below in full...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 25th - 31st

The concerns of the week begin by focussing on the troubles in Ireland...but gradually it dawns on everyone that something much more terrible is about to happen.
viewer_8.description:
July 25th
A day of buzzing about over odd jobs. Our thoughts are more and more directed towards hapless Ireland these days. All this year the crisis has become nearer and nearer, the Govt. have proved unable to cope with the Home Rule question, and at last the King called a conference which after two days has proved a failure. Affairs are at a deadlock and it is impossible to see a way out. Civil War seems inevitable and its all dreadful, and now chiefly on account of the murder of the Austrian Archduke, Austria is at loggerheads with Servia having delivered an ultimatum which they are not able to accept in which case "War" is probable and what can the result of that be but a general conflagration?

July 26th
