The Sunday papers have it that Servia has refused Austria's note so that the Austrian Ambassador has left Belgrade. The King and Court have left it too and it is being evacuated by the garrison! What times we live in, and how is it all to end? The Hoopers and Grays came to see us today, the latter having come all the way from Amesbury. It was so jolly to see them again.

July 27th
As we opened the papers this morning we read of the first bloodshed in Ireland. The cause is more gun running, only this time in Dublin, and on the Nationalist side in open defiance and broad daylight. Consequently the police and military were called out, a frightful row resulted and 4 were killed and many injured. It's just awful.

July 28th
There is naturally an awful upset over the Irish question. Redmond and Birrell denouncing the Govt in the House on account of the business in Dublin, the troops having fired on the mob who attacked them on their way back to barracks. Mr Harrel the man in the police who is held responsible for calling the soldiers out is suspended and Sir John Ross Head of Police has resigned. (David Harrel was Assistant to the Commissioner of the Dublin Metropolitan Police, Sir J Ross). The Govt. seems powerless to keep order or maintain the law and things are more complicated than ever. Meanwhile the clouds are gathering abroad. Sir E. Grey is trying to arrange a conference between the Powers in order to endeavour to avert this horrible disaster but the papers become more and more grave and the situation is just hopeless. We think of nothing else.

July 29th, Wednesday
The blow has fallen. Austria has declared war against Servia. Germany has not been able to accept Sir E Grey's proposals. Russia, Servia's ally, is mobilizing in the South and the first shot has actually been fired for Austria has captured two Servian ships on the Danube. Consternation reigns in consequence and the situation becomes more and more frightful. If Russia mobilizes in the North Germany will also, France must follow and then we too will be bound to do so. In the face of this Greater Evil the Irish question should be set aside but alas it cannot be and feeling runs higher than ever. In consequence of the crisis the Stock Exchange today shows a failure of 5 firms, one being George Craven, poor fellow (a cousin of H's ) and he will be ruined.


July 30th, Thursday
Yesterday in the Times Gazette Poggy read that the billet he had thought he had a chance for has been given to Gen. Fanshaw so that's settled. He also received a wire from the War Office requesting his presence there this morning and accordingly set forth. He returned tonight with the information that he must hold himself in readiness in case of mobilization, giving him his orders which are of course secret so our plan which we had made for going to Crowboro' tomorrow has fallen through as he may not leave home. Everywhere all is upset, all leave has been cancelled, all officers and men recalled from leave and consternation reigns. War has actually begun and engagements have taken place, resulting in heavy losses on both sides. Food prices are already up, at least flour has risen 3/6 a sack in Liverpool.

July 31st, Friday
As I write this I am alone. At 12.0 this morning my man received a wire from the War Office ordering him to join so with haste we packed and sorted all the things he had to take with him, and in this we missed Young. At 5.0 I drove down in a cab with him first to Tommy White to fit on a Kharki coat for he had cast all his Kharki and then to the station when at 6.0 he left. (Herbert had to completely re-equip himself, having sold off all his army equipment on his retirement. Officers were expected to pay for this themselves.) A horrible blankness came over me as I saw his train go out of sight as goodness knows when we shall meet again. The evening papers state that Germany is in a state of Martial Law which means she is most certainly mobilzing and all seems inevitable. One can't realize the horror of it all. The Skippys came in after dinner and we gloomed together. What times to live in, how dreadful it all is.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
The Telegram calling Herbert to the War Office....Wynne saved all the telegrams and notices the family received...and poignantly, she also stuck into her July entry letters she had received from her three young children...as you can see, she did not approach the war with any of the feelings that are normally attributed to members of the British population.

Wynne's son's letter is the smaller of the two. Ysobel's. in French, is beneath it, and both conceal a noble effort from Baby...

july.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot. She and Herbert get back from a German holiday just in time...Austria declares war on Serbia....

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne and Herbert's itinerary, starting from Munich where her Uncle Walter lived.

Ysobel describes this second honeymoon as she remembers it.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 10th

Officially retired, and after sorting out the family home, Wynne and Herbert leave for the continent. They travel to the Tyrol via Nurnberg and Munich
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Monday
A lovely day and one is so glad for the thousands of holiday makers. I write this before breakfast sitting in the sunny verandah awaiting Mother's arrival and today all linen, bedding, dining room glass and china is to be done. The house is like a barrack!

June 2nd
By dinner time last night all the sorting was finished and ready for the packers who came today with their vans and seemingly endless store of paper, shavings and other mess and by 9.0 we saw the last of them. Herbert Daniell came to say goodbye and to our surprise Bernard Roe turned up today, also Mrs Chapman on business. I looked on her with curiosity as future mistress of my dear old home.

June 3rd
The house is more barracky than ever today, and we still go round collecting "treasures". Mother has given us such heaps of things including the stair carpet and dining room ditto, also to my joy the old blue Swiss china out of the dining room. The Pennys, Daniells, Casltemains and Mr Salmon turned up today besides a lot of our old village friends and I was sad to see the last of them. I walked down after lunch to see old George and the Martins, the former insisted on presenting me with his 3 blue dishes I have so often admired and which he bought before he married . B.G. arrived at about 5 today and after tea we strolled round the garden and up to the church just to have a last look round at the dear old place. I went down to the river and over the island - the beech tree still has a little hole in it out of which still stick 2 or 3 hairs!

June 4th
H and I left by the 10.45 today and as we drove away I felt, oh! what did I feel? to think that I have looked my last on this blessed old place so crowded with memories for the last 32 years, it was very chokey and horrid and I'm glad its all over. We reached home at 5.30, such an awful journey with 2 hours to wait at Salisbury.

June 5th
Our wedding day, of blessed memory! It was spent in great rush and turmoil for we set off tomorrow to the Continent and there are so many jobs that must be seen to before we go. A dozen people came rushing in at all hours and I didn't start my packing till 10.30 getting to bed at 12.30. The garden is looking lovely - sweet peas are splendid and all roses coming out. I'm quite loathe to leave it.

June 6th, Saturday
Exactly 13 years ago we started off on this very day for our honeymoon and here we are doing it again! We left home at 10.2 and went to Cooks' office and to Cox and the Stores, then to Mother's for lunch where we spent the afternoon and at 6.30 set off for Liverpool Street where we dined, and then started by the 8.30 and crossed by the Hook. We had a splendid passage and slept all night and even I did not feel horrible.

June 7th, Sunday
All this day we travelled, the country was flat and dull except the Rhine Valley, and I for one think that is overrated. We got to Würzburg at about 6.0 where we changed and dined and arrived at Nürnberg about 10.0

June 8th
Alas it has rained nearly all day and is dull and cold, nevertheless we have spent the day exploring and a very interesting queer old town it is, all round it runs the huge wall encircled by a moat and inside many of the streets and houses are most picturesque and quaint. We visited the Fraüen Kirche in which are stone carvings by Veit Stoss and Kraft sculptures of the 15th century.

Also went into S. Lorenzo, a beautiful Gothic building containing Krafts most beautiful tabernacle reaching to the height of the church which took him 7 years to carve and for which he received 770 guilders! the glass in these churches is very fine 14th and 15th century, lucky they had no Cromwell in this country. We are staying at the Wurtemberger Hof, a fine modern hotel near the station, rather expensive, and we go tomorrow to Munich where we hope to see Walter. (Wynne omits to mention that the Lutheran reforms were responsible for quite a bit of church simplification, but she is correct in thinking that in the end the Germans did not desecrate the old churches in quite the same ruthless manner as the English).

June 9th
Still this vile rain continues and the cold is extraordinary, however we made a further excursion round the town, bought some toys for the dolls' house and some Lebkuchen, and then caught the 1.30 train for Munich, after a journey of nearly 4 hours we arrived and were there met by Walter who took us to the Baseler Hotel where we have a very comfortable room with a bathroom for 9 mark, it is quiet, clean and cheap. After a change we dined Walter at a restaurant of his choosing, excellent dinner and music. We also went on our arrival to his flat which is most comfortable and full of treasures. (Walter is Walter von Poellnitz, Wynne's uncle)

June 10th
The weather has changed and it has been quite hot today. We spent the morning at the National Museum, then lunch with Walter at his club and went out to Nymphenburg for the afternoon, built by Ferdinand Maria in 1620 it is an ugly pile with fine and very extensive grounds. (Wynne's facts appear to be a little awry. It was the summer palace of the Wittelsbach family, begun 1664 by the Elector Ferdinand Maria. It was constantly added to, especially in the 18th century. Highlights include the Great Hall, built 1756, and the "Gallery of Beauties", commissioned by King Ludwig I (Ludwig II's grandfather). )

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A page from the diary - Rattenberg. Wynne stuck in postcards but also added her own photos, some of which did not come out too well. However the one of the main street, at the top, looks pretty good - you can see an enlargement in the strip...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 11th - 15th

They leave Munich and travel on to Kufstein, Rattenberg and Jenbach
viewer_4.description:
June 11th, Thursday
We said goodbye to Walter at 1.0 today and started by the 1.30 from Munich arriving at Kufstein 2.50 and lunched on the train. On reaching our destination we walked over to the Auracher which is considered the best inn here and which is certainly most comfortable and clean, the Hausmeister showed us into a large low room most elaborately fitted with brown wooden beds, cupboards and doors all carved and ornamented with iron, for this magnificence he charges only 6 krone. The beds are quaint, they have the inevitable enormous feather poufs which we shy on to the floor always, also the 2 huge feather pillows into which your head sinks and gets lost during the night. This particular couple (beds) are carved one with the Christ, the other with the Virgin and child, why I want to know. We took a stroll after taking coffee and were quite charmed with the scenery which is enormous and magnificent and we mean weather permitting to make 2 excursions tomorrow. (Wynne is clearly not happy with the idea of sleeping under a duvet - something the English did not embrace until much later in the century!!)

June 12th, Friday
The weather was not permitting so we only made one expedition. At 10.0 we started off intending to walk to Hechtsee but taking a wrong turn we found ourselves on the road to the Thiersee so went there instead, it was a long pull up and halfway down came the rain in torrents but we were provided and on we plodded. At length we came to a plateau and there gathered lovely little primulas, buck bean pansies and heaps of flowers I've never see. Just below us lay the lake, lying like an emerald surrounded by hay fields, white houses with red roofs and framed all round by huge blue mountains. We returned another way and had done about 10 miles on reaching town. I took an easy after lunch and at 4.30 we went and took coffee in the Auracher Keller, a wierd dull sort of place on the river but it started at once to rain and has done so ever since.


June 13th, Saturday
Rattenberg. We had intended doing the walk to the Kaisergebirge this morning but though finer the mountains are all clouds so we decided to leave by the 12.30 and after three quarters of an hour arrived at this 15th century townlet. Finding no one at the station from the Ledererbraü, the hotel we are staying at we attached an aged dienstmann to our luggage and walked ahead. We entered the house by a low door way and found our way along a vaulted dark tunnel where after a search the Hausmeister was found - we then mounted two flights of dark staircases, groped our way along pitchy passages till we came to our room. What was our surprize on opening the door to find a large sunny room, two large windows and everything perfectly spotless from the boarded floor to the white crochet antimacassers which cover chairs and dressing table. Most elaborate are the embroidered sheets and lace trimmed feather poufs and pillows and actually in the centre of the room is electric light! For this delightful room we pay 2 krone 40.! One could spend a cheap summer here! After lunch which consisted of Kalbsnitzel we set forth to explore the town. It is indeed a queer old place, the houses differing in size, height, shape and colour are all built with the high "feuermauer" (firewall) reaching far above the actual roof as a protection from fire and the doorways are all low and arched giving on to tunnel-like passages of stone. The street at one end runs through a tunnel under a house and the whole town is but one street shaped like a P. We found an antiquitäten shop and on trying the door it proved to be locked. A tiny boy seeing us scuttered past us like a rabbit down the tunnel shouting in a shrill voice "Hans yemand is da" and down came Hans, a tall thin nice looking man with whom we spent a half hour and bought some glass bottles, a brass candlestick and several other curios. He talked incessantly in broad dialect but we got on quite well and he had a kindly manner and a great love for all his old things. Next door to him was a Museum containing some pieces of furniture, iron work and domestic articles but the most curious part was the house itself, roughly built into the solid rock with stone staircases and iron barred windows and walls feet thick. We went into the kitchen, a smoke begrimed hole with no outlet for the smoke except through a hole in the roof and a square iron barred aperture which served for a window. We next turned our steps across the river through hayfields where crickets sang and hundreds of frogs croaked - up through the woods to Mariatal to see the miraculous picture which till 1655 hung in a shrine in the valley where twice it was removed by unseen hands to its present position and the people recognizing the will of God built there a church over it.

June 14th
To our great disappointment when we awoke this morning we found that despite the fact of its having rained all the night it was still pouring so we waited patiently after having had our breakfast until 10.30 and in despair went out, we first explored the ruined castle above the town, a most perilous ascent, and went into the Tower where Wilhelm v Bienes (?), Chancellor of Tyrol (in the 15th century) was beheaded, a great reformer. We returned here for lunch and then set off for Brixlegg the next village to this, it is a quaint pretty little place and we made our way to Castle Matzen where live Mr and Mrs Baillie Grohmann. The lady of the house an Englishwoman came and showed us all over it, and it was most interesting. The tower is Roman and the place was bought by his Mother who from a ruin restored it into its present beautiful condition. It is full of treasures, old furniture, silver, pewter and glass and she most kindly took us all over it. We also went into another old house and found a very typical farmyard and courtyard and so home, weather still horrible.


June 15th
Jenbach. The day began in a hopeless way, heavy misty clouds right down the valley and rain again but thank goodness it cleared later on and we left for Jenbach at 1.16 after paying our bill of 8 krone odd! Our destination all along the valley of the Inn past the Zillertal towards which I looked with longing eyes was only 3 stations off and as soon as we had settled our luggage at the "Tolerance" hotel we started to walk up the valley to the wonderful Schloss Tratzburg. I never came across a dirtier road but our toil was rewarded for I never saw a finer place. It is in the possession of Count Ensenberg and he keeps it up entirely in the old style, even his own apartments look as if they had never been altered - its all very well for show but I wouldn't care to live in the style of our medieval ancestors: no carpets or curtains, no water or light arrangements, and sanitary arrangements to match! but the rooms are grand and contain the most perfect furniture one could wish for, the ceiling and wood panelled walls are wonderful, the iron work and old locks on the doors all in keeping, and they show you the rooms where Maximillian was lodged during his visits there, on the wall is an inscription said to be by him. The castle in its present state dates from the 16th century and there are said to be 365 windows. On our way home I gathered a bunch of every kind of flower, including columbine, dianthus, broom, rape and scabious campanula and heaps of others and then we went into the Church dated 1529, very ornate and restored in the usual garish fashion. The village is a collection of tiny narrow streets, one or two fine old houses but not so old or interesting as Rattenberg. It is evening and I sit on the balcony of our bedroom with the most perfect view before me.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: This is the castle Wynne and Herbert walked to: Schloss Tratzberg, in Jenbach. The rooms Wynne describes are below.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 16th - 19th

On to Innsbruck, then via Matrei, Steinach and the Brenner Pass to Bozen...
viewer_6.description:
June 16th, Tuesday
Although the day did not promise well we thought we must make the expedition to the Achensee and so set off at 11.0 by the little cogwheel train. No sooner had we started than it began to rain, arriving at Seehof we took steamer to Pertisau and the lake looked grey whilst the mountains and sky were black! We lunched at the old Fürstenhaus built long ago by the Counts of Tyrol, now owned by the Benedictine monks of Viecht. After lunch it cleared a little and thinking we would like to see a little of the country we decided to walk home as far as Eben where we hoped to pick up the train on its return journey. Accordingly we set forth taking the road all along the edge of the lake, the most muddy road I've ever been on bar none. We had not gone far when the rain descended with renewed violence, on on we tramped, arriving at length at Eben and having as we thought half an hour to wait we went into the little Church where is the tomb of St. Nothburga, very touching is the evidence of the simple peasant faith as displayed by the many votive offerings hung therein: wax models of cows, horses, babies arms and more legs all denoting blessings of recovery received by the faithful. Having inspected all this we betook ourselves over to the tiny Waartraal there to await the coming of the train, having done so for more than an hour (our clothes ringing wet) H went out to look again at the time table only to discover that that particular train did not run till June 28th! There was nothing for it but to plunge forth into the rain again and walk the rest of the way home, very thankful we were to reach the Hotel where hot coffee and dry clothes awaited us! This is a busy little village, a great number of saw mills being its chief industry, and there is a fine 16th century church and some old houses. We left by the 7.00 reaching Innsbruck at 7.30.

June 17th
Arriving last night we walked over to this large and most modern Hotel, the Tyroler Hof. It is close to the station and our room was so noisy that we got them to change and now have a room overlooking the Weiherberg and Hungerburg, with the veritable wall of mountains beyond, with snow lying along the ridge. I set off to have my hair washed and H to Cooks, and then we commenced our tour of inspection. We found the Hofgasse, Landhaus and Pfarrgasse all containing queer old houses, evidence of long bygone times including in the Hofgasse the house which Sigmund built for his court giant Haid, a figure of whom is erected outside - his legs look weak! A little further on there dazzles one the quaint and far-famed "Goldenes Dachl" which Kaiser Max raised as a memorial of his marriage with Maria Bianca Sforza of Milan. We then went to the Hofkirche containing the superb and quite unique tomb and double line of perfect bronze figures intended by Max as his last resting place. His burial however took place near Vienna. We went off after this to lunch at the Goldener Adler, for many years Innsbruck's chief inn, where have slept Kaiser Max, Kotzebue, Heine, Goethe and Andreas Hofer, and it was from the window of a room there into which we went that the latter delivered an impassioned speech to the people in anno '9. (In the year 1809 Archduke Charles appealed to the German people to resist Napoleon's ally, Bavaria. Tyrol was the only one to heed the Archduke's appeal and rose against the French under the freedom fighter Andreas Hofer. Austria ultimately betrayed Tyrol and the rebellion failed. Less then a year later, Hofer was executed).
I do wish instead of having come to this modern and most expensive hotel we had gone there. (Wynne went back to the church, and to the Palace where the picture of Francis1 and Maria Theresa's 13 children fascinated her).

June 18th, Thursday
I awoke at 6.30 this morning and realized that it was a really lovely day so up I got and taking this book out on to the balcony I sat and wrote up our doings. The view was perfectly lovely, a brilliant sun shone upon the mountains which stand like a great wall up behind us, their tops glistening with patches of snow. We set forth today to have a a day in the country, alas for the weather it began too well and before the day was half over there we were plodding along in the usual rain. We took train up to Berg Isel and from there trained to Igls and walked up the mountain road to Patsch. If it had only been fine the view from there would have been simply splendid for we were fairly high and could see several valleys all round us but of course they were full of mist.

June 19th
Bozen. We left (Innsbruck) this morning and travelled away down past Matrei, Steinach and through the Brenner Pass, then (on to) Bozen. The scenery all the way was quite lovely and once through the Pass we were once more among vines and chestnuts. We arrived at Bozen soon after lunch which we had in the train, and at once set out to explore the Town, and what a quaint little place it is: the old part all tiny narrow streets many of which are arcaded on either side with shops closely packed together, some of the streets so narrow there is hardly any room to pass and the old houses have great thick walls and iron barred windows. The Fruit Market is particularly picturesque, and one can buy lovely fruit mostly cherries now for 60 hella (? anyone know what this coinage was?) a lb. We visited the parish church, a most beautiful old building with a tower all flying buttresses and a roof all green, gold, black and white tiles, the building dating from the 14th century.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is the market place in Bozen, an enlargement of which is in the strip...

and one of Wynne's photos of Herbert up in the high mountains, near St. Christina...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 20th - 24th

Mountain excursions, then back up the road they'd already travelled, to Waidbruck and S. Ubrich. Magical mountain walks and peaceful days.
viewer_8.description:
June 20th, Saturday
We walked out all along the Wasser Mauer where poor Peter Mayer one of the Anno '9 leaders was shot, to Schloss Runkelstein. This is a splendid old castle some way up the valley Sarnthal, 700 years ago it was erected and 300 later one Nicolas Vintler, a great banker and merchant bought it, added on to it and filled it with wonderful frescoes but alas he died childless and it passed into other hands, the Lichtensteins holding it for some time after which it fell into decay and then a lucky day dawned for it when the present Emperor bought it, had it restored and presented it to the town. On our return we lunched at the famous Batzlhause, the hostel of the Tuetonic Knights many centuries ago. It is now a weinstube and the haunt of artists whose many paintings adorn its walls. (The Emperor Wynne refers to is the Habsburg Emperor, Franz Joseph. The presentation to the town occurred in 1893, and of course when Wynne is writing he is still on the throne, and his Empire still covered most of central Europe. )

June 21st
Anxiously we looked at the weather this morning and found to our joy that it was fair so at about 11 we took our seats in the Rittnerbahn which crawls up the side of a mountain all along the Eisach valley as far as Klobenstein...we lunched at the Hotel Post and then strolled along the Föhnpromenade, a shady walk along the mountain side, and when we had got some way we dipped down on to a green slope where amongst innumerable flowers we lay in the sun and watched the clouds casting huge blue shadows over the mountains across the valley opposite. Never shall I forget that perfect view which stretched away for miles and miles before us, the insects filled the air with their lazy thrumming drowsy sound, the lovely butterflies flitted about from one flower to another and all the birds in the world seemed to be singing. Alas the time came to move on and we then had a most lovely walk back through woods and hay fields to the Ober Bozen where we had two large cafe melange each and caught the train on its return, reaching home about 7.30...day of pure delight. (We are a mere week away from the assassination at Sarajevo - such is the irony of history).

June 22nd
Regretfully we left Bozen today. It is a fascinating little place and one might well spend a month there but though Time does not exist for the Tyrol it does for us and have yet several places to visit. Accordingly we left civilization at about midday and reaching Waidbruch in half an hour consigned our luggage to be driven up. (Wynne and Herbert then walked up to S. Ubrich.)
All the inhabitants of this valley have for generations been wood carvers. S. U sticks to church furniture and many are the life size figures of our Lord, the Virgin and saints that one sees. S. Christina and Wolkenstein make toys.


June 23rd
The climax of joy was reached today for we actually climbed to the snow and ate it! (Wynne took a train to St. Christina, then walked to the Regenbürgher Hütte). We had not gone far before we came to gentian and daphne, oh joy, and as soon as we had got a bit higher the ground was literally starred with the small gentian. We also found Alpen Rosen (Rhododendron, obviously still an exciting plant for Wynne), and eventually when we got above the pines a few small pieces of Eidelweiss, but it appears to be over really. Well, after about 2 hours climb we reached the Hütte and immediately sat down with glorious view in front of us and drank beer and ate rolls. Never have I enjoyed anything more. We then continued to climb till we reached the snow across a wide limestone plateau and here we found Soldanella, both white and purple, and many tiny flowers I've never seen before. (Soldanella is an alpine primrose, with a fluted trumpet. There are several varieties.) Endless are the flowers of these parts and something in the soil effects the colour of many, the common parsley becomes pink, scabious takes on a pink tinge, hawkweed is often orange and the varieties of vetch are endless. We also found the loveliest mauve clematis growing like Travellers Joy and up high, heaps and heaps of the large gentian. I've never seen so much colour. All along the path the mountain stream rushed in a fussy way and we bathed our faces in its icy waters and drank refreshing draughts. At last we had to turn our steps homeward and on reaching S.C had coffee before stretching our legs along the 3 miles that still lay between us and home. I have enjoyed today, it has just been perfection.

June 24th
If it was possible to do so I think I enjoyed today's exploration even more than yesterday, but it is hard to say. We started off again on the Mallpost and this time drove as far as Wolkenstein. (This time Wynne and Herbert walked up into the mountains from there and came across a large open meadow) The absolute stillness and almost prehistoric feeling about it fascinated one and the ground was starred with big blue gentian and pale lemon anemones. Suddenly a young boy gave a loud jödl, the echo of which came back loud and clear as a bell as did a horrible clap of thunder which frightened me to a fit in that lonely empty place! With great reluctance we retraced our steps for it was getting late and we had a 7 mile tramp home before us.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The fresco on the wall of the Hotel Elefant, Brixen, where Wynne and Herbert stayed...and below it a photo of the main street in Klausen, where they went next...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
June 25th - 30th

To Klausen, Sterzing and Steinbach before returning to Innsbruck. She makes a flower list.
viewer_10.description:
June 25th, Thursday
Brixen. On arrival we found the porter from the Gasthof zum Elefant, and drove through this sunlit sleepy town to our old, old Inn. It was founded in 1551 and so named because "the first elephant to visit Europe drew up on this spot and all the folk from far and near came to see it", as a set of verses painted on the wall together with the elephant, his mahout and a gentleman, explains. The elephant looks very knowing, both his eyes look at you though he is sideways on! The house is delightful, large and roomy, old wooden ceilings and walls and endless pewter, glass and pottery and in one room a magnificent old green stove. The cooking is excellent, the beds most comfortable and very cheap. We arrived about 1.0 and soon after set out to explore. One thousand and ten years ago Brixen was handed to Zacharias, Bishop of Säben whereby it passed from the possession of King Ludwig 111 to that of the diocese of Säben. (Wynne explored the huge Minster, or "Dom", commenting on the frescoes by Master Hugo. She also managed to get a priest to show her the Treasury, with its many treasures).

June 26th
We spent the day at the quaint little town of Klausen (pictured above). Being market day we saw it at its best, many of the country folk being dressed in costume and all had come to buy or sell or gossip. This place consists of one street, 15th century again, how much seems to date from that time, this same street is very narrow and paved with cobble stones, full of quaint signs, jutting out windows and over-hanging eaves.

We lunched at the queerest old Inn I've ever seen, the Gasthof zum Lamme. Entering a vaulted and cave-like cellar you ascend to the first floor and there find a large inner and outer room positively bogeyish, full of frescoes, arms, pewter, pottery and original stained glass windows. Everything was clean and nice though and we had an excellent lunch, but the house made me think of robbers' dens!

June 27th
Sterzing. The origin of this queer little place lay in Roman hands, who called it Vipetenium, but in 1296 it had become a full-fledged municipality but the story goes that it lacked a name and after many suggestions over which none could agree they decided to call it after the first man to pass their gates, and so laid in wait for him. To their dismay the first to do so was a crippled beggar, however true to their decision they christened the town Sterzing, borrowing from the local dialect the word Störzer which means vagabond. It is the most beautiful town I have ever seen. Like Klausen, it consists of one street only larger and longer, every house is a gem, all different sizes, shapes and colour with feuermauer and many perfect old wrought-iron gilt signs, one and all being particularly fine. (Wynne then explored the old Rathaus and other sites. You can see a picture of the street she is talking about below).

June 28th
The weather at present seems to have settled down to real heat and we set forth about 9.30 to walk to the Gilfenklamm - very lovely it was when we got there but we first had an hours walk along a very hot road. We paid 1 krone at the Gasthof and got a key, then climbed up and up into a very grand gorge where the water comes rushing and falls from a tremendous height. We walked on some long way up the valley and had a queer meal of salami, bread and butter at an isolated apology of a gasthof on our way home.

June 29th
We left Sterzing last night and came to this most comfortable hotel (in Steinach). (Wynne and her husband went off on another strenuous walk) On arriving at the tiny village of Gschnitz which is but a handful of houses and a Church we looked anxiously around for a friendly Gasthof as it was 4 hours since our frugal breakfast, none could we see! However upon the door step of his house stood the worthy Pfarrer, his flock having gathered around for service, it being St. Peter's day, so I went up and said in pleading tones, "Können wir etwas zu essen haben bitte?" In genial tones he answered "Ya, Gewiss" and so we entered and found that apparently they were accustomed to cater for passersby, and we partook of the most delicious Kalbsnitzel and kartoffe, lovely butter, bread and cheese and when finished I could have eaten it all again. It was interesting to see all the men, women and children flocking in to service, all in their Sunday clothes. The children are dressed like grown up people, with their hair up and long frocks, the women all wear black frocks now with gaily coloured aprons sometimes and the flat round hat trimmed with gold underneath. One wealthy couple came to church followed by two goats who were awfully disquieted at being locked out and attached themselves to us!
(They walked home, getting wet again, and Wynne noted 39 different flowers that she picked on the way. You can see her list in the next window).

June 30th
By some curious mishap something we had eaten I suppose disagreed with us last night and I for one was very sick! (Too much Kalbsnitzel??!). So feeling rather dicky we started later than we had intended and drove at 11 on to Matrei where we took train back to Innsbruck. (They toured Matrei, Wynne disapproving of the "Unser Herr in Eland" statue in the church, and then continued to Innsbruck.)
In the margin on this day, almost as an after-thought, Wynne adds: " Horrified to read in papers here of the assassination of Archduke of Austria and his wife in Servia. What effect will it have on the poor old Emperor? " What indeed!

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: Wynne's flower list from her walk on June 29th...

june.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband had commanded the Artillery. He has now retired, and they plan a celebratory holiday...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The Baroness Eleanor von Poellnitz on her 100th Birthday

March 13th 1814 - March 13th

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 6th

Wynne worries about her Grandmother's health as she approaches her 100th Birthday. Later in the week Wynne is involved in a shocking automobile accident.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Sunday
March has come in fine and dry but rather like a lion. We all went down to Kirk and I to the Skippy's after as usual.
Negotiations for the sale of the remainder of Brookfield (Wynne's family home) are in force with a Col Chapman. I do so hope all will be well, it would be such a load off our mind to get rid of the place although we naturally would be sad to lose our old home where we have had such jolly times.

March 2nd
The usual busy day: German and MM.

March 3rd
Again I rushed all day, first to the Annual Gen. Meeting of the SSLA at Prince Consorts Library where met together many females from all over the camp. I then flew home and after lunch we all went to the Gunner Concert at the Hippodrome and on to the Mess afterwards to tea.

March 4th, Wednesday
I am very much exercised over my Gran, she is certainly in a very indifferent state today and it is most anxious and worrying. I don't know what we shall do if anything happens. Today she is quite wandering and is suffering from acute pain in the head. (Wynne was preparing for her grandmother's 100th birthday).


March 5th
As usual when on the verge of despair Tanner (her doctor) reassured me. He says Gran mustn't lie in bed, so we got her up. He says she is not so bad as we feared, and that her pulse is good. She has not slept all night and has talked in a wandering way all the time but is more sensible today. I asked if I might leave her with confidence and he said Yes, so off I went at 9.45 to Shirts where owing to its being the last Cavalry day I had written round an appeal the consequence of which was 21 ladies all tumbling over one another with not enough to do! but this is better than too few with 1000 shirts staring you in the face.

At 12.0 Mrs Skippy came to fetch me and we drove on to the Rifle Point to Point, she driving. Through Bagshot a fearful thing happened to us, we were going dead slow when suddenly two children darted out and before anything could be done we had run over one, right over its body and its arm. I shall never forget the horror of that, but by God's mercy when the child was picked up it was found to be absolutely unhurt, only frightened and after getting a Dr and doing what we could we continued on our way. The Pt to Pt was quite jolly but the mud was simply awful and I felt rather sick at the thought of that child, however it might have been so much worse.


March 6th
Dr Tanner came up this morning and pronounced dear Gran very much better. I am so thankful for really just at present there seems a good deal to worry one, there are many difficulties cropping up about Brookfield and I feel in my bones that Col Chapman is slowly but surely slipping away, added to this Pearce is leaving at the end of the month as her father wont allow her to come to the vicinity of Aldershot!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 7th - 12th

Committee meetings, Point to Point outings and Gran's health...a busy but boring week.
viewer_4.description:
March 7th, Saturday
Gran though really fearfully helpless and weak is keeping better and Tanner is not coming today. I really will be rather thankful when next week is over. The anxiety as to whether she will be fit or not is weighing rather heavily. I am like Martha at present and have an additional worry to contend with. Help! Help!!

March 8th
I did not go to Church this morning but spent a quiet day at home reading, writing and sleeping.

March 9th
Each day Gran slowly gets back her strength Thank God, her attack has left her very weak but I have great hopes and Dr Tanner too. It is a fearful day, pouring and pelting but as usual Mon is not my day for staying at home. To Aldershot early - no German as I had no time to prepare, then a Committee Meeting up the Hill, the usual MM meeting after lunch and to tea at the de Mornays so I walked that blessed hill three times in floods today.

March 10th, Tuesday
Mrs Skippy drove me to the Cavalry Point to Point where we spent a very jolly day. The sun shone and it snowed at intervals! We met a great many friends and saw some excellent races but alas 3 poor horses had to be destroyed.


March 11th
To S and SJA Committee at 10.30, the last I shall attend thanks be. Thurie and Lena came by the 1.0 after which Thurie, H and I all went off to the Ewshott Brigade Point to Point, always a jolly little meeting. I gave away the prizes, alas about the last time I shall do it. Lena didn't come - Gran is still better. Oh! how I hold my thumbs for Friday.

March 12th
Oh! how busy I am, shall I ever get all ready in time. "To Shirts" this morning also for the last time for which I am truly thankful, a very big day as it is the final one in this season. I went and did some shopping and got home at 1.30, then after lunch back again for wreaths for Gran's cake which came today and after tea made two lampshades. Already flowers, wires and letters are beginning to arrive! Gran still well.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The Baroness with her son Thurie (Arthur), and her two great grandaughters, Eleanore and Ysobel.

Ysobel, Eleanore's great grand daughter, remembers stories she told her about the 1820s:

Below this, the great cake with its 100 candles. Behind the Baroness on the right of the picture stands her daughter, Aimee. Ysobel is by her side.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 13th - 17th

The great 100th Birthday celebration for Wynne's Grandmother - a lady born before trains appeared who lived long enough to see men fly.
viewer_6.description:
March 13th, Friday
At last the long-looked-for-day has arrived and I don't suppose that such an anniversary will ever occur again in our family. Last night I got a panic about Gran, she was sleeping so quietly that I had to come down 3 times before I finally settled off to sleep to hear if she was breathing, and in the morning I heard she had slept like a child from 9 to 7. We breakfasted at 8 at which meal I was not present owing to a fit of cramps which kept me on my back for an hour (convenient day to choose) but by 9.30 I got down and was ready to cope with the uninterrupted procession of letters, wires, presents and flowers that came pouring in. Lena and I set to work and soon the drawing room looked like a flower shop, the table then had to be arranged and I did it with the Gray's lovely flowers: white, pink and mauve in tulips, narcissus and lilac. We lengthened the Springfield table to its full length, covering it with the one huge cloth belonging to it and for table centre put Aunt Aims pink worked one made about 15 years ago! By the 1.0 train all our guests arrived from Town whose names are to be found on the page before this and when they were all assembled dear Gran was wheeled out. She knew and greeted all with appropriate remarks and was much interested in her beautiful flowers and presents and then we all went into lunch, a cold one on the table. I've never seen anything so wonderful as Gran, she took notice of everyone, made an excellent lunch and when we drank her health amidst a loud "for she's a jolly good fellow" she supped up her champagne in return with much appreciation and relish. (Go to the Family section for more information on the group here)

When lunch was over she retired to her room to rest whilst we occupied ourselves till tea with quilps and cranks taking photos of us all in a group and writing names in this book. By 4.15 tea was ready and in the centre of the table was the huge cake adorned with silver wreaths, surrounded by 100 candles - a really unique sight. Gran was delighted with it! Our lunch party of 17 was added to by the Grays, Fairholmes, Dr Tanner and Col. Fitzroy. Alas by the 6.0 train they all departed leaving us feeling very blank but with the remembrance of a most successful and delightful day behind us. Each and all have been much touched by the many thoughts which have flown to Gran from all parts of the world, the telegrams from the King and Lord Roberts bringing great pleasure and rejoicings, and so ends this great day.

March 14th, Saturday
Still there arrive congratulations for Gran from all sorts of unexpected quarters and from people one has heard nothing of for years. Gran doesn't seem at all tired or over done to day and actually gave an interview to a reporter of the Farnham Herald the result of which I stick in here (you can see it in the next page). No less than 4 others came up yesterday and this morning her picture and a description were already in the Daily Mail. Lena, Thurie and Walter are staying on a few days, a very jolly family party, but the poor Hamster is far from well and feels the cold considerably, the weather is not behaving itself and we see but little of the sun at present. We are busy making a list of all Gran's acknowledgements which must be sent off, they have now reached 102! We are going to send away 3 dozen boxes of cake!

March 15th
To Church in the morning, and the rest of the day spent in writing for Gran.

March 16th
Alas the dear old Gran had one of her restless nights and is good for nothing today, it is only what one expected and I wonder she didn't give way the day after. Walter left us today to return to Mother, I am thankful to have got him for 3 days, it just made the success of the party complete. The usual Mothers' Meeting today, only about 7 more. Hurrah!!

March 17th
Here is my Saint's birthday (her husband) and Mother brought her and my presents down with her on Friday and left them on the train! so I had to collect 3 rubbishes together and present them with ceremony and the children gave him their yearly gift of mignonette. At 12 I went up to the Home for a committee meeting and nowt else happened.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The celebration of a centenary - Eleanore Mary, Baroness von Poellnitz, nee Elliot. Born March 13th 1814.


 

The article above appeared in the local press - below are the menu, list of cards and letters received, a letter from Wynne's sister Eve from India, and the telegram from the King.... the menu was: Salmon Mayonaise, Mushroom patties, Ham, Chicken, Tongue, Game Pie, Galantine, Corned Beef, Merignues, Orange Cream, Pine Cream, Charlotte Russe, Jelly, Cheese tartlets, Eggs in Aspic and Royans de bordelaise.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 18th - 23rd

The Home Rule Bill for Ireland - Ulster in turmoil and the Army near mutiny. The nation holds its breath...
viewer_8.description:
March 18th, Wednesday
We are much saddened by the thought that our blessed Youngs are leaving us now, they go to their new billet on Monday next and Young leaves us on Friday to get his packing done. I shall miss him after eleven and a half years of service but this billet they have as man and wife to an erstwhile mistress of hers is the very best thing that could happen to them and we are awfully glad. Thurie and Lena left us today and so we are alone once more, "a lull after the storm". To Service in the evening - hymns too Sankey and Moodyish! (Young was Herbert's batman during the Boer War, and then worked in the house as the butler, while his wife did the laundry. He kept a pub after he left employment, and his daughter married a Dickens of the Dickens and Jones shop family, so moved up in the world. In fact she was probably considerably better off than Wynne!)

March 19th
We went to Town today to greet Mother on her birthday. I rushed about doing a lot of shopping and went down to her at about 3.0. where H had preceded me and where Walter also arrived. I returned home as I am due at the Ewshott Point to Point tomorrow.

March 20th
I might have stayed up after all for it has snowed the whole day without ceasing! At about 1.0 I got a wire saying the Pt. to Pt. was of course put off - sickening.

March 21st, Saturday
The Morning Papers have electrified the world in general this morning, for the state of affairs as to the Home Rule have indeed come to a head. The question has been before the country for long and this week Debates took place in the House. On Thursday night as I passed that wonderful building on the way to Waterloo, its huge lighted up pile looked grimly and mysteriously beside the river, the yard was full of cars and Big Ben's face showed that the House was sitting. Outside in front of Westminster Hall I saw the statue of that man of strength Oliver Cromwell and one felt that once again had arisen the need of such a man to enter again and sweep away the incompetent stuff that blinds and deliberately was placing the Nation in such peril, but the days of the individual are over, its all Party Politics and Socialism now-a-days, and Asquith with his brood will just have to do what Redmond and Devlin etc tell them or retire as private gentlemen minus their £400 a year. For weeks and months and years even Ulster has seen this coming and are prepared to fight. Yesterday troops were poured in by land and sea and when things came to a head at the Curragh Brig. Gen. Gough and all his cavalry officers resigned rather than go to Ulster. A pretty state of affairs and unprecedented in modern history. Wild consternation on the part of the Government, "brave" revengeful words from Seely which mean nothing at all as events will prove and a general cave in will be the result. Meanwhile the W.O. Army Council and the Cabinet are in a state of panic and Ulster in spite of intense excitement is biding her time and Sir. E Carson is with her.

March 22nd, Sunday
How one does long to see tomorrow's papers. The only one we can get today is News of the World, a sensational rag and only containing last night's news. The world at large is "Signing the Covenant", there are offices for doing so all over the country and the Women's Covenant is to appear shortly.

March 23rd
Here is a short notice of what the Globe thinks of the situation, the papers are extremely interesting at present but the Debates are too long and bulky to put in here. A crowded Mothers' Meeting - many women, many babies and no air!
(Wynne cut out and pasted in an Editorial, "The Hour of Peril" - it began: "Hatred, strife and bloodshed are before us. This is no time for Party recriminations or for attempts to apportion blame. We are on the verge of disaster almost unthinkably awful to Radical and Unionist alike. In the name of God let us remember that we are brethren, and resolve that, come what may, we will not imbrue our hands in one another's blood." People were talking about civil war, and for a time the country did appear to be on the verge of collapsing into anarchy...yet another example of the way the issues associated with Ireland affected Britain.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The Home Rule crisis, as recorded in the diary...Wynne also cut out and stuck in Editorial articles, poems and other clippings....scroll down for the editorial.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
March 24th - 31st

The Irish Crisis continues, but gradually calms down. One of several major crises that affected Britain in the months prior to the War.
viewer_10.description:
March 24th, Tuesday
Following the resignations at the Curragh (the British Army base in Ireland) comes news yesterday of Brig. Gen John Gough's resignation here in sympathy with his brother. All Heads over there were sent for and after interviews with the King and the Govt. their resignations have not been accepted and to use a vulgar term they have returned with their "tongue in their cheek" I should fancy. The Govt. have now given their solemn assurance that the Army shall not be used to coerce Ulster, but they will of course persist in their determination to enforce Home Rule and how in the face of armed opposition are they going to install it in Ulster without military coercion?! It is all a frightful tangle and of all people Asquith's position is the least enviable at the moment. One can see no way out of it and all one wonders now is what is the next step to be? It is indeed "in the lap of the gods".

March 25th
This being the Mothers Union Day Lady Day we had our annual service up at St. Marks and the Missioner. Mr Spittal who takes the weekly Lenten services came and took it for us. He is a very earnest and fluent speaker but sometimes he strikes rather too much of a theatrical note for my sober taste and it jars. We had a big meeting and in the evening at 8.0 attended the usual week day service, also held by him. There were not so many present as usual on account I fancy of a Conservative Meeting at the club which I was sorry to have missed. Political news is quieter, rumours of Winston Churchill and Seely having overstepped the mark in despatching troops to Ulster, and it is said that Seely will have to resign, Mr Asquith declaring it has all been a misunderstanding!!

March 26th
The Morning Post brings news that Seely has tendered his resignation and it has been refused! Of course it would be and I.C. (in the Post) expresses himself thus!! but there are big rows ahead and someone I fancy will have to be thrown to the wolves for this...
(Wynne has stuck in the IC poem printed in the Post:
The Secretary of War,
That gallantest of men,
He walked out of his Office,
And then walked in again.

And all his Party cries,
In jubilant elation,
"This great self-sacrifice
Has saved the situation")

March 28th, Saturday
On this day we went to Town for Capt. Trench's wedding, his bride is a whole head taller than he, rather nice looking, and the show was a very pretty one.

March 29th, Sunday
A day of leisure as usual, what should I do without this day. To Church this evening.

March 30th
I have given up my German. I find I have no time to prepare in Spring when the garden calls so what is the use of struggling. MM as usual, and the Wynters and Macdonalds came to tea, the W's bringing with them a lot of books on the Tyrol and photos which are of great interest to us, hoping as we are to go there this summer.

March 31st
The detested Black Letter Day has arrived and my Poggy is now a thing of "nearly nowt". From today on he goes on half pay and is officially a Colonel again! It seems so odd and strange to be ones own master and certainly in some ways brings relief for I have cast from me Shirts, SSJA etc etc and the time is close at hand when my Parish work will cease also!

march.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband is commanding the Artillery.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is the photo Wynne is referring to on May 3rd. Wynne is the young girl in front of the stool, and her sister Eve sits to the right. It is Eve you can see in the final picture this month, taken in India. Here she is about 19 - in the other picture she is over 40.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 7th

Cold weather and numerous chores as Wynne's duties begin to wind down
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Friday
May Day and I'm glad they haven't chosen me for Queen of the May as a strong N.E.Wind is blowing and its bitterly cold, one feels it so after the very hot spell we've been having. I went duly round my district today and saw all my folk but one and so that jobs jobbed thanks be. After lunch the children begged to go to the Horse Pond to sail their boats. Oh! the trial so I went with them very grumpily and unwillingly and we spent a very cold afternoon!

May 2nd
A busy but a pottering day doing a thousand odd jobs.

May 3rd
This strange relic of the past taken by Neville in 1891 arrived yesterday by the mail with a letter to Gran of congratulations on her birthday, I have shrieked over it, I must have been 12 and Eve only 19. She looks 100. Gran looks the best. (See in previous window). Nice letters from Eve and Ell, both had been and were on jungle expeditions, Ell very far in the wilds and enjoying it all, I envy them.

May 4th
A very busy day. Took the children down to be photographed in the morning where we were nearly 2 hours! I do hope some will be a success. I then had a hurried lunch and went up and took my last Mothers Meeting. What was my surprise to find a very nice pair of brass candlesticks on the table as a parting present. I thought it so nice of them, one values such things very much.

May 5th, Tuesday
My dear son's last day at home. We took all 3 children to Town, dropped them first at the flat and went to Tressider to see him about houses then back and picked up the 3 and dropped Pink at Paddington where I was sad to see the last of him, dear child. We then went on, did some shopping and ended up going to a RHS show where we saw some beautiful flowers, then home and H returned.

May 6th
Ami took the girlies to the Natural H Museum, much to their joy, whilst I went off and did a long morning at the stores for Mabel (her sister-in-law, a missionary in Portuguese East Africa). Then after lunch I took them to Scolls Cinema and was joined by Mrs Skippy and so home by the 5.55

May 7th
E.S. motored me over to Miss Woodward to have my skirts tried on and H went down to have his photo taken in uniform, such a business. My afternoon was spent in pottering and gardening but it was icy cold and blowy and I didn't enjoy it much.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The Royal Engineers concert programme for May 12th: Mendelsohnn, Dvorak, Puccini, Saint-Saens, Liszt, Massenet, Wagner.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 8th - 14th

Anniversaries, flying accidents, and other events. Contracts are exchanged on Brookfield, the old family home
viewer_4.description:
May 8th, Friday
Up with the lark this morning as the blessed sun put in an appearance again but such a high wind and by breakfast it was horrid. H dined this evening with Skippy at the Mess, it was quite sad to see him go off in mufti but these things come to all. She came in and dined with me, she is a dear thing and I'm awfully fond of her. We shall miss them so when we leave, that sort of thing is horrid.

May 9th
The cold is awful and one feels its so after the very hot spell we have been having. It is so sunless too and windy and this afternoon we went to the R.E. (Royal Engineers) sports with the Skippys after lunching with them. We stayed there till 5.30, a very smart and well done affair but it was too cold to enjoy.

May 10th
19 years ago today I was confirmed, it seems 2000. How well I remember driving over to Spetisbury (in Dorset, near the family home at Tarrant Keyneston) in the carriage with Father whilst Eve and Mother came in the dog cart. A pouring cold wet day it has been and to church with the Bacons in their car. My dear Gran has been full of wild fancies today and very difficult to deal with.


May 11th
In Mother's letter yesterday there was enclosed the letter from S.A &L.saying they had exchanged contracts with Colonel Chapman's solicitors and so dear old Brookfield is no longer ours, much as I regret it and sad though I am to think it belongs to others yet it has been such a worry for so long in many ways that it is a relief to feel we are quit of it. We go down about the 30th with Mother to settle all final arrangements.

May 12th
We lunched at the Ss today going on with them to the R.E.concert at the the club, a huge gathering and a very good concert. Whilst there a horrible air accident occurred not far off, 2 machines collidng killing 2 men, and several of those waiting outside saw it happen. So sad and horrible. Dined at the Watson's this evening, they leave on the 10th June.

May 13th, Wednesday
A free morning spent in house chores and down to Farnham to settle about H's photos, we now await them all with interest. He was also done in colour photography to add to her collection. I wish we could run to that but they are £5.5.0 to £10.10.0, "too moch". (I have no idea what Wynne is referring to, but the "her" must have an accent...perhaps a relative with lots of money?)
After lunch we attended the annual Missionary Meeting. Curiously enough the man who spoke, Archdeacon Gillet, came from Mabel's place and had seen her in March.

May 14th
I was glad to see the Birches today, a breath of the Military World! and to hear Camp news of them. The two Bacons came in to dine and afterwards we played games till 11. I am so regretting the time when we shall see them all no more.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The much loved garden, where Wynne spent as much time as she could - and now, in the summer of , both she and her husband could indulge themselves on his retirement. The girl in both pictures is Win Lees, Wynne's niece (Eve's daughter) who like all children of the English in India, spent most of her childhood away from her parents. The dog is Peter, often referred to in the diaries.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 15th - 21st

Pleasures in London, including the Chelsea Flower Show, and house hunting in Ipswich.
viewer_6.description:
May 15th, Friday/May 16th, Saturday
These two days that I bracket as one have been free days, no one came and no one went and we had them absolutely to ourselves to do with as we liked, and a great joy it has been.

May 17th, Sunday
A perfect day, so lovely that I went actually to the Park after lunch with Capt Skippy and there walked and walked most thoroughly enjoying the perfect Spring colouring, the scent of the May blossom and all the multitude of birds which sing there.

May 18th
At 10.2 this morning we left for Town, and are to be away till next Saturday house hunting in Suffolk. On arrival we drove to the H.P. Hotel where the dear Grays made us their guests for the night and in the evening H went with Major Gray to the Mafeking Dinner whilst she and I went to see du Maurier in "The Clever Ones", an amusing piece in which he is very clever. We all assembled later at the Carlton, the men bringing with them Major du Plat Taylor who I hadn't seen for twelve and a half years! He is just as wizened a monkey as he was the day he acted "best man" for H. He is now married himself and has a daughter, really the odd things people do marry, and she a woman with money and property.

May 19th
Another glorious day, quite hot and and 12 we took the Grays to the Chelsea Flower Show, meeting Skippy at the gate. Oh! my eye! and my hat! what perfection in horticulture, roses, lilies, sweet peas, carnations and a thousand other things, rock garden, rose gardens, japonese ditto, everything one could think of. I just revelled and spent the whole day there with an interval for lunch to which we all went to Mother. H and I spent this night with her and all went to see "My Lady's Dress", Knoblauch's new play with Dennis Eadie and Gladys Cooper in it. I was very much interested, a most uncommon and exciting play but pathetic for the most part though very true to life. The Gray's left us after lunch and we were sad to say goodbye to them.

May 20th
The anniversary of my Father's death. How long ago it seems since I saw him. We left Town for Ipswich by the 11.40 and arrived about 2, going to the Great White Horse. Soon after White T came in, he is stationed here, and we went out into the town to agents and to hire a motor to view 3 houses. This we spent the afternoon in doing but none were any use and country not particularly inviting. We got back about 6 and had dinner after which we found our way to White T's quarters where we sat talking till 10.30. When we returned to the hotel we found a seething mass of people collected there, this is election week and Masterman has come down to contest the seat with Ganzoni the Unionist and as this hotel is his headquarters the people remained singing, cheering, booing and stamping outside till nearly midnight. It was a wonderful sight. (Masterman must be Charles Masterman, serving in Asquith's government. In the February election he lost his seat in Bethnal Green, London, and was sent to Ipswich to contest what was presumably thought to be a safe seat. Ganzoni, who had been put up by the Ulster Unionists, stood against him. See May 27th for the result.)

May 21st
Early this morning we chartered a car for the day and set forth on a further tour, finishing up in the evening at Yoxford having done 60 or 70 miles and having seen 8 or 9 houses. Alas none of them suit us for some were too large or too small, too dear or too vile. The nicest is here in Yoxford, it is called Satis House and is to be sold by auction on the 11th but it is too large and we are afraid of it, but such a pretty garden and such heaps of nice old rooms. This village too is quite the quaintest and most typically old English village I've ever seen, the surrounding country also is just lovely and we have determined to live in this neighbourhood.

We stayed at the Three Tuns Inn and here is a picture of the quaint old place. There is a lovely bowling green where the village "bloods" come and play of an evening and the house is kept by an aged dame and her daughter and an aged serving wench.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: "My Lady's Dress" intrigued Wynne enough for her to add this review from the paper, of which I copy the beginning. The cast list is below it:

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 22nd - 27th

Back from Suffolk, where an election caused a major political upset. Another flying accident.
viewer_8.description:
May 22nd, Friday
Our route yesterday lay by Woodbridge and Saxmundham etc, and I must say all along the country delighted us, it looked its very best, the fresh Spring green and the masses of May blossom, lilacs and laburnham filling the air with their scent. The country is slightly undulating and very much wooded and has a most friendly appearance. We left early this morning, taking the train at Darsham for Ipswich, where we had an hour to wait, went and interviewed the agents again and then rushed off to see a house at Yaxley which was a hideous beast. A nice old boo boo clergyman showed us over it and then took us over his most interesting old church. The Suffolk churches are really very find and so old and full of history. We returned to Town this evening and spent the night at the Liverpool Hotel - a wild thunderstorm raged for a long time making a fearful noise.

May 23rd
We returned home today after our fruitless but very pleasant job - called in and had lunch at Mothers and went down by the 3.5.

May 24th
A horrid cold and gloomy day and so different from last Sunday. Ell this week has sent me these photos of Seryah, so nice to have, he seems to have a very good time if pretty hard work. (You can see two of the photos further on - obviously taken by Ell as he is not in them. His sister Eve was obviously there to help sort the bachelor out!)

May 25th
My "old man of the sea", "Veaky" (this was Veacroft, Wynne's female cook), left us today. I can hardly believe she is actually gone. For 4 whole years have we done battle together and now it is over, I shan't know myself. I have a Mrs Amey coming in on Friday, until which day Bessie turns cook.

May 26th, Tuesday
I went to Liphook to try skirts. So cold, just like winter, and 3 degrees frost last night.

May 27th
Derby Day! and a lovely one. I like to think of the thousands of people who have been on the go ever since dawn today to attend this great annual picnic, what fun it must be. I've only been once and that was in the coach days just about 15 years ago. Now there is hardly a horse to be seen there except the race horses and in time I suppose people will fly to it. Talking of flying, poor Hamel the great "looper" has been lost on the Channel. He was to have taken part in the Derby flying race and has simply disappeared. It's too sad, what a lot have been killed lately. I forgot to add to my Sunday entry that we heard that morning of Masterman's defeat at Ipswich by a majority of over 500 votes. They say the town went mad and the Unionist ...and Ulster can hardly contain themselves. (Masterman was Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, so this sent a very strong message to the Asquith government. The other news item of note, the death of the airman, was something that crops up a lot in Wynne's pre-war diaries. The rate of attrition for young pilots even before the War seems to have been high).

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
These are pictures taken at Seryah, the estate in India where Wynne's brother Elliot lived. The picture, probably being taken by Ell, consists of a typical house-party, including Wynne and Ell's sister, Eve. . She is second from the left, and was perhaps there to act as hostess in what was a bachelor establishment.

From left to right, Miss Howard, Eve Lees, Campbell, Amy Foley, Foley, Douglas Smith.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
May 28th - 31st

Wynne and Herbert travel to Brookfield to help her Mother pack up the old house. The Empress of Ireland liner sinks.
viewer_10.description:
May 28th, Thursday
A lovely day of gardening. Just ran the pony down into Farnham in the morning with Poggy and then filled the day with house chores and garden. There is so much to be done before we leave and though I am longing for the trip I wish it were possible to be at two places at once for the place is really going to be very pretty this year.

May 29th
Poggy had to go to Town to his dentist today and brought Mother back with him in time for tea, she spends tonight here and we all go down to B (Brookfield) tomorrow for the final turning out. They bring with them from Town a fearful piece of news, a huge liner, the Empress of Ireland, has been run into by a coaler and a loss of a 1000 lives is feared. It equals the Titanic in horror and we anxiously await the papers tomorrow. It happened in the mouth of the St. Lawrence.


May 30th
At 10.0 this morning arrived Maggie and Ninian Elliot in their car which they lent us to go down to B in. We took them as far as the station in Farnham and then proceeded on our way via Alton, Winchester, Romsey and New Forest. Halfway we had a fearful bust of a tyre, the outer case blowing out, so we sat by the roadside whilst Frank put on another. We reached home about 2.30 and found the maids there had lunch and quickly set to to work on the books lying at (sic) the billiard room, gradually doing them all, such a work there are hundreds of them and with great difficulty I persuaded Mother to cast any! It seems so odd to be here again, dear beloved old place, but oh! I am glad it is going into good hands and its future is secured. How awful it would be to have it on our hands anymore.



May 31st
The papers yesterday were full of news of the awful tragedy that befell the Empress of Ireland. To think of the poor wretched victims asleep one moment and almost immediately she sank, it is all too frightful and it is only two years ago that the Titanic went down. This morning Poggy and I went to early service. I went round to look at Father's grave and took some flowers there, it was very neat and tidy and well looked after. We have an arrangement with Thick to keep it so. We then worked hard all day at china and papers and went to Evensong at 6.30. I felt very sad to think that that was the last time I should sit in the little church, the new parson Mr Cooper preached very nicely and seems liked but is not at all strong.

may.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She is living near Aldershot, where her husband is commanding the Artillery. He is about to retire.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This is a picture of a proud boy. William Gilham was the Jackson's stable and garden boy at Hale. This is a classic example of the sort of opportunity the War afforded people. By signing up, William was able to break away from the rigid old systems. He had a remarkable war, which changed his life, and you can follow his story throughout this diary. (Check out May 28th 1915, Jan 6th 1916 for his news from the Front, and May 15th 1918 for a letter. A later one written on July 27th is also transcribed, and you can see a photo in November 1918)
Or you can go to the Editor's Picks, and follow the links from that page.

By the side of the photo Wynne has written: "William Gillum, the soldier of Upton Lodge" which is interesting, as she clearly had no idea how to spell his surname. Presumably he had always simply been Willie to her. By the time they are corresponding in 1915 she has got it right!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 1st - 6th

Amidst mounting losses, and missing her husband, Wynne manages to continue the daily round: Mothers' Meetings and Guy Fawkes fireworks
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Sunday
Time passes and here once more is All Saints Day. What countless thousands are mourning their nearest and dearest today, think of the huge Church Festivals abroad and of the many horrible losses which all big nations and poor Belgium has suffered since this day last year. It is too tragic for words. At Church today and this evening we had my two favourite hymns - "For all the Saints" and "The Saints of God" and I stayed to communion and wished my man beside me.

November 2nd
Mondays hold little else save Mothers Meetings for me. I had the usual large gathering and after it went on to the Chapel Service where the list of Hale soldiers and sailors gets longer and longer.

November 3rd
A letter from my man dated 29th, all well with them so far thank God. Fierce fighting, perpetual shelling and enormous losses on both sides. The papers are full of a great charge by the London Scottish and we fear for Bill who is sure to have been in it. There isn't an account of it. I drove down to Farnham. I've just taken the pony up, she looks like a woolly bear and I can't find anyone to clip her.
(Bill is Bill Fallowfield, Wynne's cousin - the man who sent her the Field Card you can see in October's section).

November 4th
We are having the most beautiful weather - fine days and brilliant moonlight night and I am hard at the garden, both herbaceous borders are being taken up this year and re dug and its a great work, but Oh! how I miss my man at it.

November 5th, Thursday
This being Guy Fawkes day we of course had to have the usual display!! and Baker and Johnnie managed them outside the drawing room window. Halfway through the performance we heard wild shrieks as of a demented pig, Johnnie having got one into his boot! ES and Skippy came in after tea, he is home again now. I'm afraid alas his foot won't keep him home for long.

November 6th
Alas a great disappointment, a letter came from H and on opening it I found it to be dated 24th. He had given it to a man who came home wounded and who evidently had forgotten to post it. I bicycled down to Farnham work house sale and met Mrs Winwood on the way who told me poor Capt. Crawshay is killed. Only 4 of the original officers of the 5th DGs left.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A typical open page from November - the card was from a friend, who I think must have been serving with the French (liaison, perhaps?). It contains a hurried scribble in pencil, thanking her for her letter, and had been censored (the stamp in the small window you clicked from). Below it is a list of the British Convoy that brought the Canadian contingent over. Wynne notes that Herman, her cousin, is on it. Herman was a von Poellnitz, fighting on the British side.
On the opposite page she pasted in a long list of the officers promoted in the RH and RFA...as she says, everyone moved up to fill in the gaps. However what became a nightmare for her was the fact that as you can see from the underlining, she knew so many of them...and so many of them did not survive. By 1916 she was close to a breakdown...which explains her desire to move away from Aldershot.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 7th - 13th

The reality of war dawned early for those associated with the Regular Army. The losses mount, and Wynne finds it hard to cope. She goes to London to help her Mother move into a new flat.
viewer_4.description:
November 7th, Saturday
I hear also that Mr Welch has lost his son, his only child. It's awfully sad for he has nothing else. Major Newcome has been wounded again and this afternoon Mrs Fitz tells me Capt. Trench is killed, how absolutely tragic it all is and one begins to wonder who is left. It has been such a lovely day today and to complete the glory of it I had 2 letters at lunch dated 2nd and 3rd, such interesting ones and full of detail. All well so far with the Staff but even H seems surprised at that. He has had no blankets for some days and sleeps on a mattress on the floor wrapped in a chintz curtain and spends the day in a dug out under ground. He tells me Capt. Douglas is badly hit so that is why Major Salt has taken his place.

Nov 8th, 9th, Sunday and Monday
To church and naught else, and Monday spent in Mothers Meeting and finishing odd jobs before going tomorrow to Town with Mother.

November 10th, Tuesday.
We started off today bag and baggage for London and went to the Knightsbridge Hotel where we are putting up till the flat is ready. After lunch we drove there to meet the owner's representative to arrange about a doorway which has to be made between the two sitting rooms.

November 11th
We have a most delightful suite of rooms here, 2 bedrooms and a bathroom opening on to a little passage. The food is good and very clean and the prices very moderate. We went to the flat again and then I called on the Todds and found all most amiable - very nice old friends.

November 12th
This morning I spent with the dentist and Douglas! (her hairdresser) and wild shopping for we can't get into the flat yet, and then to tea came the Frank Jacksons and we dined at the H.P. with the dear Grays. He has Major Kelly's billet at the W.O. as he is not fit to return to the Front and Major K is now Col. Every gunner I know is promoted.

November 13th, Friday
Times are so interesting I should like to write yards for every day, but my space is so limited I must refrain. I have been very lucky in getting several letters from H. They are holding Ypres and having a very stiff time with many miraculous escapes, it all rather raises ones hair but thank God so far he is well. I went down to Bayswater to see Mr Lindsell's 3 sisters, poor girls, they are living in a Club having neither Father or Mother.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Here is a cutting about the War off the East African Coast...the Konigsberg and the Emden were the only effective ships there, and the Australian Navy intervened and managed to destroy the Emden, but the Konigsberg proved more difficult, and was only finally put out of action in 1915. Her guns eventually went down to Lake Tanganyika where they were mounted on another warship...for the intriguing story about this back-water in the War, see Giles Foden's "Mimi and Toutou Go Forth".
