For the later story, check out the Wiki entry.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 14th - 20th

15 or the 18 officers Wynne knew at Hale, near Farnham, are now dead. The family friend Lord Roberts also dies, in France. Wynne is still in London helping in the flat.
viewer_6.description:
November 14th, Saturday
More shoppings for Flat and Front, very busy days and very comfy nights, early to bed and late to rise, very nice! News from the Front still brings desperate accounts
of wild fighting and every inch of ground is being severely contested, its all very awful and every casualty list seems to hold the name of somebody one knows. Out of Hale's 18 officers, 15 are killed and wounded. Poor Mrs Croft has lost her son now.

November 15th
I went twice today to Holy Trinity and enjoyed two beautiful services, such music and such excellent sermons, it is a treat. Owing to Lord Roberts' death the news of which we heard last night we had the Dead March and it was awfully grand and most impressive.

November 16th, Monday
Lord Roberts' death came as a great shock and surprise to us all. He went over to France to see the Indian troops, got pneumonia and died at once, but it was really a most fitting end to a grand life, dear good old man. The whole Nation and indeed the world will mourn him. This afternoon we started at the Flat, the furniture began to pour in and chaos reigns!

November 17th
More chaos but all is in now, such a lot of furniture I never did see such crowds of linen, bone china, glass, plate and ornaments, all the stuff from Brookfield as well as the Flat! but soon all will be in order.

November 18th
The two maids Mother engaged arrived today, they are sisters and alas won't suit at all, most odd familiar manners and the HP is a lunatic with adenoids, alas and alas!

November 19th, Thursday
I went yesterday at 1.0 to meet my babies and Miss Male for their yearly shopping at the Bon Marché. They arrived green bags and all and we shopped till it was time for them to go home dear things. Both these days were spent in wild skirmishings with sofas, chairs and household gods, real hard labour and we actually slept in the place this night the 20th...Rita also who arrived at 3.0. Aim and Nora have been awfully kind and all is fairly straight and this afternoon all came to tea, also Brenda and Gertie. B is now established at Chislehurst with her children whilst her man is at the Front. He has written her that their Battery has received congratulations from K and French, splendid. G tells me CWM is just going out - I do wish I could see him.
(This entry describes the annual ritual for the children who were taken to Brixton to do their Christmas shopping. The people mentioned are all relatives, except Gertie, who was Gertie Maclean, Charles' sister. Charles was Wynne's first love and is mentioned in the Love section)

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Lord Roberts was a family friend - his relationship with Herbert dated from the latter's time in India in the previous century...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 21st - 25th

Wynne leaves her Mother and London, driving through a city now in darkness: this is one of the first blackouts caused by the recent Zeppelin raids. The 20th Century really is beginning.
viewer_8.description:
November 21st, Saturday
Alas I had to leave Mother today to return as I cannot desert my family any more. I am very much shocked to hear that poor Baker has lost his wife. A child was born on Wed. at 6.0 and at 8.30 she died of heart failure. The baby, a girl, is strong and well of course. Wow has had another fearful fit today and is really very ill but he will recover I feel sure. Meanwhile it is really dreadful for Aim. (Wow was Aimee Fallowfield's second husband, and step-father to Bill).
Well I really think all is fairly straight now and it is very pretty, a large flat with 2 big sitting rooms, and a hall that Mother uses as a dining room. 3 nice bedrooms, bathroom, kitchen, servant's room and a long passage. Large windows commanding extensive views and the sun streams in all day long. It is near bus and tube and is altogether much nicer than Chelsea. I came away at 5.0 and I shall never forget the scene that I drove through. In consequence of the Zeppelin raid fears all lights are darkened now and very few are lit at all, my road lay up Cromwell Road past Hyde Park through Birdcage Walk and over and past Westminster. All was dark and gloomy, every light on street and shop window shaded and from the top of H.P.Arch (Hyde Park) there gleamed the searchlights piercing the gloom with their long rays and casting an unearthly light on the darkened buildings beneath. Buckingham Palace was quite dark and only 3 of the many lights at the gates were lit. The Houses and the Abbey stood also dark and silent on the river's edge whilst 5 different searchlights played over the sky and the young moon hung low and yellow over all. It was a most impressive sight. (This description sounds so strange in 1914 - it could have been written in 1939).

November 22nd
The weather has turned bitterly cold and my poor dear writes that they are having snow. I've ordered a patent fur coat to be despatched to him from Cording. It is on its way and I've ordered a pair of long waterproof boots for him too. (Readers might be interested to know that Cordings still exists, and you can see pictures of the store as it was when Wynne visited it hanging on the walls of their shop in Piccadilly. They have a site too: <www.cordings.com>)

November 23rd
I've never felt it so cold in Nov. One feels literally black with it, a biting east wind, its just too fearful. I attended poor Mrs Baker's funeral today, I can't realize she is really dead. I went down and saw her this morning, poor woman, she at least is free from trouble.

November 24th
Two letters from my dearest, after several weeks continuous fighting they have been drawn back for a rest. I am thankful for it. They badly needed it. The losses of the 7th Division have been frightful and I really think none have had a harder time.

November 25th
This book is getting so uncomfortable to write in I am pining to begin a new one, would that it could begin in Peace. One gets so tired, so sick of this beastly war and it will drag on for months I know. Everyone I know is at it and so many old friends are dead whilst more are wounded and one is just tired of it all. I drove into Farnham and saw Gen Percival who is home on leave for a week. It was interesting and brought it very near home. Dined at the the Skippy's today, it is his birthday, and when he went to the War he said he would be home by this day to drink champagne. (And he was, but wounded - everyone thought it would be over by Christmas).

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Wynne stuck in this cutting on November 19th - no one could say that the realities of the War were not being transmitted fairly graphically...or that information from little known Fronts was not available. As the writer concludes, "Here is a battle which in numbers engaged and , no doubt, in losses far exceeds the struggle at Waterloo or Gettysburg, yet so vast is the conflict now that even this terrible spot is almost overlooked, and probably not one man in 10 who reads these lines has heard of the name of this village, for the sake of holding which thousands of men are now mouldering in unnamed graves."
Nevertheless, this seems to me to be an exceptional report - utterly graphic, sparing no one. I wonder if different rules apply, since this is from a front line with no British troops present. I wonder also at the Austrian losses - you come across memorials (there is one in Vienna) to this battle, but with little evidence that they are still remembered.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
November 26th - 30th

"A hateful and anxious month". Diary entries become very thin. Things get quieter on Herbert's Front and Wynne hopes he might get home on a visit.
viewer_10.description:
November 26th, Thursday
Shirts! again. ES and I bicycled in rain and wind, not at all enjoyable.

November 27th
A letter from my dearest, they are all resting now and they need it, poor 7th Division how they have suffered.

November 28th, Saturday
My days are full of chores and so the time goes, I am very lucky in hearing from H. He is awfully good about writing and has a bit more leisure now that they have been drawn off, thank God for it one can get a moments peace of mind now-a-days.

November 29th
Three letters from H! including one dated 27th which he has sent home by hand of Capt Leefe who has arrived for a weeks leave. All seems quiet with them and he says the quiet and sense of peace is almost uncanny. Yesterday I met Major Newcome, he too is home for 3 days, all this seems a good sign and I am hoping that my man too may return on the same errand soon.

November 30th
The last day of a hateful and anxious month. I shall never forget Nov/14 so long as I live. I go tomorrow to Malvern to see Pink for 2 days.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
This is a photo of Maggie and her family. Maggie had lived with the family for many years and looked after the children, but left to set up on her own just before the War. She continued to keep in touch, and I managed to meet her once, in 1960, but I was too young to ask the serious questions! I think her husband survived the war, but she lost a son in World War 2.
She was greatly missed by Wynne - and you can see other pictures of her and children elsewhere.

...and on November 25th Wynne stuck in this intriquing little cutting:

november.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She manages her daily chores, but the new is not good.

Zeppelin raids in London force the first blackouts.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The open pages from Wynne's diary that she describes on October 1st. The diaries are full of cuttings like these. Below them is
I have copied the clipping about the Contemptibles...the Old Contemptibles were from the first regular divisions that set foot in France: 1st - 6th Division. Herbert, who was in the 7th, did not strictly come under that title.
Below that is the full article that lies under the small cutting - I have copied only the beginning.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 5th

The agony of parting. Herbert prepares to go the Front with the 7th Division, and the children come on a final visit. The day of departure is chaotic.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Tuesday
I insert today 2 most interesting articles on the stricken towns in the wake of the Germans, also a splendid account of the battle of La Cateau. These show most vividly the horrors of war, everything in the papers is such interesting reading now just like a wonderful history book (which you can see in the first viewer page of this sequence). This is the hottest October 1st I've ever known, I am in a cotton dress again and Bede and I went with Mrs Cavendish and her people to watch the Field Day, taking our lunch. We were right in the middle of it all the time and saw everything so well. Bede left today so in H's absence I am alone again a good deal of the day, but this I never mind and today I was able to motor down to the 22nd Brigade camp with H and on our way back looked in on Violet Wright who we met there by chance - her man is now A.S.C.

October 2nd
Today a great joy occurred. Mother, Mrs Skippy and the two children (Ysobel and Eleanore) motored over all the way from home and spent the day with us. They arrived about 12.30 and as the Division were up digging we took lunch out on to Beaulieu Heath where we found them all busy at trenches etc. Very soon H joined us and Capt. Rawlins and we gave the remainder of our lunch to poor passing Tommies who gratefully clawed in whatever they could get. We then returned to tea going to feed the horses before hand. I have tonight received a list of the men on H's staff, I am enlisting the interest of the other staff ladies and am going to see what can be done for their comfort whilst they are abroad as they belong to no unit and will get badly left if someone doesn't take it up. I insert here an extract from an order of the Kaiser, and the Times' Military Correspondent's remarks thereon. Comment is needless!
(This was the famous order which mentioned the "contemptible little army" ).

October 3rd
We live on a veritable volcano these days thinking each day that the next is to be the last, but now it is not thought that they will move till Monday, so perhaps we shall see another sunday together in peace. My morning was spent in various errands for H and after lunch we motored together to Southampton, then to tea cam the Wrights and Mr Lindsell. Violet W looks so aged and worn, I fancy she has gone through some bad times. We had a great excitement in the Hotel tonight - I had gone out for a minute to get something at a shop near by, the "Town" was particularly full of soldiers being Sat, and when I came back after an absence of two minutes I found the Hotel quite dark, surrounded by a mass of men who also were pouring out of the house, and on enquiring ascertained there was a fire in the back premises! I, Mrs C and Mrs Leate went at once to the office where they despatched a picket but very soon it was put out and calm restored!

October 4th, Sunday
It has indeed been a day of uncertainty and alarms. Poggy was able to come to Kirk at 11.0 and we stayed to sacrament. After lunch we walked to the Heavy camp, then to his own, and to tea, after which he went to Office and I sat down to write. Not long afterwards H came in and said "We've got our order to start at 12.30 tonight" - so we set about and packed. He later returned to Office and found they were trying to arrange to start at 8.30 tomorrow morning instead, and Capt Rawlins came in about 10.0 to say they had done so and went to bed about 11.30. He came again to say it was changed to 6.30 and at 1.30 he came once more to say it was 8.30!! All the night too troops were passing it seemed, the little town ringing with their cheers of "Are we downhearted" etc, so what with that and ones own anxiety we got but little sleep.

Wynne's photo, taken from her hotel room, of some of the 7th Division marching through Lyndhurst.

You can read about the 7th Division by clicking here. The web site, The Long Long Trail, is a wonderful source for the war.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A typical postcard of the period...and an article about the sort of kit required at the front. With the postcard, Wynne also added a cutting about a General Staff chauffeur doing his morning toilet: "After washing his hands and face in a saucepan minus handle, which he has balanced on an empty petrol-can, he carefully brushes his hair with an old nail-brush, using the window of the car, in which he has slept, as a looking-glass."
(The italics are in the original!)

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 6th - 12th

Herbert sails across the Channel safely, to an unknown destination. Wynne returns home to submerge herself in daily chores, trying not to think about the War.
viewer_4.description:
October 5th, Monday
At half past 6 we got up and had our breakfast. At 7.30 poor Poggy couldn't shave or even wash his teeth as all his baggage had gone. At 8.15 we walked down to the Grand Hotel where in company with all the rest of the Staff my dear man left me, motoring in to Southampton. A diary is not the place in which to express one's feelings, but all the world knows what a woman feels when this sort of thing happens, the feeling of desolation which settles upon one and the prospect of the future which stretches ahead into a series of endless tomorrows. I motored to Brockenhurst and there caught our train. Arrived home at 4.0. I found all well at home.

October 6th
I got a line from H just before he sailed for the unknown port, how much they are all in our thoughts. I heard also from Bill (her cousin, Bill Fallowfield) whose P.C. I here insert, a curious object, the censorship is so strict that all letters are opened and read. A busy day and many chores performed. Already I have had most generous response to my appeal for the staff: $7.10.0 and 2lbs of tobacco. It's most gratifying.

For message on back, see below

October 7th
What can I say these days, I don't feel inclined for Diaries or letters or anything. Life seems so objectless at present. Soon however I will buck up and take up the threads again.

October 8th
My days are full, I do a dozen chores always. I went into Aldershot to do some shopping, the place is full of K's army in the queerest kit possible. (A reference to the influx of new volunteers - Kitchener's Army).

October 9th
Today amongst my letters I found a letter from my dearest, no one can tell what a joy it was to me, it was written at sea on the day he sailed but posted on landing so I know they got over in safety anyhow. Thank God for that, for I believe the safe convoying of these transports is a matter of hideous anxiety to the Admiralty. He wrote at length and said they were having a smooth crossing, they then(the Staff) had had to change ships at the last moment as they found the 1st one did not sail till Tuesday, and Gen Capper was anxious to be over there early. Where they landed is of course shrouded in mystery.

October 10th
Kind friends continue to send me money, tobacco and garments for the men. It is so ripping to have had this kind of generous response. Antwerp is at present much on our minds, though considered impregnable its fall is hourly expected.

October 11th, Sunday
Today's paper brings the sad news of the fall of Antwerp, and gives the most distressing account of the wretched refugees who are swarming into Holland. They say that when the Germans entered the town they found a mere shell, no people, no provisions or material of any sort, just a dead city. Its all fearful, and I here insert some accounts of it. (More cuttings, not shown here)

October 12th
The Hamster's birthday, we heard from Leila today. She is at Ouchy and stays there. She says she constantly hears from him, that he is well and naturally takes the German view of things. (Wynne's Uncle Walter was in Munich, an example of how the war divided families as well as states. The family found itself literally face to face, one von Poellnitz dying on the English side).
Oh! dear, my first Mothers Meeting today and I entered about 36. It seems quite natural to be there again amongst all the old lot, little did I think last year that I should be at it again this year, supposing one had been able to see ahead!! how awful.

The Field Service cards were the censored way of communicating - you simply crossed out the lines that did not apply. As you can see - not much could be communicated!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Prayers in the field - these are Catholic soldiers at an open-air Mass.

And this is a photo of some of the first German prisoners arriving in England
I wonder how many of the men praying survived...and whether the Germans here realised how lucky they were to be out of it....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 13th - 18th

Despondency at home as news of the revolt in South Africa and the relentless German advance depresses everyone. Wynne receives her first letters from the Front.
viewer_6.description:
October 13th, Tuesday
My Diary somehow since H went has lost its interest to me. I don't somehow seem to have the heart to write properly in it, yet its stupid feeling like that for life in all its little ways must go one for us women. anyhow I've been awfully bucked today by getting a PC from him, saying all's well and dated the 9th. I happen to know now that they landed at Ostend and it affrights me to think of their being in that part of the country. Mrs Leefe came and had tea today, quite a nice little creature but also quite uninteresting.

October 14th
News of revolt at the Cape today, one Maritz, a Lt. Colonel commandant has turned traitor, Martial law is proclaimed, and there's no end of a row there. It is the result of a long German intrigue, they are brutes. (There is plenty of interesting information about this little remembered revolt on the various sites if you are interested, so here is the wiki link. Wynne was interested because of the family connections and the fact that Herbert had been out there for the SA War. See below for an Afrikaans version of a familiar marching song).

October 15th, Thursday
The German march to the Coast continues, they have entered Ghent now and Bruges and rumour has it that they are nearing Ostend. How weird to think our 7th Division landed there only about a week ago, the last of our troops to land there I fancy. I have heard since from a man in the know at the Admiralty that at the time they crossed 3 German submarines were in the Channel waiting for a chance! An awful thought. I went down to Aldershot to shop today, there one meets nowadays hundreds and thousands of K's Army drilling and working hard, some dressed in scarlet with Brodericks, others in dark blue with forage caps, it is a curious sight. Many scares of a raid upon the hangars at Farnboro are abroad, all lights are put out at night and a searchlight plays about constantly.

October 16th
Thank goodness I am each day more busy than I can say. Today I've been doing the spring bedding out with Baker and then cycled over to the Leefes to tea. She had a letter from him on Wed but dated the 9th as my card was, carefully censored by himself apparently and no word therein of their whereabouts but on the envelope in large letters Hotel so and so (I forget), Ostend!! He says they knew of one submarine and 12 hours before they landed a grain ship was blown up by a mine close to where they went. Well, Thank God they landed in safety and we hear the Germans are at Ostend today. Alas another cruiser has been sunk, the Hawk, and 500 men are at present missing. Oh! it is so fearful for words.

October 17th
To my great joy I received this morning a letter from my man and having contrived to send it some more expeditious way than usual I received it 2 days after it was written, just think of that these days. He was very well and had come into no actual action so far. It was a short note but most precious and I was so glad to get it. I took the children this afternoon to tea with Maggie in her most comfortable little quarters at North Camp. We went over them all and saw all her things, had a huge tea and then her man came in. I think they are both awfully lucky in one another and I only hope he doesn't get sent out as she feared he might about a fortnight ago. We had to walk back into Aldershot as we could get no bus and then took a taxi. Saturday night crowds swarmed.

October 18th
My delight was tremendous this morning to find among my letters another from H, a real long one written on the 14th giving a most interesting description of their life and doings and he tells me they brought down 2 aeroplanes on the 13th and 14th. 2 out of 3 of the occupants of one were killed, the 3 wounded and 2 officers in the other captured. I do hope it was Capt Leefe's gun which did it, he says all was well with them but the poor infantry and horses suffering a good deal from the cobbles with which all main roads are paved. To Kirk where the new Curate for many "hours" held forth. The choir seems to have grown dumb these days and the whole service is rather lifeless. Our new vicar and his wife are eminently worthy but very dull.

Dit is ver weg na Tippererie,
Dit is ver om te gaan;
Dit is ver weg na Tippererie,
Om my hart se punt te zien. 
Goen dag, Pikadillie
Vaarwel, Lester-squeer;
Dit is ver, ver weg na Tippererie
Maar my hart le net daar. 

This is a version of the famous song, "It's a long way to Tipperary” , in Cape Dutch. Apparently as popular in South Africa as it was elsewhere!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is the map that Wynne put into the diary, with significant places associated with her husband marked. Below it is part of an article about the Indian troops, mentioned by Wynne - very indicative of the sort of attitudes current in Britain at that time, and strange to read today.

In fact the Indian troops had a terrible time of it in France, especially at the beginning - inadequate clothes, freezing temperatures, poor treatment...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
October 19th - 26th

Although Wynne receives reassuring letters, the knowledge that Herbert is in the midst of a great battle causes great anxiety. In fact the 7th Division is to suffer terrible losses.
viewer_8.description:
October 19th, Monday
Another letter from my man dated 16th, a long and most interesting one, such a joy to get, it really makes all the difference in life to hear at these times but I can't expect it to go on. He wrote they were at last up against the Germans so I suppose have been in action since. My usual Mothers Meeting and the Intercession at the Chapel.

October 20th
Today I got a letter from H dated 11th. I knew it was on its way so now I have had all he has written up to date. War news is much better, rumours of advance all along the line and of the retaking of Ostend. I do hope it is true. Also two days ago which I forgot to mention 5 of our ships sank 4 German Destroyers. Capt. Fox, late of the Amphion, sunk by them, being in command of the flotilla. Splendid news.

October 21st
Once again a letter from H, this time written in ink on ordinary paper from a house where he was billeted, the owners were away, a caretaker in charge, and signs of German having occupied the place a few days previous though he could find no signs of their usual depredation save an empty cellar of course.

October 22nd/23rd
No letter either of these two days but I cannot of course expect it. I know full well the difficulties, indeed the impossibilities of writing at such times and must possess my soul in patience.

October 24th, Sat
A small note from H written upon the self same paper and envelope combined as he used during the S.A. War. It gave news of very heavy fighting, no rest, sleep or wash for days, but thank God all the Staff were well. No date upon the letter.

October 25th
Mrs Rawlins writes that she has had a letter dated 21st when all was well but we are going through a most anxious time and I am inwardly very worried, the papers give the most fearful accounts of the fighting and say without exception this is the most severe they've had ever since the War began and my man is in it - Oh! how dreadful it all is.

October 26th
The usual Mothers Meeting and a large one, how can one continue the daily round and common task as one does but it is a blessing in disguise and I don't know what one would do without it. We were surprised to see announced today the death of Sir Charles Douglas "after a brief illness". He will be a loss at the W.O. The papers are full of the fierce struggle and the Casualty Lists are perfectly hideous.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
This is a post card from a Prisoner of War camp - it must be one of the earliest received, and is from Wynne's friend Philip Lyster, often mentioned in earlier days. He was a Captain in the Royal Field Artillery. But as you can see if you scroll down, he was the lucky one...

"Kriegsgefangenensendung. Bruckenkopf, Torgau a Elbe, Germany. Dated 13.9.14. So glad to get your letter this morning. am quite all right again and longing to be back with the Battery. Write to me now and then as letters are much appreciated - not more than one piece of paper as before. Hope the General is well - is he still at C? "

Below is the reverse of one of the articles Wynne stuck in - these endless lists that were regularly published still shock...this is just one day in one month in one year....

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
October 27th - 31st

The German push to the Channel is resisted. Casualties mount, and one old friend comes home with a wounded foot, while another is taken prisoner.
viewer_10.description:
October 27th, Tuesday
This is the 85th day of the War, the Germans not content with dashing for Paris where they failed are now dashing for Warsaw and Calais and it is in the fighting in Flanders that the fighting is said to be fiercer than ever before in this cruel war. All available troops have been massed there and are being hurled against us, the wretched men being slaughtered like cattle. Here at home one must do something to keep the mind distracted and the hands at work, and so I have been busy gardening all day.

October 28th
I received today this great curiousity, a P.C. from Philip Lyster who is a prisoner at Torgau. I am so glad to have it and to know that he is well but how sickening to be a prisoner and there stuck for months (see it in the Page View before this). The news from the front is serious and fighting as fierce as ever, and now rebellion has broken out in South Africa but Botha is the right man in the right place.

October 29th, Thursday
No one can know how great my joy was this morning at getting a long letter from my Dearest dated 22nd and telling me all their doings since they landed which he now tells me they did at Zeebrugge, a small Belgium port. it is all so very interesting, they marched to Bruges and Ghent to cover the retreat of the Belgian Army and our Marines from Antwerp, and ever since have been fighting. The house where he was writing was being shelled and finding the front unsafe they moved to the back, a poor sapper leaning against the front door having been killed. He was well, had got one more letter and one paper but no more parcels. Alas! the poor men. White T has been wounded in the shoulder and today I hear Gen Perceval has also got it, but slightly. Shocked to see today Sir William Franklyn's death and poor young Capt Cree.

October 30th
ES came in tonight with the news that Skippy is wounded. Thank God only slightly in the foot so the wire says, which is written in French, and he probably arrives in Town tomorrow. She is very upset naturally but will be relieved to have him back and so shall we all, it will be lovely to see him again. Major Eden is also home slightly wounded but I dont know where. I've been busy all the morning doing up parcels for the men. Mother has given me a lovely weighing machine - its like a new toy. I drove the pony into Farnham after lunch, the first time for months as she has been out to grass all summer, and then M and I went to a large tea party at the Bacons, their 52nd Wedding Day. All the old mammies of Hale were there. I love the Bacons.

October 31st, Saturday
We actually have Skippy back home again. He arrived this evening about 6 with 2 other wounded officers on his way to Farnborough Court Hospital, and had motored up all the way from Southampton. he is looking extraordinarily well and has grown quite fat! His wound is only a slight one and I hope he'll be fit quite soon again. Today's casualty list is long again, and it was a relief and joy to get a long letter from my man dated 25th. He had had 3 more letters and all parcels up to 7 which is splendid. So nice to know the men are getting the things. His letters are most interesting, but what awful times.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: A picture of the cooks of the Scots Guards - it was probably taken while they were awaiting their embarkation orders, around the same time Herbert was in Lyndhurst. And below it, found on the back on one of the articles Wynne cut out, is a typical daily list of the dead and wounded...just a snapshot of the thing that confronted those at home every day.... (all the names in the list shown were dead, and I have copied only a tiny part of the cutting).

october.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She is staying near Southampton where her husband's Division is encamped.

HERBERT SAILS FOR FRANCE

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The political cartoons started almost immediately - here below is a postcard Wynne stuck into September 1st, and Haselden's reprinted depiction of the Kaiser's planned upbringing of his new grandson...Wynne stuck newspaper articles, cartoons, postcards, letters etc into the diaries - only a flavour of the content is possible here....

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 6th

Wynne is reunited with her husband...but the first casualty lists appear and a friend is on them. She decides to leave the children so she can be with her husband before his departure for the Front with the 7th Division, Royal Artillery.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Tuesday
Did ever a month begin more bitterly than this one. Hundred of thousands must be mourning throughout the world. I had the great joy of meeting my dearest today at Euston. I went up from here by the 6.0, the Bacon's lending me their car. When I arrived in Town having plenty of time I took a bus to my Club. It was a perfect evening, the moon was high on one side and the sky was clear and red on the other, the river reflecting the sunset and the thousand lights, and the Houses with the Abbey looking clear cut and black against the sky, quite lovely. I had dinner at my Club where on the phone I had a long talk with Blanche Gray, poor lady she already has him back again. He was run over by a gun team in action and broke a rib and they rather fear it may be touching a lung. He is however very cheerful and comfortable, settled in a nursing home in Town. Well at about 9.30 I walked up Bond Street and got a bus to Euston. What a different London to the old gay times which at this hour or rather from 7 onwards is one rush for the theatres. Hardly a taxi did I see and no single theatre goer. (see bottom for cutting about blackouts) Arriving at Euston I prepared for a long wait, the train was not due till 10.45 and half an hour after that one came in, the Scotch Express from Edinburgh, to my consternation H was not in it but I was told the second portion was to follow which it did at 12.15 and there he came. We motored home all the way arriving at a quarter to two. A perfect clear moonlight night and we hardly met a soul the whole way down. What a joy to see him again.


Sept. 2nd
Sedan Day, 2nd Sept. 1870
A busy day spent in getting H's kit together. ES lent us her car in the morning and we went down to Aldershot and then packed all the afternoon. A very hot day. Great things are expected from today by Germany to try and make it a second Sedan day, but they have different stuff to deal with this time.

Sept 3rd
My dearest has gone - no words of mine are needed to explain what that short sentence means to me. The Bacons lent us their car and he left by the 11.20 from Farnham. There is just a vague chance we may meet again, as the date of his sailing is not certain and I might go down to Southampton. Just at present life has no particular aim and the future seems to stretch out into a series of endless tomorrows. God help us all.

Sept 4th
Yesterday the first casualty list came out, a long one but alas not the least complete of course and so it doesn't relieve our anxieties. Poor Jack Bowles is killed, that delightful subaltern of Kildare days, an only child, not long married. Capts Birley and Bailey are wounded, and so many other gunners, one simply dreads the papers these days. I got a letter from my dearest today saying that as the time of sailing would not be yet he saw no reason why I shouldn't go down to Southampton and so joy of joy I go tomorrow.

Sept 5th
I left home by the 11.20 and reached S at about 1.20., the train being very late. Poggy met me at the station and Oh, the joy of seeing him again I simply can't realize my luck, its like a dream come true. We motored to the Hotel in a govt. motor he had and there found dear Ba Cameron that was, and her man Capt Salt. She has been here a month as he was embarkation officer and is now G.S.O. to Gen Capper, the general commanding 7th Division. We motored out to Lyndhurst after tea to find it swarming with soldiers. We went to hunt for rooms and after a great search found some in the Stag Hotel. It will be ripping out there in the New Forest, all sorts of people are here, White T turned up today, he is to command the Horse Gunners under H, how curious that seems. Charles Bridge is also here.

September 6th, Sunday
I have spent a day of real rest doing literally nothing but bask in the sun from morning till night. At 6.30 we went to Church, St Mary's, and there found that Mr Lovatt was preaching, ex Rector of Farnham. I had forgotten he had been appointed here. It has been a lovely day, so still and warm and as this Hotel has a very nice garden one can laze as much as one likes. I was sleeping peacefully under a tree when I heard a voice saying "Here she is" and on looking up saw H bringing White T along, so nice to see him again. We all had tea together and talked over many things. Alas today brings news of the sinking of HMS Pathfinder from a mine 20 miles from our coast, and as a result very heavy loss of life. War news slightly better though the Germans are reported to be within 30 miles of Paris. Our people have done heroic work and are cheerful and steady all through.

This cutting was stuck into the Diary on Sept 10th. Wynne also stuck in a letter from her tobacconist apologising for the fact that his supplies had all been marooned in Malta, and R.E. Vernede's poem about the Indian Army: "Into the West they are marching..."

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The Russian rumour was one of the first great myths of the war - there were sightings of them everywhere, and on one famous occasion the statement was corroborated by an assertion that they had snow on their boots! Wynne was deeply sceptical of all this, as she was about German atrocities, although these proved harder to disprove...

Wynne checked into this hotel in Lyndhurst on September 5th, from where she was able to view the troops marching past, and to visit the camps where her husband was working. It was called the Stag Hotel.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 7th - 12th

War news worsens. Wynne is sceptical of the Russian story, but receives first hand accounts of German brutality. Sir John French issues first despatch. Wynne watches the gay parade go by with sadness and prescience...
viewer_4.description:
Sept 7th, Monday
Weather still continues very hot. The sad news that Col Ansell has been killed has come to hand, what will she do poor thing, also that 1st and 4th Divisions lost all their baggage at Mons. We hear too that the 6th start tonight, young Skipwith and Willie Jones are in that and they have been ready and waiting for some time.

Sept 8th
For weeks past rumour has been busy that Russian troops have passed through England in great numbers for France. Heaps of "eye witnesses" have attested to the fact. No one believes it, and this has come out in the Echo tonight (see previous window). I fear "the wish is father to the thought".

Sept 9th, Wednesday
News this morning is most inspiring, the Allied Forces have assumed the offensive and where they have not driven back the enemy they hold their own. It is a horrible war, this battle of millions and repeated rumours of German brutality reach us. Without believing half ones hears it is awful to get first hand such incidents as the two following: Capt Findlayson told us he went to see a wounded Sergeant Major in hospital who told him that with his own eyes he saw old men and women driven in front of the enemy's infantry as cover, and Capt. Butler got a letter from a hospital nurse stating they had 3 Red Cross men there who had had their right hands cut off (Wynne's underlining). It's like dealing with savages, this sort of thing, and similar reports come from Belgium and Russia as well, only we've never heard it first hand before. The sober morning papers scorn all reports of Russians in France, and they are actually denied from France and Rome!


Sept 10th
Just for the time our lovely weather has broken and torrents of rain fall. I spent my morning packing our boxes and at 2.30 we all left the Polygon Hotel en masse, a huge lorry taking all the men's kit and we all in motors. After tea H, Capt. Rawlins and I walked out to see the RHA camp. They had just come in today and all looked so neat and business like, the guns in line, horses tethered eating their evening meal, rows and rows of tents with groups of men laughing and playing, washing and cooking and involuntarily the thought crossed one's mind of the hardships and sufferings before them, poor chaps. The first long despatch from French came to hand today, such stirring reading, and this morning the King's speech to his Dominions thrilled one to read. How splendidly they have all responded, India alone has sent 70,000 who are now landed in France.

September 11th, Friday
I wish I could insert here in full Sir John French's Despatch but it is too long and too bulky. It is brilliant reading and tells a story which will never be forgotten, also I wish I could keep here the King's Proclamation to the Dominions and the account of the Indian contingent, how fine it is to think how all our people have stood by us and with the force from India come countless Native Princes with their men, almost every ruler there have offered troops, money funds and personal services. Today there is Gen. Botha's speech and tribute of Boer loyalty, how 13 years have changed the situation! I went for such a lovely walk today and right into the forest, far away from sight and sound of human habitation.


Sept 12th
Our window here looks out on to the main street and sometime during the day a regiment passes through with bands playing on their way out for the day. I dont know if it is so but they look as if they were full war strength and it is a brave show. They are full of spirits and return as gay as they go out whether wet or dry, whistling and singing and cracking jokes as they go. It is a cruel thought to think of them returning months hence without many of their number.
News today is indeed inspiring, for the moment we have the Germans "on the run". God grant they will keep it up and that the world may live to see the day when it is rid of this pestilent military element which has fed its people with poison for so long. It has rained nearly all day and is very cold. I wish I had brought warmer clothes with me.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Some of the thousands of soldiers at the Lyndhurst camp - enjoying a beer, and clearing the gorse to make way for tents...the camp must have been an impressive sight, and Wynne was often visiting to feed the horses.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 13th - 20th

Herbert's preparations continue, and Wynne is often left alone. She starts to note the death of friends, and the first shell shock victim. For the regular army the reality hits home early.
viewer_6.description:
Sept 13th, Sunday - news of the Battle of the Marne.
Here is another fine extract, all the papers are so intensely interesting nowadays I feel I want to insert them all, but how my poor Diary is going to stand the strain as it is I don't know. How blessed it is to read such news after the strain of the long but orderly retreat on Paris, the enemy getting it is said within 30 miles of the capital. We were able to go to Kirk twice today, very nice services and beautiful music. At the end of each service the National Anthem was sung.

Sept 14th
The days pass one another in much work and business for my man, as for me I am just utterly content to be near him. I work, write and read and walk and this morning I turned washerwoman and washed clothes!

Sept 15th
I went home today so as to see about Pink's things and take him to Town en route for school on Friday. Found all very well at home and Mother looking after everything splendidly for me.

Sept 16th
A pouring wet day and so filled it with chores.

Sept 17th
I took the children into Aldershot where we did a lot of shopping, amongst other things getting a tea set from them for Maggie who gets married on the 3rd October.

September 18th, Friday
I took dear Pink to Paddington today and returned to Lyndhurst from Town straight, Poggy meeting me at the station to my joy. I said goodbye with the greatest regret to Maggie this morning, I shall miss her most dreadfully after 10 faithful years. She is almost like one of the family and what shall we do without her.
I was sad to see that Arthur Roe is among the wounded today, also Col Geddes and little Capt G.P.O.Springfield is killed and 2 days ago we heard Gen. Findlay is gone too, the first General to be killed. Henry Daniell is also wounded - oh! the number is endless and one wonders who is left. A great battle is raging for the Germans are making a fierce stand and I fear each day will bring its sad list of casualties. I hear Capt Legard is not to be allowed out for 6 months and his nerves have given way. (Is this the first signs of shell shock?)


Sept 19th
Alas the casualty list is heavy again, and gives the names of 12 officers killed, amongst them being our nice friend Major Johnstone. I am so sorry, such a good sort and leaves two tiny children. I went with Poggy and Capt Rawlins out to the far gunners' camp today, they came from South Africa today but hadn't come in. The road and countryside is a sight, hundreds of troop camps, equipment stores, waggons and lorries - it is hardly possible to move and we came home all along behind an infantry regiment which had just landed from S.A. Poor fellows they looked so tired and I expect they'll be awfully cold tonight.

Sept 20th, Sunday
The services here are most inspiring. The music is lovely and they chose such appropriate hymns and chants. There are always heaps of the men present even at the 8.0, they crowded there and I love to hear them sing and love to feel they are manly enough not to be ashamed of their belief.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Censorship became a big issue during the war - here you can see two examples of it from the earliest days - a cartoon where John Bull is captioned as saying: "Ah! what's this? - 'A --- force composed of --- and --- advanced on --- , routing the --- who fled towards --- . Passed by Censor.'
(John Bull's opinion of Censor: "-----!!")

And below a letter from the front, written to Wynne. It has been censored, as you can see on the envelope. The small window you clicked to get here is an enlargement of the censor and post mark on this envelope.

This letter below came from their great friend, Skipwith - Skippy in the diary entries. It is obviously written in haste, and on a small field notebook. It was posted on 15th September (written on 9th) and reached Wynne on 21st. He writes: "Dear Mrs Jackson, I should so like to have some of the Poelnitz officers here to see the horrible savage brutal and wanton pillage and destruction. It is too beastly for words and makes one's blood boil with disgust and indignation. Villages absolutely ransacked and every single article in the houses smashed wantonly, down to chairs and school desks and harmless cottage pictures and ornaments. What a horrible thing war is! Thank you ever so much for your letter. We have had no letters for about 12 days! I believe several lots of mails have gone astray. It's funny writing this peacefully in absolute safety in a roadside field with guns dealing out death a couple of hundred yards away! I am very fit and well. Your paper medicines have been a great boon. I long to be home to the garden and flowers and little Babe and all of you. This is a lovely country and it is dreadful to see so many people after years of unremitting and anxious toil now left homeless, without a single cow, horse or sheep and all their possessions in the house wantonly destroyed and in a few cases the houses burnt wantonly. A poor old village woman was shot by Germans yesterday because she had given a drink of water to a Tommy. We are moving on now so I must stop. Hope you all are very fit - I am. Best of luck and my love to you and the kiddies. Give Gen. J my dim dimms when you write them. Yours always, J.W. Skipwith. "

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 21st - 24th

Family bereavement is not allowed to disrupt Herbert's work. The news is bad: Rheims Cathedral is destroyed, and 3 cruisers are sunk with the loss of 1200 sailors. Wynne receives her first censored letter from the Front.
viewer_8.description:
Sept 21st, Monday
My dear man went off at 8.15 today to go to Frittenden to see poor Bill (his brother William) and he got back at about 9.45 having had his journey in vain so far as Willie was concerned for the poor old man died on Saturday night and so he was too late. Left to myself I hired a bicycle and made a long explore. I rode to Lymington then round by Beaulieu home. My road out took me through a perfect part of the Forest through Brockenhurst and I longed to stop and loiter, then on through L(ymington) after which a long dull stretch over B Heath till I came to Beaulieu itself, what a lovely little village and such a perfect ruin, so splendidly restored, infinite care and hundreds of pounds must have been lavished on it. I came home over the high ground between B and this, a lonely way and an atrocious road, and as I dipped down the numerous camps beneath me were really a wonderfully interesting sight, horses feeding, men cooking and washing, all so busy after a long day out. (Wynne thought nothing of doing these long bicycle rides - this one must have been over 20 miles - see map at the bottom of this page).

Sept 22nd, Tuesday
I should think surely the height of vandalism has been reached by German "culture" in the destruction of Reims Cathedral (see next window). It is almost unbelievable to think that this ancient monument, the crowning place of Kings, is now a heap of ruins. The tapestries luckily had been removed but there is nothing else left alas, and the citizens are enduring much misery from terror and famine and are hiding in the cellars. How little do we realize here in England what war really means. God grant we may never have cause to. I went into the forest today, there all was intense silence and stillness. A heron flew lazily over and small herds of forest ponies grazing, the only sounds being a busy woodpecker and two owls calling one to another. One could not imagine war could be anywhere.

September 23rd, Wednesday
Today the horrible news has come that 3 cruisers have been torpedoed in the North Sea. The Aboukir, Hogue and Cressy, and it is estimated that 1200 lives have been lost at one fell swoop. Why our battle losses are nothing in comparison, heavy though they are. The Aboukir was the first to go and as the others came up to save lives they suddenly went down also. I think it is a wonder that all our seaman aren't maniacs living as they always must at such high tension. Well this has been a strenuous day as the whole Division has been out on a Field Day, starting at 6.0, getting in at about 3.0. As H had to breakfast at 5.30 I awoke every hour through the night, struck a match, found it too early, and then finally slept over the time and woke with a start to hear H say its 10 to 5. I was so vexed but he got down at 5.30 nonetheless, and then I sat decked out in a blanket and dressing gown on the window ledge and watched them going by, such a procession, it took hours to pass. I had an early breakfast and after I had finished I was called up on the phone by Brenda of all people who is at Southampton to meet Oswald from Malta so I got her to come out here and we went out on the Heath in a car, took lunch and saw them all come in, it was a sight, miles of them.
I got this treasure letter yesterday from Skippy, how one does value such a thing, what horrors he tells of poor people and poor land, but he is well thank God, at any rate when he wrote it on the 8th. So many have come to grief that one is always anxious. Philip Lyster is a prisoner.

Sept 24th
I spent a most lovely morning in the Forest, hired a bicycle and rode away into the Greenwood, taking my "elevens" and my writing and sat there from 10 until 1, a typical Sept. day and utter stillness. I sat in a huge grove of old beech trees and one could not imagine that such a thing as war existed, so remote and quiet it was that once a large old fox padded by, too intent upon his business to see me. We were much horrified to realize today that Ni's boy young Archie was on the Cressy, but relieved this evening to find him among the saved. The battle for the Aisne still rages, this is the 14th day and what a fearful time they must be having, so many officers have been killed and I hear General Haking and Gen. Snow are both wounded.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The Germans had already shocked Europe by the destruction they caused in Belgium, which may partly have been responsible for the rapid development of the brutality stories. While some of these were undoubtedly Allied propaganda the Germans did themselves no service by demolishing Rheims cathedral - it offered another public relations coup to the other side....as the Morning Post leader put it: "There can be no adequate expression of anger at the destruction of Rheims Cathedral: the tongue of man is unequal to it...but neither in her professions nor her actions has Germany prepared for the future. She is bending her whole mind on the moment, as if no moment were to follow it. She neglects the plain truth that the days and the years are coming during which the conscience of mankind, once more at peace, will hold her responsible for her wantonness. To destroy a cathedral is easy. But is it easier to repair that cathedral than to restore the respect for the hand that ruined it and the mind that consented to the destruction."

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
September 25th 30th

Outings to the NewForest and Portsmouth. Wynne is alone most days while Herbert works - and the peace of the New Forest proves a surreal backdrop to the news.
viewer_10.description:
September 25th, Friday
This has been a most lovely day and I do trust our men have this weather over there. The Salts, Mrs C and Bede and I all went into the Forest today and spent the morning there and I lay me down and slept after lunch feeling a bit lazy, and after tea Ba and I went into the lines and fed the horses on apples and bread. Capt Salt has his orders and is to report himself at Shorncliffe at once so they leave tomorrow. Mrs C went today, I shall miss them, but Bede is staying on.

Sept 26th
I motored into Portsmouth with Poggy and Capt Rawlins, and we didn't get back till 3.0, when I returned I found the Salts had gone, I was so sorry to miss them. News from the Front doesn't vary much, this frightful battle still continues, neither side seem to gain any decisive victory, meanwhile the losses are frightful on either side, and a horrible percentage of officers are being killed.

Sept 27th Sunday
To early Service with my dearest. God knows but that this may be the last Sunday we are together before he leaves, all seems to point to departure now and one cannot tell from day to day. I and Bede went to the 11, Poggy of course could not get away but he came with me in the evening. It is extraordinary what a lot of the men attend the services here and so many go to sacrament, it is rather touching and oh! how one does admire the British Tommy these strenuous days, never down in his luck, never low spirited, and just about as full of pluck as you could wish. We all went and had tea at the little R.A. HQ camp. After tea we fed the horses, dear things, they are quite getting to know me now and call all along the line.

Sept 28th
Our day began at a quarter to 5 today, H being out all day till 4.30. Bede and I took our lunch and walked away up to Stony Cross heath, a good step, and watched them come in.

Sept 29th
The last day of Sept, what a lovely day. (Wynne is confused here, and the diary continues with an entry as Oct 1st which is clearly Sept 30th, so I have added it below as such.) Tis the day of St. Michael and All Angels, now prayers are being offered to him today, the Angel of War. Great festival day for this Church to whom it is dedicated.

Sept 30th, Wednesday (identified as Oct 1st in the diary).
I insert 2 most interesting articles on the stricken towns in the wake of the Germans, also a splendid account of the battle of La Cateau (sic). This is the hottest Oct 1st I've ever known, I am in a cotton dress again.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: Cartoon poured out of the press throughout the war...alongside poetry, it seems to have been a great growth area and some of them became very famous. Others masked a sadder story - here the joke is about the absence of the German barbers. In fact many Germans had chosen to live and work in Britain, and many suffered terribly on the outbreak of war - losing their businesses, or at the very least suffering endless discrimination and persecution.

september.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She goes to Southampton to keep her husband company before he leaves for the Front...

MONS and the MARNE....

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: See the poem printed in the newspaper in January to explain this...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 7th

"A joyous month...and yet what a mockery Spring seems."
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Thursday
Here again is this joyous month, one of the best in the whole year but what a mockery Spring seems this particular year when so many young lives will never again feel the stir of it. A very busy morning of packing and away home all of us. We came down by the 3.5 and arrived to find the house swept and garnished. All the new paint and paper looks sweet and feels so lovely and clean. My room and H's a pretty blue, the school green etc. etc. and now it is a joy instead of a dirty doghole. Tonight at 10.0 Poggy got a wire containing his orders. He is to proceed to Swanage to command the RA 17th Division New Army II. He is applying for leave till Wed.

April 2nd - Good Friday
...and never has it felt less like it was Lent or Easter either. These last few weeks have been a hideous climax to a vile winter and never do I wish to live through such an awful time again.

April 3rd
The usual decorating at Church and the care of our grave in the morning. Darling old Gran, even now I cant realize she is no longer with us, and one has missed her this home-coming more than ever.

April 4th
To Early Service, the whole house including Win who took her first communion with us. To service at 11.0 also but it is very hard to feel inspired and joyful with such endless sorrow and suffering around one. All is fairly quiet on our Front now but the casualties after Neuve Chapelle - frightful.

April 5th, Monday
This is Bank Holiday but as few if any excursion trains are running the world at large must be taking its holiday joys at home, anyway there is little notice taken of it this year. We spent the day pottering over odd jobs - its very lovely having my man for a short spell. His leave has been granted and he goes on Wednesday.

April 6th
Mothers Meeting again and the weather being so fearful I only had 6 women there - a waste of time and very boring to lose so much of H for little return.

April 7th
Win's birthday - 16 today, and Poggy's departure so I am dull and datchy. I hate everything and am sick of the rest of it!! A pretty frame of mind!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 8th - 21st

"A heart-ache about Spring this year..." but Wynne carries on, her son returns from school, and she is enjoying the redecorated house.
viewer_4.description:
April 8th to 15th
I am not bothering to write about this week - nothing has happened. Nothing ever does now. The War goes on from day to day, fresh horrors, more casualties, but little or nothing doing on the Western Front. The weather is utterly and entirely glorious, a typical and perfect Spring spell. I am up early every morning and as I have dear Maggie here to help me with the children I have plenty of time for odd jobs. Mother and I went to tea with Mrs Perceval. She is a kind lady but she exhausts me with her tireless energy and extreme "Staff-itis". She is a regular walking blue book but she is a wise woman in making bosom friends of those in high places. Poggy writes every day, dear man, and seems quite contented and very busy.

April 16th
My son came home yesterday. Mr de M (ornay) kindly met him for me at Paddington. He is looking awfully well and is as delightful as ever. We had our Egg Hunt today but could only muster 8 children. They all seem to have melted away with the War this year. A lovely day for it and many games afterwards.

April 17th
I have been so busy today. I have had Gran's little room re-papered and painted pale blue and white and have made it into a den for myself. Old oak, china, my photographs, flowers etc and it looks perfectly sweet. I simply love it and it will be a real joy to have a sanctum of one's very own, always a wish of mine.

April 18th, Sunday
These endless days of sunshine are quite lovely. I get up at unearthly hours every day and do my special jobs and writing long before the house is astir. I am afraid I felt very uninspired in church today, a feeble organist who really couldn't play at all and Blackett's guns from the pulpit. Poor miserable little worm, I wonder how many hours he spent over his dissertation, a string of obvious platitudes and seeing what it was likely to be I went to sleep! Inspiration on the part of the congregation would be real heroism under the circumstances and I am not up to it!

April 19th
Alas Mother left today, and I miss her much but when one is so bad with rheu (matism - a typical Wynne shortening!) I'm sure one is more comfy in one's own abode and she will be glad to get back. We have had the luck to be much together this winter.

April 20th, Tuesday
Mother has taken the good weather with her, it is awfully cold today, grey and sunless and after the long spell of sun and warmth one misses it.

April 21st
This day 16 years ago I became engaged to the best man on God's earth, and have congratulated myself ever since. We exchanged mutual wires and wished ourselves together! the children all went off on a primrosing expedition with Mrs Parsons and I went down to tea with Mrs Fitz who has sprained her knee and is hors de combat. My garden is my joy at present, a mass of daffs, aubretia, arabis and polyanthus but there is a heart-ache about Spring this year and the beauty of the time only seems to accentuate it. All through one's days one goes on being quietly unhappy and there is but little balm in Gilead.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 22nd - 27th

A funeral for a woman who died of puerperal fever, dinner with an officer in the "New" army, and news of her brother on the way to the Front.
viewer_6.description:
April 22nd, Thursday
I received a horrible shock yesterday. A week ago yesterday little Mrs Frank Barnes had a baby, all went well at the time and then apparently she got fever which proved puerperal fever, and about tea time yesterday I got a wire from him to say she was dead. Having planned to go to Town with Win I had instead to go to this funeral so sent her with Maggie. I got a car from Aldershot and after an hour's drive reached the little old churchyard where she was to be buried. There is a new church at Hartley Whitney but no burial ground so this old one has to be used and the church itself is abandoned, the ceiling is coming down , the floor is falling in, the seats all mouldy and the general air of desolation struck an appropriate note to this most tragic scene. The whole thing was desolate and her poor man and Baby - oh, how sad it all is!

April 23rd
Today I bicycled over to Whitmead to see the Hurdwoods, it was long since I was there. I found them all rather sad, they miss the Dr so who died on the day dear Gran was buried, 15th Feb. They are still intending to live on there as Government have taken on the san and Geoff with a locum runs it. Their little place looked as sweet as ever. I dined this evening with the Skippys, and there met a varied company, one a man who began life as one of Skippy's Lance Corporals and is now a Capt (New) and another man and his wife who effected their escape from Brussels in the the most thrilling manner of course and to whose adventures I listened with much interest. He is now doing Sapper work in Aldershot. It seemed quite strange to be at even a little dinner party again. I hardly knew how to behave!

April 24th
The children went down at 3.30 to birds nest at the Fitzs' and I followed to tea. Their garden is looking lovely, it is certainly a sweet place but I wish I had that garden to play with.

April 25th
Yesterday our dear Ell started for Europe where his destination or what his regiment is we don't know. His cable only said Europe and for 3 mails we haven't been able to write. I spent today in bed and thoroughly enjoyed it, not feeling very up to the mark.

April 26th, Monday
The weather has turned cold and grey and such icy winds. I to my MM this afternoon, the last but one. Oh! how I long for the end, its seemed an awfully long term this time but everything seems long these days and everything stale and unprofitable and I'm sick of it all.

April 27th
Win and I walked into Farnham to do some final shopping for her. The weather was extraordinarily hot, indeed coming up the hill loaded with parcels it felt like summer. How long will this heat last, I wonder.

(April 22nd was the day of the first poison gas attack, north of Ypres, supervised in person by Fritz Haber,the man who had isolated it as a by-product of artificial nitrogen. It heralded a month of attack and counter attack as the Germans attempted to capitalise on their surprise - but at the end of this period, the Allies had 2000 officers and 50000 other ranks casualties - 10,500 were deaths. The Germans losses were just as high.)

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: This is a fascinating cutting that obviously intrigued Wynne too - transplants were virtually unknown, and anyone who has studied the First World War will be aware of the terrible photos of mutilated soldiers for whom nothing could be done - it was not until World War 2 and the pioneering work of Sir Archibald McIndoe on airmen that skin transplants began to be done as routine surgery. Wynne has stuck in the original advert and then the reply, and this only obscures the sub title of the article: "Patriotic Offers to a Wounded Officer".

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 28th - 30th

April picnics and excursions, but the War is ever-present: lack of news, and the censorship of it, is beginning to get on Wynne's nerves.
viewer_8.description:
April 28th, Wednesday
Inspired by the sunshine Stella, Baba and we all went for a picnic to some woods on the Odiham road where we had tea and picked primroses. ? went in her little cart and the rest bicycled. It was quite lovely but somehow all this peace and loveliness seems almost out of place these frightful times, every day the casualty lists get longer and longer and one cannot help wondering at times if all is as well as the papers make out. Poor papers, they are censored to such a degree that they are at a loss what to make out.

April 29th
Dear Win left for school today. I miss the child much and I don't think she was any too keen to go. No news of Ell, it is most trying work to keep patient, not knowing his regiment we cant tell his destination and therefore are unable to write, day after day goes by and one just lives from one to another. News is grave all round, a new offensive on the Germans part Russian frontier, desperate fighting round Ypres again, a severe struggle in the Dardanelles and with it all so little definite news. A sort of unrestful feeling comes over one at times that we are being lied to. The lists anyhow don't lie, they are frightful. Poor Herman is home again wounded, this time in the leg, and is at Guys. Lena must be thankful to have him home.

April 30th, Friday
Pink and I got up early today and bicycled to Bourley. We got there by 7.10 and what a glory of a morning it was, brilliant sun and heat mist in the valley which disclosed as it lifted, hundreds of tents all round. He picked flowers whilst I guarded the machines and smoked a peaceful cigarette. Many cuckoos quarrelled around us and all the larks filled the sky with their joyous songs, how could one realize that just over the water such strife and slaughter were being enacted. Being a very hot day I spent the afternoon in the hammock and slept! We teaed in the garden and then I worked, watered till 7.30. After my modest supper Skippy came over and we walked up on to the Common there to see a wonderful scene. We went to the edge of Hungry Hill and below us on one side as far as the eye could see lay Aldershot and Farnborough, a blaze of innumerable lights. In the distance the air factory brilliantly lit up and with a huge search light alongside working all over the sky for ever scanning the distances with its diligent eye. On the other side another though smaller cluster of lights showed where Farnham lay, above which on the heights of Hindhead two huge red heath fires blazed away and above all there rose the moon, a misshapen red fire ball. In the far distance came faintly the sounds of bugles sounding Last Post, mens' voices, horses neighing and an occasional scream of a train. An interesting scene and most fascinating but hardly could one realize the presence in the near distance of thousands of men.

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. "A heart-ache about Spring this year..."

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne's opening two pages for August contain a piece of wallpaper from a room in a ruined chateau that her husband had sent her - probably from a room he had been billeted in - and on the facing page a card of a ruined hotel, but not sadly the one related to the wallpaper. The wallpaper is surprisingly thick and bright - it cannot have been hung for very long before hostilities began...although it does not show very well in the illustration, the yellow dots are in fact gold, and shimmer as brightly now as they must have then.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 3rd

Intercession services, news from the Front, general chores - life at home.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Sunday
This Sunday has been held as a day of Intercession here. It just seemed to come at the right time. We had a special Service and Communion. Everybody and all were remembered, even "the patient Beasts who help to share our burdens". I say Thank God one has one's faith these days. My man's guns are in action he says, they are shooting very well and I am so awfully glad but a few days since one of the batteries being new to the game exposed themselves to a German aeroplane and before they had time to move got 62 heavy shells into their position. Thank God only one man was scratched, but why they weren't all killed I can't think. It will be an eye opener to them.

August 2nd
Yesterday young Mr Whitehead came to tea and afterwards we all went up on the Common to gather heather - it was a lovely sunny evening, all still and warm, and we didn't get back till 7.30. A wee line from Ell to say he is well and getting on all right. H's letter hasn't come today, but Bank Holiday disorganises of course. I forgot to say that yesterday we were delighted when at about 3.0 Herman (von Poellnitz - her cousin) turned up having motored down with the Bouchers from London. His Board has given him another 3 weeks but he looks and is awfully well and has quite got over his wound. A long evening at the Hut and being a very wet one I was most lucky in being conveyed there and back in the Richard's car. These two ladies are two sisters from the North who have come down here and taken over this Hut and go every day and serve. (By October Whitehead was at the Front, and in hospital...see on. D.W.Whitehead appears many times during the war in these diaries, and you can see a photo of him by following the link.)

August 3rd
I received yesterday such an interesting book of views of the Vancouver district and town from John Carey, one of my Canadians. This man is one with whom I got in touch through the Victoria League, he is a builder's foreman and writes me long letters of the most elaborate style. He is a master of adjectives with a dash of Neville thrown in! but it is most touching how they appreciate any little thing from the old country.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Another example of two pages from the August diary. Wynne has stuck in two postcards, one of an Italian, sent to her son by her Mother, and another of a French soldier, "un Diable Bleu", which was sent by Herbert from the Front. Behind it are her own photos taken at Margate, and two cuttings. The first is not visible, being folded over to show the second, but was a short summary from the Times titled "A Year Ago" and summarising the momentous August 3rd 1914 comings and goings. The poem, of which this is the original first published example, is uncredited. It is in fact by Nowell Oxland. He was killed at Suvla Bay on August 9th, before it was published. He was 25. It is a poignant lament for his lovely lost Cumberland - the "water ouzel" and the "curlews faintly crying" must have seemed a long long way away at the Dardanelles...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 23rd - 25th

A break at Margate means the diary is neglected, but it resumes with a surprise from Wynne's brother, followed by the inevitable sadness of the times...
viewer_4.description:
August 23rd, Monday
I am ashamed to look at my last entry and see that it is dated 3rd and now I cannot bring my memory to account for every separate day so I must just make a resume of what has happened. To begin with for 10 days I and the two girls were down at Margate. Of course Margate in August is about as vile as you could wish so far as the crowds are concerned, but we made many picnics and got away from them a good deal.
Well we came home about 10 days ago and have been a huge household ever since. Brenda and her two boys now gone have been staying here besides Mother and on Wed last a curious thing happened to me. I was in Town at my dentist and waiting at my Club for Tommy to come to tea, he now being a sub. (lieutenant). when this phone message was put into my hand (from Ell, her brother, saying he was in London - Wynne stuck in the club message). I did not even know he was expecting to get leave, and at 5.0 the old dear walked in looking so well and as ripping as ever, it is lovely to have him back and he has 7 days and goes back on Wed. He is here with us now so that all is well and there seems so much to talk about that we never stop.


These two envelopes of leaves hold particular interest for me. H writes that in one position they took over some former gunners had planted poplars and willows round their guns to hide them from the aeroplanes. These have grown into trees so that unless they cut them down they cannot remove the guns, consequently they have been handed over 3 or 4 times from one Battery to another!
The War drags on no end is in view, the Russians are retreating ever and ever, fearful fighting goes on all round and the Dardanelles is a nightmare. H writes rather depressed, I think his new lot are a bit of an anxiety.

August 24th
We left for Town today and Mother and I tooled round Town on various errands. Found all well at the flat. We were all going to dine together at the Gobelines but couldn't get a table, this little place in Heddon St has lately become so fashionable and everyone flocks there.

August 25th
Alas, our dear Ell went back today. We all spent the morning in a taxi. Ell had a lot of business and we just went with him, and returned to lunch after which he packed and I assisted and at 5.0 he left. Of his leaving I cannot write, the same old heartache and same painful effort to appear very cheerful. One horrible moment and he was gone and that's all.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
August 23rd mentions a huge houseparty - here they are assembled, and it is the only photo in the Diary of one of Wynne's favourite cousins, Brenda. Brenda was the same age as Wynne, and had shared her governess (see 1895 and 1896). She married Oswald Swayne and had 5 children, two of whom are shown here. She is often mentioned in the diaries.

From the top: Wynne's Mother, and Win Lees (later Steed).
Second row: Herbert (Pinkie) and Arthur Swayne
Bottom row: Eleanore (Baby), Brenda (seated), Jack Swayne and Ysobel (Noots).

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 26th - 31st

Chores and visits. Using work to block out the war is a constant refrain.
viewer_6.description:
August 26th, Thursday

After a long day's shopping for my man and myself I came home in the evening and found two letters from my man awaiting me, how lucky one is for this daily mail and how starved one feels if by any chance a day is missed! He sent me this little pansy picked from a gunner's garden - these trophies are to me the most precious.

August 27th
It is nice to be back. I am most awfully fond of my home and all my chores. My people say I "make work" but who would feed chickens, do flowers and garden, order food, pack mens' parcels etc if I didn't! Besides, in these sad days work however humble is a luxury, it makes the time pass and keeps one from thinking. I was glad too to get back to the Hut again and tomorrow young Tom comes for the weekend.

August 28th, Saturday
Tommy arrived by the 4.25 today. I was at the Hut for the afternoon so left at 4.15 to meet him. His train was half an hour late. He looks so very much stronger than formerly, filled out and fitter in every way. He is now in B Reserve Brigade at St John's Wood and seems to like soldiering. My dear man sent me this sad relic out of someone's library today, he found it in a ruined train station, a bookplate, and tore it out of the book. I wonder who Francois van Hamme is?

August 29th
To church this morning and as it poured all the afternoon we sat and talked till tea and then went for a blow on Hungry Hill but got wet for our pain. Stella lent me the pony and I drove Tom to Farnham in the evening.

August 30th
The usual chores in the morning, and the Hut in the afternoon. There is great stir in the Barracks among these Divisions and it is thought that they will be on the move sooner than expected. One somehow feels that there is something ahead and as if one were on the brink of some big move. Oh dear! what a weary time it is and how tired one gets.

August 31st, Tuesday
The last day of August: never has one less regretted the passing of time, let it go as quickly as it can. Dear Ell writes of his arrival, found his regiment had been withdrawn from trenches so he plays at polo and football instead of War. Thank God the Englishman can go to War like this.

august.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The strain on the Home Front continues to show....

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
