viewer_1.description: A cutting about the situation in Serbia - at the time, very much in the thoughts of English people. As you can see, plenty of English men and women had volunteered to help them.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1st - 6th

Wynne's niece goes to London for an operation, and Wynne accompanies her after a hectic week.
viewer_2.description:
December 1st, Wednesday
Again several days have elapsed, it is not through laziness that I don't write but I simply haven't the time. Well yesterday we rushed off to Town for the yearly outing to the Bon Marche, I taking the 3 children and after trailing around all day long I took Win to Mrs Lees (her Grandmother) and left her there to await admission to the Home. It is a very convenient arrangement and I only hope they wont keep her waiting long. Today Stella and I went off to the Hut in Walker's car. I wish people wouldn't fuss so over my bicycling to my work, it really irks me very much to be so nursed, one would think I were a child and I get very tired of it.

December 2nd
All the morning I spent doing up seven parcels for the Front. They do take such a lot of doing and those for the Dardanelles must all be sewn up in cloth now as well, not over 7lbs anywhere and all sorts of rubbish. All afternoon I wrote letters and Stella came to supper. Mother is not at all well, has a chill. The Times are evil.

December 3rd, Friday
A line from Mrs Lees last night saying Win will not be admitted to Hospital till Saturday or Monday. As soon as I hear I am going up to stay a week at my club so as to be near her. Mother will look after my house and Hut and I hope all will be well. Maby goes home tomorrow.

December 4th
News that Win goes into hospital tonight so I shall go to Town tomorrow, it is a relief that so far its settled. A drenching day, pouring and pelting and blowing a hurricane. Maby went off this morning to her people in Farnham and goes to Cambridge on Monday. She is still pretty groggy but I am sure will improve when she gets home. I to the Hut this afternoon and being too bad for cycling I walked. I struggled and swam home and later on in spite of this fearful weather MR Burgess came to dinner and played to us till 10.30. But I am forgetting the news - Ell is home again on 3 days, hurrah!

December 5th
I took the children to Kirk in the morning and came up to Town by the 2.15, made a leisurely procession and arrived at a quarter to 4 and found Ell waiting for me at Waterloo. Joyous moment. We drove to the Club and then went on to Win who we found comfortably ensconced in the Florence Nightingale Hospital. She is in a ward with six other ladies and the place is ablaze with flowers and looks so comfortable and she seems perfectly happy. The day of her operation is not decided upon yet.

December 6th
I went to bed last night at 8.30 and didn't get up till 9.0! Such luxury. I then went to Douglas and got my hair washed and did some shopping , met Ell for lunch, shopped again and then to Win, and before I left I heard that her operation is to be tomorrow at 9.0. I am so thankful it is settled and I wish it was over.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
This is a card sent to Wynne by Sinnott, who was the family's groom. On the back of it he writes: "To Mrs Jackson. Dear Madam. Just a card to wish you all a Happy Xmas, from your obedient servant, M.Sinnott."
The War actually put a bomb under words like that, and after experiencing the trenches very few were prepared to resume the old ways again.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 7th - 13th

Wynne in London - her niece's operation goes well, and in between hospital visits Wynne shops and goes to St Pauls.
viewer_4.description:
December 7th, Tuesday
At 9.0 this morning Mrs Lees and I went to the Hospital there to wait during Win's operation and to hear the verdict - three quarters of an hour of horrible suspense, the dentist wasn't in it. But nothing lasts for ever, and at the end of that time we were summoned to Mr Clogg who told us that all was satisfactorily over and that she would be quite all right. God be thanked. We forthwith went out and sent 3 wires to India, Mother and Miss Hoyle and then proceeded on our way. (Win's parents lived in India, and Win was marooned in the UK for the duration of the war).

December 11th, Saturday
Four days have passed and each has seen my Win better and better. I went today, she was like her old self again, it is a blessing. I haven't written in here because I felt too restless but now its all behind me and I'm so thankful.

December 12th, Sunday
It is 9.30 and I am still in bed. I stay here most deliberately as I have most mornings since I came up and no one knows how I have appreciated it! But I've done quite a lot of Town scouring since I arrived. On Tuesday I spent most of the day with Ell, went into the city and interviewed our lawyer for Mother and had lunch at Simpsons, such a good lunch of real English stuff! and in the evening we dined at the Troc. next to No 90 of historic memories and went on to the Palace to see and be very much amused at "Bric-a-Brac", after which we returned to the club for a drink (for myself) and then alas came the usual hateful goodbye. I'm getting quite a practical hand at that particular form of amusement. He left early Wed morning. That day I explored St Pauls, in a way it reminded me of St Peters but is not nearly so beautiful in my poor opinion. I went up the many steps into the lovely old Library with its beautiful books, the shelves whereon they rest all carved by Grinling Gibbons, then to the Whispering Gallery where by some curious reason you can hear the guide's whispering voice booming at you right across the dome and finally visited the Crypt wherein lie so many of our famous soldiers and sailors and where I had a flirtation with an old "dry as dust" and the crypt cat which I found curled up on one of the wreaths! I just saw Win for a short time today but she was not fit for visitors so I didn't stay. I've seen two theatres, "The Ware Case' and "The Case of Lady Camber", the former splendid, the latter rotten. I've also been shopping like mad and we've had vile weather, such rain. I go to Win to tea this afternoon and to the Abbey this morning.

December 13th, Monday
My stay up here is drawing to a close, I'm awfully sorry I've really enjoyed the rest and its cleared away a cold I had had for weeks. At 11.30 Lady F came in and smoked a friendly cigarette with me. I wish I could see more of her but our lives lie apart. I then paced the shops, Regent Street mostly, trying to find various things which I failed in finding, had a vile lunch at Fullers for which they kept me waiting and then in due course repaired to Win with whom I stayed till 6. Mrs Lees was also there. I felt quite sad to think I should not see the child again but I can't stay away from home any longer, leaving Mother to look after my house and children and do my chores at the Hut.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The Field Postcards were a regular feature of the war - there are many in the diaries. This one is unusual in that it was designed for the Indian troops, and is in Urdu. It was sent by Ell, her brother, who was serving with the Indian troops.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 14th - 18th

She goes home, meeting mud-encrusted soldiers at Waterloo who are just home on leave...but she hears her own husband's leave has been cancelled.
viewer_6.description:
December 14th, Tuesday
Sadly I left London Town this morning, I regret that I'm not more domesticated but it isn't that I hanker after the delights of frivolity, no-one could feel like that now-a-days but I do love a little real idleness. I leave Win wonderfully well thank goodness. At Waterloo this morning the place was crowded with our men coming home on pass, most had come straight form the trenches and were thick mud from head to foot, and such costumes! Some had fur linings outside their coats and looked like eskimos, their hats were all shapes, their rifles, haversacks and all accoutrements were nothing but dried mud. I should think they were not the only occupants of their clothes.

December 15th
I found all well at home yesterday except Mother's cold which will not leave her. I really think a change is the only thing and that she'll get when she goes to Town on Friday. She and I went to the Hut tonight and were busier than ever. I am convinced that as time goes on the place becomes more and more full, my dept. - cakes - is really more than one person can manage as one has to keep one's stall supplied with cakes as well as serve. We had a concert given tonight by the Presbiterian (sic) Choir, a party consisting of about 20, and the style of song was "I stood on the Bridge at Midnight" and various glees where each person vied with the other in trying to sing his part louder than her. It was most painful but the men thought it was lovely. Mother and I exchanged mournful and despairing glances.

December 16th, Thursday
I spent the morning in doing up Mother's parcels for her. We got about 13 done up and despatched. As each day passes I tick one off in my mind against my dear man's coming for if all goes well he comes on Monday as ever is for Xmas and I go up to meet him staying the night and meet Pink the next day. I can't bear to think of it hardly. I wrote mail letters hard all the afternoon and when Mother had gone to bed continued to do so till 12.0 but of course they'll be too late for Xmas. Everything like that has had to have the go-by this year, I've been too full of other matters but all that is over now.

December 17th
I can hardly write of the horrible calamity which has befallen me today - I had a letter from my dear tonight which said that owing to rumours of increased activity on his line that leave would in all probability be stopped and so he is not coming home after all. I can't bear the thought, it had come so near and I was counting on it so immensely and now its all done for. Its hard to be philosophical under the circumstances. Mother went to Town this morning. I had my Hut as usual and was thankful as it helped to take my thoughts off this most bitter disappointment. I feel as if all the brightness had been dashed out of my life tonight but I shall be better tomorrow.

December 18th
I thought I would be very clever and try to go to Aldershot by the new bus which starts from Hale now, and went up the road to meet it at Charmans only to find that it was full. By luck I picked up a taxi there so wasn't very late. I was the only lady at the Hut today, the others all being ill I suppose, but the men helped and as we had no rush it didn't matter. I went then into the vile Town to do some shopping and not being able to get a bus home had to take taxi again. No letter today from Poggy owing to the fact that I had two yesterday. I still feel desolee, there is little or no balm in Gilead for me at present.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
A Christmas Card from the 3rd Division - on the back in pencil is written: "We were issued with one of these".
The Kind of Santa Claus we may expect on Christmas Eve.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 19th - 23rd

Absent husband and sad news does not make for a specially festive time. Wynne confides her sadness and anxiety to the diary.
viewer_8.description:
December 19th, Sunday
A glorious day and as we walked to church this morning in the still crisp air I thought to myself how extraordinarily gay I should be feeling if things were otherwise than they are, but enough of these meowings, in fact Nufsed. Sunday has passed in its usual quiet way. Bessie who I forgot to mention was married last Monday, returned home last night, she is now Mrs Kenny and her man has gone back again and as Maggie comes tomorrow I shall two Mrs in the house. Two or three days ago the announcement came out that Sir D Haig is to be C-in-C in France whilst Sir J French comes home to take over the Home forces. Its about time that man had a rest, 17 months of hard work and anxiety.

December 20th
Xmas week and never did I feel less like it. Today was the day I should have met my man, alas I see from the papers the reason he cannot come for they are in action on his Front, the Germans have been and are attacking and using gas besides, it is all very horrible. One does pray all may go well with us and I wish he could get out of that hated position. Stella and I went to the Hut together tonight but 2 regiments moved out and so we were not very busy.

December 21st
News today that Mother and Win are to return tomorrow in Mrs Barnes' car. I have spent the day in Town meeting Pinkie, but travelling is awful at present, no porters hardly either so one has to do ones box hauling oneself. We traipsed the Town and came home at 6.0

December 22nd
Very busy preparing for the advent of Win and Mother, who arrived here by 1.30. Mother has still a fearful cough and is really very seedy and I am going to get Tanner (the Doctor) up to prescribe. Win looks wonderfully well but is not to walk hardly at all and must lie about all day and be slack. Dear child, its so ripping to have her back and to think the operation is all over. My dear man writes so sadly and indeed I can hardly bear to write to him at all for what can one say that is not depressing. I know that they are continuing to fight there and every day the papers contain accounts of artillery duels on the Ypres line so that I know he must be engaged, its all so dreadful and I am horribly anxious but one has only to practice patience and bravery. Today I am shocked to see Capt. Clibborn's death, another of our boys.
(Captain Cuthbert Clibborn, D Bty, RHA, died on 14th December 1915. He was aged 32. His brother was killed the following year, on April 7th. They were an army family, the father being Lt Col I Clibborn. Cuthbert is remembered both on the Commonwealth War Graves site and on the Haileybury College site).

December 23rd
H writes that Donald Wilson, lately taken over one of his Batteries, has been badly wounded in the head. It will be a loss to him and he had only been with him 3 days. Mother's cough is so bad and altogether what with one thing and another I am just as worried as I can be and this is the only place I can say so, for it doesn't do to show ones feelings these days. We have been decorating the house today and are busy over the usual Xmas things but oh! my heart is not in it and I am only half here. No one but ones inmost self can know what the present time is like.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
These four cards were stuck at the back of Wynne's diary. They are wonderful examples of the post card craze that lasted until the postage charge went up after the war and made them less economic to send...these ones had to be held up to the light to see the 'secret' in them: spotlights in three, and the missing husband/father in the fireplace in the fourth. I have copied one below to show you how they work...




Not a very good image but it gives you the idea - you can just make out the submarine. The other two searchlights pinpoint zeppelins.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
December 24th - 31st

Wynne signs off teh year with a hard evening at the Hut and an early bed...but in spite of the gloom some merriment was had.
viewer_10.description:
December 24th, Friday
No letters from the Front today and I can scarce believe this is Xmas eve. Mother is very seedy with her cough and not feeling at all fit and everything is rather awful but for the children's sake one must keep going. I went down in the morning with Nootle to church decorate, this is a task she always helps me in. To the Hut this evening and when I returned we filled the stockings, dear me how different from other years when one really could be gay but we laughed a good deal this evening because Win had hung up her pyjamas and so after filling her stocking and putting it in first we filled the rest with various useful things, coconuts, the poker, vegetables, lampshade and basket etc, the appearance of the legs when completed was simply screwed.

December 25th
I can make no special ornamentation of my Xmas page this day, I'm simply not in the humour. The children assembled in my room early as usual to discuss the contents of stockings and we laughed much over Wins! then came church, with its most inappropriate hymns for the present time, then tree decoration, tea at 4.0, Tree at 5.0 and dinner at 7.30 and so ended a most trying day as far as we grown ups were concerned. Stella joined us and a young RAMC boy , Visick by name. No letters again this morning, one is weary for news and no papers since Friday. I am tired of the day and its forced gaiety and shall be glad to gloom in peace tomorrow!

December 26th to 30th
I am happy to say that my spirits are less at zero, the mails from the Front having brought me all I want and anxiety is less. On Monday last poor old Col Fitzroy died, he had been ill about 6 weeks and at last his heart failed. He will be much missed and I am so sorry for her. I went today to his funeral, many people were present and the R.A.Band attended and played most beautifully. I saw many people one knew but hurried away afterward, it was sad and pathetic to hear the Last Post sounded over his grave, poor old soldier.
We went and had tea with Stella afterwards. H writes that this attack of the Bosches (sic) has been an utter failure but they expect another as soon as the S.E.Wind arises in order to enable them to use more gas, a pleasant prospect.

December 31st, Friday
As I write, the year 1915 is rapidly drawing to a close. I don't care how quickly it does it. Seldom has there been a whole year of such untold misery to the World at large and at any rate one feels that one year of our anxiety and sorrow has passed away. It has all been terrible. I have not written or even touched on half or quarter of the large happenings it has contained partly because diary writing in these days is apt to become rather crowded out by the immense amount of other jobs one has to do and partly because one hasn't the heart to sit and deliberately make note of all the miserable things that are taking place from day to day. The year has gone out wildly raging: storms and torrents of rain - in the same manner as it began. I was at the Hut tonight and as we had a very heavy night with many hundreds in I feel too fagged to stay up and see the New Year in. Really these days one takes little thought for these extras, and so to bed. Goodnight and Goodbye to my Diary for 1915, may the next book contain a happier record.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: This is the end of the diary. At a much later date, Wynne stuck in the envelope at the top of the page, which she notes was a speciman of the type that came to be used towards the end of the war - she had moved house by then. Because of the paper shortage, it has been made from a sheet from a magazine consisting of house adverts. It was made by disabled soldiers at 42 Ebury Street.

december.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

An operation for her niece, and the news that Herbert will get no Christmas leave, make for a sad and difficult month.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 7th - 9th

Recovering from flu, Wynne finds the whole household going down with it, leaving her to cope.
viewer_2.description:
(Wynne has been ill with flu)

February 7th, Sunday
More than a week has elapsed since I wrote here because I've spent most of it in bed with a stupid attack of flue (sic). I tried to battle against it but had to give in and retired to bed on Sat. feeling a worm and no man, then on Friday Baby went down but only with a heavy cold and is up again today. Dear thing, this is her birthday, she is 7 today, alas so grown up and a baby no longer, she is so sweet and good, such a sunny little person, indeed both she and Noot are no trouble on earth and my very great joys and then I have what to my mind is a perfect son and niece so what more can I want! I have no stirring events to put in here having seen no one and done nothing for a week but hope for better luck from now onward.

February 8th
We had intended having a little birthday tea for my Babbit today and I bicycled into Aldershot to fetch her cake but when I got back I found Nootle well on in a flu cold and packed her off to bed, and Maby went round and put off our small guests. I attended a committee meeting at Howards and then took my Mothers Meeting after lunch so felt today I had discharged my duty. Poor Nootles' head is very bad and I suppose this most vile plague will run through the house. I heard from Pink today and so did baby and he actually sent her 6d for her birthday saying he hoped she didn't think him very stingy! She was delighted. A letter too from Win, she sprained her ankle last week at games and so is a prisoner and goes to school in a bath chair!

February 9th
I was to have gone into Aldershot today to SSandA work but the weather was so vile I simply couldn't face it and so phoned, but I felt an awful skrimshanker. My Noot is very seedy and thoroughly in the throes, Maby not well, Clark jolly bad and Gran showing signs of it. We are leading a funny old life at present and the courage of despair is upon me. There is no time for depression, one's days are taken up with keeping that away from our surroundings, but I should be thankful to see the last of this flu and at times I want my man very badly. (Clark and Graham were nurses engaged to look after Wynne's grandmother. Maby was the childrens' nanny).
These two cuttings are queer - how can people write such things in papers.

Bail out the ocean! Oh dear...but the other cutting Wynne found odd we would now not be worried about at all - in fact it was tender and emotional, which is perhaps what she was scared of:
"Stuart-Murray - At our house in Willfield Way, very happily when we were alone together, in the evening of the day of Our Lord, January's 31st day, Frank Stuart-Murray, my dere herte swete, in his 68th year. "

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne stuck these cards in illustrating the devastation in Belgium: the first is of Tirlemont Street in Louvain, the second is the Licorne district in Senlis.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 10th - 13th

Illness, Accidents and Death. Wynne's grandmother dies aged 101, and she receives news of another friend killed at the Front.
viewer_4.description:
February 10th, Wednesday
The sick ones progress. Noot much better, Clarke very miserable to keep in bed until Friday, and poor old Gran though with no head or sore throat has such a cold on her chest that she can scarcely breath. Lovely weather and I comfort myself that these rotten times will pass away like all other have done before them. Meanwhile I get my daily letter from my Dearest who is well and cheery and the papers are full of interest. The descriptions though of the fighting in Poland are simply appalling, the Russians in places have made barricades of frozen corpses in front of their trenches, what will happen in Spring. The accounts of the fighting in mass formation 8 and 10 deep simply sound like massacre pure and simple, how can they get the men to do it. H wrote me an extraordinary thing 2 days ago. He said some of his men were grubbing about for fragments of German shells and found ordinary common marbles instead of lead bullets in their shrapnel, and added "either they must be uncommonly hard up for lead or else some contractor is making money fast". I never heard anything so odd. In today's letter he tells a wonderful story. An Irish guardsman brought in a machine gun single-handed at La Basee. he found 10 Germans in a pit with this gun, shot 8 and seizing the remaining 2 by the scruff of their necks he banged their heads together and brought them and their gun into our lines. He is to be recommended for the VC. I am so longing for the next Despatch from French and the long promised list of names after Ypres, I can't think why they should be delayed like this.
(Thanks to a reader, Paul Dayton-Lewis, who has pointed me to the information confirming this story - you might like to check it out yourselves: the Irish V.C.

February 11th
There is a saying that troubles never come singly, and today is an example of the truth of such. To begin with, Clarke is still a prisoner of course and too ill to do anything but lie in bed which in itself is a worry as my dear old Gran quite overcome by this fearful phlegm and had been in a comatose state all day. During the afternoon Graham who went out for a walk was brought home in a cab by a soldier having been run over by a motor lorry which knocked her down and passed over her leg so here I am with all 3 in bed and I cannot anywhere get another nurse so I must turn to nurse all 3! I am very anxious about my old dear. Dr Hussey looked at her today and he didn't seem to think that there was any chance of her getting over this as she doesn't seem to have any strength to rouse herself, poor dear.

February 12th, Friday
At 3.15 today the Good God took my dear old Gran to her rest, and though I miss her so very much I know that it is better so. All through last night I watched her lying there unconscious and by the morning I knew it could not be much longer so I wired for Mother who came down with Aim by the 11.45 and so saw her alive but she never regained consciousness and knew nothing and suffered nothing. And so the long and wonderful life is at an end and the last of the Wolflee lot has gone to Rest. Mother and Aim stayed the night and were a great help in the numberless things there are to do at these times, and I was very glad to have them. Everyone is most helpful and kind, and we have arranged that the funeral shall be at 2.0 on Monday here. Never shall I forget the loving devotion and gratitude for all that was done for her, her patience and sweetness.

February 13th, Saturday
A month hence today and my Gran would have been 101, what a long time to live. She looks most wonderful, so peaceful and dignified and so extraordinarily young. How one does miss her though in every little way. I was most awfully distressed to see in the paper today that dear fellow Sonny Wilkinson has "died of wounds", it is a tragedy for he was to those girls (his sisters) what Ell is to us, their idol, and it will simply break them. Although I have not seen him for years I shall never forget the fun we used to have together and the lovely Sandhurst Ball at which we came out together. We hear news now that our beloved Ell expects to join the Indian Cavalry and be at the Front about March. This evening all things combined seem to have brought one to a stand still and I am just (for the time) at the end of my tether.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A family group - from the left, front row: Ysobel and Eleanore, both proudly wearing the uniforms they had been begging for.
Behind them, Thomas (Pink), HKJ on leave from the Front, and Win Lees.

In the 1980s Ysobel recalled this event, clearly a memory she was unlikely to forget: "The soldier uniforms were because walking with Dad in London we passed two small boys in immaculate uniforms who gave Dad a very smart salute and I envied them enormously. Ours were made as a surprise and we were then constantly in them because to me anything was better than girl's clothes, but as you can see they weren't at all the real thing and I wasn't allowed to have my hair cut short!"

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 14th - 18th

The Baroness is buried, and Wynne prepares to get away for a short break after all the upsets.
viewer_6.description:
February 14th, Sunday
A quiet day, the weather very bad so we did not venture to Church and I spent the day in writing hard. I've been so awfully busy over the necessary details and arrangements connected with tomorrow there is so much to do and see to. Capt Bacon dear old man has consigned to us the last available space in the Churchyard at St John's and I am so awfully pleased, it is so much nicer than the cemetery up the hill. Mr Watson is coming to take the service and Mother and Aim and Thurie come down from Town by the 11.45 train. All is now arranged and seen to but I've missed my man considerably through it all. My dear Skippys are so good and sweet and come in every day to see me and to help in all possible ways. I don't know what I should do without them.

February 15th
After two fearful days of gale and rain the sun shone out still and calm and my dear Gran was laid to rest in perfect peace. Her flowers were lovely and wreaths came from all sorts of people. I shall never forget the wonderful peace and dignity upon her dear old face, all lines gone, all care smoothed away and it was as if the Hand of God had touched her. Mother, Aim, Thurie, Brenda, Rita and Nora came down and we buried her at 2.0. There were a lot of people present but I didn't see who they were, and Mother etc went back by the 6.30 train. Now how still and empty the house seems, it will be more so when Clarke and Graham have gone, the latter is better, I don't think the lorry can have gone over her leg and she is a mimsy creature with no head. I shall miss Clarke very much, she goes next week.

February 16th
I had to go in to SSand A this morning, it is rather a bore every week, this job, a far cry for very little reason and it bores me. A lovely bright frost and so bicycling was rather a pleasure than otherwise.

February 17th
I have been going through sorting my dear Gran's things, a most horrid and painful job. I can't bear going into her little room, it seems so awfully empty. Stella S and I are going down to Newquay for a week on Friday, we have mutually some cobwebs to blow away and I'm rather longing for a rest and change. One's head gets so full of War and personal troubles of domestic arrangements that one longs to be quite idle and at peace.

February 18th
I was to have gone to take Shirts for Mrs Perceval today but the kind lady sent me a message saying I needn't do so, of which I was very glad as I am awfully busy with much to do and settle before I go. I cycled down to Farnham on various errands, the rain fell in torrents and the wind blew a gale but I had to go. I went to see the Police Inspector about Graham and her accident. I'm afraid she wont get anything out of the Inde Coop having committed herself at the time by saying it was her own fault and that she shouldn't have been walking on the road which of course the carman took down. She is a tiresome girl with no backbone or head.

Below is a picture of the grave of Eleanore von Poellnitz. It is in the churchyard of St John's, Upper Hale, near the boundary hedge, standing amongst the many graves of the kind Bacon family, who donated the space. It was completely renovated in 2012.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Like many things Wynne was sent from the Front, this was a part of life there (as was the Tickler's Jam, the label of which is in the last window of this month). This directive was not generally adhered to - well, this one certainly wasn't stuck to the Pay Book!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 19th - 26th

Wynne and a friend go to Newquay for the ozone and a rest
viewer_8.description:
February 19th, Friday
We started away at 8.30 this morning, caught the 11.0 from Paddington and arrived at Newquay at 6.30 after a long but quite comfortable journey and having had our dinner sought our beds at an early hour.

February 20th
Yesterday when I bought the Times at the station I discovered it had the first Honours list, I feverishly ran my eye down it and found to my great joy that Poggy had been given a C.B! My feelings were such that I wanted to shriek aloud, it is an honour and I do feel so proud. CB, DSO is a very neat collection and I am much honoured with reflected glory.
We find ourselves most comfortable here in a large and clean hotel, the food is good, the rooms large and clean, the people very attentive and they do you for 3 guineas a week inclusive. It is called The Headland Hotel because it stands right on the cliff and the sea beats on the rocks at the foot of it. The weather being fine and sunny we lie about on the sands, collect shells, bask and idle, and it's delightful.

February 21st, Sunday
To Church this morning, a large and very new looking building, a fairly large congregation composed of old boo boo men and women, soldiers and children. Good music and parson with a clever face and fanatic's eyes who preached against "Sunday pleasuring" and compared the opening of golf links with Picture Palaces. It seems to me that a deal of mildew must grow around the brain of such people yet everyone must carve his salvation out for himself in his own way. There are very few people in the hotel as its quite out of season, and those that are are deeply pogbaggish but after all we didn't come here to look at their pansy faces. The air is lovely, so is the sea and we are imbibing tons of ozone and I feel so much better already. All signs of flu have gone.

February 22nd to February 26th
All these days have passed much like one another, we've done nothing but slack and lie about and it has been a real joy and rest. I feel a different being from the mouldy-brained owl that came here a week ago and quite prepared to take up the daily round again. The country round here is flat, bare and ugly but the coast is splendid, a cruel coast with many deep bays and caves and not much foreshore anywhere. I have explored a good deal but Stella didn't feel up to walking so I had to go alone, which on the shore is rather bogeyish sometimes. There is a small town with some quite nice shops but I wish the country wasn't so windswept and treeless. We started again at 8.30 and I got back 6.30, Stella stopped in Town for the night.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Another example from Wynne's extraordinary collection - this is a relic of wallpaper from a house in Ypres.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
February 27th - 28th

The house is emptying after Gran's death, but the war continues to dominate everything. Cousin Bill is commissioned, and Charles, her old flame, is back from the Front in hospital.
viewer_10.description:
February 27th, Saturday
Alas the house is strangely empty without my Gran. It seems so odd to find her little room empty and I do miss her so much. She leaves a horrible blank which can never be filled but Time will help to lessen our sense of loss. I have been busy settling down again and there is always much to do on one's return. I find the mimsy Graham still here, I do wonder when she intends to take herself off. Clarke went last Wed. We are a reduced household. For some time I have not mentioned "The War", it is I know an all absorbing topic, one thinks, dreams and speaks of nothing else but one also gets to long that it wasn't there to wind itself round one's very life like this. H writes every day in spite of the Blockade which we hear so much about.

February 28th, Sunday
Maby (the governess) has gone to Town for the weekend so I am very much enjoying my 2 children. Being a lovely day I sit in the conservatory, Noot is writing to her Daddy, Baby painting and its all very peaceful but oh, how it all lacks dear CB, DSO. There's one thing I must find out about that honour and that is, the companion of whose Bath is he! I heard this morning from Bill who has been offered a commission, what in I don't know, but he mentions the 9th Division which is the Scotch one here. He sent me the most interesting memento straight from the Trench, a jam label off one of their pots, all duly signed. I was pleased. How I wish I could get more of such things, I simply treasure this. He also told me a neat little story, called "The Ladies": Our Arms their Defence, Their arms our recompense. To Arms!
He seems very well and cheery and is going to the Cadet School at ? for a course. Charlie is home ill with very bad flu and the after-effects of concussion caused by a shell bursting just behind his dug out. He is in hospital in London and I am hoping to go and see him one day next week. He is in a very weak state I hear poor chap. I heard from Walter yesterday through Leila, he had just got my letter about our old darling and was very upset, he is in a very mediocre state of health, his heart is playing him tricks and I don't think it looks like improving. I feel so sorry.

Charles is a reference to her old flame, Charles Maclean, and Walter is a reference to Wynne's uncle in Munich - and to the "postman" in Switzerland who passes on letters for them both - see January 1915 - but as you can see below, postal services continued into Germany for Prisoners of War. This envelope, notes Wynne, had been to Torgau and Burg and was then returned as her friend, Philip Lyster, had been moved to Magdeburg. Philip was captured in 1914 - one of the earliest prisoners.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
This label from a Tickler's Jam tin was sent from the Front by Bill Fallowfield, Wynne's cousin. He obviously got everyone in the Sergeants' Mess to sign it, plus a Captain or two, and she put it into an envelope upon which she wrote: "A most precious souvenir from the trenches of the London Scottish".
Tickler's was the subject of many jokes, and features in Bruce Bairnsfather's cartoons...

february.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The War has been raging for 6 months...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The Title pages for the opening of Wynne's Diary in ...

The poem Wynne has put into the centre of her opening pages is by H.D.Rawnsley.

1915

Today how many thousands will not hear
There in their changeless timeless world of light
The sad year's solemn passing in the night,
The silent coming of a happier year.
For this new year, though full of woe and fear,
Shall prove that Right has triumphed over Might,
Shall see an end of war's accursed blight,
And Peace amend the Nations drawing near.

We cannot hear their voices, clasp their hands,
The faces that we loved no more we see;
But they whose names are bright on Honour's roll
In some far world shall know we reached their goal,
That nobler for the deed our Empire stands
Crowned with the Will that set all Europe free.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 6th

Herbert is on leave so the family enjoy an outing to London: the panto and magic shows...but the time soon comes for his return.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Friday
I am sure no year ever began in a more turbulent way than this one, with most of the World at War. Since August 1914 the strife has been raging, and it is a terrible thought to realize the thousands of lives that have been lost since then. The Germans to celebrate the New Year I suppose torpedoed one of our battleships today and over 600 lives have been lost. The Hurdwoods had a grandson on her but he was saved. It is a pretty way of beginning a new year.
(Wynne is referring to H.M.S.Formidable, sunk by a U Boat while patrolling off Portland Bill. The bad weather added to the loss of life, which was actually 547 from a complement of 780).
At present my personal joy is full for I have my dear man and we are all up in Town staying with Mother in her new flat in Marloes Road. We all came up yesterday and did 2 pantomimes in one day! thanks to the kind Duke and today I took the children all up the Strand as far as St Paul's, this expedition undertaken in search of hawkers who at this time are selling a variety of penny toys appertaining to the War such as "Iron Crosses" etc....but owing to a very wet morning they were not abroad and so we met with none. We went instead into St Paul's where an Intercession Service was going on and listened awhile to the lovely music. We could not stay long as we had shopping and lunch to get through before meeting H at 2.30 at Maskelyne and Devant, where we saw a most interesting performance of magic and conjuring. I am sure H and I enjoyed it as much as the children for it is certainly a first class performance and it really does one good at these times to have something besides War to think about.
(John Nevil Maskelyne: 1839-1917, and David Devant: 1865 - 1941, were famous magicians - possibly the greatest of the period. Maskelyne himself had been performing since the 1870s, so the family were very privileged to see this. Check out a later visit on December 19th, 1919 )

January 2nd, Saturday
We all went shopping to the Stores this morning which the family enjoyed immensely. I wonder if Xmas trade suffered much this year, the hundreds of calendars left over made me wonder if it was the same in all "lines". Back to lunch and then H and I went to Charles Street to see poor Herman (von Poellnitz, Wynne's cousin) who is home with frost bitten feet, and is in a lovely private hospital with every luxury for the asking. I fear it will be a long job, the result of 12 days on end in the trenches. We all returned home this evening, it seems to me just too wonderful to have my man back.

January 3rd, Sunday
To Kirk in the morning and Col Fitzroy came up to have a long buck with Herbert and in the evening we went over and had supper with the Skippys, the time is passing with the speed and unreality of a dream.

January 4th, Monday
H and I spent the morning doing accounts, wages, insurances, licenses etc and I was thankful for his help. To lunch and tea came Frank and Lindsay (Herbert's brother and nephew). We walked up on the common to show them our view! They left about 5.30.

January 5th
Alas our short time at home is over, we left for Town this afternoon and spent the night with Mother. A short entry but what's the use of writing about such things.

January 6th, Wednesday
Up at 6.30 and at Victoria by 7.45, there assembled many other officers returning from short leave and at 8.30 saw the train disappear from view taking with it once again that which I love most on earth. I shopped that morning and came home thoroughly down at 5.0.

Herbert on the boat to France.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Two typical patriotic postcards...and Herbert's Front Line pass for March and April that Wynne obviously stuck into January at a later date...but its an interesting piece of bureaucracy.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 7th - 13th

Illness at home, and Wynne confides to her diary that she is feeling more and more depressed.
viewer_4.description:
January 7th, Thursday
And so the daily round has got to be picked up again, at times like these one is apt to think how can I do it but it is a blessing in disguise and in reality I don't know what one would do without it. The foul War continues with its ever recurring horrors, now its the poor Austrians who are again getting the knock for although one cannot help but be thankful that Russia is continuing to steamroll yet I cant help being sorry for the poor catspaw Austrians who the Germans treat with the utmost scorn and contempt.

January 8th
Win went off to Ascot yesterday to stay with the Elliots which she will enjoy, but I miss her much. I shall hate the return of those two to school but all the children are a great help during these troublous times.

January 9th
I have my Baby sick today something has upset her inside and a dose of castor oil has been administered. The child is such a good patient, takes everything she's told without a murmur and never meows. I spent the day in doors with her, Gran also seemed very frail and dozed all day and various domestic things went wrong so that I was more than thankful to get two letters from my dear man telling me of his safe arrival which cheered me much.

January 10th, Sunday
My dear shaver had such a bad night, I was up almost every hour with her and all through today she has been teazed by her small inside, so at last I got Hussey up and he has prescribed and instructed and so I hope she'll soon be better.

January 11th, Monday
My babbit has had a better night and no sickness today but she is weak from want of food etc. I shall be glad to feed her up again, dear mite. I personally have been feeling a beast myself and had to go to my Mother's Meeting when I felt very much more like going to bed, so I went to the latter very early and had a good night.

January 12th
My dear son's birthday, he is actually 12 today. 12 years ago that small sweet creature appeared with the pink hair that earned him his name. I being in bed half the day it was a very dull birthday for him, dear thing, no party or "string hunt", only a cake with no candles but I simply hadn't the energy for anything. I got two letters from my man today, quite well, but I miss him more and more I just hate his absence.

January 13th, Wednesday
Win and I have been in Town all day. I never felt less inclined to go about in my life for really I felt positively ill with my throat and if only it had been possible should have gone to bed but we had a good deal of business to do and she returns to school tomorrow. We finished up the day by going to tea with Mother who was having Bridge and found Herman and Lena there. Poor H is in hospital with frost bite in both feet, but otherwise very well. We didn't get back till 8.30. I find travelling these days a weariness: so full, so late, and nothing but soldiers in hundreds, often times very aromatic and sometimes the worse....every train crowded and every train late and then the toil from the station, its no fun at all. I long just to stay at home, somehow just now all is effort and I am feeling horribly low, though I can't own it to anyone but my Diary.

(so - a gloomy diary, but as you can see, the Press and the associated adverts tried to cheer folk up...)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The Munich item...I wonder if Walter knew this too? and below, the report of German atrocities which had started to come through in 1914, and which even Wynne had questioned then...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 14th - 18th

With her niece going off to school, and plenty of other chores, Wynne is kept busy, though Gran is becoming a big problem.
viewer_6.description:
January 14th, Thursday
I can't think what sort of a throat I've got, no cold whatever, no relaxed feeling but so sore that I could cry when I swallow and I can hardly speak, most odd. Very busy packing Win off to school. I do miss the child most awfully, she is a darling and so good. I took her to the station and Mrs Lees meets her at Waterloo. Letters from my man, nothing much doing and all this inactivity though blessed for our nerves makes the time seem to drag still more and the future stretches out in an endless series of tomorrows. Horrible news of a fearful earthquake from central Italy comes today. Rome and its surrounding have felt it badly and Avezzano is completely destroyed, thousands of lives are lost and its all a tragedy, and so even in a country which is not at war comes news of calamity, a tragic time indeed.

January 15th
A busy day of sending parcels, writing letters and fighting my throat! which still continues vile. War news is scant, thank goodness our men are having an easy and I fancy so long as these fearful weather conditions of wet last they will not do much. The Skippys came to sup, he is working at the Depot here, hard at it all day long and is now promoted Major.

January 16th
This has been rather a lovely day, we are all better, the sun has shone and we all went out for a run! and to tea with Mrs Parsons who lives on the hill. My wonderful old Gran still lives on and in two months time will be 101. I can scarce believe it, she is perfectly well but so often very wandering and every evening we have the going home tack to contend with. She cannot grasp at all that this is her home and one wearies in trying to make her understand.

January 17th
Thank goodness more than half of this month is over. I pray for the time to pass. One positively hates it and never has a winter seemed so long, yet thank goodness for more to do than I can possibly manage, it is the only saving grace. I was reading over one of my old Diaries last night, how curiously different from the journals I produce year by year now-a-days, but how much wiser it is, for this particular one I was reading was full of sentiments and feelings and though all my old journals are kept locked there must surely come a day when other eyes but mine will read them and so I shall come in for a good deal of careless jibes and jeers! This one was about my first meeting with Herbert and it is odd reading in the face of all that happened afterwards. Blessed day that brought us together.

January 18th, Monday
The day of the Winter Tea Party for my women has come and gone and I always feel a relief when this comes to pass. We had many fewer this year from one cause or another and so were not so crowded. The Birleys came and Mrs Skippy helped and all went off very well. I returned to find my dear old Gran battling with the maids and wanting as she always does every night now to go off home. I am distracted, I really don't know what to do with her, in body she is wonderfully well but her mind at times is hopelessly gone and tonight she was furious and vowed she would never come again etc.etc. So old a being is a great problem. Mead, her former maid, I had to dismiss because they fought so and in her place I have such a nice girl but Gran complains that she's not clever and has cold hands!

This postcard stuck in on January 18th is actually more interesting than the caricatures on its front - it was sent from Switzerland by a friend of Wynne's, who was acting as a "postman' between her and her Uncle in Munich - Wynne sent the letters to Switzerland, and then they could be sent on, in unsealed envelopes, to Germany from there. In this way she apparently kept in touch - but so far, no record if there was a response. As you can see in another of the windows this month, Munich was not exactly pro- British!!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The Serbian successes - an excerpt from the paper.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 19th - 25th

Wynne packs her son off to school and spends time with her cousin. Life quietens down but Gran's situation worsens.
viewer_8.description:
January 19th, Tuesday.
A truly vile day and into Aldershot I had to bicycle to attend to some S.S.&A work, a most boring job. I simply have to be at the municipal buildings to help the girl who does it and there's precious little to do. The cold was perishing and one is so slack these days about doing anything at all.

January 20th
I feel so thankful last week is over, it was a horrid time and on this day when Win and I went to Town I felt I'd much sooner lie down and die!

January 21st
There is a distinct "stirring" in the air. I hung out of the window this morning and felt it. The birds were feeling it too for their conversation I found was a little "free". Oh how one longs for Jan and Feb to go, I'm positively sick of this winter although one is always so busy it is an endless time.

January 22nd
What a difference in the weather - a snow storm rageth today and I had to take Pinkie to school (Paddington). We went up by the 10.2 and arrived half an hour late, conveyed his box to P and then rushed over to Mother to lunch, leaving her as we thought in plenty of time we found on reaching the station that her clock was ten minutes slow and if his train had not been late in starting we should have missed it. I then flew to the stores in the most awful weather, shopped and flew on to Waterloo where I had arranged to meet Brenda. I waited and waited and at 3.5 I found the 2.10 had not left the station and no B was to be seen so I went and had tea, then strolled out and sat in the train. Found B, and never left until 4.15 arriving home 6.30, too beastly for words. I vow I'll not go to Town for ages again.

January 23rd
It is so nice having B here to buck to and Maby also came home tonight so I shall not be so busy and I really do rather want a little "slack time". The weather being vile we sat in doors all day and at 6.30 went to a concert at the Institute given by the soldiers from Tweezledown Camp, a most amusing show, how we laughed, it was a real Tommies concert and one realized in K's army what a variety of men there are for really some were quite educated men.

January 24th
I get daily letters from H now, a great joy. He has been in temporary command of the Division owing to Gen Capper being on leave. All well with him thank goodness and not much doing.

January 25th
Brenda left today and I went down with her in Walker's car at about 1.30 after which I took my Mothers Meeting and was much annoyed because only 11 turned up. A long letter from H today, no particular news and nothing much doing. I wonder how long they are going to sit at Sailly sur le Lys. Old Gran has been so feeble all day and so off her head she talks incessantly and one can hardly understand a word of all she says. It is sad to watch and it is not living at all.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Some cartoons Wynne obviously liked - typical of the period, and offering a more hopeful if untrue picture!

When you're hunting a bear, You should always take care, To keep bruin well to the front;
For it's awkward to find, That the bear is behind, And it's you who are bearing the brunt.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
January 26th - 29th

Spring, the Kaiser's birthday, and various visits all noted...but Wynne is feeling poorly and goes to bed with flu without finishing the month.
viewer_10.description:
January 26th, Tuesday
A most lovely day and I actually gardened and made my first Spring Pie - of aconite, violet, jasmine, polyanthus and aubretia. I bicycled into Aldershot this morning on SS&A work and distributed prizes up at the school this evening at 6.30. An order from the police for all lights out tonight and even vehicles are to carry no lights, what will the result be!

January 27th
The Emperor of Germany's birthday - oh! why did not some Nurse give him a Plum Pudding on his first appearance, it would have saved a lot of worry! We looked today for much excitement in the way for success of the Huns as a present to William but instead it was the other way round and Beatty has managed to check another raid and sank the Blucher, the biggest Dreadnought in the world. Very fine work.
Here is a leaf from H's garden! (apparently at Sailly sur le Lys). He also sent a piece of Pink which I am going to try and grow. Gertie M came today. It is always a pleasure to me to have her and it is more than a year since she came down. We are having such bitterly cold weather it really is awful.

January 28th
This morning Herman with his poor frost bitten feet turned up just for a few minutes in a gorgeous car belonging to some people at Guildford with whom he is staying. He looks splendid and as usual like all the other returned warriors, so fat!

January 29th, Friday.
What oh! what is upon me, whence these "hairy" feelings? I creep about and my flesh creeps too, and if I'm not in for flu what then is it? Herman came to tea today bringing with him a lovely lady, a Mrs Williams and Mrs Parsons also came and I dispensed tea shivering and aching the while! One does not feel one's best at these times nor look it! but there is much influenza about and I shouldn't wonder if I found some up at the schools on Tuesday.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
This is an interesting epilogue to the story of the attack on Hartlepool that you can read about in December 1914...

Wynne stuck it into her diary at the end of the January entries...

january.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. With most of the world now at war, her diaries are packed with pictures and cuttings...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
A rare moment of tranquility - Herbert's Staff Captain, Stewart Gore-Browne, entertains the children (Ysobel and Eleanore) in the garden at Upper Hale. He is telling them a story about the marriage of their two toys - Peter (the rabbit, of course!) and Fanny. If you scroll down you can read transcripts of two amusing and interesting letters Gore Browne wrote to Wynne in October, caused by his reception of copies of the photos. You can also see and read a card from him after the war, Christmas 1919.

Gore-Browne was a remarkable man, and went on to have a fascinating career in Africa.

Once married (top picture), they could then depart on their honeymoon (bottom picture!). Both girls adored the Captain.

Letter from S. Gore Browne, responding to Wynne's enclosing the photos you see above. 5.10.

Dear Mrs Jackson
I am very much ashamed of myself for not having written before to thank you for the wedding groups. I was awfully glad to have them, the intellectual expression of the contracting parties is something to be glad of in these superficial days. One question. Is it to be hoped that somewhere about next March ? the union may be blessed etc? If so I should like to be allowed to present a christening mug. Of course there's always the chance that a War baby may have already appeared - one is so suspicious of these hastily carried out marriages.
I don't know what to tell you in the way of news, as I expect you hear it all. The General is very well, and wonderfully cheerful and equable in spite of the Arctic beastliness of the vulgar little booth we inhabit. I expect he's told you all about it - how the beautiful blue sky and the lush green grass show through the walls, and the sound of the spitting of the ancient Flemish farmer in the next room mingles with the cooking of our (ex Mauretania) chef. However we're off tomorrow, thank goodness.
You will have heard all the tales, repeatable and unrepeatable, I expect also. One rather nice incident occurred the other day when a soldier wrote to a cousin of mine asking her to send him some drawers, "for my trousers are so harsh they have my skin scoured off me"! I thought it was rather prettily put.
My home has become a hospital, at least Brooklands has, and my people now inhabit the servants' hall. I rather envy the patients in it, but very likely they'd prefer a nice cheery spot like the Herbert Hospital with its outlook on the cemetery, one never knows.
I am always meaning to write to your son to thank him also for a photograph in which I look only a little less inane than the bride and bridegroom, but that is by the way, I expect I do too.
The apology for a fire in Dobb's 50 Franc stove has ceased apologising for the last hour and icicles are beginning to form on the Louis Seize chairs (spoils of Ypres which adorn our hut like rubies round a charwoman's neck) so it is fully time I got into my blankets, and the General into his. He is sadly reading the Daily Mail of the day before yesterday (price 2d in this country) at the moment. Once more thank you for the photographs. Yours sincerely, S Gore Browne.

A second letter was sent, written 18.10.1915.

Dear Mrs Jackson,
Thank you very much for your letter. All I can say is that if they've been in bed for 5 months on end, and still there's no change then the gentleman must be what Le Petit Bob said the visitor was of whom his mother had such a poor opinion, in Gyp's (?) book of that name!
We are still idling and living in comparative comfort. I said to the old woman who cooks for us, the other day, that the general was pleased with his food. She beamed all over, and asked if you were a good cook. I plunged in, and was in the middle of explaining that you were famed throughout England for your feats in the kitchen which only just fell short of her own, when her husband interposed with "Perhaps, since he is a General, he keeps a cook as well as a wife"!
We are anxiously awaiting our next orders. To be prepared for everything I have sent for a Greek Testament, the only book in the language I now possess, but I think it is hardly likely to be required. Opinions still vary and everywhere from the Keil Canal to the Caucasus is still suggested.
Thank you very much for the kind things you say at the end of your letter. As far as I am concerned anyhow they are only too little deserved. I wish they weren't - for it would be quite impossible to have anyone nicer or easier to work for. I'm not saying that to please you. I wish you could hear what all sorts and conditions of people say in the Division, on the same subject. Perhaps you can realise the difference it makes when everybody both trusts and is fond (the two don't always go together) the man who is responsible for them, and how grateful one is.
Please, whatever you do, do not say that I said this - but I thought you would like to hear it perhaps first hand.
Yours very sincerely, S Gore Browne.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 8th

Wynne's depression with the war deepens when she learns her husband it to go back to France. Charity work and a visit to London does not help.
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Thursday
For nearly a year has this world wide conflagration been waging, what thousands of lives have been lost and we are no nearer the end of it. How ridiculous it is to look back upon the absurd prophesies of so many declaring the end would come in a few months, by Xmas, by April and so on. When Kitchener is reported to have given it 3 years all laughed but here is one nearly gone and we are "as you were" so far as the End is concerned, so it goes on. The casualties are printed day by day with never varying regularity and the papers are full of heated controversies over conscription, munitions and the carping and cavilings at one Minister or another.

July 2nd
Maby and I went into Farnham today to a concert given by Miss Leefe in aid of the Officers' Familiies Fund, that particular branch is of necessity suffering more than the world will ever know and this fund has been started by Lady Lansdowne in aid of their straightened circumstances. The concert was well attended and so I hope they made some money.

July 3rd
This is one of my Hut days but as my dear man got away for the week end Mrs Richards kindly accepted Maby instead. I am so loth to lose an hour of any leave he may get as it can't be long before he has to go.

July 4th
The young "Crinty" came to tea today. It was rather embarrassing but all passed off all right and H did not eat him up. I'm sure he enjoyed the change from barrack room fare. (This probably refers to one of Herbert's subalterns).

July 5th
To the Hut again and a very busy evening as it was concert night and every seat full. A regular Tommy concert and I inwardly shrieked over the Patriotic Songs from a bull-voiced old fool who waved his arms and sang John Bull etc, at the saucy and doubtful ditties rendered more fanciful still by a sprightly and smart young lady and so on, but the men loved it all.

July 6th, Tuesday
Today I skipped off to Town for 3 days in order to see the Holland House Rose Show and am staying with the Grays. I spent a very pleasant day there with Lena and am glad I was not aware of the bitter news which was to greet me on my return, viz. that my man has had sudden orders and is off to the Front in a few days time.

July 7th
When I awoke this morning I couldn't think what was oppressing me so and then it all suddenly came to me. Of course his ultimate departure one expected but this suddenness was far from our mind. He is to leave Winchester on Sunday and embark on Monday, that is at present how it stands. The day started and ended by being drenching wet, however having promised to meet Brenda at the Show I went and we stayed there till about 3.30 when we left to do some shopping and have tea and moon around.

July 8th, Thursday
This has been a vile day, all morning I sat tortured by the Dentist and really left feeling more dead than alive. I came home by the 11.45 and really am feeling horribly ill, bad luck with my man coming home tomorrow for the night to say goodbye.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Telegrams were used frequently, and were quite cheap. They also came to be feared. These two which Wynne stuck into the diary were (top) from her husband on his way back to France and (bottom) from her brother, newly arrived from India.
Below them is a typical Field Service Post Card - as you can see, this was the quickest route via the censors!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 9th - 15th

Wynne goes down with German measles just as Herbert leaves for the Front. With her husband and her brother "ordered Front" her worries intensify. The Welsh Miners go on strike.
viewer_4.description:
July 9th
I had a sudden inspiration yesterday to wire and ask Mary to come down to see H and she came. He also arrived and Stella drove me down to meet him at 3.50. I am feeling most horribly ill "what can the matter be", its bad luck when just today I'd like to be fit.

July 10th
A true calamity has befallen this morning. I felt less of a beast but upon looking at myself in the glass behold I was covered with rash! I went down with H and said goodbye to him at the station and tried to find Tanner (her doctor) but he was out however at 4.0 he came and pronounced me to have German Measles. My thoughts fly to Poggy - supposing he gets it out there. I am haunted by the thought.

July 11th
My man writes that he doesn't leave Winchester until Monday and is to cross Tuesday night and as all his baggage and office has gone he will spend Mon. night with the Franks at Crowborough. How horrible it is to contemplate that if it were not for my vile measles he could have come here. I do not feel cheerful today.

July 12th
What is there to write about when you are in bed with measles, when your man is going to the Front and when you can't see him - the less said the better I think.

July 13th, Tuesday
Today a fateful wire arrived from Ell: "Ordered Front" it read. On Sat. I had one "Leave Postponed". He had hoped to get over last week and so now we know why he can't get here. Oh! God protect them both.

July 14th
This morning I got 2 letters from Crowborough and his farewell wire sent from Folkstone so that is the end and by now he must be in France and the old ache has begun again, accentuated by the added presence of dear Ell there, and its all like a hideous nightmare. This enforced idleness on my part does not help matters but I am going to get up tomorrow and shall garden all day long. The evening is grey and so are my thoughts.
The papers are all agog on account of the Welsh Miner Strike which in defiance of their leaders advice the men declare they will bring off tomorrow. Accordingly the Government have served them the first course of the Munitions Act and we will see what happens tomorrow. I wish the earth would swallow the lot up.

July 15th Thursday
Today by the 2nd post I got a Field PC from my dear so I know that his crossing is safely over and he has reached Boulogne (and you can see the PC in the preceding window). Nothing from Ell as yet. The Welshmen have defied the steps taken by Government and have decided on Strike, a curious state of affairs and the lawlessness of it seems appalling, the whole thing of course has its origin in German engineering and they must be delighted to realize to what extent they have upset our industrial apple cart. The men like so many blatant fools are totally unaware of these deep waters. I came down here today and am isolated in my little room and the garden where I feebly tried to do some work but Oh! how groggy I am. I'm sure these legs cant be mine.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Part of the article about Venice that Wynne mentions in her entry for July 16th.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 16th - 20th

The Coal Strike starts, and Herbert lands at Boulogne but avoids being posted under Rawlinson. Wynne recovers enough to pick fruit and pack parcels.
viewer_6.description:
July 16th
200,000 men are out today. One awaits results with wonderment. "What can the Government do," said one to the Times representative, "they can take us to the tub and put a shovel in our hands but they cannot make us work." and there it rests and one fails to see what power the poor Government has got.
Such an awful day, it has never ceased to pour and blow since early morn. I read and write and fiddle and potter and still there seems time for more! This cutting about my beloved Venice delights me, how I would love to see it under these conditions, quite like its old days. How awful if anything happens to St Marks and the Doge's Palace. Two letters came from Ell today but alas they were both for Mother and I had to forward them. I burn to know their contents. I do wonder if they give any address!
(The Venice article is in the preceding window...)

July 17th
I was indeed rejoiced today to get a long letter from my Dearest written in the vicinity of St Omer where he went on landing at Boulogne. He had a splendid crossing and says it was rather a wonderful show as all the way they were escorted by torpedo and picket boats. He said that they were to be there for 4 or 5 days and then move nearer the firing line. He sent me this delightful picture of our German "friends" dressed up in their respirators but wished me to paste paper over the reverse! This I certainly shall not do and I only wish the whole of it were there! He also sent me this little flag: they were having France's Day and this had been given to him. (The flag is at the top of this page, the mask cartoon in the next window). No more cases of measles yet but its bound to come. I keep reminding myself, Oh! if Poggy only escapes it would be awful if he were to get it. I've been gardening a lot today but such a gale blowing and lots more rain, too vile for words.

July 18th
What is the matter with the weather in this old country, it pours and rains, blows a gale and as for the sun we never see him except when he looks dissipated and bleary eyed. Another letter from my old darling, he tells me he has had a narrow shave of being under Sir H.R's command again, ye gods! what a thought. (A reference to Sir Henry Rawlinson, a general "promoted by Haig each time he lost a battle" as Denis Winter notes in "Haig's Command").

July 19th, Monday
Mother came today and I hope she will stay some time with me. I only hope I shan't give her measles as I am not free till Wed. A letter from Ell today, did I ever mention he is now Capt. Llewhellin. Dear old man he has reached Rouen and is there awaiting orders and thinks he'll either be sent to the 15th or 4th Cavalry. I do wonder if he'll meet H, the latter and his Division were to move to their line yesterday and I gather it is somewhere between Ypres and Estaires.

July 20th
I spent my morning picking raspberries for bottling and jam and the afternoon making up 5 parcels for my different men, 2 of whom are prisoners. These latter are a fearful business, each parcel must be done up in 2 separate wrappers and contain another string label and paper and 3 notices have to be written out for each and the address is written 3 times on each, the only saving grace being that they go post free. I only hope that some of them reach their destination, poor chaps.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Propaganda.

Cartoons were everywhere during the war, but this caption assures us that this is not a caricature, but the actual official model for German gas masks! "Tout commentaire serait superflu!"

However the propaganda war was waged in many different ways - here is a report from an English paper, quoting a German paper praising the anti-war stance of the Labour party...and below that, a song purporting to be a German variety theatre celebration of the sinking of the Lusitania:

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 21st - 26th

The Coal Strike is averted, thanks to Lloyd George, but news of Russian retreats, and of conditions at Gallipoli, keep spirits low.
viewer_8.description:
July 21st, Wednesday
This cutting is really lovely, I got it out of the Times, the Berlin correspondent of the Cologne Gazette must be a splendid English scholar. Sometimes the extracts from their papers amaze one at their crass ignorance. A lovely morning ending in a vile day - so much rain.

July 22nd
The Coal Strike is Over. LG has been down talking to the men and new concessions have been put to them by the Government which they have graciously accepted. It is awful to see how the serving of the Munitions Act was not the slightest bit of use, they simply ignored it and it is a horrible thought to realize that any body of men can defy a Govt. measure, surely the beginning of the end to law and order. This was the day of the M.U. tea and I was supposed to have them all down to the garden afterwards, however the rain willed otherwise and we had to manage in the Institute.

July 23rd
I am feeling most vilely stale today. Perhaps it is on account of the weather which is disgusting, every day we get torrents and buckets of rain and high gales just like October. I tried to do a little gardening but it was no joy, and Poggy writes that he has suspicions of measles, oh! my dear and the Russians are now retreating on Warsaw and its all horrible. I hear today that Gen. Baldock has been badly wounded, I am so sorry and that Gen. Percival is to get his Division. I didn't even know he was out there.

July 24th
This letter about Gallipoli is so interesting, he is a splendid writer and I wonder has he ever written a book. What horrors they are going through, our poor men. The Western Front with all its awfulness is not as bad as this surely. A busy afternoon at the YMCA. (See a part of the article Wynne refers to in the next window)

July 25th, Sunday
What I should do without my dear man's daily letters I can't think, they are a sort of mental tonic for the day. he writes so well and tells me all sorts of small news of everything and everybody. The following story is sweet - a Corporal of his just before leaving Winchester found a lot of new harness that had been left behind so the thrifty man put it into a sack and took it along. In due course a breeching broke and he at once said he had some in his sack but when it was produced and emptied it was found to contain nothing but manure! Either he had picked up the wrong sack in the dark or someone had stolen it and replaced it by this treasure! Anyhow he'll never hear the last of it I fancy.

July 26th
I bicycled in this evening to the Hut as usual taking with me a huge armful of roses to make our counter smart for it is concert night, and such a concert, just as the tommy loves: popular, patriotic and sentimental. There is one old buster who comes every Mon. and who always sings John Bull and "Revenge", the latter a melodramatic effort containing much fiery and fiendish laughter and I nearly die over it every time.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Part of the article about Gallipoli that Wynne mentions in her entry for July 23rd.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
July 27th - 31st

Wynne discovers her brother is posted to Bethune, and hears a strange story about 50 Belgians who escape to Holland and enlist. Now, though, the time of waiting starts....
viewer_10.description:
July 27th, Tuesday
Gertie Maclean came today, it is always a joy to me to have her, so easy and pleasant in the house and so homey. We sit and talk over old days for of course she is connected with so much of our mutual past. Ell writes that he is "up" now and in his letter gave a cypher which we are puzzling our brains over as to where he is.

July 28th
Mrs Percival came to tea today and we put before her Ell's conundrum and she guessed at once "Bethune", so that is where he is and from H's veiled hints I gather he is south of Ypres. He writes an amusing story of the inhabitants of Limbourg: their anniversary of the "Battle of the Spurs" fought in 1302 between Flemish and French was at hand and they asked leave of the Governor to celebrate it by sports. One item was a bicycle race in which they were allowed to indulge on condition they each carried a German flag so at 2.30 fifty young men set forth and at 4.0 a German band began to play in the Square where the people were assembled to watch the men come in. Time passed and at 6.0 no man had appeared, the Band still playing and the people still waiting, when it was discovered that they had all crossed the Dutch frontier and gone to join the Belgian army!! and as each carried a flag they were allowed over the Frontier. It is very funny but history does not relate what vengeance the Governor wreaked upon the unfortunate inhabitants.

July 29th
Holidays have begun. Maby left on Tuesday, and my other two are gone a visiting, Win to the Farbrothers and Pinkie to the Charsleys at Sydenham, both very grown up this visiting on their own.
My dear son's Report came today. He has never had a better one and I felt quite overcome when I read his Head's remarks. The good God is indeed good to us.

July 30th
We have actually had a fine hot day and sat out in the garden, this is the first time Mother has been able to do so. I'm not fond of July, it is so often a wet cold month, and then also it is the silent month for all birds cease to sing now, only the squeakings of the young as they are being fed, and the sound of the thrush cracking his snails upon the stone anvil can be heard. I am busy bottling my fruit and jamming everything I can lay hands on, I wonder I don't seize all the furniture and old boots and jam that.

July 31st, Saturday
The inevitable has happened, that which we have had in our minds ever since Ell left Seryah, for he sent 3 lines today saying he was in the trenches, of course it was bound to come, its what he joined for, but oh! how anxious it makes one. Still nowadays with so many millions who wait at home over the same anxiety one almost feels it is a presumption to complain. In the face of so much universal sorrow our own seems like a grain of sand. It is only in one's inward and grey thoughts that one dares to give vent to the horror of it all.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: Post Cards sent back by Herbert, illustrating the destruction of Ypres...

july.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Her husband is called back to the Front...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The first page for June in Wynne's diary...

As you can see, she has stuck in not only the whole Grenfell poem, but also his obituary notice, and the sonnet Maurice Baring wrote for him after he died, and which was published in the Times:
"Because of you we will be glad and gay;
Remembering you, we will be brave and strong;
And hail the advent of each dangerous day,
And meet the great adventure with a song."
(But the songs were beginning to sound false - after 1915 they became considerably more discordant).

Grenfell's poem was actually published in the Times on the same day as his obituary. He died on May 26th in the afternoon in Boulogne.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 7th

Wynne's favourite month...but she notes the death of Julian Grenfell and other events that cloud her pleasure, and remembers her engagement 14 years before.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Tuesday
My most favourite month of the year.
