Others have much to commend them but the month of Roses, Pinks and Sweet Peas is hard to beat and I revel in it, but all months are sad this year and it is hard to take the usual joy in it all. This pathetic little poem was written by one of the Grenfells and sent by him to the Times and now he himself has died of wounds. His brother and cousin also have been killed. Alas! his is only one of many such instances. (Wynne is here referring to the now famous poem, "Into Battle" - if you want to know more, Nicholas Mosley's book, "Julian Grenfell" or Stallworthy's recent book for the Imperial War Museum exhibition, "Anthem for Doomed Youth" are both worth reading. The latter's conclusion, that the poem "illustrates the hypnotic power of a long cultural tradition; the tragic outcome of educating a generation to face not the future but the past" is hard to argue with. Wynne appears to be agreeing with that in her own way. See the title page in the previous window).

June 2nd
Ell writes that he has been very bad with fever and so he and a friend are going up to Mableshwah for a change until they sail on the 15th. Bombay must be a most awful hole at this time of year. I forget whether I mentioned that a Bazaar is to be held here on the 16th to wipe off a Parish debt - what a hopeless year to raise money. We attended a meeting at the Vicarage at 12 and discussed the stall arrangements.

June 3rd
A day at home and gardening, somehow even gardening has lost its savour these days because one feels all the time that one is wasting time and that one should be doing something else.

This pathetic little piece I found in the Times, thank goodness during even such a time of storm and stress people find time for sentiment.

June 4th
The glorious 4 of June, not so much glory about it this year. Brenda and I took Walker and drove over to Blackwater to see Rita who has taken a little house there for 6 months, such a pretty little place and lovely garden. All the way there we passed streams of soldiers, horses, mules, wagons etc - I never saw such traffic.

June 5th
Oh! Day of glorious memory! My man and I exchanged wires, would that we could have been together but perhaps next year - 14 years ago today we tied the knot.

June 6th
I was much pleased this evening when Gen and Mrs Perceval were announced. He was home on 3 days leave, he tells me that Capper, H's late Div. Gen. has been relieved of his command and is home, Gen Sir H Gough having got the 7th Division now. Would that H were under him. I had a letter from Capt Lindsell the other day saying how awfully well they had done lately and no wonder with such a General, it makes one pretty sick where H is concerned.

June 7th, Monday
Brenda (her cousin) left today to my sorrow. The weather is glorious and so hot and I am longing to sleep in the hammock but can't summon up sufficient courage! (It was Wynne's custom in the summer to sleep out in the garden at night - she continued this until she left England).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Part of an article Wynne put into her June diary which provided an interesting comment on German organisation. Germany managed to cope with the blockade in many creative ways - not least by creating an impressive military-industrial complex which was very new. One of the great unsung heroes behind this was a scientist - Fritz Haber - the man who discovered ways to make both artifical fertiliser (thus enabling the country to feed itself) and poison gas...both from the same source.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 8th - 19th

Notes her brother's arrival in France from India, and her own 36th birthday.
viewer_4.description:
June 8th, Tuesday
A wire from Ell forwarded by Mother to say he arrived at Marseilles on Sat 5th and so we now await his first letter with longing. We also got his last from Bombay by this mail - they sailed on the 18th and he had charge of 60 men. He had again been horribly seedy with fever and acute quinsy and I am thankful he is in Europe.

June 9th
Mother came today. Her rheumatism is very bad and she has decided to do a course of Droitwich baths. I do hope it may do her good but I wish she could find someone to go with. (A reference to the Droitwich, UK, spa - still evidently popular).

June 10th
I am reading one of the spy books by ex Intelligence officers, it is a description of Stiebers method, what a service, admirable in its fiendishness. I've been engaged in leaving circulars for the Red Cross Penny collection today - the whole countryside is doing it.

June 11th
This relic of ancient days has just come to light, and it really must be preserved. How sweet we all look, especially Mother and I! Gracious it must be 25 years old seeing that I am just on 36! We were very much rejoiced to get a letter from Ell today, the first after landing. They had a rough start but it improved, and were warned of submarines on the way home but thank God all was well.

June 12th...and following
A week has passed in the which I've had a birthday and become 36. I had some nice presents, an egg boiler and a blouse from Mother, garden scissors from the children, and £10 from my dear man. The sale at the Vicarage came off on Wednesday 16th, a very hot day and Stella and I worked like blacks. We realized £8.12.0 at our stall and the total was between £70 and £80 so I don't think we did too badly but I am glad it is over. On Friday i went to the Hut which I always love and on my return found my dear man who came down in order to go with me today to Malvern to see our bantling. We started at 9.24 from North Camp and arrived about 1.30 and found Pink awaiting us.
(Diary resumes on June 20th)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: An interesting comment on the times...see her comment on this in the June 23rd entry....holiday time!

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 20th - 25th

Wynne and her husband visit their son in Malvern School. Back home she cuts out an article on "idling", then notes her own activities in an age where this is now not possible.
viewer_6.description:
June 20th, Sunday
We had a ramble and a visit to the school yesterday afternoon and today we went to Service in the morning at the Priory, and for a walk after lunch and tea and then to supper with a Mrs Thursby, an old friend of H's family. Mrs de Mornay is here and we have rooms in a fearful place because the usual haunts are full. Food scarce but not bad, rooms with hardly any furniture, the very hardest bed I've ever met so that one feels quite sore in the morning, and no garden. It has been a very great joy both to Pink and me, H's coming down. He has never been since we inspected the school over 3 years ago. (Against this entry, she has stuck the Alexandra Day pin you can see on the left, given her by her son).

June 21st
We left this morning by the 8.28, Pink and Charlie (de Mornay) coming to see us off. We went up to Town to stay the night with Mother and H returned to W. I found Charlie (Maclean) staying at the flat for the night, poor fellow it is most distressing to see him, he drags one leg as a result from concussion and is quite helpless, it is so sad and the specialist seems to hold out very little hope.

June 22nd
I got back at 1.0 and went to the Hut where I took office for a while and then served the gentleman recruits. Mr Whitehead was there, he is applying for a commission. The pianist was also there and he plays simply too beautifully, it is a treat and a joy to hear him. I do wonder who he is, one comes across such strange people in the New Armies.

June 23rd
On the opposite page I insert a description of our feelings of today, "idling" an erstwhile pleasure has truly become a thing of the past and work in any form is really a luxury, now that I have two days regularly at the Hut I am happy and there is always so much to do at home. Today I've been collecting for the Red Cross. Last week leaflets had to be left at every house in the Parish and today I went to reap where I had sown. They all gave willingly except one woman who locked her door and refused to show up. I saw her within, her name is Durham, and may she get her deserts.

June 24th
A day of letter writing, mail letters and a suspicion of rain.

June 25th, Friday
My dear man got away today for the week end again. I've been absorbed in Lloyd George's speech of yesterday. As Minister of Munitions he's far more pleasant than Chancellor of Exchequer and he is now doing his utmost to cope with the shortage of ammunition and the labour question. I put here a resume of what he said. Poor Skippy has lost his young half-brother. I knew him so well and always liked him. He was killed on the 16th by shrapnel in the chest and is buried near Ypres. One by one they go and I am weary of it.
(Granville Arthur Skipwith is buried in the Bedford House Cemetery, 2.5 kms south of Ypres, or Ieper as it is known now. Bedford House was the British name for Chateau Rosendal, a private estate that was completely obliterated and ended up as a series of cemeteries.)

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
There are a lot of Waterloo cuttings in the June diary - this is one example which obviously intrigued her (bearing in mind she had just buried someone born the same year!).

Scroll down and read a poem from a woman, expressing fairly typical sentiments - but unusual in that many women wrote but few seem to have been published. If you want to check out this area, try "Scars upon my Heart" published by Virago.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 26th - 30th

Zeppelin alarms, gongs aplenty for her friends and a note on last year's assassination of the Archduke.
viewer_8.description:
June 26th, Saturday
A letter from Ell, merely a line to make arrangements about smokes. No news, nothing - wretch. He is still at the camp at Marseilles but evidently was very busy so I fancy in a day or two we shall hear something. H and I have spent the day in delightful pottering and kind Maby went and did YMCA for me. This night we had an amusing experience. At about 11.0 an unusual sound of firing caught our ear, but we thought little of it. About 10 mins after it had ceased a whistle and a voice under my window and Stella appeared in her dressing gown saying that Skippy, fearing a Zep raid, had made them all go down into the cellar!! How mad. I am sure it was only somebody's night operations.

June 27th
My dearest went back tonight, and oh! I miss him so horribly, each time he goes away i just miss him worse and the dreaded departure for the Front draws nearer and nearer. The War drags on, the casualty lists are awful, but two days ago the Neuve Chapelle Despatches and Honours List came out and many of our friends are now CBs, DSOs and Military Crosses, as for CMGs they are innumerable. It will be quite impossible to remember in future who is what! and a few letters tacked on will be sure to be correct!

June 28th
A year ago the Archduke Ferdinand and his wife were assassinated and we were in Austria, little dreaming how events would be a year hence. How strange it seems and I wonder how much Walter knew. I heard from him a day or two ago. He was well apparently but jolly hard up.

June 29th
My evening at the Hut again, a busy evening and mostly Office for me, everything gets neater and more business-like as the days go on owing to the over-mastering old maidishness of Mrs Myers, our manager. All is the pink of neatness and a host of unwritten rules and regulations hedges us about. Woe betide the lady who infringes them!

June 30th
The last day of my beloved month. Where has it gone with its roses and pinks. From a sense of duty I went today with Mrs Fitz to the Aldershot sale of work held in the garden of Aldershot Manor, Mrs Newcomes house. It was opened by Lady French (oh Lady of sad memories) and I hear they made £150. I don't think in comparison that's as good as our £81!

june.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Julian Grenfell and other events...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: National registration was brought in in to stimulate recruitment and to discover how many men between 15 and 65 were engaged in trades. Everyone had to register, and this is Wynne's card. I assume she stuck it into her March entry after the war, but she might not have done! The small window you have come from shows you the front of the card, which was folded and could fit into bags and purses.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 7th

Letters and parcels for the Front, but Wynne is feeling the pressure and missing her husband.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Monday
The month has indeed come in like a roaring lion and clouds of dust fly in whirlwinds down the road. It is a cold wind too and so one hopes the tradition about going out like a lamb will hold good. Mothers' meeting today as usual, 20 present. I have far fewer members this year but everything is upset by this vile war.

March 2nd
I rode into Aldershot this morning to SS&A. It is a stupid duty which has been thrust upon me, there is so little to do when I get there but as office doesn't close until 1.0 one cant leave before and I owe Mrs Birch a grudge for putting me on to it. It was a lovely day and I spent the afternoon pottering in the garden with the children.

(The picture on this page is of a damaged house in Antwerp - sent by Herbert)

March 3rd
I went up to Town today by 11.1 to see Charles (Maclean - her one time love). My train was late so I hastened off and did some shopping first, bought a hat, went to Douglas, had food and then to the Fishmongers hall which has been converted into a hospital for officers. it is an enormous place run by Lady Dimsdale. I found him looking fairly well but so weak and good for nothing, his head troubles him so much and his pulse is only 47, but he is to leave hospital on Friday and go down to Bournemouth to their house by the sea where he will pick up soon. (Two days after the start of the war, the Fishmongers' Company offered the main floors of their hall for use as a hospital. It was run by the Red Cross, and much of the cost was met by Henry Hirsch. It was located in the banqueting hall and could care for 30 patients. By the end of the war 1100 patients had been cared for there. It was temporarily closed in the summer of 1917 because of the threat of air raids, but did not finally close until 1919)

March 4th
I spent the morning writing mail letters and doing up parcels for the Front, such a business it is. He writes the men are so well clothed now that only eatables are necessary, so I send smokes, chocolates, soup and soaps etc...and have now reached Parcel 79!

March 5th, Friday
A day of odd jobs and tidying, constant interruptions and much exasperation in consequence. My daily news from my man continues in spite of his having moved, his move is only 2 miles away. I take it for granted that its forward, not that he's ever said so, and what can be the object of it I don't know. I have ceased to write War for a while almost in here, one gets weary of it all, back and fore goes the Russian side, back and fore the West, we hear rumours of the New Army being on the move but no one knows anything these days.

March 6th
A day of photography, it seems quite odd being at the old game again but I've got some awfully nice prints, the one of Herbert just before starting is particularly good.

March 7th, Sunday
To Kirk and second service, and wrote many letters after lunch. The children went to tea with Peggy Kipper and I to the Parsons and the Skippys came to supper which was nice of them as I have been feeling rather down today, I don't know why except that sometimes it comes over me that I simply cant carry on without my man any longer. Of course I've seen him in the interval but its over seven months since he left home for Cromarty and five since he went to the Front. 5 whole months, I can't realize it and Oh! I do want him home so horribly. I envy the Skippys being together but I would not have him wounded just to bring him home, but I can't help dreading the coming of summer when one knows things must be horrible again, what a summer it will be, what a dreadful year altogether! but enough of this.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This "cartoon", by Wynne (or possibly her Mother?) was inspired by the cutting shown enlarged at the bottom. This was from the "Sporting and Dramatic" News, a popular paper at the time amongst the shooting and fishing fraternity!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 8th - 13th

The family move to London while their house is being redecorated, and this offers a chance to cure the "blues". She hears her brother has now joined up.
viewer_4.description:
March 8th, Monday
I seem to have had a bad go of blues yesterday, it is always possible to be brave and cheerful and I think it wouldn't be healthy! Anyhow all is well today and I went to Committee in the morning at the White House, Mothers' Meeting in the afternoon and Intercession at 4 so that I was really too busy to have blues, it is idleness that is the cause!

March 9th
I am so very busy arranging a thousand things before we go to Town tomorrow. The painters and paperers are entering the house in our absence and pulling everything to pieces and there is much to see to. We go en famille to Mother tomorrow for 3 weeks and I am much looking forward to it but it will be nice to come back and find all this clean and new.

March 10th
Bag and baggage we trooped off to Town today and before the car came for us the paper fiends had arrived with their pots and pans and half the rooms were dismantled. I'm thankful to be away when all this is going on. We came by the 11.1 and got to the flat at 1.0, found Mother very cheerful and jolly and spent the afternoon unpacking and settling in. I found a letter from my dearest, he wrote from his new billet, apparently a larger house and more comfortable.

March 11th, Thursday
The children do their lessons as usual and at 12.0 we went out together and explored a little of Kensington Gardens just to show Maby where we are. We walked to the Round Pond and back and after lunch I took them to the Stores where we shopped hard till tea time, and sent H a parcel for his birthday, dear thing. I wish he were here for it.

March 12th, Friday
I didn't go out this morning as I was busy writing mail. We heard this morning that Ell had been attached to the 27th Light Cavalry at Secunderabad. He wrote on the 17th and joined on the 18th so at last he has gained his heart's desire and I suppose it will only be a matter of time before he is at the Front. Bridge this afternoon played from 3.30 to 7.30 and I won 3/6 - Aimee, Mrs Howden, Mother and I and we had very good games. I had such an interesting letter from Dearest tonight, written during action, his Division was engaged in a battle and he gave a most interesting account of it, how he sat at the telephone and below passing in the street were soldiers of every sort and prisoners captured that day. The paper today has a long account of it and it seems very satisfactory.

March 13th, Saturday
It is very interesting being in Town with a little time to do things. I was this afternoon with the children in Kensington Gardens. We walked past the Round Pond and on to Peter Pan's statue, one of the loveliest things of its kind I've ever seen with the exquisite figures of fairies, birds and animals introduced all round it. It has a grassy bank all round the back of it which is now a blaze of crocuses. We fed the ducks with bread and then walked over to meet Gertie M (aclean) at a tea shop in S. Kensington and came home by bus.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne's diary with cuttings about the advance towards Lille....an example of the quantity of material she managed to put onto every page. Part of the article is enlarged below...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 14th - 19th

Wynne is surprised to learn that Herbert has been relieved of his command and is coming home. He joins her in London
viewer_6.description:
March 14th, Sunday
This morning I went to St Anne's, Soho, with Rita and heard their lovely choir. It is a treat getting music like that. I then met Mother at the Grays where we lunched , I afterwards going to a concert at the Albert hall and Mother came home.
(St Anne's was destroyed in WW2, and now has only a small place to worship, set in a lovely tranquil garden in the heart of Soho).

March 15th
This day was chiefly spent in shopping and I took the children to Douglas where we all had our heads washed.

March 16th
I have been today to the Belgium Exhibition of Lace at the Grafton Gallery with G.M and then to tea with Miss Gilbert afterwards. I was glad to meet her, an interesting lady and a sister of "Gilbert and Sullivan".
Most extraordinary news came tonight which I received with very mixed feelings. My man has received orders to come home and report at the W.O. having been relieved of his Command of the R.A. 7th - of course the thought of having him home is too lovely but I know how he will hate leaving the 7th and I would that it were otherwise, but the world is a very upside down place at present.

March 17th
This is my man's birthday, and not knowing in the least when to expect him home and having arranged since some time to go down to Kew to see the Youngs I went off taking the children with me. It was bitterly cold, however we went all over the gardens which even now are charming and then called to see the Youngs who gave us tea and whom it was very nice to see again. He is employed as Caterer at Woolwich Regimental Mess. On our return home to my surprise I found my man had returned, he was looking awfully well and I am sure is glad of a rest and change, it is a great peace of mind to me to have him home, that last action Neuve Chapelle seems to have been awful and such hideous casualties and such awful losses among officers.

March 18th
It seems so strange having H home again. The W.O. have given him a little leave and have no orders for him yet. He lunched with Major Gray and I with her and we went afterwards to see "The Man Who Stayed at Home" in which Dennis Eadie is quite delightful. It is a splendid piece and most interesting, she came with me to tea at the Carlton afterwards. Oh! the place of bygone joys, what hundreds of years ago it seems since those days, "blues" creep over me at the very thought. This evening we dined with the Grays and Mr Mitchell was there, as nice as ever and still so fearfully deaf, poor one. He is doing ADC to the Chaplain General at the W.O. and working very hard.

March 19th, Friday
Mother and I went to the delightful matinee at the Haymarket today given in aid of the Recruiting Bands at which all sorts of "stars" performed and Genee delighted us by dancing "The Dryad", most lovely and entrancing person, every movement is a joy to behold and I could watch her for ever. It must be 10 years since we saw her do it last at His Majesty's.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Cards of the town of Estaires sent over by Herbert - they seem to have been rather oddly doctored with additional drawings...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 20th - 27th

To Sherborne for her niece's Confirmation, then back to London. they take is several shows, including a Royal charity performance.
viewer_8.description:
March 20th, Saturday
H and I went down to Sherborne today for Win's confirmation which is to be tomorrow. She met us at our rooms and after our arrival took us all over the school buildings and her house. We then had a long talk with Miss Hoyle who was high in praise of "my" child. Win then had supper with us and went home at 8.15. She is looking very well indeed and in great spirits.

March 21st
Today like yesterday has been one of endless sunshine and spring warmth. Win came after breakfast and we went to Matins at 11.0 in the Abbey, then she lunched with us leaving at about 2.0 to change and at 2.30 we went down to the Abbey to find it already crowded but managed to get good seats and by 3.0 all the candidates were seated and the Bishop of Salisbury confirmed them, over 90 of them. Win looked very sweet, her dress was of white lace and net and her veil plain net. It was all very nice. The gorgeous Abbey with its perfect decoration, the yellowstone architecture entirely untouched by time, and there knelt these young things entering on a new phase of life. I thought of my own confirmation nearly 20 years ago and wondered if I was any the better now than then.

March 22nd
We returned to Town by the 11.30 train, Win being allowed to run over early to say goodbye. We shall soon have her home for the holidays now, dear thing. Lady Fulton came to tea looking very nice as usual. I look upon her in distant admiration and awe! I shall never get to know her any better, and she gives me the feeling of being a dowdy uneducated parochial pog-bag cum camp hag frump. She is always so very au fait in everything, so full of the "very latest" in clothes, manners and intelligence, and I shall never feel otherwise than that she comes to see one for my brother's sake and that one is simply a sort of dingy microbe in her very fashionable life. I often wish this were not so.

March 23rd
A day of shopping and to tea came S'Woodie and B.G.S. It seemed odd to have around one our 3 only governesses, 3 different stages of them.

March 24th
A lovely day and alas! from 3.30 to 7.30 we played Bridge. I am very fond of the game but I can't bear it before tea, its such rotten waste of time in London too where there are such thousands of things to see and do. No town could be more full of interest than this old village of ours and so many who live here know nothing of it.

March 25th
Mother and I spent the morning worting and tidying her linen, such tons of it and in such a feverish muddle it was too! By 2.0 we were at the Colosseum for a grand matinee of all the stars in aid of the Y.M.C.A huts at the Front. The Queen and all the Royal ladies were there and the house was crammed, every item was done by celebrities and we didn't get home till 7.0!

March 26th, Friday
I have shopped hard all the morning and continued after lunch to which came Frank looking very well. He and H and the children all went off to the Zoo all the afternoon but I had to be back by 4.0 as Stella S came up. I have indulged in a new coat and skirt, a grey black cloth from Marshalls and I've got to pay 8 guineas for it which I don't like at all!

March 27th
To lunch with Mrs Gray taking the children with me, and afterwards all to the Hippodrome where the usual "Revue" took place and I must confess I was bored stiff, however they enjoyed it so that was good. I seemed to write nothing about the War these days, somehow now that Poggy is home it lacks interest for me! day after day it continues, the Russians have taken Premszyl but our side seems at a standstill and one is sick of it all.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: These are four fascinating cards. How they work is ingenious: when you hold them up to the light you can see, through a thinner section, a beam of light illuminating a submarine or zeppelin, or see in the fireplace the figure of a soldier. If you check out December you will see the one directly below demonstrated - the airship is sending a searchlight to illuminate the conning tower of a German submarine.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
March 28th - 31st

Sightseeing, Wynne is enraptured by Westminster Abbey which she obviously had never been to before.
viewer_10.description:
March 28th, Sunday
To St Anne's, Soho, in the morning and Westminster in the afternoon taking the children to the 3.0 service, what a most beautiful place it is and how full of interest. We are coming again tomorrow afternoon in order to see it properly for on Sundays the side chapels are closed.

March 29th
We went again to Westminster today but as there is a service every afternoon during this week we could not see round and went instead to the Museum of the United Service Institution. I had never been before to this most interesting place, it is in Whitehall and contains relics of all the great soldiers and sailors and battles of sea and land. There we saw the skeleton of "Marengo", Napoleon's favourite white charger. Also his chair that stood beside his bed at St Helena, the cabin furniture of Nelson, many personal effects of Napoleon including his razor and shaving brush found in the carriage he fled in from Waterloo. Cromwell's sword, Sir John Moore's medals, uniform and sash and heaps of other people's possessions besides old models of ships, old weapons, armours etc. We could not tear ourselves away and arrived home about 5.30.

March 30th, Tuesday
We have spent the whole morning in Westminster, the children, H, Maby and I, and no words of mine can give any idea of the wonderful interest and beauty of this place. It is curious how one rushed abroad to see St Peter's or St Mark's which though so perfect in their own particular style cannot be said to surpass our wonderful and aged old Abbey. All is perfect, every inch inside and out, and we got hold of a most interesting guide who was full of historical knowledge and not at all guide-bookish. He took us into that superb Henry VII chapel which he in 1503 built and decorated and filled with wealth and treasure and which his son Henry VIII devastated and plundered like he did much else. It has lately had its beautiful flags renewed for it is now dedicated to the Knights of the bath and the gorgeous colours with the sun streaming through on them made a picture to be remembered. What great interest too attaches to the chapel of the Kings, the Confessor's tomb, the chair of "Scone" around which tradition and fact are so closely woven, even asserting that the stone was the one on which Jacob had laid his head! but anyway its history begins in 850 when King Malcolm found it in Argyleshire and had it enclosed in a wooden chair and took it to the monastery of Scone in Perthshire, previous to this however it was known to have been brought over from Ireland by one Fergus, King of Scotland, the brother of the then irish King and it was erected at Scolmkil for his coronation. The "Lea Fail" or Stone of Destiny it is called and all our Kings and Queens have been crowned on it in that particular chair since the days of Edward 1 who brought it to the Abbey in 1296 and from where it has only once been removed, viz. when Cromwell was made Protector in Westminster Hall. How endless are the things of interest, the various chapels and monuments, the quaint old wax effigies of famous people, many taken from death masks all in the actual clothes they wore at their death or on some other occasion and carried at the head of the funeral procession and then kept until the monument was made. I was much interested in the malicious, cruel and yet sad face of Elizabeth, and much disappointed in the smug (face) of Mary Stuart who I had always imagined fragile and beautiful. William is just what one would imagine though and as for Queen Anne you can see in her cow-like and placid face the 19 children all of whom are buried here. Our guide showed and let us feel a gruesome thing. Long years ago the old chapel of the Norman Undercroft was used as a Kings Treasury and robbery being detected it was traced to one of the monks. Forthwith they flayed him alive and nailed his skin upon the door and there behind the iron clasps you still can feel it like a piece of hard wood! I don't believe hardly anyone knows about this! but I must not ramble on anymore**.

March 31st
Win returns today and H and I went to meet her, having done so we all went off to the City and wandered about in that strange and interesting place, then lunched and did more shopping, returning to the flat for tea. H and I dined with our dear Norman and Blanche Gray and talked endless shop which is manna to me these days!

**(Sadly for Wynne this lovely story has just been disproved - the skin is in fact that of a cow. However in the process of testing this old door, something more remarkable was discovered. It is in fact the oldest door in England, dating from around 1050, and therefore of Anglo Saxon origin. That dating was worked out from taking wood samples which showed that the tree it is made from grew between 924 -1030 AD, and the door, before it was cut down for the Undercroft, was probably an important one, possibly in use for the Chapter House. )

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
The Abbey as Wynne saw it, from cards taken from the Diary...check out westminster abbey website for the Abbey today. It has undergone numerous changes and a lot of cleaning since she saw it!

It was probably quite shortly after this that fear of the Zeppelin raids caused everything to be either removed to the crypt or heavily sandbagged - check out the later pictures.

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Her husband is recalled from the Front.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is the letter Wynne refers to in her May 2nd entry...she had a number of contacts abroad like this who sent products by mail: bulbs, tobacco etc. The stumbling English and the linkage to the war are interesting - salesmanship that suggests planting bulbs to supply hospital flowers! (see Wynne's own marking).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 7th

Wynne notes the use of poison gas, and feels very low but manages to visit Swanage where her husband is now working.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Saturday
One of the most lovely months has gone and what a lovely one it has been. Today for the first time for years it would have been possible to be Queen of the May in muslin, but there is no peace in which to enjoy it. The papers fill one with gloom and doubt. Today there is a wonderful account of the Canadians bravery at Ypres in face of these awful odds, what losses but what gallantry, the Dominions will well be proud. The latest invention of the Germans is poisonous gases and shells, and the men not being able to breath are naturally overcome. What will the devils think of next. Mysterious shells have now been fired on Dunkirk and no one seems to know from where.

May 2nd
These piteous appeals keep coming from Holland (see previous page, with the letter she mentions). They read like a Baboo's letter (a reference to the Indian babu or minor official often encountered on journeys in India) and if there were not tragedy behind it it would be very funny. I got a consignment of bulbs in the autumn from the same man - I'm bound to say they weren't much use but they came so late. I've sent for this lot and shall see if I have better luck. I've spent a long idle day by myself, just I and the children. It has been one of "blues" for me, thank goodness I don't often get them but today everything seemed stale and unprofitable and I was glad when it was over.

May 3rd
I wound up my Mothers' Meetings today and Oh! what a blessed relief it is, for though I have escaped a good many it has seemed a long season this year.

May 4th
Today Pink and I set forth to Swanage leaving by the 10.2 train which we all but missed through an error of Turner's overzealous boy who countermanded Walker! On arrival in Town we went straight to Guys Hospital where we at last ran Herman to earth, he poor chap home again, wounded this time in the leg but as the bullet passed clean through it will I hope not be too serious. We caught the 2.0 from W.Loo and on arrival at S 5.15 were met by H (her husband, not Herman) with whom we walked up the shore having sent our baggage to the hotel. Its lovely to be with him again and this is a very comfortable old place run by 3 old Miss Vincents, excellent food, good rooms and all very clean. The charge during summer season is three and a half guineas a week, without baths and morning tea. It is full of soldier folk of course as every hole and corner is now.

May 5th
As H is of course pretty busy we do not see much of him except at meal times, so we shall spend our day in exploring the coast line and country. Today we walked to Durleston Bay and found the same spot where we used to go 12 years ago when we were here before and Pink was a few months old and where one finds certain tiny shells. It seems so odd being here again and he now twelve and a half years old! After lunch we went the opposite way towards Old Harry, trudging along a very shingly beach and climbing over chalk boulders at the end, a lonely and bogey spot it seemed to me.

May 6th, Thursday
Today my son and I walked over to Studland, and Oh! what a climb it is, and how hot. We found the little place almost empty and really not much altered from the old days. We had tea at the Banks Arms, now called "The Hotel" and I gazed up with affectionate remembrance at the cave where Adie (Maclean) slept a hundred years ago!

May 7th, Friday
The weather still being perfect we made another lovely expedition. As my man was out at a field day we took our lunch in a basket and went away along the coast past Tilly Whim and the Lighthouse as far as Dancing Ledge. The pathway lay all along the top of the cliffs. I should have enjoyed it more if it hadn't for I find my nerves for precipices is entirely gone! and it makes me feel bogeyish! The view was perfect and the general air of peace hard to reconcile with the scenes of unutterable confusion being enacted across the water. The bluest of seas and skies, the faintest breeze and the very cry of the seabirds completed the beauty of it. We found a whole field full of "bee orchis" which we have sent to Mary. On arriving at Dancing Ledge an eerie lonely old quarry, we ate our lunch and I felt bogeyish so far away from the world. We found various fossils and crystals for Noots' collection and wandered home at our leisure getting back about 4.15.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne's son at Swanage - and a party out on the water....

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 8th - 11th

Wynne marvels at the new volunteers in training and notes the loss of the Lusitania. "The Germans are making desperate efforts and using the most foul and abominable methods..."
viewer_4.description:
May 8th
I forgot to mention that on Thursday I saw in the paper that poor Pussie Gowans has lost her man, died of wounds, and a curious coincidence occurred for on that very morning I lost my cigarette case which she gave me 14 years ago.
We went up today to watch some driving near barracks which H was judging, and after lunch Capt Gore Browne, H's Staff Captain, motored us over to East Holme to watch the regimental sports of the 78th Brigade who are out there in camp. It seemed so funny to see that crowd of Tommies doing exactly the same things as one has seen at dozens of other regimental sports, one could not realize that a few months ago all these men were clerks, labourers etc and their officers whatever may be their abilities or lack of them. They look as if they had been soldiers all their lives - even the Sports clown was there!

May 9th
First of all the Early Service, and then at 9.45 Church Parade Service. Oh! what crowds and crowds of men and what a short and cheery service, they sang as if they really enjoyed it and we had a good and simple sermon. At about 12 H's kind Staff Captain took us off in this motor and where we didn't go I cant tell! for we only got back at 6.0 having lunched at Ringwood and tea'd of all places at the Kings Head, Wimborne in which I've never been since our wedding just on 14 years ago! It did seem funny being there. The country is looking its very best, wreathed in green tracery, bluebells and primroses, and I am now longing to settle in these parts for good and all! The hills are large and bare, being down land, but the valleys are full of woods and lanes and its all so friendly and homey.

May 10th, Monday
This day 20 years ago I was confirmed, Oh! what a century ago it seems since I drove with Father in the brougham, Mother and Eve following in the dog cart to Spettisbury Church!
This is Monday and I'm forgetting to mention that on Sat. all were horrified to hear that the Lusitania coming from New York was torpedoed off Kinsale Head with a loss of 1500 lives. What will America do now? Many eminent people were on board including Mr Vanderbilt, Charles Frohman, Elbert Hubbard the great American philanthropist preacher and Sir Hugh Lane etc...no warning and in 10 minutes she sank. Its too awful to think about even. We went to pick flowers this morning and retuned with armfuls of bluebells, cowslips and campion which I sent to the Mission in Town, but previous to this H came with us and we looked over such a charming old house called Newton Manor, once the home of a certain Sir J.C. Robinson, a great art critic and collector. He died about 2 years ago and his son too and so it is on the market but alas soldiers have been billeted there all the winter and the place smells of Tommies and is filthy inside but could be made so lovely and has been, and the garden is quite sweet. They want 6000 for it, absurd, they'll never get it.
In the afternoon I had to have a tea party, so many of our people have called that I felt I ought to get to know them. It seemed so strange being at that old game again! There are some interesting people staying here, a Mr and Mrs Penrose, he was a great medical man and is now a scientist in general. Joy upon joys they've lent us their car for the next two days!

May 11th, Tuesday
I got my mail this morning. Ell sailed on the 25th and expects to arrive at Marseilles on the 15th. God protect him - this is an awful time. I don't write very much of the War, it is all too frightful. The Germans are making desperate efforts on every side and using the most foul and abominable methods of attaining their end. They are not to be enjoyed, these people, with their high Kultur of gas poisoning, well poisoning, and torpedoing. It is all sickening. Zeps came over Southend yesterday and dropped 100 bombs killing only one person but destroying a good many houses. They are getting nearer and nearer London, these raids. Well this morning a most perfect car came round for us costing at least £100,000,000! and we went to a lovely place called Worbarrow Bay. Never shall I forget this most lovely drive. The country lying warm and still in its fresh Spring green and we passed through many little old world villages, the old grey stone slated cottages and their gardens aglow with brilliant May tulips making pictures of themselves. The very names: Grange Creech Knowle, having an old world sound. After an hours run we came to Worbarrow, a most beautiful secluded Bay, in which we found 2 bungalows and a few fisher cottages. We clambered about and paddled and fell in! and made an impromptu acquaintance of some children and a lady called Draper. Pinkie played with the former whilst the latter took me up to the little house they have built there and kindly gave me tea! Near by was a wood literally a carpet of bluebells and Star of Bethlehem, where nightingales sang loudly and I felt, Oh!, why Oh! why cant I live here instead of our most pogbaggish neighbourhood of which I am utterly sick.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 12th - 18th

Leaves Swanage..."a most fearful battle has been going on round Ypres. A Zep over Ramsgate last night!"
viewer_6.description:
May 12th
Once again having the loan of the Penrose's car we hied us to a wood which I saw on the road yesterday, and there in that academy picture of a place we picked flowers for an hour: primroses such as I've never seen, bluebells, campion, stellaria (chickweed family), orchids etc...a perfect carpet, even Ashley couldn't beat this wood and we returned home ladened. After lunch my dear man was actually free till tea so we went off to Swanage, no, I mean Studland, where the tide being very low we gathered shells and walked a long way in the Poole direction. This place reminds me so of the old old days when we stayed, Mother, Eve, B and I at the Bank's Arms and bathed from a tent and were almost the only people there. Alas our last day has come and I am so loathe to go, it has been a great joy and the like will never come again.

May 13th
After 10 days glorious weather and tropical heat the rain is descending in buckets. We left by the 2.56 and arrived in Town about 7.0, drove to the flat where I found Rita and Brenda and we spent an amusing evening telling bad stories.

May 14th, Friday
A regular clearance today. Mother to Worthing, Brenda to Chislehurst, Rita to 12 Onslow, Pink to school and I home! I found all well and its quite lovely to see my dear small daughters again. I should like to say confidentially how pretty I think they both are with their very pink cheeks and chestnut hair, and both so sweet and loving.

May 15th
Just a day of home jobs and many chores to try and keep my thoughts off Ell who is supposed to land at Marseilles today. Dined over the way and met there Captain Campbell, wounded in the hand.

May 16th, Sunday
Church and photography, that is how this day was spent. I am still developing my Austrian films and they are a delightful success. (You can see some of these in the 1914 June pages, where they illustrate Wynne and Herbert's last European holiday).

May 17th
My dear Ell writes this morning that Pinkeye has broken out among the horses so that for the time he was detained at Bombay for how long its hard to say, I fancy by now he is on his way and I'm longing for the next mail. The rain is coming down in torrents and having to go to lunch with Mrs Birch, Stella gave me a lift and I came out by bus but got so wet and draggled - horrid. Capt. Campbell and they dined with me tonight and we eat strawberries!! A most fearful battle has just been going on round Ypres again this last week and the Lists are frightful, our poor men, how awful it is, they've never been so large before and its like a nightmare. A Zep over Ramsgate last night! poor Mary!

May 18th, Tuesday
These torrents of rain are not conducive to cheer and this morning I was horribly distressed to see poor Gordon Merriman has gone. He was killed on the 12th. Alas how sad it is , such a dear and how well we knew him, so many of the old 33rd have been wounded too: Cols. Oldfield, Kelly and Hinton, Capt. Lee-Warmer etc...one is thankful to read however that we have successfully checked their advance, the devils - talk of hatred for the English, two can play at that game, and their general tactics arouse our worst passions. The Zep that came to Ramsgate is believed to have been hit, but it rose to a height of 1100 feet and disappeared tail down. I have been gardening this evening trying to lose myself a little. Thank god I have the children but its all an awful strain on ones otherwise tranquil nerves.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The obituary for her friend, Gordon Merriman...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 19th - 25th

Herbert home on leave, and news of her brother, Ell, who has finally sailed from India with his regiment.
viewer_8.description:
May 19th
I went to tea with the de Mornays today. They have been badly hit in the financial way by the War and I wonder how they can keep going. All her money was invested in Germany and his in stocks and shares that don't pay. Luckily they have only one boy but he must be educated.

May 20th
We are enduring a vile East Wind and its quite cold today. It blows the flowers about and dries up every thing as if it were mid summer. It has been a horribly gloomy day but I've gardened hard to keep myself away from thinking too much.

May 21st
Stella and I have been shopping in Town today for our stall at this wretched Bazaar which comes off in June. Oh! how I hate it. My dear man arrived tonight for 2 days leave.

May 22nd
I have been busy showing the man the new papers in the house and garden, it is just a snatch at happiness having him home, it is nearly a year since he first left now and it will be long unless something unforeseen occurs till he comes to live at home again, not that I would have him live at home now when the world is at work. He too would hate it.

May 23rd, Sunday
Tis Whitsundtide and never I suppose did one need God's Spirit more than at the present time, more and more get drawn into this fierce conflict and Italy is in the balance. One only trusts it may come to pass for surely it must make a difference. We sat and lazed in the garden this afternoon, it was warm in the shelter but such a wind blowing still.

May 24th
Very few people are making holiday today I fancy, it would be an insult to play cricket, football, tennis or go racing and thank goodness all these things are stopped. My dear left today catching the 2.0 and reaching Swanage after 9.0. We all went down to see him off, the kind Bacon's lending us their car. Oh! I do miss him so awfully I almost wonder if i like these snatches, the aftermath is so horrible. I garden in desperation and try to forget but the whole place seems just empty. What would one do without our babies.

May 25th
News from Ell that he has had definite orders to sail on the 15th of May so if he did he should soon reach Marseilles and then where? His destination and regiment are alike unknown to us.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: German prisoners...and a poem.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
May 26th - 31st

Italy declares War, and joins the Allies. A royal visit to the refreshment centre...and letters from the Front.
viewer_10.description:
May 26th
I have got a fearsome cold, a real bad summer one. The heat has suddenly become intense and today and tomorrow all the bedding out has to be done. I'm not enthusiastic and would just as soon bury old boots.

May 27th
All is finished, tidy and neat once more, the glorious Spring colour has gone and in their place sticky geraniums and leggy daisies poke out their straggly ends, all will look right in time doubtless, but at present they all look positively affronted. I went to Shirts today for Mrs P seems - seems quite odd being at the old game again and then I gardened till past 8.0! being alone it doesn't matter when one comes in to dinner which is rather nice.

May 28th
Where has this month gone, it's nearly over and I've hardly realized its come, and this week Italy declared war against Austria so now we're all complete and a Coalition Government has been formed and conscription is in view. I had 3 letters from the Front yesterday, one from Bill, Sinnott and William Gilham. The first sent me these great treasures, 2 pansies from his trench garden! Can one conceive anything more incongruous, thank goodness they still can make gardens and monkey tricks. The 3rd must be either in Egypt or Dardanelles I think, and writes the quaintest letter. I was so glad to hear all are well. (Sinnott had been the groom at Hale, and Gilham the stable lad).
I have been gardening the whole day. All the time I have I put into my garden, there at any rate things are living, not dying, and one can forget for a space all the horror of the world.

May 29th
Oak Apple Day. I got a call from Mrs Stanley Clarke this morning asking me to go and help serve at the GMCA hut this afternoon at 2.0 to replace Mrs Harrington who has developed measles. Accordingly I went and till 5.30 we served refreshments and smokes as hard as we could go. Tea, coffee, buns, cake, chocolate etc all to be had for 1d a piece. Books, papers, writing materials and so on all provided free. Whilst we were there who should come in to pay a surprise visit but the King and Queen with Princess Mary, Princess Victoria, Queen Alexandra and the Empress Eugenie - the men were amazed! They went all round and after they had left the Queen sent back Lady Haig to say she had not realized that we ladies were serving or she would have spoken to us. I wish she had, it would have been so interesting. Rather an amusing thing happened, one fellow was asleep to whom as they passed the two Queens made bows and as he slowly roused himself Princess Mary laughingly said: "Get up, the King is passing" and he being half asleep replied: "The King. Oh! I've often seen him before"!

May 30th
Today being Trinity Sunday we are again treated to the Athanasian Creed and as I cannot hear these intolerant sentences thus thoughtlessly spoken I do not go today. How can the Church sanction it, but there - chacqun son goût, only it is not my goût! A cold and vile day, so cold I should like a fire.

May 31st
After a horribly cold day, we were treated to most beautiful weather today and alas most of it had to be spent at the Jumble Sale! which was held at the church room. We made exactly 5 pounds which was jolly good I thought as it was all rubbish. After this frivolity I, having met and been introduced to her in the morning, went to tea with Mrs Ferguson, a nice lady who lives at Lawday House. There I also met the Drakes who had come over from Farnborough, both he and she are so nice and I quite enjoyed my outing for one goes so seldom now-a-days, seeing so few people that its rather nice when one has made the effort.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: During the war Herbert's old home was requisitioned for troops - as you can see in the second picture. Wynne wonders what the old matriach would have thought of all that!

may.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Poison gas and the Lusitania...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: A post card Wynne stuck into her diary of the aftermath of the bombardment at Neuve-Chapelle. It was sent to her by her brother, who notes simply "Came across this yesterday in a shop". It has a red "Passed by Censor" triangle stamped across it, and a date November 2nd.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 1st - 5th

On the Home Front: voluntary work making hospital necessities and selling cakes to soldiers does not stifle the anxiety...and Wynne's cousin flies in from Bristol! Fireworks are banned!
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Monday
Well, this month has begun vilely, a howling hurricane, torrents of rain and feet of mud. Natheless (sic) I sped forth on my iron steed at 2.0 to take up a new job I have. I am working on Monday and Wednesday afternoons at the Parish Room in Aldershot where a War Supply Depot has been formed for hospital necessaries. Attired in large white aprons, head squares and sleevlets we all sit round making swobs, bandages, pneumonia jackets etc which eventually go up to Cavendish House. It is very interesting and as one sits there working one thinks of the hundreds of other women so employed all the world over. I have often heard Mother speak of how they used to work in like manner during the Franco-Prussian war. History repeats itself. I went on to the Hut at 5.0 and had there the usual busy evening.

November 2nd.
A day at home. I only have Tues. and Thurs. at home these days. I went and attended a vile committee meeting re Yolland House at the Vicarage at 12 and also with the aid of the children spent a long time gathering the Skippy's medlar crop which once again they have given me. H writes that they are having much rain and their part of the country is fearful already. There are so few houses standing that the men are all in dug-outs and one sub had his fall in on him one night.

November 3rd
Thank goodness the weather has cheered up, a lovely day and the wind has dried the roads. In to my Hospital work and whilst there who should arrive to my great surprise but Herman having flown over from Bristol to Farnborough. He is now training at the Filton School and expects to get his wings in about a month's time. Being my hut night I could not unfortunately return with him and the kind Skippys gave him dinner for me and I got back about 9.45 and had my supper and then we talked till 11.0. He can only stay the night and goes off early tomorrow. He is looking awfully well. I heard at the hut tonight that our Highlanders are to leave again - we shall miss them very much, such a gentlemanly crowd.

November 4th
Herman left this morning early taking Walker to the station as he returns to Bristol by train. I spent my day writing letters. I have not heard from my man today, I do feel so starved, doubtless I shall get 2 tomorrow.

November 5th
I have got 2! so I feel better. It is absurd how in these days the least thing, and it is not "the least thing", puts one off ones humour. This is Guy Fawkes Day but all fireworks are forbidden by the Police so I could not even get 2/- worth of rubbish for our usual display! but got a box of drawing room ones instead and they are just as pleased.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is a cutting Wynne put into November 9th - it comes from her paper, but it records the sort of letter that millions of officers must have been writing - the sort of detail that gets lost in the historical storm. I have not come across a better description of the mud that the poor soldiers faced this winter.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 6th - 10th

Anxiety about her brother, and news from her husband of the terrible waterlogged conditions at the Front. A description of London during the blackout.
viewer_4.description:
November 6th, Saturday
This morning in the middle of breakfast I was summoned to the phone. Mother rang me up to say Ell is "ordered abroad". This means I fear Serbia or Egypt or some such place. H in his letter today has also heard it, alas how much it adds to our anxiety because of the uncertainty of it. Well she wanted me to go up so after my Hut duty I went by the 6.30, arrived three quarters of an hour late and didn't get to the flat until 8.30. How can I describe the look of London as I stepped out of the High St Underground. Almost complete darkness met me, hardly a light from any window, only every other street lamp lit and that at half cock and painted black leaving a small square through which the apology for light spread itself in a small pool on the pavement immediately below. If I had not known the way by instinct I should never have found it.

November 7th
The main reason I came up was to hunt out Ells kit for Mother which he wants sent. I found what he needs and made it up into a bundle to take to Kings on the morrow. Various people called - Capt. Niwlay tells us he is to be transferred to the Lahore Division and is to go to Mesopotamia so that decides Ell's destination. How vile is the thought.

November 8th
I came down by the 3.5, went and did duty at the Hut and got home at 10.0 really rather tired. I don't often feel like that but it has been a long and very busy day and the hills seemed steep coming home.

November 9th, Tuesday
Already 9 days gone this month and today has been a real specimen, pouring torrents all day long and the greyness of November settled down on tree, field, garden and personality alike. My man writes today: "the country is in a terrible state, sheets of water everywhere and all the Battery positions and trenches are falling to pieces. Several of the gun emplacements were under water when I went round this morning, dugouts fallen in and everyone in a somewhat disconsolate state. It is so difficult to know what to do, the country seems impossible to drain properly, the ditches which ought to carry off the water are generally stopped up somewhere though there are rises in the ground there doesn't seem to be any flow. I found both the Infantry Brigades in distress, one's office was tumbling down. the other's had streams of water flowing through it."
Poor things, what discomfort and why don't they all die of rheumatism. He also writes me something of the Native troops which disgusts one and which makes one realize that its quite time they were removed. One of their comp. told one of his officers that 40 of his men had deserted to the enemy. The Germans throw grenades into their trenches with letters inside saying any native that goes over will be treated with great kindness and so some deluded wretches have taken them at their word and will in all probability be fighting in the Turkish army before very long.
(Wynne does not say who these troops are, or indeed quite how this was achieved - presumably the pin was not pulled from the grenades! In fact the "native" troops suffered terrible hardships, were often inadequately clad and were not prepared for this sort of warfare. Many of them fought with extraordinary courage, in a war that had nothing to do with them at all.)

November 10th
A fine day, Hurrah! and off to the Hospital Depot and Hut, such a busy night I simply couldn't cope with it and had to get Mrs Hill to help me at my cakes.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Stuck into November 19th, I have not come across this poem in other anthologies - Wynne clearly valued it. Around this time, she encouraged her daughter to start a separate book into which she pasted or wrote other poems - poetry was everywhere.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 11th - 16th

Censorship matters - and then a reunion with her brother, Elliot.
viewer_6.description:
November 11th, Thursday
This being mail day I spent the whole of it in writing and as I had sent both Mabel's and Ell's off I got theirs by the afternoon post. I was amused to hear the other day that one of Mary's to Mabel was censored and returned to her the other day, it is a strange affair and one feels so at sea as to what one is and is not allowed to say. I got a letter from H today which had been opened by the Base Censor. That hasn't happened for many a month and there was of course nothing in it. (Mail day refers to mail destined for abroad - Mabel was in Africa).

November 12th
Just a week ago today we had the scare that Kitchener had resigned and it did make one feel sick, but he has gone off on a tour to the Balkan theatre of war and one is awfully curious as to the result.

November 13th
In the middle of breakfast I was called up to Swansborough as Mother wanted me on the phone. She said she had had a wire from Ell saying he would be home today! It was a surprize, and how thankful one is to feel one will see him before he goes East. I fancy I shall go up but am awaiting news of his arrival and plans first.
(The telephone was a new thing in Wynne's life - she clearly had to go somewhere to call as she did not have one in her house).

November 14th
I actually had a talk with Ell himself this morning. He came over in a destroyer!! all Channel service being suspended as submarines are supposed to be in the Channel and he didn't arrive till 12.0. Well I've decided to go up tomorrow and have got someone to do my hut for me. Maby is better but has been so bad and I've had Baby in bed with a cold all day too. I'm for bed, so tired!

November 15th
A lovely day and I set forth for Town going in by bus, I intended going by the 12.8 but on arriving at the station I found that the 11.1 had not started so went in that and didn't get to Town until 20 to 2. i think did some shopping on the way and landed at the flat about 3.30 there to find Ninian and Brenda so nice. Ell my dearest came in later and nothing I can say can ever express what I feel at being with him again. We just sat and talked this evening, I personally feeling vile with a throat and cold.

November 16th
Today we tooled round shopping, had lunch at Les Laurier there meeting the Ninians and all went on to the same theatre afterwards, "The Big Drum" - G. Alexander and Co - not too good. I felt perfectly dead by the evening, such ill luck when one specially wants to feel well.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is a very poor photo from Wynne's paper, but I put it in because it must have seemed extraordinary to her - one of her friends, Major Lyster (seated far left) is in it. He is mentioned in the diary earlier in the war, after he was captured, and also in 1918 when he was part of an extraordinary negotiated release to a neutral country.

The people mentioned, from left to right, are:

Major Lyster, Royal Field Artillery; Major Cuaig, Canada; Captain Campbell, East Surrey Regiment; Captain Rawdon, King's Own Yorkshire L.I.; Captain Tweedie, Royal Scots; Captain Sloane Stanley, Middlesex Regiment; Lieutenant Nicholls, Suffolks; Lt Carthew, Suffolks; Lt Paget, Norfolks.

Note: Major Cuaig is spelt like that on the page, not Craig. It is quite possibly a misprint.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 17th - 28th

Painful farewells - delayed mails - anxiety and illness at home - and an incomplete diary.
viewer_8.description:
November 17th, Wednesday
There has been still no cross Channel service for 3 days and its so vile being without letters, one does miss them so abominably. We all went off to the Stores shopping in the morning and after lunch Ell having business Mother and I went to the Marble Arch Pavillion where we met Mrs Boucher and saw a very good cinema show. After dinner came Lady Fulton and we played Bridge, but oh! how ill and coldy I felt, it was no enjoyment and I longed for my bed.

November 18th, Thursday
I cant write tonight. I have said goodbye to my dear thing. He came to Waterloo to see me off and really these things dont bear thinking about. I come home hoping to find Maby about again instead of which she is back in bed with flu - I do trust it doesn't spread.

November 19th - 28th
Ten days have elapsed since writing this and a rotten 10 days they have been. On Thurs. 18th expecting to find Maby about again she was au contraire back in bed with flu and since then she has been really very ill. She is better now but naturally after over a fortnight in bed very weak. On Sunday last she was unconscious all day and I had to get a nurse up for the night. She got up today for an hour or so and I trust is making a start and as soon as ever she is well enough I shall send her home to recoup. Added to this we have Win home, pending an operation for appendicitis poor old girl and are making arrangements to try and get her into the Florence Nightingale Home in Town. She is perfectly splendid how she is taking it all and I do feel so awfully sorry for her.

november.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Home Front anxieties and work during a dreary month... fireworks are banned.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is the page of Artillery instructions that Wynne received. They had been used to wrap up some glass window fragments her husband rescued from a ruined church. They refer to 17th Division emplacements. Notice the references to aeroplanes and masts - methods of targetting. These orders are for the 5th August, . (see Oct 1st).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 5th

Death, and the errands associated with it.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Friday
On the day that H sent me home the Church glass it was wrapped in these orders, I carefully preserved them and though I do not understand a word I keep them as curiosities which to me they are. (See last panel in Sept and the panel preceding this one in October for the signal forms and Artillery notes Wynne refers to).
It has been a lovely beginning to the month, clear and fine and still but so cold. Autumn has really come with a nip in the air and I'm sure we've had frost. I've spent my day writing letters, doing flowers and chickens. The papers report still further progress and Oh! pray God it may continue. H writes but little news today, his lot are still sitting. The casualty lists are horrible and the first name I see is General Capper. I go tomorrow to see poor Aim, at Blackwater, a sad errand.

October 2nd
To my disgust it rained too hard to allow of my going over to Blackwater this morning so I am going to try tomorrow. I was able however to go to the Hut, but I did miss the 25th Div. and all the familiar faces. We have in their place the 40th Division, men of the 20th Middlesex, The Glosters, KRR and so forth. At present they do not appear to be a very prepossessing lot, rough manners and too fond of the bottle but I daresay they'll settle down in time. Meanwhile many R.A.M.C. come as usual.

October 3rd, Sunday
Actually a lovely day and I went over to B. There I found Nora too and heard all there was to hear about dear old Bill. Aim had had a wire from the King and Queen of condolence - I wonder if everyone has, it was most awfully nicely worded and also a letter from a brother officer who said he was killed whilst carrying out a wounded man and bandaging him. Dear heroic old man, its just what he would have done. It was such a nice letter and he said the men were devoted to him, and would have followed him anywhere, but the actual date was not given nor any other details and one does long to know he did not suffer.

October 4th
I spent a busy morning cleaning all sorts of things in my little room, the brasses in particular. This room which was once Gran's is my joy and delight and I live in it even to having my dinner here! It is so warm and cosy and pretty. I fill it full of flowers and feel as though it were really my own. Tonight at the Hut we were very busy as usual, an excellent concert party from London entertained us with much music and the men poured in.

October 5th
A day filled with chores, how fast the time flies and how little time there seems on our hands. I learnt from the Express that poor General Wing has been killed, he only left about a month ago.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne stuck this cutting into her diary on October 1st - very much with thoughts of Bill in her mind. Michael William Maxwell Windle was killed on the same day as Bill, in the very same action, but unlike Bill he was one of 20,000 whose body was never found, and who has no known grave. Strangely, the War Graves commission notice records no family information, and no age, but judging by the poem found in his effects, he was just another public schoolboy caught up in the "great adventure" that turned into a massacre.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 6th - 10th

A birth and blackberry picking help to keep spirits up...but re-reading July 1914 sets Wynne to wondering at it all.
viewer_4.description:
October 6th, Wednesday
I have a mania for tidyng just now, I have rummaged out and tidied up my bedroom cupboards and drawer today. Alas all summer things have been put away and winter stodges brought out and to the Hut again tonight, the air was still and calm and it was lovely cycling home at night in bright starlight. I have received from H a most interesting relic, a beautiful wine glass from Ypres. It has a milk hair thread running down the stem. I am pleased and proud, also some sweet lace collars which I've given to the children. All these things are so awfully precious to me, they will increase in value and interest as the time goes on. H writes that at last his Div. is on the move and on Wednesday, today, it goes to a place a little further back after which down South.

October 7th
We went blackberrying today, there are still heaps to be found. We went through Pine Needle Wood and it has been one of those perfect autumn days, not quite perfect as there was no sun, but standing there alone in the wood it was as if Nature held her breath. All was so absolutely still, only a wood wren shrilled at intervals and a far distant jay gave an alarm. A pungent damp smell filled the air, mingled with that smell characteristic of autumn, a burning rubbish heap. I love such days.

October 8th
At 9.30 this morning Stella's nurse came over with the joyful news that at 5 to 9 Master Skipwith arrived and all is very well. I am so glad it is a son, he will be so awfully pleased and I am glad all is safely over. I have been Church decorating all the morning for the Harvest Festival which is tonight, I'm sorry I cant go as its my Hut night. We had at the Hut the busiest night I've ever known, one could not keep pace with the hundreds of men who streamed in.

October 9th
I was summoned this morning to go and inspect the young Master. He is a darling, dark hair and eyes with finely marked eyebrows, narrow hands and long fingers and a very clear smooth skin. I nursed him for a long time and it was lovely to hear again the snuffling noises of a very young baby. I am horribly envious and wish to do it too! After lunch to my Hut, a steady stream of men all the afternoon and a letter from H to reward me on my return. His lot have moved now. Where they are going is a mystery, we know nothing of these things. The Balkans are in a ferment, Bulgaria is siding with the Central Powers, Greece, though neutral, is most unsettled and Allied forces have landed at Salonica.

October 10th, Sunday
A very peaceful day. I went to early service at St Marks and then to Matins at St Johns. All the afternoon I spent sticking in arrears of photos into my Diaries and after tea went over to sit with Stella for a while. On reading over pieces of our trip in Austria last year how strange it all seems, that was barely a month before War broke out and no one had an inkling of what was toward. What strange reading it all is, with talk of future plans etc., for a fortnight before we were quietly house hunting in Suffolk with a view of leaving this house last Sept. year! A lot of water has run under the bridge since then and what untold horrors and grief have occurred in one year's time. How many many friends we have lost and I just cant realize that my Bill is gone.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
These letters, which must be typical of millions written, have been lovingly copied by the family for circulation to everyone. They are from separate officers, one or both of whom were presumably Bill's superiors...the one dated October 7th from Harry Hyslop (which you can read below) and the second from Jack MacNab. Considering the numbers of these that officers had to write, and the fact that a major battle was raging, it is remarkable how detailed and careful they both are - both letters cover four pages. It must have been the most unbearable duty, taking up any free time out ot the trenches...

The top letter reads:

Dear Mrs Mackintosh, Your son was killed on the 25th of September when gallantly trying to bring in some wounded men. He had been back with his "Sapping" platoon, but came up to see if he could be of any help, and as all the officers of his company had been killed or wounded, we sent him to try to collect the remnants of the company and reorganise them. this he did, but seeing some wounded men still lying outside the trenches, he himself went out to try to bring them in. I understand he had brought one in and was assisting with another when he fell, killed instantaneously. We buried him alongside the other officers and near the men in the cemetery at Cambrin about 3 miles east of Bethune, and have put up a neat cross over his grave with the following inscription:
XC111
Lieut. W.G.Fallowfield
2nd Bri. Arg. and Suth. Highlanders.
Killed in action, 25.9.15.
Our Padre, the Rev Langlands, read the service. I and several of the men were present. His personal effects have been sent home to you and his valise with the remainder of his things has also been forwarded through Cose and Co. If I can do anything further to help you will you please let me know. Signed, Harry G. Hyslop.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 11th - 17th

Depressing news from the Front makes Wynne even more miserable, especially when her last letter to Bill is returned unopened. More Zepp scares.
viewer_6.description:
October 11th, Monday
I find the Times is most depressing these days, one must read ones paper, one couldn't live without doing so, but the general air of pessimism which prevails in the Times is horrid. Grave dissatisfaction over the Govts. policy in the Balkans, our failure (it has come to that) in the Dardanelles, Germany's triumph over Russia and her impenetrability in the West and her marvelous internal organization - all these do not tend to raise the spirits. I have moreover received news that the Stock Exchange has stopped payment this half year and so I am not cheerful tonight and shall indulge in the blues. Thank goodness I have my chores and my Hut and time passes somehow but one gets very weary.

October 12th
It has been one of those perfect Oct. days - quite warm and very sunny so we took our lunch out and picked blackberries, getting a great many and such beauties. This morning there arrived from Ell the two fuses that fell near him and the periscope taken off the rifle of one of the prisoners which passed through his hands - such very interesting mementoes.

October 13th
My Hut as usual tonight and on my return actually a Zep scare! I was having my supper when a loud explosion shook the house and windows followed by another so I went out to listen and there sure enough I heard several bombs drop and all the lights of Aldershot went out, most thrilling and we are wondering whether they have visited the Hangers at Farnborough at last!

October 14th
This morning's news is that a raid was made on the Eastern Counties, London and its environs and we now hear that the Zep intended to follow the last train to Fleet in order to guide it to Farnborough but took the wrong line at Woking and so fetched up at Guildford instead. They dropped bombs in the Strand, on the Law Courts, Lincoln Inns and in front of the Lyceum and killed alas a good many people. As usual they got away.

October 15th & 16th
Two very busy days. Hut on both and much work at home bedding out and clearing and cleaning many bogey holes. Oh! how thankful one is to have heaps to do these days - it is the saving of much nerve worry and the time slips by.

October 17th, Sunday
My little Noot showing signs of a cold has been in bed all the morning and after lunch I made up one for her in the schoolroom where she, Baby and I spent the afternoon and evening busy over various things, and she is much better. My dear Billy's death was crudely brought home to me yesterday by receiving my last letter to him back again and on the envelope was written "Deceased - Killed". Horrible, and I grieve to think he never got it.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: At last something to amuse Wynne - she cut this out and stuck it on her entry for October 24th. I wish I knew what the outcome was - unlikely to have been happy! However as you can see at the bottom, he had plenty of replies!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
October 18th - 25th

Wynne's husband moves to the Ypres Salient. Olive leaves and hay sent from Gallipoli. A lonely-hearts advert amuses...
viewer_8.description:
October 18th, Monday
Much planting of bulbs done today, cleaning of chicken houses, writing letters and other chores and to my Hut at night. I have just come back after a very heavy night for it was a Concert night and great crowds attended. Miss Winwood took and returned me in her cart, a great treat especially as there was a thick fog.

October 19th, Tuesday to October 23rd, Saturday.
Each individual day does not bring much that is fresh to write about. The wretched War goes on, becoming more and more complicated and far reaching but one is as tired of writing about it as thinking of it. The one piece of news I have which does not please me at all is that my man and his Div. are now moved up into the Ypres salient, a very "unhealthy" corner all of which is shelled every day and he takes over on Monday.
