They are to be in for 6 weeks and out a fortnight. I suppose I ought to write this news round the family but oh! the amount of writing I get through. I've used nearly 15/- worth of stamps since the Ist of October! and sometimes I get weary of my never ending correspondence. I had a long and interesting letter from Hilary Kenny today, he sent me Olive leaves from Gallipoli and some hay which the horses of L Battery eat!

October 24th, Sunday
The day is dreary in the extreme: torrents of rain fall and prevent us from going to Kirk, but in my little room with a fire I am very cosy and have employed my morning in getting off an arrears of letters. I got a long letter from Ell a day or two ago. His view of the general state of affairs is not exactly cheerful, but I am not sure that many people don't feel the same. The persistent refusal of the Govt. to give the country conscription, necessitating the unavailing efforts of the individual to replace it by other schemes, added to which we now have an " appeal by the King" to the manhood of the Nation, is little short of humiliating and one only has to read "Through German Eyes" in the Times to see what they think of us. Our laggard policy in the Balkans too seems amazing. One realizes in what a position we stand when Greece, though offered by us as a concession the island of Cyprus, can afford to ignore the offer and give us to understand that Germany has called at her door before us. Serbia, poor valiant little nation, is getting a hammering from Austria, Germany and Bulgaria and no news is heard of our Ex. Force which landed at Salonica and so the general outlook at present is not cheerful, and I can only afford to be pessimistic in my Diary, hence this dissertation of gloom! To turn to something more amusing, the enclosed cutting I really think beats all, the man must be mad, it would indeed need a "spirited girl" to tackle this sort of thing! (see in preceding window)

October 25th and 26th
I have not heard today from my man which is not surprising seeing I had no less than 3 letters yesterday, Sunday's having been delayed and the one I should have got today arriving a day too soon. He took over charge of his line yesterday. God grant success, it is a horrible place.
Today I have been to a big entertainment given by the YMCA in aid of funds for a Central Hall, and with some donations they raised in all over £1000. All the world and his wife were there and many celebrities took part aided by the R.A. Band.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: A cutting Wynne mentions on October 31st...this was a regular feature, papers in England often quoting from the foreign press, usually to laugh about the mistakes.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
October 27th - 31st

Wynne's husband in action again. She receives a hospital card from Lt. Whitehead, whom she had looked after in Aldershot.
viewer_10.description:
October 27th, Wednesday.
I made a blister on my hand tonight cutting at the Hut! We had such hundreds in. I simply love the men, just love them all, and it is a privilege to work amongst them. I look upon each one as a positive hero these days.

October 28th
Torrents have fallen all day, putting a stop for the time to gardening operations. I wrote letters hard all day, getting clear many debts. I received this lovely PC today from Lt. Whitehead -(see in the next window)- he has been sick in hospital for a fortnight but he didn't say what was wrong. They no longer belong to the 25th Div. but have been transferred to the 3rd for some reason. I had a long letter from Eve today, she was depressed owing to a leaden sky and the presence of Nora Hall! Ell seems fit and cheery, they are doing nothing at present, but H is in action in the Ypres Salient. His HQ Brigade house had 400 shells round it in 2 days, one shell blowing away the front of the house altogether and one fell into a pond in the garden and blew the fish out on to the lawn.

October 29th
After yesterdays torrents the sun rewarded us today by showing his face the whole day long so I said to myself away with letter writing and indoor chores and to the garden I will hie me! There I grubbed and planted and cleared up till lunch time and so hot it was that I had to divest myself of jacket and work in my shirt.

October 30th
Once again such a lovely day, it began by being awfully foggy and as I rode down the hill to do dear Gran's grave I ran into a cold wet valley fog which chilled me to the bone. When I got back again I learnt with surprise that Skippy is actually home, he got his leave suddenly and arrived last night at 12.0. I saw him at about midday today looking so well, it is lovely for her having him back again. After lunch I betook me to the Hut as usual, there the men swarmed and by tea time I had sold 20 dozen odd cakes! I expect they are having a heavy night tonight. We get such heaps of the new regiment, 14th A & S Highlanders, such a fine crowd and many gentlemen among them, so different from the low class Welsh miners and the cockney 20th Middlesex, who did not take my fancy in the least.

October 31st, Sunday
My diary is becoming very uncomfortable to write in, it is horribly fat and unsteady and I shall be glad when I get a new one at the beginning of next year. This paper I have put opposite is very interesting, it purports to be genuine, but whether this is so or not it still remains awfully interesting. I have lent it to so many that its condition is somewhat ragged! (see Through German Eyes in the previous panel). Its been such a dreadful day I do hope it will clear tomorrow as I have a long days work before me. I am going first at 2.30 to work at Hospital things in Aldershot, and then on to the Hut and if its like today I shall get drowned on the way. Last Sunday was the same and the roads are getting simply impassable.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: This is a hospital card. It is very similar to the Field Post Cards (you can see an example in July , third window). You were not allowed to write anything on them apart from essentials - dates, addresses and your name. This one is from Lt. Whitehead, whom Wynne had befriended at Aldershot.

october.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Birth, blackberrying and fear...Herbert moves to the Ypres Salient.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
While the family were in Aldershot Wynne did a lot of unpaid work at the YMCA Hut. Troops stationed in the town and awaiting their movement orders were entertained here with tea, cakes and musical offerings. You can see from the pictures how the place was laid out - Wynne would have stood at the back of the bottom picture, behind the counter. The opposite end held the stage.

Perhaps its appropriate that it's empty - so many of the men who sat here must never have come back.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 5th

Bill Fallowfield visits unexpectedly. Chores and the "Hut" take over. The 21st and 22nd Divisions leave for the Front
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Wednesday
This morning I had a wire from Bill proposing himself and Aim for the day. I was surprised and most delighted, accordingly they arrived at 11.30 and stayed to 6.30. Alas we had arranged a blackberry picnic but it poured with rain and so we had to stay indoors. Bill has 7 days leave, he too as Gran used to say has "much improved" and it was very interesting hearing his experiences. He gave me this sketch of one of his trenches, another curiousity. His regiment, 2nd Argyle and Sutherland Highlanders, are quite near Ell's lot and so I hope they may meet. His kilt greatly becomes him and he is looking so awfully well. I hear today that Herman is about to join the Flying Corps and Thurie (his father) is going off to Venezuela next month! (This was the last time Wynne saw Bill - he was one of her favourite cousins, and was killed on 25th September. He was 29).

September 2nd
My dear man sent me this today, a piece of heather picked whilst out for a walk. Its not quite like English heather I don't think - it seems strange to think of it growing in that shell ridden spot "just as if nothing were happening". I had a long and nice letter from my Canadian friend, F.W. Diggon, today. He writes so well. They have hard times over there and it must be awful to be so far away during this time of stress and storm. (Diggon survived the war, and continued to correspond with Wynne long after it ended. He was another Canadian who was befriended via the Victoria League).

September 3rd
There is much stir in Camp these days. The 21st and 22nd Divisions are on the move, presumably to France but no one knows anything. We had a very heavy evening at the Y.M.C.A. - men came pouring in by hundreds for provisions to take on the journey, and it was all we could do to keep pace with them. It is all rather tragic but they are splendid.

September 4th
A busy morning of paying wages, bills and books and then to the Hut from 2.30 to 5.30 - again much stir and bustle and as I rode through the lines on my way home the barrack squares were seething with men ready to go, their kit all lying in neat rows along the ground and crowds to see them off. Our ladies are seeing to their food at the Govt. siding every night. I have not been yet but hope to go one night.

September 5th
I went to early Service today up at St Mark's. I did not go to Matins but sent the children with Maggie and after lunch I was on duty at the Hut, at 4.30 I walked back with Mr Whitehead who came to tea, a really nice boy this and one feels that perhaps one is able to make life a little easier for him by asking him out occasionally for it must be a rough existence for those of the better class.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is the trench map Bill gave to Wynne. It's done in ink on very tough, textiled paper, and would appear to be a template. You will notice that on the left, the measurements have been altered in pencil. Bill was in the 2nd Argyle and Sutherland Highlanders.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 6th - 15th

Zeppelin raids over London, and other stories of narrow escapes. Wynne's Mother offers a graphic account.
viewer_4.description:
September 6th, Monday
A glorious Sept morning, still and calm and warm, but alas this morning early I saw the swallows and I fear they'll be off soon.

September 13th, Monday
A week's interval
I have again allowed a week to lapse, sometimes it seems a pity to do this just now when one ought to have so much to write about, but though the days are very full its much the same, one after another, and the War drags on, no great changes have taken place on the Western Front , for many weeks the Russians continue their sad retreat, the Germans penetrating further and further, but it is in no sense a disorderly retreat, only one wonders how much longer it can continue without becoming so.
During this last week there have been great Zep raids over London and Mother actually witnessed one. She actually saw it about 2 streets off and watched its bomb throwing progress surrounded by aircraft all firing at it and said the noise was terrific. (For her Mother's letter about this Zeppelin raid, see the adjacent window with picture and transcript). Sinnott (Wynne's groom of pre-War days) who is home on leave left Waterloo by the last train on the 9th and as the train left the station a Zep passed over and dropped 4 bombs but luckily missed the train. He is looking very well and it is so delightful seeing him again. He has 7 days leave after 13 months absence. My days are spent between letters, chickens, house and the Hut, to which I go 3 nights and one afternoon a week. On Saturday Win came too and we were there from 11 until 5.30 the morning being spent in cleaning, dusting and tidying. The Tommy who plays so beautifully, Mr Burgess, a former professor of music at Oxford, was there practicing and it seemed strange to be scrubbing tables to the accompaniment of the classics! We lunched at the Hut in the storeroom off ham sandwiches and lemonade and thoroughly enjoyed it. Herbert writes that one of his guns has been fitted up as an aircraft gun and the other day they brought down an aeroplane, splendid luck for the gunner. Ell wrote me yesterday, he is out of trenches again and playing polo and football once more.

September 14th
Last night Win and I went up to the Hut. She comes often with me now and is very useful. I go again tomorrow but the weather has broken and I do hope its not going to last as bicycling at night in the wet is so horrible. It has been a miserable day and so cheerless and cold. I bicycled into Farnham this morning to get a new blue apron having lost mine out of the basket coming home last night. In the Hut I noticed a lot of tiny soldiers, none of them over 5 foot I should think, and on enquiring who these strange dwarfs might be I was informed that they belonged to the Bantam Battalion of the Welsh Fusiliers and South Wales Borderers who came in a few days ago.

September 15th
Another cold wet day and tonight coming from the YMCA it rained quite heavily and blew in my face, most horrible and I am rather wondering how I am going to face the winter night rides, it'll be rather a problem but I do so hope I'll be able to carry it on.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
This is the letter from Wynne's mother about the bombing raid - in retrospect it all seems so innocent and extraordinary, given what we came to expect later.
Notice the black-bordered funereal writing paper - a pretty general requirement for people at that time.

Dearest Darling
Today I have something to relate - last night at 10.30 Bessie was just brushing my hair when BoomBoomBoom in quick succession a terrific noise suddenly came, then a lot of firing, 2 machine guns going - I looked out and there slowly and quietly coming along quite low and it looked just 2 streets off was a huge Zeppeline (sic) our aircraft like wasps all round - She dropping bombs and firing from a small cloud of smoke. The noise was terrific. The maids rushed in in a panic and I told them to dress - Cyril and I watched it all from the window, it was so exciting one forgot the danger but after a while when she came too near and one felt afraid some of our own shells might hit the roof, I scooted downstairs with wonderful agility! We all did and found everyone there in dressing gowns, night gowns, pyjamas! It really was rather amusing. The porter opened the ground floor flat for us, the people being away, and we sat in the hall smoking cigarettes till about 12.30 - then nothing further happening we went up stairs. The maids would not come at first but I made them. The Zep sailed away calmly pursued by the aircraft like so many wasps - All the fire engines were out and the special Constables - but the trains were running as usual and a good many motors about - It isn't a pleasant experience - I am afraid they will go on annoying one like this - She went towards the South. I am longing to hear what the damage is - but fancy she came right across London and you should have heard the noise - it was like a battle! and wildly exciting.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 16th - 20th

Wynne's son goes back to school and she hears news from the Front. Hot weather makes for hard work at the Hut.
viewer_6.description:
September 16th, Thursday
This being the last day of Pink's holiday we had arranged as a treat that if fine we should go to Hindhead by bus but alas dark lowering clouds hung over us and a thunderstorm seemed imminent as it has suddenly grown fearfully hot and so we gave it up much to our sorrow. We had our tea out and I endeavoured to write to Mabel afterwards but was too often interrupted. Life these days is one long interruption!

September 17th
I have had a day today. Pink and I started off to Town by the 11. It did not reach Town until 1.0 and so we only just caught his train at Paddington. Dear son, I miss him so, but am very proud that he's been made a Capt. and he is much honoured by the new dignity. I went and saw Mother after leaving him and she drove with me to the station, the heat was tremendous and I arrived half an hour late at Aldershot and walked up to the Hut where Win met me, and I think we had the heaviest evening I've ever known, we simply could hardly cope with the streams of men and all the time the air was like a furnace.

September 18th, Saturday
Another grilling day, its rather lovely this second summer but Hut work is strenuous when its so very hot. I was there from 2.15 to 6.0 and had a very full afternoon again. I don't know why the place is always so full these days but it is splendid, they pour in and it should do well at this rate. My dear thing writes that they too are boiling, it will help to shorten the winter months. He sent me some interesting relics of broken Church glass out of a church near him called Deckebusch and two pieces of 8 inch armour-piercing Naval shell which was fired at one of his guns but did no damage. Ell seems well and writes often dear boy. The 25th Division leaves this on Thursday, we shall miss them and wonder who we shall get in their place.

September 19th
I have been developing films today and tomorrow intend to do a lot of printing. I've been so lazy over photographs lately but somehow there is always such a lot to do and it takes a long time. Young Mr Whitehead came out to tea and supper today, he now looks thoroughly equipped for War having had his head shaved - it looks awful and makes them appear like convicts.

September 20th
Monday mornings are always busy. Mrs Bailey and Monica Bacon came in, the former to see me about the Mothers Meeting which on account of the YMCA I had to give up. I felt that with 4 times a week at the YMCA I couldn't keep it on. We had a very heavy night there tonight, a concert was given. It breaks my heart to think that so many of our nightly visitors are off on Thursday with the 25th Division, so many will not come back again but all seem glad to go and really after a year's training these sort of soldiers get sick of waiting.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: An example of the Home Front trying to keep things going!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 21st - 25th

A letter from Germany, and more departures.
viewer_8.description:
September 21st, Tuesday
It has been such a very lovely day, a day that only Sept can produce, very warm , quite still, and that faint smell of burning rubbish in the air. Last night when I was bicycling home the moon which is nearly full had a huge solar ring round it which means rain but nothing could have been more lovely than today and we all went blackberrying taking the maids with us and got a lot for bottling.

September 22nd
This morning Win and I went down in the Skippy's little cart to do some last shopping for her, for she leaves tomorrow.

September 23rd
Win and I went down in Walker's apology for a car and I saw her off to Waterloo. On my return I had a furious altercation with Walker over my bill which he has not given me since Jan. I had a letter from the Hamster (Wynne's Uncle in Germany) today, much to my surprise, it came through Leila who is back at Ouchy once more and it had been opened by the Censor. He is well and gets about more than usual, it gave no news of course but he did mention Theodore who he said was at the Front so he is evidently still alive. (Ouchy is in Switzerland, near Lausanne, and letters were able to be routed through this neutral territory, so that families could keep in touch).

September 24th
I had to bicycle to the Hut today in the heaviest torrents of rain I've ever seen. I nearly got drowned and arrived simply drenched, but I had promised to take a man his watch sent to me by his wife so I had to go. It was lovely bicycling back however, quite still and a beautiful moon.

September 25th
My morning was spent in many chores: my house, Gran's grave, visiting a sick old man, feeding Pink's caterpillars and making rissoles for lunch. At 2.15 I hied me to the Hut where I was till 6.0 when at last I got away and young Mr Whitehead walked back with me to supper. They have at last their definite orders and his lot move off on Monday sometime, their destination unknown and their letters are to be addressed simply to their regiment, nothing else. They have been packed up ready to go for 4 days and yesterday in all that rain the King's Liverpool stood on Parade for 2 hours waiting to go to the station and then were ordered back to barracks again. The popular belief is that all this Division is to go to Serbia! It surely can't be true.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Many of these cards were sent home from France - they are machine-embroidered on cloth, and most contained patriotic symbols/colours/flags etc. The odd one out here is the card with a beautiful flap on which is embroidered a lucky horseshoe - the patriotic bit is the little card inside, a "souvenir de glorieuse memoire", with its poignant "Remember Me" which for me evokes only Purcell and Dido's terrible lament...Wynne's favourite was the Forget Me Not card with the flags as flower petals. She notes by one of them "specimen of PC much patronised by Tommies".

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
September 26th - 30th

Death and good-byes. Wynne's beloved cousin Bill is killed at Loos. War news is grave.
viewer_10.description:
September 26th, Sunday
My Noot got a bad attack of little Mary yesterday so I've kept her in bed all day and she is the better for a large dose of castor oil! Poor maid. I've been spending sometime ready over my diary of 1913, how full those days seemed but compared with these, full of emptiness. Think of the simple serenity of it all, one round of pleasures mixed with parochial duties and yet how busy one seemed, but now, how altered everything is. Oh! the hideousness of these awful times, the never- ending good-byes, the anxious days and nights, never knowing what you may hear next, the weary waiting and the deathly tiredness that comes over one at times as the days go on and more and more are drawn into the fearful conflict. Now both Bulgaria and Greece are in arms, the former to join with Germany and the latter with the Allies. The Russians continue to retreat, the fighting at the Dardanelles gets no forwarder, and our Western Front in spite of persistent rumours of a big move etc remains the same. A line I had from Bill two days ago said " Dont worry about Herbert, he will not be in", nothing more, and H himself writes that every day they hear heavy sounds of firing down south but don't know who it is. (This was the Battle of Loos)

September 27th and 28th
A vile microbe has come here - my Noot has been so bad and so has my vile body. Dr Hussey has prescribed I eat nothing and lie squirming.

September 29th, Wednesday
Great news yesterday and today from the Front. The sound of persistent bombardment down south heard by H for 48 hours is now explained. A great attack has been planned and carried out by us and the French together, we apparently made headway of some considerable distance, captured about 2000 prisoners and 15 guns whilst the French in Champagne penetrated much further capturing and disabling 20,000 and 79 guns. Both our men are safe. H's Division was not directly used but Ell was pretty well in it all, and his job was guarding prisoners because the man who was told off to do it was such a bad linguist. He said the mob who passed through his hands were a miserable crowd, knees through their breeches and boots tied on with string and all nearly boys. Oh! how one does just hope we follow it up.

September 30th
This morning amongst my letters there was one from Rita, on opening it I was stricken to read that dear Brownie was killed in action on or about the 25th or 26th. It is a great loss to me, he and I have always been such pals for years and now the life has gone to make up like countless others the sum total of this most hideous war. Only about ten days ago he was here spending the day with Aim being home on 7 days leave and his last letter to me must have been written only about three days before he died. Thank God Ell and H still are well but the times are indeed anxious and one dreads the next day. The weather has turned horribly cold just like winter and oh, the poor men soon will be freezing again.


(Brownie is Bill Fallowfield, Wynne's cousin. In this photo taken in 1913 he is on the right. Both Bill, and Wynne's other cousin Herman pictured here playing with Ysobel, were killed in the War. Bill was killed on the 25th September - the first day of the Battle of Loos. This was a joint British and French offensive which started well but quickly collapsed. By the end of the battle in 1915 there were 50,000 casualties and nothing to show for it. Rudyard Kipling's son died in the same battle two days later, on the 27th. Bill is buried at Cambrin Churchyard Extension, 200.2, Grave B17. You can read more about him in the October diary, and another picture is in the Family section. For Herman's death, click here).

Ysobel, pictured above, remembers Bill as a bit of a wild card, like Herman. You can hear her memories of Herman if you use the "click here" link above.

To read the letters sent to the family, which they copied and circulated, click on the coloured word. They are in the October section.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: On Sept. 18th Herbert sent Wynne some fragments of glass from a church window, and wrapped them in these old signal orders (and in the 17th Division RA order you can see in the October diary). This one reads: "Half day report. A few rounds fired on enemy working parties at South West corner of BOIS QUARANTE and on suspected machine gun emplacements. "

september.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Zeppelin raids, and the "never-ending good-byes"...death comes to the family

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Zeppelin attacks became much more frequent as the war progressed, though in the later years they became vulnerable to counter-attack. You can see various references to them if you use the Search...this article was stuck into the diary on April 2nd.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 8th

More Zeppelin raids. Wynne is in London while her husband organises things for his new Home Front job.
viewer_2.description:
April Ist, Saturday
The children of course are busy making fools of the servants and vice versa, there is no peace till 12.0!
Last night the porter came up and warned us that Zeps were expected and this morning we see that they arrived, 5 strong, and dropped over a hundred bombs on the Eastern Counties. We have not heard the extent of the damage. I went this afternoon to Sidcup to see the Thuries. He met me at the station and we went to see the hens! He has a large field and on it has created heaps of henhouses etc. We then went to the house where we found Lena and had tea, afterwards inspecting her garden. Poor Thurie was very sad at just having had a summons for lighting.

April 2nd and 3rd
I miss out yesterdays scribbling because I was lazy and stayed in bed but the weather continues beautiful and it is a joy to be alive. Poggy and I went down to the City on the tube to our tea merchant and home on the top of a bus. The old City looked so lovely in the spring sun with a slight haze over all. The dear old churches St Mary le Strand, St Clements Dane etc, the lovely Lay Courts buildings and then the Bank, Exchange, Mansion House and St Pauls are all lovely and sublime and every time I go there it fascinates me more and more. After lunch Miss M and I took the children right up there again on the top of buses and the heat all day has been extraordinary. Great raids on Sat and Sun night and a good deal of damage and loss of life.

April 4th
For some 8 or 10 days my old dear has had shingles and so has been unable to go to this new billet, the 67th Div. at Sevenoaks, but now that he is better he proceeds on Thursday. Today we went down home to collect his kit, it has been a lovely day and seemed so fresh and clean after London, really up here one cant keep clean a day, our hair, face, clothes all absolutely black and its rather a bore. I am having a turn out with servants. Bessie has to leave as her Mother needs her and Olive is leaving for War work but I've replaced them both. Louie is coming back as cook and a sister of Mrs Wynter as housemaid, a between maid I cannot get and I know not what to do, its a real problem and I can't do without I fear.

April 5th, Wednesday
BG came to lunch and stayed to tea. She is looking very well and seems settled down in her school.
(BG was Wynne's old governess.)

April 6th
I and the children went to the Zoo today with Lil Taylor and her boy, a singularly quiet child who did not open out the whole afternoon. It was nice seeing Lil again, I don't think I had met her since I had my hair up, they used to stay with us a lot in the old days. Lil's husband is dead so she has no one but the boy.

April 7th
This is Win's birthday and she is 17 today, so grown up. She returned from school at 11.0 and Mrs Lees met her as I had some shopping to do. Herbert left yesterday and I was sad not to see him off. We went down to Kew after lunch by train and spent a lovely afternoon there rambling round its perfect grounds and through all the houses and then finished up with tea at Mrs Young. Young wasn't there as he is still at Woolwich, a Sergeant now in charge of the Sergeants' Mess.

April 8th
Today I lunched at the Club with Blanche Gray, poor dear, my heart aches for her, so sad and lonely. We motored down to Kew afterwards but there was such a crowd there which spoilt it all, it is its quietness which delights me ordinarily.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This surprisingly frank letter (how did it survive the censor?) gives a very clear picture of conditions, and explains in detail what it was like to suffer bombardment. It is perhaps an indication of the changes that were taking place in the perception of what was being undergone - the understanding that shell shock might be explicable as something rather more than plain cowardice.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 9th - 14th

Herbert becomes CRA Northern Army. The family remains in London, visiting a sand-bagged Westminster Abbey amongst other things.
viewer_4.description:
April 9th, Sunday
To Westminster with Win. We got there in time for the Sermon and stayed on to Communion. Dear wonderful place it impresses me more and more, and as one kneels there in the grandeur and stillness a thousand scenes crowd up before one's mind and one feels the inspiration of it all immensely. I took the children to tea at the Todds, a lovely evening, and we walked home across the Park. Our way led us past the statue of Peter Pan. Whilst gazing at his loveliness a soldier and his girl came up, "What is it supposed to be" she asked. "The Pipes of Pan of course" he replied, good enough for Punch. Everywhere throughout the Park and garden great giant trees lie smitten by the recent gale, over 100 fell in Hyde Park and it'll be long before they are cleared away.

April 10th
Today I came down to Malvern to pay Pink a visit and be present at his last Sports. I found the de Mornays there and her brother, a lot of parents were present and we first had Sports and then tea after which we took our boys up into the town. The de Ms and I are staying at Gold Hill which is full of that strange species of being which inhabits such places, dreadful females full of talk but I never utter on such occasions.

April 11th
The de Ms left this morning. I pottered about till Pink was free and spent the afternoon watching him play hockey, then tea with the Woods and at 6.0 I took Charlie de M, the two Charsleys and Pink up to tea in the town, sent them back at 6.45 where several sang and recited to me, including Pink.

April 12th, Wednesday
I left M this morning by the early train and had to carry my bag in the rain to the station! There I found my son who saw me off. He leaves tomorrow for good after 4 years of Southlea, and I am sure will be sorry. The Woods have been very good to him. On my arrival at home I found to my suprize a wire from Poggy saying he has been made C.R.A.Northern Army and was coming up to lunch and spend the night en route for Norfolk. It is a great surprize and a very jolly one. I had to go to the Club to meet a woman, then for tea, but hied me back pretty soon. Two such billets have just been created - he has one and General Phipps Hornby the other, it is a question of Eastern Coast defences.

April 13th
This is Nootles' birthday, 12 years old today, Mother made her a lovely cake as she did Win last week and she had many presents. Pinkie also arrived, Poggy taking the two little girls to meet him. We had an early lunch and then all went to Liverpool Street to see him off to Norfolk. When he had gone we made our way to see Westminster, Win and Pink never having been round it before. A lot of the most precious things have been removed for safety, the Coronation Chair, precious glass etc and many of the ancient tombs are completely sand-bagged so that one cant see them at all. All the gorgeous flags out of Ed VII chapel have been removed also and beautiful though it always is it is a great miss. We stayed till nearly closing time.

April 14th
At 10.30 I and the 4 children armed with our lunch set forth to the Zoo where we spent hours in every place especially the Monkey House of course, saw the baby Puma and stroked it and played with it, went behind the scenes to do so as its not on view. At 1.0 we repaired to a bench and had our lunch and at 3.30 met Mother and Aim who arrived to join us and had tea with us and we stayed till closing time, 6.0, a lovely day but awfully cold wind.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The Mesopotamian campaign against the Turks was not going well - yes, here we are in Iraq again! The British were beseiged in a small town on the Tigris called Kut, and a relief army failed to get through, with the result that the whole garrison ended up in dreadful conditions as prisoners of war....Wynne's brother was part of the relief effort, and was wounded during it.
These are two letters describing conditions....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 15th - 23rd

Home again. Wynne worries about her brother, who is attempting to relieve Kut in Mesopotamia. Easter is also the 300th anniversary of Shakespeare's death.
viewer_6.description:
April 15th, Saturday
Once more we find ourselves at home, the house smells fresh and clean and the garden looks lovely, full of daffs, polyanthus, hiacinths (sic) etc..and much though I've loved being in Town with Mother its good to be home again and clean, for Town is dirty.

April 16th
Win is in bed with a cold. I and the children went to Kirk and the afternoon was spent in footling and fiddling as is usual on a Sunday. A nice morning and torrents in the afternoon.

April 17th
All these days and weeks though one says very little about it we are most frightfully anxious about Ell. He is on the Tigris with the relieving force of Kut. What tragedies are being enacted there, God alone knows. We know that heretofore their Hospital and commissariat supplies have been very inadequate, that the weather is awful and the ground under water. He is now attached to the 33rd Light Cavalry and as for Kut, poor besieged little force, one cannot think of their lot without shuddering and it is so awful for the relatives of these men.

April 19th, Wednesday (18th omitted)
Mother has sent me a line from Ell to read but alas it is only dated March 5th, one day after the last we received 11 days ago and is therefore 6 weeks old. It's heartbreaking, what a long time they take to come. He was well and had got over a bad bout of fever he had had, but oh! how one longs for him to be anywhere but there. We've had a typical April day, rain and sun every few minutes. Win and I bicycled into Farnham early to a dentist, its the first time she has ridden since her operation. In today's paper the Russians again are making great strides in Armenia and have now taken Trebizond on the coast. I've just been reading an account of the old history of this very old place, it has great importance as a port.

April 20th
The weather is slowly improving and today also my man came home for Easter leave, such a joy to be all at home together again, the whole family. How I wish it would last for ever! Very busy preparing for his home coming, killing the fatted calf etc...

April 21st
This day is an anniversary with us, for a great many year ago today, 1899 in fact, an event happened on the balcony of the Watson's Annexe Hotel in Bombay which altered the course of my life and for which I have never ceased to be thankful! We have spent the day gardening, He Pink and I, and it has been so awfully ripping. My tastes may be simple but I ask for nothing better.

April 22nd
Yesterday was spent in the usual quiet way and today Noot and I and Baby went down decorating, the flowers are in great profusion this year as Easter is so late and the church looked very pretty. Poggy took the two elder children into Farnham shopping and we gardened after lunch.

April 23rd, Easter Sunday
This is an Easter full of associations and anniversaries. It is also the Russian Easter Sunday, a very unusual thing, the Tercentenary of Shakepeare's death, also Cervantes, and St George's Day all rolled into one. We all went to communion, H, Win and I at 8.0 and the maids at various other times. After tea we all went for a long walk away into the fields and picked primroses - a lovely evening.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: A typical postcard - the staple for most communications, and very cheap still. The views are the black and white joke pictures you can see in larger form in January, and you reveal them by lifting the hut up - they are folded behind it.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 24th - 30th

The Easter Rising in Dublin; the fall of Kut in Iraq...two disasters in one week. But the hot weather means a picnic, and a hammock in the garden.
viewer_8.description:
April 24th, Easter Monday
Alas! my man has gone again, he had to leave at 7.30 this morning and all the family got up to see him go. We had our Easter Egg Hunt this year but as there are no children to ask except Charlie we were only 5, but I hid the baskets so successfully that they took half an hour before they were found.

April 25th
The weather is gradually getting warmer and warmer, the garden looks lovely with its garlands of flowers and every bird sings its song of praise all day. There is no time of year like this and one regrets the passing of every day.

April 26th
These two cuttings read like one of Henty's books, what a subject for a story. (This refers to the cutting headlined: "Rescue of the Tara Prisoners" and "Desert Hardships". You can read the first of these in the following window). What fearful experiences and if it had not been for the Duke of Westminster all these men would have died. Surely he will get recognition. We all went out today for the whole day taking a sandwich and ginger beer lunch. We went over to the Old Park Fields and there we read, birds nested, and picked primroses to our hearts content. It was a perfect day and everything over there is so quiet and still. The jays chased angrily the agitated cuckoo who screamed defiance in every tone, the little sedge warblers sat motionless in low bushes pouring forth their endless songs and all the other birds joined in the chorus, but so much peace and loveliness seems almost a mockery these dreadful days.

April 27th
A burst of extraordinary heat has set in this week, today it is as hot as summer and I just spent the whole afternoon in the hammock!
All sorts of fearful agitations are happening. Ireland is in a ferment, risings and rebellions, a bombardment of Lowestoft on Tuesday and an air raid but we are so accustomed to all this now that one doesn't think much about it. Only Ireland is dreadful and the Germans are behind it. Poor credulous nation always running their heads into bags for no end.

April 28th
A letter from Ell! Oh! red letter day! No date, but the postmark is March 14th. I enjoyed getting it so awfully, he was fairly well but found the Tigris water a trial and gave a description of the engagement of 9-10th March which alas was a failure. He himself was hit by shrapnel but by God's mercy it only bruised him. His description of their life and hardships fill one with dread but he says actually very little, only one can read between the lines.

April 29th
The weather leaves nothing to be desired, its very hot and very lovely and one regrets the passing of every day but ... is one really in sympathy with it for this year "we carry our own winter with us everywhere". I have sufficient excuse to talk about carrying winter with us for this evening the tragic news has come to hand of the Fall of Kut. Never has there been a more tragic drama acted before our eyes. For months and months this devoted garrison has held out in a dirty little Arab town against appalling odds and at last no food was left. A relief ship sent a few days ago supposedly ran the gauntlet of the Turkish guns only to be stopped within 4 miles of the town by a sand bank - irony of fate - and on the 27th or 28th april Gen. Townshend had to surrender. He has been allowed to retain his sword and the sick and wounded are to be exchanged altogether the Turk has behaved like a gentleman. The force - 4 Generals, 277 British Officers, 274 Indian ditto and 13,300 men are to be marched to Anatolia wherever that may be. One's heart aches at it all and to think of the hundreds of lives lost in the efforts to relieve the Town all for nothing. Our anxieties for Ell still continue, his daily danger we cannot fail to appreciate, but there is a God over all.

April 30th, Sunday
The heat continues. I was overjoyed at getting an "Observer" today. Garvin's article on the Irish Question is most interesting. We have news through now of a tremendous Rising over there on Easter Monday, and on Good Friday a German ship was captured on the South Coast trying to land arms and ammunition, with Sir Roger Casement on board, so he is safely out of the way.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
An article about the fall of Kut - one of the less noble stories of the War - and below it, another article mentioned by Wynne on April 26th, which was much more to the public's taste, and as noted, very much a Boys' Own type of story....this was the rescue of two shipwrecked crews who had been captured by local tribes.

If you are interested in the latter story, check out:
http://www.1914-1918.net/mespot.htm

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Herbert is now on the Home Front; Kut falls; and the Easter Rising in Dublin is noted.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This is the letter Wynne received from her brother who was then in Mesopotamia (as Iraq was then called) on August 10th (note the date on it). It had been preceded by a telegram that told them he was going to India, so they were even more confused...but it gives some insight into the conditions and into the rudimentary organisation. I have transcribed it below...

Elliot's letter from Basra is a copy Wynne has made from the original. This was often done in the family, so that copies could circulate - sometimes they even noted how many copies had been done.

June 23/ 16

My Dearest Mum
Back again and shall rejoin my regiment tomorrow morning. This last week has really been rather a foretaste of the after place. I started from Basra on the 14th and they put me in a place about a yard broad over which I thought there was a tattie roof and an awning over that - well, there wasn't and down I went with the sun the very first day. In addition the heat was terrific and one could not sleep at night. I was not happy - when i got to Amara they wanted to shove me into Hospital but I told them to be blowed and crept on shore and the cool night on shore did me a lot of good. Next day i was able to go and see two people in hospital but the day after I was bad again, but having taken 30 grs. of quinine by mistake in one dose really intended by the Doctor for 3 doses I was very nrealy cured and by the time I got here I was quite fit again and at present am exceedingly well (arm quite healed up). But did you ever hear of such an iniquitous thing to do - that boat was one of the actual boats that runs between Paloza Ghat and Bankipur. She had two small barges tied to her and they put 650 troops on her just out from home, the consequnece was 50 were landed at Amara and 20 at Sheik Saad all down with heat stroke. The Dr. took the temp. of one place they had to sleep in and found it 139°. There was a south wind which was a hot wind following up all the time. However that is over and as i say i am extremely fit again. It is very hot in the day time but quite cool at night and one does a great sleep. Yours etc...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 10th

Wynne meditates on the war, the friends she is losing daily, and the fears for her brother in Basra
viewer_2.description:
(Wynne is keeping the diary in fits and starts - at the end of this month she will stop and not resume until December)

August 10th
When last I wrote in this my man and I were on our way or just going rather to see the new house. We had a successful expedition and I think he was quite satisfied, the house is certainly charming but the garden alas leaves much to be desired. It is of course in very rough condition having been entirely neglected for 2 years. The lawns have been down for hay, all the roses have run to riot and there is very little in it at all. Moreover there are no large trees, a great disadvantage, but one cant have everything. Mrs Southy was there and so we were able to fix up everything. We put up at Crewkerne in the principal hotel and were very comfortable and had a very nice landlord but what a journey back! It was awful. The heat intense and every train so late that we lost all our connections and got home finally at 10.0! Poggy stayed till Monday and left by the 12.08. It has been a very busy fortnight since he left. I've been working at the Stanhope Hut and it is a desperately full one, situated as it is in the middle of the lines. Most (of the men) are RE and Middlesex, a rough crowd and not nearly such a good class as the Alexandra lot who are mostly RAMC. The work too is much more strenuous and by the end of the evening in this great heat our feet seem several sizes larger than they should be. I am writing in the Park. The children are busy playing in the stream, damming up and making a deep pool. I hear their high piping voices shrieking out the most ridiculous make believe conversations. Noot calls the loads she brings for the dam "contribulations"! It is very lovely here and so peaceful one simply can't realize that not so very far off men are fighting and killing, each side trying to out do the other. Even here in this solitude the sound of firing from the rifle ranges comes as a sharp reminder that more and more men are training for this awful devils game. It's all too cruel, the slaughter goes on and on. Last week I saw that Charlie Hughes Gibb had been killed, this week Major Cavendish and today Joc writes me that her eldest brother Graham was killed on the 4th - so it goes on. We have been anxious too about Ell - for a month no letter or wire but 2 days ago came a wire saying "All right, leaving for India". We cannot think what it means and only hope he goes on duty and not through ill health, but such horrible things happen one never can be at ease, anyhow its a blessed relief to think him away from that awful hole. Today Mother sent me a letter from him dated June 23rd which arrived yesterday. I have copied it out and stick it in here. It speaks for itself. He had been down with sunstroke which is not surprizing since the temp. at night had been up to 139°. Surely that must be a record. No one will ever know what these men have gone through out there and to what end? The whole thing has been another huge failure as the Dardanelles was, everything a muddle and hundreds of lives lost to no purpose. Oh! it does make one's blood boil.
I am alone with the children at present. Win is visiting the Maynards in Devon and Pink is with the Gwythers in Cornwall, lucky beggars, how we three do pine for the sea, but I am glad that they are both having such a good time. Mother comes on Monday and H I think for the weekend. Pink returns on Friday 18th. Meanwhile the weather is perfect, very hot for working, and what with hutting (working at the Army Hut) and potato crop gathering its been a pretty hard week but here its lovely. I am very busy with various things connected with our move, writing endless letters, selling the brougham, the coal etc...Robins has bought the brougham for £2!!! its positively humourous but one get nothing for them these day. We are thankful to be rid of it.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A letter from the trenches, written by Wynne's cousin, Algernon Fallowfield. He is the brother of the Fallowfield who was killed in 1915. It is written in pencil on YMCA paper, probably at some rest point just behind the front line.

17th September, 1916
Somewhere in Flanders

My Dear Wynne
It was very good of you to send me a parcel and you may be sure that it was duly appreciated. You do get rather tired of bully beef and hard tack as the staple diet, tho' the transport really works wonders when you come to consider things. Of course there are Y.M.C.A.s, canteens etc scattered around this country in the most surprising places but when you get there the stock is usually down to cigarettes, tobacco and biscuits. Also we do not get very much time for going out as we are in the trenches daily or nightly as the case may be. Not having enough R.E.s to go round, each division now has a pioneer battalion to supplement them. Which said toil and travail we are performing at present and will continue to do so until this trench warfare is over.
It is not so bad in a way as we are in billets about a couple of miles behind our front line trenches and go up daily or nightly to our work. Of course the drawback is that though we have to expose ourselves
most of the time to the tender mercies of Fritz we have no come back on him as we are not allowed to fire back. Our only chance will be when we have a general advance and then we will be able to pay back a few old scores.
Of course the worst things out here are the mud and general dirtiness. Water too is for some unaccountable reason rather scarce and all the drinking water is reinforced with chlorine of lime that is not very nice. Still on the whole we are all pretty happy in a way but it is inevitable that everybody should long for the end of the war. But still, nobody seems to contemplate peace at all except under one condition and that is the unconditional surrender of Germany.
Tho' things here are supposed to be quiet as compared to the Somme it is quite lively enough for us. Fritz too is at a distinct disadvantage - our artillery is immensely superior to his both in weight and numbers and for every shot he sends over we return about 10. Our aeroplanes are about all day but Fritz seems to be either very very modest or deficient in this commodity which must be a great handicap to his artillery. We are also continually sending over raiding parties to his trenches which parties rarely come back empty handed. Last night we had a series of raiding parties organised all over the front. The two brigades in our part of the line took between them 329 prisoners which was a pretty good nights work.
The really curious part of all is this, that once you get a couple of miles behind the trenches you would hardly know that there was a war going on. It is true that there are batteries of guns in the midst of standing crops but the crops are there and they are being harvested too. In the villages most of the houses are of course rather knocked to pieces but still there are quite a few little shops doing business. Where they get their stocks from is a mystery to me. Still it is very hard to get anything nice.
Souvenirs consist as a rule of extremely patriotic silk-embroidered postcards, silk handkerchiefs covered with the Allied flags in bunches and similar atrocities. The first week we were billeted just inside the communication trenches in a nunnery but my diligent searches were only rewarded with an extremely dull and worthless theological treatise printed in 1641. It was not worth taking away, especially as it was very bulky.
Did you ever come across a Colonel Ironsides? He is chief of staff to General Watson who is in command of our division. If you had met him you would remember him. I think his deeds will become legendary amongst this division, but the tales are too long for a letter. His speciality is the catching and treatment of German spies.
Mother enjoyed her stay with you very much and must have had quite a gay time. She does find it a relief to be able to do as she wishes and not to be tied to an old man of the sea. I suppose you will be pretty busy just now on account of moving. How does Pinkie like Wellington? Remember me to the children if they remember me - I am sorry I did not send you my contribution to Gran's stone any sooner but did not know that you had definitely arranged anything. I enclose it in this letter. I hear Herbert is keeping fit. Remember me to him if he is down on leave - I expect he is pretty busy just now. With love, your aff. cousin, Algernon Fallowfield.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 14th - 20th

News from India that her brother has been taken to Bombay with typhoid, but is recuperating there.

Wynne stops her diary to move house. It resumes in December.
viewer_4.description:
August 14th, Monday
My dear man has been home for the weekend, that's to say Sat. night to early this morning. I do so love to have him but can anyone miss their man more than I do I wonder, its really dreadful to me when he goes. Yesterday I took a morning in bed being a bit off, but got up to lunch to which came our old friend little Potter, home from India and stationed at Ewshott. It was good to see him and to hear news of all ones old friends, it seemed a veritable breath from the veldt. To tea came the Brendons, they are living in the de Mornays house for 3 months. They tell us old Gen. Brendon has become quite helpless and dotty, it is very sad. My man went off this morning.

August 15th
I went over to Ascot yesterday to fetch Mother who was staying with the Elliots. We used Walker's car and came over quite comfortable. She has had a wire from the India Office saying our Ell has gone to India, arrived Karachi 11th, left the same day for Bombay, invalided with "para typhoid, condition favourable". It is all a hideous anxiety but we are thankful he's out of it for a while, and I hope that perhaps he will go to Eve when better. What particular form of typhoid this is or what it means I don't know, but I hope we get another wire in a day or two. Pouring torrents today and I have my hut tonight.

August 16th
I had a pleasant surprize today, a line from Mr Whitehead saying he was coming to Aldershot on escort duty and at about 3.0 he turned up here, finding that he would have to stay the night I asked him to do so with us. He looks so well and has grown I do believe for he looked very tall. He is likely to go out with a draft any day again and so I am glad to see him. We have also had the extreme joy of another wire from the I.O. saying Ell is at Calaba Hospital, Bombay and is convalescent. It is a merciful relief and a weight off our minds. We have had letters too dated 14th July saying he was in hospital at Basra with this fever and giving more awful descriptions of the heat.

August 20th, Sunday
Nothing particular has happened the last three days. Douglas Whitehead left early Thursday morning. I went to the Hut Friday night and on my return felt more dead than alive by reason of a fearfully heavy night and a horrible chill which gave me fever, but I couldn't give in and go to bed because of Mother who always is so nervous that one cannot let on. Pink came back yesterday and we are quite a large party now. I wonder if Mistress Win comes back tomorrow - she has never said a word.

(Here Wynne breaks off her diary, as the whole family moved house down to Somerset. The diary resumes in December).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: An interesting article about the changing face of London.

august.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She stopped writing the diary at the end of August, and did not start again until December, after the family had moved to Somerset.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Patriotic Postcards of Haig and Kitchener - these are very elaborate textile cards, machine made but quite intricate. They were made in France and were very popular with the troops. These two were sent to Wynne by Gunner Heron - clearly someone who had served under her husband at some time.
(As they were copied with different resolutions you can see the textile more clearly on the Haig card)

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 3rd

Wynne brings her story up to date after a long break, and introduces us to the inhabitants of Hinton St George, the village she moved her family to in October.
viewer_2.description:
Ysobel's memory of the move to the new house in Somerset.

December 3rd, Sunday
Hinton End, Hinton St. George, Somerset.

It is a matter of great regret to me that I have for nearly 3 months dropped writing my Diary, a habit of years and in such interesting times, but its just "the times" that have done it for really with this War dragging on and on and the World so full of huge events it seems almost impossible to write down each day the little happenings of our microscopic existence. One's brains get "furbed" up with it all and one gets on the other hand utterly weary of reiterating the progress of a War that is seemingly endless. Nevertheless before another month passes and leaves behind it another year of misery and anxiety I am determined to put in a bit more just to give a résumé of our very thrilling life! As will be seen by my address by anyone who happens to light on this we are now settled in this house in far Somerset. Arrangements as to Agreement etc being fixed up we accordingly moved here on October 6th, that is to say, I , Martha and Cathy with Peter Vyell and a rabbit, and were followed next day by Win. The move was a great piece of work and I missed my man in more ways than one. To put it briefly I am charmed with the house and surrounding country whilst the garden is vile, the hot water arrangements ditto and our landlady "tres dificile". During the move I sent the children and Maby to Mother where they stayed for 3 weeks, in due course I gathered in a parlour and between maid and so far all goes very well. I am more than busy all day and every day and having got the house straight my time is now entirely devoted to the garden which from a howling wilderness is slowly becoming more civilized. I shall never care much for it as its too plain and straight but there is much in many other ways to commend the place and I am as happy as any one can be these days. There is in the village a local Hospital, a portion of Lord Poullet's house which he has given to the Red Cross, and there Win goes to work being enrolled in the V.A.D. for General Service. We have got to know all the men very well and 4 come down to tea every Saturday. I have no regular War work now so am glad to be able to "do my bit" in this way. They are very easy to amuse and we play games with them till 6.0 when they have to be escorted home. I am longing for Spring to come, I hear it is lovely here and that there are masses of Primroses everywhere. I do not regret leaving Hale at all save for some few very nice friends there. I also shall not forget some very jolly times there but I always hated the horrible neighbourhood with that vile Aldershot so near and I never want in all my life to return!
Our last month there was a very full one. We were 13 - 14 nearly all the time and there was much coming and going between us and the A.S.C. Mess where Tom Swayne was commandant. They played tennis at our house nearly every day and we were up there a lot as well, but no, I don't want to go back at all, this war has filled it with associations of nameless anxieties into the bargain and I'm glad we quitted.
Now the "Society" of Hinton reminds me of Miss Mitford's "Our Village" (see note at page bottom). We are far removed from the world and here "move and have their being" some odd dozen of so of people who go to make up a real old world community. The owner of the place and surrounding property is Lord Poullet who is away fighting. When we first came down here his Lady and her children were here and came to call before they left for Town for the winter. She, Lady P, was an actress, Silvia Storey by name, daughter of Fred Storey, an amiable lady apparently but just of the people. (Wynne has not spelt the name correctly - Sylvia Storey was a member of the London Gaiety Theatre company and married Earl Poulett in 1908...again, note correct spelling. Their son was born in 1909, and lived until 1973, after which the title died out. Earl Poulett fought in the war as a Captain in the Royal Horse Artillery, and died on 11th July 1918. The funeral is covered in the July 1918 diary).
She (Lady Poulett) asked us to tea one day and we went taking the children. Words fail me when I would describe the beauty of that house, it dates chiefly from Inigo Jones and it contains the most beautiful tapestries, pictures, furniture and china anyone ever saw. I shall never forget the beauty of the room in which we had tea, immense in its proportions it rises in the centre to a huge glass dome, its walls are oak-panelled and hung with enormous tapestries, round it stand numbers of beautiful old Chinese cabinets, lovely chairs and antique tables covered with china. At one end was an enormous open hearth with big steel fire dogs and a blaze of logs. Her Ladyship, dressed like one's great great grandmother after the fashion of the present day, also sat in the centre dispensing tea from amidst a mass of sliver which betrayed an experienced "Butler's Thumb". Her small children are charming, quite un-airified and well mannered and one day before they left they came here to tea.
The first to call here was a Mrs Lowe, she is a sort of Queen of the Village, and with her daughter Miss Dorothy Lowe lives in a little old house in the village,the wife of an Archdeacon and the mother of many scholastic sons and daughters. Miss Dorothy is doing Commandant at the Hospital and has a very busy time. Then there is Mrs Dolling who has lived here for 52 years and whose husband and son were both Rectors of the parish and who is very very poor and lives in a tiny house which was converted from a labourer's cottage. Another lady is Mrs Pardoe, also I believe a clergyman's widow, of her I know little. She came to call with Mrs Dolling and is doing masseuse at the Hospital. Round the corner by the church live the two Miss Coles, too poor to keep a servant at all, a couple of old maids rich in gossip and who when they came to call warned me of the various things I must not mention to this person or that, valuing my discretion I fancy as much as I valued theirs! but amongst all this collection of old Pussies we are not wanting in our "worldly element" for there is Mr Love, a man of 43, a land agent whose Father was the same before him and who has lived here for many years. He is quite the "man of the world", is away a great deal on business and when at home lives also in a tiny house (all the houses are tiny) with his old housekeeper and devoted slave, Harriet. It is all rather like Cranford and many are the strange histories and old world stories connected with the place and the inhabitants thereof. We are lucky in having a very nice church, old as the hills and filled with monuments and memorials of the Poullet (sic) family. Our parson is an earnest Churchman, a little pious but sincere. The services are well attended and the singing (Miss Coles plays the organ) very bright and nice and it is a blessed relief after the gloom of Hale and its coldness and emptiness. I have long gossips with my gardener, he being over age so far has not been called thank goodness. He is a real character and keeps me in fits of silent laughter. The tales I hear about one and all would turn the subject of them green with amazement. Lots of people have called, too many for my liking as its difficult getting about on one's bicycle these busy days and in the fearful weather we have had so much of since our arrival here. Distances are great too and the roads are very hilly. Mrs Lowe took me to Illminster in her car the other day to attend a sale of work. There I saw assembled crowds of other old Pussies all buying wool mats, dish cloths, string bags, print garments and the like and I was introduced to one after the other until I felt myself positively furry! but everyone seems awfully kind and pleasant in these parts and in the summer one will see more of people.
(Note: Miss Mitford, or Mary Russell Mitford, turned to writing to support a profligate father who had managed to waste a large inheritance. She lived from 1787 - 1865, and her village stories started to appear in the "Lady's Magazine" in 1819, immediately increasing its circulation. They were eventually collected into five volumes between 1824 and 1832, and were much praised as introducing a new style into the literary world. They were based on her own experiences while living at Three Mile Cross, a village between Basingstoke and Reading).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Charles Mullins knew the family well, but when they first met is unknown. Clearly he had served with Herbert- if not before, then certainly at Mafeking, since both were present at the relief. Given Wynne's comments, he must at some stage have visited the UK.

He won his VC during a British attack at Elandslaagte on 21st October 1899 under Major General Sir John French. Mullins rallied the men under heavy Boer fire at one point of the battle, and was wounded. He was seriously wounded again at Maritsani in 1900 and thereafter took no further part in the war. He never really recovered from this, and died on 24th May aged just 46. His VC had been in South Africa, but is now on loan and can be seen at the Imperial War Museum in London.

The author of this article is unkown, but it comes from a publication called "The Kingdom"

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 3rd (cont) - 8th

Wynne gives thanks for her loved-ones' survival. The winter is bitterly cold, and Asquith's Government falls. Lloyd George takes over as P.M.
viewer_4.description:
December 3rd, Sunday (cont...)
I do not attempt to follow the events of the War which have followed one another in quick succession since I felt unequal to writing these pages. They are too numerous and too tragic to dwell on. Suffice to say the daily casualty lists are as large as ever and we seem no nearer the end. More and more of our friends "go west" and of the old lot there are very few left. I see in my last entry that young Whitehead had been staying. He went out again shortly after that and got wounded in the hip almost immediately, and has been home in Hospital ever since. He is just now back on duty at Pembroke Docks. Our dear Ell is settled for the time in India. he went to Simla to recoup his wound, sunstroke and para typhoid and when convalescent went on leave to Behar, he and Eve being at Seryah together for about a fortnight. How I envy them both, what wouldn't I give to be all together again just once. His regiment has gone back to India much reduced by casualties and sickness and he now has a very nice billet as commandant of the bodyguard to Lord Pentland in Madras. He is for the moment however at Ooty (Ootacamund is a popular hill station located in the Nilgiri Hills in South India) as he cannot quite shake off the fever, such a bore. Herbert is still on the East Coast but came down here a short while ago on 3 days leave. As he hadn't seen the house before except of half an hour when empty it was very interesting showing him all round but oh! how it did make me long to get him back altogether. For over 2 weary long years this has been going on now, but I do not grumble. I am only too thankful to have him alive at all. God has been very good to me in this War in sparing both the men I love best in the world - and some day it must end, it can't go on for ever.

December 8th, Friday
This beauteous card I had sent in from John Carney one of my Canadians who is now serving at the Front. I love to note the two clinging stars, the candles on the trees all ready but what the halfway house has to do with Xmas I cant think, its quite a long time since I got one of these. Since writing this we have been suffering, really suffering from the most intense cold. It has been an awful week and really one felt the cold biting into ones bones. One couldn't get warm even in bed and I was thankful to see a thaw set in last night and to get it warmer today. This cutting which I stick in here was sent to Herbert about our dear old friend Charles Mullins, who died this summer. I was so glad to have it, he was a gallant gentleman and one felt proud to be numbered among his friends. (see previous window).
Great happenings have taken place this week. Our present Government has fallen, Mr Asquith has resigned and in today's paper we see that Lloyd George is Prime Minister. Now things will begin to hum I fancy, no more "wait and see" policy! but how extraordinary it seems that this man who years ago we all hated for his vulgar Billingsgate rhetoric should now meet with approval on all sides as the one man who knows his own mind. Meanwhile frantic and tragic things are happening. Rumania has practically succumbed, the Germans have occupied the capital and overrun the country, capturing thousands of prisoners and stores of all sorts; chaos prevails in Greece, a hideous reign of terror, civil war and unimagined cruelty all round, what a seething mass of horror and sadness the Balkans always are, and the larger powers seem able to do nothing.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: This is a letter from Wynne's brother, convalescing in Ootacamund in India - its five pages is typical of the sort of letters they wrote to each other. The feathers on the first page are "off a snipe and a jungle cock I got this evening".

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 15th

The winter cold is unlike any they have known. It is becoming more difficult to get provisions for the family.
viewer_6.description:
December 15th, Friday
This past week has been a perfect nightmare of cold, the land has truly been in the grip of winter. Every morning we awake to find the world a sea of hoar frost, every leaf and twig glistens and a great stillness reigns, it would be very beautiful if it were not so deadly. I don't think I've ever experienced such cold before in my life, and it goes on so long. Yesterday not being able to work in the garden I went for a long walk to Dinnington with Maby, Win and the children. The air was biting but everywhere a great stillness prevailed and how shall I describe the beauty of the scene - the whole land was one sheet of white crystals, the fir trees looked like gigantic ostrich plumes, the larches like uncurled ones and it looked extraordinary to peer into the depth of the woods and see every twig and branch looking like a crystal. Great frosted spider webs covered all the barns and the lichen covered apple trees in the hollow at Dinnington looked like bearded old men. We gathered large branches of mistletoe which grows in profusion there and as we strode along the ground crackled under our feet and the trees and hedges crackled above us. It was a perfect sight, one I shall never forget, but I do not enjoy this weather, its too painful. Today I had to make an expedition into Yeovil and bicycling in such low temperatures almost hurts one to breathe. The reason I went in arose from a curious coincidence. For some time Maby had been in negotiation with a Mrs Wilkinson and last week was asked by her to meet a sister-in-law in Yeovil and who should it turn out to be but Dot Sealy! and so I went in to meet her today. It was so very nice and she doesn't look a day older. We had a great talk. All the world is agog at present because Germany "in the cause of humanity" is offering Peace Terms. The Allies so far show no compliance but nothing of course is settled or even begun. The truth to me seems as though she were sick of it, so long as she was winning she didn't think much of the "cause of humanity", nor is she doing so now with her deportations and her outrages on every side, but the papers are extremely interesting and one watches it all with deep concern.
We are slowly but surely beginning to feel the pinch of the War. Living is becoming very complicated for many many mouths - no meat has been obtainable except beef and mutton, its price now stands at 1/2 and 1/3 respectively - that is down here. All provisions are up and in London eggs are 6d each! After the New Year no more white flour will be used and standard bread will be the order of the day. Today there is a rumour in the paper that sugar rations are coming and of course we heard that meatless days are to be enforced, that will not affect us for we've done it for months. The railway companies are making great changes. All fares are to be 50% dearer, no luggage but what you carry is taken free, fewer expresses are to be run and the speed of those remaining limited and so on. I can get no figs this year, no Elvas Plums or Carlsbad of course, raisins and sultanas are so high that we use chopped dates for cakes and pudding and find them an excellent substitute. Butter we never have but Blue Band Margarine always and its awfully good, really excellent. Well, its a doubtful blessing living in these awful times, and often times one gets very weary of it all. Everyday and all the day however "my knees are bent" in thankfulness for our personal good fortune in those we love best.


(Wynne's daughter Ysobel remembered this winter well. She writes: "The first winter in Somerset was bleak in more ways than one. The house was freezing, full of draughts - I suspect walls too thin, it was pseudo Tudor and only recently built. The grounds were a large piece fenced off as a garden, a field and a vegetable garden at the end of the field. This had been let to a farmer so no vegetables for us! and for some reason or other we couldn't buy any. Davis the gardener used to pinch swedes and cow cabbages for us and we ate hop tops and nettles. Also there was rationing and we couldn't get taken on by any shop so no butter, very little flour and sugar and we were hungry all the time. We used to bicycle round the country hunting for golden syrup and cheese." In fact Ysobel is conflating the years, because rationing did not start officially until 1917, but as you can see above, it was still very difficult obtaining things and the family happily did without butter!)

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: This is another typically brief note - a Christmas Greeting from one of Wynne's many Fallowfield cousins - this one Walter, serving in the Navy. He appears to have censored it himself, not that it needed any attention. He was the Commanding Officer on HMS Basilisk and writes: "Wishing you all a cheerful Christmas and the best of luck in the New Year."

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 19th - 24th

The family gather for Christmas, including Herbert who comes down from the East Coast on leave.
viewer_8.description:
December 19th - 23rd, Tuesday to Saturday
Up to today the desperate cold has continued, perfectly phenomenal cold. I have never endured worse, the whole earth has been frost bound for days, white glistening hoar frost and thick fogs all day, all day long we have crept about black with cold. Bathing in such weather is torture, also getting out of bed in the mornings, and its really been too strenuous but this day and since its been much warmer and we've had a lot of snow. Today the 19th Maby left us, it seems a great break after over 6 years and I shall miss her very much, she has been all along so conscientious and careful with the children in every way and I shall in many ways find it hard to replace her, but tout passe and nothing can last for ever. Today also by the evening train came Mother and Pinkie so our party began to increase and the next day Wednesday 20th my dear man came. It is so lovely being all complete, so far easier to make the best of this time of association. I am very busy with my large household of 11 and Kathie and I have our hands full catering for them all in these trying times but all goes well so far. On Wednesday Mr Love came to tea, he left for Bournemouth the next day to have a Xmas bust! and today he sent me a box of chocolates and such a lovely little Crown Derby tray for my collection, a very kind thought. (Wynne collected miniature china pieces).
Yesterday H and Pink, Davis and I got at the two Plane trees in front of the house and pollarded them. They now look stark and bare but will be greatly improved through next summer. We decorated the house today, it lends itself to such and looks awfully pretty. We also set up the Tree and shall start decorating it tomorrow. Its all so jolly being together - "jolly" - well that's hardly the word to use these days but when one can cast the burden of the war off one's back its a very great blessing and an enormous help having all one's dear things round one. My man coming home is splendid and such a help, it seems quite odd not having to do everything oneself. and such a rest. Some day surely the time must come again when he will be with me for good.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: This is a Christmas card made for the 15th Army Corps in . Although it would appear to have been designed by someone in the Corps, it was actually printed in Paris by Devambez, 63 Passage des Panoramas. This is a roofed market street in Paris, one of the first covered passageways in the world, and included engravers amongst its crafts. The card was sent from J.M.R.Harrison.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
December 25th - 31st

Christmas and New Year. The family manage a traditional Christmas but Wynne is heartily glad to see the end of 1916.
viewer_10.description:
December 24th, Sunday, to December 31st.
I am writing this upon the last day of the old year and having inveigled the rest of the household to bed at 10.30 I am going to see it out! I have much writing of sorts to do and I have this excellent opportunity in which to do it. Having seen all members safely to bed I have creepingly returned to my sitting room, my sitting room indeed - it is mine no longer in the sense of a sanctum or haven of peace but simply a public sitting room where the household congregates!!
