Well, Xmas is over with, its stockings and tree, and my dear man has once more returned to duty. He had a full week and did not go back till Thursday. The days flew by all too soon and every day was full of jobs. We lopped the front trees, put up the hen house and the garden frame, three things I never should have got done without him, also got all the wood chopped that Mr Love gave me. On the afternoon of the 24th we decorated the Tree, H and Mother and I. During our move the packers lost our box of decorations, some of which I had had since old Brookfield days, but kind Mother bought me a whole new set and it looked lovely. That night we filled the stockings, how many many times has this been done before!? and at 6.15 the next morning all four children came trooping in to empty their contents upon our beds, the reason of such a very early visit being that we were going to Early Celebration. H cowered beneath the bed clothes utterly refusing to be made excited over anything at such an hour! Higher and higher grew the papers and contents and as the clamour became louder he only disappeared further from sight until at last he arose and scattered children, stockings, paper etc in all directions! To Church at 11.0 the whole family went, a very well conducted service taken by Mrs Lowes' son and son-in-law but while this war lasts how can one sing with our hearts the old hymns of Peace and Goodwill.
After lunch we got all the presents ready and arranged the schoolroom having tea at 4.0. We lit up at 5.0 and rang the bell when according to custom in trooped the children and servants headed by Baby being the youngest, each flew to the table there to find their own particular corner and were soon immersed in their presents. Dear things, it is a joy to live in their joy, one can at any rate forget for the moment one's burden of the present time. "The present time" - will one in years to come ever forget having lived through it? As I write this during the last few hours of this hideous year and look back on all its strife and sorrow I cannot find it in my heart to regret the passing of one single day. I would not have one hour back. God has been so very good to me and mine during the whole of this fearful time that I feel most deeply our tremendous cause for thankfulness but the sorrows of one's friends and ones losses outside one's family cannot help but sadden one on looking back through the weariness of it all. Please God 1917 will see better times - the War cannot go on for ever, it must end in time.
I have greatly neglected my diary of late, and such a thing hasn't happened to me for years but somehow the troublous times have taken the heart out of one. It has utterly destroyed the "even tenor of one's way". I am going to make an effort to be more regular in my next but I doubt of success. Daily happenings these days seem too utterly trivial to set down and yet one cannot write perpetually of War and nothing but War. Goodbye 1916 - I am glad I shall (see) your face no more.

december.description:
The Diary ....in AUGUST

Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She stopped writing the diary at the end of August, and did not start again until December, after the family had moved to Somerset

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The first page of the Diary. Wynne has copied a poem by R. Gorell Barnes.

"Ye are holding in your hand, Liberty of little lands,
Seeking nothing, giving all, answering to Honour's call,
Stay Aggression's grim attack! Hurl the impious menace back!
Devotees of Liberty, ride ye now to Victory!"

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 5th

Losses at sea, Foul weather at home. Haig takes over in France, and Herbert is mentioned is Despatches.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Saturday
On looking at the first page of my Diary of last year I see that it too even as this one began in a tempestuous and frightful way. That day we learnt of the sinking of HMS Formidable, and this year we hear that SS P.O.Persia has been sunk and most of the lives lost. The telegram gave no details as to how, where or when, just the bald statement, and Oh! what a hideous shock it has given one. One lives in awful times and the weather is suitable as a most fearful gale is raging and has been for 3 days. I was at the Hut this afternoon - bus both ways, quite impossible to cycle. My man who has been in the Ypres Salient for the past six weeks writes that it is thought most probably another attack is to be made upon them, another gas attack I mean, but they have to await a S.E.Wind before it is possible. He writes of a possible Relief - I do trust and pray it may come off, I am so longing for his presence again. Great changes in the Commands out there are taking place, and recently Sir D Haig has gone to relieve Sir J French who is now at home in command of the Home Forces and has been made a Viscount. I hear Sir H Rawlinson has been given the 4th Army - how sweet for it! I must to bed now, it is weary that I am, all the others have been in theirs since long and the house is still and quiet.

January 2nd
Eve's birthday (Wynne's sister). Bless her, we were so glad to hear this mail that the wire we sent them arrived the morning after the letter in which we first told them that we had decided to have Win's operation performed. So they only had one night to think about it all, such a blessing. (A good example of communication in those days - they decided on the operation towards the end of November so the letter must have taken around a month).
This day began by being still, warm and dry and a thrush sat on the oak tree and gave me a long spring song before breakfast, it was very beautiful to listen to. By 10.0 our usual rain appeared and it poured and pelted to such an extent that I couldn't take the children to Kirk. This has been Intercession Sunday with special services for those who are bearing our burden at the various Fronts, how full our heart feels as all those many thousands come into our mind, poor brave ones. What horrible conditions many are living in, it almost makes one hate the comforts which are still our daily portion. I took the children to evening service at St Marks, a pitch black night but with the spasmodic aid of Pinkie's new torch we found our way. The church was very full and we had a nice bright little service.
No letter from H today, but I am rejoiced to see that in the Despatches on Saturday his name was again mentioned. Such a horrible disaster was published in Sat. evening's paper: SS Persia, one of the big liners, has been torpedoed off Crete and nearly all hands appear to have been lost. She was to have reached Port Said that day, I long for further news and details.

January 3rd
Although just to make us feel at home I suppose it did rain a trifle today, yet on the whole it was most lovely, warm and sunny and still and a thrush sat in the oak tree singing away like they do in April. The children played about in the garden all day long and I went out and poked around, all the bulbs are shooting out of the earth, great masses of them. A letter from H today telling me the delightful news that he has been given the billet of Corps Artillery Commander and so will have 3 Divisions to look after instead of one. I am so awfully glad though of course I fancy it will retard his leave somewhat, but its worth it. I bicycled in to the Hut today and my goodness, the road - at most places they are simply not fit to use so I had to walk most of the day.

January 4th
A day of darkness and rain. I spent most of it trying to write letters but interruptions were everlasting and Oh! I do long to go and hide sometimes. The world is too much with one on these occasions. I've just come back from the Heath End Hut - there was not enough to do at that little show and its very wearying and tiring. We never get more than 30 or 40 men and one could manage them alone quite well. I got three letters from H today, nothing further as to his movements.

January 5th, Wednesday
The whole day in Town at the Panto and most awfully good it was. I haven't laughed as much for ages. Brenda and her two elder came and a friend of Win's. We returned by the six and Win stays with Mother for the night.

This picture of her son, sitting bottom row, extreme right, was a rare personal picture in a Diary full of war material...it features the Southlea First Xl 1915, with their very successful season: they won 5 or their 6 matches, scoring 46 goals for and only 7 against!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Two examples of New Year greetings Wynne received - the first is from Capt Lyster in his prison camp, and had a simple pencil greeting on the back:
SPECIAL CARD
"To wish you all luck and a happier New Year - P E L."

The second is an interesting example of a card produced in the field - designed by a Sergeant (B.G.Tomkins), it appears to have been sent from the Dardanelles, which the Allies had finally evacuated on December 20th.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 6th - 10th

Mud at home as well as in France, but news arrives that Wynne's husband is to get leave after 6 months away. Aldershot in the blackout.
viewer_4.description:
January 6th, Thursday
I had to go and do Shirts for Mrs P today and gaily started off to bicycle. I had not got far before I realized that I couldn't use the road at all, I've never seen anything like the condition, enormous crater-like holes filled with water and a foot of slimy mud all over them, so I just rode on the footpath. On my way back Win overtook me and so I got a lift up, bicycle and all. The driver then told me that next week as a raid is expected all headlights are to be forbidden and only two small oil lamps will be allowed so no cars will come into the country at all, what is to be done I don't know. How to carry on about my Hut work. I can't walk home all alone and bicycling on these roads is out of the question. I do hope I shall not have to give it up but it looks precious like it for the present.
I had a letter from William Gilham today, from what he says I gather the boy must be in Serbia, he describes the bitter cold and the huge mountains. He begins his letter by saying "Just a line to tell you I am in the best of the pink and not popped over yet" ! I also heard from Pte. Blowey yesterday who I think is there too, but his letter was written on his way out and dated Nov. 28th so it took its time about coming. (Gilham had been the garden and stable boy for Wynne. Blowey I have no record of. There are many more references to William G - simplest link in to go to Editor's Picks, where you will see a photo in the strip, and follow links from that entry).
Two letters from my Dearest today, their Relief comes off on Sat., how pleased they all will be to get away from that desolate and dreadful spot, the Ypres Salient, with its frightful mud and constant "delivery of coals".

January 7th
Torrents of rain as usual but thank goodness we got a taxi to take and fetch us from the Hut. Next week most stringent lighting restrictions are coming out and all the taxis say they will not run. What I am to do when the weather is too bad for cycling I don't know. A very full Hut, over 4000 tickets sold during the afternoon and evening.

January 8th
Though the roads were and have been for sometime impossible I rode to the Hut today using the footpath the whole way. I met a Red Cap who sympathized with me and said he didn't blame me! A very busy afternoon, no cessation to the steady stream of men. I got home about 6.0 and played games with the children. Mr Burgess came to supper and played most beautifully.

January 9th
After two days blank I got 3 letters from H this morning telling me the delightful news that he is coming home on leave on Tuesday, he will have been away for 6 whole months. I am to go up and meet him and the whole prospect has filled me with the greatest joy. I simply can't collect my thoughts and feel perfectly mad!

January 10th, Monday
Have just got back from the Hut where Stella came too, doing Mrs Perceval's job for her as the Gen. has been home too. I'm sorry I didn't see him this time. All lights in Aldershot were very subdued tonight, all barrack windows with blinds and no flares. We came back by bus and hardly any taxis were running, it seemed quite strange.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
January contains 5 examples of these black and white cards, and in the next viewer window you will see examples of the Active Service cards.
Here are three examples from the black and white Camp Silhouette series...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 11th

Wynne goes to London to meet Herbert.

Her description of Victoria Station when the troop trains arrive is particularly moving - note the story of the whistling group.
viewer_6.description:
January 11th, Tuesday
How can I describe the delights of this day of days. Lovely weather to begin with and I started forth at 9.30 to catch the 10.0 train, the last thing I saw being Nootie vigorously pumping Peter's paw up and down in farewell to me. (Peter was Ysobel's toy rabbit - see his wedding story in 1915!) I got to Town and Mother's flat at 11.30 to find her just gone out with Aim and so I went to buy me a new hat! then back to lunch where I found my dear B.G. and with whom we had a great cackle. At 2.30 I left and went to Douglas for my hair wash and then to Victoria - as the time drew nearer my heart thumped louder and louder. Thinking the train arrived at 4.30 I went to the platform at that hour to find it didn't do so till 4.55 so as I was much too restless to stay on the platform I went and had some tea but I gulped it down in about 5 minutes as I was again far too restless to stay there! so back I went to the platform.
How can I describe this most curious scene. The platform was in semi-darkness and many people were walking up and down there to meet their beloved ones, upon their faces were expressions of contentment and suppressed excitement. I got up on to a bench in company with many others in order to be above the crowd. Behind us was the huge station clock - how those hands dragged, it seemed as if they never moved. At length there was a whisper that she was coming and round the bend in the line I saw two great eyes gliding along, one green, one white, and immediately there was a sort of hush on the platform as she crept in, coming at last to a panting standstill as all the doors burst open and hundreds came pouring out. At once all was wild confusion and as one after the other on our bench spotted their own they dropped off like leaves from a tree and darted towards the object of their search. I eagerly scanned each face as it hurried by but no Poggy did I see, and as the place cleared a bit I realized he hadn't come. Questioning the Guard in anxious tones he reassured me by saying that as more crossed last night there were 2400 to come this night and that the trains would come in every 20 minutes! so I waited another half hour of feverish expectancy and at length amongst the crowd of the next one I found the face I looked for, and all else was forgotten. We took taxi and drove to the Flat, passing the evening in talking and contentment but never shall I forget that scene, the dim light and the crowded platform, upon one side of which long tables were set with tea, buns, sandwiches and cakes by some Charitable Society and upon which the famished men fell to break their fast before each melted away to some joyously awaiting home, and what a strange sight they were in their motley clothes, all covered with mud straight from the trenches, mud on boots, accoutrements, rifle, face and clothes! Poor chaps - there were some people on my bench come to meet their Tommy who had arranged to whistle. This they did over and over again and at last in the far distance I heard the answer coming, nearer and nearer, till at last they met. Such joy is almost too sacred to look upon.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Three examples from the Active Service series - Wynne has 5 of these stuck into January too...
The titles are, in descending order: Rifle Brigade within a short distance of the German trenches; Our Indian Troops in France on their way to battle; and A Happy Card party at the Front.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 16th - 19th

News from India, "Spring Pies", and Herbert's leave ends. The Diary breaks off until March
viewer_8.description:
January 16th, Sunday
I have had no time for writing this week, with a man on leave one does not idle away the precious hour by too much writing. Suffice to say that each day since Tues. has passed like a dream and only too quickly. I want to catch hold of each day with both hands and detain it, we just idle and I am enjoying my "leave" as much as he. I go not to the Hut, my kind friends do that for me, and I am just living every hour. these most interesting photos were sent me by Eve this mail. This pillar is at Pursa, alas that I never saw it. It is one of those which were erected to mark the religious journeyings of the King Asoka who lived so long ago and died BC 231. It is inscribed in Prakrit, the spoken language of those times, and exhorts to good living

January 17th, Monday
A still warm day and fine rain fell on most of it. We seldom get a day just now without some rain but it's so warm and the thrushes sing all day long. On Sat. I made my first Spring Pie and found crocus, violet, aubretia, jasmine, daisy, carnation!, polyanthus, arabis, anemone, auricula, rosemary and aconite...quite a little garden and Baby has a hyacinth in bloom in her garden but we shall pay for all this warmth. H and I walked into Aldershot and took bus home. We heard this morning from Mother that she had heard by cable that Ell had reached Suez by which we know that he has gone to Mesopotamia and not stayed in Egypt. It is a horrible anxiety, they are having such fighting there and we know such heaps of men there now. We had tea with the Bacons and supped with Stella, most dissipated for these days.

January 18th
We were so pleased today to see Mr Presbury walk in. He stayed to tea and we had a great talk over old times and old friends. He commands an Ammunition Column over at Deepcut in the 185th Brigade. H, Win and I all went to the Hut tonight as Toots Fulton's concert party came down, a very full house and an excellent concert. They were a party of six, they go round to all sorts of Huts and Hospitals and give these concerts to the men.

January 19th
Still mild and moist, a day of lovely pottering, picture hanging, chicken house cleaning, letter writing etc. I am so enjoying this absolute peace but alas it draws to a close for we go tomorrow to Town to stay the night and H leaves early Friday morning, but I do not complain, I know I am jolly lucky.

(The Diary breaks off here, as Wynne became ill - she describes her problems in March, when she resumed writing).

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Wynne clearly reviewed her Diaries from time to time. In the January section of which contained postcards of a ruined Ypres, she has added much later (1928) photos of some of the rebuilding which was taking place - they were not taken by her. First is a view of the two pages, then two details follow...

january.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Tempestuous start to another year of War.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Battle of the Somme prompts Wynne to put in a large cutting from the Times - below is a look at the whole front page, which also contained a full map, the top of which you can see...I have blown up the first two columns to give you a flavour of the reporting style, which can can see if you scroll down. It was optimistic...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 5th

The Battle of the Somme begins, and is noted.
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Saturday
A new month but no new weather, just the same old rain and wind and I am very weary of it. Today I had a letter from my beloved Ell giving the first news of his wound. He was out with a few men when a Turkish aeroplane threw some shell about and a piece of shrapnel hit his arm and he picked a piece of about ¾ inch long out and went sick for about a week. Thank goodness it wasn't worse.
He seemed quite fit when he wrote and said he was but alas! he gets no parcels from us, those from India reach him but nothing from Home and its rather disheartening but one must go on sending. Mother came today to stay a few days.

July 2nd
I do really think that in spite of a high wind the weather has improved a little today for we have had a bit of sun. I did not go to Church in the morning but wrote yards of letters and got through many arrears and after tea I took the children to St Marks of which little village service I am very fond - so hearty and simple.

July 3rd
Today the papers have brought us great news. For many months past we have on our front been steadily working up for a great offensive combined with Russia, France and Italy and on Friday it commenced in real earnest. A most wonderful description has been sent to the Times from their correspondent which I am cutting out. It reads like a tremendous novel and Oh! how thrilling it all is. Quite awful.
(Note: this is Wynne's description of the beginning of the Battle of the Somme.)

July 4th
The Battle progresses slowly but steadily and its wonderful reading. Our heart stands still at the appalling loss of life there will be, its not to be contemplated, and one dreads the coming Casualty lists. Such a bombardment has never been seen or heard before and Oh! how one hopes and prays all the day long. I can think of nothing else.

July 5th, Wednesday
The weather has changed for the better the last few days, thank God for it for now our men have it fine which makes all the difference. I've been busy over various things today but my heart is over in France and I thank God my man is safe at home, it must be awful anxiety for those whose men are there.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
This is the reverse of the page you can see in the first window of this month - I put it in to show you some of the headlines, with names that are now iconic, like Thiepval and Anzac, and a poignant note about Charing Cross. I often stand in front of this station and think about those arrivals - in fact there is a very well known painting of just this event that is described here.

The article reads: "Moving scenes were witnessed last evening at Charing Cross Station and its vicinity, on the arrival of trains conveying wounded from the front. Access to the platform was, as usual, strictly forbidden, but a large crowd assembled in the station yard and on both sides of the road in the Strand, and for two hours greeted the brave men in the Red Cross ambulances and private motor-cars with sympathetic cheers, subdued cheers, as it was obviously felt by the crowd that any boisterous demonstrations would be out of place".

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 23rd - 27th

Wynne finds keeping the Diary very difficult. After three weeks she notes the appalling toll resulting from the current offensive.
viewer_4.description:
(Wynne resumes her diary after a break)

July 23rd, Sunday
It is a sad but true fact that I cannot write my Diary just now. Perhaps it will come to me again but the times though full of interest are paralyzing and one's brain stands still. One simply cannot follow it all. For 3 weeks now this enormous push has been in progress, day after day of fearful, incessant bombardment attack and consequent appalling loss of life. Thousands have fallen for all Fronts have been engaged and its all just too dreadful to think that this is the 20th Century too. The madness of it, and how can it end. All goes well with our beloved men so far as fighting goes but one simply recoils from the horror of it all. Thank God Ell's wound was slight, a piece from a shell dropped by a Turkish aeroplane struck his arm and he was taken to Basra but the heat out there, 120º in the shade, is enough to kill them all and why it doesn't beats me. Our house agreement is signed and settled and we move at Michaelmas. It seems so odd that its really all settled and we shall have a move and a half after six and a half years here. I shall be very sorry to say goodbye to various people here, especially the Skippys and the Bacons but I'm longing to move to fresh places and pastures new. It is all very exciting and on Friday H hopes to get leave so that we can go down there to see the house. He has of course not seen it yet. I do wonder what he'll think of my choice!

July 25th, Tuesday
Last night and tonight I've been working at another Hut, viz. the Stanhope lines but as they are short handed there. I go again tomorrow, it is situated in the middle of the Camp and in consequence of this hundreds and hundreds come in. It is at present much fuller than the Alexandra and the heat in there is stifling.

July 26th
I am so busy these days I don't know if I am standing on my head or my tail. I have had men here from 2 firms as to Removal estimates and tonight I was at the Hut again. The heat is suddenly tremendous.

July 27th, Thursday
I've been making jam today, also went down to Farnham to have my ear syringed because its been bothering lately. I picked two armfuls of roses before breakfast for town and sent them off the Lady F and Gertie. They were all covered with dew drenched spider webs and there was a thick mist denoting heat which has certainly come for its been boiling all day and this evening I go to Town to meet my dear man, stopping the night with Mother.

(The Diary breaks off here until August 10th)

july.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The Battle of the Somme starts...and Wynne finds it hard to keep up the writing

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Diary contains a number of very long cuttings about the Battle of Jutland - this is only a flavour of one such...it was clearly even then a blow to the British to suddenly realise how fragile their big ships were. When the Queen Mary disappeared in six minutes, struck in her arsenal by an accurately aimed German shell, there was general disbelief in the fleet itself, and this is reflected in the reporting. Both sides claimed victory, though both sides had significant losses...probably the most that can be said for this one major naval action was that it confined the German fleet to its bases for the rest of the war.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 6th

The Battle of Jutland starts the week, and Lord Kitchener's loss in the Hampshire ends it. Verdun still rages, and the Canadians suffer at Ypres.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Thursday
Once again we are arrived at this most glorious month but there is no rest in one's mind. I went to Town for the night and stayed with Mother. I arrived at lunch and there found CWM who it was very nice to see again, and looking so well just like his old self. Gertie came to dinner and we had a great talk, she is working very hard at the Admiralty, too hard by the look of her, and I am sure it is too much for her. We have had no further news of Ell. (CWM was Wynne's old flame, Charles Maclean).

June 2nd
Very early this morning Mother and I dragged off to Euston to try and meet Mrs Chapman with whom Win is to go out, should she go to India in Autumn, but finding out that the ship by which Mrs C is now going to Canada didn't sail until the next day I got on to her by phone. I then went and took Win's passage, its actually come as near as that, but oh! I cant think she will really go unless conditions change considerably in the meantime. Poggy is home for the weekend, its glorious seeing him home again.

June 3rd
On opening the paper this morning we were aghast at reading of a frightful battle at sea. The German fleet it appears came out of its hiding hole and met our Destroyers and Cruisers and a fearful fight took place. Very few details are to hand as yet but it is known to have been the biggest sea engagement that has ever taken place and thousands of lives have been lost including I see Sir Robert Arbuthnot so poor Dally is now Sir Dalrymple.

June 4th
We have got hold of a Sunday Times with a few further details. The engagement took place on 31st May and night of the 1st June. Words cannot describe the horror of it all but I have put in here some cuttings relating to it . Only 3 men so far as I can hear are gone from this place, one of the girls' husbands being one only married 3 months.

June 5th
This is our wedding day. 15 years of an ideal existence. I wish, I wish I could have it all over again. It is ripping having my man home for it but he left this morning. I drove him to the station in Stella's pony cart and got caught in a big storm of rain. The paper has more details today and gradually its coming to light that what looked like a pretty bad knock has really been almost the other way, our losses have been frightfully heavy but those of the Germans' as much so and they have lost appalling numbers.

June 6th
The weather suits the depression of the present time - cold, grey and wet. Most fearful happenings are taking place on every Front. Verdun still continues in increased fury, the Germans using every possible effort; poor old Ypres is again the scene of horrible fighting and the Canadians which hold that line have taken a knock; the Russians have a huge move on and claim to have taken 13,000 prisoners; on the other hand the Austrians are driving the Italians back badly but the climax for us was reached by hearing tonight that Lord Kitchener and all his staff have gone down in HMS Hampshire off the Orkneys. He was on his way to Russia. Torpedoed or mined, no details yet, but consternation reigns.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: News of Lord Kitchener's drowning when the Hampshire went down.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 7th - 15th

House hunting starts in earnest with a trip to Exeter and a stay at the Clarence Hotel for 5/- a night.
viewer_4.description:
June 7th, Wednesday
Really this news of Lord K and the Hampshire combined with the huge naval battle coming on top of each other is really too awful. One can hardly grasp the situation, day by day, as more news comes in of the latter one is certainly more reassured as it is slowly coming to light how very heavy the German losses have been but when one thinks of the thousands of lives that have been lost and all the stricken homes and now this second horror its almost more than one can bear. Up to now no survivors of the Hampshire have been found to tell the tale. Two of his staff we knew slightly, Sir F Donaldson and Gen Ellershaw, both of whom were at Woolwich during our time.

June 8th
I drove Stella down to Aldershot this morning as she was going to Town, did some shopping and returned before violent storms broke all through lunch, the rain and hail banged down but it cleared for a short while afterwards and I took Cathy down to Farnham to attend a lecture on cooking given by a lady belonging to the National Food Reform, such an excellent lecture and most interesting.

June 9th, Friday
A day at home and full of chores. My hen yard occupies me to the full these days, I have now 67 head in all and so far have only lost one chick, but I wish I had more room. Today's paper announces that 12 survivors of the Hampshire have been picked up on a raft!

June 13th, Tuesday
The interval between this and the last date is lost. I failed to write it and therefore cannot remember anything about it. This day though I started forth on a strange quest all on my own, viz. that of house hunting for we have decided to leave this lovely spot at Michaelmas if I can find a suitable home and this is what I am out to do. I am at Exeter, a lovely and fascinating town though I expect to be too busy to see much of it. I am here at the Clarence Hotel, an old Coaching Inn, most comfortable and clean and have a room in the top storey for 5/-.

June 14th
A busy day is behind me. I sallied forth directly after breakfast to see an agent with the result that during the day I managed to view 4 houses in the morning at Whimple to which I went by train and found neither (sic) at all satisfactory and after lunch I bicycled away out to Chudleigh where I saw two more, one was a grim little old house which had been a grammar school, quite impossible, and the other a more modern affair with convenient interior but of hideous appearance, so that was off, and I went home by train. The ride there was absolutely lovely and I am amazed at the beauty of this country, miles of rich deep pasturage through which the red cattle wander knee deep, high wooded hills and long valleys and most picturesque houses.

June 15th
My birthday and I am 37 today - perish the thought! Letters from the dear man and kinder but I quite forgot at first that it was my birthday. Again to the Agents and cycled out to Cullompton all along the Exe Valley past Pinhoe (scenes of my early childhood) until at last after about 12 miles I found the village. There I saw another house, Bolealler by name - hideous - standing in very pretty grounds and buried in the heart of the country. I rested half way and went into a wood where I ate my lunch and then proceeded. It is frightfully hot, quite perfect weather and no wind, absolutely ideal for cycling and so different from home where it is always raining these days. But none of these houses are any use so I go on to Yeovil tomorrow.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A report of the War on the Land, with special mention of the Canadian action at Ypres.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 16th - 19th

More house hunting. Wynne does all of it on a bicycle and the local railways. She travels miles across the hilly West country.
viewer_6.description:
June 16th, Friday
I arrived here about lunch time having broken my journey at Taunton as I thought my next Agents had an office there but found it was closed so I came on here (Yeovil) and calling on them got orders to view two houses at Hinton St George near Crewkerne. I rode out and at the end of 12 miles at length came upon a lovely village. The property is all Lord Poulett's and I saw two houses there, one no use, the other seems just what we want but it is not very pretty but has a lovely garden. A dear old woman caretaker showed me round and then I wandered round the village and inspected the Church which is charming, indeed I am most struck with it all, there is hardly an ugly house in the place and the surrounding country is perfect - but I yet have one or two more to see.

June 17th
I have had such a journeying today. I first went by train to Axminster and rode from there 2 miles to see another house, a castellated dwelling of vile appearance with a pretty garden in vile order. Such a nice young woman showed me round and insisted on taking me back to her cottage and gave me tea, I find the people round here are extraordinarily courteous. I next rode down to Seaton on the coast but was very disillusioned, it is a pokey new little place and no sand, it lies between Beer and Lyme and I don't want to see it again. At 5.0 I took train and after a journey of 3 hours pottering arrived home and very glad to be there but though I am not finding suitable houses I am enjoying myself immensely.

June 18th
I realized yesterday that I was only 6 miles from my Win and so accordingly I rode over to lunch at Sherborne. I went and fetched her at 2.0. We went off to the Digby where we sat in the garden till tea time which we had at the Hotel and then went back to the school where we attended Evening Chapel and listened to an admirable address by Miss Faithfull of Cheltenham College. After that I had supper with the girls and at 8.45 rode home in the cool of the evening, it has been a hot day though and the road is one long switchback, such awful hills I nearly died over one of about 2 miles long. Win dear one, is looking splendid, no eczema and as Head Girl of her house is thoroughly enjoying herself. I can't realize that it is her last term.
(The Digby was then a hotel. It is now a Sherborne Boys School Boarding house. Below is a picture of the hotel taken at about this period)

June 19th
Today I had another fruitless errand and the longest traipse of all. I went to see a house at a remote spot called Upton. I took train to Morebath, a wee station on the Barnstaple line. When I alighted no one else did and the train went lumbering on its way. I then enquired of the Station Master and a youthful porter the way to Upton. They vaguely waved their arms and said they couldn't direct me but would ask Mr ..., a countryman who happened luckily to be there. He too waved his arms and when I realized that my road in that boiling heat lay over a mountain my heart sank. However, Excelsior I thought and started forth. The road was a mere track covered in ruts and huge stones and grew steeper and steeper until when I had reached an angle like that of a fly on the wall I paused, mopped my fevered brow and one by one removed my gloves, my silk coat and my woven knickers and strapped them all on behind. Still the road climbed up and up and still the sun beat down, and not a creature hove in sight to ask the way of, but at long last I arrived at the village of Upton and there found a very polite young woman who led me to the house one and a half miles further on, there I found a nice house in a wood far remote from any human habitation with a lovely view and large grounds but oh! not for us and after a look round I cycled to Wiveliscombe 12 miles distant through the most lovely country, the high hedges covered with roses and honeysuckle and ferns, such hills like precipices and at 10.30 I at last got home to bed, a wild goose chase indeed!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Two interesting propaganda postcards from France. In the first, we see the Kaiser about to be guillotined - led to it by Poincare. The caption reads: Apres la bataille de la Marne: Guillaume voit, en reve, la Justice s'accomplir"

The second card looks to the future, and the partition (or sharing out) of the central Empires, represented by the featherless cockerel. The sign on the map reads: "Terrains a Vendre ou a Louer - s'addresser aux Allies" - in other words, for sale or to let.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 20th - 30th

Wynne settle on a house in Hinton St George, and then goes to London to stay with her Mother.
viewer_8.description:
June 20th, Tuesday
Today I went over again to Hinton St George to have another thorough look round St George's house, the only one so far that seems at all possible. It has in it certainly every thing which seems convenient, the right number of rooms, excellent hot water arrangements, electric light, phone etc and a very pretty garden. Mr Love met me at the station and drove me up in his car and on the way he showed me another house and I at once fell in love with it. Built by Hampton 8 or 9 years ago it looks quite old and is most picturesque. Moreover it has a billiard room and 3 bathrooms in it! but I fear me the rent is far too high for us. Mr L gave me lunch and tea and drove me back to the station where I only just caught the train! My mind is now full of the other house, Hinton End. Alas and alack.

June 21st
My pilgrimage is over and I am back in Town staying with Mother till Friday when H hopes to get leave and come home for the weekend. I received this afternoon the address by wire of the owner of Hinton End who lives in Town so I went and had a talk with her. They want £150 a year but I told her that was impossible so she is going to talk it over with her husband and phone me in the morning. She told me moreover that both the late occupants of St George's House have cancer and that it is very damp and unhealthy, that was quite enough. Even if we cant get this one I shouldn't dream of living there. Mother had a box this evening and we went with the Bouchers to see "Ye Gods", quite amusing and we had a good laugh.

June 22nd
Soon after 10.0 Mrs Southey rang me up to say they would let us have the house for £110, this to include all fixtures and billiard table. I then went to see her and talked the matter over further and I have asked her to let me have the agreement so there the matter finally rests and if it is in order we shall sign it and march to Hinton End at Michaelmas! This evening we went to the Opera and saw "The Critic" and "Phoebus and Pan". I enjoyed it very much and the music was lovely.
(This may refer to Sheridan's play, and to a Bach cantata - played on the same night).

June 23rd
Herbert came up today dear man and we journeyed home together. It is so delightful and ripping getting him home so often.

June 24th
Today H and I went over to Wellington to spend the afternoon with our dear son. He met us at the station looking beaming and we walked up to the Hotel where we first had lunch and then on to the College. H had not been there for 40 years! so he saw some changes! and we found Mr Eustace the Tutor who took us up to Pink's room and through the Lynedock Dorm where H was as a boy. We also called on the Master and then walked round the lakes. Whilst there the rain descended in a flood and we had to fly back to the Hotel where we had tea and then returned by the 6.0 train. We had just had Pink's first Half-Term report, it is as good as anyone could wish and he is head of his form and I am awfully proud. If he can keep it up he'll get a double remove at the end of the term.

June 25th - 30th
I never have anything to relate for Sundays and I've purposefully missed out this week as nothing worth recording has happened and the weather has been vile. The roses thrive but the sweet peas wont come out and the flowers as a rule have a draggled appearance. I have been busy this week bottling gooseberries and making them into jam. I have also sold lots of eggs and have already made £1.3.0d which will help pay for their food as the food prices at present are enormous.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
In an envelope stuck into the entry for June 19th is this edition of the Balkan News. This is No 264 from its first year of publication. Its actually dated July 25 so was clearly stuck into the diary by Wynne in a spare space, with no real connection to the dates. It was an English publication, printed in Salonika in Greece. The byline is: "Printed by the Proprietors of "Independant" and "Opinion", Jean Tchimiski Street".

It would appear to be quite objective editorially - the article on the left, headlined "In Germany" points out that English and French papers are rather ignorant of the situation in Germany regarding food, and that in fact the country is getting along fine and no one is starving. However the style is on the whole light, and generally optimistic, and various demonstrations and debates in Germany are reported as indicators of problems in that country. You can see a part of the "In Germany" article if you scroll down.

june.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The Battle of Jutland and the loss of Kitchener, but house hunting is important too...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: A suggestion for the revised Arms for the House of Hohenzollern - on the shield you can see their take on the Lusitania sinking, the Zeppelin bombing raids, and the execution of Edith Cavell...the fourth quarter shows the Kaiser as a daschund. (Scroll down for the enlarged crest).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 3rd

Wynne has just had a painful operation, performed at home, to repair X-Ray damage to her armpits. Meanwhile, her husband returns from France.

She notes the battle at Verdun has begun
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Wednesday
For six weeks or so I've had to knock off my Diary. I haven't done that for years but this time it was not voluntary, and this is the explanation of it all. Before H came home my right armpit began to feel sore and as it was the place I had had X-Rayed 3 years ago I sent for Hussey. (See May 13th 1913). For a week I played around with ointment and unguents to no avail and so the day my man left, Friday Jan 21st I went on Dr H's advice to see a specialist in Town, Dr Sequira, who gazed at it, asked a few questions and ordered me to bed. Little did I know that it would be 5 or 6 weeks before I got up again. Well after a fortnight as it wouldn't get better the Drs here sent me to Town again to see another man, Sir Watson Cheyne. He ordered an operation, so on Feb 10th each armed with their black bags and various bogey tricks they worked their wicked wills upon me. I will not dwell upon the time that followed, it was one of horrible pain followed by much discomfort and now I am still hors de combat but come down stairs in my négligé!
(A Dr Sequira was a witness at one of the Ripper inquests in 1888 - can it be the same man? Watson Cheyne was a very famous surgeon at the time, and became embroiled in a controversy regarding the relatively new art/science of chiropractic which had been taken up by the army before the war. Extraordinary though it may sound to us, Wynne had had her armpits bombarded with X-rays in 1913 as a cure for excessive sweating. Given the paucity of knowledge then about these things, this was regarded as a miracle cure, but clearly what happened was a cancer formed. They cut out the damaged skin in an operation performed at her home - hence the reference to black bags etc).
I did my hair up for the first time so am beginning to feel less bogeyish and Dr H says we may start off for Town in about a week's time. Meanwhile I have other more interesting news to relate, some 10 days ago I had a letter from my man to say many of the higher commands are being filled by younger men and he is coming home. Since which I've had no further news of his coming, each day I get more impatient and always expect a wire. I don't think they can keep him much longer now and I think its rather rotten their doing so at all after telling him that he is to come. One day, the 9th Feb., Capt. Gore Browne came to see me, he was on leave, and it was a refreshment, so cheery and nice and said such nice things about my man, it made me feel quite chokey and all through these past few weeks one has been glad of all the cheer one can have. But everyone is and has been very kind, Stella and Joane Bacon come in almost every day and I am kept supplied with fruit and flowers and literature. I also get visits from Mrs Newcombe, Mrs de Mornay and Skippy who has been home on leave but who alas left yesterday. I read and read and read. I've got through 3 volumes of Motley Dutch Republic for the second time! (this refers to "The Rise of the Dutch Republic" by John Lothrop Motley, a Victorian author who died in 1877. It was published in 1856), the Letters and Memoirs of de Sévigné and Saint Simon, Social France in the 17th Century besides some novels and the daily paper which at present is full of thrills and excitement. The Germans are making an enormous push round Verdun and so far though they have forced the French to retire a bit yet the latter are making a great stand and the paper says that we've had no bigger battle since the beginning of the war. How anxious are the times.
Later: since writing above I have had a wire from H saying he is to arrive in London tomorrow. Alas! would that I could meet him. He will stay the night with Mother, go and report at the War Office on Friday and then I hope return to the bosom of his family. What a blessed peace it will be for us to have him here and I hope he'll be with us for some little time.
Two horrible disasters at sea have just taken place: the P&O's largest liner, the Maloja, sunk by a mine near Dover, 155 lives lost, and the French transport in the Med, over 900 lives lost - awful.

March 2nd, Thursday.
Another wire from H today saying he has arrived in Town and is coming down by the 11.45 tomorrow. My arm is so much better that I'm hoping to be able to go to Town on Tuesday where we shall all be with Mother for a month of five weeks. I am much looking forward to a real change. Mr and Mrs de Mornay came to tea today followed by my faithful crony Joane Bacon. She had just been milking. Fearful battles are raging round Verdun. One of the outer forts, that of Douaumont, has been captured by the Germans but they are now surrounded, it is the largest engagement since the War and fearful loss of life on both sides but the French are making a valiant stand and one holds ones breath as to the issue.

March 3rd
At 1.30 my man returned today having reported at the W.O. in the morning and stayed the night with Mother. It is so awfully nice to have him back and feels much nicer than I have words to say! I have heard today that our Ell is attached to the 33rd Light Cavalry and is in Mesopotamia with the Euphrates force under General Brooking. So far so good and I hope we soon get a letter.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A picture postcard of German trenches, sent by Herbert to his youngest daughter Eleanore. On the back he says: "This isn't a very interesting picture but I thought you'd like a different one to N's and these were the only 2 in the shop. Write me a letter soon. With love from D. "

It has a Passed Field Censor stamp 1581.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 4th - 12th

Wynne and the family go up to London. Verdun is noted, and her brother Ell turns out to be in Basra as part of the ill-fated attempt to relieve Kut.
viewer_4.description:
March 4th, Saturday
At last after 7 weeks with the exception of the day I went to Town to see the second specialist I have been out in the garden. Also have I dressed like a Christian and gone in to have my dinner in the dining room so all is well. What with this and having my man with me I feel quite bucked.

March 5th
As I still get up rather late I did not go to Kirk and as Maby was away for the week end H took the children down.

March 6th
I spent most of today packing in a leisurely fashion and at tea time Dr Tanner came to have a last look at my arm and says I must wear it in a sling for a fortnight and not use it at all, so a little more patience is needed. Still Maby came back about midday and it has begun to snow again.

March 7th, Tuesday.
Up to Town in a snow storm, so dreadfully cold, so wet and dirty and black and the nearer we got to Town the dirtier it got and as we drove through the streets everyone was swimming along through slush and black water and the whole thing looked vile but its nice to be up, nice to have a complete change and rest from the housekeeping and house chores and to see Mother again.

March 8th
A day of idleness except that after lunch I and the children with Maby went off to do some shopping, walked to the Legards only to find them out of Town.

March 9th
To the Stores in the morning and on the way we met Miss Waller and Betty curiously enough and still odder came back with them too. The children and Maby are to go for a walk with them tomorrow and were there at tea today

How long since I've used that old language. Aim and Brenda came for Bridge today and to tea came Capt. Wilson. I was so glad to see him but he's been so badly wounded and has lost an eye and its sadly disfigured him. It happened at Ypres where he was one of H's battery commanders.
(the above is Wynne's private code - see 1895)

March 10th, Friday
I am so lazy of a morning nowadays, not getting up till about 11.0, that there's not much time to do things in the morning but after lunch H and I took the children down to the Stores where we shopped. So bitterly cold and really horrible out.

March 11th
I have not been out all day, the weather did not look tempting and so I just refused to move. H went out before lunch for exercise and again after lunch and so did the children but Mother and I snoozed quietly till 4.0 when I went down to see Muriel Kuyrett who lives just below. The horrible old war goes on day after day, wild battles going on round Verdun still really fearful happenings but one gets most weary of it all. We had letters at last from Ell, Feb 2 and 9, from Basra and further but since then he has gone to the 33rd L.C. and so if probably further up the river.
(Oh dear - just another Basra experience. Funny how no one learns from history)

March 12th
How I do enjoy a Sunday in Town. What advantages people have who live up here and how many take no notice of it - H and I went this morning to church at St Margarets, Westminster. The music and the sermon and the whole atmosphere is all so inspiring, so different from our dead service at home and the wrothy but laboured efforts of Blacker and things like that. The Dean of Manchester preached and we had such a beautiful anthem with mens and boys voices all of the best. Then after lunch we went and heard delightful music at the Queens Hall which I enjoyed immensely. When one hears no music ever one does so appreciate it.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
This is a list from the Jodhpur Lancers of their Parade state, which Ell must have sent over - it lists the wounded, sick etc - the translation of each of the categories is below: bigilash - sick; jakmi - wounded etc...


Translation:

Top line: Parade state, Jodhpur Lancers

Name Duty
B Class (sick)
Jakmi (wounded)
General Hospital
Nagar (bugler)
labarash (La Barossa camp)
Langar men (cooks)
Arli (orderlies)
Rashan (rations)
pitang jhahaj (fatigue ship)
sigraikeshan (segregation camp)
Raj mant duti (regimental duty
pitang camp (camp fatigue)
limar hall (sick)

Used
Total

The three columns are Alwar, Jodhpur, and total.

If you are interested you might like to visit the Brighton Pavilion site. There is an excellent small exhibition in the Pavilion centred on its use during World War 1 as a hospital for Indian troops. What they thought, sleeping in the great dining room under the palm leaves on its roof, is unrecorded.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 13th - 17th

Wynne notes the death of her great friend, Major Gray. Herbert goes to the Palace for his C.B., and there are visits to the Raemaker exhibition and the Zoo.
viewer_6.description:
March 13th, Monday
Mother and I had intended going out shopping this morning but a fearful fog came on and so we put off till after lunch, when we drove to the stores and on our return we found both Blanche Gray and her sister, dear nice women, they are going to Torquay on Wed. for a week to see if they can find the sun for here they are certain to find none. I missed so much of diary writing this year that I have never mentioned the death of our dear Norman Gray which occurred last month, up at a San in Scotland. He died of consumption which was the result of injury to his lungs by the running over of him by a team at the beginning of the War. We felt it very much and he is a great loss to us. H has been out since the morning meeting Frank and going to the W.O.
(The Commonwealth War Grave page details are as follows: In Memory of Major NORMAN MACNEILL GRAY - 45th Bty. 42nd Bde., Royal Field Artillery who died age 42 on 09 February 1916.
Son of Archibald Gray; husband of Josephine Blanche Clolilde Gray, of 19, Kensington Gore, London. Wounded at Mons, 1914. Remembered with honour. He is buried in the London cemetery of Kensal Green in a specially designated area. The Gray's were very close friends - as you can see if you check out the Welsh trip they did in May 1912. The NMG on Wynne's Snowden "diploma" you can see in June 1912 is Norman Gray. Herbert and Norman Gray went back a long way, to Mafeking and probably before. You can see his signature on the menu for one of the relief column reunions).

March 14th
This morning Mother, Aim and I went to a greengrocer's establishment in Portobello Road called Jesse Smith. It is a wonderful place where you can buy all such things much cheaper than up West and where we purchased the weeks vegetables and I got a lot of flowers, such lovely tulips and all Spring things. H and I were going to Brenda today but her small son Jacky is ill so we put it off.

March 15th, Wednesday
H and I have been out nearly all day shopping carpets, first to Cardinal and Harfords and then to lunch at club and afterwards to Waring and Gillow. We bought 3, one for my little room, one for Maby's room and one for the children. They are a price these days and so few orientals are coming in at all. I made H go to Evans and have his silhouette done and its awfully nice, the man just cuts them out at sight.
(Extraordinarily, Wynne does not mention the fact that also today Herbert went to Buckingham Palace to be invested with the Order of the Bath. Instead she inserted a cutting from the Court Circular. Clearly at that time this was not an event that impacted on their lives very much!)

March 16th
We did a virtuous thing today - went and lunched with Mrs Thursday at her Club, the Ladies Imperial. She has been very kind to Pinkie at Malvern and so we returned her kindness by lunching with her!! We went afterwards to see Raemaeker's Pictures of the War. They are creating a great furore and are certainly clever but many are most horrible and haunting, no Englishman would have a vivid enough mind to draw such things, it is a regular Wirtz gallery. At 4.0 we went to meet Mrs Brecks at the Club who came to have tea with us. It was very nice seeing her and we had a long regimental conversation digging out old friends by the bunch and hearing news of many of whom we had not heard for ages. She is living in Town as he is at the W.O.
(Louis Raemaeker was a Dutch artist who was employed to add cartoons about German atrocities to a propaganda pamphlet - he was one of a number of artists and writers to become involved in the Government's clandestine propaganda campaign).

March 17th
This is my dear man's birthday and as a treat the children were given a whole holiday and we all went off to the Zoo. It was a lovely day, warm and sunny, and we stayed there till 1.0 when we went to have lunch with the Jacksons at Regents Park, they are old Indian friends of Mother, she and her Mother Mrs Stevens, they live in a lovely flat and keep native servants and gave us a most lovely India lunch: prawn curry and chicken cutlets. We all thoroughly enjoyed it! We then went back to the Zoo to see the lions fed and other items, returning home by 5.0. The big mandrill is dead, no more shall we see his lovely proportions! I do love that place and should like to wander about there for days on end. The Mappin terraces for the bears and chamois are very fine.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Part of an article about a reception at Buckingham Palace for wounded soldiers that Wynne stuck into her entry for March 24th...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 18th - 23rd

Still in London: a concert in aid of Soldiers' Free Buffets, attended by the Queen; visits to Westminster Abbey; and an exhibition of work by wounded soldiers.
viewer_8.description:
March 18th, Saturday
A little shopping in the morning and Mimi Jones came in to see us and after lunch Mother, Noot and I went off to the Irish Concert at the Albert Hall. It was in aid of Soldiers Free Buffets and a great gathering was there, the massed Bands of Guards played all sorts of things most beautifully, amongst others the National Anthem, the first verse of which Agnes Nicolls sang, the second Lady Maud Warrender and the third the audience. The Queen and her ladies were there and if I had been her I should have broken down, I know it was simply lovely. Albert Sammons played the violin and 2 men sang. There were many wounded there in their blue hospital garb, alas now so familiar, the most pathetic of all being the blind - one's heart aches for them.

March 19th
Mother's birthday, many happy returns. H and I went to Westminster, got there just before the sermon which was an excellent one and stayed to communion. A feeling of awe comes over one in this most perfect building, crowded as it is with its countless historic memories, every stone of it I love and I couldn't help thinking how merciful and wonderful a thing it is that so far it has escaped accident from Zeppelin. One cannot imagine a worse tragedy. After lunch H took the children there to service whilst Mother and I went off to the Queens Hall to a concert. It was not nearly so interesting a one as last Sunday and a long symphony of Beethoven put me to sleep!

March 20th
I think specially of Father today as it was his birthday. He would have been 77 had he lived and he was only 59 when he died 18 years ago. Where have all those years gone to. We set forth at 11.0 to get a carpet at Harrods for the hall but failed. We then went into an exhibition at Princes of Active Service things and there saw all sorts of work by wounded Belgian and French soldiers, war relics etc. We bought a ring made of alluminium (sic) from the top of a shell for Noots' collection, of which there were hundreds all made by Belgian wounded, and there were there all kinds of others things they make. To lunch with Mrs Gillson who is living with her sister, both are war working - Mrs G at a YMCA where she goes every morning at 7.30. We then went and got a carpet at harvey Nichols and so home to tea.

March 21st
A fine drizzle fell all day and it was very raw and cold. I had to go out to my dressmaker in the morning and after lunch H and I took the children to the Victoria and Albert Museum. It does contain some lovely things but is such a vast place that it would take weeks to go round. After tea I played Bridge and won 3/9. I am putting whatever I win on to my Red Cross cards and have filled quite a lot of spaces now.

March 22nd, Wednesday
Again a fine rain and most unpleasant. I had Lady F lunching with me at the Club, did some shopping on the way home and Charles and Gladys came to tea. It was nice seeing them again and he is much better and at work at the W.O. now.

March 23rd
I had rather a bogeyish day today viz. two visits to the dentist, dragging with me my two poor victim children. We went to a man called Dr Pare as my own man has gone to the War, and he turned out very nice. He first did two stoppings for me and examined the children, we then returned to lunch and went back again at 3.0 when my poor Noot had 2 teeth out with Novacame and Baby had her lip separated from her gum, he having found it joined almost down to her teeth and he said it would have the effect of making her second teeth grow apart and crooked. Both children were awfully good and brave and simply said nothing and I am so glad it is all over. I just hated it! He then prepared another hole for me and next Wednesday i go back to him to get finished up.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Part of an article about the Star and Garter appeal, which starts with John Gallsworthy's effort at imagining what it was like to be one of the disabled men...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
March 24th - 31st

Augustus John in person at his exhibition, then a show in aid of the new Star and Garter Home for disabled soldiers. The family stay in London, visiting theatres and going to the Zoo again. They see D.W. Griffith's "Birth of a Nation".
viewer_10.description:
March 24th, Friday
At 11.0 this morning I went over to Chelsea to pick up Gertie M and with her I went to see Augustus John's work at Chenil Galleries. He is supposed to be the coming man and is worshipped by a certain coterie. I am no art critic and I know nothing about art but personally the paintings are a chamber of crude horrors, the etchings are works of art beautifully fine and though sometime violent none the less clever. As we came out he himself appeared, a typical artist face, and I am glad to have seen both them and him. I went then with her to the W.O. buildings where she works and saw all over the busy beehive and at 1.0 we lunched at Stuarts. Then I fled home and immediately again rushed forth with Mother and H to the Palace Theatre where a huge meeting was held in aid of the building fund for the Star and Garter Home for totally disabled sailors and soldiers. it was a most interesting show. Lord Charles Beresford, Ben Tillett, Lady Betty Balfour, Miss Compton and others spoke each in their own way most excellently. The women of England have undertaken to collect £50,000 for the rebuilding of the old Star and Garter at Richmond to make a permanent home for the totally disabled, and i hope they'll raise it quickly. The thought of these helpless men with a future many of them of years of hopelessness in front of them makes one feel one cannot do enough.
(Betty Balfour was a Lytton - one sister, Constance, was a notable suffragette. Betty was not militant, but did support the movement. Lord Charles Beresford was a sort of caricature John Bull figure, wheeled out for these events. He was an Admiral and an MP, with a reputation as a ladies man - the Empress of Austria and the Duchess of Warwick being amongst his trophies. The Home was funded principally by the women of the Empire, who made it their lasting War Memorial).

March 25th
To the Stores shopping in the morning, to lunch at the Breeks, and I to tea with Mrs Parsons. She has a little house near here and is hard at work at munitions every day.

March 26th, Sunday
To St Mary Abbots in the morning with the family and after lunch to a delightful concert again at the Queens Hall. Wagner began it and a good deal of Tchaikovsky followed played by a man called Benno Moiseiwitsch, an expert quite and much applauded and it ended by "1812". The Concert began by the Russian national anthem, it is a most beautiful air. The organ accompanied today and all stood up and the same impressive scene occurred at the end for ours, which everyone sang
(Benno Moiseiwitsch, 1890 - 1963, was originally from the Ukraine and came to London in 1909. He became a British citizen in 1937, and was awarded the CBE in 1946 for his work during the Second World War. He specialised in the Romantic repertoire.)

March 27th
Fearing for sometime past that there was something wrong with Noots' eyes I took her off to the occulist and was very much relieved to find that they were quite sound, but she pokes over her books so we thought she was short-sighted. After lunch H and I set forth to Chislehurst to see Brenda and her crew. Jacky has been horribly ill but is better, the two smaller ones are sweet and look splendid.

March 28th
We saw a fine thing today, a big cinema show at Drury Lane called "The Birth of a Nation", viz. the American War. It was awfully well done, horribly pathetic and emotional but so interesting. The kind Duke lent us his box. H's orders came tonight, the 67th Division at Sevenoaks.

March 29th
Off to the dentist this morning, thank goodness I've fixed up for a while now again. After lunch Mother took us to see "Please Help Emily" at the Playhouse - Charles Hawtrey, Gladys Cooper and Lottie Venne - so amusing and clever and it was a real treat seeing a theatre again.

March 30th
I've been out all day, first for shopping, then to lunch with the dear Todds after which to Douglas to have my hair washed and then to tea with Muriel Kayvell.

March 31st, Friday
I and the two children have been at the Zoo all day long, my man was to have come too but he has an attack of shingles and so is keeping the house. It is most unfortunate for him coming now as of course he cannot join but I am only too thankful to keep him a little longer. Well we started forth at 10.30 taking sandwiches with us which at 1.0 we devoured with some drinks which we bought. We did the thing most thoroughly, and got hold of several keepers who took us behind the scenes and showed us various unseen animals which is always so interesting. The children also rode on elephants and camels and drove in the lama cart and we didn't get back till 6.30.

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. She was ill in February, and wrote nothing - the diary resumes in March with an account of her illness.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Dublin Rising of .

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 5th

The Irish Uprising in Dublin but secondary education for the children is uppermost in Wynne's mind.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Monday
Alas! the weather has changed and we have a typical May day, rather cold and grey. The papers are full of the Irish Rising and Easter Monday seems to have been the beginning. How awful it all is and all backed by Germany who has caught hold of the Sinn Feiners and duped them into expecting an armed force to come to their aid. Bloodshed and murder, wholesale looting and burning, and the whole of Dublin in an uproar. No communication with the country as they took possession of the Post Office and cut all the wires but each day the papers are able to tell a little more and troops are being poured in.

May 2nd
Here is a picture of what Dublin looks like, the "Rebellion" is practically at an end, the Rebel leaders have been caught and many rebels shipped over to England. I hope stern justice awaits the leaders, the rest are dupes. Martial law is proclaimed over the whole of Ireland and Sir John Maxwell is in command.

May 3rd
This morning Win, Charlie, Noot and I all cycled into Farnham to do various shoppings, after lunch for the last time I packed Win's box. She has been made Head of her House and Games Captain of the School, though a year younger than is usual and we are very proud of her, and I can't realize that this is her very last term. (Win was at Sherborne. Meanwhile Wynne's son was about to start at Wellington).

May 4th
I saw Win off at 10.24 and on this day my son began his public school career. We went by the 3.10 and on arrival were informed that as there was no vacancy in the Combermere he had been placed in the Lynedock - Herbert's old dorm. As this was quite by chance it seemed a good omen and I was so awfully pleased. We went at once to his Tutor who with his wife gave us a very pleasant welcome and tea, both young people and her Father was tutor of Lynedock in H's time, Airey by name. He then showed us the dormitory and Pink's room as for this term there is no vacancy and Pink and 3 others are living with the Tutor which is rather nice. We then betook ourselves to see the Master. We entered his mystic portals with faltering steps, and sat awaiting his awe-inspiring presence. When he arrived I humbly presented my little microbe and we both sat up on our hind legs, a pleasant and friendly man and Pinkie afterwards decided that he wasn't so bad as he expected! We then went off to the tailor to get his cap and ribbon which act made him a member of the School. Pink came to see me off and out of the train came young Lewis who had been at Southlea so they were able to trot back together. Dear Son, good luck go with you, its horrid being a Mother on these occasions.

May 5th
I feel utterly bereft without my two school children. Maby came home this evening and so term and regularity begin once more. I think I hate the end of the holidays just as much as they do. We hear that 3 Rebel Leaders have been tried and shot, not much delay about that, but Roger Casement the beast still lives. I heard from my dear Ell yesterday dated March 29th - very hard work chiefly patrolling and very hard on the horses but he was well, thank God. At last we are to have Compulsory Service - see cutting. At last it has come after nearly 2 years shilly shally. I fear Baker will have to go and his children are rather a problem. What times we live in.
(Wynne's attitude to the Irish uprising was probably very typical, especially from an army family during the war).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Conscription finally came in during , after a long debate. The need for men was so great that Parliament decided to make it compulsory for all males between the ages of 18 and 41.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 6th - 12th

Conscription and Daylight Saving - but domestic duties make Wynne keen to leave Aldershot.
viewer_4.description:
May 6th, Saturday
I have cut out this cutting and am rejoiced to think that this Bill stands a chance of being passed, it will be ripping and we shall save no end of lighting, it is splendid. (This refers to the Daylight Saving Bill, and you can see some of the cuttings further on in the view windows)
I am having such a clear out and change of servants, my Bessie after 9 years is leaving me as her Mother needs her at home, and Cathy is coming back as cook. Olive is leaving to do War work and Mrs Wynter's sister comes in her place and I have a new between maid also so all will be changed but I do hate changing after so long. Cathy comes on the 10th and Martha today.

May 7th
A cold grey day, alas where is our lovely hot weather, but this often happens in May, this Queen of Months in all other ways. I was so very pleased today to see Algie, he is in the 67th Western Scottish C.E.F. over at Bordon and came to lunch and tea. I was much interested to hear all his experiences which are many and varied. I walked down to the station with him across the Park which is looking its very best, but oh, how I die to quit this neighbourhood with its country which is no country and its horrible Aldershot which is no Town.

May 8th, Monday
I went to resume duty at the Hut today after an absence of about 3 and a half months it seemed so strange being there again and it was very empty, the 41st Division having left last week and none come in in its place. Mrs Doran was there and we had very little to do, how different from the old days when we were run off our feet, but I expect it will be busy again by the end of this week as several thousand are coming. I have heard from my blessed little son, he feels very strange and I fancy a bit lonely and I miss him most horribly but alas, it happen to us all and is the best thing for a boy. He'll soon settle down I expect and then of course he will love it all.

May 9th
Oh! it is cold again, much rain all day and a general air of dankness around. After lunch went to a meeting at the Vicarage on Parish matters.

May 10th
This day a huge fair was held in Farnham in aid of the Farmers Red Cross Fund and we went down in the afternoon. The crowds were enormous and it was very hot down there, the children went on the merry-go-round but there were too many smelling people!

May 11th
A day of gardening and there is lots to do at this time of year.

May 12th
Today to my great joy I got a letter and a wire from H saying he was coming home for the weekend. Its awfully ripping getting him back like this, and at 5.30 he arrived. I didn't tell the children of his coming and just sprung him upon them, much to their excitement. He is looking so very well, I don't think I have ever known him better and it is a joy to me. I have been gardening hard all day so as to look very tidy against his arrival.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
People clutched at many straws during the War - everything from the Angel of Mons to Spiritualism. This is just one example...which you will note Wynne endorses..."This is I believe quite true and a very wonderful thing."


The quote below the caption is out of a letter from the Front: "One curious thing which all of us have noticed is that in the midst of all this ruin and destruction of Churches the Sacred figure on the Crucifix is so seldom damaged."

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 13th - 20th

The clocks go back for the first time between May 20th and 21st....Wynne rejoices in the new experiment.
viewer_6.description:
May 13th, Saturday
An ideal day, so far as the Jackson family are concerned. H and I walked into Farnham in the morning and we gardened all the afternoon up to about 8.0, planting out a bed of stocks and asters amongst other things. Its a bit early but am hoping for good luck.

May 14th
The weather is not as kind as it might be, it is so cold we have got back to fires again in the evenings but 'twas ever thus in May. Poor Noots was hors de combat today and had to be withdrawn from church but I put her to bed with a large dose and she was better by evening. I think curry was the cause of it! No more curry!

May 15th
H went off by the early train, the family getting up to see him off. Alas how hateful is his going, I always feel so flat and dull when he is gone and so desolate but it is rot to talk like this in these days when no one has their men. I to the Hut today but it is so empty just now.

May 16th
Up at 5.30, a lovely morning, if it only lasts. My days pass now in gardening and chickening, interleaved with the Hut. I had supper with Stella and sat and worked afterwards till 10.0 when I dragged my sleepy bones to bed. One needs early to bed these days of early rising.

May 17th, Wednesday.
Lovely weather and very hot still. We had a lovely afternoon taking our tea away up into the fields and gathering heaps of bluebells for the Flower Mission. I set off ahead on my bicycle and Maby and the children followed after lessons, it was perfect up there, the only sounds being the endless song of reed warblers, an occasional cuckoo or pigeon, the lazy hum of insects and the distant voice of a ploughman. Through the air there floated the fluffy seed of some tree and not a leaf stirred but in these perilous and stricken days one almost feels out of tune with all this peace and quiet, one cannot imagine that the world at large is one restless state of toil and activity.

May 18th
Up again at 5.30, out into the perfect freshness of early morning, how I look forward to next week and the Daylight Saving Bill! I heard today at last the old Wow is dead. He died yesterday at 2.30, an end to a very unlovely life and peace will now come to Aimee I hope, what a fearful time it has been for her, poor thing. (The Wow was Aimee's second husband, and not the father of all the Fallowfield children. He was not very popular in the family).

May 19th
Continues glorious weather and very hot, and too hot to garden in the day time so I put in a lot of work before breakfast.

May 20th
I think a change is coming, the hills are clearer and the wind a little colder. Skippy came home on a week's leave today, it is so nice to hear a man's voice about! All clocks altered tonight.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: We are so used to the clocks changing that we do not consider it much, but for the generation living in this must have come as a bit of a shock!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 21st - 31st

After a visit to the Chelsea Flower show, Wynne receives news her brother is wounded. She now has to wait and pray - something "the women of this generation should know how to do".
viewer_8.description:
May 21st, Sunday
"Summer Time" has come into law at last. Last night upon going to bed the country put its clocks on 1 hour, it seemed like playing at charades! and this morning when we awoke we found we had dropped one hour's sleep! but I rejoice in the arrangement. I used hardly any artificial light this evening - I think its a lovely arrangement.

May 22nd
All thoughts of weather change has gone. The ground greatly wants rain and much watering has to be done. I am very busy gardening and there is much work on hand. To the Hut this evening but it is still very empty and the surrounding Barracks have not yet been filled. Mrs Perceval and I bicycled back by daylight.

May 23rd
