Bedding out day. I worked with Baker from 9.30 till his departure and then on to 8.30. This daylight arrangement is positively perfect and I never feel I want to go in.

May 24th, Wednesday
To Town today to the Chelsea Flower Show with Mother. A perfect day. I went up by the 7.57 and met her there at 10.0. She brought her chair and we wheeled her round in comfort as there was no crowd then. The show is much curtailed this year but very beautiful. I returned by the 5.30 with the Skippys and on arriving was rung up by Mother saying she had had a wire from the India Office to say our dear Ell was wounded on the 20th or 21st. We are in great anxiety.

May 25th
One wonders how one gets through these days of stress and anxiety. We cannot expect to hear of our Ell for some days, and one only can wait and pray - by the end of this War the women of this generation should know how to do both. One feels terribly helpless and the distance is so awful. I fill my days with as many jobs as I can and have today been rejoiced over a hen which has hatched 12 eggs out of 13.

May 26th
All signs of rain gone, the wind is rising and a change appears in the air but it is a long time coming. Maby went to the Hut for me today as I wasn't feeling very fit, but there was nothing doing.

May - 27th to 31st
All these days have been uneventful to me. I have nothing to record except the doings of garden and chickens, it seems so odd to me to be doing no War job at present but I'm not altogether sorry for the rest. I am going to take up the hospital depot work again soon, a mild form of work but better than doing nothing till our Hut opens again.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Meanwhile, theatres continued to operate - on the back of the article about the time changes were a lot of adverts for London shows, including this one for a film starring Sarah Bernhardt.

may.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The Irish Uprising, Daylight Saving and Conscription - the War is changing everything.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 8th

The freeze continues...as do the chores. Wynne entertains wounded soldiers from the local hospital.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Sunday
"Oh! to be in England
Now that April's there"
I don't think the poet would have envied us this year - for it's as cold as December and a wind that cuts you through. Its all utterly abominable and I've never lived through so long a winter, hardly any signs of life appear and we all freeze to the marrow.

April 2nd
A heavy fall of snow, several inches, but as the sun has some power it cant lie, thank goodness.

April 3rd
More snow and hail storms. Pink and Maggie came this evening. Oh! Glory be. Gertie is so very seedy that we have the Dr and I am not going to let her go tomorrow.

April 4th
Gertie is in bed and likely to stay there for the present poor girl. I do feel so sad for her. The Dr says it is rheumatism in a nerve and does her little good. I went off to Hospital today and found there a new cook, a nice girl of 25 and a lady, she hails from B. Columbia. More men arrived making a total of 21 now so she and I were busy.

April 5th, Thursday and April 6th, Good Friday
The weather was too vile to do much today, Thursday, and it rained and snowed at intervals. Friday we all went to Church at 11.0, then for a long ramble in the woods, home to tea and a little gardening and then again to Church at 7.30. I miss my man very much. We have never been separated before at Easter.

April 7th
Win's birthday and she is 18 today. It hardly seems possible to think it is 18 years since I first held her in my arms, an elongated grey worm of a baby, the first I had ever held! We had the men to tea as usual but alas! Win could not be there as she was unexpectedly called to Hospital, such a bore. Our activities have been unbounded this afternoon for at 2.15 Mr Love came down and we all set to and mowed and rolled the lawn but could not quite finish it and the men of course were a sad interruption, poor fellows. I had 3 crutches here today and one with one arm, so sad to see all this maimed humanity and they are so grateful for anything one does. Gertie is so bad still and has been in bed again all today, such pain and feeling so sick it seems an endless job.

April 8th - Easter Day
Very early this morning I arose to see the sunrise but being 5.30 he had already been up nearly 10 minutes. Summer time came in today but our Rector having decided not to alter the church clock we likewise have to wait till tomorrow. It began by being a most perfect day and Win and I went to 7.0 service, the 8.15 being choral which I dont care for. At 11.0 we all went to Mattins except Gertie and Win.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A Palestine that would be hard to recognise now?

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 9th - 14th

Winter continues but Wynne's blues are alleviated by the arrival of her husband on leave, and her sister-in-law.
viewer_4.description:
April 9th, Monday
A fine day on the whole but a high wind blowing and of course we've had snow again, it seems the natural thing for it to snow every day. I've been doing a day in bed, must be the fashion! and Win has been there all day long and so bad that I had Dr out to see her and he has given lead lotion, it's really rather a trial but I hope it will be better tomorrow. (Win had used an ointment given her by another Dr with the result that she had come out in severe exzema. )

April 10th
A most bitterly cold day, snow as usual and a biting wind. I was up the village all the morning on some business with Mrs Lowe about an agricultural hostel it is proposed to start here, and I didn't get back until 1.30! All afternoon it was too bitterly cold for words and poured with rain and snow at intervals so we didn't go out much but I did some work in the greenhouse.

April 11th
The very greatest news from the Front today, an enormous advance and since Monday over 11,000 prisoners and 100 guns captured. Its all too wonderful to believe, the papers are thrilling. (But Wynne's descriptions of the weather will give you some idea of what hell it must have been in the trenches early in 1917).
Today the whole family went out and planted potatoes but constantly we were driven in by snow and this even we had a heavy fall. I am expecting my dear man tomorrow and I do hope nothing will prevent him coming for I am wanting him very specially.

April 12th
It does not often come to me to give way to real blues but I've had two very depressed days and there has been sufficient cause for it but the coming of my dear man this day has cleared away the trouble and I am happy once more. He has till Tuesday when once again I shall be derelict, it is all too short, and one gets so weary marking time through all these wasted years. The news continues so good from France, the advance steadily goes forward and we are creeping nearer and nearer St Quentin, that scene of so much old world strife. Lens too is threatened and we hear whole battalions are giving themselves up.

April 13th
Nootie's birthday, and the dear child has entered her teens for she is 13 today. I am getting very old and were it not for these terrible times one would hang onto the coat tails of time but now one speeds it on its way and the sooner the months fly past the better pleased I am. Our dear Mabel came today and I sent my two daughters down to meet her. I am hoping she is coming for a long stay for her presence is to us all the very greatest joy. We are a large household now, 12 in fact, and its all so jolly.

April 14th
It is much warmer today but such perpetual rain and hail storms in spite of which M, H and I went off for a walk in the woods and stayed out all the afternoon. The rest of the day we just fossicked around and H did all sorts of useful things for me.

The POW postcard which you can see in the next window was sent form Philip Lyster, a prisoner who wrote often to Wynne. She stuck it in her diary on April 11th. This is the postmark on the address side:

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A heavily censored postcard from a prisoner in Germany, Philip Lyster. It reads:

Clausthal 21-2-
It was such a pleasure to get your letters of 7th and 21st, also the sweeties at Xmas time, ever so many thanks for them all. I can understand what a relief it must be to you to have your man at home again.....We are under snow since before Xmas and while the weather has been mostly fine its very cold - we have had it down to -10°F or 42° of frost. Sometimes we go out for a short walk which relieves the monotony of the camp. We have an ADS which gave "Charlie's Aunt" on 13/1, the French also have done a play.....I"m rather worried about my head and eyes, they dont seem to improve. I cant do any work without suffering from intense headache - I can stick out this summer.....I wish I could tell you everything, Mother is so nervous I have to be careful what I say - Write when you can and cheer me up - may all continue to go well with you.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 15th - 22nd

Wynne's husband leaves again but the weather improves enough for walks and gardening to be enjoyed.
viewer_6.description:
April 15th, Sunday
Mabel, H and I went to Early Service this morning, it was very good to get the opportunity of being all together again, and then we went to Mattins which Mr Burns took.

April 16th
We ventured to do some gardening today but the weather was vile and bitterly cold. Today the Pardoes came to tea - old Mrs P and her daughter Mrs Halliday. An extraordinary little woman, the latter smokes 40 cigarettes a day and reads novels and that's all, and consequently she looks more dead than alive. Mr Love came to dinner and we spent a hilarious evening playing games and ragging the latter to such an extent that H ended by collapsing on the floor!

April 17th
My dear man left today, and Oh! what a blank it leaves. I miss him so dreadfully, but I am thankful he has been, as I had wanted him more than usual this time, and he has left my mind in a blessed peace.

April 18th
My day was spent as usual at the Hospital today, revelling in the effluvia of the sink! and as there were one or two extra jobs to do I was home rather late.

April 19th
A high wind blowing and I had to bicycle to the Swabys to tea. It was a lovely day but coming home I was nearly dead battling against the awful wind.

April 20th
I've felt positively hot all day long, its been perfect. We gardened all the morning planting out sweet peas.

April 21st, Saturday
My Saturday's programme is always much the same. I always go to Hospital on that day now and the men generally come down to tea. They seem to enjoy it and are very easily amused. It is about the only piece of War Work I can do, besides my kitchen work up there.

April 22nd
We went off for a long long walk today. We went across the fields to Castle Hill, up Liddons and through the woods along Strain Hill to the far Keeper's house, there we found white violets and primroses and came back ladened with flowers. It was a long toil but such a joy and it's just glorious having weather which makes such things possible again.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Britain was very slow to understand about rationing in the First World War - in 1939 the Government acted immediately, with the result that a much fairer situation existed. This is the royal proclamation - appeals to economise were sent out to every household. At the bottom of this page, you can also read about a little historical footnote when Queen Victoria decided to do the same!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 23rd - 30th

Good weather enables the family to enjoy the countryside...when Wynne is not slaving over a greasy sink.
viewer_8.description:
April 23rd, Monday
This being St George's Day there used to take place here an annual Fair where sheep and cattle were sold, and merry go rounds, shooting galleries and the like all did business. The children in hopes all went up armed with pennies and found there only one old man with a sweetie stall, all that remained of an erstwhile Fair! Mabel and I gardened.

April 24th
Our lovely weather has come to stay and goes on day after day. No one can know how one appreciates the sun after an 8 months winter such as we've had.

April 25th
To Hospital, a hot and weary job today. Pots and pans and greazy (sic) sinks have nothing to recommend them on a hot day, but Holsworth by mistake turned up as well so we got finished in double quick time, much to my relief.

April 26th
Our kind friend Mr Love came to mow the lawn today. It is a most enormous help as until we get an arrangement for a horse it is such a labour but he is so strong. He rushes up and down and wields the machine as though it were a feather. He stayed on to supper and we played many silly games afterwards. We have come to look on this man as the tame house cat, he comes in and out at will, the children love him, and there is something particularly nice about his way with them.

April 27th
Win and I rode up to the Husseys to tea today. It is a big pull up Liddons and we nearly died in the effort. They have an enormous house up there, it is execrable taste and looks like a large railway station or lunatic asylum and has a most perfect view. They appear quite nice and most hospitable but I don't know how they made their money.

April 30th, Saturday
This is the last day of this month of months. Alas the Spring comes but once a year and is so soon over, the latter part of this April has been lovely and one has appreciated it after winter. We all walked over to Dinnington today to show it to Mabel, and everything is just coming out as the season is so very late.

april.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The terrible winter of finally draws to a close, and Wynne's mood lightens with the arrival of her husband.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is recycling, WW1 style! The envelope has been made by disabled soldiers out of an old edition of The Queen, a "lady's newspaper". It has a gummed flap, and a clear address label, making the whole quite thick.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 28th

It has been so wet that they have been imprisoned in the house for much of the time. Wynne has found diary keeping tedious.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st - 26th
I have written nothing all this month because it has passed in one long torrent of rain and howling gales. We have literally been almost prisoners and have only had 2 fine days in all the time, so what is the use of making a record of the period of flood. On Thursday 9th Poggy came down bringing with him Pinkie and Charlie de M, and P left again upon the Monday. On Tuesday 14th Mother and I went up to tea at the Pouletts as I so wanted her to see the house and lovely saloon. On Tuesday last being one of the fine days we all went off for the day to Charmouth taking the Squire with us. It was a complete success. We all bathed and disported ourselves upon the beach in a very free and easy way! and we didn't get home until 10.0. The next day I went on duty at the Hospital and Win and the girls went to the Blakes. Thursday Pink and I rode over to the Haywards in a perfect gale of wind and there Pink revelled with Mr H for hours over bugs.
On Friday Win and I were summoned to Hospital where we alone cooked dinner for 32 people!! quite an achievement and I think the Commandant was most trusting but all went well. In the evening my man came home intending to stay till tonight but received a wire recalling him to Salisbury so he left yesterday alas. He brought with him a gun for Pink, a beautiful little double-barrelled gun and yesterday evening he made his first bag, 4 sparrows and a rabbit, a red letter day in his life! Today the rain has reached a climax, it is simply torrential and has never ceased since early morning. I cant go to Church, its too awful.

August 27th, Monday
There has been nothing to record today except torrents. All day long it was gloomy and dark and at night a regular hurricane blew.

August 28th
Again we have been compelled to stay in the house all day and today I am thinking much of my poor Jackdaw who is undergoing his final exam. I am holding thumbs and do so hope all will go well. I am thinking too of H who is inspecting shooting on the Plain in all this torrential rain. I am expecting both at the end of the week.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Two photos of the family with R.D.Whitehead, whom Wynne had befriended and who she visited in Bristol in July. Below, in the first, from left to right: Eleanore (Baby), Thomas (Pink), Win (standing), RDW, and Ysobel (Nootie).

In the picture below, they are now dressed up for some charade - poor little sweeps? Wynne's comment in the margin is simply: "Mad".

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 29th - 31st

Both husband and Wynne's young officer friend arrive to stay. Herbert is about to finally be discharged, while young Whitehead has just passed his officer's exam.
viewer_4.description:
August 29th, Wednesday
The day began by being as usual wet and gloomy but now this evening it has turned into a fine clear evening, a high wind still but it is so blessed to see the sun again. I've actually been doing some gardening and now I must go to bathe and get away from chicken house aromas for I've been clearing them out.

August 30th
To our joy my man came down today again for a long weekend and hopes to stay till Monday when he returns to the Plain. I take it that this will be his last work there for he is down to be discharged with a lot of other time expired men and I am expecting him home quite shortly. How strange it seems that his long service is nearly over. 39 years of soldiering and now all is at an end. I feel for him as its always horrible when such a thing comes to an end, but secretly in my heart I rejoice to think that I shall have him always here. I simply cant believe it, its been such a dreadful long time of waiting these 3 long years, and how splendid to have him alive at all and to think he's come through it all.

August 31st
A wire from the Jackdaw saying that he would arrive at Ilminster at 1.45 so
I arranged for Cathy to finish up my Hospital work in order to go and meet him but a muddle was made of the car so I didn't go. Well, he arrived nevertheless and I am overjoyed to find he has passed his exam and in A section too. I am so glad and proud especially as he's been nearly three years in the ranks as well. Poor Jackdaw very embarrassed at Herbert's presence and I must say it is rather a trying experience but very good for the lambs general welfare to lie down with the lion!
We are a household of 12 now and it keeps me busy looking after all their numerous wants.

august.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

August proves a wash-out, and Wynne finds little to say.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Below are examples of three letters from this month - the first with its post mark advertising War Bonds, which Wynne clearly thought most unusual! Then a second one, using an economy label for re-use (shades of our own green times?), and finally a fascinating one for her brother that had been redirected many times after he was invalided back to England. You can see the front and back of this envelope.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 3rd - 14th

War news is not good. Wynne does her local chores, then goes to London via Portsmouth, where she sees her shell-shocked friend
viewer_2.description:
December 3rd, Monday
I shall not regret missing out several days these times as I cannot write long pages about nothing. The War goes on as usual and as far as I can see its never going to end. The news is none too good, the Germans who seem to be as numerous as fleas over run all parts of the earth and Russia is entirely mad and Oh! how sick to death one is of the whole thing. I had to attend a decayed Infant Welfare Meeting this afternoon at which old Lowey, old Nick and I weighed babies and then I went on to Hospital to play Bridge.

December 4th
All day I laboured in our cabbage plot.

December 5th
I bicycled over to lunch at the Rawlins today. They are Behar people and he has retired and bought this place. I'm glad we haven't bought ours. A nicer house or prettier country I shall never find but I do so dislike many of the people who live in this village, disgusting gossips and such outsiders. I've never met such an odd collection before but I suppose its the same in every little country place.

December 9th, Sunday
To Kirk as usual where our worthy vicar held forth in his usual meaningless way . I have a fit of sort of blues tonight and so I had better not write any more!

December 13th
The past 3 days have gone by occupied in their usual way and there has been nothing to relate. Today by the 8.28 I left home to spend the weekend in Town, taking Portsmouth on the way for I was anxious to see my young Jackdaw who is there in hospital. He met me at the station looking well but still has in him the results of shell shock, a most horrible thing. We drove to the Hotel where he had got me a room and then walked on to the Pier and then to tea at a Cafe where swarmed dozens of young officers and their ladies. We then went to see his hospital, a vast place, a portion of the huge Workhouse converted into a hospital for officers and men. After this we retuned to the hotel stopping on the way to watch the searchlights and planes in the harbour, a most wonderful sight. 9 and 10 lights working at the same time. After an early dinner we went to the Hippo. and saw Seymour Hicks in a sort of scramble and laughed much. Tried to buy chocolate and were told none could be sold after 9.0!

December 14th
I left by an early train and spent the whole day shopping wildly. It is a scramble these days - scanty counters, masses of people and hardly anyone to sell. At 6.0 I turned up at the flat and found Mother busy playing Bridge so wrote letters till Ell came in.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne stuck these adverts from Harrods into the back of her diary. They show how things have changed - it would not have entered the head of a young lady shopping at this store in 1914 to work on the land!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 15th

A description of the Choral Commemoration of the work of the First Seven Divisions, held at the Albert Hall in the presence of the King and Queen.
viewer_4.description:
December 15th, Saturday
My chief reason for coming to Town this week end was to attend the Choral commemoration of the First Seven Divisions at the Albert Hall today, and I wish my words were adequate to describe so impressive and beautiful a ceremony. I went first this morning to meet Pink at Charing Cross and took the young shaver home and he went in the afternoon to see a cinema with Ell. I at 2.0 went to the Hall but unfortunately so great had been the demand for seats that we could only get two and those not even being together Poggy didn't come up, therefore I went alone. Arriving in good time I found my stall and met around me many old friends, and gradually that vast place was filled from arena to gallery with one closely packed sea of faces. Round the centre in the boxes sat 700 of the available survivors of the "Mighty Little Force" who had previously lunched with the Lord Mayor and processed in cars through the city, and in the Royal Box were the King and Queen and royal party. At one end the huge organ was packed on either side by the men and women of the Bach choir whilst below Allen and his immense orchestra sat waiting. When all was ready in absolute silence Allen raised his baton for the opening piece, a joyous intimation of what London was like before the War, followed by various items on the enclosed programme some of which were above the heads of the soldier audience, but I loved it all. About midway Mr Balfour read that most wonderful and appropriate chapter out of Ecclesiasticus in memory of the dead and then the Roll Call of every regiment in the Seven divisions was called by Lord Derby. As each pathetic group of men heard its regiment called long cheers echoed up into the roof of that huge building, a great outburst greeted the mention of the R.A.M.C and loud ones of derision arose when the list was completed by the A.P.D! (A.P.D. = Army Pay Department). The King then called for Three Cheers and the ceremony was over. On leaving the Hall I met our dear old friend General Sandilands, it was like a bolt from the blue and we walked to a tea shop in the neighbourhood where we talked over old friends and old times and I heard all his news and a history of his wanderings since we last met in the days of Aldershot. So ended a very wonderful experience. I am forgetting to mention the blaze of colours made by the regimental banners which were hung round the Hall which many of us women helped to make, and I shall always feels proud to think that the 12th Battery in which dear little Fatty Lee was, was the work of my blundering fingers. All our banners, the R.As, are going to be hung in the Garrison Church at Woolwich, a most fitting destination. Also there were hung around the Hall huge laurel wreaths sent in memory of those who have gone west, and very pathetic it was to see one or two tiny ones amongst the larger tributes, all emblems of a great love and great sorrow. The hymn "For All the Saints" was sung by the whole audience and it was most terribly upsetting. One felt that the spirits of all our dear men were very close, and I am convinced that they are always with us.
This evening which was most cheering Ell took Pink and me to see Chu Chin Chow at His Majesty's, a wonderfully staged sort of pantomime.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Alongside many women, Wynne worked one of the banners that were to hang at the Albert Hall for the commemoration of the exploits of the first 7 Divisions in 1914. Below is her banner, and also samples of the cloth used, from the royal School of Art Needlework in Exhibition Road.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 17th - 24th

The run-up to Christmas is made more difficult by an absent servant - Cathy's sister is killed in an accident and she has to rush home.
viewer_6.description:
December 17th, Monday
Pink and I went off to the Stores to do more shopping, such a Babel and Bedlam, and returned to a hurried lunch and caught the 3.35 and arrived at 7.4 found all well at home and a great welcome. Ell went off to his club and goes up to Scotland shooting before he comes to us at Xmas.

December 18th
I have had a severe reverse today, poor Cathy has had news that a sister has been killed in a bicycle accident and is off home at once. I in consequence must do the cooking, it is rather an undertaking for 12 people!

December 19th
There is much to be done these strenuous days, all morning I have cooked and after lunch put in some work in the plot to get a little fresh air.

December 21st, Friday
I have been far too busy making messes for my household to eat to think of writing diaries. Today my dear man came home, and almost for good, he just has to return to hand over and then I shall have him for always, God bless him.

December 22nd
I flew off to Hospital having left Florrie in charge of food, did my jobs there and rushed home. Life is composed of rushing these days.

December 23rd
All to Kirk in the morning, and after lunch we got out all the Xmas tree things and tied on their strings and saw to all their hangings, having found our old lot which we lost last year. We shall have a fine display this time.

December 24th
I have seldom if ever spent a more busy and harassing day! for I got a wire from Cathy asking if she could stay away over Xmas because her brother is coming home. I nearly had a fit, indeed I had one, for here I am with all to do myself. Well there was no getting her so I just cooked and decorated and fussed. In the evening Ell arrived.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The Choral Commemoration Programme - held at the Albert Hall.

(Note the Air Raid warning at the bottom of this page!)

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 25th - 31st

Christmas is celebrated, and then Cathy returns. Wynne's husband puts on his uniform for dinner for the last time, having finally retired from the Army (for the second time).
viewer_8.description:
December 25th. Xmas Day
I usually deck this page out with all sorts of decorations but I'm not inspired this year. I've had such a frantically busy day that there's been no room for frills. Of course its been the joy of my life having my Ell here as it must be quite 22 years since he spent an Xmas at home, but its all been rather more of a toil that a pleasure in consequence of Cathy's absence, so important is a cook's presence in the house! We went to Church, all of us except Mother of course who cannot get, and Florrie managed the lunch very well. Then we decorated the tree and carted in all the presents into the schoolroom, had tea and at 5.30 all trooped in and we had the usual distribution and all very gay. The War certainly made no difference to the children I think they had more things than ever and thoroughly enjoyed themselves. Early this morning they came in with their stockings and emptied the contents on to our beds and all seemed very pleased. It would all have been perfect in spite of things if I had been a free agent but there was too much anxiety on my mind to enjoy myself over much. However nothing lasts for ever and in two days I fancy my responsibilities should cease.

December 26th
We spent a good part of it laying the new brick edging in the garden but it was very cold and not very enjoyable. I wish I could have Ell with us for weeks, he's awfully good on odd jobs and quite keen and its all so jolly working together.

December 27th
Poggy went off today back to Norwich to hand over to Gen Nicholson and hopes to return on Sat. Then his time will be up for good, how strange it seems. I simply cannot realise it.

December 28th
At about 2.30 today came back Cathy and so with joy I handed over the reins of office. Spent the whole afternoon with the two Elliots sifting the Ash Heap! We put up a cinder screen and made a large heap of ashes in one place and another of cinders, another of rubbish which we burnt and then collected the pots and pans in large sacks and stuffed them down the rabbit holes! and so a good job is in progress for we shall use all the cinders for burning and the ashes for paths, besides which the pit is clearer and all labour voluntary! But it is strange what ones fancy will lead one to do. We'll be cleaning out the sewers next!

December 29th
I am unfortunately in bed today alas. Poggy returned tonight and when he dressed for dinner he doffed his uniform for the last time and I am quite sad.

December 30th
Poggy took the kids to church and Mother, Ell and I were heathens. After lunch we made jigsaw puzzles. Every evening the family assembles and plays games of sorts, and this being Sunday and cards being debarred we turned to other frivolities.

December 31st
The last day of this year. It is with few regrets that I see it go. It has brought me some good things and times I shall never forget but having a 7 in it, it was bound to do that because everything of interest that has happened to me has had a 7 in it.
We all sat up to see the New Year in, even my Baby. At dinner we drank healths and thought of all those absent ones who we love and after dinner we four elders played Bridge whilst in the corner the children shrieked over other games. At 12 we opened the window to let in 1918 and sang Auld Lang Syne and at about 12.45 we all retired to bed and so goodbye my Diary.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Christmas Cards that came in . The brown one is from the 17th Division, and contains a poem in it:

"No Night, without a sun to end it/ No tear, but there's a peace will mend it/No Right, unless a man defend it/No cheer, if there's no means to send it."

The other card is from the No 8 Veterinary Hospital, and came from Staff Sergeant M Sinnott, who had worked with Herbert and Wynne as their groom before the war. There are various sites you can find that cover this activity. The poor horses had a hard time of it in World War 1.

december.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The run-up to Christmas includes the great choral celebration of the first Seven Divisions in 1914, held at the Albert Hall.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 7th

Ice skaing and sloe gin - the more pleasant accompaniments to a freezing month.
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Thursday
(but started Feb 5th, Monday)
The beginning of another month, thank goodness Jan with its icey (sic) wind and hideous cold is over but the latter is still with us and its almost too cold to breath. Still there is always balm in Gilead for on Saturday "The Loved One" rang me up and asked me to go skating with him on a pond near Furlands Farm. Skating! the very word sounds magic to me - it is so long since I had the joy and we motored round there and plunged about till 4.0. I was awfully shaky and came a lovely cropper (so did he) and we planned to go to Chard on Sunday but alas the snow came down so thickly in the middle of the day that we had to give it up and I was awfully disappointed. Today, Monday, we all went to the Pond again which I and Davis brushed this morning but the snow had greatly spoilt it and it was awfully rough. However tomorrow with any luck we are going to Chard. Hurrah! I am longing for a good long stretch. And whilst I try to keep the cold out of my limbs by this simple and uncommon joy, the most untoward happenings are taking place, for Germany has declared universal submarine warfare against Allies and Neutrals combined, against armed and unarmed vessels and hospital ships included. It is the tactics of a wolf at bay, and is I verily believe her last stroke. And now in today's paper America has at last got upon her high horse and negotiations are broken off between them. Whether it means war one cannot tell but it looks precious like it.

February 6th
The intense frost still holding up Mr Love rang me up last night and asked me to go skating with him today to Chard and so hiring a car as he feared his own might not get there we accordingly set forth at 2.0. It was a brilliant day, windless and sunny. On the way the car bucked twice but eventually we turned up to find an enormous sheet of what had been perfect ice, but Sunday snow lay thick upon it and we could only struggle round and round upon some alleys which a gang of sweepers had cleared. At 4.0 we felt we had had enough and so retired to the bank where we drank sloe gin and then walked into Chard to have some tea. The car meanwhile had gone to a garage to have its innards looked to and we had tea and waited for it. Well, hour after hour went by and still no car so Mr L went down to ascertain what was up and found that it refused to go at all so had to hire another and we eventually got back at 8.0 but it was lovely out: a brilliant moon and a complete absence of wind and if the ice had been possible I should not have wanted to come home even then.

February 7th
My beloved Baby's birthday but she is a baby no longer for today she is 9 years old, the dearest and sweetest child, so good, so pretty and so absolutely perfect in my eyes. She is just like a perky little bird and has robin's eyes. We hid her presents in the dining room according to time honoured custom and the robin's eyes positively glistened with beady excitement. I had to be at Hospital all day at kitchen work but we had a big iced birthday cake and games afterwards. Poor kids there are never any very special birthday treats now-a-days.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne's ideal man - which she appears to have cut from a publication called Books of Today and Tomorrow.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 8th - 14th

Freezing weather continues. News of Germany's decision for submarine warfare on all shipping. Allies await American decision after it breaks off diplomatic relations.
viewer_4.description:
February 8th, Thursday
What extraordinary weather it is, day after day the cold continues and holds us in its grip. In the Midlands on Sunday there were 38% of frost, on Monday 34 and on Tuesday the thermometer went to zero. It hasn't been as bad as that here but enough to apparently kill everything in the garden and the snow lies everywhere. Win and I went over and called on the Cheshires today and the Rawlins and found them both out. We had a lovely ride but the roads were awful, for all along they were covered with inches of frozen snow that was like hard mud in cakes and the going in consequence was very heavy. The papers are still all agog as to what is to happen with America. Neutrals have not followed the President's lead in breaking off negotiations with Germany and things still hang in the balance. The U Boat policy has started in earnest and every day we see "13 ships sunk", "11 ships sunk" and so on, and the wretched Neutrals have to put up with it. Three great questions are toward with us: the War Loan, the Rationing problem and the National Service. They are all voluntary so far but the Times says if the country does not take them up they will be forced to in each case, and really things are getting very serious. The Rations fixed for the country are 4lbs Bread per week, 2½lbs of meat and ¾lb sugar and I have calculated that we are very nearly with the limit all round.

February 12th
Three more days of lovely skating and how we have enjoyed it but today there are signs of a thaw and I fear we shall get no more. Tomorrow I am going out with Mrs Lowe on a prowl to visit some farmers' wives at Dinnington and Wed. I'm on duty at the Hospital so by Thursday its sure to be all over. Today the paper tells of another large liner sunk, a B.I. boat going to India but all lives were saved except a few of the crew. The Times from today is to cost 2d with a further possible rise to 3d and perhaps 7d - it will have to be given up in that event and what shall we do.

February 13th, Tuesday
I much enjoyed my prowl with Mrs Lowe today, a real country ramble. We started at 2.15 and the day was perfect, very bright sunshine and quite warm. She takes very small quick steps but walks about 1 mile an hour so our progress was slow but all the way she talked on and on in her endless and oddly breathless way telling me long interesting histories about all the neighbouring families, every detail of which she knew by heart.
We went to see several of the farmers' wives, such nice friendly folk, real old Yeoman stock, so well mannered. At one place, old Mrs Tozer's, Pink went with Dinnett on a mole catching expedition and they gave them lunch, refusing payment and Mrs Tozer told me she hoped he would come again. We returned in a leisurely way to tea and after tea being a lovely evening I didn't return home directly..

February 14th
This is my day at the Hospital. I work there every Wednesday in the kitchen and its one of the dirtiest jobs I know. The sink is out of order so one cannot use it at all and the only tap therefore (cold) is useless. All the water, hot and cold, has to be brought from the mens' bathroom miles away and all the dirty swill is thrown down a drain in the courtyard. Holsworth and I were alone today and had to provide for over 30 people. Its no loitering job but we got on splendidly, the cooking part I enjoy and I shouldn't mind the washing up if it were not for such a lack of water. Also Mrs Lowe provides nothing in the way of brushes, vim, mops or such like and so I take my own. I didn't get away till past 4.0 today as one has to leave everything tidy.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The letter below, from Philip Lyster, a prisoner in Germany since Mons in 1914, was written in 1916. Wynne has stuck it into her diary in February . Philip shared a room with two others, and the photo above shows his confinement to be relatively comfortable.

A day's existence - Up about 8.15, bath, dress and prepare breakfast. Roll Call on Monday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday at 9.30. Other days known as "Bath Days" at 12 o'c. On these days parties go down to a mine about half a mile away for a hot bath. British and French on Tuesday, Belgians on Wednesday, Russians Thursday. After breakfast generally a short walk round the grounds! and then play about with our gardens till 12 when the papers come in and are read by someone who knows a little German. This with the discussion which usually follow and the reading of any letters which may have come in takes us up to dinner time, 1 o'c. The Allies are always in their places early but as we mostly meal off our parcels we turn up at any time up to 1.30. By 2.15 it is all over and some lie down, others walk, read or garden. Lately we have had the tennis court we are making to accupy a good deal of our time and then there is always our squash court tho' I have had to give up long ago. 4.30 we make tea, amuse ourselves as best we can till 7, when we begin to prepare supper. I play bridge from 8.15 to ten broken by roll call at 9 after which we are confined to the house. Smoke, chat or read till 11 o'c when lights are put out and so ends another dull and weary day! For feeding purposes we divide ourselves into messes. I work with Majors Tweedie (R.Scots) and McCuaig (Canadians). Glad to hear your news of the General and a letter from you is never superfluous. P. 15/6/16

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 15th - 19th

Spring suddenly arrives...as does advice on food economy in wartime. Wynne subscribes to the War Loan.
viewer_6.description:
February 15th, Thursday
It has been a particularly lovely day today and directly after lunch we all set off walking, Miss H and the children to the woods, and Win and I across the fields to Seavington to call on Mrs Hole, a nice lady who we found at home. We did not know the way so just went rambling on, halfway there we met an old hedger at his work and asked the way of him, he gave some vague directions which we failed to follow, but found our way eventually. The more I ramble through this country the more fascinated I am by it.

February 16th
Win is at Hospital today and so I rode over to North Perrott to answer a call on the Dashwoods and found them out. It is a long way and I always seem to be going over there to answer calls, so many people have called and I never seem to get to the end of them.

February 17th, Saturday
February is an extraordinary month, a month of surprizes. Last week we were in the grip of the hardest weather we have known for years, and today it has been like April. Feeling the Spring in the air and in our bones we all set forth for the woods, and Oh! the loveliness of it all. The sun, the pale Spring sunlight that I love so much was streaming slantwise through the trees, casting flecky shadows eveyrwhere and glistening on the wet grey green trunks of beeches and the red rough stems of large firs. The larches shone bright gold against a very blue sky and all was very peaceful and remote. Two days before the children found one or two primroses out in bloom most wonderful to relate, and today all the earth smelt strong of coming Spring. How I do love it all, but alas, how incongruous it is in these sad and evil days.

February 19th, Monday
Yesterday, feeling a worm and no man I stayed in bed, wrote letters and read Macaulay's Essays with keen interest and felt thoroughly ashamed of myself that never before had I realized how interesting they were.
Poggy sent me today two pamphlets on Food Economy in War Time - both most interesting and having read them very attentively my mind is now full of "Protein and Calories", every mouth is now full of food economy and it is a complicated affair. I cant say that actual want is experienced among anyone I've met, still we are all "doing without" very many things we never thought about before the War. The big Loan has just closed and apparently it has been a great success. We personally have put all we could into it and have taken up a good deal of New Money which has got to be worked off somehow!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The Times increased its price to 2d, which received a great deal of publciity...this was from Books of Today, and you can read about it in the March 2nd entry.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 20th - 28th

Much planting and gardening. Lloyd George and Carson both praised for recent speeches.
viewer_8.description:
February 20th, Tuesday
A most lovely day but I've been rather decayed for a day or two and so I took it easy and didn't do much. I was pining to go and garden but just felt as though I couldn't!

February 21st
I went to Hospital today and did the usual chores. I got away about 3.30 and went to give a message about the men on Sat to Mr Love who is kindly going to fetch Paddy for me. We walked round his dear little garden, it is an ideal spot and oh! it makes me sick with my hideous one. As time goes on I must try and make it look less flat but his wee place just breathes old world and I wish I could go and work in it! I stayed and had tea with him and we talked the philosophy of the hour. How is it that so kind and gentle a man has escaped ensaring!

February 22nd
Today came a consignment of roses from Bees and as the frost was quite out of the ground I planted them all and put down the few I had from Smith too. Win came and assisted and we have the long bed nearly full now.

February 23rd


It actually rained today, the first time for weeks, it seemed quite odd to see it coming down. I put in a lot of work sowing seeds and repotting in the green house. This PC is one of a room in an old house at Norwich which H sent me and I put it in here because of the extraordinary likeness to the Springfield rooms. He said he was so struck by it.

February 24th
I have been much interested in some recent speeches in the House by LG and Carson. The former on National Economy and food, the latter on the Navy Estimates. Most wonderful they were and one felt on reading them that at last the country had men who would tell them the truth, but things are getting very acute indeed and I feel that compulsory rations will undoubtedly come into force before very long. Truly the times are evil.

February 26th, Monday
Today we sowed the first peas in the open. I also painted frames, put my autumn snout peas in the cold frame and pricked out lettuce! This is not a gardener's diary, but nowadays I'm nothing if not a labourer and its all very interesting.

February 27th and 28th
On Tuesday, that was yesterday, I sowed first Broad Beans. A lovely Spring like day. The last of February I spent a greater part in Hospital and there found both Holdsworth and Chadwick absent so had to manage with the Riddles cook, she was very capable and we got on splendidly but its pretty hard work for two. I afterwards refreshed myself by going to inspect Mr Love's garden and having tea with him. I love his little house and garden, both are utterly unique, such a sense of old world feeling about it.

february.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The freeze continues - Germany declares unrestricted submarine warfare - food economy looms.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The title page of Wynne's new diary for - note the ghosts rising from the graves on the right to urge the men on....

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 6th

A New Year and a new home means chores, gardening and mole catchers.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Monday
Last night having seen all the others to bed I slipped back and sat the old year out by myself. It was not an amusing occupation, being so full of association, but I determined to let the New Year into the house this being our first in our new home which we hope will be our home for many a long year. (Wynne has added in pencil in the margin here, "Thankful gratitude it was not." 1922!)
There was a certain amount of satisfaction in saying goodbye for ever to 1916, it has been a wretched year and I would not have one day of it back, not one day. This year has come in mild and warm and it is such a blessing being able to live again after our most fearful spell of cold. Mother and I went motoring this afternoon and paid a lot of calls.

January 2nd
Today is dear Eve's birthday, many happy returns. It is many years since we were together for this day. We have had 4 of the men from Hospital to tea today, Walton, Skinner, Clayton and Dukes. They are a nice lot and very easily amused, and on Friday I think we have four more.
My Pink was very sick all last night, I suppose something had disagreed with him for he was very bad and I kept him in bed till about tea time when he arose and was better. I've just been doing high executioner - the lady mouse had 10 babies the other day and so I've just drowned 6! I hated doing it! but it was too many for her and they would have exhausted the poor little creature. Truly a mouse is a strange thing, for one month ago she had seven and when they were 10 days old she deserted them.

January 3rd, Wednesday
All this morning I have been writing letters, mail day, also doing accounts, paying books etc till I felt "fair furbed up" and had to go out and get a blow. To tea came Mrs Love who stayed to supper and we played wild games of Pug and Giggypeg and Up Jenkins.

January 4th
Its been such a lovely day and I've done a bit of gardening with Davis and Pinkie. There is such a lot to do and so little time ever to do it in. Mother heard from Ell today, he says he is really better. I do trust he will keep so now.

January 5th
After several very mild days we had a frost again this morning, it always seems to come with the full moon, but it was only slight and we gardened all day and have now finished clearing up every border in the garden. (She then describes shrubs and other plants she is expecting to be delivered).

January 6th
This morning I cleaned chicken houses, an occupation I love! and this afternoon I tried to peg out a kidney shaped bed for my coming flowering shrubs, but cannot get it to my liking. I made also the acquaintance of Dinnet the mole catcher, a very interesting type of a profession now nearly died out. He is coming to catch moles for me on Monday and I am going out to watch operations.

(The illustrations on this page are hand-painted cards done by Wynne's daughters for New Year)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Views of Hinton St George in Somerset that Wynne stuck into her diary.

Church and Rectory, and the home of the Poulett family as it was in . Below, the Cross and Sunnyside.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 7th - 19th

The weather gets worse, 6 moles are caught and both her son and Mother depart.
viewer_4.description:
January 7th, Sunday
This day passed uneventfully. I like Sundays though as when one works pretty hard all the week one is glad to rest. Win was at Hospital all day, she has been there for the last three days and as she is going to Bath on Monday for a week we get little of her company.

January 8th
Job Dinnett the mole catcher came today and set his traps. I went out with him and a most awful snowstorm came on, it was freezing and I nearly died of cold. I took the children up to tea with Mr Love today, he gave us a royal repast and we played games till 7.0! all having enjoyed ourselves very much and he walked back with us.

January 9th
The vilest and most freezing day blowing a hurricane but in spite of most inclement weather Pink and I dug away at the new bed we are making for the flowering shrubs. It was very hard work and we couldn't do much.

January 10th
Dinnett has caught six moles here, we should get rid of them soon at this rate. Pink went off with him and they had lunch at a farm away near Dinnington. I took the children to a party today to the Symons. The kind people sent their car for us and brought us home again, most awfully polite I thought it. There were a lot of children there and in spite of many grumblings I think my two microbes quite enjoyed themselves but how they hate going to parties.

January 11th, Thursday to January 19th, Friday
An uneventful week has passed and I foresee many others to follow. I also foresee that my efforts to write a Diary will be very spasmodic! I am feeling bereft this evening as both Mother and Pinkie have left and I do miss them both so much. My little son is such a companion, he is always about with me doing jobs and is of the utmost help, besides its such a joy having someone to work with instead of always doing so alone. I have a probable prospect, a great joy in front of me. Am trying to arrange with my dear B to come and be governess to my babies and I am hoping she will consent. I should enjoy it so very very much, it would be such an enormous pleasure to have her under the same roof again and would seem just like old times.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A beautifully pencil-written card from a prisoner of war....the stamp is in the strip you navigated from. The prisoner in question was Philip Lyster, and there is a longer letter from him in February.

CLAUSTHAL
I hope this may arrive in time to wish you all and your belongings a very very happy Xmas and all possible good things in . May all your wishes come true and more! Time with us has gone slowly of late and we are feeling so weary and so old. I suppose the end must come some time. We held a sort of fete on 3rd to raise money for a Christmas dinner for the men in certain prison camps. All the artists drew or painted programmes which were sold by auction - 200 brought in nearly 6800 Marks. Top price 360 Marks. Russians have an excellent officers band and Russian dancing was A1. British did a play, danced and sang - One danced as a girl and fairly brought down the house. We have a gramaphone in our room which helps a bit, but it isn't easy to get records. Had a long letter from old Hal lately, he seemed pretty fit. Hope you are flourishing and that all goes well with you - Wonder if any of our friends will recognise us if we ever get home again. I tried for Switzerland but wasn't accepted. Better luck later perhaps. If you ever find time heavy on your hands write to me - I'll appreciate it. Best of wishes. P.G.L.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 20th - 29th

The freezing winter of 1917. Wynne worries about coal, her frozen garden and the lack of a governess.
viewer_6.description:
January 20th, Saturday to January 25th, Thursday.
My Diary gets written up by most spasmodic leaps and bounds but really the days are most uneventful at present and so icey cold that our brain freezes. Not being very fit yesterday I spent the day in bed and I should like to spend the rest of the winter there if this black cold is going on for weeks. I don't think I've ever felt the cold so much as I have this year, whether its the season or this house I don't know but its not for want of coal for I've had £24 worth from Crewkerne and another £13 from London and its really awful to see the way these grates eat it up. This last week has been spent chiefly in chores round the house because the frost has been too hard to garden, one literally cannot get to work out there but I find plenty to do inside and being in charge of the children keeps me busy. I am now at last on the tracks of a governess, a girl who lives at Swindon, a Miss Hall, and I am to go and meet her on Monday at Yeovil. I do hope she will prove a success for its really time these two got at it again.
Since last writing this there has been a most fearful explosion in some chemical works near Woolwich, the noise was heard even at Norwich 90 miles away. So many lives lost and so very many injured. Mother says her kitchen curtain blew right out into the room from the concussion. She writes me today that Mary Todd lies dangerously ill from pneumonia at Harrogate. I am much distressed, it will be awful if she dies, her poor young husband having been killed so short a time ago.

January 26th
The bitter cold increases instead of diminishing - every day it grows colder and colder and today is added a howling East wind which is killing all the wallflowers and forget-me-not plants. This weather is truly abominable and I never remember another winter like it.

January 27th
Still colder today, and the wind so biting that that one could hardly walk against it. I have been working in the Hospital kitchen from 10 to 3.30, there were three of us and we had to get dinner ready for 30 men and 6 helpers, it was a business but the Rector's cook who was in charge was most competent and made most delicious food.

January 28th, Sunday
The East Wind or rather hurricane continues and going to church this morning my hat was torn from my head and laid in the dust!! It was simply bitter, it made the back of my head ache and coming home - well I shall never forget it: my eyes streamed and one could scarcely breath.

January 29th, Monday
In this frightful cold I had to go to Yeovil today and as I literally funked the wind I had a car, took my bicycle and rode home in the evening. I went to interview a lady now engaged as governess, to all appearances she seems quite satisfactory and I am very pleased. She comes on Friday and I hope all will turn out well.
(It appears that Wynne was unable to persuade her old governess to come, Miss Scratchley - she mentioned it in the previous week, but nothing more was said).

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: A part of the article Wynne stuck into her diary, about the situation in Germany...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 30th - 31st

The freeze continues. Prices are rising, Germany appears to be suffering and Wynne comments on the development of air power.
viewer_8.description:
January 30th, Tuesday


This cutting I took from the Times today. I wonder if in 10 years time it will come true. I think if 10 years ago someone had prophesied the extraordinary part that the air has played in this present war he would have been jeered at. I well remember seeing the first aeroplane flying over Hale - everyone rushed out to see it and I made a note of it in my Diary, it cannot be more than about 5 years ago. Of course if Lord M's words come true we shall go to India for the week end! but the ticket will probably cost about £1000 each way!! We are still victims of intense cold. If only there was any place to skate how one would love it, but the nearest I believe is Chard. I took the girls for a walk this afternoon, we went through the Park. I had no idea it was so large and I'm longing to explore it in Spring, for even now it looks fascinating, but the great cold has made the country look just dead, not a leaf or blade of grass, even the brambles are withered up, and every branch lying on the ground has had all its bark gnawed off by the starving rabbits, poor wretches. All day long we find jobs of energy to try and keep ourselves from freezing and when I go to bed I dress up and this is what I wear: a pair of combies, a flannel nightdress, a bed jacket, bed socks, shawl round my waist and a hot bottle. I wish I had a dozen of the latter and tonight I shall don my dressing gown as well!

January 31st
I have been working in the kitchen at the Hospital all today, of all walks of life I dont think I shall choose that of a kitchen maid, a filthier, more greasy, slimy occupation would be difficult to find and with no water arrangements its worse, but one puts ones hand to anything these days and no one thinks of complaining, it all for the men who put up with far worse for us.
We had four down to tea yesterday: Izard, Bolton, Grant and Coats, the latter poor man still goes on crutches and will never be much again. Bolton is marked out and goes tomorrow, Grant has a dropped wrist and I don't know why he isn't discharged because it can never be better, such a thing must be dreadfully depressing. Izard has been here for shell shock which caused a loss of memory and he is soon to go I believe. They are all such boys, its awfully sad.
This cutting (see previous window: "Arctic Weather") is in today's Times - it shows only too clearly what misery is being endured in Germany and how sad one is for all the helpless children who must suffer untold misfortunes. Oh! how hateful the whole show is. I suppose all the Nations are preparing for a big Spring Defensive, to what end? The End seems no nearer as far as one can judge. Living is becoming a very complicated affair, all prices rise and rise and taxation goes up in leaps and bounds but so far as we as a nation are concerned real want is not known.

january.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The New Year finds her working to improve her new home in Somerset, at Hinton St George.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne worked a great deal in the local hospital. However this is a pc from a man in a different hospital, and it was sent to someone staying with Wynne. Poignantly, he writes that "the sunshine comes beautifully into my cubicle". Wynne's work place was smaller than this I think, though she still had to turn out a lot of food for the patients, and as you will see in the next picture panel, she also invited them into her home.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 8th - 12th

Air raids on London worry Wynne, but the weather means gardening can continue. She inspects a neighbour's kitchen garden. Food is scarce, and growing it has become very important.
viewer_2.description:
July 8th, Sunday
The whole of June, my favourite month, has gone, gone like a flash, and Oh! how I regret it every year. Even in these days when one longs for the time to pass for it is so lovely with its roses and hay and mid summer madnesses all around. On the 9th of the month Cathy and Martha betook themselves off for their holiday so I turned cook and cooked for us 7 people for 3 weeks. It was a very interesting experience but a bit hard work in addition to all my other jobs. The rest of the time was spent in the glorious long days of a very perfect month by gardening and picnicing. Win was away all the time and returned on July 2nd looking thin and fagged I thought but such heat in London is very trying. They had a series of raids whilst she was up and much loss of life but she saw nothing of it. Today we hear they had another yesterday and killed 30 people and all in broad daylight. That we brought down 4 of their machines is no compensation to us. On the 30th Douglas Whitehead came to spend his leave with us, he is now in the O.C.B. at Bristol and he stayed until Tuesday 3rd, it was so nice to see him again and we spent a very jolly 4 days just idling about. It is such a dreary dull day today but I have the joy of H at home, he came on Thursday and stays until Tuesday. It just gives one a taste of what it will be like to have him always again.

July 9th
We spent our day gardening together (Wynne and her husband). The weather was kind and I just wished it could go on for ever, we worked really hard but it was hot and we were quite ready for tea in the rose corner where we sat and idled for a long time.

July 10th
Alas my dear went off today but not until the evening so we had nearly another day together. I then went in with him to the station and saw him off and when that horrible train took him away I left the platform with the same old feeling of blankness which I have so often felt before, and to which I should be accustomed by now. He has gone to Salisbury inspecting for 2 days, and then goes to Mother for the night en route to Norwich.

July 11th, Wednesday
A whole day at home and much gardening got through beginning at 6.30. I did the garden paths down there - a vile task. Hoeing is an awful work and these paths get as bad as ever one week after they are done.

July 12th
Today I and the children rode over to Scavington and had tea with Mrs Hole and Margery. They have a nice place over there with shady lawns and huge trees. We had tea out and then inspected the kitchen garden in which we are all so interested just now, and we came home through the water meadow lanes. So lovely and peaceful and still, all up through the high hedges grew dog roses, purple tufted vetch and honeysuckle whilst down below the meadow sweet grew in a thick fringe filling the air with scent.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is a photo of some of the wounded soldiers Wynne has been looking after. As they got better, they were invited out into people's homes, and this picture shows a group at Wynne's house with two nurses. Wynne is at the centre rear. They have probably just had tea and games, as often described in the diary. One man is unselfconsciously showing us his amputated leg, something that would probably not have been shown in an official photo.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 13th - 20th

Terrible rain, the death at the front of a very old friend, and another attack of depression
viewer_4.description:
July 13th
I went over to tea with the Rawlins today, a long deferred visit, and found them so very pleasant and nice. They have lived curiously enough in Behar for years and know everyone I ever knew out there, it was most interesting. They are also great friends of the Hutches so we had much in common.

July 14th
Such a day of rushing around - Hospital, nursing committee, tea at Tiggy Winkle and Thomkins garden and after dinner the latter came down to talk and being a hot night Miss H and Win slept out in the garden.

July 15th, Sunday
This is St Swithins day and its been pouring heavily the whole day long. Horrible and dreadful prospect! It was too wet to go to Kirk even and we are not often stopped from doing that. After lunch Win and I went down to the garden to work and it came on suddenly to rain in torrents and we were drenched when we got back. The men came to tea today: Coats, Harman, and Butterfield. Coats leaves tomorrow after nearly a year's soujourn here, we shall quite miss him. We all went up to church this evening and Mr S gave us such a gloomy sermon that I settled myself to slumber and so missed coming away depressed. It was fearfully stuffy in church, the esprits de corps being particularly rich.

July 18th, Wednesday


I do not write of Mon and Tuesday, they passed uneventfully and quickly thanks be, full of rain and gloomy clouds. I was today at Hospital having arranged to exchange with Holdsworth as I am hoping to go down to Bristol for the weekend to see Douglas Whitehead. I had tea afterwards with the Lowes and found there the young Australian who is convalescing with Mrs Shelmerdine, a pleasant young fellow with a very strong colonial accent and manners. What rough cards some of them are. On my return I found a letter from Poggy with the horrible news that Kenneth Potter has been killed. He thinks it must have been in the awful Nieuport attack when so many were killed about 10 days ago. I am so very grieved. He was one of our oldest and most cheery friends.
(Major Kenneth Mitchell Potter, DSO, died on 8th July 1917 aged 35. He is buried in the Dickebush New Military Cemetery Extension).

July 19th
I've had the most hideous blues today, I don't ever remember being attacked worse, how curious it is, must be liver I think - anyhow a mental pill would be a good thing on these occasions. Miss Billing came to tea a nice old "left over" lady, and Squire Love came down after tea and gardened with me and made himself generally useful. He looks so seedy still I cant make out quite what's wrong with him.

July 20th
Today...we sat down 14 to tea! It seemed quite like old times to have a crowd again. I was surprised that the (tennis) court played as well as it did considering its condition in October!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Views of Bristol that Wynne stuck into the diary. If you visit the city you will see that it has changed. In the B&W photo of the Avon (top) you will find that a large road now occupies the rail lines on the left of the picture, and in the colour pc of the Cathedral in the centre, the steps have been replaced by a landscaped park in front of the council offices, and the Queen has been moved.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 21st - 24th

Wynne travels to Bristol to spend the weekend with her young admirer who is in training there. She enjoys the Hippodrome and walking on the Downs, but finds the Cathedral acoustic "vile".
viewer_6.description:
July 21st, Saturday
This day finds me at Bristol! I came here this morning to see the Jackdaw (D.W Whitehead, often DW in entries. Nicknames seem to have been an inveterate habit in this period and everyone had to suffer one.) and to stay until Monday. He met me at the station looking so tall and smart and lean, I felt quite proud of the creature. We drove up to my hotel, the Lyndale, where too are living all his officers and after lunch we started forth and walked to Leigh Woods of far fame! It was very hot but so lovely in the woods which are of immense size extending all along the great spur of land on the Clifton side. We had a late tea in the town on our return and then sat in the Square garden till dinner after which we went to the Hippodrome and saw an excellent performance, much laughter and much boiling heat.

July 22nd
I got up and went to Early Service in the Cathedral, then after breakfast at 10.30 DW came for me and we attended mattins. The singing is lovely but the acoustic properties of the building are so vile that we hardly hear at all and I wished afterwards we had gone to a smaller church. After lunch we took tram to Westbury and walking from there to Coombe Dingle found ourselves in the heart of the country and sat down under a hedge discussing the earth and the heavens until it was time for tea which we had at a tiny cottage in company with many Bristolians who had also blown out that way. A lovely day but so hot and after supper we trammed to the suspension bridge, took the hydraulic railway and walked along the Downs and so home. (Wynne would have taken a tram to the base of the bridge, and then caught the now closed hydraulic railway that took her to the top by the Avon Gorge hotel).

July 23rd, Monday
Alas all good things come to an end and today I sadly took my way home again. DW just ran up to see me at 8.30 before he went on Parade and I returned by the 12.12. I found Holt awaiting me at Ilminster and on the way back at Seavington his old rattle trap broke down and there I sat for half an hour whilst he tinkered. Found all well at home.

July 24th
This day I spent at Lyme Regis with Mr Love. We went off early and had lunch at Lyme, after which we drove out to Charmouth and had tea there and paddled! It was lovely to see the sea again.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: An interesting article that mentions the work of the airmen in the war.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 25th - 31st

Wynne travels to Norwich where her husband is on the staff of the Home Defence. She meets the CO Sir Bruce Hamilton.
viewer_8.description:
July 25th, Wednesday
The children and I went over to the Blakes today, they are of a huge family of that name in the neighbourhood and this particular branch have bought a place near here called Marks Barn. They have lived for many years in the Falkland Islands and there made their money in wool.

July 26th
Today I freed myself from all shackles of domesticity and fled to Norwich to see my dear beloved. I have been invited here by some people called Cardew - he is MS to Sir Bruce Hamilton, H's (Wynne's husband) boss. I stayed an hour in town and had lunch with Mother and then came on and H met me at the station.

(General Sir Bruce Hamilton was in command of the Home Defence during the war, and Herbert Jackson served under him when he returned from the front line in 1915. He was in age an almost exact contemporary, and had also served in the Second Boer War.)

July 27th - 31st
My stay at Norwich is over and I am back at home again. It has all been so short but I have enjoyed it. The Cardews were kindness itself and every day indeed to nearly every meal asked someone in to meet me and it was simply ripping to find myself in a real soldier atmosphere again, this atmosphere of small courtesies and underlying well-bredness after a long course of Tommies of New Army's free and easyness!! good fellows though they are. Each day we went somewhere and saw people and I met a good many old friends amongst whom were the Malwells. She has grown fat and plain and he bears a sort of haunted appearance and has several times been very near lunacy I believe poor chap. Sir Bruce came to lunch one day - a very big bug in the soldier line and my host and my General both sat up on their hind legs and pawed the air to show their respect. In the course of conversation I found that he had been as a boy in '72 at Woodcote - the company laughed much at such strange school fellows. I returned home by the 8.20 from Norwich, had breakfast in the train and found confusion worse confounded at Liverpool Street. No porters, no barrows, no taxis. I had to get my own stuff out of the van and rush off for a taxi and getting to Waterloo the same thing happened. There I found Mother and Thurie , also Algie who is home on a weeks leave and who did a lot of porters work for me!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: I could not resist putting in this little selection of the London theatres. They occur on the back of the Messines article in the previous picture slot. Note that the hugely successful Chu Chin Chow is running at His Majesty's - many soldiers on leave mentioned this show.

july.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

She wrote nothing for June, as she was too busy with cooking and gardening - July affords some happier occupations alongside the usual hospital work.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: This is from the Telegraph in - nothing changes does it...and as Wynne herself noted, this victory did nothing to eradicate the bitter memories of the loss and wastage that occurred in 1916.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 8th

Bad weather continues: colds and flu, and a trip to London. The Spring "push" appears to be nearing as hospitals are made ready in Wynne's area.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Thursday
March has come in like a lamb. I'm not sure that I'm pleased because it means such gales later on. The air is mild and warm and we are revelling after our most terrible winter. Was there ever such a winter with its hurricanes, its zero of frost, torrents of rain, snow and every other form of vileness, add to it this appalling War which not only continues endlessly but which is ever and always increasing and even now preparing for fresh hostilities. "The Spring Push" is in everyone's mind , quietly and secretly it goes on and one hears of more and more hospitals being put in readiness for the tide of maimed young life that is expected about April and May. Dear God, how cruel it all is.

March 2nd
The cutting on the preceding page is from Books of Today and Tomorrow and is a laugh against the Times which has of late been carrying on a crusade against its many subscribers, every argument has been used to induce them to discontinue their use of it owing to the present shortage of paper - they find it impossible to produce it so eventually they raised the price to 2d with further threats of 3d and even 7d. I now take in the D.T. and very interesting and good it is. (You can see this cutting in the February entry)

March 3rd
Win and I walked with Mr Love today to Bryces Mill. He showed us the way across the fields and when we got there we found masses and masses of snowdrops. The place is derelict and has been abandoned for years. In the sad neglected garden grow these lovely flowers and we picked huge bunches and I sent them to Mother. Mr L returned with us to tea and played games till 8.0 afterwards!

March 4th
My Win is down with another of her awful colds, this time she really is very bad, such a throat and fever and I am keeping her in bed. A high wind and snow blizzard blowing today, right back in winter.

March 5th, Monday
Mother has written demanding my presence in Town so as H goes to Bedford on duty next Friday I have gladly accepted her offer to pay all my expenses and go up on Thursday.

March 6th and 7th.
Nothing doing except gardening and chickening. Mrs Pardoe junior came to tea - a poor haggard looking woman lately married with a husband in the trenches. To Hospital today, Wednesday, the usual greazy (sic) jobs, and it seemed particularly unpleasant today.

March 8th, Thursday
By the 8.24 I went up today, arising at 6.30 to finish my packing and have my breakfast, a lovely bright frosty morning and a good journey up. Found Mother on the verge of a bronchial attack, its awful how many people are down with it now, makes one quite jumpy. My dear man arrived at 1.30 and it was the usual joy seeing him, a very very great delight to me after what I call a long diet of starvation. At 3.0 dear Mabel came, we had not met for about 5 years, she looks well, indeed better than I should have expected after so long out there. We had a great talk and its seemed to natural and delightful to meet again. She is unfortunately bound for a nursing home soon to have a slight op.
(Mabel, Wynne's sister-in law, was working as a missionary in Portuguese East Africa)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The beginning of Percival Landon's report from Baghdad. A later paragraph goes thus: "For us Englishmen there is no more suggestive or significant fact than the occupation of Baghdad by the white race that first ventured into these ancient wildernesses, first treated with the Sovereigns of the Middle East, first established their trade and that terrible responsibility and strength which the Indian Empire usurped from the decaying Caliphate. The shores of the Tigris are better known to us than all but a few of our Imperial rivers. The police work of the Gulf for the last hundred years has taught us to know it like our pocket. We have but temporarily exchanged the topi for the helmet. We shall go back to the topi in a few months, only to realise that once again in our history the security of a point along our frontier and the wanton hostility of a race which we had notoriously trusted and helped for sixty years, compels us to take up our burden in lands beyond our furthest outposts."
I wonder even today if we have quite managed to shake off this attitude?

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 9th - 15th

Baghdad falls at last - a relief after the disaster of the previous year. Sugar and other necessities are hard to find, and no one dresses for the theatre any more!
viewer_4.description:
March 9th, Friday
Poggy went off to Bedford this morning and I to shop at the Stores.
