London of course is not itself just now, there is a feel of general strain and distress in the air, the streets are swarming with soldiers, chiefly it appears Colonials, everything feels abnormal and at present we await the hourly news of Baghdad being captured. General Maude is getting very near and this time all is so well organized and managed, alas how I wish and long that my dear Ell were amongst this lot and not in that first exp. so miserably mismanaged and such a failure in every way. Mother is very seedy and I am feeling a beast tonight but so far have managed to conceal that fact! I hate telling about my colds but the truth will out sooner or later!

March 10th
I have discovered that my dear Stella is in Town and so rang her up and we foregathered at the Stores, going on afterwards with her to Harrods. Alas I've just missed Skippy, he went back yesterday and is very seedy with a wound in his foot. He sometime ago jumped into a trench and struck a broken bayonet blade, poison got in and now it will not heal so he has gone to a Base Hospital after a month a home. How I do wish I had seen him. I have successfully procured today my Glucose for jam making and 13lbs of sugar, such a triumph. I am hoping to get Corn syrup also but that is doubtful, the sugar question is acute, one simply cant buy it and we are scraping and saving all we know. H and I went to Drury Lane tonight and because taxis are nil we went and came by train and did not dress - what times!

March 11th
The Fall of Baghdad
At last the Eternal City has fallen into our hands and great is the rejoicing thereof, but all the time the taste is taken out of the good news by the memory of that bitter disappointment of some months ago when the precious lives of our dear men were ruthlessly sacrificed to mismanagement and incompetence. Well one is thankful anyhow that at last we've done something without "muddling through".

March 12th
Mother is a bit better now but not at all frisky. I went this afternoon shopping and called on Blanch Gray to see her and her new house, everything is very spick and span and not a pin out of its proper place and all very new. She was looking much better but has got so grey and is always sad.

March 13th, Tuesday
I sadly took my leave of Mother today and journeyed home. It has all gone so dreadfully quickly, all passed like a flash. I did hate saying goodbye to her and to Poggy on Sunday, the more I see of that man and its little enough the more I want him home altogether. Its getting on for 3 years now since all home life for everyone was broken up, thank god this past cannot come again.

March 14th
I had to send Win to Hospital for me today as I simply had to stay in bed. I don't know when I've had such a throat, I think I must have picked up a bronchial microbe from Mother.

March 15th
I did not get up till 12.0 today - I have no voice and wanted to be alone. At 1.0 Gertie (Maclean) arrived - its quite a long time since she was under my roof and as she is a link with some of my happiest years its always a joy to have her. (Gertie was the sister of Wynne's first real love).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The first news of the Russian Revolution...and below this, an American account of the early success of the March revolution.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 16th - 22nd

The fall of the Czar electrifies Wynne, who inserts cuttings about it and ponders on the new republic.
viewer_6.description:
March 16th, Friday
Verging on Resurgam I ventured forth to do some mild gardening. Whilst in the potting shed Davies brings the paper and there I am electrified to see "Abdication of the Tzar", "Overthrow of the old Regime" etc and I could scarcely believe my eyes. How extraordinary it all is, and I shall read the paper from end to end tonight.

March 17th, Saturday
Here I insert various cuttings of this most marvelous and wonderful happening. (Three can be seen in the accompanying March pages to give you a sense of how the story was reported. Wynne stuck in a great many cuttings here). It is so long and intricate a story that no words of mine could describe it. What beats me is how a Court in the 20th century could live and carry on in such an atmosphere of medieval superstition and mystic spiritualism. The hideous influence of the drunken immoral Rasputin over the Czarina and her little son, the corrupt Ministry, the appalling scandals and the German Propaganda which has crept and crawled all through the whole system of govt. like some awful cancer all go to make up the most extraordinary tragedy that the devil ever devised and in the midst of it all the rather pathetic figure of the weak and vacillating Czar now a mere nonentity.

March 18th
We went to Kirk today and had a Memorial Service for those who had fallen in the War from this village. The little church was crowded and it was horribly pathetic to see all the poor ones who had lost their men. I read yesterday that China now has broken off negotiations with Germany - who next!

March 20th, Tuesday
The news from Russia continues to be extraordinary, but all seems quieting down in a wonderful manner. One cant imagine Russia of all countries a democratic country governed by a Republic, which I suppose is what it will come to in the end. No one seems to know what has become of the Czar!

March 21st
Here is a most interesting account of the Czars and their former greatness, but alas it is so brief that just as one thrills to know more of Peter they pass on to Catharine. What extraordinary people, a mystic and tragic race and I wish I had some books upon it but alas books are not here and one cannot spend money on luxuries just now. To Hospital today with Gertie and we worked hard all day there feeling much begrimed and weary at the end, but there are not very many men there now, more however will be coming shortly doubtless with this push that is going on.

March 22nd, Thursday
I here insert some articles by Philip Gibbs*, the War Correspondent of the D.T.. They are well worth keeping and reading, most vivid accounts of our Push out West and the awful destruction of country and people we are meeting with in hapless France. One cannot conceive what it all is like. The Germans are behaving just like they did when they overran Belgium and the whole place lies waste, it is all to terrible and surely some day they will get their deserts. We are losing Destroyers each week through submarines and mines and it is awfully anxious work for those who have men on them. Daisy Whitworth's (Gertie's sister) husband is a commander of one and it keeps her very anxious.

*I have added here not Gibbs' articles, but one by Perris - as the British correspondents were allowed to advance into what had been German held territory, all the articles share the same sense of outrage.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
More news from Russia...in its early stages the revolution was greeted warmly in Britain. The Allies one concern was that Russia continue in the War, and this the new Provisional Government agreed to do - thereby helping to ensure its early demise.

Meanwhile stories about the deposed Nicholas and Alexandra were avidly consumed...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 23rd - 31st

Too cold for gardening...and one of Wynne's visiting soldiers comments very unfavourably on the countryside.
viewer_8.description:
March 23rd, Friday
I took Gertie up to tea with Mr Love today to show her his neat little house and garden but owing to our ever present winter weather conditions everything is awfully backward and the whole countryside looks like January.

March 24th
I tried to do some gardening today but the wind simply cut me through, my hands were dead cold so I gave it up. Our men came to tea as usual, 4 of them, and we played the usual baby games with them and they amused themselves like children. They are most easy to amuse and always so appreciative.

March 25th, Sunday
To early Church with Win and a lazy afternoon, that's to say a letter writing afternoon for it was too cold to garden, a practice I have lately taken to under the public advice of the Archbishop of Canterbury!

March 26th
Today I pruned roses in a biting East Wind that nearly killed me and was at length driven in by snow. The weather continues to be as mad as it possibly can and so far as clothes are concerned I am still wearing all my thickest garments and every day we cower over fires and freeze.

March 27th
My morning was spent in sowing seeds, vegetable seeds. I am greatly interested in my kitchen garden as I feel sure that Govt. will take my garden this summer and it behoves me to learn as much as possible in the meanwhile. After lunch kind Mr Love drove me over to Illminster to return a call of some distant people living in that direction, it was good of him because I certainly shouldn't care to prance over there on my bicycle.

March 28th
To Hospital again and had to hang around there for some time as some new men arrived and had to be fed on arrival.

March 29th
This afternoon I attended Mrs Lowe's Bible Meeting! She was thoroughly happy being able to discourse for an hour on end all by herself and her voice went on and on and on until I nearly fell asleep. It was held in old Mrs Dollings wee room and there were 13 of us present. I felt most virtuous. We discoursed upon the History of the Israelites and their vagaries. Mr Love came to dinner tonight and oh! we had a riotous evening playing idiotic games and laughing till we were all ill. It seemed so odd to see a man in evening kit again, such a thing is almost obsolete these days as all are in uniform even in the evenings and I should think the moth must be getting into a few thousand evening suits.

March 31st
Friday and today passed much as usual. The men came to tea. One man had never been in the country before and his comments on it were not flattering - a regular cockney, he wondered how we could exist here in winter, his only knowledge of the country was August in Margate which was his height of bliss.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: Some of the truths and fictions that swirled around the Russian story at that time...

march.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. The Spring "push" - Baghdad is captured at last - and the Czar of all the Russias is toppled from his throne

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: A letter which was sent to every household, following on from the King's appeal that you can read about in April's section.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 12th

A round of "calls", dentist vists and leave takings. Wynne wishes that paying calls could be abolished...a strange ritual.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Tuesday
For the first time for many a year I would not have minded being Queen of the May in muslin today, for its really been a lovely day. We spend our entire days out of doors and live in the air. Mabel and I were invited up to the Riddles to tea today, they are our almost nearest neighbours, and we see least of them. They are amiable but oh! so dull. I don't think they have any sense of humour. She is pretty and much younger than he, they have two babies and their whole minds are upon domesticity and their home interests.

May 2nd, Wed
I took Pink into Yeovil today to the dentist to have two teeth out and am glad that that's over. I always hate these things for my babies so. He had novacane (sic) however and felt nothing. He returns to school on Friday alas.

May 5th, Saturday
I am feeling thoroughly bereft today, for not only have I lost my son and Maggie but Mabel has gone too, so we are a little party once more. Mabel went off to Winchester and goes on from there to Cornwall. She is of course spending her leave on a long round of visits but there is grave doubts as to her getting back to S.A. at all as no women are allowed to cross now.

May 10th, Thursday
This day about a thousand years ago I was confirmed. How well I remember driving in solemn state with Father in the brougham to Spetisbury Church, Mother and Eve following in the dog cart and there the ancient and meandering old Bishop Wordsworth of Salisbury confirmed me.

May 12th, Saturday
The past week has been spent in paying calls. I do think this form of tax ought to be abolished during war time. I've scoured the county this week and been all over the place ending up with tea at the Rectory and Hospital today. At tea there was Mrs Pardoe, the Rector's sister and husband, and the Lowes - very chaste and correct and I behaved with seeming propriety.

Novacaine (procaine is its proper name, the former being a trade name) was a relatively recent introduction which made dentist visits much less traumatic. It had been first synthesized in 1898 and was introduced into medical practice by the German surgeon Heinrich Braun in 1905)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The famous rabbit (and mole?) catcher - Wynne's big garden was invaded, and this was serious at a time when food was short and everything you could grow was valuable.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 13th - 21st

Rogation Day is celebrated in the open air - a return to old practice. Jumble sales and more teeth agony.
viewer_4.description:
May 13th, Sunday
This morning the Rector announced that Tuesday being Rogation Day there would be a revival of the ancient open air services all over the country to bless the crops, a curious and a charming idea. To tea came Miss Despard and to supper Mr L but I had blues. I have lost my little Mowgli which i've had since I was 14 so I'm afraid I was not a lively hostess!

May 15th, Tuesday
This evening the village attended by surplus choir congregated in a field and a short service was read. It seemed to me as we all stood there asking God to bless our efforts that there was something extraordinarily charming in the idea and I wonder why it was ever dropped.

May 16th
Again to the dentist at Yeovil, Nootie, Baby and I. We bicycled in to catch the 8.24 and arrived at the station just in time to see the train go out. i was in despair as i didn't know what to do, then I bethought me of a car and luckily got one at the George and we arrived at 9.15 in time for our appointment. Baby had two teeth out with gas and didn't mind at all, I went through all the tortures instead, then Noots was looked at and then for 2 hours he played about with me. I wish all my teeth were in the dustbin instead of in my mouth.

May 17th
Went up to tea with dear old Mrs Dolling today, the late Rector's mother. We call her Mrs Tiggy Winkle, she's just like her. Win went to Town.

May 21st, Monday
I cannot write a daily Diary these times, events are too great and too never ending to write about and the daily round is too trivial to mention. We had heavy rain yesterday, the first for weeks. After lunch I went and sold at the Jumble Sale. It was as funny as these shows generally are, and was held at the Lowes. I wonder Mrs L wasn't sold by mistake - she was dressed up in dingy rags and a string of fish bones round her neck!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Philip Gibbs (later knighted, he lived until 1962) was a famous reporter during WW1. He had some run-ins with the censors, and was a prolific writer. This is just a part of one such report, made in , by which time he was one of five fully accredited reporters, and thus subject to censorship (something he managed to avoid at the start of the conflict). Wynne cut out many such reports, as you can see elsewhere...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 24th - 29th

Wynne's husband comes for a brief visit, and then they go to London. Women's suffrage enrages a male friend!
viewer_6.description:
May 24th, Thursday
My beloved came home today for a few days leave, no words can ever express what it means to me to see him. I do so appreciate every minute he is here and we get so little of each other these days of ceaseless waiting seem never ending and the monotony sometimes seems almost more than one can endure. If he were at the Front the anxiety would certainly be greater but the interest more for him but I know he gets very tired of his East Coast job and longs to throw up the sponge and come home.

May 26th
I picked the first Sweet Peas today and I'm sure I've beaten Hinton record. They promise well and there are now plenty of roses out as well.

May 28th
In consequence of Mother's urgent appeals I made up my mind suddenly last night and came to Town with Poggy today. He wanted to be up at a meeting by 3.0 so we sallied forth to catch the 8.24 only to find on arrival at the station that owing to its being Whit Monday it wasn't running so then we sat for 2 hours and came by the 10.35 which arriving an hour late made him half an hour late for his meeting. We both were in a fine rage! this line is the limit. I found Mother wonderfully better - I forgot to mention that a short while ago she was very ill with gastric flu and it left her so weak and knocked up that she couldn't do anything, but she seems more like herself now.

May 29th
My dear left today, life seems to be made of of saying goodbye these days but the whole world is alike, we none of us know any other word hardly and so many alas have said that dreadful word for the last time. I went down to Liverpool Street to say goodbye and though that beastly train was only taking him to Norwich it felt just as horrible and chokey as it ever did before. Ninian came to lunch today and grew quite fierce over an argument on Woman's Suffrage. I didn't know it was such a red rag to him.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne's house in Hinton St George. Ysobel and Eleanore are just visible in the garden which caused Wynne so much hard work and heartache...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
May 30th - 31st

In London Wynne manages to get to two opera's, conducted by Beecham: Othello and The Girl from the Golden West.
viewer_8.description:
May 30th, Wednesday
I indulged myself this morning as I very often do when up in Town by staying in bed to an inconscionable (sic) hour having my breakfast there and thoroughly enjoying myself and then I later rushed round the Town and finally went to the Opera, "Othello", which Beecham conducted and enjoyed it very much. It is lovely to hear some music again and such an intellectual treat. Win was with us and it was her first Opera. Oh! dear how long ago was my first one I cant even remember anything about it.

May 31st
Another lazy morning in bed, how I revel in the laziness for life is really a bit strenuous with me as a rule. Win and I spent the afternoon at Roehampton, just sat about and had tea and came home in time to dress and go to another Opera, "The Girl from the Golden West", some fine songs in it but oh! so stupid. The kind Duke lent us his box for both nights and these lucky people are going to La Boheme on Monday how I wish I were too but alas duty calls and I must away home again tomorrow. I would that I could turn a deaf ear to duty this time but I am at work at Hospital on Saturday. Its been a very jolly interlude in an otherwise happy but at times very unsatisfying life.

(The operas Wynne refers to are Verdi's Othello and Puccini's La Fanciulla del West. The latter had been premiered in London in 1911, so was a relatively new experience for Wynne).

may.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Winter finally gives way to Spring, and Wynne enjoys the weather and a visit from her husband, but paying calls and the dentist prove less pleasant.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
On November 4th Wynne added this poem, from the October edition of Blackwood magazine. She was clearly moved by it, its domestic setting speaking to her very directly. She had been going through a very difficult time, probably close to a breakdown, which the gaps in the diary attest to.

The full poem is copied out below. It is only signed P.S.M.

The Voices - written on leave in a Kentish garden.

1
Soft breaks the hushed June dawn:
The pear-soft light
Strikes from the dew-wet lawn
Diamonds bright,
And, out of sight,
Poised in the limpid blue on quivering wings,
A lark pours out his soul to God and sings
Of hope and faith and love and homely things.
Each dew-kissed rose
Lifts to the ardent sun his velvet lip.
The splendour grows,
And every jewelled tip
Flashes a myriad, golden, mimic suns.
Then  -  on the stilled air,
Sullen and sinister,
Mutter the Voices – the Guns.

2
Noon lifts his flaming crown:
Faint in the heat
The blue hills burn, and down
The village street
On laggard feet,
A carter walks beside his sweating team,
Pausing to let them water at the stream.
On the white road the purple shadows dream,
And like a bell
Tolled faint in fairy land, a cuckoo’s note
Rings from the dell.
Clad in his emerald coat
Across the dusty road a lizard runs.
Then – through the heat,
With dull menacing beat,
Mutter the Voices – the Guns.

3
Soft falls Night’s star-hung veil:
In the warm gloom
The roses sigh and fill
With rich perfume
The lighted room,
With wave on wave of incense like a prayer.
And candles burn straight in the windless air,
And there is sound of laughter free from care.
Softly the light
Falls upon gleaming sliver and then glass
And damask white.
But – as the moments pass
And the talk dies to silence and hushed tones,
With shuddering breath,
Chanting their song of Death,
Mutter the Voices – the Guns.

P.S.M. (Blackwood, October )

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 1st - 5th

Air raids are now a matter of routine...and the full moon makes them more likely. A dull month, but gardening continues, helped by the arrival of her husband.
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Thursday
Here is this dull month again, but there is never any time now to think of the weather and at any rate it is warm. I do not love our English climate from November to March but there are always lovely days or hours in every month. It is again the season of full moon, consequently air raids almost every night. I think it seems so odd how now we take these visitors as quite a matter of course, I can remember when not so long ago the first Zep came over and created a most tremendous fuss and ferment. Nowadays we seldom have a Zep raid, it was found that so many came to grief it was too expensive a game and so they have substituted planes which do much more damage and nearly always get away owing to the far greater difficulty in hitting them, but last week or so having I suppose a few Zeps to spare a sort of job lot as it were! the Bosche sent them over on a dark night with the most disastrous results to themselves and very little damage to us for they were captured and shot and lost their bearings and their way, some finding themselves as far away as the Mediterranean, another giving itself up to an old munition worker in France armed with a shot gun! whilst another that came down had been too high and all its petrol was frozen and its occupants were frozen dead, one and all. Most horrible. I don't fancy we'll see many more of that craft over here. Early this week Parliament had a special sitting to pass a vote of thanks to all the men and women of the country for their heroism and endurance during the long time of stress and strain since 1914, and the Premier made the most perfect thing in the way of speeches I've ever read. I was simply thrilled by it, a splendid simple flow of words and how proud it makes one feel to belong to England. He laid special stress upon the valour of the fighting man, those countless thousands who have given up everything and life as well for the Cause, and then he gave an account of the marvellous records of Navy and Army in all branches. It was fine and I wish every man and woman in the world could read it.

November 2nd
All day long I've been working "wrestling" with "endless chains" of couch grass in the kitchen garden. It is a heart-breaking job and seems simply never ending. At 3.0 I had to attend Mrs Lowes Bible lecture which is held every month at Mrs Dollings. Old Lowey thoroughly enjoys herself on these occasions for she has the floor entirely to herself and her voice for one whole hour goes on in a ceaseless flow. I flew back at 4.0 and went to the station to meet my Poggy who has come home for a few days leave. He has till Wednesday and it is the very greatest joy to have him back again. It is such a treat to me, I don't believe anyone can know how awfully I miss him all the time and how I never get used to being without him.

November 3rd
A long days gardening with Poggy, a huge barrow load of couch the result. Little by little it gets dug up but it still seems endless and one wonders if this dreadful garden will ever be quit of it. Mr Love came to dinner and we played Bridge afterwards.

November 4th, Sunday
I am spending the day in bed not feeling very burzling and so I've taken the opportunity of writing long letters to various neglected ones. I've just finished Pink's news sheet of the "Home mail", it is an enormous double page out of a huge ledger of Father's! and on the opposite page here I copy out a poem from Blackwood which has fascinated me as much an anything I've read lately. ("The Voices" - reproduced in the previous window).

November 5th
We awoke to a very red sunrise today, the whole sky was ablaze, and I feared it meant a wet day but the rain kept off and we worked in the kitchen garden all the morning at the everlasting couch and then we planted some new currant and raspberry bushes: Boskoop Giant currant and Superlative and Hornel raspberry - 3 splendid sorts from Laxton. (The first two names are correct - and appear in Victorian catalogues - but I cannot find Hornel, and the word is difficult to decipher anyway in Wynne's scrawl).
We only have one post a day now, and none on Sundays. Really primitive state of affairs.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is something Wynne received from her brother, and dates from 1915. It is a message to the Officer in charge of prisoners of war, Indian Corps, acknkowledging the receipt of 37 prisoners: 36 men and 1 cadet officer.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 6th - 12th

A friend suffers shell shock, her husband has to go back, and the chores continue. She entertains the wounded, and comments on the collapse of class distinctions.
viewer_4.description:
November 6th
I received a letter today from the Jackdaw saying he would be back in Blighty as soon as I got it. He apparently is suffering from shell shock, its awful bad luck poor boy as he hasn't been out a month and was so hoping for luck this time. I got a wire later in the day giving me his address and he has gone to a hospital at Southsea. Well I'm thankful he's out of it anyhow for now.

November 7th
My dear man left very early this morning and I went in to see him off. On my return I went back to the garden and worked and worked till I could no more see. Each day and all day is spent like this now so there's little to relate in a diary!

November 8th
Ditto!
To tea came the Squire and after tea I made a jigsaw puzzle. We've got a mania for them again now and I'm making some to do as I gave away all my old ones very foolishly.

November 10th, Saturday
To Hospital as usual, a long and strenuous day, much cleaning of pots and pans and kettles and I worked today up to nearly 4.0. I am glad of this work, dirty though it is, for one feels these days one cannot do enough directly or indirectly for our men, knowing what they are going through for our sake. This may sound mawkish but it is a very real reality.

November 11th, Sunday
The Sabbath once more, to early service and matins and to tea and supper came Mr Love and Miss Edwards. The entertainment was not a success and by 10 I was thoroughly bored and despatched them. We did jigsaw puzzles all the time, an excellent way of passing it but I don't think I'll repeat that operation.

November 12th
All the day long have I been at work, I sometimes get bewildered by all there is to do and dear old Davis (the gardener) muddles on in his willing way but he is a regular spendthrift of time. To tea and Bridge came two of the men (from the hospital), Dennis and Welch. The latter was my partner and he began by playing 2 aces and 2 kings and then exclaiming "Now I'm done". I thought to myself, if that's his style we're in for a jolly evening! but he improved and we had quite an interesting game, incredible though it may sound. Oh dear, how odd are the times when in our drawing room we sit down to hob nob and play cards with men of the people and think nothing of it!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A drawing of Elliot in his waterproof - anyone know what NILGA stands for (unless its some sort of ref to the Nilga animal)?

"When we see ourselves as others see us" is written at the top, and the date 19.8.17.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 13th - 17th

Her brother is finally safe home in England. Wynne rushes up to London to be with him.
viewer_6.description:
November 13th
Oh! Day of days! Red Letter Day! I was working hard this morning on the couch plot when Cathy brought in this telegram. I could hardly believe my eyes and for a few minutes worked horribly at random! I had not expected Ell for another fortnight at least and here he is safely landed in England. I packed up my goods and chattels, looked up a train and fled away to Town by the 4.28. It was very full but I had quite a good journey and arrived not very late at Waterloo. I had much difficulty in finding a porter and when I did he failed utterly to get me a taxi as they are nearly all on strike and those who weren't would not go as far as Kensington so the only thing was the Tube. My box in one hand and my despatch case in another I therefore trudged along and by the time I reached the flat after many rests by the way I'd had about enough! When I got to the door I rang and it was opened by Ell. With his hand on the edge of the door he said "you can't come in". I laid my hand on his and said "If you don't let me in at once I shall burst into tears" and in my intense excitement I felt like it. What followed I cannot well remember, I only know that it is heaven to be with him again, to see him looking so well and so unchanged. The seven week voyage has done him good and we three sat and talked till all hours but we have 2 years arrears to make up.

November 14th
I sat indoors and took the opportunity of absence from home to write a lot of letters whilst Ell went out. After lunch I went off shopping and had my tea there. The place was crammed and one could hardly get attendance, all the decent men except the very old ones have gone and their places have been taken by impudent females of the usual counter class. Everywhere in the grocery dept are huge placards stuck up - "No Tea Today" "No Sugar Today". Indeed to buy sugar over the counter is no longer possible, we are all on strict rations. Mother has none in the house and uses honey for cooking and Saxine (a trade name for saccharin) for tea and coffee. At tea I was waited upon by a very pretty girl who looked ill and tired. I entered into conversation with her and gathered that she was very unhappy. Her home was a sad one, her sister in consumption and her erstwhile man she had quarrelled with and he had disappeared so I got her name and address in order to send her some flowers. How little sunshine some people have in their lives. I then went home and after dinner we played Bridge.

November 15th, Thursday
Ell and I lunched at Lady Fulton's today and afterwards went to a matinee of Ibsen's "Ghosts", a most interesting but truly horrible play on heredity with a tragic ending. I was very glad to see it as i had never seen one of his before. We had tea at the Bath afterwards.

November 16th
Barkers first and then on to Oxford Street, ending up with tea at Stewarts in Piccadilly. Came home on the top of a bus. The evening was warm and still and all the shaded lamps and lights (because of air raids) down Piccadilly and Knightsbridge and across the Park looked like some huge stage scene, the big search lights on the top of Hyde Park gate reminded us of the reality of war and also made one feel safe as they never play on Raid nights.

November 17th
Today Ell and I spent the whole day at Wellington with Pink. Met the dear son at the Great Gate. he came running out of school with an eager face and in spite of English reticence and many school boys I just hugged him up! We then went up to his dorm and deposited various grub we had brought and went on to the Hotel to lunch after which back to College to call on Tutor and watch footer and then to tea and buy more grub and so came the end of a very happy day. Got home to find Poggy had come up for the weekend.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is the programme from the Royal Opera House for "Samson and Delilah"

This was an afternoon show. To give you an idea of Sir Thomas Beecham's season of Grand Opera in English, it was followed on the same day by Boris Godunov, then Mozart's Magic Flute on Thursday, Butterfly on Friday and finally Gounod's Faust on Saturday as a matinee (with an evening performance which sadly is cut off from the programme). I would not have liked to have been a stage hand with all those changes!

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 18th - 22nd

Final days in London take in "Yellow Ticket" and "Samson and Delilah" before Wynne returns to Somerset. She ends her diary on 22nd with nothing further to say.
viewer_8.description:
November 18th
Poggy and I went off to service at the Abbey, the communion service at 11.30. (In the evening) there was a big fire in the coal yard behind the flats. I've never seen such a thing, it blazed to the sky and hundreds of tons of coal were burnt. It lasted about 2 hours and was most exciting to watch.

November 19th
My man went back today. Went to meet a Mrs Henderson at my Club. On December 15th there is to be a huge commemoration of the first Seven Divisions at the Albert Hall and each regiment and unit of all the Divs are giving a Banner which is to be hung in the Hall on the occasion. The R.A. 7th Div have done me the honour of making me President of the Committee and so I went to meet Mrs H who is doing the organising and together we went to the School of Art Needlework to see our Banner. It is in the regimental colours with a big golden gun in the centre surrounded by a scroll in red on which are embroidered in gold the different Brigades and Batteries. Some of us have worked on it and I looked in fear and trepidation at my handiwork but was relieved to find that there were some which looked worse! They are doing about 50 of them, it ought to be a very wonderful sight. Tonight Ell and I went to a play called "The Yellow Ticket" about Russia and the horrors there. Gladys Cooper, Allen Ainsworth and Sidney Valentin most excellent and I should like to see it again, it is a most dramatic affair but has a happy ending. Oh the treat it is to go to a play once more, to see the world for a few days and to get away from the petty and ridiculous smallness of life in the remote country! (Note: The Yellow Ticket was based on a Frank Harris short story, and is about Tsarist Russia, and not about the current situation as might be implied here. The story is about a Jewish girl who can only earn money in order to study by getting a yellow ticket, which allows her to operate as a prostitute. Because of the anti-semitic laws then in place life for Jews was very difficult).

November 20th
After lunch went to Lady Fulton's Bazaar at the Grosvenor Galleries. There were hundreds of people and very mouldy things to buy, it was in aid of an institution for papier maché surgical aids.

November 21st, Wednesday
Flew to the Pall Mall to have lunch, it is a busy little place of rendezvous this restaurant and so many soldiers seem to go there to meet friends, but indeed soldiers one meets everywhere these days, and every square inch of ground is occupied by one of them. Directly after lunch Gertie S and I went off to the Opera, there to meet Mother, BG, Ell etc. "Samson and Delilah" was given and very lovely it was. One knows the music so well and the singing was splendid. We then drove back to the flat to tea and hastily dressing Ell and I went and dined at the Williamsons, it was long since I had seen either and it was so very nice talking over old times again.

November 22nd
Alas I had to return to home and duty today. I rushed off and did more shopping, and on my arrival (at the flat) Mother with grave face told me that Barbarina Booth had come to lunch, and I absolutely believed her. I turned to go into the dining room with disgust and there stood - Skippy - of all people in the world. I was so relieved I nearly fell upon him and embraced him! At 2.30 we drove together to Waterloo and there sadly took my homeward train and so ends my delightful jaunt.

I can't fill in my diary every day here because often nothing happens but garden work and Hospital and it makes me feel utterly uninspired. If there were not a war on nothing would please me better than to go on in our humdrum way but sometimes in these strenuous days I feel rather lost away from everything and everyone. However it cant last for ever.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The Battle of Bourlon Wood, November 30th, , by W.L.Wylie RA...Wynne has stuck this black and white print into her diary at the end of this month. 1917 was a particularly terrible year for the pilots, with life expectancy very low.

november.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Air raids, a shell-shocked friend, and a brother who is finally invalided home.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
R.D.Whitehead was one of Wynne's protegees - she took various young men under her wing, apparently with Herbert's quiet acquiescence, and Whitehead was a definite favourite. He had just been commissioned (Wynne visited him on his final course in Bristol in July), and the photos she has stuck in are of him as an officer and previously, as a Tommy. Her nickname for him was "the Jackdaw".

Below, a final photo of RDW in Somerset - and his card from France that she mentions arriving so quickly. On it he simply states that he will send an address later. The card comes via the Army PO, and carries the red censor stamp on the left. Note the lack of a stamp.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October - to the 10th

The war, the loss of many friends, and the general state of things is increasingly depressing Wynne. Reading her old diaries doesn't help
viewer_2.description:
Until October 10th
(Wynne is finding it very hard to write)
I cannot write my Diary as I used to, it's no use trying. Dates, days, weeks pass one another in aimless succession down here and life is one long period of waiting for the end of this seemingly everlasting war. The world is full of happenings, full indeed of endless horrors but I cannot bring myself to write about them all. Since writing in here nothing remarkable has happened to alter the even tenor of our ways. Miss H has been away to London for a week to see her man who has had a weeks leave and who has now left again. I have been very busy having perpetual toothache and making a series of visits to the dentist. Yesterday I got a wire from the Jackdaw saying he was to arrive tonight by the last train at Ilminster and I am going in to meet him. I suppose this means that he is on his way to the Front once more. London and the East country has been nightly visited by air raids. It always is now at full moon season. The damage appears not to have been very great however and people are getting quite accustomed to keep clear of the streets as soon as the "take cover" is sounded. Mother has practically lived downstairs with Mrs Haby and I am thankful she has her there. Yesterday not feeling very brilliant I spent the day in bed and amused myself by reading over some of my old Diaries written at Woolwich and Kildare but oh! what blues it gave me. Why half the men I mention have been killed - but what a gay life it all was in comparison to these days, what hundreds of people we saw every day, endless parties, bridge, concerts etc...in fact the World. Now of course wherever one lives all is changed. Social life except for some in Town is at a standstill and oh how utterly weary one is of it all, such a waste of life.
The other day I got a letter from Skippy (Skipworth - old friends from Aldershot days) sending me these flowers picked in the vicinity of his billet - to classify they are Hibiscus, Weigelia and Balsam. He says the wild flowers are wonderful but he doesn't know what they are. I hear since that he is now CRE 35 Div. so he is Lt Col...dear me, when I first knew him he was Capt. I also stick in here my latest PC from Phil Lyster (from a Prisoner of War camp - see next window). I do hope indeed that he'll get this exchange in Holland, it would indeed mean comparative freedom. How I do long to see him and hear all about his strange life, surely it all must come to an end someday and then what things they'll be able to tell us. Ell has been at sea for three weeks about. Now he and Mabel will cross one another somewhere on the way. (Wynne's sister-in-law was on her way back to Mozambique as a missionary).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Pages from October, containing the sealed envelope with Skipworth's flowers sent from the front line, a jokey prayer from the Westminster Gazette, and the POW card from Philip Lyster, saying that he hopes the prisoners might get moved to Holland. It is dated 31/8/17 and read:

"So very glad to get yours of the 7th July. Just now we think and talk of nothing except our chance of going to Holland. Dear Friend, I am very tired and very very old - and very bald - all that's left of me is hardly worth worrying over! My eyes have been a bit better lately and except for a more or less permanent headache am fairly it. However comparative freedom will work wonders I expect and after 3 years I ought to be fairly sure of going. You are lucky to have your man at home, good luck to him. it seems more than 3 years since the old days and yet they are very green in my memory and I long to live them over again. Please god I shall be able to write you a letter before long. Bless you. P"

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 11th - 16th

Her newly commissioned friend, R D Whitehead, goes back to the front for the 3rd time. Gardening and God help, but not much.
viewer_4.description:
October 11th, Thursday
I went into Ilminster to meet the Jackdaw last night and this morning he left again by the 10.35 to Town where he stays the night and sails tomorrow. I have been so glad to have seen him again before he leaves for the 3rd time for action. He looks so well and fit and is in the highest spirits at the thought of going. Not so I. It is always impossible to keep free from anxiety these days about someone or other, one lives in it always and I've had his care now for over 2 years. I spent the rest of the day gardening for whenever my mind feels down I get back to the earth, it is a great salve and there is very much to do these days.

October 12th
I spent my day in gardening as far as the rain would allow me, but it is really very trying this constant rain for there is so very much to do and I cannot work in wet mud. Sometimes just now there comes over me a sort of breathless feeling, shall I ever get it all done in time. I do so miss Poggy in this as in a thousand ways.

October 13th
I've been at Hospital nearly all day, it was pretty strenuous, so many to do for and such endless washings up. We have a new permanent cook there now, a nice girl seemingly.

October 14th
It was a perfect morning today as I rode up to Early Service, a slight frost had whitened the land and all was very still. Thank God in these times of anxiety one knows where to find help. We all went again to 11.0 and after lunch i went off by myself and gathered sloes for sloe gin and some blackberries. It was very lovely down there in the fields, so quiet and still and when one lives in such a scene there cannot but come to ones mind the dreadful chaos in which our dear men are living over there. The conditions are frightful, see enclosed cutting and one wonders how any come back alive. It is all too heart rending and oh! oh! how one longs and dies for the end of it all.

October 15th, Monday
A day of good hard work. I have had much happiness at intervals in 1917 but also much weariness - I don't mean to complain, God has been too good to me and mine for that, but one must feel the hideousness of it all. I find the dear earth a great salve to sickness of mind, my spring beds are nearly done and all is beginning to look tidy and decent once more.

October 16th
It has been a truly vile day, pouring and blowing all day, so I just occupied myself with household affairs all the morning and to tea came the Squire and 4 men, Jones, Francis, Sudwell and Gore, such a nice four. We played baby games and they amused themselves like children.
(Squire is Wynne's name for Mr Love - see back)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A contemporary report of the Passchendaele offensive...but Wynne seems to have known how appalling conditions were over there.

The report is from the Daily Telegraph of October 13th, . There is a lengthy article from Philip Gibbs with it.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 17th - 21st

Hospital whist drives, a plague of rabbits, and sloe gin instead of divine service.
viewer_6.description:
October 17th, Wednesday
This morning to my surprise at its quickness I received a PC from the Jackdaw, posted 15th saying he had arrived over there in safety. I have been gardening all day long. Alas a dreadful long List today, and Col. Godman among them. Soon there will be no one left of the old lot.
All day long I've been gardening. I worked from 10 to 4 and so felt I'd done something, after which I fed my fowls and rounded a thoroughly domestic day. I feel thankful that I have got my domestic jobs these days of stress and storm otherwise I should become a lunatic. The worst of it is that I have no one with whom I can discuss the happenings of the times, my little governess and Win are just a couple of children and sometimes I miss a grown up mind awfully.

October 18th.
This evening Win and I attended a Whist drive at Hospital. It was quite a big show and we were over 70 players, all the men played, and dozens of queer damzels from the neighbourhood, also the farmers, and we all spent a frisky evening hobnobbing with all and sundry. Oh these entertainments are a trial but quite amusing in their way as one has thank goodness a sense of humour and watches it all from an outside point of view.

October 19th
Little Harman came down to shoot and bagged one rabbit, these pests are continuing to be perfect plagues again and eat up everything. I am very weary of them and it is chiefly their presence which makes me long to flee this place which we certainly shall do as soon as our three years is up. (Wynne is referring to her lease. They took the house for three years, so had to stay there. As was common in that period, most people rented, and Wynne was no exception. None of the houses she lived in were her own. Wynne had other reasons to leave Hinton, not least a rather unpleasant whispering campaign waged against her by Mrs Pardoe at the village PO, along the lines that W might have connections to German spies and other nonsense...which given Wynne's family background, was a rather difficult situation since anti-German feeling was so strong in those years).

October 20th
At Hospital all day and to tea came two of the men, Brown and Walker by name. The first is a pleasant bug-a-boo who has created quite a flutter in the dovecot because he's a gentleman, a Varsity man and has taken his degree. The other also has elite relations but is certainly not a gentleman. He sings rather well but too loudly. I made him perform today and he nearly blew all our heads out of the window. (An interesting comment on class divisions, I think).

October 21st, Sunday
I broke the Sabbath this morning by refraining form going to Kirk and stopping at home to make sloe gin instead! It was only with the greatest difficulty that I managed to get any gin. Things are getting very short, I hear bacon and tea are scarce and I must write to my suppliers at once. H says they have a whiskey famine at Norwich and cant get any, but what we are undergoing is nothing compared with other countries. I have heard several times from the Jackdaw, he is now on the move. He has been posted to the 1st Cheshires and is of course in the Ypres district.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne, like everyone else, was becoming obsessed with food. Anyone who had a bit of ground grew what they could, and you can see constant references to vegetables, fruit, pickling etc in the diary. This cartoon she stuck into her October pages.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
October 22nd - 26th

Shortages in essentials, prices are steep, and the only available blouses are in silk, which are useless for the cold weather.
viewer_8.description:
October 22nd, Monday
Thank goodness my last visit to the dentist pro tem is over for I went in to Yeovil today and sat with him for one and a half hours. It was quite painless this time and the nerves of both teeth are now dead. I was lucky in getting taken in and brought back from the station by Squire Love. Tried to get flannel blouses but failed, there wasn't one to be had! Really things are in an odd way, all the winter blouses are silk and cotton and crepe de chine. Thank goodness I have a chamois jacket which keeps out all cold. I wish I had knickers of the same! It is getting pretty nippy now and we have fires in the evening but coal is almost unprocurable. Thank goodness I have some.

October 23rd
I worked again from morn till eve, and as soon as I get the beds tidy the rabbits dig holes all over them. I miss Pinkie's shooting round about, I cannot fag to spend the time doing it myself.

October 24th, Wednesday
This was "Our Day" down here and at an early hour Wood and Perrett came round with their flags for sale and later on Brown and Walker. The Hospital scoured the country and I am sure must have done awfully well as no one would refuse them. There was a show on in Crewkerne and a concert and all the men were taken in and didn't get back till 12.0!

October 25th
The only result of my enquiries for bacon is enclosed (see letter in next window). I daresay I could procure it locally at prohibitive prices, even that I am doubtful of, but in any case I'm not going to try and we must just do without it. I have a lot of eggs potted and so we must fall back on them. Fish is very expensive but I shall have to get my weekly supply again from Grimsby, After lunch I rushed off to attend a M.U. meeting at the Almshouses, and then I rushed back as I had five men to tea: Harvey, Smith, Osborne, Webb and Miller. We played spoof and snap afterwards with much vim and gusto.

October 26th
My Babbit has been in bed for 2 days with a heavy cold, poor darling. She could scarcely see out of her eyes but as usual the patient and uncomplaining little creature was quite content to stay up there playing with the cats and reading and playing Patience. Nootie and I bicycled down to have tea at Miss Blakes at Lopen. The roads are appalling, the mud goes nearly over our rims, coming back it was bright moonlight, so still and beautiful and we had no lamps but escaped the village policeman!
I felt as if I could ride for miles if it hadn't been for the roads.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: A letter from her bacon supplier, letting Wynne know that there was none available. It seems odd that she had to go to Bristol for this, but presumably such centralisation was to prevent country folk getting an unfair advantage. Below the bacon letter is a public notice about tea, reprinted from the Telegraph, and with a red letter notice stuck over it warning about the big price increases.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
October 27th - 31st

Wynne worried about RDW who is at Ypres. She is fully aware of the conditions there. She manages to get some extra rations in order to entertain her wounded from the hospital.
viewer_10.description:
October 27th, Saturday
I had a long day at Hospital today and stayed working till 4.0, taking the opportunity of doing some metal cleaning which sadly needed attention. I wish I were resident cook there, the work is fairly easy and it would be awfully interesting. Now of course going up once a week one can't take the same interest.

October 28th
This morning as I rode up at 8 to Early Service the world was white in the grip of winter, a brilliant sunshine over the scene that glistened all over with hoarfrost. All was very still and the roads were quite hard and crisp. I went to that service to find the "peace which the world cannot give" , it certainly can't at present, in these days of stress and strain, it is a wholesome comfort to go and lay all my anxieties and inward horrors there. To tea came Miss Busby, Miss Edwards and Gore, a nice fellow who is shortly leaving as he's marked out. We all sat round the fire after tea and ate nuts and roasted chestnuts till 6.15. when they left.

October 29th
I was much surprised to receive a F.P.C (Field Post Card) from DW today saying he was in Hospital sick, but relieved to get also a letter written two days after saying it had been a cold and he was rejoining his regiment that day. He is by now in the line of course as I constantly see mention of the Ist Cheshires as they are in that horrible Ypres cesspool. The horrors they are living through fill one with despair, how do they live through it? The country is in worse conditions than it has ever been before, thousands of deep crater holes filled with water, miles of bog and mud, morass and endless desolation. Our poor boys. Oh! how heartrending it all is, and today comes the fearful news of that splendid Italy's severe reverse, in 2 days they lose nearly all their hard-fought ground which it has taken them months and months to gain, not that this will make any difference to the ultimate end except perhaps in retarding it but it will cause such high glee in Germany and do much to raise their morale.

October 30th
All morning I spent in cake making. We shall be about 30 people at this Whist Drive. I've managed to extract two extra pounds of sugar from my grocer and I've tweaked all the flour out of my weekly ration of 30 lbs. We have no currants or raisins in our cakes but always use dates now. Tea also is a difficulty but I'll manage it all somehow. I feel these days that nothing one can do for them is enough after all the fearful horrors that they go through for us, dear blessed creatures, and its quiet enough for them down here.

October 31st
Much bustle and preparation for this evening's show. We pushed the school table to one side and arranged all the little tables in the middle, each with its cards, numbers and ash trays! We cleared the dining room likewise and had a stand up tea in there. The bachelor rooms and bathroom came in very handy, for the men didn't have to come in by the front door at all and I was saved much mud there in consequence. We started to play at 4.30 and finished at 7.30 with a tea interval mid way and when it was over we played games till 8.15 when they had to return. It was all great fun and I hope very much to do it again at Xmas time.

october.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The war grinds on, and the loss of so many friends is becoming unbearable. A month when the strain shows very clearly.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Two postcards of the village Wynne lived in in Somerset, which she stuck into her September entry. Hinton St George has not changed much since.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 5th

A surfeit of plums, potato problems, and fears about the air raids in London. 107 reported killed in Thanet.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Saturday
The wettest August I can ever remember is past and gone, and thank goodness for it. Since Mother came a month ago we've had about 3 days fine and only tea out once. Today is a slight improvement and after lunch Poggy, Pink, the Jackdaw and I went off into the Park to try and find mushrooms. Both boys last night were very seedy and felt horribly sick, it is the Plums I'm sure, they do this trick every year to some of us. Our mushroom hunt was unsuccessful, only finding one large one. We played games after dinner of Vingt et Un and varieties, for love of course. I quite missed my nightly Bridge.

Sept 2nd
Pink is all right again but the Jackdaw very sicky still so I administered a large dose which I hope will have the desired effect! We all went off the Kirk in the morning, and Poggy and I again in the evening, dragging poor DW also, his feathers being somewhat less ruffled.

Sept 3rd
My dear man left this evening and as it was the Crewkerne car I couldn't go in to see him off. Our local cars are no more at present because poor young Chambers died last week and Holt's car is out of order. We have been very busy cutting all the potato haulms in order to prevent the possibility of disease getting into them before we dig them. Its been an awful year for it.

September 4th
Mother left this morning and I went in to see her off walking back by the lanes. I hate her going up alone but I hope she'll manage all right. The papers are full of horrors, a raid over the Isle of Thanet on Monday night resulted in a bomb being dropped on Chatham Barracks and 107 men were killed and 86 wounded. They were all asleep and as there was a haze they were able to approach without being seen and so no warning was given.

September 5th
Poor Mother must have come in for the bad raid on London last night, it is bad luck it happened her very first night. I am anxious to hear how she fared. The Jackdaw left today so we are a small party again.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is a classic example of the little cuttings Wynne sometimes kept - this one from her paper quotes a Daily Mail columnist who is writing his column in the style of Pepys. The fear of an increasing bureaucracy and of the erosion of civil liberties is particularly relevant today!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 6th - 10th

An expedition to Beer in Devon to look for a butterfly. A change from the hospital chores.
viewer_4.description:
September 6th, Thursday
We had news of Mother this morning. She is all right but the planes were well over her house and in the middle of the night she had to walk down and up those 14 flights of stairs, how she did it I cant think and in future she is having her maids taught how to use the lifts as this sort of thing will happen again and again and she simply cant walk all that way. It is most unfortunate that she should live at the very top of the house, as its bound to get on anyone's nerves. I cycled over to the Rawlins to tea and on the way back my Pink met me and we sat awhile by the river in the quiet cool of the evening and it was very still and very lovely. There is something most delightful about the sound of running water.

September 7th
A Friday and 7th, my lucky day and number, almost everything nice that has happened to me has come on either one or another. Today it proved itself again by bringing Mabel with it. She arrived in the afternoon and it is a joy to have her again.

September 8th
Alas I had to go to Hospital toady and on arrival there realized that I was alone in my glory and had to cook for 30 people by myself. Cooking is nothing, its the amount one has to get through by 12.30, however one of the men did the potatoes which is an enormous help and saves no end of time.

September 10th, Monday
Yesterday passed uneventfully, with Mabel in bed as she had been so rushed about lately that she was quite done up. Today proving very lovely Pink and I set forth on an expedition to Beer (on the Devon coast, near Seaton). Mr Hayward had told him of a certain field there where "Clifton Blues" could be got so we determined to go and try to find them. We took train as far as Seaton Junction, going by the 9.41 and from there we rode to Beer, stopping by the way to have our lunch in the fields. By 3.0 we arrived at our destination and found such a jolly little place lying in the hollow of a step gully, a tiny old world fishing village. We left our machines at a pub and climbed the hill, arriving at our field, where to our joy we found the bug we sort (sic). The view was perfect, one could see right over Seaton with its red sandstone cliffs, on beyond to the curving point where the cliffs became yellow and white, the sea and sky were intense blue and all was very still and warm and oh! I longed - well, for all sorts of things.
At last it was time to go. We had tea in the hollow and then went down to the beach and watched the fish being brought in and sold, all sorts of bogey looking things and the smell! and then we went for a row round to the smugglers caves and so home getting back about 10.0! rather tired but with a ripping day behind us.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
This is just one example of the hundreds of notices that appeared in papers all over the country...and of course, these would only have been for those in society who could afford it. However even the humblest homes often went to the expense of funeral cards, photos and other mementoes, and would have tried to have at least a brief note in the local paper.

The Jacksons knew the Boones. Wynne, as an army wife, lost many of her close friends in this way.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 11th - 21st

Another friend is killed at the front. Wynne occupies herself with some displacement activity, and bemoans her aching teeth.
viewer_6.description:
September 17th, Monday
An uneventful week has passed. We have just meandered through it filling each day with such jobs as habitually come our way and so the time passes somehow. All time is much alike these days, one is in a continual state of waiting and marking time. Occasionally I get the most awful feeling of staleness on me - it doesn't come from idleness, God knows, I've so much to do that there is not sufficient time to do half but one gets so weary of this desperate war and its never ceasing horrors. One by one old friends gradually go West. I hear now that Capt Boone has died of wounds, and his poor wife has just had her second baby. Its too tragic and one just gets tired. My dear man came today to see Mabel before she sails.
(Henry Griffith Boone was in fact a Major when he died, on September 6th, leaving a wife, Margaret, and two children. He is buried in Mendinghem Militiary Cemetery, Poperinge, West Vlaanderen, Belgium).

September 18th
We all went down to Briar Mills this morning to gather fruit. It is sad to see the profusion which lies wasting there, masses of pears, apples, damsons all lying on the ground rotting and I have had permission to go and gather as much as I like for 9d a doz lbs! One day we went down and brought back 64 lbs of damsons which I jammed and bottled, luckily I still have a good deal of sugar left and so am using it for these as I used saved sugar for my garden fruit early in the summer. It is a sad and derelict little place, so lonely and far away, and must be awfully dreary in winter.

September 19th
I've had a horrible day - it has poured with rain from morn till night and I had to bicycle in to the station to go to Yeovil with the purpose of visiting Mr Dickin to have 2 teeth out with gas. I've been having so much trouble lately that i thought it best to have them out. Well he only managed to get one out in the time and so I must go again, such a bore. I also had three stopped after the extraction so by evening I'd had quite enough of it.

Sept 20th
I've done nothing all today as I am really feeling rotten, my gums ache as if they had been ripped with pincers and I have a vile swelling in my face.

Sept 21st
My dear son went back to college today, and I alas his Mother am thoroughly bereft. I wonder if any boy however much he must hate returning himself can realize what it means to us. I returned home to lunch thoroughly depressed, also with vile face ache and I have decided to go in to Dickin tomorrow and see what can be done.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: A Telegram - the sender is Wynne's brother, who had been invalided out of the front after fighting in Iraq, and was now coming home via South Africa. This one has printed letters - many were written. Note also the clock system for including times in the message.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 22nd - 26th

Wynne hears her brother is on his way home, but is sad to say farewell to her sister-in-law. More air raids reported.
viewer_8.description:
September 22nd, Saturday
On the opposite page is a surprising and most lovely piece of news that I found amongst my letters which in my agitation about the dentist I forgot to mention: my beloved (her brother, Ell) is actually coming home. Alas I fear on account of health but it will be splendid to have him again after 2 years absence. He is coming round by the Cape and so it will be long before we see him or can hear and I dread the horrible voyage these perilous days but God grant all my go well. My dear man left today and I went as far as Yeovil with him and had a most painful treatment of iodine forced in by electricity, a horrible experiment and I don't think I can stick that again so I hope it'll get well without.

Sept 23rd
I wanted much to go the Early Service with Mabel but I really felt too decayed, my mouth is so painful and all my teeth on edge. We rambled over the fields and saw one of the most beautiful sunsets I've ever seen, all gold and green and red.

Sept 25th
Another day of hateful goodbyes for I saw Mabel off by the 9.41 on her long journey. I felt so desperately left when I saw the train steam out and knew I could not see her again for 4 long years. Well, one should be used to saying goodbye these days for one does nothing else practically. I got to Earth as soon as I came home and dug and gathered potatoes all day long, a prosaic but healthful cure for a sore heart.

Sept 26th
The weather today just fits in with my mood. I am feeling utterly stale and unprofitable. All our house party have now gone, Miss Hall has returned and we are just ourselves once more and lessons are in full swing. More raids - every letter one gets is full of descriptions. Mother has taken to sleeping sometimes with Mrs Haly downstairs and is thinking of leaving Town for the weekend as there is a full moon and the Huns are sure to be busy. Its really awful and it is getting naturally on her nerves. Mary from Margate writes also about it, indeed this country is sorely beset, all had better congregate in Somerset.

(The diary picks up again in October, starting with a summary on October 10th)

september.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

A day out away from daily grind - another death, more farewells.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: These are postcards typical of the year - they all focus on the food and rationing issues. This one, and the one in the next picture window, were sent to the girls by their cousin Win, thanking both of them for birthday chocolates. Clearly some things were still available!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 8th

The news from the Front is terrible, and is accompanied by reports of the death of people Wynne knew. "Why should the cause of Right suffer so?", she asks.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Monday
Two "important" things happened today as well as the creation of several April fools! The grass was cut for the first time and I sat my second hen! Meanwhile the fearful carnage continues and our line is withdrawn day by day further and further back. One can hardly think about it, much less write. Thousands and thousands of our precious men are being taken prisoner and so many will come home no more.

April 2nd
I drove into Crewkerne this day with Win who left by the 10.35. It was a real break to see her train run out, she has lived with us so long and I miss her more than I can say. (Win was a niece who had been living with the Jackson's. Her parents were in India, and this had meant that she was unable to travel back to see them throughout the duration of the war. She eventually managed to get home in 1919).

April 3rd
I had a letter this morning from Mrs Hutch enclosing a line from Norah Hinton telling that her husband has been killed. He leaves her very nearly penniless and with five children, how she is going to exist I don't know. The Hutches are at Bournemouth - she will not go near their house at Folkstone because of the raids.

April 4th
Miss Hall, the children and I all motored into Yeovil today, she to leave and we to meet Pinkie. Pink looks very well, has finished his term by regaining his lost places and so has a chance of a Remove next term again, and then he will be within reach of the Upper School.

April 5th
Once again to Yeovil this time to the Dentist with all the family - that's to say the kids and I.

April 6th
A very busy day. First to hospital, where as we now have 33 men we had plenty to do. Then at 3.0 I hied me to the Church there to meet the girls and redecorate the font, and then at 3.30 to a committee meeting of the Nursing Association of which I am Sec. and Tres.. Got through a lot of business and presented my Report and Balance Sheet and thank goodness its over because it really does entail a lot of work.

April 7th
A horrid cold wet day which I have spent in writing.

April 8th, Monday
Today I get a letter from Mrs Kelly telling me that poor Hilary has been killed, another case of the widow's only son. There is no end of the misery and the horror of the present time and one is utterly sick of it. I cant write much about it all here for it is endless and every day seems more and more hopeless. The Retreat continues and God knows why the Cause of Right should suffer such a reverse. Surely, one feels, that if as some people think these horrors have been permitted as a punishment for sin, the World has suffered sufficiently. It is all very mystifying and bewildering - but at the back of it all one knows that the Good God is working all the time, only how weary one is of it all.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The second card from Win, postmarked 12th April .

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 9th - 17th

Parliament debates raising the age of conscription to 50. Haig issues his famous Order of the Day. At home, rationing appears to be in a muddle.
viewer_4.description:
April 9th, Tuesday
Pink and I bicycled up to Liddons after lunch today and took our tea. We went in the hopes of finding white violets but we were too late. We went and sat down in the Rose Willow Wood and there in the complete solitude had our tea and watched birds through H's field glasses.

April 11th
I make no entry for yesterday as I spent it in bed. Read Blackwood, a very interesting number. Also I read the paper from cover to cover and was frightfully thrilled by the Debate on the raising of the age limit to 50 and the Irish Question.

April 12th
An unexpected call to Hospital where I and Miss Poole wrastled (sic) with the food for 40 people! A perfect day and the news from the Front does not coincide with it for we have now lost Armentieres and the Retreat continues. We are in full swing of Meat Cards now. Butter and Margarine hang fire and though all cards are ready and issued a wire has been circulated today that we are not to be rationed after all, what a waste of time, energy and paper, and what a muddle everything always is. I am very pleased to be able to report that yesterday I got 12 chicks out of 12 eggs, and such a strong brood.

April 13th, Saturday
My dear Noots' birthday, she is 14, and from now on stays up to supper so is promoted. Alas no lovely cake with candles and a plain Victoria sponge is looked upon as a great luxury. To Hospital again, and once more was I the cook and in a tiny frying pan I had to fry about 80 piece of liver! The news from France is really rather desperate. The hoards are not so far from Bethune now which is a most important junction and which if captured will make Calais a good deal easier. I herein stick the C-in-Cs message to the troops. Its very English and consequently very fine, but how grave and serious.

April 14th, Sunday
There is now being raised in the House the very big questions - the Man Power Bill which is to raise the age to 50, and the Irish Conscription. The latter proposal has raised a storm from the Irish members and there are tremendous scenes in the House. Our Govt seem determined and the Irishmen quite as much in the other direction and God knows what trouble will result over it all if it is passed. Verily this unhappy country is a thorn in our flesh.
Service was very earnest and sad today for honestly at this time one cannot help wondering how long we'll be left in peace to pursue our daily round. It seems an awful fear to voice but its difficult to get it from one's mind and of course one doesn't say such things. I keep wondering how my dear friend Skippy is and where he is and all the other blessed men we know of which there are so very many.

April 15th, Monday
Such a bitter icy wind is blowing. Most valiantly walked over to the Blakes to tea. On my way back I gathered handfuls of the most lovely primroses to send to Annie Martin who lives in the London slums, a wretched cheerless thing to do.

April 16th
So cold again. H and Pink carpentered all day, the girls tidied out their dolls house and I wrote letters and sewed garments and so the day passed busily.

April 17th
No warmer today and the rain continues. Cut our first bunch of asparagus today! Alas the rats have eaten Babies' two new wee rabbits. It's too tragic, they were so lovely and we are all sick and disgusted and today a great wiring in has been taking place up there and they ought to be rat proof now. My new chicks so far are all right thank goodness.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Sir Douglas Haig's famous "backs to the wall" Order of the Day, as published in the British press.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 18th - 24th

Home chores and memories of her marriage proposal 19 years before. The Home Front means fighting rats and raising chickens.
viewer_6.description:
April 18th, Thursday
Each day now I have to record vile cold weather. We try and keep warm by sawing wood with the crosscut and such like things. H is busy making trays for storing apples and onions, they will be a godsend for so many went rotten last year and the rats eat half our onions. Talking of rats we have laid down poison and moved the bog barrel trap to the ash heap and anxiously await results. I am so afraid they will play havoc with my chickens like last year.

April 19th
We have had the Sweep here and oh! the havoc and general upset and I shall be thankful when all is over for carpets are all up and china washing in full swing.

April 20th
At last after 6 weeks I've heard again from Eve (her sister in India) - her letter is dated February 20th so must have been round by the Cape. Sowed many seeds this morning. All the rat poison has been taken, hurrah! and the trap bait too so in a day or two will begin to see what luck we have.

April 21st, Sunday - First cuckoo! Swallows!
Nineteen years ago today my fate was decided, and the balcony of the Watson's Annex Hotel, Bombay played a great part in my life! Mother writes that Ell has been up for his Board but they wouldn't pass him for abroad so he has returned to Southampton where his Remount job continues to suit him. Thank God he and H are safely out of this horrible fighting. (The Marriage Proposal - for Wynne's description of the marriage proposal)

April 22nd
We completed Potato planting so that is off our minds. I am much bucked today too by getting another splendid brood out, 10 chicks from 11 eggs, all such healthy little creatures. I am potting eggs hard and have over 400 already.

April 23rd
First to the Hospital with H, then to Thornton and afterwards Mrs Lowe. After lunch we all went down to pick primroses and have tea at Bryce's Mills and it was lovely there, and then I cycled to Crewkerne to a meeting and got home at 8.0 so I've done a good days work.

April 24th, Wednesday
Was called to Hospital today and worked there till nearly 3.0. At about 3.0 Babbit called for me (Eleanor, her daughter), and we bicycled away on a long ramble getting home at 6.0. We first went to Allowenshay to visit a farm where they sell cheese and fixed up with them to supply us. We then rode on to Dowlish Wake where we stopped and had tea in a field, on through Cudworth, up and up a long hill right to the top of Upper Chillington and down home through Dimington. It was a perfect day, very hot and still and I've never seen the country looking more beautiful, every tree in a different shade of green, all the hedges brilliant with freshness and all simply lined with primroses. I've never seen such masses and enormous ones; dog violets, periwinkle, and soon the wild garlic will star the banks. Dowlish Wake is a lovely village as old as the hills, Allowenshay ditto, tucked away in a sleepy hollow surrounded by deep rich pasture land, and the farm we went to there keeps 70 cows!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.excerpt:
A portion of Philip Gibbs' newspaper report which appeared on April 13th:

"51st Still Sticking It".
viewer_7.description: A part of Philip Gibbs' article - it gives a flavour of the type of reporting that was going on during this very dangerous period...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 25th - 30th

Country visits and chopping wood for next winter. The news continues to be grim, but Wynne hopes that the retreat is planned.
viewer_8.description:
April 25th, Thursday
The weather continuing perfect we made another expedition today and rode over to Ham Hill, through Merriott, Norton and Stoke. We put our machines in a hedge and climbed up. Ham Hill is famous for the hamstone which is quarried there and of which all the houses are built here in former times. It was an immense Roman encampment, the biggest I have ever seen, and it has the most wonderful earthworks. Noots and I dug for fossils and treasures - we found many bones, shells and also Roman pottery, one quite good piece, black with ornamental cuttings. It is a most curious hill and dips steeply down into the valley below exactly like a cliff into the sea. (Wynne perhaps did not realise that the fort is much older, probably dating from the Bronze age, and becoming a very large Iron Age hill fort which Vespasian conquered in AD 45 - the Romans might have camped there temporarily, but created a permanent camp at Ilchester - but the work had been done by others, not them).

April 26th
Still very hot and we set forth to go beyond Clapton, a dull ride through dull country, but we came at length to a small wood and stream where the kids paddled.

April 27th
