For several days past I have not mentioned the War because one feels sometimes at the end of one's thoughts about it, it is all so desperate and this awful battle rages still. We continue to retreat and more and more ground is lost, but all according to plan, I hope. Today news came of an extraordinary feat by the Navy who bombarded Zeebrugge and blocked up the submarine base there by sinking ships in the harbour. The Germans must be pretty sick. Hospital today and more parsnips to peel! Oh how I wish they'd never been invented, they are like elephants hides and leave one's hands a bright yellow.

April 28th
To Early Service, and H now being a Church Warden handed round the bag! We employed our whole afternoon in pricking out seedlings and repotting tomato plants. Sunday is no longer a day of rest!

April 29th
A cold North Wind, but we got hot this afternoon as we have bought the wood in the hedge in Best's field and are busy cutting it. It is a big job but ought to supply us with wood for the winter.

April 30th
Today we progressed still further with the hedge cutting and went all day at it. Its a long job. Every bundle we tie up and every trunk we fell we think of the lovely store we shall have in the winter.

april.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The big German Offensive. Haig's famous "Our Backs to the Wall" special Order of the Day.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne stuck this Hymn into her entry for August 4th. It was sung at the anniversary service at St Margaret's, Westminster...and the previous year had been sung at Westminster Abbey.

Wynne also stuck this rather touching article into August - clearly so she could think of something other than war for a change...it is about Greenwich, in London, and she didn't cut it out very well.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 7th

War news improves with American and French advance. Wynne remembers the start four years ago.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Wednesday
As I spent my day at Hospital yesterday there was nothing to write about except the unsavoury smell of the sink and tomorrow's dinner of fish! Mother came down from Town for the Aug holiday today, such a joy to see her again after so long an absence. I haven't seen her since Feb. Mother is looking very well and is greatly assisted by a patent crutch she has and prances along like a two year old. Her train was nearly an hour late owing to the holiday traffic and when it arrived it was full of children going to the sea. I wouldn't take a family to the sea these precarious days, for one thing one would probably go short of food!

August 2nd
All day long it has poured with rain and so I've sat and talked 19 to the dozen, and worked and written and got through many house jobs.

August 3rd
To Hospital I did not go today and sent Florrie instead. I am glad to get off some of it whilst Mother is with me.

August 4th
"Remembrance Day"
All through the land this day is being commemorated by special services for it is 4 years ago today since War was declared, 4 long years of anxiety and misery and loss for the whole world. It brings back to one's mind much that one would willingly forget, but none of which one ever will. Many people think that this winter will see the end of it all, the Americans joint in must make a difference. Their weight in numbers surely must appall the German heart (if they have one) and by next year there will be 4 million more of them in the field. The Germans daily retreat, they would say "according to plan", but we know better. The atrocities they commit on each evacuation are as foul as ever they were in Belgium and whole ghastly devastation goes on as usual. We went to Early Service and the church was very full. i wondered what was in the minds of us all, all through the land this day, every church of every denomination at each service is to give its collection money to the Prisoners of War fund and I am keen to know what the grand total will be. It is a splendid thought and I wonder from whose brain it emanated.

August 5th
We are much heartened by the War news these days. The French and Americans are having great success in driving back the Germans and gradually bit by bit we are regaining the ground lost last month. We too are doing well and the Hun is having his turn of Retreat but it really is like the pendulum of the clock and as it continues to go on the world becomes shorter and shorter of food.

August 6th
To Hospital but I managed to get off early and return to tea. Sister leaves for a fortnight's holiday and Miss Clark does ditto for a month so the air is clearer!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: An article from the Observer, dated August 18th . It is a long article, and only a part is copied here...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 8th - 20th

Endless chores, but the fresh news from the Front continues to be encouraging. The W.I. is now flourishing - lectures on Servia and a vegetable show.
viewer_4.description:
August 8th, Thursday
Mother left today and I went and saw her off at the station. Pink returned and BG arrived so I was on the road most of the day. BG arrived at about 6.20 looking so well and just the same as ever and it is so delightful to have her. I am hoping she will give us all her holidays. (BG was Wynne's old governess).

August 11th
The days succeed one another in unvarying business. It is either Hospital or garden every day. Sometimes there comes over me the longing for a real good period of idleness.

August 12th, Monday
This day our Women's Institute held their third monthly meeting, a lecture by Miss Pares of the Scottish Women's Red Cross Hospital, telling us of their experiences in the Servian retreat, followed by a vegetable show. It was held in the Lowes garden. At the conclusion I gave away the prizes and then Sgt Major Higgins auctioned all the exhibits for the benefits of the W.I.Fund. We got two 2nd prizes but the Lowes vegetables were too good for us. There was great competition and rivalry and many quilps and cranks over the auction.

August 18th, Sunday
I have missed out nearly a week because it has just passed away like all others. I suppose future generations when they read this important document would be interested to hear that though there is a war on we still get up in the morning (I at 5.30!), work in hospitals and gardens, have our food, wonderful to relate, go to bed at night in the usual way and start again the next day, but one cannot go on writing on such exciting topics, one's diaries would become too thrilling.
Each day the paper contains fresh news of our successes which is so very cheering and makes life more worth living. B and I went for a long walk today to Dimington and home through the Park where we saw the camp and lots of "be-breeched"young females hopping about!

August 19th
Ell's birthday, bless him. He is still at Swaythling at the Remount Depot and hears nothing further from the India Office. I wish I could see more of him but he cannot get away, nor can I. (Wynne also notes she received letters from her sister in India and her sister in law in Mozambique, in spite of the distances and problems).

August 20th
This has been a very hot day and I have spent it idling in bed. Mother writes that Oswald (Swayne, married to Wynne's cousin Brenda) is off to the Front again in a fortnight's time. Daily fresh evidences are published of German cruelty and further stories of their brutality to prisoners have lately come to light. Just lately an entirely new device was discovered - stretcher bearers approached a dead man to carry him away, in his hand was a grenade and one man noticed it was not of our pattern and found it was a live one so placed that directly they touched him it would have exploded. Charming simple minds they have.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: There were many atrocity stories during the war, beginning very early with the German incursion through Belgium. Wynne was sceptical early on (as you can read) but clearly considered many of them true by ...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
August 21st - 31st

A Luxury Tax has been imposed. News arrives of her friend Philip Lyster's wedding - as an ex POW he is still restricted to a neutral territory.
viewer_6.description:
August 21st, Wednesday
This top cutting is from some evidence lately to hand, comment is superfluous, only one thinks in amazement of the fertile brains which can devise tortures worse than any savage tribe has ever yet succeeded in inventing. The smaller cutting is amusing, there has lately been passed the Luxury Tax, on pianos, clothes, jewellery, vehicles, scents, foods etc and so now everything is at standard prices, even gloves and shoes, and if you chose to pay more you have to pay the tax, so much in the 1/-. We shall shortly take to grass and leaves. I personally haven't had a new coat and skirt for 4 years, my best one being 5 years old, and for all I care it will be 5 more years before I cast it.

August 23rd
Ell writes that he has a Board upon the 4th Sept and if they pass him he will have to go to India again. I hardly feel that they will, seeing he has an enlarged spleen which means fever at the slightest heat but I shall be glad when I hear the result of the Board. How much I long to see him - I look upon all this time as time wasted as when and if he goes out again goodness knows when he'll be home.

August 24th
A hard day's work - up as usual at 5.30 and worked in the plot until 7.0, then chickens, rabbits, frames etc. Hospital from 10 to nearly 3.0, home and swept the drive tidy, cleaned chicken houses and fed them and pranced down to the plot for rabbit food. Supper 8.30 and bed at 9.45! A full programme!

August 25th, Sunday
To Early Service with H. BG and I to Kirk at 6.0. Shelley preached on the evil of underestimating the importance of little things, an excellent subject, but he always preaches as though we were all children or village idiots and need simple language. I daresay he's right! I got yesterday this announcement from Phil Lyster of his wedding, it seems so strange to read it, quite a fashionable affair and it seems so odd under the circumstances, he so lately a prisoner. (You can see earlier letters from Lyster when he was in Germany).

August 26th
Today Mother arrived.

August 27th
At Hospital all day, sister is in great trouble, her son being dangerously wounded. She heard apparently on Friday and has had no line since or wire. It is horribly anxious work waiting and I fear it looks bad.

August 28th
I am making marrow jam and have made 18lbs using only 3½ of sugar. It is not really the kind I like but I am getting the proper receipt from Mrs Young.

August 29th - 31st
Win arrived. We are now 13 in the house, a very gay party.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The news of Philip Lyster's wedding. Philip was an old friend who had been captured at the very start of the war, and who in was released into neutral territory as part of a negotiated deal. He was not able to travel to the UK, so his fiancee came to Holland for the wedding. The wedding service you can see in the small window you have come from - it arrived in the special free mail "Service des prisonniers du Guerre" envelope you can see at the bottom of this page. In the left corner of tht envelope you can see written "Major Lyster R.F.A. Interned at de Ruyter Straat 54, The Hague, Holland".

Immediately below is the news article about the event. The wedding took place on July 23rd.

august.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

At last the War news improves - Americans in action!

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The article Wynne mentions on December 7th

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 1st - 10th

The flu epidemic rages. No interest shown in the coming election, but Wynne exercised by articles about Germany and the returning troops.
viewer_2.description:
December 1st, Sunday
The last month of the year has arrived, and it is mild and sunny today. For the sake of our comfort these coal-less days one hopes it may continue but I fear until we get a period of frost this terrible scourge of Influenza will continue. There seems no abatement and people all over the world are dying like flies, never since the days of the Great Plague has there been such mortality and we with all our hygiene and science seem unable to check it. I am glad to be in clean country air though there is also much of it down here.

Dec 7th, Saturday
I have missed out a week as there has been nothing to recount. Hospital today for a final clean up but it is closed for the present and so I am free from that job. It seemed so strange up there, all the wards empty and al the clothes and bedding piled up in heaps. I gathered large pans of final dust and took Pink up who did the kitchen grate and came out looking like a sweep!
One day this week our member, Colonel Herbert, had a meeting at Merriott to which we went. There were not a dozen people present - a pity as he spoke well, but I hear that the Liberal member had the same luck, people are not keen on politics at this election, at any rate not here. We are to have three meetings for women in this village and I am curious to see how they go off. I don't believe half the women know that they have the vote even! The papers this week have had some very interesting articles by Gibbs of our advance into Germany and I have cut one out.One simply cant realise that our army with the rest are streaming into Germany with the intention of squatting there until the whole indemnity is paid, meanwhile though we provide our own food Germany has got to pay for it. The other cutting by Leonard Spray is an account of the return of the German armies. If these people had been clean fighters and had played fair how much more tragically this would read, but as it is one's heart is stoney. There is an article in Blackwood this month called "For Women" by one. It is the most fearful reading I have ever read and if the women of England have any souls in their bodies they will see to it that these ghastly horrors are not forgotten. It is not the Army alone but the whole nation is poisoned all through.

Dec 8th, Sunday
How could anyone after reading an account like this have any pity left, any mercy in their hearts or anything but the hardest determination that justice, not revenge, but ordinary and common justice, shall be meted out to these devils. The description of the Lille Black Hole makes one wonder that any man came out alive and even if alive how could they retain their brains. How horrible and literally fiendish it all is, and this is supposed to be a human race. This cutting about the fate of the poor Romanoffs is another proof. Its all too frightful.

Dec 9th
It has been a vile day, cold, wet and grey. I was out at intervals all day, from 10 to 10! I spent the morning in Crewkerne shopping, then after lunch I went up to baby Welfare and had the usual four and at 6.30 I went up again, this time walking in a streaming torrent to the meeting of the W I. To my great surprise we had 33 or 35. We had a very cheery little meeting ending up with tea and music.

December 10th, Tuesday
A day at home spent when the weather permitted in wood sawing and snatches of gardening. My morning washing is no longer such a nightmare as it was however, as I now have the water put into a hay box over night and it is quite hot in the morning. Formerly owing to the delightful hot water arrangements of this house I always had to have cold.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 11th - 16th

Election Day on 14th. Women Vote for the first time! "I, a mere woman, went to record my vote".
viewer_4.description:
Dec 11th
I was reading last night in my diary of 1912 and found it most interesting in the light of present day events. It was just the time when the Suffragettes were making such exhibitions of themselves and I describe Town a wreck from their excesses. Well they have their way now for we go to record our votes on Saturday. Fools they may have been then and certainly behaved in a very disgusting way but in this War I think our sex has redeemed any former folly for Lloyd George last Monday speaking at the Queen's Hall to a meeting of women emphatically declared that we should never have won this war without the women and then gave figures of the numbers who had gone on to Munitions, the Land, the Hospitals, Railways, Air Board etc etc. Indeed there is little that they have not worked at. If the men had suddenly been called upon to look after the house and babies I bet they would have washed the latter in ink and given it kippered herrings to eat. We go tonight to hear the Labour candidate speak, one Kelly.
(Later) A most bombastic speaker, a candidate for the job of PM I should think, and a woman speaker. The meeting when asked to hold up hands for Kelly held up none at all.

(See also April 1913, for April 5th diary entry and news of Mrs Pankhurst)

Dec 12th
What a dark time of year this is, when we get up in the mornings one cant see across the room and owing to the need of economy in everything I dress in the dark. It is extraordinarily warm which is a blessed mercy with coal at 2/7d per cwt. We never light a fire till the evening and then only of stick and coke, no coal is burnt except in the kitchen engine house and chicken boiler. I have been sitting on committees from 4 until nearly 7, the first that of the W.I. and then for the Hospital tea and tree on the 23rd. I have been put in charge of the latter, a big job.

Dec 13th, Friday
I am at present amusing myself by reading over old diaries. The one I am engaged on at present is 1913. What tons and heaps of fearful parochial and camp work I did, besides all the entertaining and dining out and then the number of times I used to fly to Town! What a strange difference, when (now) a spoilt dish becomes a calamity, a spot of ink a tragedy, and an extra 2d on the butcher's book an occasion for fear of bankruptcy!

Dec 14th
I heard today from Ell, he was just leaving Suez. I cannot help wondering where our feet will be wandering this time next year. A little house and two servants is my heart's desire. I long for a small balance in the Bank too for a change, which we can never hope to have in this place. Besides I am sick of the "Trivialities" who live in this village with their petty and most malicious gossip.
RED LETTER DAY FOR WOMEN!
This was Polling Day and I, a mere woman, went to Record My Vote. Below is the man of my choice! My number on the register is 105. It was so strange today at the Poll to see the women rolling up and several old
boo boos brought their wives all dressed in their blacks and I doubt if many knew their rights from their left! Well, its been a great event and hardly won.

December 15th, Sunday
I am much elated because my hens have begun to lay again after a cessation of about six weeks!

December 16th, Monday
I went up this morning to witness a sweet making of Dorothy Lowes, she is an expert hand at it and makes them beautifully. Old Mrs L came pottering around and was severely reprimanded by DL who dismissed her abruptly with many dears and darlings as is the wont of people when snubbing one another! The climax being reached when she found that night lights had been bestowed in the same box as her cocoa butter to keep them from the mice.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne's election day card, for her favoured candidate. December 14th was the first time women had been allowed to vote.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 17th - 23rd

The children are home for Christmas. Preparations begin in earnest, and the charity Hospital party goes off well.
viewer_6.description:
December 17th
My joy was complete when I met today at Taunton my dear darlings. I found them (the girls) on arrival in the Refreshment Room, having got there sooner than they expected. I got their reports the other day and felt very glad and proud. I think I should die if I got a really bad report of any of them.

Dec 19th, Thursday
All the children including my dear Win are with us now and the house rings with "merry laughter" and much stampeding! Win looks splendid. She has bought all her outfit and now awaits her passage which may come any day. (Win had had to stay in England for the duration of the war, and was only now able to return to India to be reunited with her parents).
Nootsie is learning milking and had her first lesson today. She is also to learn butter making.

December 20th
A day is over of which I am glad as it has been spent at the dentist in Yeovil. I had as usual 6 teeth stopped, Pink and Baby nothing and Noots two tiny ones. It was market day and a very big crowd, hundreds of little jingle carts containing farmers and their wives and all sorts of booths and treat sellers haranguing and shouting out their wares and the shops were crowded. One was actually able to buy Xmas cakes and chocolate today!

Dec 21st
On Monday there is to be a huge entertainment at the Hospital for all the staff and I have been put in charge of the tea. We cooked cakes and mince pies all day long, accomplishing 308 pieces! We are to provide for 50. I dash round the village on various errands, do up parcels, write letters, frantically finish sewing last stitches to gifts until my brain is fair mazed. I thought I was so well ahead this year too!

Dec 22nd
To Church in the morning, most awfully cold. Our sermon surpassed itself for dullness, of which I was sorry as it was on the subject of the sacrament and might have been so good but Shelley is no preacher.

Dec 23rd
By the time the day was ended I had had about enough. I went up to Hospital in the morning and arranged the tea room, set the puddings to boil and clawed in all the kettles, pots and pans, cut up sandwiches etc etc. Tore home to lunch, changed and went back again. At 4.45 all was ready, and the lions fed - they did feed, and all at length rose up stiff! At 6.0 a crowd more arrived and the Xmas tree was superintended by Shelley as Father Xmas and he did it awfully well. We had games, refreshment and dancing and really it was a very jolly evening.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is the card sent by Wynne's brother, Elliot, to wish the family a Happy Christmas. Note it is passed by the Censor, Base EEF, and has a Shepheards Hotel stamp on it, so it must have been posted there. This was a famous meeting place in Cairo, much used by expats. He has written "On Active Service" across the top - hence the lack of a postage stamp.

"Merry Xmas to you all. Wish I were with you. Just leaving here. Best of luck." 26.11.18

 

I wonder what became of these soldiers? So many came over to Europe, suffered terribly from the conditions, and did not really receive adequate recognition for their sacrifices...

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 24th - 31st

A peaceful Christmas at last, and teh first dance in four years. The election returns a Coalition, but the MP Wynne voted for gets in. Postage costs complained about.
viewer_8.description:
December 24th, Xmas Eve
Here is Xmas Eve and we have just finished filling the four stockings! It is getting late but I daren't go to bed yet because on these occasions the kids don't go to sleep for hours. I to Hospital this morning to clean up, then to Church to decorate, home to lunch and afterwards we decorated the house and tree and made paper chains afterwards, this latter reminded me so of old and ancient times. Tonight we actually had carol singers for the first time since the War began. I went to my old Almshouse people this morning to distribute a little tea.

December 25th, Xmas Day
Once again Xmas has come and gone and I am sad for its been so extra happy this year feeling that one could legitimately make merry. At dinner we had no turkey, but two large cockerels did duty instead, and a plum pudding I managed to secure.

December 26th, Thursday
It has been horribly cold the last few days so it was an effort this evening to shed our warm garments and dress in flimsy fabrics for the Hayward's dance, a children's dance from 6 to 10.30. It was the first dance ours had been to. It was really jolly to see people dancing again after 4 years abstinence. Personally I frisked about with the children like a two year old and by the end of the evening I was dead! It seemed so strange to be actually dancing again - one has felt during these last four years as though everything were at an end.

December 27th
So mild again today but Oh! how I hate these inky mornings and getting up in complete darkness to feed the chickens is a torture, but they are repaying us well now and we get 9-10 eggs a day so I am hoping to sell some and help this food bill which is an awful one these days.

December 28th
I've spent my day in mending clothes, undressing the tree, washing brushes and cleaning chicken houses. Dear me how thrilling it all sounds.

December 29th
I have spent the day writing reams of letters. Postage these days with the extra ½d tacked on is really an awful expense, and the pounds one spends in stamps is appalling. (What would she make of postage costs today?!)
I am at present reading one of Walter Scott's novels, how can I? is what I ask myself, but if one can get away from the stilted language and prudish ideas there is really much interesting history to be gleaned. This one is Anne of Geierstein, in two volumes and very small print.

December 30th
The papers contain the great news of the Coalition Victory, a clean majority. Amongst the list of defeated ministers are Asquith, McKenna, Snowdon, Ramsay-Macdonald and many other horrors. Our own member, Colonel Herbert, beat both the others and came out with a majority of 2933. I am rather amused at the women's bid for seats. 16 stood and only one was returned, a Sinn Feiner from Dublin!!! However they'll do better next time doubtless and meanwhile can air their opinions freely.

December 31st, Tuesday
The last day of the Old Year. Thank goodness that it and its preceding three have passed away. No such four years have ever brought with them such untold misery and anguish to the whole world and one now hopes that better and saner times may come for all of us that are left after this frightful upheaval. Tonight according to custom we all sat up and saw the New Year in. First we played games with halfpence in the pool. We then turned our attention to Table Turning but they wouldn't work out, our company being too young and unformed to get up sufficient magnetic current! As the church clock struck 12 we opened the front door and all went out on to the starlit terrace and dancing round in a ring sang the usual Auld Lang Syne. The church bells were ringing far and near and continued to ring until 12.30. Tonight they are sounding the "All Clear", and indeed it is a fine thing to feel we are "All Clear", at any rate from War.

(At the end of 1918 Wynne stepped down from being President of the local W.I. and also Secretary of the Nursing Association, and by the end of the following year had left Hinton for ever.)

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Christmas cards from the serving soldiers the family was in touch with in - first, cards from the 33rd Division, partially obscured by a card from the 17th Division, the inside of which you can see below. And at the very bottom, a card from the 17th Division Royal Artillery.

"40 Miles and still going strong" - the advance is marked on the card, ending at Neuvilly. This was the 17th's progress from August 23rd until October 11th.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.description:
More Christmas cards Wynne has stuck into the back of her diary - this time one from the 5th Division from Gore-Browne, and one from Mesopotamia - in both cases I have included the inside as well:

Below, the inside picture, enlarged...

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description: Wynne stuck this curious article into her final pages - it's an interesting addition to the story, and the Karolyi curse is still well known...

december.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. Women vote in the general election for the first time. The flu epidemic continues.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Meatless Day Menu - two days, Tuesday and Friday, had been ordained as to be meatless under the Defence of the Realm Act. Note also the cover charge (table money) and the war tax of 2d in every shilling, quite a high percentage - virtually the equivalent of 17.5% VAT that we pay today!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 6th

Rationing in London, ferrreting in Somerset. The Meatless Day Menu makes its appearance.
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Friday
Off to the Stores again and there wrestled with crowds and a paucity of stock and then took bus to Trafalgar Sq. Whilst waiting there for my change of bus I realised from the decorations on the King Charles statue that it was yesterday the anniversary of his execution. Wreaths of scarlet flowers and ribbons, laurel leaves and violets were hung around it from the Jacobite clubs and Royalist families. How strange that this sentiment should live so long. I lunched again with my Ell. Today is a meatless day ,there are two in Town just now - Tuesday and Friday - and here is our bill of fare (you can see it in the first window). Very good it was and one certainly doesn't miss meat under these circumstances. We went on afterwards to see "General Post" at the Haymarket, a piece to please democracy, quite the rottenest thing I've ever seen, fool characters and altogether banal but its been running for months and is always crowded by the mob. I only hope I may be mouldering in the grave when this state of affairs becomes general.
For old times sake we went and had tea at the Piccadilly, that erstwhile haunt of the very smart now crowded with the New Army and their very questionable or frumpy lady friends. The place was full of ghosts for me and entirely shorn of its former glory. Again we were given a most meagre tea and came away hungry, at least I did being accustomed to large hunks of bread and jam. I've had no margarine for tea ever since I came up.

Feb 2nd
Alas my time in Town is over and I don't know why I say alas, because though i love dashing around here I'm always glad to be back home again, and really in these times of most difficult food problems ones place is at home. Ell and I spent the morning at the Imperial Exhibition at Burlington House. It is of War Relics and most interesting, containing trophies and many splendid photos enlarged. I said goodbye to him at 12.30. The result of his Board is most disappointing - they will not pass him for any foreign service whatever so for the present he is debarred from leaving the country. Its awful bad luck .

Feb 3rd
As we are still in quarantine we cannot yet appear in church so my day was spent chiefly in writing letters and doing odd jobs. After lunch H, Win and I walked to Brices Mill there to gather snowdrops which grow in masses in that deserted old garden. I heard a thrush sing out his high clear call, most perfect. He sang of his wedding day which comes on the 14th of the month and he told the world at large how very beautiful was his lady and how entirely happy he was.

Feb 4th
Today the rain is coming down in a flood so nothing can be done out of doors.

Feb 5th
A clear day and H, Harman and Davis have been ferreting. It is the first time we have used Ell's ferret Jacky and she did very well. They managed to get 6 rabbits which is six pests less, and besides they mean food.

Feb 6th
I spent the day pottering around doing odd jobs such as picking over the apples, sowing various seeds and such like. There is much to be done now.

On the back of one of the cuttings Wynne placed in February, are some poetic pastiches regarding the current rationing - I suspect these became quite common, but they also reflect the poetry that was popular at the time (ie: Fitzgerald's Omar Khayyam and Tennyson, poets almost every soldier knew by heart):

"Here with a scrap of Bread beneath the Bough
A Cup of Tea, a Crumb of Cake - I vow
My Inside still feels like a Wilderness,
But 'tis all that Lord Rhondda will allow."

and

Come into the larder, Maud!
For the tins of tongue have flown.
Come into the larder, Maud,
Where the shelves no longer groan.

The prawns in aspic have had their day;
Of our pickles we've seen the last;
The calves' foot jelly has passed away,
And blancmange is a thing of the past.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The Field of Battle

Below these photos is the text: " 'Field' is a word which reads oddly in connection with photographs like these. Instead of the ripple of the young grass in the wind there is nothing to be seen but a waste and desolation of mud, broken only by a field-gun firing from one shell-hole, and a horse struggling to extricate itself from another."

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 7th - 10th

More concern about food and Wynne returns to work at the Hospital.
viewer_4.description:
February 7th, Thursday
My "baby" is 10 years old today, and still like "squirrel with the robin's eyes" as Skippy used to call her. I heard from him two days ago. He is now CRE 35th Division and writes that he is longing to quit the land of mud and desolation he lives in for clean country and home and comfort. Poor fellows, one cannot realise the hideous discomfort they live in perpetually. I heard a vile story about food. A friend of Aim's (her aunt) got a rabbit from a poulterers skinned and when her cook brought it home she found it had a cat's head! She took it back and man offered her £4 to hold her tongue but she refused. How disgusting it sounds.

Feb 8th
Mother writes me today that "poor Bella" (her servant) has walked out of the house! and so she has only Grace. Aim too is in trouble, her one and only has been her tyrant for so long that at last she has given her the sack. I believe in Town things are very difficult this way but I'd much rather do all the work myself than live a dog's life like that.

Feb 9th
Our quarantine being up on Monday I was thought clean enough to go to Hospital today and so once more I went up there to work, it seemed quite odd being back again and quite nice too. I really received quite a welcome. Went and had a talk to old Thornton and there I ordered some shallots and some lettuce plants. He's a wonderful old man and we often have a crack together. It was quite like old times coming in for some of the village gossip again but I do think without exception this is the most vile and beastly place for evil tongues I've ever struck.

Feb 10th Sunday
I insert here a letter I got at the end of Dec last from Tristan da Cunha in answer to one sent from me in the previous year and written in May! I have this day written a reply and am sending off a parcel of things tomorrow as a ship is leaving during the latter end of this month. These poor derelicts who live on this remote island so far from the world's ken are the result of a garrison who was stationed there when Napoleon was a prisoner at St Helena, some of whom elected to stay on. (See the letters window, which includes one from Bavaria too).

Much has been written of late about Lord Rhondda, and the food question. This essay (see next panel, where it is reproduced) a propos of rabbits came out of the Books of Today and Tomorrow and is rather amusing. All sorts of skits on the problems of the day appear in various papers and although things are getting pretty tight everyone takes it all so good naturally. Personally I find housekeeping a chinese puzzle - it is so awfully difficult to make a variety when one is so limited in food stuffs. We can get no bacon at all, hardly any margarine, of course no butter. No dried fruits for cakes of puddings, only once a week does the butcher call and fish is fearfully high. I am sure things are going to get worse too.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Lord Rhondda (David Thomas, a Welsh Liberal MP) became the Minister of Food Control in June 1917, and remained in that post until his sudden death in July . He was consequently much in the news, and a name everyone would have known since his decisions impacted on daily life.

Below is one of the skits Wynne mentions:

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 11th - 17th

The absence of gold, teh warmth of Spring, and general chores. Wynne revisits 1914.
viewer_6.description:
February 11th, Monday
I've been reading up my 1914 diary - my goodness how strangely it reads and what an awful time we all went through. I shall never forget it as long as I live and it seems so odd to think of the food panic we were immediately plunged into and how we rushed off to buy a ham, some flour, tinned goods etc just as if we were preparing for a short siege. Little did we think we should still be fighting after three and a half years and be going through a real food shortage with a vengeance. Gold too at once became scarce and we all changed feverishly our bank notes, fearing they would become waste paper! There again, how little one could realise a paper currency and no gold at all. I have not seen gold for years! We seem no nearer the end now than we did then.

Feb 12th
The mildness of the weather misgives me - all the prunes blossom is out, daffodils nearly, so crocus and snowdrops of course in full bloom. We shall pay for all this - severe weather is bound to come. We have been very busy this morning preparing one of the frames as a lettuce bed, and I am going up tomorrow to Thornton to get some young plants which will give us a start.

Feb 13th, Ash Wednesday
We did not go to Kirk today to my relief. I am not partial to the Ash Wed. service with its maledictory sentiments. Instead we planted lettuce seedlings and young onion plants in the specially prepared beds and applied Basic Slag to fruit bushes. A good days work, and we worked after tea until 6.30 when we were forced to come in because it was quite dark.

Feb 14th
The birds' wedding day! And such a lovely one, as mild as April and we've been hard at work all day long. I saw several young couples hopping around and the chorus of wedding marches came from every twig and bush.

Feb 15th
Today we had another good ferreting. We got 10. I meanwhile tarred the chicken scratching sheds which is a good work done and at 4.0 we proceeded to walk over to the Blakes at Marks Barn to tea. They are a nice people, with a large grown up family, and have lived all their days in the Falkland Islands where he apparently made his money in wool. They come of a very large and old Somersetshire family and are Radicals and Unitarians.

Feb 16th
To Hospital as usual and a rather hard day, many pots and pans. I didn't get back until 3.30 when I set to and cleaned the chicken houses and the rabbits' runs, our usual Sat. occupation.

Feb 17th, Sunday
Once again after a long lapse we all trooped off to the Kirk. After lunch we started to do the enormous puzzle I've just made, it is an awful business. To tea came the Riddles and Miss Edwards. We see very little of them as like us they are self sufficient. I find one gets awfully unsociable these days.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Two letters from February - transcribed below:

From Frances Repetto, in Tristan da Cuhna
Dated May 27th 1917, in reply to one received the previous year. It took 6 months, and is a poignant record of a very isolated community. Wynne had sent out parcels to them. Her letter is the one on top of Walter's.

Dear Madam
Many thanks for your kind letter which I receive on the 23rd of November but I am very sorry to say that my dear husband have passed away 6 years ago. I am a widow with 7 children, 4 sons and 3 daughters my Eldest daughters are married and got two little daughters there are a hundred and 6 people on the island, such a lot of little children that need teaching I do hope some day a clergyman may come to teach the children….the ship arrive and brought letters and gifts from friends so far away I had nearly given up all hope of hearing news….I do hope a ship will call and take letters I have, we have only saw one steamer since the mail and she was too far west, I do hope one will call soon but it looks rather doubtful as winter are coming on and then it will be much surf to get off. I was sorry that letters could not be sent in the Whaling Steamer but I saw the Captain and he told me he would have been only to glad as another steamer would take them on but it was to late….I do hope that the terrible war will be over long before this letter reach you how happy it must be for all dear friends to return home but I feel sure that many thousands have gone to there bright home above may we all meet in that bright home above with all kind wishes and many thanks for you parcel and letter believe me to remain yours sincerely Frances Repetto.
(I have not corrected any of the spelling, and …indicates additional writing not transcribed).

From Walter von Poellnitz, 35 Isabellastr., Munich. 26th January.
Wynne's Uncle Walter, living in Munich. Amazingly, they managed to correspond via Switzerland throughout the war.

My dearest Wynne - It seems a lifetime since I heard from you - and i don't know who is to blame. This roundabout way of corresponding has its great drawbacks. Firstly it is not private and secondly the possibility of getting lost is imminent. Well, I'm all right and hope to hear the same from you about all that are near and dear to me. I wonder how poor old Thurie is getting on. Of course you are not so much in touch with him as while you were living near London. We had glorious winter weather. Hard frost, deep snow and lots of skating, tobogganing etc, not that these sports affected me much - things of the past. I rub on pretty comfortably - of course we have to be careful about money…living rather more expensive than before the War. However I manage to manage and though I have not grown fat I am flourishing, no asthma, no heart complaint, to bed at 11, awake at 8, very good appetite, so I may have some more years in store for me - which I hope and pray may bring this dreadful war to an end and in time re-establish relations between two nations which have been on good terms for ages. And now goodbye, love to all and don't let me wait too long for a letter. Ever your loving affectionate old Hamster.
(Poor Walter did not have as good a time after the War, as the inflation in Germany destroyed his pension and left him virtually starving).

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
February 18th - 22nd

Raids over London, the resignation of Sir William Roberston, the feared German Offensive everyone knew was coming, and chaos in Russia.
viewer_8.description:
February 18th, Monday
We hear there has been another raid in Town and no papers came today so I fancy the mails were delayed. Mother writes me that they had of course to go downstairs as usual, that Ell was at a theatre and came in about 12 having given a taxi £1 to drive him home!

February 19th
Another raid but they failed to reach Town so the papers say. Mother writes that they heard little or no noise and went upstairs to bed before the All Clear. Sir W Robertson has resigned owing "it is said" to his disapproval of the Versailles policy. They gave him the option of continuing in his present post or on the Versailles council but he could not accept either and has now accepted the Eastern Command. This is a great surprise as it is a mere nothing and seems so strange that one is forced to think there is much more than meets the eye. Political trouble seems imminent and it all happening just now when we are on the eve of the expected offensive is most unfortunate. Sir W R is a man in whom everyone has the greatest confidence - entirely self-made, beginning life as a butler! he is now second to none as a soldier barring Haig. The man who has taken his place, Sir H Wilson, is thought nothing of in comparison - what will the outcome of it all be?

Feb 20th
It was with much anxiety that we read the paper today and were relieved to see that Lloyd George had made very clear explanation of affairs in general and that the political aspect seems less clouded, which is a mercy as we are on the eve of Germany's long waited offensive which may burst upon us at any moment. One dreads to think that even now it may have begun. Our poor men - may God help them. Philip Gibbs writing on this yesterday calls it Germany's last effort to impress the people. They certainly need it if half the horrors which are toward over there are true. It is said there would have been a revolution long ago but there are only women at home and they are not capable of organising such a thing. My goodness, our Leeds and Manchester women could do it. (see next window for the article)

Feb 21st
This cutting about Russia is really well worth reading. It is an amazing state of affairs, bewildering and quite appalling. Russia has of course long since collapsed and rushed around like a mad dog biting itself. Germany made peace with a portion of it, the Ukraine, and now various troops are fighting the Germans and getting beaten. the most awful accounts of life in Moscow appeared today, the place is full of starving people amongst whom are hundred of erstwhile officers who have been kicked out by their own troops and who with their wives are selling newspapers and sweeping crossings. Open robbery in the streets is common and it seems to me when a man does not commit suicide he is mysteriously done away with. A frightful situation altogether. (This cutting is too long to put in, but covers both censorious remarks about the previous Tsarist regime, news of the German advance into the Ukraine and the general chaos then current in Russia itself).

Feb 22nd
A lovely sunny day again and we have sown the first Broad Beans and Peas out of doors, just a week earlier than last year but then the weather is so different. We were skating this time last year and never shall I forget the hideous coldness of it all. Today we had a breadless tea and very little of it for breakfast, but I am determined to keep within our flour ration and this week I shall do so. I made a lot of oatmeal scones and we eat that instead.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: The start of the article about the feared coming Offensive, mentioned by Wynne on February 20th:

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
February 23rd -28th

Rural life, and news of the bombing in London of John Bull's office.
viewer_10.description:
February 22nd, Friday
I spent this day in bed and was quite happy writing dozens of letters and reading and sewing. I am almost ashamed to own that I positively enjoy a day in bed occasionally and find it an enormous rest. Mother writes me that Ell is busy exercising horses in the Park every day, whose and what horses I cant imagine.

Feb 23rd
I am tired tonight. I've been up at Hospital most of the day as Sat work is always a bit lengthy and then I had to come home and cook as Cathy left this morning and it gives me a bit to do. On Monday Hilda comes thanks be and I hope for a peaceful time.

Feb 24th
For the first time since Xmas owing to quarantine H and I went to Early Service this morning. It was fresh and cold but so awfully nice. I then sent the family to Matins and cooked their dinner for them. After lunch I donned my working clothes and with H cleaned up the front borders which really look awfully nice and quite gay with heaps of daffodils out and polyanthus coming along. The prunus trees are a sight again this year, such a wealth of blossom and against the blue sky it is really a dream of spring. After tea we went down to the stream and gathered catkins and then to Evensong and so ended a day of great content.

Feb 25th
A perfect day and we were out working till the sun set in a golden glow and the moon rose full looking like a ball of fire, but I fear with this perfect still weather and bright lights they are bound to have raids in town. I hear that some of the wretched people who got buried under John Bull's office are still there buried alive and a hole has been made through which they put food, but what an agony they must be living in.

Feb 26th
A great digging of couch grass and weeds in the future potato patch. I see in today's paper that we are to get sugar allotted to us for jam making this year again, this is a piece of great good luck. 10 pounds per head which will give us 90, the same as I had last year. It seems too good to be true.

February 28th, Thursday
The last day of February! and we awoke to a most glorious morning, not a cloud in the sky and all the usual assets of Spring. Before 11 the clouds appeared and we were without any notice in the midst of a wild snowstorm. It fell thickly for about half an hour but did not lie and is all gone now. Too cold to work out of doors.

february.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Meatless Days, rationing, and the feared coming Offensive...

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Title page for Wynne's diary - the final year of the war. Scroll down to read a magnified version of the article she has stuck onto her page.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 6th

Food shortages noted - sugar cards already in force, and rationing for all is about to commence.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Tuesday.
Here begins a New Year and New Diary. I wonder if I shall be as dilatory in writing this one as I was last year. I know that these days in which events race on there would be much of interest to put down if only I had the energy to write it but somehow with the War dragging on year after year our mind and body get utterly weary - weary of separations, anxieties, food problems and so forth.

January 2nd
Above will be seen pictures by Charles de Mornay, and as he is a coming celebrity artist I treasure them! (CdeM was school friend of her son. The cartoons depict English - top, Russian left and French soldier right). Pink this day has been discovered with Mumps. It means an endless quarantine.

January 3rd
To my sorrow Ell and Mother left today. We miss them much and though they've been here 10 days I've seen little or nothing of either having spent most of my time in the kitchen owing to Cathy's absence. Ell was away shooting all yesterday with the Rawlins and Pink was to have gone too but alas poor child he of course was prevented.

January 4th
Sometimes I just wonder what is going to happen during the next six months where food is concerned, for its getting more and more difficult. Down here in the country we are not pressed in quite so many ways as they are in the big towns, but things like butter, tea, flour are all a struggle to get. Sugar cards are of course in force now and compulsory rationing for all is near at hand. Each individual now is allowed half a pound of sugar per week and so we use a good many substitutes such as saxine, honey, treacle and "sucradraw", a clear sticky substance like glucose and corn syrup. We have indeed fallen upon evil times but in Germany all is far worse and thousands we know are really half starving whilst clothing is made of paper and shoe soles of wood.

January 5th
Whilst working up at hospital today Dr Sibbald has talked over the matter of our quarantine with the commandant and has decided that there must be no communication between us and them for a month at least. We now look forward to isolation for weeks, such a bore. I've been reading today in the paper about the frightful shortage of meat in the big towns and the endless queues that await food for hours at every big shop. Its really getting rather awful.

January 6th
We have our joint of meat today. There are thousands who have not, thousands of quite well to do people. As the paper says, "one cannot eat ones money or ones War Loan Certificates", and this weekend meat was not there to buy. Smithfield yesterday must have been a scene of much distress and the shortage was terrible. I would not be Lord Rhondda or Arthur Yapp - they cannot know which way to turn. Truly these days the words "Give us this day our daily bread" have a true significance which they never really had before for thousands of us, and worse is to come.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Two prints Wynne stuck into January, the first "Bringing up the Guns" by H Septimus Power, and below that, "Big Guns Going up to the Front" by Lucy Kemp-Welch. These are only two examples of many such stuck into the diary.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 7th - 13th

No birthday cake material can be found but the hens lay well and a sponge cake is possible.
viewer_4.description:
January 7th, Monday
A very busy morning over household chores and interviewing our District Nurse, and after lunch we gardened. There seemed a faint far off touch of spring in the air. The hens obviously thought so too as they laid me 11 eggs! My fowls are looking so well, so healthy and strong and we eat a May hatched cock the other day who weighed 7¾ lbs and he was good. I feel repaid by my horrible early rising to feed the creatures. I cannot get over the joy of feeling that I have my dear man home for good, it's such a help materially as well as theoretically for he takes much work off my hands and gives me time to breath and think.

January 8th
A very cold day and in the evening snow fell, but not very much. this afternoon to get ourselves warm we all went off wood sawing and cleaving, a very exhilarating occupation.

January 9th
Are we never going to get another mail, its weeks since we heard but today I had a letter from a friend form whom I hadn't heard for about 3 years, viz. White T. He is at present serving in Salonica. I also heard from Gen Sandilands, nice little man.

January 10th
I had a letter from Ell today. He is seeing about something which will be a great thing if it can be managed, viz the transfer of our few pennies in India to England. Not only shall we score on the exchange but shall get better percentage at home now as much of our stuff is only 3½% and we can get 5% in War Loan. Much wood sawing has been the order of the day. The whole family turns out and works these days and as Win and I cant go to the hospital we get quite a lot done. My hens laid 8 eggs today so I am able to send them off to various friends.

January 11th
Today it really had a touch of Spring in the air. We put up two rose poles and tied roses and all the time there was that curious feeling I know so well when Spring is on the way. It was very faint and only a suspicion but it was there all the same.

January 12th
My son is 15 today. We hid his presents as usual but could get him no cake alas and so he only had a sponge sandwich. No fruit is to be had, no icing sugar, indeed these are evil times. We so far have had no shortage of meat but the butcher now says he cannot call more than once a week. Mother writes that it is almost unobtainable in Town and so is milk. She can only get a quarter pound of butter a week and no margarine. This is the same with us. I wonder how we are to manage in future.
Cathy is leaving me as she can no longer be spared from home. It is a bore as I have no doubt she will be difficult to replace, but there are so many big things to worry about at present that a small item like this doesn't worry me at all.

January 13th
It has been a lovely day and I really believe I felt a faint stirring of Spring again. Being in quarantine we cannot go up to church and it seems so odd not all trooping forth. After lunch H, P and I went for a ramble across the fields to the larch copse on the top of Liddons, a strange stillness was in the air and small birds flitted noiselessly in and out of the hedges as if they were bent on secret missions of espionage! To my great surprise right on the top of that exposed hill in the larch wood I found 5 primroses in flower. Fancy that.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 14th - 20th

Food, snow and a letter from a prisoner of war who has been released into neutral territory occupies this week.
viewer_6.description:
January 14th, Monday
After yesterday's lovely day we were surprised to awake this morning to 3 inches of snow. The world looked very lovely so I got up and went out to my chickens. There was no breath of wind and every twig was thick with snow. The children dressed up in rubber attire and had a great snow balling in which we all joined, and not being so well equipped got thoroughly soaked. We kept ourselves employed in sawing wood.

Jan 15th
A wild night and pouring torrents and not a vestige of snow to be seen. Very dirty and horrible out today.

Jan 16th
Very busy today making scratching sheds for my fowls who are feeling all this damp and cold. The family's colds are better and all more cheerful. The following extract out of an American's speech is rather neat: he said "We'll fight to the end and the Kaiser has about as much chance of whipping us as a celluloid cat has of catching an asbestos rat in Hell". A most ingenious turn of thought and so American! Yarmouth has been receiving a shelling from a raider and today the guns were going like mad.

Jan 17th
A perfectly fiendish day, deep snow in the morning and a drizzle of rain all day long, but the snow lay all day and in a howling hurricane the poor Hutches arrived looking draggled and soaked. They have come for 3 or 4 days and what are we to do if this sort of weather continues. Enclosed cutting (see Hoarding article in previous window) shows to what a condition things are coming to, housekeeping is anxious work and I really sometimes hardly know which way to turn.

Jan 18th
All day long it has poured and pelted and we have been prisoners in the house. I was most awfully pleased and interested to get this morning actually a letter from Phil Lyster telling me all about his release and as it is a matter of real interest I stick it in here. Poor fellow, how awful its all been. I wrote to him some days ago and I do hope he will get it. Of course I expect it takes ages but this letter has no date. (Lyster had been a prisoner of war in Germany, and could only write cards - but had recently been released with a group into more congenial conditions in Holland…see earlier years for cards and a photo from him, for instance April 1917. You can read the full letter in the next window).
Two more Destroyers have been lost in the recent gales and all hands lost save one. Horrible. All theatres are closed in America to save coal! No more methylated is to be sold, a real trial, and so on and so forth.

Jan 19th
The frightful weather continues though not quite so wet today. Today being the weekly day for cleaning out the hen houses and animals we all set to and did it. Its rather an arduous work these days what with 3 hen houses and four animal pens. After tea we played wild games such as Bears and Dark Game and Sky etc. I had a phone message from Ell tonight asking me to go up to the Panto on the 25th but alas I do not feel justified in spending the money.

Jan 20th
A howling gale and torrents of rain. At the moment, 7pm, the Hutches and Baby are doing a jigsaw, Noots on one side of me and Win on the other are reading and writing respectively, and Pink is doing stamps. The wind is roaring round the house and shrieks down the chimney sounding perfectly awful. My dear son goes back to college tomorrow alas, and the Hutches also leave. We are supposed to be in quarantine for another 3 weeks and I am getting a bit sick of this isolation. No more fresh cases so far but I cannot believe that we can escape.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Philip Lyster has been a prisoner of war since the very early days of the conflict. You can read several of his cards in earlier entries, but this long letter, which is transcribed below, comes from Holland. Along with a number of other POWs he was part of a negotiated transfer, though he was obliged to remain in neutral territory. At least it meant that his conditions improved.

 

Hotel Royal
Sheveningen

My dear Pal
Here I am at last! I can hardly realise it. I feel like a man in a dream, afraid of waking up and finding myself back in Hell. I mean Germany. Seven of us left Clausthal on Christmas afternoon at a few hours notice and arrived at Aachen at 11pm the next night when we were first told where we were going to. You can imagine how excited we were! We spent one day there and then started for Venloo, the Dutch frontier town. Knowing the Huns as we did we didn't feel safe until the train had actually crossed the frontier. I cant tell you what it felt like to see a friendly face again after all these years. Here they had prepared a most magnificent reception. I should say we were 47 officers and about 200 N.C.Os. as others had joined us at Aachen. Sir J. Hanbury Williams read us a message from the King and Queen, all the foreign diplomats were present in full uniform, the British Minister Sir Walter Townley, Gen ? the Dutch General in charge of us and the italian Minister as representing the diplomatic corps all made speeches and then we were given tea by a bevy of ladies. It was almost too much for most of us, I know I very nearly wept! The Hall was most beautifully decorated with lovely flowers, it was a scene that I shall never forget. Since everybody has been too kind, I have been out to lunch, tea or dinner every day, sometimes all three. We are in a big hotel which will hold 180 when full, the senior officers have small rooms to themselves, the others are 2 or 3 in bigger rooms. It wont be comfortable as there are only two small sitting rooms but we don't care, we are free and that is everything. It will take a little while to find our feet as we have hardly got accustomed to things yet. Everything here is most expensive - a florin nominally1/8 only has the purchasing power of 1/-. There are cards for most things, the population only get half an ounce of tea and ditto of coffee per fortnight and bread is only allowed at breakfast. Still as I say we don't care, we're free. I am in charge of the Hotel, sort of Mess Secretary and have been very busy naturally getting things straight. We are 20 minutes by train from the Hague where most people are busy getting rid of their money. Letters only go now and then when the convoy goes so correspondence will be rather spasmodic. Will write you again when I feel a little more settled down. At present there is no question of leave home or people coming out. I so long to have a chatter with you again. The best of luck to you and your man in the New Year. Yrs always, Phil

Notes:
1. Philip Lyster was imprisoned at Clausthal-Zellerfeld, a small town in Lower Saxony, in the SW part of the Harz mountains. He was captured very early in the war, and you can read post cards from him in earlier sections of the diary. He was released into neutral territory as part of a negotiated deal. As you can read later this year, he actually managed to get married, but at this stage they were not allowed much freedom of manoeuvre.
2. Major General Sir John Hanbury Williams (1859-1946) had an interesting war, much of it in Russia, but from August 1917 - March he was in charge of prisoners of war at the Hague.
3. Sir Walter Beaupre Townley (1863-1945) was Minister Plenipotentiary to the Hague, 1917-1919.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 21st - 27th

Wynne goes to London, where even the Carlton Hotel is rationing the sugar. She sees the Pantomime and "The 13th Chair".
viewer_8.description:
January 21st. Monday
After 4 days of fearful weather it was simply perfect today, bright sunshine and a light Spring breeze was blowing around just searching out every leaf and blade of grass and brushing its face clean. Alas my son has gone back to college again, and I "drove" him to Yeovil in Holts car.

January 22nd
Again the sun shone and it is so very warm that we've had no stove lit. I have quite a gay Spring Pie, it contains primroses, catkins, polyanthus and daisies, also three daffodils I picked up yesterday at the station. We have been very busy today working at the bricks in the kitchen garden.

Jan 23rd
I have been busy over a few last jobs before going to Town, mending clothes, gardening, ordering my house etc. Now I pack up my horrible old rags and depart tomorrow by the 10.35. (Wynne has obviously overcome her previous concern about spending the money!)

Jan 24th, Thursday
By the 10.35 I departed, arriving rather late by a crowded train and reaching the flat by about 3.30. I found Mother very well and we proceeded to buck and have an early tea, for at 7 I had to be at Ell's club to dine with him and do a theatre. I was as usual very much rejoiced to see my dear and we went afterwards to a play called Carminetta at the Princes in which Delysia is very clever and all the others good. From there we went to the Carlton and not being able to get a taxi drove along in a 4 wheeler! rolling up in style into the Palm Court of many joyous memories. We tried to get coffee and sandwiches and cigarettes but were informed that owing to regulations neither of the two latter could be bought! Curious times. (However they did get coffee, and Wynne enclosed the envelop with their sugar portion that came with it).

 

Jan 25th
As soon as I could drag my lazy body out of bed I hied me to Barkers and Pontings to do some shopping. This occupation is however a farce, one may go armed with money and a basket as everyone now does but as there is very little to buy one spends hours in waiting and comes away disappointed. At 12.30 we lunched and proceeded immediately afterwards to the Pantomime where we were joined by Lady Fulton. It was much the same old show as ever but one missed George Graves who is now at the Colliseum and I wasn't awfully amused. Still it is always worth seeing and the Duke's box makes it a very comfortable way of spending the afternoon. What horribly blasé sentiments!

Jan 26th
Away in the morning to shop at Evans. Food stuffs are getting very low and so very dear and though clothes seem as abundant as ever the price of everything is enormous. I went at 1.0 and lunched again with Ell at the Bath Club and we saw afterwards Mrs Pat Campbell in "The 13th Chair" at the Duke of Yorks. Quite one of the most thrilling things I've ever seen and I want to go again. After the performance thinking to revive old memories we walked to Princes to tea, ye gods, how are the mighty fallen. Only a small room is reserved for tea and we were given two tiny slips of toast, half a scone, some very small dry bits of bread and butter and ditto cake.
(THE THIRTEENTH CHAIR was produced at The Duke of York's Theatre, London, on October the 16th,1917, with the following cast of characters:--
ROSCOE CROSBY Mr. Charles Rock
WILLIAM CROSBY Mr. Lionel Belcher
EDWARD WALES Mr. Yorke Stephens
BRADDISH TRENT Mr. Dennis Wyndham
HOWARD STANDISH Mr Vane Sutton-Vane
PHILIP MASON Mr. Arthur Finn
POLLOCK Mr Charles Bishop
INSPECTOR DONOHUE Mr. James Carew
SERGEANT DUNN Mr. Frank Harris
DOOLAN Mr. Denham Charles
HELEN O'NEILL Miss Hilda Bayley
MRS. CROSBY Miss Dorothy Hammon
MARY EASTWOOD Miss Margaret Moffat
HELEN TRENT Miss Ethel Carrington
ELIZABETH ERSKINE Miss Grace Darby
GRACE STANDISH Miss Gladys Maude
MME. ROSALIE LA GRANGE Mrs. Patrick Campbell
The scene throughout the play is the Italian Room in Roscoe Crosby's
House, New York. The time is evening. The second act takes place ten
minutes later than the first and the third act half an hour later than
the second. Not to be confused with The 13 Chairs, which later became a film starring Sharon Tate).

Jan 27th
Went to St Martin's in the Fields to church and heard Dr Littleton preach. He spoke very well and held forth on the evils of compromise which he said was a great characteristic of the English nation! The church was crowded, not a fashionable congregation but many men and thinking people. I like this old church and it calls to my mind how when passing it one day with Father as a child and on hearing its name I asked him how they managed to bring it up from the country!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: An example of one of the many cartoons in the diary - there is another in the next picture window...

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.excerpt:
January 28th - 31st

Air raids over London on two separate days - and Wynne smokes a cigarette in the street for the first time.
viewer_10.description:
January 28th, Monday
I experienced this day my first Raid but first I must begin at the beginning of the day. I received a letter from the Jackdaw by the first post saying he was coming up to Town and would be staying the night. He has lately got engaged to a girl in Bournemouth and I wanted to hear all about her. I accordingly went down to Waterloo to meet him at 10.35 and having done so we preceded to the club where I fed him and then we shopped and went to Cox and back to the flat for tea and an early dinner for I took him to the 13th Chair. Arriving somewhat early we went into the lounge to have a cigarette. Hardly were we seated than two loud reports sounded and the barmaid languidly remarked "another raid, those are the warning guns". This was followed by the police calling "Take cover, take cover" and then the show began. We went down into the theatre and took our seats and then all through the guns banged and the barrage rattled and everyone was perfectly calm and quiet. I wondered at times what it would feel like if a bomb came crashing through the roof for the noise was so loud that at times we could scarcely hear what the people were saying. At the end of the performance the Manager came forward and said that as the "All clear" had not sounded all who wished to stay were at liberty to do so, and that the orchestra would play to them so we sat and waited for half an hour and then I phoned home saying all was well and as it seemed useless staying any longer we set forth. A glance into the exit of the Trafalgar Square tube was quite enough to put us off taking cover there and coming to the Piccadilly entrance we found the gates closed so there was no chance of going back by that. No taxis would look at us and though a few buses were running all were full to overflowing. Therefore there was nothing to do but to walk and this we did all the way. The moon was nearly full and it was as light as day. I left the Jackdaw at High St (Kensington) as he had to go out to Turnham Green and hardly had I got in but it all began again. I watched the strange scene from my bedroom window. It was like a Drury Lane spectacle, the great gun flashes across the sky, the tremendous noise and the bursting shrapnel in the air. Alas I was dragged away too soon and made to beat a retreat downstairs to Mrs Haby's flat where Mother and Ell had been spending the evening. I was much bored. I did so want to watch it, it was such a curious experience walking home, the streets were crowded with people doing the same and occasionally a taxi would rush past one, its bonnet being placarded with a large notice "Take Cover". And another strange thing I did and that was to smoke a cigarette all down Piccadilly! Never did I think I should commit such a queer breach of etiquette! But on raid nights one does do queer things, and no wonder.

Jan 29th
This day at 11.0 I met DW (aka Jackdaw) at the club. I was very glad to see him and to hear that he had got home last night without misadventure. We had some tea and then went down to the Abbey. It is very interesting being in Town with someone who has seldom been here before. Everything is new to him and I was so glad to show him a little of the Abbey though we were hurried to do more than rush round then we took the top of a bus to Waterloo Bridge from where we walked to the station. It was a perfect day and the river looked lovely, the sun shone through a faint mist casting a pink glow on all the lovely buildings. Somerset House, the Savoy, Houses of Parliament etc. In the middle of the river were a lot of green and red barges. Dear old place, how I love it all. I saw him off, then returned to Oxford Street to do some shopping at Evans. I tried to get some tea there but they had no milk! Various things I wanted I failed to get. We planned to go to bed early, but at 10 the warning sounded and downstairs we had to go as once again we realised our friends were with us. This time the All Clear sounded at 1.30 but the special constables declared for safety at 1.0 so up we went to bed. This time the windows rattled and banged and shook and I think the raiders came nearer our side of Town.

Jan 31st
I have nothing to relate of yesterday as I spent the day in bed. I was entirely happy with my books and writing. This morning I ventured forth to shop but came home to lunch. I went to tea with Gertie and coming home the fog was so dense that I literally had to feel my way home. It was really frantic and the crowds in the tube were appalling as all above ground traffic was stopped.

january.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Food shortages, Air Raids - the start of the desperate final year of War.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Two examples of postal problems during war time. The first, sent to Nigeria, clearly never found its recipient. You can see the front and the rear of this envelope, the back covered in different post marks.

The second has clearly been in the war itself - it is addressed to a man in the Royal Engineers, No 4 Wagon Section, Wireless Signal co, British East African Exped. Forces, c/o GPO London.

The note on the front of the second one reads:

The accompanying article has been damaged by enemy action. No compensation is payable in respect of such damage. Returned Leter Section, London Postal Service.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 13th

Baby Welfare, cooking lectures, and the endless hospital work. The news of Lord Poulett's death stuns the village
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Monday
There has been nothing doing this last fortnight. We just work all day long, as Davis has now left us to "go for a soldier", and I cannot write of every day's doing when they consist of nothing but garden work, but today has been a really busy day for at 3.0 I had a Baby Welfare meeting with a nurse from Taunton to speak, to which scarcely any of the women came and which I shall not do again and at 7.0 we had our monthly Women's Institute meeting which seemed to give much pleasure. We had a lady to speak on War cookery who put up with us afterwards and was really very interesting.

July 2nd
Our speaker lady left early this morning. She was a most eccentric little person, a real food crank, brought her own butter and ate no meat, said she had not had a dose of medicine for 30 years and hoped to go to her grave without, but despite all these freaks I wish I could have picked her brains for longer, she was splendid. Hospital again as usual and on with Miss Irish. Our new convoy arrived today, and such a limbless lot I've never seen - arms, legs, hips all missing, poor beggars, and one has been in bed for nine months on end and another on and off for nearly 18, an ex postman named Gibbs from near Yeovil.

July 3rd
The heat continues and every evening we have supper on the Terrace and tea out of doors. The toil of watering is upon us, its very hard work in the detestable garden miles away from the house.

July 4th
A day of very glad remembrance for me but I'm glad also its over. Old times, that is to say good old times always depress me and just at present I've got a phase on of feeling rather at the end of all things. I suppose however lots of people feel that way these days.

July 5th
A long and rather strenuous day at Hospital as I was on alone all day, in consequence helped with the dressings first, then did the surgery, crockery room, stairs, dinner and so one and so forth.

July 6th, Saturday
Hospital again this day, kitchen and fish! Oh, the aroma, it permeates into everything, and then the washing of the fishy plates and fish kettle. Oh its loathsome and I wish they would cease having it in the summer. I was glad when work was done and I could escape into the fees' air. Generally my fate on Sat is liver! but that is a bouquet of fragrance in comparison to fish!

July 11th
The whole village was electrified to hear today of the sudden death of Lord Poulett. (He owned the Hinton estate, was was the local Lord). The wire came to Bilsdon and immediately all the people issued forth from their cottages to talk over such an extraordinary piece of news. It appears he got flu followed by pneumonia and as he had a weak heart it was fatal. An unfortunate family, it never seems as though an heir could become of age for their child is only 9 and the late Earl was 16 when his father died and he succeeded from a cousin whose family all died young. Its a bad day for the estate, this long minority, for the Countess late chorus girl is not adapted to wise rule. Poulett family history.

July 12th
At last the weather has broken and rain is falling. Every drop that comes down we are thankful for.

July 13th, Saturday
Hospital - kitchen again, no odoriferous fish or liver but cold meat, the gods be praised! Poggy came up at 2.30 and had a talk to one or two, chiefly Gibbs. I have discovered him to be an extraordinarily clever artist. He's never had a lesson in his life and I saw some sketches in his book which he had evolved out of his own head, really awfully clever and so well drawn. This sort of gift is a very curious one, it is of course pure instinct and one wonders if cultivated what would be the outcome of it.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The full scan above omits the detail bottom right...see below!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 14th - 19th

The funeral of Earl Poulett, the village all agog. Wynne works at the hospital and in the garden.
viewer_4.description:
July 14th, Sunday
We had to go early to church today as we had had warning it would be full of W.A.A.Cs from the Flax Bulling Camp at Dimington, and they came in their dozens. Girls of every age, size, colours and kind, and the little church was full to bursting, and the aroma was in proportion! There are 470 there I believe. (This refers to the recently formed Women's Auxiliary Army Corps - check them out).

July 15th
St Swithin's Day! and though no rain fell before 12 it made up for it after all right and as I sit writing this after dinner it's coming down cats and dogs. Early this morn at 6.45 I rode over the Shepton Beauchamp to leave a note on Mrs Brodrck and Miss Penny, on the way back it was very hot and a high wind blowing and I was glad to get back by 8.0.

July 16th
This day was all the village agog for it was the day of Lord Poulett's funeral. It was also my day on duty at the hospital. All the men and all the staff went but as someone had to remain on duty I pleaded that I might be that one and so escaped this most vile duty. All the rest went off in high fettle thoroughly enjoying the prospect and all pretending they didn't want to go! At 2.30 the big communicating door between the dwelling house and the hospital was thrown open and there in the huge saloon was the coffin.
