It was really a superb sight, the sun shone through the yellow blinds, throwing a pale yellow light on the tapestried walls, the old cabinets, and the softly coloured furniture and the coffin looked like a glittering gem covered with brilliant wreaths of crimson, gold, bronze, pink, purple and white. At 3.0 they all departed and I and the two cot cases had it to ourselves and I busied myself getting tea ready for them and us and the firing party of 33. They all returned very late at 4.30 so it took them nearly an hour. Just as I was leaving the Quarter came in and asked if we had heard the news which was that during the funeral a wire came for her summoning her to her little son who we knew wasn't well and who evidently had taken a turn for the worse. Poor woman, what sad news and shocks one after the other. I do hope and trust the child recovers. (He did, but he died childless in 1973 and his titles died with him).

July 17th
A rainy, muggy and dark morning when I went into the garden at 6.15 to gather rabbit food. We have so large a stock now that they eat up tons. Lets hope the time will not be long before we eat them up! I've been bottling carrots today, just 6, its rather a toil and one wonders if its quite worth it but they make a nice change in the winter. I shall have sadly enough many empty bottles I fear as I have not had sufficient raspberries or black currants and red currants are not good done like that but I am building up my hope on the blackberries which are making a good show of blossom.

July 18th, Thursday
After having many weeks of drought the rain now descends daily and we are perpetually in the clouds. I have had a very interesting letter from Willie our erstwhile stable boy (Gilham - Check out the section in the Editor Picks for all his links. The letter mentioned here is not in the diary, but a later one written on July 27th is transcribed in a later window this month, and you can see a photo in November 1918). He is now in France and writes after having seen six different fronts and an absence of 3½ years he has only been in hospital twice. What experiences the child has been through. Martha, who gave me all Hale news on her return tells me after some months exemption Baker has been clawed in again and has departed (but see what William G has to say about him in the letter!) and that Sinnott is shortly to have a months leave. I wish I could see him again. (Sinnott was the groom at Hale, see his card at Christmas 1915).

July 19th
Torrents still and we spend our time in rushing out and planting and pricking out seedlings, which the rabbits eat as soon as possible.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
The embroidered card from William Gilham...you can find lots of entries about him, so check out the links. These cards were very popular and there are plenty in the diaries.

The smaller card is inside, under the embroidered flap. It reads: Greetings from the Trenches.

Willie writes on the back of the card:

Dear Madam
Just a few lines to let you know that I am now on leave after 3 years and 4 months abroad. I went and saw some of the old servants that was in your service. Some new (sic) me and others never but when I told them who I was they was very glad to see me back again. From your obedient servant, William. This card came from Belgium.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
July 20th - 24th

The momentous decision to send the two girls to school. They are 10 and 14! Wynne decides on a school in Malvern. Meanwhile the WAACs get a rough press from her.
viewer_6.description:
July 20th
We have after much pondering come to what to us is a momentous decision and that is we have decided to send the children to school. Miss Hall leaves us at the end of this term and we have felt for some time that it would be very nice for them if we could manage it. I therefore made enquiries from Mrs Wood of schools at Malvern and have received excellent recommendations of Malvern Girls College, and go up on Monday to have a look round. I cant contemplate what life will be like when we are without any of them, it will seem like the early days before any arrived only much worse as then we didn't know them! I am writing to Mother and Ell about it and am curious to know what they will say. I am so longing for them to have young companionship and games and all the other advantages of community life and they are both very excited at the thought of going. (Ysobel was 14 and Eleanore 10!)

July 21st, Sunday
A church full of WAACs again. Going up this morning we met a lot going to work, their costumes really made one feel unsexed! We are not built for such weird manlike garments and those who owned legs like gateposts and bodies like bolsters did not show to advantage. One was swaggering along in khaki breeches, her hands in her pockets, a hat on one side and she only needed a cigarette to make her quite complete. Their hair makes me sick, it flies in angles to the four winds, all dust and twigs, and I'm sure judging from their gentle aroma they never wash!

July 22nd
I travelled up to Malvern today by the 9.0 from Ilminster, changing at Taunton and Bristol, then on by the Midland changing at Cheltenham arriving at 2.40. I went straight to the Woods who had offered to put me up, only to find that when they received my wire they thought it was Bob and so they wired back "Delighted" as though their spare room was full they intended putting him in Mr Wood's dressing room. Finding ultimately my name on my PC they got me a room at Gold Hill. Well I had tea with them and then Mrs W took me over to Hatley St George which is the Junior House and where I interviewed Miss Dawson, the Head of it. I found a large house and garden, a crowd of excited girls who go home tomorrow, a very nice lady and a nose that called for a powder puff. I went over the garden with her, then the house, and talked about all things connected with it and finally had supper with her and the staff.. Quite a pleasant set of very plain headed females of the usual school ma'am type! I left at about 9.0 and to the Woods where I smoked a cigarette and talked over matters. Well the long and the short of it is that on the 19th Sept they both set forth and we shall be utterly bereft.

July 23rd
I travelled home again today leaving by the 11.21 with a crowd of girls going home, changing at Hereford and Taunton at which latter place I had two hours to wait. I met on the platform Vodden (one of her patients at the hospital) who was returning from 3 days leave so I took him into the town and gave him some tea after which we walked around and inspected the place and then on arrival at Ilminster drove him home with me.
This day my friend Philip Lyster was married in the Hague as enclosed wire which I got from him some days ago will show. He is interned out there and his girl went over to work with the Dutch Red Cross. I am so very glad of it as his health is none too good and now he will have someone to look after him and nurse him. What a difference it will make to him, poor one, after nearly 4 years imprisonment. (For the full story, with links to each part, go to his page in Editor).

July 24th
I had to go first to Hospital and then to Dimington on W.I. business. The difficulties of starting village industries are slowly but surely driving me dotty!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
The Letter Wynne refers to on July 29th. You can read a transcript below.

As before, I have left it uncorrected. He has finally received leave after over 3 years at the Front, and has returned to Hale. William worked with the Jacksons while they lived in Upton Lodge, Upper Hale. See May for previous letter.

27th July
Dear Madam
Just a few lines in answer to your most welcome letter which I received quite safe dated the 24 July I am so glad to know that you all are keeping in the best of health as I am A 1 at present but it is not very lively down here for a young fellow like me for there's not any more young men I know in Hale or heath End so I am longing for the time to come to join my unit and be back with the boys once more for its jolly more lively out there than it is here.
Yes Madam they have gave me a leave at last but I don't think it is anought (enough) for being out there for three years and months and seeing the different countries as I did for they have only granted me a fortnight that was from the 18th of this month to the first of next so you see that a week have gone already. I have seen Mrs Sinnott and Mrs Amey and they all was surprise to see me and also I went up to London to see Mrs Young. (All the aforesaid were servants at the Lodge).
Well dear Madam I went by the Lodge the other day and it was looking quite alright but not so good when I was there for there don't seem to be any life there at all, yes madam I would very much like to see you so I could sit and have a quiet talk and tell you where I have been and what I have seen for I have travelled through eight different countries since I lift Blighty, that was the 21st March 1915 and I am sure you would be interesting to hear what I had to say but I supposed I will have to wait until this awful war is over if I am spared to come back for they say it is all fair in love and war and if it is my time for me to die I will do my bit with good hearth and the same as every other Brittish lad who have laid down his life for his country.
I saw Baker the other day when I was up Hale and I was very upset to hear that he was one of them fellows that wont fight for his country because he don't like facing the cold steel and doing a bit of killing, a big man like him seeing these young men go out into the hardships where we are doing a bit of fighting. I don't call him a Brittisher at all. We are all quite well at home and Mother is looking a lot better than she did when i away to do my bit at the age of 17 and 6 months. I will now bring this letter to a close hoping that it will find you all in the best of health
from yours truly Servant William

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
July 25th - 30th

Duties continue and she receives a letter from William Gilham you can read in the previous window.
viewer_8.description:
July 25th, Thursday
Miss Hall (the governess) left us today for good. I miss her much, it is quite sad to see her empty room and place at table. We have had 18 months of uninterrupted friendship with never a shadow of a disagreement and she has always been so helpful and pleasant.

July 26th
The workings of Tommies' minds are strange - that my shy and frightened erstwhile stable boy should now consider himself as my "soldier boy" is an example thereof! Willie is home on leave at least after over 3 years service on six different fronts. I should like to see him again. I also had a card from Tom today who is also home on leave and him we hope to see as he may be coming to Burnham to see a brother and that is not far. (Willie's letter is transcribed, see previous window, and the reference to "soldier boy" comes from the embroidered card seen in an earlier window this month, also with a transcript. Go to his page in Editor for all the links).

July 27th, Saturday
I am having a day off in bed today and there steals over me a lovely feeling of real legitimate idleness. My body is lean and hard and strong as a horse so that I can work like a horse but I do find that one complete day off occasionally is necessary and just bucks me up to renewed effort. Pink writes that he fears he has missed his Remove this term as his exams have pulled him down 7 places. Its awful hard luck as it means he wont be in the Upper School next term.

July 28th
I went up to Early Service today and so am taking a day off from Matins. H having taken the girls I sit here under the beech trees for we have fine weather again and the prospect is very fair. The air is full of the sound of bees and summer insects and the garden gay with colours. In the distance the scene provides a touch of War and its needs, for I see a huge field of stacked flax. the work of women pullers. These stacks looks exactly like a large herd of grazing cattle, so odd and at the back are three big wagons loaded ready to go. Soon the harvest will be cut as it is all getting golden now, how quick the year flies by. I can scarcely believe we have been here nearly two years. I hope the Fates will move us next year. I'm quite ready to go!

July 29th
This letter came from Willie, such a good letter considering what he was. How well I remember him when first he came, a small wizened underfed misery and how Veacock (the cook) took him in hand and made him go to Church and get confirmed and wash etc and now he's turned into such a smart soldier and quite a man. I wish we could have seen him. I often wish we could meet some of our old servants - I have had luck. (Letter in previous window + transcript)

July 30th
Hospital again. Our cookie alone in the kitchen again so consequently the air rather electric. Coming home met Aimie Coles who requests help in the kitchen tomorrow so up I go again. (There is no July 31st)

july.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The death of Earl Poulett, WAACs, and local chores occupy her.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Postal mail dominated people's lives. Just imagine if your e mail account collapsed. Wynne maintained a furious correspondence, writing hundreds of letters, and she often stuck in envelopes such as this one, damaged in transit. She has written on the side: "The condition of an envelope on arrival from Cairo, evidently been to the bottom".

You can see more examples in July. Sometimes the letters tell other stories, such as the ones she received from her uncle in Germany during the inflationary period, when there was often not enough room for the number of stamps required.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 2nd - 6th

Wynne becomes President of her local Women's Institute branch. Gardening and war work continue.
viewer_2.description:
June 2nd, Sunday
I have not written anything since 19th May for the remainder of that month, perfect in weather and a wealth of flowers, passed in the usual way. I have been up at 5.30 and working till 10pm. We are out the whole day long, having our supper on the terrace and watering afterwards till bed time, tis a strenuous life and likely to become more so as Davis had his papers yesterday and attends his medical on Thursday. The present weather is extraordinary, day after day we have endless blazing sunshine, everything is being forced into flower long before its time, the house is covered with roses and clematis, the sweet peas are in flower and gorgeous snapdragons of every colour fill the borders. The poor Thuries are with Mother now and she says they are wonderfully brave. Poor people, what is there left for them to live for. Go to the Family Section for details - Wynne is talking here about the death of her cousin in Mesopotamia. Scroll down the page you come to and you will see a photo of both cousins lost in the War.

June 3rd.
This evening I had to flee away from many arduous garden tasks to attend a committee meeting of the Women's Institute. I have been made President, a doubtful compliment, but its one better than being Secretary. It has been decided to have our first regular meeting on the 10th when we shall see how it takes on and what settled industry we take up. I personally am for toy making as it is so very necessary to try and keep this particular trade in the country.

June 4th
Very hot weather still, everyday the sun beats down mercilessly and if we don't get rain soon our crops will suffer horribly, as it is there are no apples, pears or plums, the East wind blight having seen to that. I was on duty at Hospital from 10 to 5 today. Poor Vodden (see May 9th) is ill with malaria again, a temp of 105º and Gibson in bed too. He is like a fretful porcupine but the other so patient. This evening Capt Cleland RA gave a concert up there in aid of the P of W Fund RA. He acted as a "lady" and really looked wonderful! These sketches he did for my diary : one word is Calais and the other Jock - awfully neat.

June 5th
The even tenor of our way was broken today by the annual Jumble sale! at Mrs Lowes, where once again she appeared in garments culled from the stalls previous to arrival! Everything was cleared away in half an hour!

June 6th
The weather is changing. We walked all the way to Maincombe to the Husseys. Their house a vile and hideous railway station of a house is perched high up on a commanding position. It is rather nice inside and had once a pretty garden which is now alas all run to seed as they have no labour. They run that huge house on two maids. We went over their farm where we saw the lovely dairy and tons of ripping butter and then walked home through the fields.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Two cartoons by Captain Cleland R A, mentioned on June 4th.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 7th - 14th

A strange tea party, hospital, and the first meeting of the WI branch. 60 members attend.
viewer_4.description:
June 7th, Friday
Once more we had to spring forth and leave our much loved garden work for 2 or 3 hours, our friends are very kind but I wish we needn't ever go out to tea. The Clelands had asked us to tea, first we pleaded we had no means of getting, but they insisted upon sending a carriage out for us and so like a gentleman and lady once more we drove behind a horse! On arrival we found old Miss Wills and Mrs Lane and a Lady Leslie and two spinster nieces, the three Clelands and ourselves. We all sat round the dining table and I conversed with Miss Wills who poor old dear is quite blind but so very cheerful, both the nieces were deaf, one stone deaf, and old Professor C (once a very clever man, Professor of Anatomy at Glasgow) is now childish and feeble, so it was rather a "maimed" party!

June 8th
Hospital day once more, how quickly it comes round. I've been washing up pots and pans for over 18 months now. It is very odious work and if one wasn't only too glad to do any kind of war work I'd gladly do no more of this kind. I went up during lunch to see Vodden. He looks ghastly poor chap, and Sister in her usual way of favouritism, he not being one, has no sympathy and declares he loves his bed. When one is having malaria for days on end one doesn't feel much like prancing about. I wish he could get a transfer to a proper malaria hospital, they know nothing about it here nor does the Dr, but there is alas so much in the country now that there are many hospitals exclusively for it. It is a weary disease.

June 9th, Sunday
Went to Kirk in the evening. Shelley held forth for 20 minutes again. I wonder he doesn't know that he cant possibly hold his people for more than ten. I suppose this sort of thing is good for one's sub-conscious self, it certainly doesn't make much impression on one's conscious one! but I am not a good Christian and I know it. I can find the Good God much easier in the woods and fields.

June 10th
This was the first meeting of the Women's Institute of which I am president. We had it at 7.0 and it was a really successful meeting, just on 60 were present and all passed off very well. We started after I had read the Rules with a demonstration by Mrs Rapson on how to mend one's boots. We also had two songs, a question box - people writing on slips of paper what industry they wish to take up, a little show of War Time cookery with receipts and a Hay Box talk by Annie Coles. The two hours passed very quickly and it all went off excellently, lets hope it will continue to do so because in time it should prove very beneficial to the village.

June 11th
My day in the wards - in the morning I work with Miss Irish and in the afternoon Mrs Hole. As I love charing it is no fag to me. After work we had tea in the garden but the flies were horrible. At 6.0 I went to the yearly Mother's Union meeting or rather Service at which Prebendary Green preached. I was not much moved as he is supposed to be very excellent.

June 12th - 14th
Three whole days I have had at home, a rare treat, and much garden labour have I done. What I should love best in the world is to garden always and never be called away.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Two examples of ration cards. The first is for Sugar - and you can read a transcript of the severe rules and regulations. On production of this paper you received coupons. She appears to have got coupons in January and April .

The second is a margarine and butter card, quite different from the first in that it recorded the purchases, and was only usable in one shop.

Sugar coupon paper:

DEFENCE OF THE REALM
Instructions

Upon production of this Ration Paper at a Post office, sugar coupons will be issued for the next ensuing period, the Paper being date stamped to show when the coupons were issued. It may not be again presented until the period for which the coupons were issued has expired. A coupon must be handed to the retailer upon the purchase of the corresponding ration.
This Ration Paper may only be used by or on behalf of the person named on the other side, to whom it has been issued. It is not transferable and anyone using it except for the benefit of the person to whom it has been issued is guilty of an offence. It must be preserved with the greatest care, since if it is lost or destroyed it will not be replaced except upon the strictest evidence. Anyone finding it must immediately hand it in at the nearest Post Office unless able to return it at once to the owner.

IT IS AN OFFENCE FOR ANY PERSON -
1. To make, or attempt to make, any use of this Paper except the person to whom it has been issued or a person acting on behalf of the person to whom it has been issued.
2. To personate, or falsely represent himself as, the person to whom it has been issued or a person acting on behalf of the person to whom it has been issued.
3. To retain this Paper, where he has no right to retain it, or to fail to comply with any direction issued by lawful authority for its return.
4. to alter, or attempt to alter, or to forge any entry upon, or otherwise tamper with, this Paper, or to make or cause to be made, or knowingly to have in his possession, any paper so made as to resemble or colorably imitate a Ration Paper.
Offences are punishable with a fine of £100 or 6 months' imprisonment, or both.

Margarine and Butter card

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 15th - 20th

Falling asleep in church, strawberry jam, local work.

Entries cease until July
viewer_6.description:
June 15th, Saturday
My birthday today, and I am 39! Whilst one is in the 30s life is bearable but next year when I plunge into the 40s!! Help help, I shall have one foot in the grave. I had such lovely presents - 13 pairs of stockings from Ell, blue voile and white silk blouse length and a tea cosy from Mother, 6 cups and saucers and chocolate from H, chocolate from Win and Baby, plants from Noots and a lovely painted table centre from Miss Hall. Hospital again and jam making, 45 lbs jam beside bottling fruit and at 7.0 away up again to a committee meeting so that when bed time came I was quite ready for it.

June 16th, Sunday
It is a strange but true fact I have recently developed the horrible habit of going to sleep in Church! This evening I once or twice nearly rolled over in my pew. I know that Shelley must have seen and really feel disgraced.

June 17th
There is no peace for the wicked and I must be specially evil as there certainly is none for me. I made strawberry jam directly after breakfast and then dashed off to Hospital to interview Miss Blake on W.I. business.

June 18th
At Hospital from 10 until 6, a long and busy day as I was on alone from 1.0. I had to get men's, washerwomen's and nurses' teas besides all the rest of the work. There is an awful atmosphere of trivial irritation up there and the staff spend their time in picking holes in the Head, such rotten bad form.

June 19th
Today I had to ride down to Lopen to leave a note at Miss Penny's. Lopen is a quaint little place lying in a hollow, just a few houses and a bogey little church and very out of the way and primitive. One tiny dusty little shop which sells a few decayed remains and combines Post Office. The pub, the King William, is a creeper clad thatched cottage and looks as though it were tired of pub business.

June 20th
This is always a day of sad remembrance for me as my dear Father died upon it so many years ago.

(Entries cease here until July)

june.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The Women's Institute comes to Hinton St George.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: A joke menu, linked to the constant disturbances caused by the bombing raids.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 8th

Home chores and the scramble for food - keeping the home going.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Friday
March has come in like a lion all right - it was a little lion this morning but quite full grown by midday and roared rudely around the house. I had a letter from the Jackdaw (R D Whitehead - see earlier refs) who is now at Ripon in Yorkshire at a big Command Depot camp for 8 weeks. He must be very lost away from his girl in Bournemouth which I should think was Paradise by comparison.

March 2nd
This has been quite a Red Letter Day. I have at last got my Dividends due 3 weeks ago, so feel less high and dry, the second of Ex dated Jan 9th so I suppose its been round the Cape and I conclude the first must have gone down. Then my dear Vim (cat?) turned up again looking very sheepish and so he has evidently been on the tiles but I was thankful as I feared a trap and lastly we discovered to our great astonishment that Nootsie's new rabbit had had babies in the night!

March 3rd
To Kirk morning and evening and for the rest contented myself with reading and snoozing and trying to keep warm wrapped in a fur rug and hot bottle. This icy blast searches one out and permeates every corner of the house.

March 4th
Still we freeze. How I long for the mild warmth of February. A busy morning weighing flour, tea, putting away stores and planning how little one possibly can live on. Went up to the Infant Welfare Meeting at 3.30 and weighed babies and then home to tea. Horribly hungry, indeed too hungry for I am afflicted with the vilest of appetites.

March 6th, Wednesday

I made an excursion into Crewkerne this morning, Win with me. We both trundled behind old Irish whose hair is growing to such enormous dimensions now that he looks like this:
It floats behind him in the breeze and looks most unsanitary.
We rushed around scraping together margarine, biscuits, fish, onions etc all like so much gold, tried everywhere for matches and syrup, got a few of the former and none of the latter and got home by lunch. After that meal which was a meatless one and consisted of vegetable curry we set to work cleaning hen houses and animal houses, and then fed all and so in to tea.

March 7th
Such a day! Old Norman arrived at 9 to clean out the kitchen boiler which hadn't been done for over a year. Therefore there was tons of solid cement therein. We are hoping when its clear to have hot water again - at present its never hot, and much misery is thereby added to life.

March 8th
Today I virtuously attended old Lowey's monthly Bible Lecture. Oh! dear I wish I didn't have such a sense of humour. It always takes place in old Mrs Tiggy Winkles house and I am sure both she and Miss Attree welcome it as one of their greatest dissipations for does it not bring "the World" into their house! Old L thoroughly enjoys herself having the whole field without competition and its all very funny to watch.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne placed these sketches into her March diary because she knew the artist, Eugene Fuller, who lived at Farnham. Tanks were still a relative novelty, and their ability to both deal with barbed wire and make their occupants sea-sick, are commented upon.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 9th - 17th

Thoughts about her diary. Wynne's family and friends chide her for wasting her time...
viewer_4.description:
March 9th, Saturday
Today as Miss Edwards was away for the weekend I was cook up at Hospital. I have been deriving much entertainment on looking over the resume of the week's doing, and I will give it to show how dissipated our life is:
Monday - Baby Welfare 3.30; Tuesday - Mrs Pardoe to tea; Wednesday - Crewkerne; Thursday - Boiler cleaned; Friday - Bible meeting ; Saturday - Hospital and Blakes to tea…I can't help laughing, and either I must have a very amiable disposition or I must be a lunatic because in spite of these distractions I am perfectly content.

March 10th, Sunday
The family to Church did go as usual and after lunch it being lovely and sunny I betook myself with a book and a piece of mackintosh to the stream and there I sat all afternoon reading.

March 11th
All this morning I was helping Hilda with bread and cake and buns. After lunch we sowed turnips and prepared the onion bed.

March 12th to 16th
I have not written anything of this week's diary because I haven't felt really inspired. We gardened all day and every day, that really sums up our doings. Of course the great events of the World continue but even the War and its horror gets monotonous after nearly four years of it. Zeps have actually visited the East Coast again after an absence of many months and raids have taken place as usual in Town. They come now, moon or no moon, and Mother, who had seriously thought of leaving Town, has at present decided not to do so as it seems useless. Ell I hear has at last got a job and leaves for Southampton any day, a remount billet. I am sure he must be awfully glad that his enforced sick leave is at an end. I have been reading over some of my old diaries. Sometimes people see me writing these tomes and they say "What a waste of time, what can you find to say and I'm sure you'll never look at them again" but I often do read over the old ones and very interesting I find them, though I wonder whether they'll strike me as idiotic as these old things do. One thing that may prevent that is that a woman of 38 is not so likely to write such rot as a girl of 18! But I've had a very interesting life - the last years no one can wish to live through again, they have been and still are very terrible, but for me personally the anxiety ceased when my man and Ell came out of it and God has been very good. At present our life down here seems just to go on quietly from day to day. If it were not that War still rages and the difficulties of living become more and more problematic, my goodness, wouldn't it be easy to be always happy - having my man home for good is the greatest comfort, he is such a help and such a companion.

March 17th
Poggy's birthday! I have given him a crosscut saw as it was so needed by the household! Worked after lunch but it was rather cold and my vile tooth was bothering me so that I have decided to go and have it out. I'm sick of it.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A classic embroidered card, typical of many sent from the Front. This one was sent to Wynne by an Irishman she had befriended, known only as Paddy. The diary contains several of his very individual letters.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 18th- 26th

The expected German Spring Offensive has begun. The news is terrible. St Quentin falls.
viewer_6.description:
March 18th, Monday
I have not had any letters for days. "My lovers and friends have forsaken me", and I feel with David. Cake making today, and oatmeal stodges for tea. We find our bread ration so close these days that something of this sort is necessary to eke it out.

March 19th
This little picture denotes an incident in connection with my oak bookcase which H made me. He put into it the glass doors commenced before the War began and it looks ripping and will keep my books so clean. Besides no one can now purloin them! The figure sitting on the books doubtless is me!

March 20th
Such a perfect day, such endless hours of sunshine and so warm.

March 21st
Another glorious day almost more so than yesterday. It was so hot this morning that we had to shed coats. We were sowing seeds. We went off primrosing down into the valley below the village and got quite a lot and sent them off to Blanche Gray. The air was like crystal and it simply felt good to be alive.

March 22nd
I went off to Yeovil this morn by the 8.28 and had a vile tooth out with gas. I am thankful to be rid of it as it has been an enemy for months.

March 23rd
The long expected advance by the Devils over there has begun. We read in the papers that they had broken through our outposts, this was only to be expected. Today they are advancing on St Quentin but we hear that our men are holding the line up at Arras. One can think of nothing else, its like a fearful nightmare from which there is no awakening. I cannot record in the face of these horrors the trivialities of daily life down here.

March 24th, Sunday
Summer Time
It is very hot, so hot that this afternoon I lay upon the top of a haystack in summer clothes till tea time which we had in the garden. How one longs for a Sunday paper - all this peace and perfect weather seem a kind of mockery.

March 25th
This being Lady Day and the day of the Mothers' Union I went up to Early Service, and I thought of all the many thousands of mothers the world over who were doing the same. The news today tells that the Germans still advance and claim to have taken 40,000 prisoners and 600 guns. Dear God, it surely cant be true. They are now on their old ground which we took from them last year. The Crown Prince in the south, Prince Ruprecht in the north, and they say the Kaiser is in command.

March 26th
St Quentin and various other towns have fallen and Paris is being bombarded by a gun which is reputed to carry 75 miles. It is unthinkable and I cannot write.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: The page from Wynne's diary for Good Friday - an example of a typical page.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 27th - 31st

A sad Easter full of fear and foreboding. The advance continues. The Germans appear to have regained everything won in 1917.
viewer_8.description:
March 27th, Wednesday
Still the retreat continues and the Germans are now almost back again where they were last year but the DT holds a most sensible view and says that though the losses of men and guns is larger than we expected yet there is no reason to believe that the enemy has got done half what they hoped for and nowhere have they broken our line which is everywhere thank God intact. We went tonight to Intercession. The congregation was a good one but my man was the only one present with the exception of the Parson and the Clerk who by reason of their office naturally had to be there. Why must religion always be left to women and children
The day is ended and I am glad. I got up feeling dreary and remained so all day. The weather has been dark and gloomy with a tempestuous wind and somehow I was suddenly overwhelmed with a feeling of utter uselessness. We work hard its true but its all on our own and with the exception of one day at Hospital I get no war work at all, and one does miss it awfully when all the world seems to be working for others. Still, what can one do when one is responsible for running a household of 10. Our place distinctly is at home. The news today is a little better in so much as we are now holding the line and have given them a check.

March 29th - Good Friday
This is Good Friday, and seldom has the day occurred when more sorrow and horror and unhappiness abounds. Oh! these are indeed most evil times. One great source of thankfulness is that we are holding our line still but the loss of life and material must be appalling and that of the Germans still more. To Church in the morning and again at 2.0 to 3.0 after which we went off to the woods primrosing, as is our wont and the rest of the household did likewise all in different directions to see who could get the most for decorating tomorrow as we are doing the Font this year - blackthorn, daffodils and primroses - it should look pretty.

March 30th
It was pouring in torrents this morning as we all marched up to Church to decorate. Old Lowey was fussing around aiding and abetting and hindering all in turn! Win met her later in the village flourishing flowers in one hand and an oil can in the other, why the latter I can't imagine! Her wild wisps of hair floating in the breeze, a large rent in her cape, a hat the origin of which was I should think a jumble sale and her whole appearance that of a female crow-scarer.

March 31st, Easter Sunday
Such a wild wet day. We proceeded to Early service in torrents at 8.0 and the maids, Win and Miss H went at 7.0. As we came out of Mattins we were again caught in a deluge and such a raging wind. So strong was the wind which blew through the church when the doors were opened that it blew down the whole of my decorations on the Font, thereby making it look like a rubbish heap.

march.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The big German Offensive begins, bringing March to a sad conclusion.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The Diaries are full of things sent to Wynne, including flowers from the front line. These ones she has carefully placed in a small envelope - they are from Palestine, from her erstwhile servant William Gilham. You can read his letter to her which accompanied them in another window.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 8th

The Women's Institute comes to Somerset. Postage goes up - the days of the halfpenny postcard are over for ever.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Wednesday
As so often happens May Day arrives in rain and cold wind and we are all freezing.

May 2nd
Had an unexpected call to Hospital this morning, the second this week. Worked till 3.0. and then being fine the children came for me and we rode away up to Windwhistle, and had our tea up there.

May 3rd, Friday
I went up to the Lowes to a meeting about the Women's Institute they are wishing to start here. I'm afraid it will be rather up hill work but I'm sure its a good scheme if the women will play up. We each agreed to get 3 if not 4 members by the end of next week and where mine are coming from I cant think. The idea is a revival of old industries and social intercourse and work for the country. (The W.I. was founded in 1915, and this was clearly the first stirrings of it in this part of Somerset. It has now become a massive organisation, with over 200,000 members).

May 4th
As I had to go to Hospital today I could not see my son off (to school) and H and the kids went in with him instead.

May 5th, Sunday
A day in bed and I wrote stacks of letters, got through sheafs of bills and generally brought myself up to date. Soon postage is to be raised to 1½d for letters and 1d for postcards so there will have to be a truce to the endless correspondence! (and in fact this did affect things - particularly the massive use of postcards which had been a feature of pre-War Britain).

May 6th
I had my Welfare Meeting this afternoon and quite a lot came contrary to custom and I weighed babies all the afternoon. I also called in on the Marriotts and roped them both in to become members of the W.I. so that's two out of my three and I went to Miss Davis and left the papers with her to peruse hoping thereby to claw her in as well.

May 7th
A lovely morning during which I planted out all my little Stocks and then the rain came down and forced me indoors. We were to have had an open-air Rogation service tonight but the rain put a stop to it. I am sorry as its a nice idea.

May 8th
A perfect perfection of a day, endless sunshine all the day and we've done a lot of work. We stayed out until nearly 8.30, the birds were all singing and it was quite light and felt a sin to come in. How good it feels to be alive on such a day, and the garden is really looking lovely now.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
William Gilham loyally wrote to Wynne during the war. He had been the kitchen boy, but was transformed by the war. Check out his photo in November, by which time he had served on 6 different fronts. He joined in September 1914. The letter from William Gilham, describing his experiences in Palestine, is transcribed below. I have left his spelling and punctuation unchanged, which given his education, is actually very good. The letter arrived in this state, which Wynne wondered might have been in the sea.

Dear Madam
Once more I take my pencil in hand to let you know that I am still in the best of health hoping you and the master are the same sorry I have not written to you befor this as I have been moved about a lot since I last wrote and have been waiting to get settled down befor I could write and let anybody know how I was getting on or where I was and have been waiting to joine my regiment which I am now up the line with and have been with them for three months and don't feel none the worst for it but when we go in these big stunts it nearly does me in with the egiment (equipment) and pack we have on for it is very hilly and rocky where we are fighting (Jacko) the Turk now befor Jerusalem, the city that I never thought of seeing (obscured word) marched through it and it is a very pretty place indeed for I saw a lot of places that I read out of Bible such as the walls of Jerusalem which have been standing now for thousand years and also I saw the golden Gates of the City, the Garden Tomb or Gethsemane where our Lord Jesus Christ was buried and was camped on Mount Olives was (where) our Lord was crucified and also we was camped on the side of the Mount of Temptations.
Now dear Madam seeing that I have now left this very interesting place I will now sent you my address: Pte. W. Gilham 071810 B Coy, 24th Queen's R. W. Surrey's 53 Division E.E. Force as we are not allowed to put it on the top or bottom of the letter. We are now getting some very fine weather after heavy four days of continuous rain and wet through to the skin with out anything else to put on so we had to keep on until it got dry I will now close this short letter hoping that it will find you all in the best of health
from yours truly Servant, William Gilham

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 9th - 13th

Wynne travels to Southampton to visit her brother. While there a visit to Lyndhurst evokes memories of the 1914 call-up
viewer_4.description:
May 9th, Thursday
An unexpected call took me to Hospital today and very unwillingly I went I'm afraid as it was such a perfect day and there is so much to do at home. However duty calls so away I went and worked away at pots and pans and schminky sinks (sic). When I got back I had three of the men to lie in the garden and have tea, three nice fellows, Vodden, Stobart and Lowe. I have had a delightful invitation from Ell to go and spend the weekend at Swaythling where he is with the Remounts.

May 10th
At 10 to 2 Holt appeared and took me to the station, travelling via Salisbury and Romsey I arrived at 6 at Eastleigh where my Ell met me with an American buggy and a regulation "hairy", the sight of which filled me with joy. We drove to Stoneham to the Hambros who I knew before at Woolwich and Aldershot and who kindly welcomed me. They have one small son who arrived after they had been married 13 years! a neat little person, very much petted and treasured naturally. We have had much talk over Dorset and old times as they were granddaughters of Gen Pitt Rivers of Rushmore (he of the famous museum in Oxford). These people are very well off and she is very pleased with the fact!

May 11th
The weather is lovely and I sat in the garden writing and reading till about 12.30 when Ell appeared. After lunch we all repaired to the cricket field where we watched a match in which Ell and Col. Hambro were playing and where were assembled the rank and fashion of Swaythling Remount society, the ladies watched the cricket not at all and discussed clothes and food solid all the afternoon. To dinner came the 2nd in Command, Major Mathews, an ex Cavalry man, and we played owlishly solemn bridge till 11.0. Mrs H appears in the most gorgeous toilettes which are her "country clothes", and much bedecked with jewels, ropes of pearls, diamonds, rubies and the like and I feel quite relieved that I have brought my best glad rags.

May 12th
To church in the morning, and at 12.30 Ell came and took me for a lovely expedition to lunch and tea with some people called Wells Sandford who have a delightful place in the Forest. We went out and inspected their lovely model farm of chickens, ducks, cows, pigs and rabbits, such crowds and so beautifully kept, also a charming garden with the Forest coming straight into it. I thoroughly enjoyed it and broke the 10th Commandment badly! Our road there and back lay through Lyndhurst, place of tragic memories, and I looked up at our bedroom window in the Stag Hotel where we lived for a month nearly 4 years ago. The Forest is looking quite perfect, the great beeches with their semi-transparent foliage and black stems and all the lovely oaks. (See Sept 5th 1914 ff for Wynne's previous visit and stay at Lyndhurst, where her husband was preparing to go to the Front).

May 13th
Alas I had to leave today and came away by the 10.45. All well at home and even in these few days everything has grown so tremendously it is quite astonishing to see.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Herman von Poellnitz was Wynne's cousin. She had already lost one favourite, Bill Fallowfield, so this was another blow. Herman refused to change his name, and had fought on the Allied side with no repercussions. In fact Wynne probably experienced more anti-German feeling in her little Somerset village than he did.

He was killed while out in Mesopotamia, not in the air but in a motor accident. This photo is of the monument erected to him by "The Officers, WOs, NCOs and Men of his squadron".

For a photo of both cousins, and news of Bill's death, click here.

And now listen to Ysobel's memories of Herman. Both Bill and Herman were favourites of hers, largely because they indulged her so kindly.

Herman is buried in the Baghdad (North Gate) War cemetery, (Memorial ref: X.F.8). This is a big cemetery, containing over 4000 graves. He is listed as dying on 11th May .

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 14th - 19th

A letter from the Palestinian front line - the inaugural meeting of the local W.I. - and news of her cousin's death. Wynne stops writing after 19th.
viewer_6.description:
May 14th, Tuesday
I have signed on at Hospital for General Service, so decked out in a brown frock and VAD trappings I went up for my first days work today. How I do wish I could quit the vile kitchen and go up into the wards altogether but alas it is not to be and I am on for both. I was on from 10 to 5, first with Miss Irish and then Mrs Hole so I was in lucks way.

May 15th
On my return home I found a letter from Willie (Gilham - see July 18th 1918 for a second letter transcribed, and links to other references to William). I had not heard for so long that I rather feared the worst, but he is now in Palestine and had I imagine been present at the taking of Jerusalem. I am sticking his letter in here because it is interesting and rather a wonderful letter for a boy like him. He sent me some flowers which I put in here also but alas they had partly stuck to the letter which has evidently been at the bottom of the sea for the envelope was all unstuck and the letter is all stained. I have sent him a parcel but things are so difficult to get now and chocs and sweets almost impossible. I heard too today from Swayne who is at Corfu still but was moving back to Salonica much to his regret. He seems to be having no end of a time.

May 16th
We are having a spell of the most lovely weather. I have begun my early rising and Oh! it is perfect out the first thing, I simply cant lie in bed and take no heed of Pogg's groans of remonstrance which come rumbling out from the fastnesses of his blankets.

May 17th
The heat continues, each day succeeds the last with cloudless sky and brilliant sun. The country in its first green gowns, the spring flowers, the never ceasing songs of all the birds all go to make up perfection in this quiet sleepy hollow. Alas that it should be so sadly different over yonder.
There has been a meeting held here today in order to start a branch of the Women's Institute Movement, an organisation originating in Canada for the Improvement of Rural Life and the revival of Home Industries. It is a self-supporting affair and not a charity and we formed our branch here with between 30 and 40 members. They have elected me President, Miss Altree ViceP, Mrs Tozer Sec and Miss Welch Tres. and we are to have our first meeting in June at which it will be decided what industry we are to take up.

May 18th
Hospital as usual and Fish Day! A sore trial on such a hot day. After work went to decorate the Font for tomorrow.
I have now heard the most horrible news. Poor old Herman (her cousin, Thurie's son) who was in Mespot in the R.A.F. has been killed in a motor accident. His poor people heard by wire. What they will do I cant imagine for indeed there is little else for them to live for, he was their one and only and such a fine specimen of humanity. It is all a horror to me and I cant get over the tragedy of it all.

May 19th, Sunday
We went this morning to the 7.0 Service as the 8.15 was Choral and we neither of us care for the efforts in this direction of the village choir, well intentioned though they are. It was a morning of absolute perfection. If only this horrible carnage was not going on over the way all would be perfection, but still it continues. The Huns are now preparing a further push which they say is to be final! God knows what the result will be but one has no fear of that, only one dreads the horror of it all and the loss of lives and misery it brings in its train. One is utterly weary of it all.

(Wynne stopped entries here, and only resumed on June 2nd).

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Another Septimus Power reproduction. Wynne stuck a number of these into her diaries - cut from an illustrated magazine. The poor horses in the War suffered terribly, as recently exposed in Michael Morpurgo's "War Horse".

may.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

A death, a visit to her brother, and the inauguration of the local W.I.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The news of the famous meeting in the forest of Compiegne. Wynne stuck this in on her November 9th entry.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 1st - 8th

Wynne and her husband are in London. Wynne is recovering from flu, but manages to get to the theatre. Her brother leaves for India.
viewer_2.description:
November 1st, Friday
The day being fine and very warm I made my first essay to take the sun and air and crept forth with H, but oh! how groggy I felt.
Such immense things are happening in the world, Empires falling to the ground, Republics rising and the whole German pack of cards falling about their ears. One cannot keep pace with it all. The papers are all absorbing and read like the most extravagant novel.

Nov 2nd
Today I cast off the shackles of inertia and meeting Ell at 12.30 spent the whole day with that altogether desirable person. We lunched at his club and then went to see "Eyes of Youth" in which Gertrude Elliott acts a most interesting and strange play full of incident and excitement. We then teaed and talked at his rooms, repaired to our respective clubs to titivate, dined at Les Goblins, and went on to see "The Naughty Wife", a ripping play of Hawtrey's, Gladys Cooper and Ellis Jefferies, one of the neatest things I've seen for ages. We whisked home in Ell's car and demanded supper and so ended a very ripping day. (Note - the Hawtrey referred to is Sir Charles, and not the Carry On star).

Nov 3rd
It has rained the whole day long and so we have been prisoners.

Nov 4th
I went and met Win and we repaired together to a strange little eating house in Devonshire Street called The Peasant Shop where for 1/2 we had an excellent meatless lunch including coffee. Everything was scrupulously clean and run by ladies. To tea came the beautiful Charles looking just the same.

Nov 5th
Ell rang up today asking if I would go and help him pack (he had been ordered back to India). At 1.20 we parted, he to his Club and I to Win with whom I did a matinee, "The Chinese Puzzle" at the New, a most unsatisfactory play. Ell came and dined, alas his last night.

Nov 6th
H and I went and saw Ell off at Waterloo at 11.45. H, W and I went to "Nurse Benson" which delighted us - Marie Lohr and Lottie Venne. It was awfully good. (It was such a success that Marie Lohr allowed herself some time off to play her second silent film role. She went to star in many films, and died in 1975).

Nov 8th Friday
Hilda left today, and I took her down to Waterloo. Then to Evans where i shopped till lunch at a parcel for Eve, a most interesting piece of shopping and I bought her just the things I would most have loved myself. I do hope it wont go down! (ie: be sunk by submarine attack) but surely there is less fear of that now. The Town is all agog tonight, a rumour is out that Peace has been declared but of course its all false.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This is the diary open on Armistice Day, with articles, pictures and letters from Wynne's three children, which you can see and read in a later window. The Kaiser's abdication, and below an article about the situation in Germany.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 9th - 13th

PEACE. Extraordinary scenes in the country. Chaos and abdications abroad. Every daily paer is read from cover to cover.
viewer_4.description:
November 9th, Saturday
Alas our stay is over and I hate returning to pastoral and rural life. I should so love to stay up here at any rate until Tuesday, by which date we shall know if the German delegates have accepted our terms. We left by the 11.0 and buying the Times and Daily Telegraph, we buried our noses in them and read from cover to cover. The delegates are even now with Foch. They left Berlin on Wed morning at 5am and arrived at the French lines on Thursday 6pm. From there they travelled blindfold to Foch's HQ and were presented with the Terms. We are told "they were astonished at their severity"! and asked for a cessation of hostilities whilst negotiating. This was not only refused but they were given 72 hours in which to say Yes or No. This they are empowered to do but they will not undertake the responsibility and have despatched a courier to Spa to German HQ asking for instructions. So now we await with anxiety the answer. I cannot but think they must accept. The internal commotion in Germany defies description - revolution is widespread, the Kaiser's abdication is only a matter of days, the Navy is in the hands of the revolutionists, and Bavaria has been proclaimed a Republic!!!

Nov 10th, Sunday
We found all well at home. To early Service and 11 and from 5 to 8. I was on duty at Hospital owing to the Flu. The plague has been and still is bad in these parts. Merriott has lost a number of people but none have died in this village. The schools however have been closed and have only just opened.

November 11th, Monday
PEACE
Signed this morning 5.0am
This is the wonderful news which came to hand this morning after over four years of waiting. We were busy cleaning out chicken houses! when Hilda came flying up saying that Bildsden had brought the news out from Crewkerne. At once we hung the flags out and tied Peter up with ribbon. One simply cant grasp all it means. I was up at the village for Infant Welfare but naturally no one came, then at 7.0 I repaired to the School House where the members of the W I assembled and at 7.20 we all went over in a body to Church, there to take part in a short service of thanksgiving. Crowds of people went and I am sure all felt it very deeply, it seemed the natural way ending this most terrible time. We Institute women then returned to our meeting where I had a little stall of Xmas gifts all of which were bought and then we sang songs and danced about and dispersed with the National Anthem. Meanwhile, the Kaiser has abdicated! and fled with his son and staff into Holland. Germany continues to be in a state of chaos and revolution and all the world is upside down with excitement. I cannot think connectedly, its all like a miracle.

November 12th
We read in today's papers of the wonderful demonstrations in Town on receipt of the news. It defies description. People all went mad, rushed into the streets, downed tools, hung the town with bunting and just flew about everywhere making as much noise as they could. Every house of business closed, and at night the lighting regulations being off all the street and windows were illuminated. How I wish I could have been up instead of which I was washing up plates and pots at Hospital!

November 13th
In yesterday's paper the full terms of the Armistice were published. They are as they should be, very severe, and Germany is now protesting to Wilson saying they were obliged to sign but that in the name of humanity the terms should be mitigated. They have on their part shown much humanity these last four years. Reports are current today that the Crown Prince was not with William in his flight to Holland and has been shot by one of the German sentries. I only hope its true. The paper today for the first time in four years has no war communique, and looks so strange.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
All her children wrote excitedly about the Peace - I have transcribed the relevant sections below to give some sense of what happened in two very different schools - the girls at school in Malvern and her son at Wellington College.

From Eleanore, aged 10 (from school in Malvern)

Isn't it glorious PEACE DAY at last. Have you put up the flags, we have put two ones on the gate. We marched round the town with two flags at the head of us, then when we came back we had a service and sang God Save the King, then we had dinner and Miss Dawson said we might do whatever we liked the rest of the day…..

From Ysobel, aged 14 (from Malvern)
Isn't everything too lovely for words, the bells rang this morning at exactly 11 o'clock and we all rushed down to the gate, Miss Dawson and everybody shouting and yelling and then we listened to the bells and then we cheered until we were hoarse and then sang God save the King after which we went up to church because we thought there would be a service but when we got there we found there was no service until this evening so we bought two large Union Jacks and processed through the town down Church Street to see the flags which were hung up - one girl counted 520 flags! Then we came home and had a Thanksgiving Service of our own and we are having no lessons today.

From Thomas, aged 17 (from Wellington College)
….Well, I must describe to you our Peace day. It all seems too ripping, and already two old peace things have come in. First of all the clock chimes all through the night and next we need not draw our blinds, before we got fined if we didn't. It seems so funny. Work in the morning went on as usual but towards the end of the third hour a hooter began and went on for the rest of the morning nearly. In the middle of the fourth hour Millar, the head of school, came in with a notice form Vaughan saying that he had had news from a reliable source that the armistice had been signed at 5am and hostilities had ceased at 11. In memory there was to be a half. At 12.45 when we came out of school we all went up to Dormitory and plastered the windows with every kind of flag, some people even hung out their carpets and pyjamas! Dinner was a kind of rag at any rate for Lynedoch. We seemed to be the only dormitory with any guts. After lunch College went mad. The Coll. Pres. got up on the roof and towers and hung dormitory scarves (ie: pot rags as they are called, you get them when you get your colours) all over them. They then put an old bowler hat on Wellington's bust and finished by turning the fire hose on the crowd which was playing football with lounge cushions and cans in the quad. Then the Hill, Anglesea and Blucher and ourselves turned on our hose and the unfortunate Bursar who wanted to set up a flag staff got simply drenched. Luckily most of dormitory and myself were upstairs watching from the window, we didn't get any fun in getting soaked. Instead we broke the padlock and burst open the door leading to the clock and rained lounge cushions and things on the people below….

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
November 14th - 21st

The British Army begins its march into Germany, and at home everyone prepares for a general election. Rationing continues.
viewer_6.description:
November 14th, Thursday
I have been on duty at Hospital today but by luck got off soon after two. It appears they have had a frantic row up there for on Peace night six of the men went off to a dance at C and didn't return till after 2.0am. This was reported to the Sister and then there was a real old row which resulted in her shipping 6 straight off to Taunton for detention! There are rumours that it may close altogether before Xmas. Glad as one has been to do our bit it has been a strenuous job and I shall not be sorry to quit.

November 15th
A white frost this morning and a very cold world. The effort of getting out of bed on these occasions is stupendous and cruelty to animals, the early feeding of chickens and rabbits before breakfast is not to my liking at all!

Nov 16th
A still whiter and colder world this morning. The world outside is full of the General Election forthcoming in December.

Nov 17th
This nice photograph I got from our faithful William yesterday. He is at present in Manchester having been gassed on the Western Front, but he has had rather a wonderful record having joined up in Sept 1914 since which time he has served on 6 different fronts, ending up with France.
What will tomorrow's paper bring. Yesterday we read that Revolution was threatening in Holland now, and Switzerland is in the same way. One really feels that England is the only sane place to live nowadays.

Nov 18th
I suppose after such a world conflagration one cannot expect things to be anything approaching normal, but really our continental neighbours are in a fretful state. Germany is making a Republic, revolution now has broken out in Switzerland and Holland, and we see announced that the Royal entry into Brussels has had to be postponed owing to the German soldiers who in spite of the armistice are pillaging and sacking the place. Our army has begun its march into Germany and so at last we shall "wind up the watch on the Rhine".

Nov 19th
The country is now preparing itself for a General Election and Poggy read me the splendid speeches by LG (Lloyd George) and Bonar Law. The former is certainly a born orator and if he is not re-elected PM the country will be the loser. Asquith's speech today is vague and unsatisfying, its only merit lies in its length. He leaves his hearers cold.

Nov 20th
Sgt Major and ? came to ferret, but beyond expending 6 cartridges they achieved nothing, but lost the ferret. We had much angry conversation about Hospital, what a rotten show it is. Just as I write, Poggy brings in the ferret, so very glad.

November 21st, Thursday
It has been cold today, I bicycled into Crewkerne to get the week's margarine etc, armed to the teeth with ration books and couponed in fats, jams etc…the wind was awful and so icy and this afternoon we warmed ourselves by digging hard from lunch till tea.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: How the war ended for some at Mons, where it had begun...Philip Gibbs' last message as a war correspondent.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
November 22nd - 30th

Schools close - her son's because of the flu epidemic. The local war hospital starts to close down too - Wynne is thankful that war work will end.
viewer_8.description:
Nov 22nd
We motored to Yeovil to catch the 1.10 and arrived at Wellington at 4.30. There we were met by Pink who told us that the previous Tuesday flu had broken out and there were already over 200 cases. We drove to our rooms at Crowthorne.

Nov 23rd
At 12 today our dear monkey (their son, Thomas, aka Pink) was confirmed by the Bishop of Buckingham, out of 120 candidates only 70 could attend. Flu continues to spread and everything is disorganised. The service as usual was very impressive and the Bishop spoke well.

Nov 24th
We all attended communion this morning a very big attendance as all the parents came. After lunch we went to see Pink's "cue", it is the next one to where H was when a boy. I wish it could be the same! The walls are covered with pictures but oh! the horrid little hard bed with vile and wooden bolster, his Mother's heart bled for her lamb!!

Nov 25th
With a sorrowful heart I said goodbye this morning. We both left, H for home and I for Hale for 2 days with my dear Skippys (he is home on leave). I got to Aldershot at 1.0. It seemed so strange to see the old place again looking just the same as ever, and I went after lunch to see dear Gran's grave which looked all right.

Nov 26th
Spent the day going round seeing old friends.

Nov 27th
I had a wire this morning from H saying Wellington broken up, meet Pink Yeovil When I got to Yeovil there I met him, and it appears that W has had 500 cases of flu in 10 days so that the whole thing is upset and they've sent home all who are well enough. I'm thankful to have him home safe and sound.

Nov 28th
When I got up to Hospital today I found only 5 men were left and the place in a state of upset, as the inventory has been taken and all the bedding stores and appurtenances lying in stacks. I am sure we shall all feel that an arduous labour of War can soon be brought to a close.

Nov 29th
News in the papers seems strangely tame after our surfeit of colossal events. Elections are in the air but it is causing little excitement and the majority appear to wish for a continued Coalition with LG at its head. Expert committees are considering the Terms of Peace which are to be concluded by 17th December, and Germany is uttering plaintive appeals to all who will listen to her as to the harshness of our terms. Poor Austria is on the verge of famine and things in Vienna are in a fearful chaos. Every crowned head of Central Europe has abdicated and all are in exile, a truly strange state of affairs.

November 30th
I have been reading Buffon's Natural History. He relates strange things and where his quotations from remote authorities fail him, his imaginations supply the difference. On the causes of the Deluge he comes to the conclusion that as we have the simple fact of its happening set out for us in Holy Scriptiure it should be sufficient and he consider that to enquire further is impious and unnecessary!
(But in fact George-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon, is seen as the father of the study of natural history. He died in 1788 and left a very influential legacy, including amongst his followers scientists like Lamarck)

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: This description of the surrender of the German fleet was placed by Wynne into her November diary, though it originates from a later day.

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.description: Two articles stuck in, one about the Austrian Emperor and the other about the Kaiser, both now without power.

viewer_11.title: Viewer 11
viewer_11.description:
The theatre programmes - Wynne saw both these plays on the same day, making up for lost time after her flu bug. She refers to them on November 2nd.

The image in the small window is of Gladys Cooper, who starred in the Naughty Wife.

november.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 9th

Hard work in the garden and hospital, but the war news continues to improve.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Tuesday
Whilst I was up at Hospital today the most glorious news came in, viz: that Bulgaria has accepted our terms which we presented when she asked for an armistice and has surrendered unconditionally. From all other Fronts comes news of advance and capture till one is "fair mazed" with it all. God grant that it is the beginning of the end, for over four years this Horror has been going on and men are sick of carnage.

October 2nd
I am so awfully anxious to get in my blackberries for bottling and every day rain falls and spoils it. I went up to take some of the men over the house (Hinton House, being vacated after the death in the war of the seventh Earl Poulett). It all looks sad and forlorn now being half packed up and wholly deserted but there is plenty of interest. I was amused at the strange things that took their fancy - one man was immensely interested in Lady P's quill pen!

Oct 3rd
I fear a hard winter. God knows what we shall do if this really turns out to be the case for our coal shortage is very real and none but the very poor will get enough. That they will is promised and one is thankful. We have got all our spuds in, a very fine crop. I have been out blackberrying today for bottling, it is a marvellous season for them.

Oct 4th
Earthing celery has been our work today. Poggy had to go up the hospital after tea to help make out the returns for the committee. We have just had a new convoy of 12 making a full hospital now.

Oct 5th
I've had a pretty heavy day today in the Hospital kitchen, cooking and washing up for 41. The masses of spuds and vegetable I did were all eaten up in a minute. Nine rabbits also disappeared at once. Poggy came up at 2.30 to do more returns and at 4 we rode over to the Blakes to tea. On our return all the fowls had gone to bed supperless but we fed the large rabbit family and then felt the day's work was done.

Oct 6th
A fairly fine day but high winds as usual. From 2 till 4 and from 5.30 till dark blackberrying, but only got in all 6 lbs.

Oct 7th
We have had for the past three days here three ladies who belong to a little community called the Pilgrims of Prayer. They make tours throughout the country, enter the homes of anyone and hold prayer meetings, their object being to try and improve the homes before the men return. One just wonders how much good they are able to do.

Oct 8th and 9th
Yesterday was spent in bed reading and sewing. I am at last finishing my pillow shams, and about time too as those I have are in pieces.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A part of a very long article by Philip Gibbs that Wynne cut out and stuck into her October pages -

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 10th - 14th

The momentous news that Germany has asked for an armistice, a request sent to President Wilson. He demands complete evacuation of occupied territory.
viewer_4.description:
October 10th, Thursday
In writing of trivial domestic things I forgot to mention those of world wide import: viz Germany actually asked for an armistice on Tuesday with a view to ultimate peace!!!! The Note was addressed to Wilson, ever since which he has been hatching a reply. They stated they were prepared to accept his terms of Jan 1918 which included the restoration of Belgium and Alsace and L(orraine). Surprising fact - but they forget that America has stated that until Germany has a representative government they will not negotiate with her at all. G has lately taken unto herself a new Parliament with Max of Baden as Chancellor and his crowd is just as autocratic as any other has been before. They are one and all Hohenzollern puppets. So what will Wilson's reply be?

October 11th
I was called to Hospital today and was there from 10 to 5. I wish the Fates would remove our poor little Sister (note: this is the woman Wynne mentions on September 3rd who had lost her only son). She quarrels with the Committee, rages with the men, is vile to her V.A.D.S. and seems thoroughly soured with life. One must see how hopeless her outlook must be but meanwhile its not easy to live with.

October 12th
Wilson's reply to Germany was published today. He refuses to negotiate unless G evacuates all enemy territory, and one awaits the reply to this with wonderment as to what it can possibly be. Austria and Turkey have declared that if G does not accept his terms that they will separately.

October 13th
The air is full of strange rumours - that Germany has accepted Wilson's terms, that the Kaiser has abdicated and so on. It can't be true but in these surprising times, rumour of course is rife and one lives for the papers. Meanwhile they continue to torpedo liners - an Irish mail boat has been lost, the Leinster, with horrible loss of life, and so it goes on and the end is not yet.
I had a line from Skippy yesterday, he says the desolation over there is awful, absolute and complete ruin and wholesale devastation, even trees which have their roots untouched are dead and the country one mass of shell holes filled with water. A perfect day here and we picked over 9 lbs of blackberries.

October 14th
A full day today as the 2nd Monday in the month always is, for after lunch I have the Infant Welfare to attend to, a boring and most useless way of spending time I find, and at 7 our monthly meeting for the Women's Institute. We have been granted the use of the school room for our meetings which is far preferable. We have about 35 present this evening and I think and hope they enjoyed it. I find the honour of being President rather arduous and in resigning in Jan I shall be glad to hand over the duties.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The introduction to the Younger Report, mentioned by Wynne on October 20th. She stuck the whole massive report into the diary. Sir Robert Younger was High Court Judge, Chancery Division at the time.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
October 20th - 31st

Negotiations continue, but the Austro-Hungarian Empire is breaking up, and Turkey is begging for peace. The German Army is in retreat.
viewer_6.description:
October 20th, Sunday
A whole week has elapsed, a week full of important happenings in the world at large, but my life is so full of hard labour at the little things that I simply haven't been able to scratch in here. The "toing and froing" between Wilson and Germany continues, Austria and Hungary are breaking up their extraordinary cosmopolitan community, all declaring independencies, Turkey on her last legs begging for an armistice and through it all the War wages most fiercely, town after town on the Western Front is liberated and the joy of the poor oppressed population knows no bounds. The German army is in full retreat and in their wake they leave ruin and desolation, deporting as they go vast hoards of the young men and also girls. The enclosed account from Mr Justice Younger's commission will show the horrible treatment meted out to our poor dear prisoners, the account makes one's blood boil.

October 22nd
I have been at Hospital all day. The thought of getting quit for a while of the vile atmosphere of petty spite and gloom! Spent the evening in packing prior to our departure tomorrow. I am looking forward to it.

October 23rd, Wednesday
I had a frantic letter from Mother saying that Mrs Nice her char was ill and could I bring a maid so after hasty consultation I decided to bring up Hilda. Accordingly by the 10.35 we came, a strange experience for H having only been in Town once before as a child of 10! Oh how lovely to hear the sound of London again and to see the dear old spot once more.

October 24th
We went to the stores this morning and did some shopping and at 12.45 I met Win with who I went to lunch at a restaurant in Victoria Street. At 2 I attended the mass meeting of delegates of the Women's Institutes at Cathedral Hall, going on afterwards to Caxton Hall to the exhibition. I must say it made one realise what a big movement it all is and I was very glad to have the opportunity. The ex. was a wonderful show, everything there was the work of women and many counties were represented: toys, baskets, food, garments etc.

October 25th
We went to the stores, and into the Caxton Hall again. Went up to the Marble Arch cinema and saw a very good show, going on to tea at Ell's rooms in St James' Place - very snug and nice.

October 26th to 31st
Alas little did I think what was before me when I wrote the last entry. On Sat 26th we all went to Drury Lane and saw "Shanghai" and all the day I felt horribly ill, and by evening I knew I had got "It". Went to bed and there I've been since, 5 precious days of my much longed for holiday have been wasted.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: This story was probably not unique, but it stands today as one example of the appalling cost of this terrible conflict. For an English version check out the equally sad and wasteful story of the Souls, a poor family living in the village of Great Rissington, in Gloucestershire.

october.description: Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895. War news continues to improve - rumours of an armistice are everywhere.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne stuck in this cutting, which I reproduce in full as it interested me as much as it did her...there are hints here of the pressures building up in the opposing forces, not least the fact that they were running out of soldiers...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 6th

Concern about food and coal lead to strange plans from Wynne's mother. The German retreat continues. More sad news, both personal and public.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Sunday
I am writing on the Terrace and beside me sits Mother. We are discussing the coming winter and the prospect of frantic hardships about coal, its going to be a sit tight job and no mistake. She is weaving the most marvellous plans how we should all migrate to her! dismiss all the servants, get new ones in the Spring, kill off and eat all the livestock and shut up the house!!

Sept 2nd
Yesterday afternoon Pink and I went blackberrying, it is an occupation I love. The still autumn days, the rambling round from hedge to hedge, and the competition as to who shall get the most. The crop is very fine this year, the bushes being laden with fruit. Government has organised a public collection and hundreds and thousands of lbs are being gathered for jam. The news from the Western front continues good. Yard by yard the Germans are being slowly pressed back and we are gradually regaining the ground lost, it is a blessed thought and I hope and pray it may continue. We are capturing thousands of prisoners and poor chaps it seems that they are absolutely sick of it and only too glad to cease fighting.

Sept 3rd
To Hospital as usual and I was on alone all the morning so had plenty to do. Sister is in great distress, her poor young son is dead and as he is the only thing she possessed in life it is indeed a desolate look out for her, one feels so helpless in the face of such loss and grief for she is absolutely alone in the world now. So far she has heard no details, simply a wire to say he was dangerously ill and then a letter from the Chaplain to say he was buried, nothing more.
