Sept 4th
A day at home and very busy digging potatoes. They are coming up well and I hope that all will prove as good as it means food for the winter. Mother came down to the garden and all the family assisted.

Sept 5th
Alas! we were awakened by torrents of rain, and all the household said to each other on meeting, "The Potatoes!" for we had left them out to dry. Well all gardeners suffer these vile set backs. Thurie arrived. He looks thin and worn but seems wonderfully plucky. It is however the last real bad stroke of ill fortune of the many that have dogged his life that Fate can play him. Herman was his pride and the light of his life and now that he has gone there is nothing left for him or Lena. We hear now that H had just succeeded to the Aviation Command in Mespot - its all too tragic to think about.

Sept 6th
A great work went forward today and I got the whole household on to the garden paths. We put the cinders down having sufficient for the two long ones, it looks most awfully nice and will save me weeding for a while. Every day the papers continue to give us more and more splendid news of our advance. British, American and French all going forward and the Huns in full retreat, fighting it is true a desperate rearguard action but each day sees more ground gained and more prisoners and guns taken.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
A painting of a Jay's wing by Charles de Mornay - Charles was the friend of Wynne's son. Ysobel, Wynne's daughter, thinks he went on to work for the film team that animated Bonzo.

Some of his caricatures are in sections of this month's diary.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 7th - 13th

More advances along the Western Front. News from Russia of the murder of the Tsar. Jam making in bulk, but the weather is dreadful.
viewer_4.description:
September 7th, Saturday
All the household went off blackberrying today, at least those this side of the kitchen door, and we got 7½lbs. Soon we shall be able to double that amount, meanwhile these come in very useful for feeding my huge family of 14. Catering is a business, especially as this week the butcher had no meat!! I secured however a piece of corned beef and fresh bacon, and what with rabbits and some grouse Ell sent down from Glenogil where he has gone for a week's shooting, we feast. Our dear Ell has had his Board and is passed for India and goes out probably in October.

Sept 8th
Tons of water fell from the sky this morning but as it cleared in time for Church the household all proceeded thither and H and I disgraced ourselves by going to sleep in the sermon. We were told afterwards that the preacher, Mr Burns, admonished people for not paying attention during the whole service.
I spent the afternoon mending clothes, helped by Mother.

Sept 9th
When evening comes after a day such as this has been I've had about enough! Our party has begun to break up. BG (her old governess) and Charles (de Mornay, her son's friend) left and I went to see them off. Torrents of rain started to fall about midday and I had both the Infant Welfare and the W.I. meeting on. Alas a very small attendance at both owing to the fearful weather. I was awfully sick about it as we had a most interesting address on Food Produce by a man from Taunton and another on Autumn Gardening by Miss Lowe. Well, these things cant be helped. The rain descended in torrents and the wind blew and it was as dark as pitch. (See Charles' painting of a Jay's wing in the picture section).

Sept 10th
My usual day at Hospital. We have only 13 men there now but whether there are few or many the jobs still remain and its about as much as one can manage.

Sept 11th, Wednesday
Our new acquisition in the village, Mrs Lyon, came to tea today. She is a war widow, her man having been killed last March, and she has taken for 3 years the house Mrs Pardoe lived in whilst that dear woman has moved up to a cottage. She talked long with me about the gossip of certain evil people here and expressed the same sentiments as I did when I first came, viz: that she had never experienced such gossip in her life before. Well, all being well we shake the dust next Sept. I am quite ready to quit.

Sept 12th
Mother, Thurie and Win all went off this morning.

Sept 13th
The news of the Western Front could not be better, each day brings fresh news of further advances and the Bosch seems for the moment fairly on the run, leaving destruction everywhere behind him, blowing up whole towns and devastating the entire country. I read today a speech of the Kaiser to his workers at Krupps works. One had been inclined to credit him with a certain amount of brains but reading a speech like this gives one the impression that his brain is a tissue of lies and mawkish sentiments, and the never ceasing allusion to Almighty God. Meanwhile the situation in Russia defies imagination. News comes today that the Bolsheviks, not content with murdering the Tzar and his little son, have now down the same to his wife and four daughters. It is all too horrible. Petrograd and Moscow are in flames and the whole country in chaos.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
A notice to all homes from the Board of Trade, Coal Mines Dept.

(note Wynne's exclamation marks at the thought of breakfast in the kitchen)

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 14th - 20th

Essential blackberrying, but government calls to all to pick mean they are hard to find. Children to school - the two girls for the first time in their lives (aged 10 and 14!)
viewer_6.description:
September 14th, Saturday
A dark, wet tempestuous day and I am rather in despair about blackberry picking. Somehow or other they must be got for we have no apples or plums or stone fruit at all. The tomatoes are doing splendidly and I am bottling fast but the lack of sun is bad for ripening. I heard from Mother that they got up quite comfortably and had no crush, while BG and Charles were 16 in the carriage. I am sticking in various drawings, some by the children and some by Chariie.

Sept 15th
This is the last time for some weeks that we shall walk en famille to Church. After lunch Pink, H and I went out blackberrying and brought in quite a decent amount, but owing to the Govt. contract this year the people are very busy picking everywhere. They get 3d a lb and hundreds of tons must be being collected. The Govt require 30,000 tons for jam!

Sept 16th
To tea today came the Lyons children, and ours go there tomorrow. They seem nice people and I hope to see something of her during the winter, but alas she doesn't play Bridge. Pink went in today to have his coat tried on - we are having a winter coat made for him out of H's British Warm (a British officer's greatcoat).

Sept 17th
I am very busy at present doing all sorts of last jobs for my three prior to their going to school. One thing that cheers me in this coming separation is the news from the Front is so splendid. Daily we advance and daily all seems to go well.

Sept 18th
A day of packing up. Three boxes and three children in attendance, such a flying around and bringing of treasures which must be packed somehow.

Sept 19th
We all had breakfast together at 7.30 and at 8.15 Holt came and took us away, leaving H and Pink, which latter leaves this evening by the 5.15. We arrived at 2.40 and I took the two up to school first of all and left their bags. We then betook ourselves to the town to call on an old friend who has promised to be kind to them, then to Cox to get their clothes tried on and afterwards tea at a shop. At 6.30 we returned to school and I left them at 7.0.

Sept 20th
I am home again and how can I describe the desolation of the house, it is like a dead place without a child and H and I roam about like ghosts and give ourselves over to gloomy meditation.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Some paintings done by Wynne's daughters - the poppies are by Eleanore, and the rose hips by Ysobel.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
September 21st - 30th

Retreat on all fronts. In Palestine the Turks are routed, and in Bulgaria a retreat becomes a call for an armistice.
viewer_8.description:
September 25th, Wednesday
I have purposely left out 4 days but inwardly not outwardly I hope I've been so depressed. I miss my 3 so desperately. I here insert their letters as a remembrance.
More good news from abroad and in Palestine a complete rout of the Turks is taking place, also the Bulgarian army is in retreat and all is well on the Western Front. Thank God for it all. Meanwhile we have a railway strike on and no mails today.

Sept 26th
We picked potatoes - the Arran Chief which is coming up splendidly. Wheeled manure on to the spring cabbage patch, but there is so much to do one gets fair mazed!

Sept 27th
Called up to Hospital today and worked there from 10 until 5. After I had finished I went to the Alms houses for a committee meeting and so didn't get home till 6.30.

Sept 28th
To Hospital again, kitchen this time, and it is no mean job cooking and washing up for 30 people. Then to the church where I decorated the font for the harvest festival. I had a letter yesterday from Phil Lyster who was actually in London! and on his way with his wife to Dublin. How wonderful it must seem to him to be really free after 4 years hideous imprisonment. All war news simply marvellous and Bulgaria asking for an armistice.

Sept 29th
This has been the wettest and coldest day we've had for months. When Poggy came home he insisted on lighting a fire, which we did of wood for coal is out of the question. The joy and comfort of seeing and hearing hissing logs made one warm all over.

Sept 30th
The last day of September and such a disappointment this month has been - torrents of rain and high winds. I had today a long letter from Douglas Whitehead - he is now in hospital at Newcastle. It is 8 months since I saw him last in town, since when he's been engaged and is now disengaged, so quickly do things happen, but its better to find it our before marriage than after. (See Jan 28th and 29th - DW is Jackdaw).

This caricature by Charles de Mornay is of a conscientious objector. Wynne has written "Baker" underneath it, in reference to an old servant of hers mentioned by William Gilham in his letter in July.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: A postcard of Malvern. The girls were to attend the Hatley St George College for Girls at Great Malvern - later they attended Malvern Girls College.

september.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The good news continues abroad, while at home food and coal shortages are a worry.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 18th

The month starts cold but enters a lovely warm spell in time for the children's arrival on holiday. The news from Russia fascinates Wynne - she cuts out the articles.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Tuesday
April has come in in a vile and mouldy way as it often does and every night we have 2 or 3 degrees of frost and the whole world looks white. There is hardly a sign of life on any of the trees or hedges, indeed the landscape is quite wintry still.

April 2nd
The weather has brightened and we spent the whole day potato planting, the ground being just right.

April 5th
We have had 3 most perfect days. We are rather pestered at present by people coming to see over the house.. I am getting sick of saying "this is the dining room, here is the drawing room" etc. Each day passes here with its usual quietness and busyness, it is a strange contrast to soldiering but I suppose many people's lives are like that, and thank goodness we are unsociable by nature otherwise we should feel the ennui of it all - and whilst we quietly pass our lives here the most horrible happenings are toward in other lands. Germany, Austria, Hungary etc and above all that poor Russia where the population is almost imbecile from starvation and cruelty by the Bolshevik Terror. There are the most ghastly accounts of Petrograd and Moscow horrors which beat the tortures of the Middle Ages, inconceivable horrors to which those of the French Revolution are as nothing. The officer class are suffering fearfully and hundreds are tortured to death, buried alive, burnt alive, their epaulettes nailed to their shoulders and soon I should think the whole country will be mad. And here we sit in peaceful England and become very agitated at Labour unrest!

April 8th
The holidays have begun! Our cup of joy has begun to fill for today Nootsie and Babbit returned and on Thursday it will fill up when Pink gets home. I love the noise and life and Oh! how can people exist without children!

April 17th
A week has passed since I wrote last, a week of holidays I hate to think of it and begrudge it. I have to my relief had this cable from Win from Suganli telling of her arrival at home and so I now feel at peace. I can rejoice to think of her with her delighted people. I enclose here some letters about the Cossacks in Russia. They are so dramatically written that one feels quite chokey in reading them, anything more tragic than their fearful and hopeless position can hardly be imagined and one only hopes and prays that the relief which the Allies are sending may be in time for it is indeed a struggle for existence.

April 18th, Good Friday.
This is not a very appropriate picture for the day! It is the Irony of Fate that it should thus occur! This Good Friday has had the most perfect weather of any one I've ever experienced: no wind, a cloudless sky and a brilliant hot sun. To Kirk at 11 and again from 2 to 3.0 and then H and I went on to the Park where we met the children who brought tea which we had in the woods. I don't think there's anything to touch an English wood on a day like this with the flowers in the fine undergrowth, the pale sunlight streaming through the leafy boughs overhead and the birds all singing their Easter songs. We picked primroses for Church decorations and wandered home through the fields getting in about 6. I wish one could have this perfect weather for ever!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Russian Terror - from the Daily Telegraph, April 4th, .

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 19th - 30th

The weather change back to a cold wind, so that worries about fruit for jam making and the lack of coal dominate their lives.
viewer_4.description:
April 19th
We have been up to decorate the Font and I am now sitting on the terrace basking in the sun. It is really hot today and the distance is actually filled with heat mist. Every bird sings and heaps of butterflies flit about and oh! its just too lovely for words.
Later - it was extraordinarily hot this afternoon and I had to retire behind the hedge and divest myself of my knickers! hanging them up in a careless fashion so as to represent a coat!

April 27th, Sunday
Generally nearly a week elapses between my entries as otherwise I shall find myself with nothing to write in. I hope by next year to get a proper book again. This last week the weather has been lovely and we have much enjoyed the country. One day we took our tea down to the river in the Hazelbury meadows and another day Pink and I rode over to the Rawlins. The road there all through the lanes and low lying meadows is awfully pretty and the blackthorn is like snow on the hedges now, whilst primroses are everywhere. It has certainly been a most perfect Easter, so nice for the people, the first decent Easter they've had in Peace. One night Pink and I went out after dinner down to the stream armed with a lantern, a sheet, a hockey stick and a killing bottle to beat the palm bushes for moths. It was very still and very dark but quite warm and we got three and two caterpillars, much to our joy.

April 28th
Will it ever get warmer, here we are with May nearly upon us, a NE wind blowing, and a fall of snow this morning. Its all very well in normal times but now that our coal has again been reduced to half it doesn't tend to improve matters. I went basket making this afternoon and at 4.15 the girls came for me and we went on to the Pouletts to tea. She is a most amiable and simple lady, the children are spoilt and though endowed with everything this life holds are often peevish and gwingey (sic), a common trait in the children of the rich. She looks ill and worried and I think the young son and sole heir causes her much anxiety. He looks so frail. Poor thing I am sorry for her. I had today Eve's first letter since Win arrived and was so very interested to hear all about it.

April 29th
We are having the same hideous NE wind that we did last year. If it continues, goodbye to all fruit again, its bad luck, especially as we are promised sugar this year for jam making. This afternoon we went over to the nice Blakes. We all played wild games of Hide and Seek, Giants etc…I haven't run so much for ages and its good to pretend one is 14 again instead of 40!

April 30th
The children were going over to the Hopkins today but it turned too wet so we just footled at home.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: A second article (part of a much longer set of reports stuck into the diary), from the Daily Telegraph, April 14th, .

april.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

April as usual - warm and then cold...Wynne notes the grim news from Russia.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
A lot of Wynne's family were in India. Her sister Eve and her brother Elliot were over in the East, while her much loved cousin Yso was married to Denis Vanrennen, owner of a large estate in the Punjab, in what is now Pakistan. These photos were taken at Khilanmarg up in Kashmir. This was a favourite holiday destination, away from the heat of the plains. The top photo shows daughter Hazel and the ponies, while the bottom one shows the family sledging: Yso with three of the children - Hazel, Doris and John. Walter apparently avoided the photo!

A note from Jean Mitchell about the photos above:

I recognised Yso ('Granny Van' as we called her).She seemed to be on
the sled with Hazel and Doris (my Mum) with her brother,John,on the
other sled.We called him Uncle John,but he was commonly known as Jumbo
as he was very tall for those days.

During my preschool days,we used to spend the Summer in Kashmir,partly
in Srinagar and mostly in Gulmarg.I still have memories of that
time.Granny Van had a 'hut' in Gulmarg.It was a large dark brown
wooden building,quite rustic with a lovely garden,in a small valley
above the Vale of Gulmarg.The family often gathered there.I never knew
my grandfather,Denys Vanrenen.He died before I was born.A number of the
family were brilliant golfers,particularly Hazel.The only way up to
Gulmarg,in those days,was by horseback from a point where the road
ended from Srinagar.

It was a beautiful area,but unfortunately when my husband and I visited
Kashmir in 1988 much of the golf course and other structures were quite
run down,though there were signs of developing a ski resort.From the
description given on Kashmir Online.Net,the area appears to have been
opened and more fully developed as a holiday destination.I noticed in
the description of Ferozpore Nallah,'the stream is particularly good
for trout fishing'. My grandfather,on my father's side of my family,was
instrumental for introducing trout into the streams of Kashmir.There
was a pioneering spirit on both sides of the family.Unfortunately,
Kashmir became divided after the Partition of India in 1947 into India
and Pakistan.Gulmarg is on the Indian side.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
August 1st - 19th

Fetes galore, including a very successful W.I. event that raised £47. They visit Newnham to inspect the house again and meet the trustee.
viewer_2.description:
August 1st, Friday
A muggy wet day and last night sleeping out as is my custom I was soaked by heavy rain falling on my bed so with much fury I "left my watery nest" and dragged it into the house spending the rest of the night in my other bed! Yesterday we all went to the Merriott Fete, got up by the Women"s Institute. There were crowds there and all sorts of weird shows. The Lowes took and returned Mother and we didn't get back till 7.30. The children discovered the ice bucket and there was no getting away, the fancy dress procession was lovely, the two Jefferies winning 1st and 2nd prizes. One was a female looking for a house dragging a cart containing all his household goods and the other also a female represented the Merriott Women's Institute Drapery Stall, both awfully clever.
I spent a most interesting day down at the Bee man at Merriott, Mr Crowe. He showed me all his bees and told me such lots about them. It is a most engrossing subject and I am longing to start them in our new home but everything to do with them now is so expensive I don't know if I shall be able to do so.

August 17th, Sunday
Our household now consists of 13. On the 5th Charlie de Mornay came, on the 7th BG (Miss Scratchley, her old governess), and last Tuesday Freda Patterson, Nootsie's friend. Our days are spent in endless laughter and fun and the children rag from morn till eve. Last week on 14th our village W.I. fete came off, a lovely day and a great success. We worked feverishly for our stall and roped in £8.13.0. The vegetable show was splendid and we actually won 3 firsts for open class vegetables, eggs and herbs! I hear we have cleared over £47 with which we are well content. Last Monday H and I went up to Newnham there to meet the solicitor and the builder. We arrived at about 2.30 after an abominable journey. The heat was intense and the crowds frantic. After standing nearly all the way we arrived at length and picking up the solicitor Mr Haines on the way drove out to Broughtons. There we found the Wemyses in the throes of moving, a lovely old mess.
We met there Sir Francis Crawley Boevey our near neighbour and one of the Trustees who came up to see us. I was much taken with his kind and courtly manner. We proceeded to go all over the house and decide what needed doing and then they gave us tea on the lawn - mulberries and lashing of cream! All seems as though it will be very pleasant and nice but the Agreement still hops about between the lawyers and will continue to do so doubtless for some time.
Here I stick in two little snaps sent by Yso of her kids. (These are in the first window of this month). They propose coming home next year and I suppose she will have to leave some at home. We hear today that this house is sold - to the Hutchinsons. I am thankful it is sold so we shall now be no longer pestered by applicants. We have proposed to Davis this morning to take him with us and he is cogitating the matter and I wonder what he will decide! Martha comes with us and I am seeking a cook.

August 19th
Ell's birthday today bless him. I only wish he were here for it. It is a very dark , windy morning with a drizzle and I didn't find it at all pleasant out feeding the chickens. Teaed at the Marriotts, the boys playing tennis, much loud conversation, in fact it was like the macaws cage at the zoo. Heavy rain coming we returned. Eat our first ducks at dinner and as a result of this damp muggy weather they were high! Lovely.

(A picture of Wynne's brother, Elliot, is in the final window this month).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Winifred Lees, who had been living with Wynne throughout the war, was enjoying life on her side of the Indian subcontinent. Her father managed an estate called Lalseryah. Below you can see the house, and then a group ready for a fancy dress party. Win is marked with an x, and is in the single photo below.

The photos appear like this in the diary, so I have copied the whole page to show how Wynne put things in. She wrote so many letters that she had a lot of the sticky stamp paper that used to edge the sheets of stamps, and everything was stuck in with that. The pictures can lift in order to read the text.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
August 20th - 30th

Bug hunting in the fields at night, picnics on Ham Hill - a pleasant final few months in Hinton. They start the gradual process of packing up the house.
viewer_4.description:
August 20th, Wednesday
We had asked some young things to tennis today but it rained all day till tea so only Alison turned up and we all played around, even I playing and prancing about. After dinner we went off to Dimington treacling (sic - Wynne's word, this was a method of mixing a sugar solution which you paint onto surfaces to attract moths. It is normally called sugaring). It was a very clear and starlit night but very dark and as my lamp had to be used for inspection it went out as I started home. I thoroughly enjoyed it, so still and quiet down the in the meadows, and the wood above us full of owls holding a great deal of conversation. Half way home C's lamp went out too so Pink had to guide us both for we braved the policeman and rode! I love going forth on these expeditions and aim going again soon for as far as moths were concerned it was a dud night and we got none!

August 21st
I conceived the idea of going for a picnic to Ham Hill. Accordingly after lunch I and the 5 kids set forth leaving H, B and Mother to keep house. It was a perfect ride, no wind to worry, and when at length we climbed to the top of that huge place the view was splendid. We had tea, then the boys went bug hunting and we poked about the quarries, eventually getting home at 7.30. A lovely day.

August 22nd
We were all sorry to lose C who went home today (Charles de Mornay). Pink specially misses him. He went over to the Rawlins to play in a tennis tournament and came home with the 2nd prize!

August 23rd
Another lovely day. In the morning I made a basket for Mother and after lunch lay like a sleepy fly on a rug and went to sleep. After tea Mother and B went up to the Lowes to watch some tennis, Pink was at the Rawlins again, the girls up the village and down in the fields so H and I were actually alone. We did a lot of cleaning up and then attacked the hen houses. Our time here is getting short and soon I must begin to pack up and tidy up. Our agreement has not been signed yet and is now with the Charity Commissioners but I hope all will be well and I am longing for it to be settled.

August 27th, Wednesday
We all intended to go to Lyme yesterday but alas a high wind and heavy showers at intervals put the lid on that.

Aug 28th
Such rain again, torrents. We have been packing up my little collection cabinet, such a business.

August 29th, Friday
Rain falling in torrents and I've been writing and paying bills all morning. Arrangements re the new home go on gradually. We've bought all the outside effects, also take over from tomorrow so far as the gardener is concerned. He stays there till Michaelmas and then we are in hopes that Blake will return to us. We have written to him and had his reply. It would be most useful to have him as he is such a good and knowledgeable man.


(Blake, seen here photographed in 1924, was married to Lettie, who was Maggie the nanny's sister - he had worked for a long time at Brookfield until the lease was given up by Wynne's mother, and he did come to Gloucester, though that move did not last for long.)

August 30th
We spent the morning packing up the dolls house and Noots' cabinet and I laughed so over it. Mother did it and I assisted and by the end of the morning we both felt exhausted and lunatic. It was a job and the unpacking will be about as awful for there are such multitudes of things. (Herbert and Wynne had built a dolls house for the two girls, and made all the contents themselves. H was a very proficient carpenter in his spare time).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Win's brother Elliot was also out in India, and lived quite near his sister. He managed an indigo estate, and as you can read, was also a Colonel in the Behar Light Horse, and had been made an ADC to the Viceroy.

august.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Final times at Hinton - and another visit to see the new house.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Three operas in a day sounds a bit extravagant, but Wynne was always determined to make the most of London visits. Sir Thomas Beecham had started his series of opera productions in 1910 (you can see other programmes in previous years), and his initiative had not only popularised the art form but introduced very interesting new work to London audiences.
(See December 20th)

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
December 16th - 19th

House arrangements finally completed, everyone goes to London for Christmas. Wynne looks for servants and finds none, and they all attend a magic show.
viewer_2.description:
December 16th, Tuesday
After struggling for the past 3 weeks during which time I have had to put my diary aside we have at last got the house straight and this day set forth for the joyous Town and Mother. I really am looking forward to my holiday more than I can say. One long time of real hard work, interesting but a grind as well and not like an ordinary move, however its all over now and here we are settled for a bit over a fortnight. We brought Martha up with us, parting form her at Paddington where H put her into the tube and the first thing she did was to fall into H on the escalator! I came on with the luggage and arrived here 6.30 to find Mother and B very well and jolly.

December 17th
This house that Mother has is very nice , much larger than the flat, with big high rooms which show off all her lovely furniture to great advantage. A large drawing room and dining room, and very nice sitting hall and huge basement in which (are) our bedrooms and which looks out on to the garden. This latter she has had dug and manured and planted with bulbs and herbaceous things, a little lawn in the centre and some almonds, laburnum an lilac all round, it will be quite pleasant in the Spring and Summer. This day we spent shopping at the stores, a wild lunatic asylum, a mass of struggling people, weary and harassed assistants and hours of wait to buy each single article. Very tiring and brain turning.

December 18th
Today the two girls came back and we went to meet them at Paddington. After lunch we went again to the stores and frantically tried to get Xmas presents but it is a hopelessgame and deadly tiring.

December 19th
I went off this morning to Hunts Registry in the vain hope of finding a cook, but one clerk just hands you to another who merely tells you it is hopeless, takes your address and promises in a languid way to send anyone to you who applies and that's all. This utter dearth of servants is frantic. The other day the unemployment pay came to an end putting 34,000 women in to the market and still there seems no servants to be had, everyone is in the same way, nobody has any, many people are doing without altogether and the present time has earned for itself the name of the "Do It Yourself Age". We are assured that after Christmas they will become more plentiful. From Hunts I went off to Evans and bought more things and suffered more buffeting. At length being ladened from head to foot with parcels I took a taxi and went home in style. On arrival I found my dear son, H having gone to meet him. After lunch we all went off to Maskelyne and Devants and there saw many wonderful things, the conjuring was excellent, a man called de Bierre doing the main part following a magical play and scientific electric display. We saw light and heat by wireless and also lightening, all of which simply leaves one amazed at the brain of man. (Note - Maskelyne was dead by this time, and Devant, one of the most celebrated illusionists of his age, was about to retire. It is possible they saw Devant at least, though it looks as if his role has been taken by the aforesaid de Bierre. You will find earlier pre-war references to these shows, so Wynne had seen Maskelyne in the past).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Home and Beauty was a very popular production, starring Gladys Cooper, whose photo brought you here.
(See December 22nd)

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
December 20th - 23rd

Three operas in one day, a play (Home and Beauty), independent taxi drivers and crowded tube trains. Christmas in London in fact.
viewer_4.description:
December 20th, Saturday
Never before I am sure has it been my lot to do three operas in one day! but I did it today. The kind Duke sent us two boxes and in the evening Susanna's Secret and La Boheme were given whilst in the afternoon we had Boris Godounov. Mother and Ella Healey went in the afternoon and the Skippys who it was a great joy to see. We all met at the box and about half way through Poggy turned up. The children meanwhile were out with Aim at the Alhambra. Boris G is a Russian opera but as it was produced by Beecham it was in English which I must say at times sounds very crude! but the music is fine and at time very wild. I am sure if one heard it often enough it would appeal to one still more. We had tea at the box in great comfort as usual and after a great struggle managed to secure a taxi to come home in. They are so independent these days that if they don't like your locality they simply wont drive you! Well we got home just in time to change, have some light food and taking with us the two elder children dashed forth again. It was a milestone in their lives as it was their first opera, and two more things which added value to the event were that La Boheme was given and it was Beecham's last night of the season. We like Susanna's Secret very much, it is light farce and very amusing, and of course Boheme is perfect, one cannot see it too often, perfect music and splendid voices. There is not one poor voice in all his company and it was a joy. I sat there at the finish and howled as I always do but I'm not at all ashamed . At the end the audience rose to a man and went mad, they cheered and shrieked and whistled making the performers come forward again and again and then yelled for Beecham. When this clever but conceited ass thought they'd shrieked enough he came forward with gracious bows and acceding to their oft repeated request made a long speech and practically the house remained full until he had finished. So ended a memorable day!

Dec 21st
Its just lucky that Sunday comes round occasionally or we should all be dead! Today beyond going to church nearby at St Philips in Earls Court Road we stayed at home. I don't care much for St Philips , the music is nothing special and the preacher very mediocre but it has the advantage of being near at hand, which is an advantage when you are indulging in late risings!

December 22nd
We spent the whole day from morn till evening shopping again, more rushing and scratching and fighting, more agitated and harassed assistants and further fruitless efforts to get what we wanted. We spent, H and I, a delightful evening dining and going to see "Home and Beauty" with my dear Blanche Gray. The play was excellent, entirely improper and most tut tut but Hawtrey was as good as ever and it was very pleasant rolling there and back in a lovely car with two men on the box!

December 23rd
H went off to Margate today to spend the night with Mary (his unmarried sister) poor old thing, she is very seedy. Pink went off at 10 to pick up Charles and do a day with him, while I took the two girls to the stores once more to do a little final shopping. We bought buns there and rushed off at 1 to stand for a Pit at Chu Chin Chow, arriving at His Majesty we found that it was closed until Boxing Day so we went on to the Coliseum but finding that de Bierre was on there and having seen him at Makselyne we thought we'd go to the Hippodrome so on we rushed and there in the centre of the front seats we found Pinkie and Charles and so after the performance we all went to the Corner House and had tea together. The performance lasted for hours beginning with a cinema and continued by being a Revue with Robey all through it. He is good and we all died with laughing. the whole house was packed and we were high up in the Upper Circle. I have such a stupid head that I couldn't with comfort look down at the stalls. We crushed home in the Tube which is horrible these days, fighting and pushing for standing room and hanging on to the straps like so many hams in the larder. I was glad to get home.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Cinderella - the Christmas pantomime had become an essential fixture in the calendar. But Wynne missed Dan Leno - check out her earlier visit in 1896. She also saw him on March 1st 1902.
(December 27th - the performance lasted from 1.30 until 6pm).

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
December 24th - 26th

Christmas. Two church services are attended, but plenty of time for stockings in the morning and turkey and plum pudding in the evening.
viewer_6.description:
December 24th, Xmas Eve
Not feeling that our Xmas shopping was complete we sallied forth again. Mother's boy from the cripple home came at 11 and we all went along to the High Street (Kensington). We rushed into the P.O. with dozens of parcels and then we all went into Cramer to listen to some records which we intended to buy. We also visited Hopes, Pontings, Barkers, and Derry and Toms. We returned home like dead flies and lay about snatching a hard earned rest having persuaded Mother to alter her fixed determination to have the presents on Xmas Eve! Thurie came and spent the evening and helped to fill the stockings.

December 25th, Thursday.
Xmas Day
I've never spent Xmas in London before in my life, it is a curious experience and to all outward appearances it might be a Sunday. I borrowed the maid's alarm clock and set it for six but awoke at intervals from 3 onwards because the clock, which looked distinctly anaemic, I thought might fail and lucky I did so for at six it gave forth a few feeble croaks like a sick frog which never would have disturbed my slumbers. I crept upstairs in the dark and roused my three sleepy children who came quickly to life when they saw that Father Christmas had called. We all bundled down to Daddy, roused the poor thing well up and made tea whilst the contents of stockings were unearthed. At 7 we got up and dressed, H, P and I went to the early service at St Philips. There we found crowds and crowds of people, how different from the little country celebrations, 6 or 7 clergy and people being marshalled by sidemen. I don't care much for that sort of thing, so unrestful. For Mattins we went to St Margarets Westminster, a service I always like with its beautiful music and perfect setting. They now have their old East window back in again which was taken down and replaced by plain glass all through the perilous times. Canon Carnegie preached and it was nice to hear his irish accent again. We walked home as far as Hyde Park when a downpour drove us to seek the Tube. After lunch we did dead fly for a while and after tea we had our presents. It seemed strange having no tree but anything like decorations are so awfully expensive that it was impossible to contemplate so we just set tables and the presents thereon and all enjoyed ourselves very much. For dinner we had a huge turkey and the usual plum pudding and then played wild games of Snatchcork with shrieks and yells so that our neighbours must have thought us very trying. H and I got a lot of lovely things and I have so many letters to answer I don't know where to begin.

December 26th
I stayed in all the morning and got through a lot of letters of thanks. This afternoon we took the children to the British Museum. It was years since I had been there and their first visit. A vast place and one wants months to see a third of its glorious possessions. We simply were in the Brahmin, Buddhist Central Asia and Ancient Mexican and Peruvian sections and I was so fearfully interested and engrossed that I could have stayed for hours but alas the time slipped quickly by and we had to return.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
A typical Christmas card from the occupying forces living in Germany - this one comes from Major Gore Browne - he had been a Captain under Herbert, hence the reference to Swanage. He was now stationed in Germany. His letter written inside the card is transcribed below it. If you follow the link it will take you to 1915, where you can read two more letters from him.

Christmas Card from S Gore-Browne, based with the Army in Germany

Dear General
I've been meaning to answer your letter since last January when I received it. I am so ashamed. I hope you and Mrs Jackson and your son and daughter are all flourishing. I sent him a knife from here, as its one of the things the Bosch turns out pretty decently.
I finished up in the 5th Division last April when it ceased to exist, and came on here to GHQ. At this actual moment I'm C.E.S. (more or less) to Sir William as my General's on leave. I'm wondering how long I'll survive. Normally I'm GS Operations and Staff duties with a good big department doing things like neutral Zone moves to Silesia and other things over and above the usual defence schemes and organisation. It's all extraordinarily interesting, and its been a wonderful year.
Its funny to think of Swanage and then of Cologne - they seem so very far apart. I was up in Berlin the other day and there you really do feel you've won the war. Please remember me to Mrs Jackson.
Yours sincerely, S Gore Browne.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
December 27th - 31st

Cinderella, Peter Pan, a church service at the Tower of London, and a visit to the war-depleted Zoo. The New Year is seen in in style.
viewer_8.description:
December 27th, Saturday
An early lunch today and off to the Panto for which we had the Duke's box again. At 12.30 we all crammed into a taxi and drove to Drury Lane. Cinderella is on this year and I think its quite as beautiful as it has ever been and very amusing and clever. Florence Smithson is Cinderella and is rather improved, not quite so much of an ass as formerly. Will Evans, Lupino funny as always, and new man du Calion most entertaining. I laughed a great deal but to my mind no one ever has come up to old Dan Leno, or is it that one found it easier to laugh in those days? I hardly think that can be so for he was a Prince among comedians. the colours of the costumes and scenery were perfect. At the interval we all went and had tea in the drawing room , a not unwelcome break as the performance last from 1.30 to 6.0! The house was densely packed and I hear there is not a seat to be had. We got a taxi after much trouble. The streets at night now are so brilliant again, so different from last year's utter gloom.

Dec 28th
My family is indulging in colds, an almost unavoidable disaster in Town where every shop and place of entertainment is so boiling hot and the weather winter. Poggy kept to the house today very wisely owing to a return of lumbago and neuralgia consequent of the said cold. I meanwhile took the three (kids) off to church at the Tower, where I always love to go and where "the spirits of the departed" are so present. It is a nice soldier service too and the Padre who came out afterwards to talk to us is so nice. We are going on Thursday to see the old place under his guidance. After lunch I and Noots went off to see poor Gertie who is in the Nightingale Hospital under treatment for a month. We went all the way on the top of a bus, a way of getting about I like best!

December 30th
A very busy day and out from 10.30 until 6.0. H and I went off to the City to try and buy a drawing room lamp but found that they were all so awfully expensive that we returned to the Aux Stores and found a much cheaper one. The children meanwhile had gone off with a packet of sandwiches to spend the day at the Zoo. We joined them there and had lunch but alas it poured with rain as it nearly always does so we could only hurry from house to house. Many of the poor animals had to be shot during the War on account of a lack of food and many died from food difficulties of the right kind but they are gradually getting up their stock again.

December 31st, Wednesday
When we first came to Town we tried at once for seats for Peter Pan and were told that all seats were engaged for the next six weeks. The children were dashed as it was their particular wish to see it again. We happened the other day to mention it to Blanche Gray and a few days later she rang us up, indeed came over to see Mother to say she had procured seats and would we all go with her. So we all went to her to lunch and afterwards to this Play which is Immortal to grown ups and children alike. We missed Pauline Chase, but Renee Mayer was very sweet as Wendy and if Peter was somewhat disappointing the whole was so delightful that we felt entirely satisfied. The house was crammed with children, some so tiny that wails and shrieks resounded when Nanna the dog was banished from the Nursery. It is a mistake to take such tinies (sic), they only cause disturbance to others. We had tea in the theatre and ate chocolates, this time with no ill effects for I remember well the last time we saw the play some 5 years ago the chocolates made the whole party sick in the night. We got back about 6 after which we spent a strenuous night seeing the New Year in. We played games of skill and chance till 11.30 when we removed to the dining room where we had a lovely supper and drank champagne, drank to the King, then our hostess and then absent friends and last but not least Mdle!! At 12 we opened the windows and from outside there came prolonged and loud sounds of rockets, hooters, church bells and shouting. We all turned out on to the pavement, Mother included, and I and the children danced round in a ring with many shrieks and squeaks. The bells and hooters went on for quite a long time though our street itself was quiet and so ended 1919. A year of unrest and much badness. Peace is signed and yet how very far we are from it, for in many parts men are still fighting and the Labour question is still much vexed. To look at the shops you would never think we'd been at War but prices are very high of course and food though plentiful is very expensive. However thank God we are better off in this country than most and in no way can we or may we complain.

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9

viewer_10.title: Viewer 10
viewer_10.description: The end page of the diary, with art work by Blanche, Wynne's Mother, who also supplied the tag.

december.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

The house finally settled, the family go to London to spend Christmas with Wynne's Mother.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne was a great believer in fresh air! In the summer, she liked to sleep out of doors in her garden, and as you can see, back in 1912, her Mother's disapproving cartoon after a visit tells the whole story!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 6th

Strikes and freezing weather make life difficult. "A spirit of Bolshevism" is in the air and Wynne praises the Defence of the Realm Act.
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Saturday
As one picks up our daily paper nowadays nothing but strikes and labour unrest greet one. Everyone is striking and Belfast and Glasgow have consequently been indulging of course in riots. Now the railways are threatening again, miners of course are doing the same, and that charming society the Engineers, its all very sad and horrible but there seems throughout the whole world a spirit of Bolshevism let loose and it runs like a consuming fire up and down the country. One cannot foresee how it will end and one is thankful these days to be far away from any big manufacturing town, though in time it must of course affect us too. A busy day - I've been basket making and my hands are sore and bruised! but I've made quite a decent basket. I had to attend a sale at Hospital and sat at the receipt of custom of the kitchen dept. I afterwards had tea at the Lowes and counted out the total gains which amounted to just on £90, and as the residue is to be sold by auction they'll certainly clear over £100. Today's money is all from helpers as no outsiders were allowed in at all. One woman paid for her stuff in gold!! and said the Merriott mill hands were paid in gold today!

Feb 2nd
To Kirk this morn, an icey sleet came down and all the country looked black with cold. Our hot water is behaving abominably so that we cannot even get a decent bath. Who would live in England during this horrible season.

Feb 3rd
I have been so frozen today that I was quite relieved to get some digging so as to get warm.

Feb 4th
Oh! no, this flight of butterflies is ridiculous, they never go about in flocks in February. If Mother had painted fleas instead there would have been some sense in it for I am sure Peter brings heaps in, he being at present on the rampage. (Wynne's mother had taken the 1919 diary at the end of 1918, and painted little pictures all the way through it, including these. Most of the painted illustrations are by her, including those built into the design of this web site. They are almost all signed with a miniscule B, for Blanche).
This morning we carried the eggs down to the Webbs. 7 dozen, and sold for 4/9d a doz. They are laying well just now and we hope so much to partly meet our food bills this way.

Feb 5th
I have a letter from dear Ell written from Calcutta where as is usual with all Indian people seemingly he was having a great time. I hear from Win today that her only chance of getting out is if she gets a berth on the Naroya, a P.O. boat sailing on the 27th and if that fails then she'll have to wait till autumn. I do hope it will really come off this time.

Feb 6th
There has for sometime now been stirring throughout civilisation a spirit of Bolshevism so called from its origin in Russia which country has by its tactics been plunged into terrible chaos. Germany too of late has been rampant with it and its poison or something very like it is with us now. So long as we had a war the country was at one but since the Armistice has been signed we are treated to one big strike after another. Belfast, the Clyde, Glasgow and now London, beside of course the miners who are ever ready to "down tools". Today the Railway are out so that if anyone had wanted to leave Crewkerne they would just have been disappointed for the station was shut! The most extraordinary spirit of unrest is astir and where it will end is a mystery. The Engineers threatened to cut off London's electric supply but the Govt has stepped in and under the much abused D.O.R.A has decide to use extreme measure which I hope will steady the people Its all a hopeless outlook, the men strike simply because its a poison in their brains and their demands are nothing short of delirious, always up to now they have been given into only to bring about increased demands but it cannot go on without crippling the country. All the tubes were shut yesterday and all the waiters at hotels and restaurants came out so that guests had to wait upon themselves or go without. Despite these enormous outside happenings we pursue our rural occupations in peace, wood sawing all the morning, basket making all afternoon and very sore fingers the result!
(DORA was the Defence of the Realm Act. These opinions were widespread at that time in this class - Wynne had no experience of conditions in the mines, for instance, but it is interesting to see how early the rumblings of discontent manifested themselves, culminating in the General Strike of 1926).

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne used to include lots of fashion pictures at the back of each diary, so here and in the next picture window you can see some examples from . Of the ones here, I particularly like their names - Cannes and Monico...I wonder who was responsible for that. Naming the designs was common, but spelling them incorrectly less so.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 7th - 22nd

Railways, Engineers, even Waiters are all on strike. Village visiting and W.I. work keep Wynne busy.
viewer_4.description:
February 7th, Friday
Can it really be 11 years to the very day since my precious Babbit arrived? We despatched yesterday various parcels to her but as the railways are on strike there is no knowing when she'll get them so we sent her a wire this morning. The strike fever is raging, the Engineers threaten to cut off London's light, the waiters are still out and as for the railways chaos reigns and all the Tubes are closed.

Feb 8th
When we awoke this morning there were frost flowers all over the windows, the first this year in spite of the intense cold. I went up to get some more withies at the Alms House after lunch and had a crack with Mary Cridge. Her abode and the approach to it are just like entering the Ash pit. The garden borders are decorated with oyster shells, tin lids, old rags and boxes. At the door is a wire entanglement where abide two hens, on the top of them in a box hung round with rags a jackdaw lives, the floor of whose cage is strewn with unconsidered trifles for him to play with. Beside this two cats greet one at the door. The interior is a strange collection of miscellanies. 6 China dogs, two of which are red and embrace impossible castles, sit on one chest. The mantle shelf is a mass of painted tea tins, photographs resting on woollen mats, broken teapots jostling for elbow room with pots of jam, plates, cruets and vases. Its all like the dwelling of the Witch of Gorgonzola and Mary, who suffers from "the sciatics", stands proudly in its midst which reminds me of another old female here who says she cannot sleep for the "newrighteous"! From her I went to visit Sgt Major Higgins' wife. They are a nice couple, he was a patient here in hospital and has settled down in Hinton. Then I made a vain attempt at both the village shops to get some chocolate or sweets and found actually sugared almonds, a thing in peace time I hated, but all is welcome these days.

Feb 16th, Sunday
A week has passed since I wrote in here. Miss Collins, our toy making teacher, turned up on Monday and stayed until Thursday. We put her up here and worked hard at toys all day long, having two classes a day. I accomplished a frog, a duck and a pig and am now doing a doll. Its very interesting but not at all easy. On Friday the Jackdaw (D.W.Whitehead) came. He is looking well after his long stay in hospital and is now discharged and gets to work soon.

Feb 17th
Influenza is raging again. We hear that Chard is all down with it. Nootsie writes that Malvern is ditto, and out of 58 girls only 7 remain up. its really like a nightmare and I do hope and trust it will sweep past us. Strikes of all sorts continue and we are in danger now of a general coal strike. If this happens it will plunge the country into chaos. The prospect is a real horror as if one cannot get coal one must do without everything else. God grant it may not come.

Feb 21st, Friday
The boy left today and it has rained nearly the whole of his stay. We walked for miles in spite of it and my liver should be in excellent working order but I could scream at this daily deluge.

Feb 22nd
I was in the middle of breakfast this morning when the phone rang. Spitting forth anathemas I went to answer it and heard to my joy Win's voice announcing the delightful news that she has at long last got her passage and sails on the "Nagoya" on Thursday 27th. We are going up on Monday toss tay for a week and see her off. I have been assisting at a sale of rubbish at the hospital today, and that is the very last time I shall enter its portals. That whole show is now done and finished with, thanks be!

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Tailor-mades and Afternoon gowns....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 24th - 28th

Win, Wynne's niece, who has lived with the family throughout the War, finally gets a berth on a boat to take her home to India.
viewer_6.description:
February 24th, Monday
A busy morning dashing around doing last jobs before going to Town. Interviews about basket making, toy making, nursing assistants etc till I felt glad to escape from it all. We journeyed up by the 2.23 arriving at about 7 and found all well at the flat. Win very excited naturally.

Feb 25th
Its awfully nice being up here again in this dear old city though the Influenza is raging and I am old maidish enough to gargle at all hours! We went up to the Stores and Harrods today shopping various things, home to lunch and out again up West. Afterwards I took 10 of Mother's rings to the Goldsmiths to get them cleaned, met Win who had been lunching out, and all went to tea at the Club.

Feb 26th
I have spent the whole day packing for Win and doing last jobs. Her hold trunk, cabin ditto, hat box, sent case and holdall. All is now finished and ready to go. I didn't go out all day but H went down to Liverpool St with the luggage and deposited it in the cloak room for the night and Win went out to say goodbye to Miss Barnes and Mrs Lees.

Feb 27th
I am not happy tonight. My Win has gone and as it may be years before I see her again I cant bear to say goodbye. We went down to Tilbury and saw her on board but were not allowed on ourselves. I hated her going off like this all alone but no other arrangement was possible and so I trust all will be well.

Feb 28th
This is the last day of February. It has been a horrible month, so wet and so cold and I'm glad to see it go. We have decided to stay up here another week and shall return on 8th. It is a great treat to be up and see some of ones friends again after our benighted life in the Sleepy Hollow. How small and petty life down there seems after the great concerns of this big city, the huffs of Miss W, the gossip of Mrs G, the petty jealousies and ridiculous "feelings" by which one is persecuted, up here one simply forgets the whole bag of tricks and in 6 months we quit the gossip sink for ever thanks be.

february.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Strikes paralyse the nation - a spirit of Bolshevism in the air.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: The first page for ...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 10th

Normal life continues, as does the cold weather. A good dinner at the end of hte wek is accompanied by a notable relaxation of standards!
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Wednesday
After a fine still night the New Year has begun in tempest, a raging wind and torrents of rain kept us in all day and so we celebrated the beginning of 1919 by playing the ancient game of "Pug", a game introduced to us as children by a queer and eccentric old female called Miss Wales. It is merely "Spy" with the addition of screams attached and is of so thrilling a nature that old and young are alike fascinated.

January 2nd
I am much delighted at having induced Mother to paint in my Diary this year. I sent her the book and she has returned it with all these neat little pictures throughout. I tried to get my usual size but like everything else in these days of shortage I failed and could only secure this one which has but 182 pages in it so I'll not be able to write every day this year. This afternoon Poggy and I rode over to the Blakes at Marks Barn. The mud is feet deep on the roads and H who rode Davis's machine skidded and came off but no damage done.

January 3rd
The cold has arrived. I had to attend a committee meeting at 3.30 and rode up to the village in torrents of rain and on my return was caught in a blinding snowstorm.

January 4th, Saturday
Spent the entire day mending the children's clothes!

Jan 5th
I really thinks we all should get the V.C. for off we went to church as per usual. I wrote letters all afternoon before a huge wood fire.

Jan 6th, 7th and 8th
It is not laziness which makes me combine three days into one entry but simply that my diary is so small so that unless anything of note happens I feel I must not waste space. A lot of snow still lies about but we are having great storms and a good deal of rain so that it is gradually disappearing.

Jan 9th, Thursday
I am now a victim of the house cold and having a mind to nip it in the bud I have stayed in bed today. Win (took) the children to a party for me, they all went off at 5 looking very nice in their white serges! (This is a reference to the material used). We have heard from Ell who wrote from Bombay and so we feel happy now - he got there on the 6th.

January 10th
I quite forgot to make a note of a great event which occurred here on Tuesday. To our amazement we received an invitation to dinner with the Lowes, and there found Mrs L, her two sons and two daughters. We spent a very pleasant evening and had a jolly good dinner, a thing not to be despised these days. After dinner I was electrified at being offered a cigarette and was joined in this by Miss Lucy Lowe the Principle of Leeds, and Mrs L was not shocked!!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Family photographs taken outside the house at Hinton, in what looks like freezing weather. Note the gun under Pink's arm (he was just 16), in the first photo, where he is standing looking at Ysobel. The second photo shows him with Eleanore (Baby) and the final one is of Herbert looking like he does not approve of the photography session.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 11th - 16th

Various dances, including the Women's Institute Social for the village - a jolly affair for all.
viewer_4.description:
January 11th, Saturday
The weather was kind and fair and mild, so this afternoon I roped in the family and made them come weed picking on the kitchen garden paths with me, but it was a very rebellious gang I had to deal with, Win finally declaring that if she ever had a garden it should have asphalt paths, linoleum lawn and just a large pond in the middle in which she would sit all day! In the evening we went to the Hopkins' dance which began at 6.30 and went on to 12, a fearful rag and as to begin with I fell back against the stove and cut my head I didn't enjoy the rest of the evening much but they all loved it and we came home dead to the world.

January 12th
This is my son's birthday, the creature is 16 today and in honour of the fact I have here stuck in these neat little pictures he copies from his stamps. We hid his presents after breakfast as is our usual custom but alas of late no birthday parties or treats can take place, however the time is coming when such things can be renewed.

Jan 13th
Our Women's Institute gave a Social after its monthly meeting this evening and it was a very animated and amusing show, almost the entire village turned up, the maidens in their elegant attire, the swains in their blacks besides a good many tommies. Dancing was the order of the evening and we hopped round from 7.30 until 11.30 with a break for refreshments. The dances were chiefly Polkas, Veletas, Schottisches and Lancers, all danced with extreme correctness, and at the end of each they retired to exactly the same seats they had come from hand in hand. Poor people, they get little enough amusement out of life, especially the women who work from morning to night day after day.

Jan 15th, Wednesday
Yesterday was a day of Peace! I personally was rather relieved for today we sprang forth once more and I took the three elder to a dance at the Hoskyns. They have a large and very comfortable house, we danced in the Hall and there were heaps of places to sit out in and smoke and eat. I have come to the conclusion however that in these days of outré dancing of the Fox Trot, Chicken Scratch, Tickle Toes, One and Two Steps, these days when the splendid Waltz is no more, that dancing is a thing of the past for me. I think the present style is horrible, suggestive and vile.

Jan 16th
We have been having weeks of drenching weather and discovered today that the drawing room is so damp that the furniture is becoming unstuck! so we have transferred ourselves thither for the evenings simply to air the room. But thanks be the evenings are lighting up and we shall soon have less damp to contend with. We always tea without a lamp now and at 4.30 on a fine day such as today it is quite light.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Posters from the War years, calling on women to enrol. The war liberated women.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 17th - 22nd

The house-party breaks up - for school, and for Win to go to London to try and get a passage to India...after years of separation from her parents.
viewer_6.description:
January 17th, Friday
A perfect day, bright clear and windless almost and in the morning the whole family turned out and went ferreting, we got 2 rabbits and ended by losing the ferret, of this I am awfully sad. I only gave it to Pink at Xmas and it was such a beauty, that's the fourth that has come to grief! After lunch we all went sawing and cleaving wood, a splendid occupation for a frosty day, and we achieved a large quantity. We burn nothing but wood and coke in the drawing room, leaving the coal for the kitchen, and we seldom light a fire at all until after tea. Imagine one existing in former times in winter without a fire all day.

January 18th
Win's passage may come to hand any day now owing to Mr Lyall's kind effort and I am so envying her and long to go too (to India). She is very busy doing all sorts of jobs and we've been packing up a huge case which is to go to Calcutta. We had news today of a house at Long Marston in Worcs which I intend to view from Malvern when I go up with the children on Thursday.

Jan 19th
Went to 7.0 Service and it was so dark that it felt like going out in the middle of the night. The cold has permeated into all my bones and only now at 6.0 when we sit with curtains drawn and a huge wood fire am I warm at last. I've just finished "Adam Bede", the first of G. Eliot's book I've read. I'm ashamed never to have read any of hers before.

Jan 20th
Today my dear Win left us and the chances are I may not see her again because if by any evil fate she should sail on Thursday I shall be at Malvern seeing the children to school. We shall all miss her more than I can say after so many years of having her as our own child but I feel glad too that the time has come when her long period of waiting and that of her people is nearly over for one realises how very much they must be dying to have her.

Jan 21st, Tuesday
Everyone is moaning and groaning about the weather which is persistently wet. The roads are appalling, as I know to my cost having had to ride to Lopen today and to Crewkerne. I got mud all over my dress, even my coat, and it is an exertion, almost like riding over plough. I had a letter today from P.G. (Lyster). He is stationed at a place called Colinton in Midlothian, in a Reserve Battery, and he and his wife are in their first home, how strange it must be to him to be in harness again after four years imprisonment.

Jan 22nd
I need to look at this picture today, it is a suitable tonic for Pink returned to Wellington and tomorrow I have to take the girls to Malvern so our very jolly Xmas holidays are really over. I often wonder if children can realise how horrible parents feel on these occasions, poor dear ones, they naturally feel that it's worse for them and they'll not see differently until they've tried being parents!

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: More posters - This time for the Land Army and the Women's Royal Air Force.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 23rd - 31st

The two girls are left at Malvern. Wynne returns to a freezing house.
viewer_8.description:
January 24th, Friday
I have missed out yesterday because I had nothing to record but a seven hours journey (to Malvern). This day however I've been on an interesting quest to look at a house called "King's Lodge" at Long Marston. I did not think much of the outside but was much struck by the interior which is as old as one could wish, all oak beams and rafters and queer levels. It is the house to which Charles 2 fled after Worcester. The house has part central heating, acetylene gas and co.Water (company water, ie: mains),three great assets. We hear that the owner who is in France has had an offer and if he accepts then all is off. I got back at 5.30, took B out to tea and at 7.30 Noots came over for an hour's talk.

Jan 25th
I said goodbye to my two dears this morning and left by the 11.21. It is bitterly cold and the whole countryside covered with frozen floods, the trains were crowded and when I got to Taunton where I had a 2 hours wait it had begun to rain and so I couldn't leave the station. By the time I reached Ilminster at 7.0 I had had about enough and was rejoiced to see my Poggy awaited me.

Jan 26th
Two quaint conceptions copied by my idle niece (Win) from the Bad Child's Book of Beasts. Failing anything original from her pencil I am forced to preserve these relics of her art, but she is naughty. She can draw so well and never does. Win has so far heard nothing of a passage and I am so afraid she will be disappointed again, every ship is crowded and after Feb is out Govt is commandeering all available tonnage on account of demobilisation. She may get a returned passage.

Jan 27th
It is bitterly cold and the snow is falling in great lumps but the ground is I should think far too wet for it to lie. I think of my three poor babies all freezing in detestable class rooms and call an anathema on all schools.

Jan 28th
A letter this morning from far Tristan da Cuhna. This is in answer to one of mine written Feb 11th, 1918 and is dated May 22nd but may not have been posted for some time. (You can see a similar one received in 1918, written in 1917).

Jan 31st
Good riddance of another Jan for a whole year more and I trust Feb will go as fast. The cold is intense and we perish in this "House of Winds". I sit as close to the fire as I can get and I have six under garments on, a velvet tea gown and shawl, and my feet are deep in a huge fur bag and still they are cold. I nearly died bicycling up to basket class and went up again on various errands after lunch. Our hot water arrangements are making things still more comfortable by refusing to play up and it is a very vile deprivation. Despite the cold my hens are laying well and we've had 380 (eggs) this month.

january.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Life has returned to a sort of normality, with dances and travel, but the cold is vicious

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne had worked tirelessly throughout the war, and once down at Hinton had been assigned work in the hospital for wounded soldiers, where she did everything including the washing up. This was a thank you sent to the thousands of volunteers.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 21st

A visit to Newnham, in the Forest of Dean, to see a house...and an unpleasant night in a Bristol boarding house!
viewer_2.description:
July 5th, Saturday
The whole of the last two pages of this book are a wash out. H went up and saw the house, thought it would suit and wrote on Tuesday offering to buy it, the owner having said not to wire, that a letter would do, and on Thursday came his reply saying that having received no wire he had sold it to another applicant. Some people have strange ways, so we are "as you were" and must begin all over again.

July 21st, Monday
This year's diary will be a stupid one as I can only make short entries. The lack of paper and not being able to write regularly make it so uninspiring. On 16th H and I went off house hunting to Newnham, near Gloucester. We had previously been down to Beaminster to see one there, a most charming old place but much in need of modernising, no bath room, no water laid on, antiquated kitchen range with Jack and spit! This one near Newnham is an old house brought up to date with electric light, water laid on and all etc standing on a rise with the Forest of Dean on one side and the Severn on the other in 18 acres of land. Well we are quite pleased with it and its worth thinking over. We missed our connection at Gloucester and had to wait 2 hours then on our return we went and walked about. The town was gay in flags and bunting and there were crowds of people. We tried to see the Cathedral but they always close at 6. We put up at Bristol for the night where we failed for some time to get a room, at last we were taken in at a lodging house and given a room belonging to a man who was absent for the night. It was lucky getting in anywhere but Oh! what a filthy place, they didn't even give us clean linen, the sheets were his! and the pillow cases and towels begrimed, it was more than I could bear and so I remonstrated. The landlady, a regular stereotype article, was furious and offered to turn us out! She certainly had the upper hand there for we couldn't walk onto the streets at 10 therefore we had to cave in and I wrapped my pillow up in my dressing gown. On Sat we celebrated in concert with the rest of the country the Peace - we were to have tea, sports and dancing in the Park but the rain saw to it that we did not so we had the feed and a dance in the schools. All day long we prepared and at 4.30 began the feed, it was a real success. The sports are to be held the first fine day, but the weather has badly broken and is quite unsettled again.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A newspaper reaction to the industrial turmoil...

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
July 25th - 31st

Another coal strike is on, and the result will be higher food prices and fewer trains. The move to Gloucester however would appear to be agreed.
viewer_4.description:
July 25th, Friday
This four leaved clover has come just appropriately, for today my blessed little maids return for the holidays and I can hardly wait until 3 when we go to Taunton to meet them. On Wednesday the Mothers' Union had their annual festival. We teaed at the Lowes first and then proceeded to service where Canon Coles talked to us and then at 6.30 the village held their sports. I didn't go down as bean bottling claimed me and I couldn't leave but H went and all seemed to go off very well. As I write of these peaceful proceedings there comes into my mind the turbulent affairs of labour, for we are in the midst of another coal strike. The Yorkshire miners with fury in their hearts have flooded their mines and all is chaos. The Govt has put in sailors to work the pumps but already untold damage has been done. Food will go up, coal is only delivered by the 2 cwt in town and trains are to be fewer. One dreads to think of the consequences and its all quite awful. We are in further correspondence about the Newnham house and have written to accept provided the agreement is in order and so we now await that with interest.

July 31st
The last day of July, and it has been an indifferent month so far as the weather is concerned. A good deal of rain and wind but today seems better and I hope Aug will be decent for I have all my brood here now. I am not at all happy about my man, for some days now he's had such a bronchial cold and cough and such earache and feels altogether rotten. He's been into Sibbald who is prescribing but its vile to see him so seedy and just especially now when he wants to feel his best with all the children at home. Mother too has been having a liver attack but that I am glad to say is better.
We continue to have great account of Win who is having the time of her life. They have had a record hot season but she doesn't seem to feel it at all and is busy shooting, riding, rowing, motoring and playing tennis and bridge. It is a blessed thing for them to have her, but Eve hasn't been at all fit and feels the heat most horribly poor dear. Ell is as busy as ever what with his BLH (Behar Light Horse) work and factory, has two cars and is here, there and everywhere. The strenuous life they lead makes one gasp in this sleepy hollow where although life is very busy in its own way yet what a difference and so far as gaiety goes, isn't life at all!

july.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

House-hunting everywhere...and then another coal strike threatens

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This letter from Wynne's Uncle Walter, living in Munich, offers a picture of what life was like there. After the defeat Bavaria experienced a period of turmoil - you can see the strain on the old man's face.

You can read another letter from him in September. A transcript of this one is below if you scroll down. The letter itself is stuck in as shown over the June 22nd entry.


Letter from Walter von Poellnitz, Munich, June 5th 1919

My dearest Wynne.
It was a great pleasure to me getting your letter of the 25 May this morning. I was very remiss in writing but you will understand that the times were not propitious for correspondence. I was so glad to hear that you were all doing well. Fancy Pinkie, Nutie and the Baby at College and school! How the time flows! And yet think of what has happened since you and Herbert were here! I am all right as far as health goes. Of course I am much much thinner having lost about 4 stone but I cannot complain. Only my heart has given out and I had to have a good many camphor injections to keep it going. Also my asthma prevents me from taking much exercise. I read a great deal, all the more as my evenings are always spent at home theatres and concerts being beyond the reach of my purse. We have gone through terrible times here in Munich. While the Commune, the Rathe Republic, was in power the daily arrests of the better elements, officers, titled individuals etc as hostages made one feel very insecure. 10 of the hostages were shot, butchered in the most brutal manner. One never was sure if one's apartment had not been plundered and pillaged when one returned to it - nightly raids were very frequent, so that doors had to be kept double locked. After the Government troops had arrived all this was done away with and quiet and serenity reigned again. The new form of government has done away with all that was holy and dear to me - traditions and ideals are destroyed - perhaps for ever. Will this peace ever be concluded! It is most wearying and trying and the suspense harder to bear every day. Give my love to all that are near and dear to me. It is sad to think that I may never see them all again. I am getting on to 76 so there is scant hope. And now, with best love to yourself, Herbert and your Mother, believe me, your very affect. old Hamster.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 22nd

Gooseberry bottling, Women's Institute Outings, and a sermon-less church service. Village life. A letter from Germany offers a very different picture.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st - 4th…
A most perfect beginning to this month, a cloudless day and absolute stillness. To Kirk but no sermon and so one did not have to think of old George Herbert's saying "when the sermon is wholly devoid of sense, God takes a text and preaches patience".
I spent the whole afternoon asleep in the sun and after tea we picked gooseberries for bottling. On Monday we had our W.I. meeting, a large assembly, and settled all sorts of business. Yesterday we went to Yeovil to have teeth pulled out, I two and H one, and feel nice and free today!

June 12th
I cannot write a Diary these days. There is much to do but little to record. For nearly six weeks we have had endless sunshine and its been quite perfect.
