We've sat out, fed out and I've slept out all day and every day. The poor earth got drier and drier, nothing has grown, and the aphis and caterpillars innumerable are eating everything up. Tonight however a change is in prospect. I was up Bristol way looking at a house last week, a very pretty house and garden but a bit too remote I fear, so now we are "as you were" and its getting really rather near time.
I've been up to my old Almshouse people today, took them some chibbles (sic) and had a talk with them all, a wonderful peaceful ending to hard lives but oh! what monotony for some who are helpless and bed ridden, its not life at all.

June 22nd
I see I have only made two entries for the whole of June, its really very neglectful. Next week I'm going away into Oxfordshire to look at houses and a week ago we inspected two in this neighbourhood, both bogies, and so it goes on, and the time gets shorter and shorter! One day last week I went on an expedition to Lyme with the W.I. We motored in charabancs all the way and really spent a lovely day. D Lowe and I bathed and paddled and spent all our time on the Landslip (?), a lovely place, it was a perfect day and we got back at about 9. I get good news of my dears at College and had long letters on my birthday from them all. (On this day Wynne inserted the letter from her Uncie in Munich which you can read in the first window).

Ysobel (on the left) with some College friends.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: A small part of the massive article Wynne stuck into her entry. It reads like a fantasy, and it is interesting to note that Wynne herself was sceptical - see her inclusion of the article relaying German press reaction in a later window.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 28th - 29th

The Versailles Peace agreement is signed at last, but the news is not received locally with much interest. House hunting continues as the planned move from Hinton approaches.
viewer_4.description:
June 28th, Saturday

PEACE

The very end of the Great War has arrived for today at 3.0 at Versailles the two German delegates Herren Muller and Bell put their names to the fateful treaty, the terms of which have taken seven long months to settle. How weary one has been waiting and waiting but now at last it is settled and done and extraordinarily impressive it must have been. I enclose a long account of it. The fact has excited very little interest here at home, at least in the country. People hung up a few measly flags, Parson said a few words from the pulpit and that is all. So different from Armistice Day when we all went mad. For one thing one feels really sort of unsettled about it as in G at present they have no representative body and where one section now agrees to sign simply because it cannot help it, a dozen others will in coming months rebel at the terms simply because they'll be able to say they did not hold with it. The anger that some of their party papers are now expressing is a fine specimen of " Hate" and I enclose one. It's pretty reading. One does not feel that the mere signing of papers will bring Peace. At the present moment people are fighting in all the odd corners as fiercely as ever and one is weary of the word war.

The painting as it actually appears. It comes in the middle of the above entry, and had been painted by Wynne's mother many months before, so had to be adapted!

 

June 29th, Sunday
I am afraid that just now our particular minds are much taken up with a matter concerning our private affairs, a matter no less that buying a house. Last week I went off with my bicycle up to Oxford and stayed 2 nights with Sir Charles Roe and the Pennys and did tons of inspections and found there a little old house which I really think may suit us and H has gone to see it today. it is quite small and a little garden but I do think in many ways it is just what we want. It is in a village called Appleford. The immediate country around is flat but well wooded, and the house itself if of old red brick and red tiled, and its title deeds go back to the 26th year of Elizabeth's reign. The interior is old and quaint with oak beams and old corners and though it is very tiny I do think it could be made to look very comfy. I returned home on Thursday having done 55 miles. We shall see what Poggy thinks of it, he has gone to see it today.

(This was a very unusual move, and in fact as you can see later nothing came of it. Buying a house was not something the family contemplated - few did - and in fact in the end when they moved again, it was into another rented house).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.description: As Wynne writes in her June 28th entry, "where one section now agrees to sign simply because it cannot help it, a dozen others will in the coming months rebel".

june.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

THE PEACE TREATY IS SIGNED AT LAST.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Postcards of Westminster Abbey, in its war state.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 6th - 8th

Provisions in the shops are back to normal, and the sandbags have been removed from the Abbey. Wynne meets Philip Lyster, a POW for the duration of the War.
viewer_2.description:
March 6th, Friday
A whole week has passed since I wrote in here, the real reason being that this wretched book has so few pages in it that I have to concentrate my efforts. It has been a week of quiet enjoyment seeing friends, shopping and window nose-glueing. We have been to no theatres because the epidemic of flu is still raging and that naturally is the best way of catching it. I am going to risk it however tomorrow as Philip Lyster is coming up from Shoeburyness to dine and do one with me and I must hope for luck. I am fascinated by the shops which make you feel that there had never been a war at all. They are full of everything, masses of provisions, clothes, furniture, jewellery and now the sweet order has been removed the big stores are crammed with sweets, chocolates and candies but the price of everything is enormous, beyond all conception and how people find the money to buy anything I cant imagine. There are masses of the most beautiful ribbon a foot wide of dazzling colours and unique designs at anything from 10/- to 43/- a yard made in Lyons, and the shop people say they cannot get enough to supply the demand. Coats and shirts are anything from £10.10.0, costumes 17 or 20 guineas and so it goes on. We shall come down to dressing in leaves and twigs. The Town is congested to bursting, and its fearful getting around.

March 7th
One day I strolled in to poke around Westminster Abbey. It is always a place of great delight to me and I know it very well, it was such a joy to see it in its original condition again, minus the sandbags that is, for they have all been removed and now only the flags in the Edward chapel and the stained glass over the Chapel of the Tombs await return. All the effigies over the tombs and the coronation chair were removed to the crypt but all are in place again now and indeed one cannot sufficiently thank God that this great treasure has come safely through this horrible war. St Paul's too and all our ancient buildings are all intact in spite of all the many raids we suffered.

March 8th
I had a busy and an interesting day today. First to Douglas where I had my stray locks camouflaged into masses! then I met H and we went to lunch, then a hurried departure to meet Brenda at the Aeolian Hall to hear Rosing the Russian sing his strange songs. His style is dramatic and illustrative in the extreme and he sings of death and blood and moans and lunacy till we feel thoroughly depressed and morbid. The Hall was crowded. His voice is wonderful and he has the most marvellous compass and flexibility but I cannot away with such music, it does not suit my commonplace mind.
We hastened home as I had to change early and went to meet Phil Lyster at the Troc at 6.15, this meeting was "according to plan" of years all through his long term imprisonment we've planned it and at last it has come to pass. He was little changed but looked older and bit fine drawn which is not to be wondered at. I made him begin at the very beginning and tell me all about everything and it was most interesting. He says that during his term he personally received very fair treatment but on his first journey to the first camp they met with various forms of cruelty. At Cologne the station was full of Red Cross women who came to feed the troops passing through. They also came alongside their train and being very hungry and thirsty and seeing they had provisions he held out his hand for some water to a woman who offered it to him. She slowly withdrew it and slowly poured out every drop on the platform, offering him sandwich she withdrew that also and spitting upon it offered it again. This from a Red Cross nurse. We went on to the Coliseum, saw an indifferent performance which we hardly noticed as we were talking all the time, and then completed our evening by having a short while at the Carlton but everything closes so early now that I was back home again by 11.30 and found the others still up playing Bridge!
(The Trocadero, on the corner of Shaftesbury Avenue and Windmill Street, has many mentions in Wynne's diaries. It was a favourite stopover when theatre visits allowed. It closed in 1965, and should not be confused with its dreadful modern namesake.)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: The Versailles Peace conference became a subject for cartoonists - the wrangling amongst the Allies, the slowness in coming to a conclusion, and the issue of reparations all featured...below you can see Clemenceau, Wilson and Lloyd George marching in line, and then a rather topical cartoon, illustrating Lloyd George's problems that were emerging from the Coalition government.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 12th - 31st

Women's Institute activities are beginning to bring in money, and she hears from her niece en route to India. The Peace Conference staggers on with no outcome, but at least the UK strikes are over.
viewer_4.description:
March 12th, Wednesday
We are home again. We left Town on Monday and once more take up the daily round. Its always nice to come home but I do wish the weather would improve, its freezing cold, rains all day long and is so dark.
Ever since I got back I've been hard at work basket making, we have the county instructor here for a fortnight but having missed a week of him I'm attending every lesson I can. We are 31 workers now and at the monthly meeting they sold 56/- worth which is not bad for beginning. I had a long letter from my Win today from Marseilles. They stopped at Gib and she went ashore and though they had had some very rough weather she had only been thoroughly sick once, and had found Capt Skipwith, our Skippy's brother, who had been very good to her. I was so thankful. There has been a fearful fire at Wellington and half the Dorms have been burnt down. I am so thankful that it is not Pink's side. The fusing of an electric wire caused it and within an hour the roof fell in.

March 19th, Wednesday.
I find I write a good deal on the weekly resumé now. We have 3 fine days since last I wrote which were occupied in sowing seeds and gardening hard. For the rest it has rained unceasingly, and the work has stopped outside. I seldom remember so wet a season. Sunday was one of our three lovely days and I sat out on the terrace all the afternoon writing, the gnats even thought it summer and "jazzed and hesitated" around me in clouds.

March 22nd
I have heard today the very surprising and delightful news that Ell has been given command of the B.L.H. (Behar Light Horse) and so he is now Lt Col. I am sure he will be pleased. I heard this morning that out of the four girls chosen from her House, she (Ysobel) was one whose name has been entered for the Junior Oxford Exam in July. All these matters of family news are of great importance to me, I cannot help it, if the poor wretched world is still twisting and writhing though arms are officially laid down. The Peace Conference continues to confer in Paris and we are encouraged by the hope that all will be settled by 29th March but there are too many Mad Dogs let loose in Europe to be silenced by any Peace Treaty I am thinking. (see cartoons in previous window)

March 29th
A week has gone by since I last wrote in here and no sign of a Peace Treaty nor likely to be, they go mildering on in Paris meanwhile the Huns are as uppish as they can be and a faction in Germany is now declaring for the Kaiser and Ludendorff again. The General Strike of Coal, Railways and Transport workers is settled thank God, and few people realise that the country has been through an awful crisis.

March 31st
I got on Wed these P.Cs (see below, of Port Said) from Win and so by now she should have arrived in India. I am daily awaiting her cable saying so. The enclosed cutting is interesting showing comparative prices. Food supplies are becoming much easier here, all sorts of things are down in fact most things, the chief being margarine which is now only 8d lb and most excellent. We really have no shortage of anything now.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: These cartoons feature the issue of reparations, and clearly approve of them, indicating in one Ebert locked into the deal, but in the second complaining that he is not paying enough. Of course with hindsight we now realise that the terms were a recipe for future disaster, but at the time they were often considered to be too lenient.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6

march.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

A visit to London to see a released POW, and to marvel at Westminster Abbey.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Another cartoon satirising the pace of the Peace negotiations...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 12th

Wynne organises her first dinner party since the beginning of the war...and hears news of her Uncle in Bavaria.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Thursday
As is usual in this country the 1st May seldom comes up to our expectation of flowering wreaths and muslin frocks. It has been grey and windy all day. After tea in order to get some fresh air we went out and footled around, but it is so cold and damp. How one does long for the warm weather.

May 2nd
Today we actually had the excitement of people to dinner! and the dovecot was quite in a flutter! We invited the Lowes and Mrs Grafton and Dorothy came. Out came the best dinner set, out came the best dessert set, menu holders, finger bowls etc all of which had lain perdu for 4 years, and I am thankful to say our simple dinner proved quite a success. It seemed quite strange to be sitting upon ones hind legs again.

May 3rd
Though the weather look doubtful we braved it today and took lunch and tea up to Ham and ended by having a ripping day. Noots and I dug for Roman remains, finding the usual bones and pottery and also a quaint little piece of copper. It is ripping up there, such a view and such air!

May 4th
Pink's last Sunday alas, and we spent it up in Liddons Wood nature watching. Such destruction is at work there as extensive tree felling is taking place, all the bluebells are out and the campion is just coming. After tea we all gathered heaps of primroses which as usual are perfect. What is this rat doing up there, catching butterflies or picking his nose like that one on the Terrace so long ago?!

May 10th, Saturday
We are feeling horribly bereft, all our dears have gone back to College. The house seems so desperately quiet without them and their perpetual ragging. I asked Poggy if he couldn't run up and down the stairs shouting and screaming just so as to create a noise but he didn't see his way to doing this! We had a phone message from Mother on Thursday night in despair because Brenda had phoned to her that her cook having quinsy she could not put her up so she is coming to us on Monday, much to my joy. Lena forwarded a letter from Walter a few days ago poor old man, he is having an awful time, he has lost 4½ stone, says that the bread he eats consists of bran, potatoes and turnips, that tea and coffee are non-existent, and that no condiments of any sort are to be had. I do feel so sorry for him and really one wonders if during these terrible times of the last month there he is still alive. I cant think how he has pulled through at all. He says he has had no money from his investments since 4 years. They are of course all in English Securities and that Theodore P and others have been very good to him, my goodness it must have been pretty galling for him to accept help from T, they loathed each other. I hope to get a letter through to him via Leila soon but with all this civil warfare and local horrors all posts etc may now be non existent. (You can read later letters from Walter to Wynne that describe his experiences - one in June and one in September)

May 12th
The day began by being rather vile and I thought Mother was going to bring her usual weather but it cleared. At 5.45 we rushed out hearing a car only to find that Holt had picked up the wrong fare at the station, a lady who wanted to go to Beaminster! I wildly phoned in to the George to send something else for them and a short while later a wagonette drove past the house ladened with Mother and co. We rushed up the road after them and clawed them in and found it was a conveyance a porter had got them from the Queen's! Well, alls well that ends well.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Both Ysobel and Eleanore were boarders now at Malvern College. Below is a picture of the College as it was in , and below that two pictures taken in 1990 when Ysobel visited it again for the first time since she left. She is standing outside it with her daughter Patricia, and as you can see, the central tower has been substantially reduced, and a new wing added in the same style.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 20th - 22nd

Lack of space explains the leaps in date. Her P.O.W. friend comes to stay, and the village hold a Rogation Service.
viewer_4.description:
May 20th, Tuesday
I shall never feel that this years Diary is a proper one as I can but barely write once a week owing to the shortage of leaves, however it must just be a summary of events. Last Wednesday was exceptionally hot and D Lowe took me with Miss Altree and Mrs Tozer into Taunton by car to a big meeting of the W.I. where we heard some very interesting speeches and the doings of other W.I.s There were I should think between 100 and 200 women there and the Hall was stifling. On Friday to my great pleasure came Phil Lyster for the weekend. He is doing a course at Shoebury (ness) and Salisbury and came over from the latter. He is looking so much better than when I saw him in Town and we had much interesting conversation about his prison days and also some birds nesting in which he is very keen. On Sunday we broke the Sabbath and did not go to Kirk in the morning but to the stream and watched for nests instead. I feel that the Good God was as near us down there as in a "Temple made with hands". He left in the afternoon as he had to be on the ranges early Mon, but is coming again next weekend. Yesterday, Monday, H went off house hunting and I am longing to see results.

May 22nd, Thursday
This is continuing to be the most perfect May I can ever remember. Every day Mother sits out in the garden from morn till eve and each day passes the other in quiet contentment. Last Sun also we sat down 10 as the Marriotts came up and Dorothy Lowe brought her two Australians. The Lowes are entertaining men from overseas for a week at a time to show them a little English home life before they leave the country. On Tuesday last we had our yearly Rogation Service in the fields. It is a very charming revival I think and was held in a field on the Lopen road overlooking miles of glorious countryside at 8pm, and there in the midst of God's perfect work we asked His Blessing on the crops for the year.
Phil Lyster came this last weekend again and we did an afternoon at Bryces Mills on Sat, taking tea with us. It was just perfect down there, so still and warm and quiet. We hunted for birds nests and lazed about and talked about his past 4 years. He left again on Sunday afternoon for the Plain and goes north tomorrow. I've been getting up at screech lately, the early mornings are so perfect I cant lie in bed. Poggy came back from his hunt having drawn a blank. He went to Malvern and saw the girls and found alas that poor Babs was in bed with a cold so she couldn't go out with him.

may.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

Pre-war life begins to assert itself - a dinner is arranged...but the news from Bavaria is bleak.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This is Broughtons, their new home at Flaxley, near Newnham, in the Forest of Dean. If you take your mouse over the first photo, you will be able to see the house in all its splendour today, including an extension.

Listen to Ysobel's memory of Flaxley and the house:

Scroll down, for present day views,
with grateful thanks to Simon and Jo Murray. Visit the Editor's strand for pictures of previous homes, and another rollover shot of Broughtons.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
November 16th

They move at last, only to find that the painters have barely started, so upheaval continues...but its new friends, a wonderful view, and the excitement of electric light for the first time in their lives.
viewer_2.description:
November 16th, Sunday

BROUGHTONS

It is exactly four weeks ago since I last touched my Diary but truly I have plenty of excuse for this has been a fearsome move and I'll now insert a little backchat in order to inform my descendants that life for the past four weeks has not been all roses! We left Hinton End the day after my last entry (October 20th), going to the Lowes who kept us till Thursday, and very comfortable and happy we were. We spent that time in saying goodbye to all our village bogies and really felt we left a lot of kind hearts behind us. We came up here by the 9.0 from Ilminster bringing with us Martha, Peter, Tip the cat, and the canaries and arrived here soon after 2.0. We knew of course that the house was being done up but had hoped to find that trouble well underway, when to our dismay we discovered that beyond the kitchen no interior had begun! Well there was nothing for it but patience so in the most extreme discomfort we have lived for the past three weeks, dirt, dust, straw and paper being our daily joys. For 10 days we had no coal and as I am cook I had to negotiate the kitchen with coke and wood. It puts the lid on the art of culinary pursuits rather! Then the electric engine having got really cold proceeded to buck and every night we had to return to lamps and the climax was reached on the day when our last load of furniture trailed in and I found that two of my huge egg crocks were broken and ever so many eggs smashed and sat down beside them and nearly wept! However nothing lasts for ever. The coal came, the water engine was mended, the electric light recovered and all seems better, but after nearly a month we still have only three rooms completed, the drawing room, Babs' and Pink's room in which latter we are sleeping whilst the men are doing ours and Nootsie's. The drawing room is sweet and sunny and faces south. It is pale primrose which suits the old mahogany furniture. On the floor are our two beautiful Persian rugs and on the walls the dear watercolours from Springfield and some of Hal Jones'. The piano stands with its back to the room across one corner and has a Bokara drapery to hide its innards, another such hanging conceals a closed doorway and our humble collection of old china with heaps of flowers complete a very pretty room. The curtains the old gold ones from Brookfield look lovely having been well darned by BG and me! I hope we are going to be very happy here. I'm prepared to love the little house with its very nice garden and its 18 acres of charming fields full of big old trees, the views too are perfect, on the one hand the Severn runs like a sliver streak all along the valley backed by the Cotswolds and on the other side is the great rise of the Forest of Dean which has been simply glorious in its autumn dress of red, gold and brown.



Several people have called: the Vaughan Hughes who seem very nice; the Colchester Wemyss who own Westbury Court, a beautiful old place, but have lost their money so live in a tiny house at its gates; the Kellys, the rector of Westbury, and some people called Shelley but I refuse to be "At Home" whilst the house is in this frantic state, so no one has entered it yet. We've visited both churches (Westbury and Flaxley) and are struck by the extreme emptiness of both. Westbury has no excuse as its a large place, Flaxley is a tiny village but the parson preached a decent sensible sermon today and I only wished there were more to listen to him. Close by the church is the ancient seat of the Crawley Boeveys who have been there since the year one - horribly renovated by this man's father who employed local labour and has spoiled the old house, but nothing can mar the perfect beauty of its setting surrounded by wide level fields and lawns and backed by perfect wooded hills. The church is frightful within and without and quite modern I should think, red brick, slate roof and no tower, quite horrid, and such a sadness when there must have been an old one somewhere. I must find out all about it. The Crawley Boeveys don't live there in winter but always depart to Town. We are working hard at the garden here, finding much rank neglect but its all going to be lovely and I am most awfully pleased with my new home.

The full width start to a new life:

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Ysobel and Herbert sitting outside the garden windows.

And below, a shot of the garden with Herbert enjoying a book (uncharacteristically, as they were both normally working in the garden from morning till night!)

A photo of the Church at Flaxley, with the Crawley Boevey house in the background, taken when Ysobel visited there in 1990.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
November 27th

The house gradually takes shape - the painting is almost done - and the gardening begins in earnest! Another letter comes form Munich.
viewer_4.description:
November 27th, Thursday
I do not think that Nov is likely to have more than two entries in it for the times are not propitious to diary writing. My mornings are spent in cooking (woe is me) my afternoons gardening or answering calls and my evenings various odd jobs and letters and so the days go. We have been here 5 weeks today and yet are still hand in hand with the painters, however we begin to see daylight. The dining room, landing and stairs are now in their hands, my bedroom is complete and looks very nice in its fresh pale green. I've hung up heaps of my photos and pictures and feel at last happy and comfy. The garden too goes on apace, we've done all the flower part, planted heaps of bulbs and herbaceous stuff and soon the roses and shrubs will be here, it should all be lovely and I'm longing for Spring. Yesterday I returned the call of the Flaxley parson's lady but found her from home so went on to Blaisdon Hall, the "seat" of the MacIvors. I've never seen a larger private house, I felt like a microscopic flea approaching its enormous portals. It stands in a huge park backed by wooded heights with a view from here to Australia, quite new and not very beautiful battlemented towers sort of thing, but they seem pleasant people and I hope we shall see something of them as they have three girls. I heard from Walter yesterday, now that communications are open once more he often writes, and it is most interesting to hear truly of the state of affairs. What awful times they have lived through and are still doing as the Spartacists continue to hold up horrors over them and food too is very scarce. Coal is at a premium and the mildest of luxuries unobtainable. I put here the envelope of his letter showing a surcharge German stamp and the usual Freistaat stamped over it, how odd this seems from an autocratic country like Germany. I feel so sorry for the Hamster, a proud man most truly humbled, all his traditions shattered, all his ideals broken - for the country one cannot help feeling the justice of this humbling but for many an individual it must be very bitter.

(The envelope and stamps are in the next window. The letter has not survived.)

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The envelope mentioned by Wynne...its stamp is the one that brought you here, and is a German Reich stamp overprinted with Freistaat Bayern. The red stamp is a Bavarian one, similarly overprinted.

november.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

AT LAST! They move house to live at Broughtons, near Newnham, in Gloucestershire.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
A letter from Wynne's old governess, B.G.Scratchley, describing life in London during the strike. A transcript of the letter is at the bottom of the page.

Extract from a letter from B G Scratchley, Wynne's old governess, writing from London on October 7th,

Darling Wynne.
Thanks for yours received this morning. I posted the letter at Church End, it caught the 12.50 so will be on its way by now. I feel very sorry for the Baron and any time will post them for you. (This refers to her posting letters for Wynne to Walter, presumably because Wynne did not want the local Somerset post office gossip to know about her writing to Germany).
I am sure this dreadful Strike has upset the whole of England. I do hope you will be able to do your move soon and comfortably, now it is over I suppose the trains will be running as usual. Was it you who wrote me you have no coal, truly the experiences one goes through nowadays are remarkable, not to say trying in the extreme. How do you manage about cooking. What a good thing we had all taken our departure or you would never have got rid of us all this time! I left 25 a few days sooner than we had intended as there was a rumour the buses and trams were coming out so I thought it best not to delay, or there would be no means of getting out. It was a false alarm as they stuck to their posts and were not in sympathy with the strikers at all. Strange sights were seen on the roads, people who were brave and thick skinned not minding what they did hailed motorists and motorbikes with the sidecars for lifts. I should never have summoned up courage to it and really motors stopped and offered seats to pedestrians. People had to walk 12 or 14 miles to work in the mornings and back again in the evenings. Buses and Trams were simply laden, the Specials were called out again to regulate the traffic, the Police were wanted in different parts of London to keep order but with it all the public kept smiling and the Londoners showed their usual stolid front by bowing to the inevitable. Really these times seem to bring out the best in people, for they do many little kindnesses to each other, and are so chatty and friendly and so good tempered over it all. But we are still kept very short in the way of food. I had to go to town and went in to one of Lyons places and had a snack - a little fried fish, price 8d, one small piece of bread, and being still hungry thought I would have a portion of apple tart. "As you have had bread", the girl said, " you cannot have pastry" so I ended by having some weird milk pudding! Milk here is now 11d a quart, is it not awful!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
October 1st - 5th

The strikes continue, and Wynne thinks that while this period might well be of interest to historians, it is not much fun to live through.
viewer_2.description:
October 1st, Wednesday
September, most dear month, has gone. I always regret it, with its glorious still warm days, days when all nature seems asleep or preparing anyhow to "settle off". But how does all this peace coincide with the present strife and insanity. How often during the past 5 years has nature in its extraordinary Peace seemed a mockery. Now although one can no longer hear the guns, the surging anger, hatred, malice caused by incessant labour trouble certainly make one feel that insanity is astir throughout all lands and one wonders again and again will things ever become normal again. These times to look back on will no doubt be interesting but they are not enviable to live in.

October 2nd
I spent yesterday in bed with a vile throat and head. Today I arose after breakfast and felt decayed and so cold. After lunch not being able to bear the house any longer I went out and we gathered apples till tea. Such a perfect crop. The strikers still hold out so does the Govt and the latter are quite determined apparently to break them. Crowds of volunteers for all sorts of work have come forward and many trains are running. Much transport is being done by lorries, motors, steamboats and aeroplanes and a motor service has started from Manchester to London every half hour or so! I do hope and trust the Govt will win, it should be a lesson to other intending strikers.

Oct 3rd
One thing that is glorious in these far from glorious times is the weather, still warm and sunny just like Sept though at nights we come very near a frost. We went over to lunch with the Rawlins and ate pheasant, such a treat! I remember in the old days at Brookfield how sick we used to get of them! I actually got Poggy to bicycle, with many a moan he accomplished it but complained bitterly!

Oct 4th
Today we were bidden to tea with Her Ladyship at the House. Lady P draped in a grey jumper cut square and very low with short sleeves and a grey knitted skirt to her knees just like a dish cloth! (Lady P is Lady Poulett)

Oct 5th, Sunday
I lay on the Terrace all afternoon basking in the warm sun and reading Blackwood. There is an article on Belgium by Whibley telling again of the hopeless devastation there and the utter awfulness of it. One is so sick to think that the Hun, that common thief and outrage of humanity, goes back to a country untouched by War to start his commercial schemes afresh with years of start of his neighbours whose machines he has destroyed or carried away. Already his goods are coming into this country and the irony of it all is that if the World boycotts him in trade he cannot pay the enormous Indemnity. How I wish some devastating blast would sweep the entire inhabitants off the face of this fair Earth.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
October 6th - 19th

The strike finally comes to an end, but rationing continues and coal is very hard to come by. The house is packed up and the move north takes place.
viewer_4.description:
October 6th, Monday
We heard this morning that the strike is over! and so that's that. Well I only hope it doesn't mean that Govt has given in . One feels that our much criticised Got is capable of doing anything foolish. We got no paper today which is fearfully trying just at these times. We both went into Crewkerne. We did much shopping and he got his hair cut, so returned like a convict. After lunch we picked up potatoes, not so good a crop this year as last but very little disease. Then I went to a Com Meeting of Baskets up the village and rode home in brilliant moonlight without a lamp. Brown the valiant policeman was not astir!!

October 7th
It seems from the paper today that the Govt have made wise turns, but it also adds that the railwaymen think they can claim a victory which seems a pity, but having missed yesterdays paper one is not clear what really happened. Anyhow trains are running as usual today and things will soon be straight again. We are rationed very short still and will be yet awhile - 6oz sugar per week, 4oz margarine, 4oz of lard, and 1cwt of coal a week. This is the hardest thing of all.

Oct 19th, Sunday
I have purposely left out the last 10 days. They have been spent chiefly in cooking and packing. On Thursday last Rapson (the mover) arrived with his minions to work their will upon the house and by now, Sunday evening, it is delightfully cosy. We had to cancel our engagement with Lalonde to move us because they could give us no definite date and so Rapson is doing it. And here we sit and it is positively the last night in Hinton House for tomorrow we go to the Lowes for 2 or 3 nights and then to Broughtons. I am thrilled. I am simply pining to be settled there and I leave this tiresome and freezing house with very few regrets.

(The diary stops here, and starts again in Broughtons, their new home, on November 16th. It will be their last move in England).

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5

october.description:
Wynne has been keeping her diaries since 1895.

"Will things ever be normal again?"

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
This is the second letter Wynne put into the diary from Walter in - post-war life in Munich was hard for him. Money was short (and about to be destroyed by inflation), his health was not good, and the political situation was very tense - as you can see, his letters were all opened and inspected. Note the overprinted stamp too, the republican Freistaat over the old king's face.

Below you will find a transcript of this letter - the other one can be read in June.

Ysobel also remembered this time, and her Great Uncle's problems:

And the reverse of the envelope: the translation reads "Opened on the ground of the decree from 15th November, 1918".

Below is a transcript of his letter in full:


Letter from Walter von Poellnitz, Munich, Sept 1st 1919

My dearest Wynne
I begin this letter today but will only send it off after having heard from you that my last has arrived. I do not know if Hinton End is the complete address. Well, my last was rather incoherent. The fact is that I received the same morning a letter from my lawyers in Edinburgh saying that they could not comply to my request about forwarding the moneys due to me since the beginning of the war, having received instructions from the Custodians of Enemy's moneys not to do so. The sum is about £1500 and as I have been forced to live on halfpay which gives me £22 a month for 5 years I was rather upset. Subsisting on such a sum meant genteel poverty with a vengeance. The money is not lost I hope but it will be some time before I am able to handle it. But enough of this. I will now try and tell you how I have fared all these dreadful years of anxiety. Deprivations began very soon after the outbreak of hostilities. White bread disappeared and the black bread, a mixture of rye, potatoes and turnips, was very nasty and not nutritious. Sugar, tobacco, rice were not to be had, or if so at famine prices. As for sardines, sausages, ham etc things where with to make one's meals a little interesting, they were only to be dreamt of. So on the whole life was more or less a burden. To cap everything the Armistice which made Germany absolutely powerless, forcing it to accept every condition imposed upon it, then the revolution which gave us the coup de grace, did not serve to make life worth living.
We Bavarians were the first to upset authority, depose our King and make havoc among institutions which had been up to now the welfare of our country. More shame that the masses were misled by a pack of Galician Jews and the rabble collected about them. But this was not the worst. After the King's flight the Communists got the power into their hands and a reign of terror commenced. The proletariat was armed, plunder and rapine reigned unpunished and unrepressed. I was never sure of not being seized as hostage, nor sure if on coming home in the evening of not finding my rooms plundered and my housekeeper murdered. At last the Government (sic!) troops entered and defeated the Spartacists. The shooting was tremendous and a lot were killed, also some of the regular troops. Now quiet is restored for the time being. But as we have no coal, and very little bread, it is probable that the scenes of lawlessness may repeat themselves. The winter will bring great discomfort for me. The house has central heating and no coal to heat with, so I have to put up an iron stove in one room only and heat with turf which gives little heat. So you see that the Hamster is not to be envied.
I had a very good time last month. I was stopping with Prince Quadt, an old friend of mine, who has a big place in Württemberg, Very fine, very good cheer so that I gained half a stone in weight. You would be astonished if you saw me. I am as thin as a whipping post and my clothes hang on me like on a clothes line! But I am very well, not depressed (more than necessary) and hope to pull through all right. Some good friends have helped me a little now and then, else the workhouse or a quick end would have been my lot. I am so glad to hear that you are all well - how often do I think of the happy days at Aldershot - the pleasant house, the lovely garden and all your and Herbert's kindness. God bless you both for it. With best love to you and yours, I am ever your affect. old Hamster.

(The Prince of Quadt referred to is probably Bertram, 1849-1927, 1st Prince of Quadt of the family of Quadt zu Wykradt und Isny, a family with roots back in the twelfth century).

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
September 1st - 12th

A distressing accident while blackberrying causes much hilarity, and a lovely trip to Lyme produces a man from Wynne's past.
viewer_2.description:
September 1st, Monday
Alas Mother left us today after nearly 4 months stay and we miss her much. Yesterday she spent in packing and washing her hair and this morning by the 10.52 she and Grace and the canaries all took their departure. Sept has begun with a lovely day. We seized upon the front garden, Davis mowed and we cleaned out and tided all the beds.

Sept 2nd
I awoke this morning to a high wind and torrents of rain and darkness.

Sept 3rd
Such pouring torrents still come down and so we set ourselves with much energy to turning out and cleaning up drawers and cupboards against our removal. To tea despite the rain came the Crossleys and Haywards and we played all sorts of noisy games and behaved like lunatics.

Sept 4th, Thursday
The whole family went to Yeovil hand in hand to visit the dentist today, a detestable and vile occupation but a good thing done. I must alas take in Babs again to have two teeth out.

Sept 8th
Nothing much has happened since Thursday last but today we set forth blackberrying and took our tea down into the fields below Barlows. It was a perfect afternoon, still and warm, and we picked hard in all directions. Shortly before tea I heard distressed cries and on looking round beheld a bedraggled figure covered with mud from head to foot, BG having fallen into a bog! I rushed to her assistance, divested her of her shirt and jacket which I dragged in the grass and she luckily having a petticoat on, borrowed Pink's coat and sat thus eating her tea whilst her clothes hung round on the cornstalks drying. How we laughed. Her boots were caked with mud and her gloves stiff with it! I left the party at 6.30 and went to the W.I. meeting, the last I shall attend.

Sept 9th
A lovely day so we took the opportunity and went down to Lyme. On arrival we all went and bathed, it was ripping and we had a great swim, then afer dressing we went along the shore paddling to where no one else was and had our lunch and explored and then went for a row, the girls never having been on such an errand before. Nootsie and Pink took oars, the former catching one crab! We stayed out for an hour and then had tea and left sadly at 5.15 that being our last train. Whilst walking on the beach I beheld the brown and fat proportions of a man in a bathing suit and a gold bracelet talking to a huge fat female and I recognised Harry C but did not stop and he didn't see me - how strangely time has altered one's feelings!

(This must refer to Harry Castleman, mentioned often in the early diaries when Wynne was living at Brookfield. They lived at Chettle House, which she visited. If you click on the date, you can read of an outing on June 30th 1897 when Harry is mentioned. The two present that day were Rachel and Harry. I suspect she rather fancied him then!)

Sept 11th, Thursday
To Yeovil with my Babbit to have two teeth out. We had to bicycle in as we could get no car and it was grilling. I've never felt hotter. It all went off very well.

Sept 12th
We spent all the afternoon blackberrying again and got enough for 12 bottles - there is a great crop this year and I want to bottle as many as I can for winter.

All the illustrations in 1919 were painted by Wynne's Mother, Blanche, who signed each one with her B...this is a hugely enlarged one, copied from the illustration at the top of this page.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: ...community. Wynne has cut the final word off the cutting.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
September 15th - 23rd

Blackberrying, millinery classes, and other country pursuits. They all attend the local church for last time as a family, as the children are soon off to school.
viewer_4.description:
September 15th, Monday
BG and I went up at 2.30 to a millinery class given at the Almshouses by a Miss Bee, a girl who was at Liberty for 5 years. We learned to make roses and leaves of satin and after two hours toil we left for tea at the Marriotts where we met H. There we gossiped and went round the garden inspecting roses, and rabbits and chickens which latter Miss M says supply the house with eggs and pay for their food. There are about 8 of them and they get 2 eggs a day!! They must go short of food and ditto the house of eggs!

Sept 16th
The girls teaed at the Marriotts today whilst Pink went to the Hopkins and we to our millinery! Set to and did some gardening. On account of the rabbits here we've never worried much about really stocking it but I am busy making out long lists for the next place of shrubs, roses and plants and I'm longing to get at it with Blake who I trust has not lost his former art.

Sept 17th
The whole family went over to the Rawlins to tea today, we riding and BG and Poggy walking. A large party were there and it was a perfect day. We all played games and ate huge teas.

Sept 18th
We have been blackberrying all day long and our united efforts resulted in 28lbs so I can have a good bottling. We sallied forth all round the home fields before lunch and after we took our tea down into the Lopen fields. I do so love roaming round and browsing on these quiet still warm days, each in a different direction giving family whistle occasionally and then assembling for tea. We took BG over some hairy fences in spite of violent protests and much rebellion but she managed to "leap high oer the fence" like Sunny Jim and we got back at 7.0.

Sept 20th
BG and I employed ourselves in mending the yellow curtains, a long and weary job, and during our arduous labour we amused ourselves by discussing tombs and the "laying out " of corpses! A sad letter from Hamster today, and the stamps thereon. What a world of meaning is in that one word "Volkstaat" written across the King's face. (In fact, Freistaat Bayern).

Sept 21st, Sunday
This is the last Sunday that we shall all be in this church together. How odd it seems and where have the past 3 years gone. To tea came Mr Love to say goodbye. It must be nearly a year since he was in the house last. I thought him looking much older.

Sept 22nd
The morning I spent in "turning out", sorting and throwing away.

Sept 23rd
My dear BG left us today. As I had to take Babs into Yeovil to Dickin again we travelled so far together. We got back about tea time and there I washed both their heads which is a good job jobbed and now I am going to my bed, for which I am more than ready.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The Railway Strike.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
September 24th - 30th

The children all go back to school, and then a general Railway Strike starts, causing widespread disruption.
viewer_6.description:
September 24th, Wednesday
Mother writes that in her last letter from Ell he tells her he has been made A.D.C. to the Viceroy. I am so awfully pleased and proud of my dear besides which he is Colonel of the BLH and has sold a lot of Indigo well so is very happy all round. How I long for a letter from him sometimes but I know that he is too busy to write to me, so I just go on doing so and feed upon secondhand crumbs. But he is one of the best things I have in life and sometimes I rebel when I realise that practically all our lives we have lived apart.

Sept 25th
Alas my two dear things left for school today and how I miss them. What shall we feel like tomorrow when Pink has gone as well. I arose at 6. It was quite dark and I dressed by lamp light. We all breakfasted at 7.30 together and soon after 8 I took them to Ilminster. The girls are going back alone this time, it is so much less harrowing than taking them up but I miss them both more than I can say. We have had a fearful blow today. Lalonde Bros, the people who were to have moved us next week, write calmly saying they cannot do so until the 3rd week of Oct and then possibly not, and the Hutchinsons want to come in during the middle of the month. We are awfully upset.

Sept 26th, Friday
The day was spent in doing last jobs and packing for my dear son who left us tonight.

Sept 27th
A General Railway Strike is declared. No trains and consequently no letters, an appalling state of affairs and of course all business is at a standstill. We went blackberrying with the Lowes.

Sept 29th
How strange it seems to think that so far as railways and posts go we are cut off from the world. We get no papers or letters and if we wished to make a journey we couldn't do so. I hear that the Railway Union is allowing 2 trains to run per day for milk on account of the babies, otherwise road transport for food and a few mails is resorted to. Poggy an I spent a most tranquil and delightful afternoon, went down to the Lopen fields, took our tea there, and then picked till 6 when we had to return as we are back at winter time now. The clocks were changed last night. We got 15 lbw and I am going to try the Salicylic Method of bottling. They say it is perfectly satisfactory and requires only the heat to boil the water.

Sept 30th, Tuesday
A few letters came through this morning by road mail I presume because no trains are running yet and I hear that the Govt means to break this strike. I hope indeed they may and show for once that men cannot put the whole country into confusion at will. All sale of petrol is stopped and all motor transport commandeered for food supplies, so our move is further off than ever. However we have heard this morning from Col Hutchinson that it makes no difference to them and so we are not so worried. Their schemes are all knocked on the head as well.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: An interesting development...and check out the cartoons in October...how often strikes are received with these warnings!

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Although Wynne was a great visitor of exhibitions, art shows, theatres etc, she was resistant to most of the new ideas - her tastes were pretty safe and middle-class in other words, though new developments interested her as you can see during this month.

The family approved of Punch's take on the show, however:

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
April 1st - 6th

Wynne records coffe spraying and her distaste for the works of Jacob Epstein...but approves of Howard Dresser's book.
viewer_2.description:
April 1st, Wednesday
Resolved. Today I will not allow myself to be overcome with annoyance because my totos cut their footies, because my water boy neglects for the umpteenth time his daily duties, or the turkeys make dust baths in my new gerbera bed and so on ad nauseum! Rather will I concentrate upon the entire desirability of Life which holds both at home and abroad so much of interest!
I have not seen my son all day as from sun up to sun down he has been spraying the coffee, the factory in Kitale having invested in an appliance one hires for 20/- a day. He managed 30 acres and does the rest tomorrow so I hope it'll have the effect of beating the various doodoos (Wynne's spelling of the swahili word, dudu: insect) by which we are beset. He and Nootsie went into K as the former wanted to have an interview with the new Bank Manager. He came home very pleased with the same! They didn't get back till tea having been delayed by two punctures and no spare! H also went to Kerr House about the electric lighting plant so perhaps we shall get a move on at last. This has been a good day and resolve has been kept!!

April 2nd
Yesterday evening I read again some of my old diaries, that of 1918 is particularly interesting, recounting as it does all the difficulties of that year and the horrors we lived through during the great Retreat prior to our final triumph.
Tonight by wireless we heard that there was to be a total eclipse of the moon, so at 9.0 we sallied forth and sat there watching the odd affair till 10, by which time it was entirely hidden and hung in the sky like a shadow. A perfectly clear sky enabled us to see the whole thing splendidly.

April 3rd
The glorious "Art" of Epstein!! What can the mind be like that can produce productions such as these - is it madness or mere effrontery? No comments are needed but like August John and many another of that ilk he has his following or they would not allow his "Night and Morning" to be erected in London. Punch's picture here filled us with joy but when there is so much that is lovely in this most beautiful world it seems altogether an outrage. This is Good Friday - at Home how different to out here. We went over to see D this morning who we heard had been having a bad attack of this tummy trouble that's going about but found her much better and cheerful.

April 4th
Mother has presented me with a new wheelbarrow, such a long-felt want and I'm so awfully pleased. I'm having a seed bed made near my seed house and if only the rain will return we shall be content.
I often think when in the future these diaries come to be read, if anyone would be sufficiently interested to open one, how the thought will occur to them of the utter triviality of our daily lives. That the world is indeed full of huge happenings, or one might call it tragic chaos, is only too true but to dwell on such things spells morbidity and it is up to one to work in our daily circumstances as free from that as possible.

April 5th, Easter Sunday
I have been reading this morning Dresser's book, "The Power of Silence". There is much there that is sound and wise. The human mind, unless self sufficient, which mine certainly is not, is so apt to get befurred and fogged, revolving as it were upon its own axle. One experiences a real sense of practical help in much he expresses. He is no sentimentalist and has arrived at his ideals through common sense practice.
Nootsie stayed at home to keep Mother company and the rest of us went to Kirk. We have a good road all the way now so it takes much less time to get there. The little place was full right up and Knight officiated, our Padre being at Kitale. He preached a good sermon on the necessity of looking at things from a right perspective, an attitude much to be recommended these days when amidst much that is large and important one is awfully inclined to allow the many smaller things to fogs one's brain.

April 6th, Monday
We have had a spot more rain so I feverishly dig and delve. Pricked out first seedlings. Tonight at sunset we saw the most marvellous cloud effect, two vivid ends of rainbow, a rain storm sweeping over the plain all misty and pink whilst on the left rolling masses of pink and grey clouds which turned to orange backed by intensely blue sky. We do get some perfect sky scenes out here.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Another development Wynne notes. She did not really like the idea of such gardens.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
April 7th - 16th

Her brother Elliot arrives with his new bride. A much longed for reuniion.
viewer_4.description:
April 7th, Tuesday
Win's birthday. She is my god child and I never remember it, but she seldom writes and time drifts along so fast that one finds it hard to realise how long it is since one has written. I read the Standard tonight. It is naturally full of the large happenings of the world. I have seldom mentioned India here but for years that unhappy trouble has been growing more and more acute. Gandhi, the amazing man who was imprisoned, has been for some time released and continues on his wild career. Serious riots are reported from Cawnpore and elsewhere and the whole thing is rather a nightmare.

April 8th
H and P off to Kitale on business, wanting also to go on to Elgon after lunch to listen to Admiral Crampton who is standing for Legislative Council this year as well as Kirkwood. Meanwhile at lunch the mail arrived bringing letters from Eve, Ell and K and a wire from the latter saying "arrive Eldoret Wed, coming on by goods". Immediately the place became a hive of activity getting ready for them. Eve wrote of a disastrous hail storm which had wiped out their oats and indigo.

April 9th
Such a busy day. At 10.30 while busy with a thousand things there arrived Mrs Trench with Mrs and Miss Crampton, the former showing the latter the mountain area. Then, hardly had we sat down to lunch when Mrs Harold Hill drove up bearing Sir Elliot and Lady Colvin, old friends of Mother's in India. They took pot luck - real miraculous feeding! At 3.30 they departed and almost at once Colonel Kirkwood arrived with Ell and K from Kitale!! - thrills and excitement, and the rest of the day passed in the same.

April 10th
The Lugards brought our mail out today and amongst the letters was one from Frank by Air. It acknowledges the one I sent to Tilda on March 6th. He also sent a picture of the arrival of the first Air mail at Port Bell, Kampala, which picture had likewise travelled Home by Air. HowI should love to have seen that. What a moment. Its a fact now that we are no longer isolated from the world!

April 11th
We have a gang of 8 men on the front now, perhaps we'll get a move on. I shall set to and have all the grass areas done which are looking horrible. Pricked out hundreds more seedlings.

April 12th, Sunday
Quite a good rain today and tomorrow much activity will take place sowing seeds, but our rains are taking a long time this year to arrive and stay.

April 13th
The seeds went into the ground today, amongst them my second sowing of sweet peas, the first not having germinated at all. Ell took K out riding this morning, it was the first time she had ridden astride and it seemed a success. She has hunted a lot in Cheshire. This is my dear Noots' birthday, bless her.

April 14th, Tuesday
Owing to the shortage of rain we are having trouble with water and all day long M'Coy has been pumping only to discover we found that he had omitted to put the end of the pipe into the water! Such is the native mind. The Lugards brought out the mail and the paper tells of another attempt to wreck the Delhi express. They managed it all right but loss of life was not as bad as it might have been. I've been having a long talk with Ell on India, he takes a very serious view of it and is not at all reassuring. I wouldn't be the new Viceroy Willingdon - a most frightful job. This autumn is supposed to be the critical time but all the time its critical as far as one can see and how can it all end.

April 15th
This month half over, its flown, and tomorrow Ell and K leave. I'm awfully sad, its all been so jolly having them.

April 16th
The presence of Ell and K is much missed. Pink took them into Kitale soon after lunch and we feel a great blank.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: For some reason Wynne was rather exercised by the abdication of this monarch - perhaps because she had seen so many consigned to the dustbin?

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
April 17th - 23rd

Home news seems very distressing...the Depression was terrifying, and the King of Spain abdicates, but this week Wynne had to contend with an invasion of safari ants. Heavy rain at last.
viewer_6.description:
April 17th, Friday
This evening we are still more alone, the 3 having gone to K, Pink to a meeting re this Mixed Farming question, and the girls to a Race Committee meeting. The house seems so quiet without them and one misses the wireless which requiring a new battery is silent. After tea Mother and I went gardening. I am cleaning the long border. I wheel her to the scene of activity and she knits and talks to me whilst I grub. H also came along and dug couch, and now that the Rose garden terracing is well under way I'm taking my gang on to this part to glean the grass which has got to look awful.

April 18th
The return of the wanderers at 12.30 found us immersed in chores, picture cleaning! I've found a thing called "Bon Ami" which is splendid for glass and everything is having its face washed. They brought with them the mail, and also the amazing news that the King of Spain has abdicated. Thus after 15 centuries that country is now a Republic. All through his reign it has been torn by revolutions and conflicting parties and now that they have their will, things with no one at the helm must surely become more and more chaotic. His was a wonderful character and the whole thing is a tragedy.

April 19th
Everyone writing from Home refers to our really desperate condition there. Unemployment, national extravagances amounting to disease, the Labour Govt powerless to extricate the country from the frightful burdens in which they have plunged it and Lloyd George playing around like a mad man. From all one can judge the feeling among many appears to lean towards a Conservative party and many have turned over but unless it is a live one it will be just as useless. Owen writes, and he really lives in the know, "what we want is a live Conservative party and a Tariff". It is certain that no country can go on for long "overdrawing" as England is doing, it all reads like a nightmare.

April 20th
The day began well! On going to say good morning to Mother I found that she had been indulging in a severe nose bleeding but was quite cheerful and thought nothing of it. I then proceeded to my store cupboard and there right across it and concentrated upon a dish of meat were millions of siafu ants. I had the whole thing rushed out into the yard and then applied boiling water and paraffin. They are disgusting and it makes me sick to see these seething masses moving swiftly along. Well, to counterbalance this the water is now OK. How soon one gets to find a thing indispensable. For years naturally we had none laid on and now if it goes wrong for even a week one feels as though the worst has occurred.

April 21st
My Mother is in for a liver attack, one of her periodical ones. I am worried, it is exactly like dear old Gran's complaint, nothing can be done it just must wear itself out but is so painful and vile whilst it lasts.

April 22nd, Wednesday.
Our engagement day, a never to be forgotten event in my thrice blessed life. A meeting here today of the District Council. Much conversation and acrimonious argument. Also the mail bringing letters from Eve and vile news from India.

April 23rd
I am rushing everything out as fast as I can, pricking and planting and as I write heavy rain falls, just quite splendid. I've made a new bed too on one of the terraces and pricked out a million seedlings, collected all the Gerbera in one big area and made a Canterbury Bell colony near the drive. Tyack turned up to lunch, so very nice to see him, one's old friends have petered out it seems to me, and the new ones don't come up to them. Times are so hard that people have ceased to run about the country to any great extent. We scarcely go to anything.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
April 24th - 30th

Voting for the Legislative Council...and discussing the Depression, much as we do in our own times (2012).
viewer_8.description:
April 24th, Friday
Stuck in opposite (see preceding window) is an interesting article on this amazing craze for extravagance. It does not appear to be so much an individual trait as a national one, and amounts to mania. The article speaks for itself and where this suicidal policy is going to land the country is beyond conception. On the other hand the World Slump in prices is ruining the individual and consequent chaos reigns. Unemployment is no bogey of the imagination, but thousands are living on the dole from choice and a nation of "unemployables" is growing up, an amazing state of affairs. One wonders if there exists a spot on earth which is not affected by the universal trouble. Even on a desert island I fancy the price of coconuts is up!

April 25th
We all trailed up to Elgon Club to register our votes. We have two candidates this year, Kirkwood and Crampton. I do no think the latter has a chance but voted for him thinking a change would be good. Tyack went off today and Pink went with him, the former to record his vote. They did not return this evening so I fancy they have fallen among thieves and may return tomorrow.

April 26th, Sunday
The wanderers did return and brought the news that Kirkwood got in by a large majority. I expect he is very pleased and it shows that he has the general confidence. Opposite I put a strange advert of the new Berkeley flats, really what will people invent next. I cant fancy these gardens on the tops of houses and what could grow when the soil cant be any depth at all. Mad.

April 27th
Tyack left us today, so pleasant to see him. I feel sorry for this lone man who really does have a very large share of bad luck all round but who is always cheerful and philosophical in spite of it all.

April 28th
Shaw and Billy Symes came along today. The latter is going Home immediately and wants Pink to take over charge of Frank's farm for him. That young thing "Billy" has just done an amazing thing. The Montgomerys introduced him to a girl they brought out the other day and after knowing her for a few hours he proposed and was accepted! To contemplate lifelong companionship with an individual one has only just met seems to me a bit risky, it is of such stuff that disasters matrimonial are made. I am hoping that this is to be an exception for he's too good for that sort of thing. How Shaw will miss him.

April 29th
Up drove Billy Symes and Upton. They and Pink then went up the hill to Frank's place and after due inspection returned to lunch. Billy looks scared! I think he must be amazed at himself and this act of impulse. I cant get over the comparison of a few hours with a lifetime!

April 30th
The last day of April. H and Pink went over to dine at the Wrefords. I was to have gone too but a far approaching storm put me off. D (Wreford Smith) has been waking up and getting at her garden. All these people never seem to start till about May and they seldom raise anything themselves. I should hate to be dependant on others for the gayness of my garden.

april.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895.

Life on a Kenyan farm.

Jacob Epstein and Safari ants compete for Wynne's disapproval. Her brother arrives with his new bride.

errors: Seems to be a placeholder with no content.
Seems to be a placeholder with no content.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Wynne was a passionate gardener, and now with the house completed she was tackling the landscaping around it. These are two views of the early efforts - noticeably with expansive views down to the plains. Much later, most of these views were hidden by the extensive planting, of trees and shrubs, in amongst which grew a wonderful collection of African orchids collected on the many trips that her son made while collecting butterflies.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
February 1st - 11th

Life in the Depression is tough and most of the farmers are living on overdrafts. Some are already selling up and leaving.
viewer_2.description:
February 1st, Sunday
We had intended being holy poly today but early in the morning a boy came to inform us that the garage had fallen upon the car and that inconsequence she was a prisoner so no Kirk for us. The only damage luckily enough is to one side of the hood which is bent. The boys soon pulled down the wreckage and now poor Pink will have to build a new one, a job he simply hates. Wrote more of my endless letters, as usual I am deep in debt and cant get on the right side.

Feb 2nd
The monkeys have gone! Stoneham came over to lunch and fetched them away and if he had looked back he'd have seen the whole family dancing a jig upon the drive. That's one pest removed but Miggles capped his and their delinquencies finely today by pulling over the whole dolls house. We expected to find it a complete wreck but beyond a few little china plates nothing was much damaged.

Feb 3rd
The Coffee officer looked in this morning full of gloomy exultation re: beetles and bugs. We refused to be gloomed. The girls busy sowing their herbs, millions of them.

Feb 4th
A day of M.P., this time the kitchen premises, and Goin, the fundi (carpenter), is colour washing it all. How difficult and almost impossible it is to keep these premises as one would like them to be when half the shamba congregates in them every day despite all our efforts.

Feb 5th
My scourings and sweepings are nearly through, my back premises are for the moment fairly clean but it is a case of never ceasing vigilance out here for the native is not clean by nature, it is nothing to him if the yard is littered with paper and the kitchen floor a mass of dust and vegetable skins! I was amused today, Pink went over to dine at Ashbys, they were just the two selves and he provided a dinner of 6 courses. We never have more than 3!

February 8th, Sunday
We three went over to the V.Ps this morning. We discussed as usual cheese paring and wondered how we could manufacture our own oatmeal for porridge! It strikes one as pathetic when one sees his shamba, his cribs all full of maize, his neat and well cared for establishment, to realise that there is nothing behind it all but an overdraft.

February 9th
The new garage is nearly completed and the monkey house rewired.

Feb 10th
Our coffee picking is almost through, that is to say the main gathering. There will always be a certain amount to collect all the year I fancy but the bibis (women) do that and now the maize reaping has begun. We are making small cribs this year to garner it in until such time as it is shelled.

Feb 11th
Pink went off with Wreford to a sale over Turbo way and returned at dinner time with a variety of bargains. These sales are a tragedy these days, everything is sold for nothing. Wreford bought a new Jumbo plough for 20/-! Mail today, letters from Eve and my dividends, most welcome! News of locusts!

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: Wynne was always fascinated by the many new developments and technologies that were developed after the war. Here are two cuttings she stuck into her diary - one of a road notice warning about low flying aircraft, and the other illustrating the first automat serving ready meals. Cicely Courtneidge was a well known actor.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
February 12th - 20th

An aeroplane flying over the house causes great excitement. More schemes are hatched to make ends meet, and the dry weather continues.
viewer_4.description:
Feb 12th
Babs took a toss today and has hurt her hand and arm. Though its still very dry and hot there are signs of Spring, the thorns are coming into leaf and I found two Crinums showing, also two of the Nandi Gloriosa well up.

Feb 13th
Pink went to K to do the week's shopping and evidently spends the night as he has not returned.
I am busy digging up all the freesia bulbs, gladiola etc preparatory to replanting. All increased enormously. I also did a lot of pruning aided by Mother's presence in her chair.

Feb 14th
St Valentine's Day, the birds' wedding day at home. Here they seem to have no fixed season but build and breed all the year round. Pink came back to lunch and Mrs Haly and Eric (Shipton) arrived at tea, she is to stay about 10 days as their house is roofless. A small spot of rain fell at lunch time, marvellous sight.

Feb 15th, Sunday
Rain measured .01! I wrote letters and jabbered all the morning and the boys went off to the spruit.

Feb 16th
A morning spent in bulb sorting, an afternoon tracing cards. This work bores me but as at Xmas they sell better than anything it behoves me to get busy since I have taken up the role of bagwoman in common with most of us out here! I know of one household where all the good peaches are sold and the family only have the bad ones!

Feb 17th
I ought to have been at the Kirk this morning but I simply forgot all about it. Our crowd (they were a party of ten overnight) all left today. Alone again and peaceful!

February 18th, Wednesday
Hoards again as the local council held their meeting here this morning, and all sat in conclave in the dining room talking blather! Dorothy May came with her father and played with bricks - how many children have these same bricks amused since the time when H first made them for his own. We asked her if she could count to which she replied "I only count in my own house. I don't count in other people's houses".

February 19th
An aeroplane has just passed over the house! In this far spot where such things are so unusual we fly forth to gaze upon this, to us, amazing sight. This is the second, the first being Lord Rothschild's when he returned about a year ago from his safari de luxe. We've been down to the factory this morning to show it to Miss H and to search for lemons. Walked back from the avenue and let Pink have the car as he had had word that the wagons with the coffee were hung up en route with a broken dusselboom (ie: the main pole from the wagon to which the yokes are attached). We now have gathered up to date 18 ton and there is a bit more to follow besides of course the April crop. It is distinctly better than we thought to get.

February 20th
We set off this morning to set up the sign board at one of the many cross roads. It was hot. The country all round for miles is burnt black and arid but up in this district we always have the thorns and the green trees in the many spruits. So different from the Nzoia plains.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: The family had had tennis courts in England, and they decided to make one in their new home - it looks as if it took precedence over the garden, but then, there were few social events and this was one way of entertaining each other and guests.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
February 21st - 28th

More coffee bagged and sent off and the rain starts at last. The first signs of locusts - swarms have been predicted.
viewer_6.description:
Feb 21st
This morning I was engaged in culling back and rewiring the road archway. Heavy clouds rolled up and a fierce wind blew all the leaves about, it might have been an autumn day at Home.

Feb 22nd
Sunday again. The weeks fly by so fast that it's always Sunday here. The Olivers came in to tea and to buy skins and to say goodbye as they are off on Wed, Mrs O remarking pathetically "Poor Newy he's been out here 4½ years, its time he had a change". Shrieks from the unfeeling family, what nonsense it is - did the early pioneers rush off Home every few years! I trow me not.

Feb 23rd
A spot of rain and a cloud of locusts in the distance.

Feb 24th
Great rejoicings. Good rain fell on and off most of the day. Thankful for our poor tired coffee. Locusts still in the offing.

A view of the young coffee plantation.

February 25th, Wednesday
Rain measure .65. Waggon left with 60 bags more coffee, making about 20 ton. This rain makes one feel alive again. Mail in - letters from Eve who writes about the visit of Ell and K (her brother). Dorothy also wrote letting up that Mr Blake was ill only for four days, just a cold which turned to bronchitis and he apparently did not realise that he was dying.

Feb 26th
A bit more rain and as my totos have now finished the kitchen job I shall finish clearing out and bedding up my flower borders. H is busy making my seed house and I am longing to start sowing.

Feb 27th
Noots has sold her incubator for 120/- so the girls carted it into Kitale this morning. There they saw the world and his wife and made many arrangements for weekends.

Feb 28th
The last day of Feb and unmarked by any event save the usual chores and the digging of holes for the wood work of the seed house.

february.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895.

Wynne is living in Kenya, on a farm in the Trans Nzioa.

Life in the Depression is tough, but their coffee is beginning to produce, and so far the locust swarms are staying away.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
KENYA

New Year

The Jackson family moved to Kenya in 1924, following Thomas' decision to establish a farm there. You can read about their journey and arrival in Travel. This was a tricky decision for Herbert and Wynne, because they could not afford to support Thomas and continue to live in England at the same time. As a result, Herbert commuted his army pension, and took the risky decision to invest in the new venture, just at a time when the economies of the world started to move towards recession. As you can read, by 1931 times were hard, and many of the folk the family knew were in trouble. Banks repossessed farms, and families left the area, but the Jackson family managed to continue, and Thomas remained here until his death in 1968, by which time he was a Kenyan citizen. The money bags in this New Year frontispiece painted for Wynne by her Mother represent their rather vain hope that the year will provide financial success.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
January 1st - 6th

A New Year is seen in with a fancy dress dance, but times are hard and the outlook is very gloomy for the struggling farmers.
viewer_2.description:
January 1st, Thursday
It is not easy to strike a genuinely cheerful note as one writes a journal in these truly abnormal times but in any case we did our best last night to cast all cares and anxieties from us as we danced the New Year in at the Club. No one looking on at that gay assembly would have thought that many were down and out and that few whilst ringing the old year out could look forward with any sense of ease to the coming one. The last few days have been more than hectic preparing for the event and the whole family set to making our dresses: a cabbage, radish, carrot and gardener, Mother being as busy as the rest. (Wynne's mother, Blanche, although very crippled, had managed to come out by sea to visit them). Just as we were having a dress rehearsal who should appear but the Taylor family on their way to a children's party at the Lugards.
