They seemed outwardly cheerful but their lot is about as hopeless as it well could be as they are now in the hands of a mortgager who is about to foreclose, and unless they can sell or get someone to take over the mortgage they will walk out of their house and off their shamba* in the clothes they are wearing as there is a lean on the furniture as well…and to this they have come after about 16 or 17 years toil and moil.
Well at about 3 we went forth leaving Mother and H to guard the house and arriving at Kitale took our things to one of the tents set up for this evening's guests, and had tea. Soon various people turned up and after sundowning we all went to dress. It was a great success, a lot of people, many original dresses but alas a good deal of mufti, a most unusual thing at this particular show but I fear a sign of the times. We left for home at about 12 and found all well on arrival.

January 2nd
Each morning now we are victims to the hot weather wind which blows at various hours most of the day. All through this land there is that dry hot feeling and dust ladened distance, the plains once more are covered with unnameable veldt fires and at night assume an almost theatrical appearance but although no one likes this time of year what have we to put up with in comparison to India and many another place out East.
The Padre came to spend the night. He is full of his trip Home and produced many photos. I greatly wonder if sufficient funds will be forthcoming to afford him much longer, church finance is at a low ebb and the means of raising money nil.

January 3rd
Yesterday was Eve's birthday. She is 59 this year! for I am 52 in June. Ye gods, how frightful! I'm trying to get through Xmas aftermath letters, such a collection I don't know where to begin.

January 4th
At 7 this morning I heard the car go off. Poor Pink had to go down to see the wagon off to Kitale with the coffee, not much of a Sunday morning for him. Then directly after breakfast he went off to fetch old Ashby, the father of a boy lately settled near by, and they spent the morning in the spruit* after butterflies. Pink took him back after tea. He is a very keen "bug" collector. This I may mention is a great factor in Pink's life, he is getting a very fine collection and spends most of his spare time at it. (T.H.E.Jackson became a well-known lepidopterist. On his death in 1968 his enormous collection was split between a museum in Kenya and the Natural History Museum in the UK. Several of his discoveries were named after him).

January 5th, Monday
The first Monday in the New Year! Mondays are no longer "black" for me, but I remember once long ago bemoaning the day to Martha, and her reply: "Mondays black?! Why its a new day, a new week, and new work. I loves me Mondays". Ever since perforce I've loved mine too! I spent most of this one remaking lampshades and cushion covers of some of the lovely stuff mother gave me at Xmas and as we now have clean furniture covers we look really smart. The girls are busy now every day reconstructing their stables, converting them into loose boxes.

January 6th
A spot of gardening today and my totos* cutting hedges, a very long job. Another party turned up today, they came to inspect the factor as they are thinking of setting one up.

*shamba: a field, or in this case, farm
*spruit: a small stream or creek.
*toto: a young boy, taken on for general work.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Initially the family lived in mud-built houses with thatched roofs, the first of which burnt down. You can see the first house they actually stayed in on arrival if you click here. By however they were finally in a permanent building, and beginning work landscaping the area around it:

The bedrooms were in the two wings, right and left. The centre contained the sitting and dining areas.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
January 7th - 15th

The dry season is at its height. A house clearance provides a surprise, and the mail brings wedding news.
viewer_4.description:
January 7th, Wednesday
Ell (Wynne's brother) was married today to Kathleen Dixon in Calcutta. This amazing news we heard by wire about a month ago and we are still unable to get over our great surprise, but oh! how glad we are.

January 8th
Xmas aftermath letter writing still upon me, last year I wrote 50 and this year having left everything to the last I cut them down to about 30 but now come letters from most of those I cut out and all must be answered.

January 9th
To Kitale for a Horticultural meeting at which we sat from 10.30 to 1.0 discussing the new schedule. The Show is to be at the schools on the 15th August. We went in (to town) before breakfast, and didn't get out till after tea!

January 10th
All day long has Pink toiled at the car from breakfast to sundown. All his meals were sent out to him as the poor thing was grease from head to foot. Well, she responded to all this kind treatment and 2 days ago we furbished up her interior as well. This wonderful old car Pink bought in 24. "The old Dodge" has become a sort of local celebrity and we are really proud of her. This morning we too were on the rampage. I had the little machine room turned out and every box of rubbish we sorted and cast. We are most terribly dry just now, the poor garden is parched and dead but there is rain in the offing.

Jan 12th, Monday
I missed out yesterday! My blessed son is 28 today. Two things happened that I must record. The old store has been pulled down and all its remaining contents were brought down here. Amongst them was a small leather covered case which no one seemed to know anything about. Upon examination it was found to be Aunt Maria Elliot's dressing case given to me by Mother and completely forgotten! and in it the amethyst set and long chain and a heap of small bits of jewellery I had completely wiped out of my brain. Ages ago I realised that the amethysts were astray and concluded they had been stolen but of the very existence of all the rest I had become entirely unaware.
The next event was the arrival from K of the wagon bringing with it the old dolls' house. This had been left at home and stored by the Shelleys for us at Newnham but moving house they could no longer. We found on unpacking it very little broken and now we are going to set about and renovate it. It is a joy to see all the funny little things again.

Jan 13th
Mrs Kirk is giving a series of cooking classes and I went over today with the Leonards for it. We learnt about fruit crystallising and when I have more leisure I shall try my hand. The girls went into Kitale to attend a meeting of the Gymkana club and stayed the night with the Hills.

Jan 15th, Thursday
The Indian mail came in yesterday bringing an account from Eve of "K" as I suppose we now call Ell's girl. She writes of a very attractive character and she sounds exactly the sort of girl to suit him, both in appearance and abilities, a sportswoman and a business head. The Fates do the right things sometimes. An afternoon of F.M. (family mending). How domestic our lives have become.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Wynne was looking for a home for her pet monkeys. These two responses caused much amusement in the family, and she stuck them into the diary...

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
January 16th - 23rd

Invasion by safari ants, a new disease in the coffee and an amusing answer to their advert looking for a home for the pet monkeys. Everyone seems to be living on credit.
viewer_6.description:
January 16th, Friday
Some time ago a safari up the mountain was proposed for this week by Eric (Shipton, the famous mountaineer - see June entries) and Pink but the former is vague and has sent no word, however as he may turn up Pink went off to K to get in certain provisions. On his return he brought the mail and a letter from Dorothy Carles to say Mr Blake is dead. No particulars, it is a shock as only a short time ago he wrote so full of life and vigour and one wonders what possibly could have been the cause. We feel we have lost a good friend.

Jan 17th
LIfe has its ups and downs for us all. D writes over to say that the siafu ants have killed all their young chicks but 15, and their new puppy has seen to 10 more. They had lately had a splendid hatch from their incubator and it is a loss they can ill afford. I am busy making up seed packets for Mrs Hill to sell. She proposes giving me 20 cents a packet.

Jan 18th
The siafu have been busy here too and have eaten 7 of Noots' young turkeys. At this time of year these dreadful scourges are on the march and there really is no way of protecting our stock from them. One is only lucky if they don't march through the house as there is no real way of stopping them and it means clearing out one self.

Jan 19th
My days are chiefly spent these dry and arid times in sewing and house chores. I had a few extra of the latter to do this morning as my Nandis have leave to be at an n'goma (kiswahili word for drum, but used often to mean a meeting or social event), but there is not much one can do in the garden and I've put my totos on to the kitchen garden until it is finished.

Jan 20th
At 6.30 this morning the 3 went off to Mummias for a big native show taking food with them and we didn't expect them back until tomorrow but at 10.30 they returned bringing with them 3 lovely beaded wooden stools and a little brass cup. We on the other hand had a day of monkeying, all three (monkeys) got loose at frequent intervals and I was nearly dotty by the end of the day. I have put an advert in the papers which by the way they printed thus (xxx) and which brought forth this reply over which we had many cackles. V.P. looked in and Mrs Lugard, also TJ to tell of a new coffee disease, "gonocephlum", a beetle, which is apparently putting the wind up them all, but Pink is undisturbed and says we've always had it slightly. Paris Green (copper acetoarsenite) to the rescue.

Jan 21st
The mail brought with it an enquiry about the Potts monkeys! The whole family danced and sang Halelujah. A wire came from Eric saying he and his mother come on Friday so the safari this time will come off.

Jan 23rd
Nothing to record about yesterday and today we went to Kitale to attend a EAWL meeting. All settlers as usual shopping on 2½d even as we do, and paying for nothing. Mrs H and Eric arrived at tea time.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description: Wynne had always adored this dancer, and she notes her death in the January 24th entry. You can see her saved programmes stuck into earlier diaries if you click here.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
January 24th - 31st

Pavlova's death is noted, and raises comments about the mundane level of their lives.
viewer_8.description:
January 24th, Saturday
Early before sun up all were astir and the boys left at 6.30. Having got them off I had a Sat morning choring, and made rock cakes - they were as I forgot the butter! We heard tonight on wireless that Anna Pavlova is dead. That incomparable dancer. What pleasure she has given to thousands. I shall never forget her dancing "The Dryad", a performance of dancing and music without words which reduced me to tears and now that most elegant and charming little creature has gone to dance among the Shades.

Jan 25th
After the usual very welcome day of do nothings we were all sitting out on the terrace when who should drive up but Shaw, Upton and Clark. Local news was cackled over and the topics of our little world discussed. How difficult it is in our small backwoods existence to keep from shop, with the best intentions in the world one drifts back to it always.

Jan 27th
This most interesting picture I cut out of the Illustrated London News. I am sure of course at the time one must have known of this awful disaster but the years have swallowed up most of the individual events of that terrible time. Our boys returned today having had a good trip and seem to have enjoyed it but Pink says that walking on the slippery grass is killing work and worse than the wet weather.

Jan 28th
Mrs H and Eric left this morning. The mail today brought us letters from Ell and K, the first after their wedding, and told us all about it.

Jan 29th
We went up to tea with Swan, his mother and her husband. His farm is way up at the back of beyond and quite lovely but the approach is frightful. It all looks rather neglected and forlorn but he has come entirely to grief with £sd and is seldom there.

Jan 30th
To Kitale again, the last time for months I hope. Attended a KHS meeting, there was also a big maize meeting on so crowds were in. So hot and dusty and vile, how I should hate to live there. When we returned we found both monkeys had escaped and they haven't come back! and Stoneham is to come and fetch them on Monday!

Jan 31st, Saturday
We took Mother over to tea with the Lugards, much spitting and swearing on her part, an entertainment not to be repeated!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description: On January 27th Wynne cut this out of the Illustrated London News. The anchor had been blown three miles across the city. "One of the most appalling of the disasters which occurred outside the war zones during the Great War was the blowing-up of the SS Mount Blanc (laden with picric acid, a thousand tons of T.N.T and a deck cargo of benzol) in Halifax harbour after a collision in 1917. Three thousand men, women and children were killed or desperately injured, six thousand were rendered homeless and two square miles of the city became a burning ruin. The largest remaining part of the vessel, her anchor, was hurled three miles across teh city, and remains embedded in the earth as a mute and undesigned memorial of the tragic event."

january.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895, finds Wynne in Kenya, on a farm in the Trans Nzioa. The whole family moved there in 1924.

They have finally moved into their new house, and are hard at work in farm and garden on the slopes of Mount Elgon.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Another classic Wynne artistic outburst - see July 4th. She saw nothing in Henry Moore, and, more surprisingly, could not work out this rather lovely picture by James Fitton. Her comment about the picture having "a want of perspective" is puzzling. Perhaps we are more used to flying and high buildings, so that this angle does not appear unusual?

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
July 1st - 8th

Wynne notes the attempt to reach the North Pole by submarine and zeppelin. She is bitten by her pet monkey - an event that brings 36 years of diary writing to an end.
viewer_2.description:
July 1st, Wednesday
If one wishes to be gloomy what I say is to do it thoroughly! No half and half measure for Lady Drummond Hay anyhow who writes thus in the Sphere. One knows indeed that we live in queer times, that something odd is certainly happening to civilisation, but surely it isn't really as jaundiced as this! The mail arrived today bringing many letters and I was greatly interested to have one from Eric Shipton written a day's march from Base Camp. His description of the country is quite lovely, scenery of distances and near vicinity all made me green with envy, but their real work was just before them and sounded grim!

July 2nd
Mother too had a big mail yesterday, a long letter from Ell which in advising her to give up the idea of going to India on account of the unrest depressed her thoroughly, poor dear. Well one can only wait and see how things develop and it will be for the Lees to settle. I've been very busy pricking out stocks and gerbera today. It really is a job to keep it all going but the place is looking very gay and we are beginning to think of the show. Nemesias are particularly lovely, and my seedling dahlias a joy, also carnations are making a beginning.

July 3rd
Have I mentioned before I wonder of this amazing venture about to take place, viz: the attempt to reach the North Pole by submarine under the ice and the proposed meeting of it there by the Graf Zeppelin air ship! Lady Drummond Hay, the Sphere correspondent, is to be on board the latter, the first woman to venture forth on this quest. The submarine, the Nautilus, called after Jules Verne's novel ship, has just made the journey from America and got into fearful trouble in doing so, see enclosed. It all sound a hair raising nightmare and what is to be accomplished by it all?

July 4th
Here are two more examples of modern art, truly I find more excuse of Mother and Child than for the landscape, for what possible beauty can lie in a want of perspective? No one surely really sees nature all skewwhiff and yet some critics say that in 5 years time these freaks of art will become the recognised thing!
A rainy cold afternoon and the Morgans who were to arrive at tea didn't turn up until 6 - torrential rain in Kitale apparently. We played Bridge and Vingt et un, ending up by "Chasing the Ace", a game we hadn't played for months.

July 5th
Our guests were trailed round the garden and the coffee according to custom, so boring for them, and then made to play tennis. An afternoon of meditation and Bridge concluded the day.

July 6th
The Morgans left after breakfast. I went down to the coffee nursery and collected the roses we have struck and replanted them up here awaiting the rose garden.

July 7th
A day of the usual garden work. The postboy took with him today a registered slip for me. What can be contained in a registered letter from London - we all say "wool"! for one of my various works.

July 8th, Wednesday
The peaceful order of our ways was somewhat disturbed today. A lovely morning during which I "digged and delved", and at about 1.0 when we came in for lunch we heard over the hill a tremendous noise of labour shouting, a sure sign these days of locusts. Over the hill they came, a huge swarm. Down rushed Pink and the Neopara's whistle sounded, all our crowd turned out and stood by but they whirled round and down and did not settle, but spent the night all over the trees in the spruit and it only remains to be seen if tomorrow morning early they descend on us. After lunch the biggest storm we've had for years arrived, the noise was terrific, thunder, lightening and a deluge and we were in a sea of rushing water. In my little kitchen with its tin roof it sounded as though all the fiends were let loose. The mail came in to calm us down. It brought me 3 books from Arthur Owen. This more than busy day ended for me by being bitten by Miggles. The little creature has become unnaturally excitable these days and wont stand any correction. He had seized hold of the rain gauge and on my scolding him flew at me and bit my elbow. Must have got a nerve I suppose as it was rather painful and felt like it does when one knocks one's "funny bone".

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
Winifred Gladys Jackson, née Llewhellin

1879 -

The monkey bite turned sceptic, and because this was pre-anitbiotics, the only solution to septicaemia was amputation. Unfortunately, they took Wynne's arm off too late, though it is doubtful if that would have saved her.

Wynne is buried in the little local cemetary in Kitale. Her death had a devastating effect on everyone.

Her poor disabled Mother had to struggle back to England, and she was followed later by Wynne's husband, Herbert, who decided on the move for health reasons. He died there in 1938 and is buried in West Mersea. Both Wynne's daughters left the farm to marry, leaving her son Thomas to look after what became a very productive coffee estate.


Thomas' passion for butterflies turned into a very professional collection, and although his publications were small in number, he made a number of discoveries and collaborated with scientists in the UK, Paris and elsewhere.

He died in 1968.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.description: The Last Page...

july.description:
The final month in the last diary.

Wynne was bitten by her pet monkey, developed septicaemia, and died in the local hospital.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
Wynne cut these out of the Sphere, lamenting the loss of the Hotel Cecil, which had been famous in her youth. She wondered if she would recognise London, so much of which was changing...

The hotel was a very grand affair, located between the Embankment and the Strand. Below, a picture of Piccadilly - also facing some changes...

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
June 1st - 7th

Electric light is switched on amid much celebration. Wynne and Herbert celebrate 30 years of marriage.
viewer_2.description:
June 1st, Monday
A short but sharp shower of rain refreshed us this day and I felt grateful for the young coffee. Capt House and Pink returned together as the car has been left in K for the hood repairs. All day long the engine is running and all night too now and the work of connecting up the wires is toward today but no sign of course of further lamp shades and we cant get on with our job.

June 2nd
I am wondering still what has become of our Post Boy, if the Police have taken a permanent fancy to his face and if he has run away! He is supposed to have forged his kipande I hear but as a rule they just fine them for that. However we've sent in another today. Our last Standard gave an appalling account of the locust plague, it is said that in some areas they are miles long by wide and we can see them each day flying thick over the plain. I dread their arrival up here but there is so much young maize up now that they may not come, but our heart aches for these same maize planters. To lose all one's crop just this year seems quite too terrible and of course it means famine in the Reserves.

June 3rd
King's Birthday and Electric Light.
Derby Day! How many hundreds and thousands of people's hearts are burning with expectation today? Over the whole world there are ticket holders for the Calcutta Sweep and the (Dublin) Irish Hospital Sweep for which latter two million pounds have been subscribed, even the house of Jackson had a venture in each! Well, having failed there we have today gained in another way for today we are revelling in our Electric Light. It is an actual fact and we all sat around in the drawing room wondering if it was all a dream. We felt we had to indulge in something to drink Mother's health and a very genuine sense of gratitude was felt by all for really its just too lovely for words.

June 4th
Capt House left us today. The installing has taken very nearly a month. Our rain break continues and though was have a little it is the real June break which comes along every year up here and the days are truly lovely, warm and still and sunny and the garden is a real delight. We should be very gay this year.

June 5th
Our wedding day and we have been married for 30 years! How utterly splendid its all been and how good in every sense. Pink returned today bringing with him the most disastrous accounts of the locust plague. They've eaten up acre after acre. It makes one's heart ache, the whole thing on top of the starvation prices is more than a tragedy. Well, who knows, they may come here and if they do one must just put a decent face on it but I will not meet trouble. Moore was away somewhere and on his return he found his whole house eaten out, carpets, blankets, bedding etc whilst one of the Tyack boys returned from Nandi with the tale that at his home on their arrival people all turned out, leaving a small toto to look after a newly born baby and on their return found the locusts had eaten it - I cant believe this, but neither could I have believed the incident of the bedding etc if I did not know it for a fact. I hear the Dowlings have closed down this year and dismissed all their labour. It really is a frightful nightmare.

June 6th
Here are two pictures of changing London. How shall we recognise the Town when next we see it. The Hotel Cecil! Once the resort of only the very rich, the place to stay at if you had the money, but fashion changes all, no one who wishes to be thought "it" goes there now, and the Ritz, Savoy and Carlton hold sway, besides several other huge caravanserai the names even of which I don't know!

June 7th
Charles de la Harpe came along this afternoon bringing with him the leopard skin he has been curing for Mother but unfortunately the native skinners had left so much fat on that the hair came off in the curing so he brought another of his own as a substitute. We couldn't let him do this so gave him one of ours. H and I went off to Kirk. The little Padre who has been told with appropriate tact that he hasn't the gift of tongues, read to us a sermon for over half an hour! So foolish when we've all got so far to go. We didn't get back till past 2.0. We also had a special locust prayer which prayed that this country might be kept from locusts which seems to me beside the mark as it is already eaten bare from end to end.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: This time, the record of a grand hotel opening. Wynne was clearly very struck by it, and having just finished reading Arnold Bennett's "Imperial Palace" she compared it to that. Below are exterior and vestibule shots of the newly opened Dorchester Hotel on Park Lane...and a picture of the men behind this new venture.

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
June 8th - 18th

Wynne's birthday on June 15th - she is 52. Race Day in Kitale takes place, but brings no victories for the Jacksons.
viewer_4.description:
June 8th, Monday
Pink is back this morning and plays off his finals next Sunday - we shall I hope be there to see him do it as we are intending to stay in to the dance after the Races.

June 9th
Having got myself dirty while gardening I fled indoors to change on hearing a car, but stepped forth to find alas that Mrs Hoey had not come, only Hoey and Tebbitt the road man. Tebbitt struck me as being an extraordinary man, he has it seems a knowledge and great love for the beautiful and is I hear entirely self educated. Hoey got at the wireless for us but cant find out whats wrong. He has now taken off a valve to test. It is a great disappointment and we do miss it so. During lunch the Padre arrived to stay the night.

June 10th
Mail Day but no letters for me. I'm rather relieved really as I am just clear and have none to answer.

June 12th, Friday
A day missed out, uneventful. Much preparation took place today for the Races tomorrow and the ponies left at dawn.

June 13th, Saturday
The day of the Races! Off we went early before breakfast, much packing and fussing, and we arrived in time for breakfast at the Club. Alas our luck was out today, we lost all our money and the girls their races, but there were horses of such different type entered, especially two new ones of the Llewhellins, that we hadn't a chance. We stayed on to the dance, the girls sleeping out at Tyack. A lot of people at the dance but the old order changeth, a crowd of mechanics and shoppies and one feels inclined to say "where are my playmates gone?"

June 14th
I went down early to the club and watched Pink play his finals, losing the doubles and winning the singles. Then struggled home. Heavy rain fell and we stuck badly near the round hill but a gang of boys providentially arrived and pulled us out. Heard today that Billy Symes' girl has already chucked him and has gone Home with one Vallings who she intends marrying. It's a tragedy for him but everyone else is glad as from all one hears she is just a little rotter.

June 15th
It is my birthday and I am exactly 103 today. How lightly my years sit upon me! After lunch I went forth a took a lot of rose cuttings.

June 16th
I am thankful to say that Mother is herself again. Pink and I are preparing to go on safari. We propose starting on Thursday and I am thankful Mother is fit for otherwise I couldn't possibly go. We go to the rest house at Kakamega where a belt of forest should supply many bugs and I am much looking forward to a complete idle.

June 17th
Pink has been up at Franks all day and after tea went down to the factory to get coffee weighed ready to transport tomorrow. Locusts came horribly near today.

June 18th
We breakfasted early and set forth by 8.30. Our road was good nearly all the way but descending a somewhat rocky part we sprung a puncture which delayed us a bit. We arrived at length at this little rest house on the edge of the forest line, the country round is the usual sugar bush variety but opposite lie the everlasting hills, a big range dividing us from the Nandi Reserve. We went down to the forest and found the whole place swarming with butterflies of every sort and kind, great groups of them collected over patches of moisture and flying up and down the road. An ideal spot. We lunched and slept and after tea walked down across the bush towards the ridge. An early dinner and an early bed.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Eric Shipton had come out to Kenya in 1928, to farm coffee, which may be the reason for his friendship with similar coffee farmers, the Jacksons. He became a famous mountaineer, climbing the Kenyan peaks before attempting Kamet with Frank Smythe in . At 7816 metres their successful ascent meant that they held the record for the highest altitude climbed at that time. Shipton went on to have a very colourful career, but was overlooked to lead the 1953 Everest expedition even though he was by far the most experienced Everest hand on the planet.

Two letters from him to Wynne survive in the diaries, the first written on the long route march needed to reach Base Camp: it is transcribed below the picture, and a map of the Indian Railways indicates their route to Kathgodam, from where they had a long and arduous walk - much harder in those days to get to the peaks.

First letter from Eric Shipton
31st May, 1931. En route to Base Camp, Himalayas.

Dear Mrs Jackson
I thought a line from here might interest you, to let you know how we are getting on.
I had a short but very amusing stay in Bombay before Smythe arrived. I was met by a fellow called Oslen who had been instructed to do so by the people Marge had been staying with in Madras. He strongly disapproved of my hat and took me off at once to buy one which was a little less barbaric. After this he had further trouble in making me conform to civilised ways; he gave me an excellent time though, among other things I saw my first "talkie" - I rather liked it.
I had a good many things to do - seeing that all the Expedition goods were landed free of customs etc - and when Smythe arrived we left directly for Ranikhet. The journey up was very hot and dusty as I suppose all Indian journeys are - through vile country. At Muttra (now Mathura) where we changed, we had a five hour wait and so we went along to the R.A. Mess. We were given baths, dinner and far too many mixed drinks, with the result that we nearly missed the train and passed the rest of the journey in a very pleasant condition! From Kathgodam we were taken in a bus for fifty miles into the hills - rather a wonderful drive.
Ranikhet is a delightful spot - right in the midst of oak and chestnut covered hills. We were given the Forest Bungalow to live in, and there we spent a very pleasant three weeks making all the arrangements. People were frightfully good to us and did all they could to help, besides giving us a very good time. It was my first view of Army life in India and I was very interested. We were asked to stay at G.H. at Nani Tal which was great fun.
The arrangements on a show like this involve rather more work than one would imagine, and we had our time well filled. Everything was ready by the time the others arrived and we left two days afterwards. All sorts of firms had sent us things and we had to leave masses of stuff behind. Huntley and Palmers sent us ¼ton of biscuits landed free at Ranikhet, also Ovaltine, Malted Milk, Chocolate etc appeared. The most acceptable gift however was a new portable H.M.V with 40 records.
We have been marching for 14 days now. I am in splendid company and I like all my companions very much indeed. The journey has been through wonderful country, range after range of forest covered mountains. I've never seen such complicated country. the flowers are glorious and Holdsworth, the botanist of the party, is in his element.
We have had frequent views of the great peaks of the Trisul Range which we have now passed. Their features are on quite a different scale to those of the Alpine peaks. Owing to the strange plastic (?) ice, enormous hanging glaciers, more than 1000 feet thick, form in every possible place on their faces. Another feature in the thinness of the ridges, through which you can see the sun shining from a distance of twenty or thirty miles Everything looks fearfully formidable.
Three days ago we crossed over the Knani (?) Pass from which we got a superb view. We saw the whole of the Kamet and Badrinath ranges and over the great glacier region where the Ganges is supposed to rise. We are going to attempt to explore that part but how much time we will have for it depends on how Kamet treats us.
Life is very good at the moment - days are full of interest and evenings in the mess tent are huge fun. One does not know whether or not to look forward to our arrival at Base Camp where the holiday part of it ends. I think we all do though. Our equipment is excellent - we each have a small Meade Tent to ourselves while the sleeping bags are splendid, they are wonderfully comfortable and can be regulated to four degrees of warmth.
I'll add to this if there is time at the Base Camp from where the next Times despatch is to be sent by runner. I hope you can read some of this as writing in a sleeping bag renders my normally bad writing dreadful.
I hope you are all well and that things are doing satisfactorily. One feels amazingly remote from Kenya here and one forgets all the problems of rain, fences etc. My love to you all. Eric.
PTO
4th June, Niti
We are delayed for two days here owing to transport difficulties. We are 2 marches from Base Camp and have a lot to do sorting out kit etc which will enable us to cut short our stay at B.C. As O.C. stores I am very busy making up provision boxes for the high camps. We leave tomorrow. This is just going off with the despatch runner. In haste. Eric.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
June 19th - 24th

Wynne and her son go on safari to the Kakamega forest, to collect butterflies.
viewer_6.description:
June 19th, Friday
I am waiting for breakfast and as I sit outside the hut on a car seat the utmost stillness reigns, broken only by the "poor father" wood doves and a few other bird notes. Our hut which is a little rest house of the D.C.'s (District Commissioner) consists of two tiny rooms, no window, and two openings for entrance. We thought at first to do without nets but the mosquitoes soon arrived so we fixed them up. Sometime during the night I was awakened by the sound of matches striking, and found it was poor Pink, mosquito hunting, a huge hole in his net having let one in. Yesterday on arrival we were met by the chief, we presented him with a blanket and he returned a little later and asked us if we required eggs, milk and chickens! Accordingly they arrived, the cock being released wanders about in a friendly way eating crumbs and coming into the hut and I feel a murderess. The night was warm and still, not so today, as I write this in the evening for a violent thunder and rain storm has just broken over us with the usual preceding hurricane. The forest was obliterated by thick clouds and heavy rain and one could scarce believe it was the same peaceful place in which we have been wandering all day. We went off at about 9.30 armed with lunch and wandered up and down all day getting some new stuff and several enormous caterpillars. The road which has been cut through the absolutely impenetrable forest reminds me of the aisle of some immense cathedral for the trees which meet far overhead are like huge gothic arches. A lovely spot.

June 20th
Last night when we returned we found tea all laid and the table decorated with flowers! Kisuelli being an old hand at safari is a gem on these occasions and one can leave all arrangements to him. He enquired by the way last night if he should make bread to which I replied certainly, how he intends doing this I know not but he evidently has ways and means. After a good day's hunting including also a long fruitless search in pastures new we returned getting just caught by a violent storm. When we got down yesterday there were not many butterflies around, it was early and too cold, so after a bit of a search we decided to go to another place. There we came to a track leading to the far forest and up it we took the car. What a track. I wonder the car didn't break in half. We stopped at the edge of a sharp drop and walked on and on right down to a river. Here we had lunch and Pink waded across. I sat down to await his return, choosing as it proved the better part for he came back not long after disgusted at complete failure. This part of the country has been devastated by locusts, all their crops have been eaten, the maize stands stark and bare and even the buffalo grass is but sticks, a dreadful prospect.

June 21st
After a long day in the forest fearing lest the evening storm overtook us we hurried home and were horrified at the frightful noise the car made. Pink examined her innards and fears trouble. I hope this really is not so, with us stuck out in the wilds many miles from a garage. She wants oil, and hearing a car passing we hailed it. It proved to be Dr Ford of the Missions and he took our toto with him to bring back the necessary. I only hope it isn't some mysterious break. I walked this morning to the Mission house up the road. All the way locust devastation is in evidence, not a thing has been left them and the prospect is indeed tragedy. After tea we returned to the forest for possible moths but found only 3. Instead we were rewarded by the most marvellous sight, fireflies in every direction, just like a scene on the stage, thousands of tiny lamps flitting here and there.

June 22nd
I am keeping camp today and shall pass the time writing and sewing. Meanwhile the local chief is holding a Baraza outside in the compound, an interminable and never ceasing flow of conversation or rather babble holds sway. The chief I presume is hearing petitions and adjusting grievances, anyway it sounds as though no one were paying the least attention to anyone. There is one amongst them dressed up to the nines, a skin, horns and a huge head dress of sticks decorated with masses of feathers.

June 23rd, Tuesday
I've just seen my son off for the day, he goes to pastures new and I shall be interested upon his return to see if he has met with any success. I am thankful that no Baraza holds sway outside today. I must confess that about tea time yesterday I had got a bit tired of the infernal din! I hear on enquiry that the much dressed individual here yesterday was a Jelua witch doctor. How I wish I'd had my camera for one seldom sees anything like that in our more civilised parts these days.

June 24th
This new place is another forest about 10 miles distant and the hunting ground is the old road through it to Kakamega, long since in disuse. It winds its way through leafy shade and is utterly remote and fascinating. Soon surely the forest will have claimed its own again. Meanwhile we shared it with the butterflies, monkeys, squirrels and various frequenters of the ways who stopped to pass the time of day with us in their usual friendly way. If only the insects did not so furiously rage it would be perfect here.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
This is the second letter from Eric Shipton, but as it is dated arriving in Kitale on July 13th it is doubtful if Wynne read it. Amazingly, it is written on the climb - in his usual pencil scrawl.

Second letter from Eric Shipton
19th June .
Camp 4 (22,500 feet). Kamet

Dear Mrs Jackson
A short, grubby note about our progress might interest you. We spent many days trying to find a route up to here from Camp 3, and at last yesterday this camped was established by Smythe and I who spent last night here. Tomorrow he and I intend to push a light bivouac camp from which we hope to have our hit at the summit. We may be joined by Holdsworth who is at the moment at Camp 3 with the others.
We really seem to be on top of the world here. Great Himalayan ranges have sunk beneath us and the eye travels for hundreds of miles amongst the highest mountains of the world. Through a gap there is a wonderful view into the vast plains of Tibet - a stupendous contrast from these ice-bound regions. Kamet towers above us - a wonderful sight amongst its snow devils and ice armour.
Our ice bed gave a series of great cracks during the night, which made us suspect that we had camped on a small hanging glacier. We passed a good night though. Nights are long up here as even when the weather is fine one has to be in one's sleeping bag by 4.30 or 5 unless one is climbing.
I hope you will excuse this letter - altitude has a queer effect on one's mind as well as one one's limbs - for instance Smythe has just put a throat pastille in his mouth a lit a match!
My salaams to you all, yours very sincerely, Eric.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
June 25th - 30th

Home again, and Wynne hears from Eric Shipton, who was on the successful attempt to climb Mount Kamet in the Himalayas.
viewer_8.description:
June 25th, Thursday
Alas our little holiday is over. We struck camp and left at about 12, finding all well at home and everything looking lovely. The big lamps in the drawing room and dining room are up and 2 electric bells so we are now complete!

June 26th
One of the reasons I had to return yesterday was a committee meeting of the Kenya Horticultural Society. The town was full and the air was electric with locusts, all sorts of frantic stories are afloat, an immense swarm from the Suk miles in length apparently descending upon us, no one discusses anything else and one hears of the most amazing things.

June 27th
Not wishing to have any chores tomorrow I had a field day and did all the flowers this morning, 12 vases.

June 28th
Sunday morning, a blessed peaceful time. I've got into the habit of waking about fiveish. I make my tea, it is just what Mother used to do. As each day dawns now one's thought is, will the locusts come today? Yesterday we watched the immense Suk swarm as it processed along the plain and everywhere huge fires mark its passage. I hear there is a large collection under the bluff. One can only wait and hope. These pictures of Kamet are from the Sphere, how strange it is to think of Eric, so short a time ago sitting quietly with us here and now actually on this amazing venture. I have just finished reading Arnold Bennett's last book, "Imperial Palace", a tome of over 600 pages. This sort of effort after having written over 70 books is really an achievement but though well written and clever doesn't appeal to me at all. I am so tired of the present day custom of calling a spade a shovel and all this bald dealing with every intimate detail of life. In the Sphere I find these pictures of the newest thing in hotels, "Dorchester House", and it seems to me it is the Imperial Palace to the life.

June 29th
Locust news as usual, the whole plateau is a screen of smoke.

June 30th
A page of prophecies! Two still to be fulfilled whilst that of Mother Shipton's has all come to pass. All these things would have been unbelievable at the beginning of the 19th century, how much more so in the 16th. Russia is the big problem of today. She and her Five Year Plan. Will the day ever come when she overruns Europe. Stranger things may happen. The other cutting is from the Standard, its fulfilment according to the woman should come along in the immediate future. Truly one hopes she is not mistaken for never was there a time when we so needed a MAN.

The Mother Shipton cutting is below, with Wynne's notes. Sadly she was not aware that this was a fake, published by Charles Hindley in 1862 - it has appeared in various versions with different end dates for the world, but in fact has no connection to the famous lady. The other cutting was on predicting a political dictator for Britain - and Wynne's rather chilling approval makes one realise how fragile democracy can be, especially in times of deep economic distress...

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Every year Wynne used to stick fashion plates into the back of her books - often of clothes she thought ridiculous or frivolous, but sometimes of things she really liked. As her final diary already contained some of these, I have added a few of them here, to two of which she has added comments!

And finally, a cutting about "The Little Coat of the Forties" - " A return to a fashion our grandmothers adored"...

june.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895.

Wynne is 52 this week.

Electric light for the first time...and a safari butterfly collecting in the Kakamega forests.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description:
The Eldoret church that Wynne mentions on March 4th. This was typical of many parishes - small, almost home-made, edifices were put up to accommodate the locals, many of whom were still regular church-goers.

The house she mentions is the small building beyond.

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
March 1st - 8th

An outing to Eldoret to the Agricultural Show. Wynne sends her first ever letter by airmail from Africa. The locust threat intensifies.
viewer_2.description:
March 1st, Sunday
We went to Kirk today. I seldom felt anything like the heat in that arid spot. Quite a lot of people present. On the way home we drove through masses of locusts, clouds of which were flying over Soy way, filling the horizon, most disgusting, but no one seems to fear them as we did 2 years ago. Billy Symes to lunch. He is chungering Frank's farm, and gave us news of that one who had been ill with flu and tonsillitis - far better stay in Kenya! (Chunga in swahili means to care for or look after).

March 2nd.
The Padre wrote some days ago asking us to go into 64 (Eldoret) for the Agricultural Show. I wrote to thank and decline on account of petrol, however he came up today to say if we could meet him in Kitale he would take us out himself. As one looks across the Plains they look today as though they were filled with volumes of yellow smoke - locusts! But this afternoon a sharp storm broke accompanied by a fair amount of hail which I imagine will damp their ardour somewhat.

March 3rd
Into Kitale where the Padre picked us up and after lunch at the Hotel we came out here, a fine road now-a-days, how different from 6 years ago.

March 4th
We got here yesterday about tea time, luckily escaping storms with which the surrounding country was full. The Padre lives in a very decent little house built for him by the Diocese, solid grey stone with tin roof, it is entirely unimaginative but serviceable. Opposite is his toy, a little grey church of concrete blocks, quite frightful but nice inside and furnished with light wood pews and blue altar fittings. The hassocks are covered with swara skin (swara is swahili for antelope), very neat and original. I noticed on the altar of the side chapel two of the brass vases were shell bases! an incongruity that did not seem to strike the Padre! Having arrived at this peaceful harbour, how many lives have they been responsible for I wonder? The house and church are set down in a large plot of ground and I long to get at it and create! At present there is nothing but a few straggling geranium bushes and age-old coreopsis. I've suggested his handing over the care of it to some gardening woman of the Parish.
We went down into the town this morning to shop, a dud place it is, really little better than Kitale. On the way we went into the R.C. church - very well looked after, very clean but with the usual R.C. ornateness of cheap rubbish.

March 5th
On re-reading the concluding remarks of yesterday's entry they strike me as being narrow and intolerant, "one man's meat is another man's poison", no doubt. We are all travelling to Rome and must all choose whatever system seems best to us. The day of the Show proved fine throughout. The new Governor opened it at about 2.30 and Colonel Swinton Hume held forth in a long speech. The exhibits were for the most part excellent and I was particularly struck by a section called Farm Exhibits which was won by J.D.C Harvey of Spring Valley Farm, Moiben. It consisted of every sort and kind of farm produce and was complete down to the most minute details, beautifully arranged and thought out.

March 6th
We left 64 about noon and were lucky enough to get through without rain. Met Nootsie at the Club and came straight home finding all well. Pink busy shelling from morn till eve, getting 600 bags ready for Kirkwood's wagons on Monday. Sent 1st letter by Air Mail, the first to leave this country. 85,000 letters were sent.

March 7th, Saturday
Rain last night and so this morning I planted grass on the two small terraces. The front operations have actually started!

March 8th, Sunday
There came to lunch today two nice creatures, Billy Symes and Guy Nattel. There are very few young men about these days who are not either boring or pogbaggish but these two are neither and I wish we saw more of them. Symes is Shaw's manager and Nattel is looking for land to buy. A lazy day as usual.

(Note: a letter by Air Mail, the first I've seen - see picture)

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description:
The advent of airmail was a huge event - suddenly mail which took weeks could arrive in days - though still you notice, 9 days as opposed to 23. The flying boats made frequent stops, and did not fly at night. If you want to check out the very first air mail ever sent, click here.

Wynne notes on the envelope that she can no longer consider herself in the wilds!

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
March 9th - 17th

With the wet weather coming, gardening is a full-time occupation. She adds a cutting from the paper about an early endoscopy - another marvel of these times.
viewer_4.description:
March 12th, Thursday
A very busy few days. The seed house is nearly finished, the kitchen garden wired and the sweet pea trench dug at last! Locusts have paid us a visit and slept here one night but seem to have done very little damage.

March 13th
If my old Gran were alive today she would be 117! As she died on the 13th Feb 1915 how awfully long ago that seems and what a nightmare of a time it was with H at the Front and I alone to manage everything.
My seed house is finished and it is a joy and will be I hope unless the wind blows it away. I am getting all my boxes ready for sowing and am dreadfully late. We seem to have got rid of our locusts. The labour were all out at an early hour catching millions for food! and beyond smashing up the grevilliea somewhat they don't appear to have done much damage.

March 14th
The mail arrived bringing letters from England, one from Arthur Owen which I enclose. It gives rather a good account of the state of affairs at Home now-a-days. Well may the Club bore reiterate "England's going to the dogs", it has been doing this since time immemorial to wit an ancient book on husbandry I've lately been reading dated 1700 in which the pedantic writer bemoans the then conditions generally. But surely such a state as exists now-a-days cannot have been equalled at any previous date and so far as one can see it is swiftly riding for a fall. Well may the British Israelites sit up on their hind legs and paw the air

March 16th
I played around crystallising figs this morning, with what success is doubtful, then sowed first sweet peas, and as I write a lovely storm of rain is falling, what a joy. From now on the place is full of interest, everything comes to life, the grass is green again, the crinum and haemanthus lilies are in full bloom and Vulgar Hill is a blaze of the latter, really lovely. The digging and trenching of the rose garden has begun and all feels alive again. It is so perfect to feel that the period of desert dryness is over and from now on our flowers will return. My seed house is filling up and the girls have sown a variety of precious herbs therein as they are specialising in that line this year.

March 17th
My man's birthday, bless him. A strenuous day! Off at 9.30 with Mrs Lugard and Dorothy to the Kirks for cooking, where in company we learnt a variety of soups and puddings. We then repaired to the club where we eat our lunch and then in a body all went over to the Church garden to tidy it up and clean it for Easter. It is a pity that there is no one really nearby who can run it properly. Heavy rain fell all round and we had a sticky journey back but with chains managed all right.

March 18th
What I wonder will they invent next. What would our ancestors have said to this, but after all it is no more marvellous than the many other amazing things belonging to this most wonderful age. The mail came in today and in the Times I see to our great sorrow the death of Lady Wilma Lawson. She has had of late years so many dreadful losses beside her own ill health that she could not have been sorry to end it all but what Sir Henry will do I cannot imagine. I shall never forget how entirely charming she was, one of those people with a perfectly natural charm for everyone and they are conspicuous by their rarity. (The Lawsons were old Aldershot friends, Sir Henry being the CO there in 1914).

March 19th, Thursday
This is Mother's birthday, it is many years since we spent it together and how odd it is that Africa should see her here for it. I have planted out the carnation bed and after tea Mother, Pink and I went along the terrace and planted two Cape Chestnut trees, Mother prodding around them with her stick so we say she planted them. I have been sent Frazer's "Golden Bough" from Frank. I long to retire to a desert island in order to read it, a wonderful work the result of many years research and most awfully interesting. He also wrote that finance at Home is said to be chaotic but that there is no outward sign of it whatever, all places of amusement are crammed, champagne flows and no one appears to go short of anything.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description: Nostalgia for home....

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
March 20th - 25th

Eric Shipton, the mountaineer, is staying - and news arrives of Malcolm Campbell's world speed record. Local opinion up in arms about a new "mixed farming" initiative.
viewer_6.description:
March 20th, Friday
Mrs Haly and Eric arrived for the weekend, this will be their last visit as they leave for India in about a week' s time. He is going climbing with the Smythe expedition in the Himalayas. (This is Eric Shipton, a noted mountaineer - this expedition was to climb Kamet, which they succeeded in doing. it was the highest peak climbed at that time).

March 21st.
Today E and Mrs H told us a most macabre story. A certain Mrs Demitrioff next to them died the other day very suddenly of meningitis. A Post Mortem was held and the next day the funeral took place, Eric being one of the pall bearers. That was a Tuesday, and on the Thursday, Dundas, the Dr, rang up a man concerned and urged that Mrs D should be buried! How such a thing could happen one cant imagine but by some weird mischance they buried an empty coffin and she had to be collected at midnight and buried again. Her husband was away. Too horrible.

March 22nd
The rain has gone again and all day long it was brilliant. Mrs H and E left us after tea, they sail for India in a week's time, she to join Margie in Madras and he for his expedition to Mt Kamet. Thank goodness my son is not a mountaineer, but Mrs H is one of those calm people who seem to possess few nerves.

March 23rd
Our garden world is waking up and there is much to do. I'm busy over many things in that line but owing to the rain hanging fire much later in everything that last year. The picture opposite (of an April Elm) gave me such tugs of Home Memory I had to cut it out of Country Life. How vividly it brings before my mind those days of early spring when the pale clear sunlight casts its first real shadows through the trees when first they present that misty beginning of their summer clothes. We have our spring here too but the feeling of it is absent.

March 24th
On Feb 5th Malcolm Campbell broke the World's Speed record on Daytona Beach, Florida, in his "Blue Bird" of British make and this evening on the Wireless he gave an account of it all. It was produced on a flexible record sent out by Air to Galton Fenzi. Truly we live in a remarkable age. It was an amazing record and really gave one the creeps. The man can have no nerves and he cannot be much younger than I am. He is the son of that Campbell who wanted to marry Mary Fairholme, and was a contemporary of Bill Fallowfield. (See the next window. Bill Fallowfield was Wynne's favourite cousin, and was killed in the war. She clearly knew the family from Dorset days).

March 25th, Wednesday.
We had been expecting a big Mail today as owing to its failure to arrive last Sat (the post boy being new forgetting to call for it) we thought two mails will be thrilling, but personally I got nothing at all!
A meeting here this morning of the local Council, somewhat heated as we are now fighting a new bogie of which V.P is the sponsor, "Mixed Farming", the proposal being that the above is more profitable than a one branch line but Govt stipulations are that all farms should dismiss all squatters and fence their farms, the money to be loaned. We are all dead against it, we personally not having sufficient grazing should not take up cattle so we should find ourselves minus squatters which means no manure for coffee and plus a fence and further overdraft. It is a rotten scheme and one trusts will come to nothing.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Campbell's "Bluebird", which reached a speed of 245mph.

Interestingly, Mrs Bruce's achievement does not appear to merit the same coverage! though at least the car's financier gets a look in here...Betty Carstairs.

viewer_8.title: Viewer 8
viewer_8.excerpt:
March 26th - 31st

Depression angst combines with the wonder of modern developments...and the rain fails but the children manage to bring some fish from their expedition upriver.
viewer_8.description:
March 26th, Thursday
The D.Js over here to sundowners and dinner, full of mental stomach ache over the Mixed Farming etc and the subject of cheese paring. I think it did them good to come amongst the crowd! They do hear the wildest stories, viz: the Reynolds now have dismissed all house boys and live on £3 per month, the Andersons on £2. Its impossible, and anyhow, what a life!

March 27th
On March 21st Cambridge again won the boat race and we heard it the same day on the Wireless. I haven't yet got over the wonders of our present time. The other day the King spoke by telephone to his 2 sons in South America and we heard that he had done so by wireless the next day. What would our ancestors have thought of this. Dorothy S left us this morning and goes to Mau Summit, 120 miles. As she departed in her very ramshackle old car I thought, "well, you have nerve!"

March 28th
All the morning I and my totos "cleaned up" the old garden, dug and mowed grass and jembied the road. At tea time Billy Symes brought Shaw here to spend the night. We had a most interesting evening listening to him. He is a great talker but a good one, he talks upon all subjects and it is a relief to get upon some other subject than farm topics and cheese paring. One thing he was discussing was Maeterlinck's book on the White Ant, an amazing work which he is lending us. (But see this link, to Marais, for the real story about this book).

March 29th
Billy Symes came at about 3.30 and after tea they both left us, both so nice. The former is one of those young things who really does get down to it and whose outlook on life is one of determined optimism, a refreshing one these days and seldom met with.

March 30th
Our 3 came home this afternoon and brought with them some lovely fish, the result of their labours, a great treat in this country.

March 31st
I think the rain has gone away again, it is a sad tragedy having planted out masses of gerbera which are now all dying. The terracing of the rose garden slowly proceeds but it all looks quite mad to me, however Pink has it in hand. This has been a bad day - a day for me of fretful porcupining…I had occasion to look up something in a Diary of 1917, bringing to my mind again those momentous times which seem to me now so great and spacious with their happenings of enormous import and I could not but compare the present which much though I love it has a way of thrusting forward all its tiny trivialities and one allows them to assume proportions of ridiculous importance!

viewer_9.title: Viewer 9
viewer_9.description:
Along with pictures of fashion trends, Wynne stuck in these ideas for the new decor.

And below, a room with the caption: "A modernistic cretonne in warm sunny colours with bright accents of red and blue is used for these window curtains, the screening curtains being primrose net. The escaloped pelmet, of plain canvas material, has insertions of cretonne similar to the hangings."

march.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895.

Wynne is living on her farm, Kapretwa, in Kenya.

Local problems compete with news of amazing new developments to occupy her mind.

viewer_1.title: Viewer 1
viewer_1.description: Some interior views of Wynne's house. Fire's were necessary at night, as the altitude made it quite cold. A very different look to the picture of rooms that she had cut out in March!

viewer_2.title: Viewer 2
viewer_2.excerpt:
May 1st - 13th

Budgets, leopard skins and garden work. The Bank Manager comes to stay...and Wynne's Mother offers to pay for the installation of an electric light generator.
viewer_2.description:
May 1st, Friday
How exquisite are the early mornings now. When I step forth forth, the grass is silver with dew and everything glistens in the fresh sunlight. It smells so good too and I love the complete absence of even the slightest breeze. We had a full day today, at work from 7.30 to sundown planting out delphiniums, acquilegia, wall flowers, nemesia, cynoglossom and dahlias but alas no rain so they all had to be watered, an arduous labour. Mother came out both morning and evening with me and sat in her chair knitting and reading and basking in the sun.

May 2nd
We are alone tonight the 3 having gone off to Hunts for the weekend. It seems quiet in this peaceful room, the only sound being the "cricket on the hearth". For 3 days now no rain has fallen so each evening I have to water, and its an awful game really, especially when one has only bath water.

May 3rd
I had intended having a good morning's letter writing but to "elevenses" came the V-Ps who stayed till lunch. It was sometime since we had met so there was much local gossip to be got through. After lunch being sure more or less of peace I deliberately lay down on the sofa with a book and slept solid till tea.

May 4th
Our 3 returned for lunch and brought with them 5 fish! Also there came Capt House and his lorry bringing all the stuff for the electric lighting. Have I even mentioned this most marvellous happening, that Mother is presenting us with it is so very wonderful that I really cant grasp it. He returns next Monday to begin operations and meanwhile we are putting up the engine house. This morning three magnificent leopard skins were brought in and we bought them for 18/- each.

May 5th
Good rain! Today's paper contained the budget, this most anxiously awaited trial! An extra 2d on petrol, and certain other items which my brain cannot grasp. Snowden seems satisfied with the general state of affairs which is more than the general Press appears to be, but what budget ever pleased everyone. I see the King of Spain is at Windsor. I wonder where he will ultimately live.

May 6th, Wednesday
I've been planting out the girls' border today and because the buck ate everything in it last year I've filled it mostly with snapdragons and larkspurs, neither of which they care for.

May 8th, Friday
There came today Charles de la Harpe to lunch. He is a character and no mistake, his never ceasing flow of conversation and his funny old sentiments. He took one of the leopard skins away with him to cure for Mother who is going to send it Home to the Duke of Bedford. Then to sundowners (which they don't drink) came the Js and just before dinner Hunt rolled up invited by the 3 and by whom he was entirely forgotten!

May 9th, Saturday
Hunt left before breakfast and Pink went off at lunch to join him at Elgon Club.

May 10th
No peace for the wicked. At 12.30 the Fermins (our new Bank Manager) arrived. He has the reputation of being "difficult" about overdrafts and is therefore called "Vermin" but they seemed pleasant amiable people and I hope went away feeling that we were safe to lend money to! The child kept me in fits, a typically colonial little bratling, utterly uncontrolled and entirely disobedient. They came in a brand new car looking more smart than anything I've ever seen and I'm sorry they did not see the Dodge as they would have realised then that we need an increase on our overdraft! Good rain fell this evening.

May 11th, Monday
Today Capt House arrived to see to the electric light. Day of days! I really cant realise the amazement of this wonderful thing.

May 12th
Today the little engine is installed! in its house in the kitchen yard!! More and more planting out and a good rain, all most satisfactory.

May 13th, Wednesday
A little more than a year ago I tentatively enquired of Pink when he thought we should be able to put the gangs on to the front garden and he replied "Oh not till about June I fear". Well the top rose garden being now finished we started in on the main front yesterday and today I signed on four more totos and he put on two of his boys so I really feel as though we were getting a move on at last.

viewer_3.title: Viewer 3
viewer_3.description: "A sweet Advt.", writes Wynne at the top of this - "soon we shall no longer have to think at all".

viewer_4.title: Viewer 4
viewer_4.excerpt:
May 14th - 22nd

Work on the lighting system continues...and the post boy is arrested, so no mail arrives.
viewer_4.description:
May 14th
We finished setting up the batteries this morning so thats that. I hope we've made no hideous errors. Work progresses slow and sure and it is to be hoped that the Waterloo of lamps is in sight.

May 15th
We are reduced in number this evening. Capt House has returned to Kitale for the weekend and Pink has gone to spend the same with the Morgans who are having a large "do". All the morning we worked in and around the shrubbery, after lunch darned stockings by the millions and attacked the long border after tea.

May 16th
Dear Peter Shaw is with us today, a man of many parts, and I'd rather be his friend than his enemy. A day of Saturday chores and mail day, my letters were from CMJ and Sir Henry Lawson, the latter in reply to mine about Lady Wilma who died this Spring. Dear gracious lady, an outstanding personality and a real personification of the meaning of "lady". How desperately "left" he must be.

May 17th
A day of leisure and the solving or rather attempt thereat of crossword puzzles. Peter S is good at these. We are much amused at his often outspoken acidity, his caustic remarks and pessimism. I cannot think that he and Upton can be a comfortable pair and yet they have stuck it since 1924, longer than most such arrangements.

May 18th, Monday
At 7 this evening we saw car lights coming up the shamba and thought it was Pink but to our amazement who should arrive but Charles de la Harpe and Swan his pupil! The females looked at one another and said: food? and the girls rushed out and divided the puddings which was fruit in glasses. Meat being patties sufficed. Well they played Bridge and then after dinner more Bridge and eventually at 11.30 they went, Pink returning in the small hours was not seen this night.

May 19th
Capt House works on like an industrious ant all day and the electric light gradually gets nearer and nearer. I simply cant realise it and I am busy making shades. The front garden also progresses.

May 20th
What has happened to the Mail? The post boy never returned today. What has become of him I wonder, he who is always early and comes singing up the road. Electric wiring creeping from room to room.

May 21st
Apparently the Police detained the post boy not on account of misdemeanours but a dilapidated kipande. This day began and ended with the most wonderful sky effects I've ever seen. The compete double rainbow and the amazing colouring in the clouds tonight really got me by the throat.

May 22nd
I went this morning up to Frank's place with Pink, he with a bag of shillings to pay the boys. Armed with my work I sat under the trees and drank tea which a minute toto prepared and brought me whilst Pink went round the farm and afterwards did tickets.

viewer_5.title: Viewer 5
viewer_5.description:
Wynne was fascinated by all the new developments taking place. This page, and the final viewer window, contain clips from a large sheet she stuck in about medical innovations.

Here, on the left, is the mobile dental clinic. It contained everything down to the drill and covered 6000 patients. Next to it is an innovation at the London Middlesex, where babies are being treated with ultra violet - presumably to combat rickets.

And below is the Water Panacea, a treatment developed at Berlin University Institute. All diseases not involving an operation are attacked by water, and not by allopathic or homeopathic remedies. The picture shows a heated spiral for stomach ailments.

viewer_6.title: Viewer 6
viewer_6.excerpt:
May 23rd - 31st

Rain comes in torrents. The electric engine is started to run it in, and a favourite cat is killed.
viewer_6.description:
May 24th, Sunday
I am having a day in bed! A rare occurrence but the fierce order of a fierce Mama keeps me meekly enchained. I must say if one has to do this mine is a most pleasant room in which to do it. The sun streams through the open windows and one might almost be lying in the garden. I read in "The Golden Bough", that tremendous tome, and once again am impressed that there is nothing new under the sun. I have just finished also Maeterlink's book on the White Ant, most bogeyish but I refuse to bogeyed.

May 25th
I have to recount a horrid tragedy. Our dear little cat was killed last night by apparently a Cerval Cat. This beast two nights ago took a turkey mother and 10 of her brood, such a loss. Tonight we are putting a poison bait down for him and shutting up the other two cats.

May 26th
A most terrific storm. Capt House returned from Kitale. We had hoped he was bringing lamps and shade frames but those fools in Nairobi had sent all he wrong thing and so a further delay must be endured, but he did bring the stores out and with much excitement and thrill we unpacked this now yearly joy. It is a joy to a housekeeper's heart and my cupboard is now well stocked for another year.

May 28th, Thursday
Such rain and how we welcome it, we've had over 5 inches in 6 days! and the whole place looks lovely.

May 29th
Oak Apple Day! We have had a day without rain and I was glad for the girls had to go to Kitale and started off before breakfast. They returned to lunch having had rather a sticky journey but no delay.

May 30th
There came to our house this morning that rare visitor Commander Kerr, and as I told him, duty alone brought the wretch! The reason for his visit viz, the refusal of the engine to start, was found to be that the turning handle had been put in the wrong way round! So all day long we have listened to the sound of its music and will have to do so until Thursday by which time it will have "run in". The men all left soon after lunch and so we had a quiet ending.

May 31st
The last day of May. June the month of Roses is once more upon us, for it is rose month out here as well as at Home. A cloudless day and no rain again. I do not wish to cavil but we are in the midst of planting coffee and this sudden cessation is a bit trying. All day long our engine has been thrumming. I shall be glad when this part is through with as its rather distracting, especially in the evening.

viewer_7.title: Viewer 7
viewer_7.description:
Another look at the medical innovations - Marking babies for indentification using an ultra violet ray pencil at the Beth Israel Hospital, Neward, New Jersey; and an Austrian invention, the use of electric sparks instead of steel for the cutting required in an operation. It was claimed this method was germ free.

And finally...everyone's dream - a room of your own. This is in the West London Hospital where 100 rooms like this were proposed, and where a flat rate charge to cover nursing, treatment and surgeon's fees was going to be introduced, regardless of the complexity of the case.

may.description:
The final diary, one of 30 written since 1895.

Life on a Kenyan farm.

Budgets, Bank Managers, and the installation of an electric light engine produce different reactions.
